But the inclusion of both those Italians is quite warranted by the background role they played in the art theory discussions of the time.  Hals's teacher, Karel van Mander, had traveled extensively in Italy before settling in Haarlem, personally knew almost all the most important artists and theoreticians, including Vasari, and was thoroughly acquainted with the Venetians' style. Van Mander had been apprenticed to the Flemish painter Pieter Vlerick, who had worked for Tintoretto, who in turn had briefly been a pupil of Titian's.  As a theoretician, Van Mander was the first to formulate the distinction between the "neat" and "rough" styles of painting, using Titian's late work as his primary example of the latter (and taking his cue from Vasari).  As a teacher he encouraged his students to begin with the "neat" manner as the easier of the two to master, but quite clearly ceded pride of place to the "rough" style that became the hallmark of his most famous pupil.  So it is indeed good to keep Titian's "grandfatherly" relationship to Hals in sight when looking at Hals's paintings, as well as those of Rembrandt, Rubens, van Dyck,  Jordaens and others who sometimes strove for a "rough" effect in their finished paintings.  With these contemporary painters, Hals's juxtaposition "eye to eye" is not at all an exaggeration, for the book does an excellent job of relating their works to one another.The four meticulously annotated scholarly essays that precede the catalogue underline the fact that the painters were well aware of what their colleagues were doing and were always looking over each other's shoulders, so to speak.  As an example: it turns out that Rembrandt's celebrated device to enliven the action in his "Syndics of the Cloth Makers' Guild" (1661), viz., having one of the men apparently caught in the act of rising from the table, is taken from Hals's "Regents of the St. Elizabeth's Hospital" of twenty years before.  And Rembrandt was not even the first to crib the gesture from Hals; Johannes Verspronck had already adopted it in his parallel painting from the same year as Hals's, "The Regentesses of the St. Elizabeth's Hospital in Haarlem" (1641).  And Hals himself had modeled the two figures at the extreme right of his table on those in Thomas de Keyser's  "Four Burgomasters of Amsterdam Awaiting Marie de Medici" from 1638. This is just one of the very many instances of direct influence and straightforward quotation that the writers discuss; they are not limited only to matters of technique, either--we find the same interaction also in themes (the sole musician in the manner of Caravaggio, the "Pekelharing" or tipsy entertainer, the great banquets of the militia companies, etc.), in composition, in coloration, and in virtually every aspect that they have in common.  Understanding the closeness of all this interchange is greatly facilitated by the excellent selection of paintings exhibited (lent by over twenty-five institutions and private collectors) and by the many judiciously chosen companion illustrations. Obviously, such mutual reverberations did not go unnoticed at the time, and there is frequent reference to the judgments and comparisons of the painters' contemporaries, be they painters themselves, collectors and potential buyers, or simply casual observers.In the catalogue section, all forty-seven exhibited paintings (reproduced in very good color and mostly full-page or half-page, including some blown-up details) are accompanied by a signed commentary by one of the essay writers or another contributor.  These are obviously at the forefront of Frans Hals scholarship, and I found them very informative on all manner of things touching the works, from the relationship of genre painting and portraiture to the ranks of the militia officers and the customs of the companies.  The volume concludes with a useful selected bibliography and a checklist of the exhibited works with pertinent curatorial data, but it unfortunately has no index.  If I could, I would dock it half a star for the lack of an index and especially for the chaotic arrangement of the plates, which are scattered throughout the essay section in a way that makes it very annoying and frustrating for the reader to locate any particular one.  Apart from that, however, this is a very interesting and useful examination of the mutual influences among these artists, an excellently produced catalogue that I recommend very highly.

This is the volume published to accompany the exhibition of the same name at the Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam from May 2013 until January 2014. It is edited and largely written by Marije Vellekoop, who is Head of Collection, Research and Exhibitions at the Museum and since 2008 the leader of an extensive multidisciplinary research project on Van Gogh's studio practice. It has contributions by several other curators and conservators, and  it is a superb book.  Over the course of many years' appreciation of his art I have accumulated some fifty or sixty books about him, ranging from small monographs on particular works to some blockbuster coffee-table editions and retrospectives and exhibition catalogues large and small in between, and this is one of the very best of them.  (That number does not yet include the major result of Dr. Vellekoop's project, the simultaneously published volume "Van Gogh's Studio Practice," which is a larger, more comprehensive and apparently much more scientifically detailed account, to which this "At Work" volume is a more approachable companion.)Van Gogh came late to painting (already twenty-seven), and he knew he had to make up for lost time.  That probably explains the monomaniacal intensity with which he threw himself into acquiring the roots and fundamentals of his new study and which struck some people as fanatic, abrasive and irritating.  It is the great merit of this book to concentrate on demonstrating how Vincent went about learning what it was he needed to know and to avoid the kind of biographical attention that his singular personality tends to invite.  Thus the whole Christmas Eve blow-up with Gauguin, frequently so luridly described, is here soberly dismissed as a "row" that "threw [him] into a mental crisis and he wounded himself in the ear" (191).  Instead, the emphasis is on how eager Van Gogh was to learn from the more experienced artist and how he studied the double portraits that Gauguin and Emile Bernard had sent to him for clues about the new painting.  That is the focus throughout: interactions with other people are recorded only in so far as they affected his work, i.e., the artists with whom he painted and whose studios he visited, etc.; the only woman mentioned is Sien Hoornick, who appears only in her function as an unpaid model for him, and a nude one at that.The book is divided into two parts.  The first, a bit more than two-thirds of the whole, follows Vincent chronologically and geographically in fairly short segments that enable us to easily trace his path and his development.  The first section, "Cuesmes, mid-August to mid-October 1880," records his decision to become an artist and his first steps in sketches, copies of prints and photographs, and his following the course of study in drawing manuals.  The second, "Brussels, mid-October 1880," discusses his first studio course and experience of life drawing and his initial interaction with other art students.  Then come "Etten, late April to late December 1881," with its charcoal drawings of the "Brabant types" and a brief excursion to The Hague, "The Hague, late December 1881 to mid-September 1883," with his study of watercolor with Anton Mauve, the nude drawing with Sien, his exploration of the perspective frame, etc., and so on until the end.  All of these sections are extremely well illustrated with reproductions of Van Gogh's own work and that of other artists with whom he was working and studying, like Mauve himself and his fellow student Anton Van Rappard.  There are descriptions and illustrations of aids like the perspective frame and the wooden drawing frame, of tools like pens and brushes, materials like paper and canvas, and of  drawing materials in black and white and watercolors.  There are discussions of color theory and  his study of color charts, his fascination with Delacroix and experiments with color combinations, of oils and pigments and where he bought them, of kinds of supports and how he learned to treat them, etc., etc., just about every aspect of what he had to learn and do to make a painting. Much of the documentation is from his letters to Theo, and many of the letter sketches are also reproduced, especially when Vincent is describing a new technique or implement.The second part of the book, about the last seventy-five pages, is topical, rather than chronological or geographical, and consists of short essays on specific subjects by contributing curators and conservators.  These are very focussed pieces, also extensively illustrated, on matters such as "Painting thickly and thinly" (his experimentation in the summer of 1886 with pronounced brushwork, complementary colors, and thick impasto in the dozens of flower still lifes he painted in the style of Adolphe Monticelli; followed a few months later by experiments in painting thinly, almost as if drawing, in the manner adopted by his friend Toulouse-Lautrec).  Other topics are the painterly relations of "Van Gogh, Bernard and Gauguin," "Reused canvases," "Van Gogh's new colors," "Van Gogh's cobalt blue analysed," etc.  Indeed, color is one of the major priorities throughout this study, and much attention is paid to the artist's preoccupation with it.  One particularly engaging strategy is the analysis of Van Gogh's self-portraits in the act of painting, where the author focusses on and discusses the paints on the painted palette, which by necessity are the same paints as were on the palette of the painter painting the portrait. By numbering the paints on the palette and treating them in turn, one can achieve a very coherent discussion of the paints in the portrait. The last section in the book is "Looking through the researchers' eyes," a brief discussion and explanation of the  analytical tools available to the conservator and which were used in the evaluation of the paintings in the exhibition, things like X-ray fluorescence spectrometry, high-performance liquid chromatography, and other advanced technologies.  The volume concludes with some brief bibliographical references, an index of names and works, and a separate index of Van Gogh's works. This is a very serious treatment of those works as work, the hard work he had to do to get where he wanted to go.  As I am not an artist, I can not judge the usefulness of the study to a working painter, although I can imagine that at the very least the many pages of blown-up pictures of the tubes and brushes and palettes and pencils that he used would be of interest to one.  In any case, despite the variety and the excellence of the reproductions, this is not a book for someone who simply wants a nice representative selection of Van Gogh's oeuvre with some curatorial commentary.  I myself found it greatly informative, as well as beautifully produced in all respects and, as I wrote, one of the very best of the huge Van Gogh literature.

This volume is published in conjunction with the exhibition of the same name at The Jewish Museum in New York from September 2013 to February 2014.  It is not an exhibition catalogue in the usual sense of a numbered series of reproductions of the exhibited items; it consists, rather, of two essays centered around and commenting on the fifty-odd paintings and drawings in the show and a small  selection of Chagall's poems in English translation. (In fact, the only serious argument I have with this book is that the originals of the poems--in Russian, Yiddish, and French--are not also given.  Poetry is, as is well known, the first thing to be lost in translation, and surely a great number of the people who would want to see this exhibition and have the publication would be able to read the originals.) The focus is on the years between 1930 and 1948--although these are bracketed by the inclusion of both earlier and later works of a similar kind--and it should put to rest the notion that only the early Chagall is worthy of serious attention. For these are serious works indeed, and in fact rather shocking in their insistence on the figure of Christ as their central image.  Who would have thought that the godfather of fiddler-on-the-roof imagery, for which this transplanted Russian Jew became most widely known, would have created during these years at least twenty-five images of the Crucifixion?  How this came about, why Chagall went in that direction and what the figure of the crucified Christ ultimately meant to the artist is the subject of the fascinating seventy-page essay by Susan Tumarkin Goodman, the Senior Curator at The Jewish Museum, an established Chagall scholar whose many publications on the artist include the excellent "Chagall and the Artists of the Russian Jewish Theater," the catalogue of an exhibition she curated at the museum in 2008 (see the reviews on this website).  Dr. Goodman calls her essay about Chagall in the '30's and '40's "The Fractured Years," a title concisely evocative of the "Love, War, and Exile" theme of the exhibition: years in which Chagall was forced to flee the  Paris he had come to love, first to temporary refuge in the south of France, and then to the United States, where the increasingly credibly documented reports of the Holocaust caused him excruciating existential anxiety in his exile, and where at the same time he had to suffer the death of his beloved soul-mate, Bella, his muse and wife of over thirty years.The second essay in the book is by the noted art historian Kenneth E. Silver, who has written extensively on French art in the early twentieth century and on French-Russian Jewish artists such as Chaim Soutine.  His essay is titled "Fluid Chaos Felt by the Soul," a formulation used by the French Catholic philosopher Jacques Maritain, a friend of Chagall's, to describe the artist's work.  Prof. Silver notes that the artistic theme of the "Jewish Jesus" had been evolving since at least the late eighteenth century, and he situates Chagall's Christ iconography well within this tradition: the connection between the Christian savior and Jewish martyrdom is at the bottom of the "flood of turbulent imagery [that] was the aesthetic rule of Chagall's oeuvre" (114).There are about fifty full-page reproductions of the works, as well as numerous companion illustrations and photographs.  The color of the reproductions is excellent, which is crucial with Chagall: as Picasso said, "when Matisse dies, Chagall will be the only person left who understands what color really is."  Everyone who has seen a general survey of Chagall's works is familiar with one or two of his Christ paintings. But it is quite a different thing to see so many of them gathered from over thirty-five institutional and private lenders world-wide and to realize how important the image of the crucified Christ was to him in the insane years of  World War II and the Holocaust.  Having seen these paintings and read these essays, it is not likely one will ever think of Chagall in the same way again.

This is the catalogue of the exhibition organized by The Museum of Modern Art in New York and mounted there from September 2013 to January 2014.  It will subsequently travel to Houston's Menil Collection (February to June 2014) and The Art Institute of Chicago (June to October 2014), both of which institutions collaborated with the MoMA in producing the exhibition and catalogue.  All those museums have extensive holdings of Magritte's works (the Menil alone is surpassed only by the collection in the Royal Museums of Fine Arts in Brussels, which includes the Magritte Museum itself), and their contributions make up the majority of the works exhibited, augmented by significant loans from Brussels and from some fifty further collections and private lenders worldwide.  Many of the expected and iconic paintings are here, alongside many far less well known images, collages, objects, commercial catalogue and periodical pages, and photographs of and by the artist and his circle of "accomplices," as they called themselves.  This is, in other words, a major and comprehensive exhibition; it is likely to remain the definitive show of Magritte's Surrealism for some time to come.The catalogue, edited by Anne Umland, MoMA's senior curator of painting and sculpture, does full justice to the exhibition.  There are 132 plates of exhibited works, mostly printed full-page or, in the case of photographs and periodical illustrations, two to a page, and there are several two-page detail enlargements of the paintings.  The essays are also accompanied by numerous companion illustrations. Four scholarly essays follow on a general introduction by the show's curators; these trace Magritte's path during this period of his life, from his initial involvement with Surrealism in Brussels (1926-27), his decision to live in Paris in order to be closer to the center of the movement and the failure to become satisfactorily established there (1927-30), his return to Brussels (1930-36), and his brief work in London, creating panels for the decoration of Edward James's town house (1936).  This is a concentrated period of time; it takes Magritte from his twenty-eighth year to his fortieth, the years most fruitful for the development of his Surrealist style and which set the foundation for the remaining thirty years of his life.  Throughout, the writers are keen to relate their discussions to Magritte's project of illuminating the "mystery of the ordinary" through his various "alienating" or "defamiliarizing" devices like the "misnamed" objects in the early word paintings, the morphing of figures into one another, the effects of optical illusion and trompe l'oeil, etc. The essays and their notes have frequent quotations from the artist's writings to elucidate the semiological motivations behind the paintings, the quest to reinvest meaning into things that have lost their meaning through everyday familiarity and routine inattention.  Magritte's interaction with his friends and fellow artists (most of them writers) is also highlighted enough to give the sense of Surrealism being a cooperative and collaborative effort, a real group movement.  I found these essays to be very informative and helpful, even though they average only about fifteen pages each--which of course means that the majority of the volume is given over to reproducing the art.  There is also a detailed and annotated chronology of  Magritte's life during these years, which provides information and material beyond that given in the essays.  The volume concludes with a checklist of the exhibition giving full curatorial information including the Sylvester/Whitfield catalogue raisonne numbers, a selected bibliography and an index of photographs and figures.  This is about as comprehensive and informative a book on the artist's founding Surrealist years as we are likely to see for some time, very solid and professionally produced and highly recommended.

This is the catalogue accompanying the exhibition of the same name at the McMullen Museum of Art at Boston College from September to December 2013.  Exhibition and catalogue are both joint ventures of the McMullen and the Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium in Brussels.  Writing in "The Boston Globe" ("Catching up with Courbet," September 22, 2013), Sebastian Smee rightly called attention to the Museum's admirable ambition in putting together such a show, which mounts no fewer than seventeen Courbets (and one from his "workshop") and almost twice as many works by artists on whom he had a palpable influence.  The show divides, somewhat unevenly, into two parts.  The first, which we can call "Courbet and the Belgians," consists largely of about twenty paintings loaned from Brussels; these are both original Courbets and works by several painters whom he encountered on his trips to Belgium and who were clearly affected by his painting, including Alfred Stevens and Louis Dubois, the latter represented by six canvases.  The second and larger part, "Courbet and the Americans," brings together about thirty pictures from private collections and American museums (mostly in New England) and documents how Courbet's presence projected itself across the Atlantic, carried back to this country by artists who had come under his sway while studying in Paris (mostly with Thomas Couture).  Here figures such as John LaFarge and William Morris Hunt are prominent and are exhibited along with Theodore Robinson and Winslow Homer.  It must be said that the net was cast fairly wide in making these selections; it is not always apparent how some of the paintings betray much influence of Courbet, beyond their basic realist techniques.  In this respect, it is unfortunate that the plates are not given any specific commentary. Many of them are referenced by the scholarly essays preceding the catalogue, but, for the most part, readers are left to make their own connections in the absence of curatorial guidance.  The paintings are all reproduced full-page; the colors, although adequate, are somewhat muted and a bit somber-looking.Six scholarly essays precede the plates; all are meticulously annotated and accompanied by copious black-and-white illustrations.  Jeffery Howe, Professor of Fine Arts at Boston College and the volume's editor, provides both an introductory "map" of Courbet's influence in Belgium and the U.S. and an essay on the painter's landscapes, which increasingly occupied his artistic attention and in the end made up two-thirds of his oeuvre.  Dominique Marechal, curator of nineteenth-century paintings at the Royal Museums in Brussels, writes on Courbet's travels in Belgium and the Netherlands and his reception of the art of those countries, including the masters of the Golden Age and, more surprisingly, some contemporary figures like Alfred Stevens and his brothers.  The longest essay is that of Claude Cernuschi, also an art historian at Boston College, who discusses Courbet's many self-portraits from the point of view of social psychology: since Courbet insisted that he was a Realist and prided himself on being one, how is it that his self-portraits are so consistently unrealistic?  Dr. Cernuschi  uses the concepts of image-management and self-symbolization to explicate the artist's notoriously difficult personality.  This is a very well informed analysis and the most perceptive discussion of Courbet's psychological make-up--as well as the most persuasive explication of "The Quarry" (1856-57)--that I have come across.  Obviously, there is no dearth of books on Courbet or Realism; as recently as 2008 there was the double-whammy of the Metropolitan Museum's huge Courbet exhibition and its catalogue along with Segolene Le Men's immense and comprehensive monograph (see my reviews on this website), but Courbet is a fertile and endlessly fascinating figure, and this "map" of his realist reverberations in the two countries considered is just one of the many aspects from which his work can be profitably considered.  A nicely done volume and, despite the rather disappointing reproductions, a welcome addition to the literature and a "must" for Courbet enthusiasts.

This is the catalogue that accompanies the exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum from April to July 2013, the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston from October 2013 to January 2014, and the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston from March to May 2014.  Both exhibition and catalogue are collaborative efforts of the Boston and Brooklyn museums and are curated and edited by Erica Hirschler and Teresa Carbone, their most senior curators of American art.  Perhaps the most surprising thing about this exhibition is that it took so long to get it together, because it's an obvious idea: the museums have owned the two most significant collections of Sargent's watercolors for over a hundred years.  The artist was notoriously reluctant to sell his watercolor paintings, not because he did not think them worthy or because he considered them only as products of his leisure, "unofficial" painting time--indeed, after the turn of the century they came increasingly to occupy the major part of his artistic attention--but because he thought of them as groups of serially related works. "United they stand, and divided they fall," he wrote to a friend (40); the only thing that would tempt him to sell would be if "a Museum should offer to buy the whole lot [. . .] for they only amount to anything when they are a lot together" (39). That is precisely what happened: Sargent was persuaded to send his watercolors to only two major exhibitions in the United States, both times at the M. Knoedler gallery in New York: in 1909 the Brooklyn Museum bought eighty-three of the eighty-six pieces exhibited--just a day or two ahead of Boston--and in 1912 Boston, once burned, secured the basis of their collection by buying up the whole lot of forty-five watercolors before the show even opened.  Finally, a hundred years later, the two collections are exhibited together for the first time: 102 paintings from the museums, the majority of them from Boston (the MFA since expanded its collection to include over 500 works by Sargent, whereas shortly after the artist's death the Brooklyn Museum deaccessioned  forty-one pieces of its original purchase), augmented by a few loans from private collections.  They are all beautifully reproduced full-page (or over two pages in the case of the larger horizontal formats) and are accompanied by numerous photographs, companion illustrations, and over thirty detail studies; the jacket text says there are 175 color illustrations in all.  The reproductions are in sharp focus, and the colors seem natural and authentic, but as I have not yet seen the exhibition, I can not comment on the quality or accuracy of the colors.The paintings have been organized thematically, rather than chronologically or geographically, although there is naturally some overlap: the paintings in "The Quarry" section, for instance, were all done in the marble works of Carrara in the fall of 1911; they constitute the most coherent group of watercolors in his oeuvre.  But most of the other dozen or so sections have only a given subject as their unifying principle:  "In Villa Gardens" features paintings made from about 1903 until 1910, and in locales from Aranjuez to Florence and Lucca; "Sunlight on Stone" has work from 1906 to 1911 and takes us from Florence to Corfu and then to Venice, etc.  The paintings are not individually commented, but each of the sections is prefaced by a few pages of well annotated and very informative discussion by one of the contributing curators, and a couple of major introductory essays deal with the role of the watercolors in Sargent's development and the circumstances of the museums' acquisition of them.  There is also an excellent section by the museums' conservators on the artist's techniques and materials, which should be of particular interest to practicing artists.  The volume concludes with a select chronology from 1900 to 1917, a select bibliography, an exhibition checklist with curatorial data, and a comprehensive index.  There is no lack of books on Sargent, but this one provides insight into an area of his art that has not been extensively treated. It is a very welcome addition to the literature and also a beautifully produced volume.

When exactly Cennino Cennini put together his famous handbook is not clear.  It must have been quite early in the fifteenth century, for although his stated intention is to provide advice "for the use and good and profit of anyone who wants to enter this profession" (1), he has only very little to say about oil painting and seems unaware of the latest developments of that exciting new medium in the early decades of the century. (It was enough, though, to disprove the contention of Giorgio Vasari and others that oil painting had been invented by Jan van Eyck.)  In any case, it is absolutely a book intended for the professional, for the active practitioner, the working artist, and one can note that most of the reviewers on this site have praised it for the practical advice it provides.  It has also been reported that it was an important source-book and wellspring of useful technical information for Eric Hebborn, the notorious English art forger and author of his own handbook ("The Art Forger's Handbook," 1997), who is reputed to have employed Cennini's technique of using egg-white to simulate the appearance of aged varnish.I am not an artist and have never painted anything but some old furniture, a couple of book-cases and a dog house--and I must confess to never even having forged a Renaissance masterpiece--so to me this book is of no practical use, but it is greatly entertaining as well as historically informative.  Just to realize the huge amount of preparatory labor a fourteenth- or fifteenth-century artist had to accomplish in order to get ready to work adds a humbling perspective to the art we so easily admire on the walls of our museums.  And there are some wonderful insights into the times, too, such as the use of chicken bones: the older the better, "just as you find them under the dining-table" (5) and, while giving "the exact proportions of a man," dispensing with those of a woman, "for she does not have any set proportion" (48).  There is practical advice here for almost anything a contemporary artist might have been called upon to do, from drawing for embroiderers to waterproofing a wall with boiled oil, but behind it all is Cennino's sense of his profession as having the dignity of a calling and requiring a measured life-style, "just as if you were studying theology, or philosophy," and he admonishes the fledgling artist to eat and drink moderately and, in order to ensure an unwavering and unfluttering hand, to avoid "indulging too much in the company of woman" (16).  Obviously, times have changed, and that makes up a great deal of the charm of this book for one like myself, who is not about to enter the profession but who nevertheless also found in it much "use and good and profit."

This is the catalogue for the exhibition of the same name at the Palazzo Strozzi in Florence from March to May 2013 and at the Louvre in Paris from September 2013 to January 2014.  It is an enormous tome of around 550 large pages, beautifully produced and lavishly and excellently illustrated, and as far as I can see, it is the most comprehensive and up-to-date book on its subject currently available.  The legacy of Italian painting roughly from Duccio to Barocci is so huge, so ubiquitous and so overwhelming in its beauty and brilliance, that we can easily forget that the artists who began what we now call the Renaissance were not painters at all, but generally sculptors and, before that, goldsmiths.  The exhibition thus rightly places the plastic arts at the center of the "springtime" of the new sensibility, but also rightly indicates its relationship to the entire sphere of artistic activity, and in the first of the book's scholarly essays, "On Primacy," the editors write of the developments in sculpture that "imparted a new language and spirit to the other arts" (25).  With one or two exceptions, the remaining essays all deal with aspects of Quattrocentro statuary in its manifold varieties, from "Pisa and Antiquity" to Brunelleschi's dome, from the great equestrian statues of Donatello and Andrea del Verocchio to Luca della Robbia's glazed terracotta, etc.  Some of the essays address specific works of art, while others discuss more general themes like the role of antiquarians and relevant theological debates.  Most of them are quite short (6-8 pp.) and are well illustrated and meticulously annotated, so there is even less than six or eight pages of text, and they all make frequent references to the reproductions in the catalogue section. There are twenty-eight of these essays, and they have the usual advantages and disadvantages of anthologies: a great diversity of topic and perspective, but also some repetition and uneven quality in the writing. The majority of the contributions are by Italian scholars; the translations are at times odd to an English ear and occasionally even inaccurate, but I did not find any instances where the intended meaning was obscured.  They are all informative, authoritative, and obviously at the cutting edge of Renaissance scholarship.  Unfortunately, there is no list identifying who the contributors are; some are well known, but others not, and it would have been useful to know what academic or curatorial positions they occupy.The second half of the book is the catalogue itself. It is divided into ten themes, which follow the roughly chronological arrangement of the exhibition itinerary, starting from "The Legacy of the Fathers" and including such topics as "Christian and Civic 'Romanitas,'" "'Spiritelli' Sacred and Profane," "The Revival of 'Condottiere,'" and "'Sculptured Painting.'" Each thematic section is preceded by a short introduction and an indication of which of the scholarly essays are pertinent to it, so that if readers wish to start with the essays, they know which catalog sections are referenced; and if they wish to start with the works, they know which of the essays are relevant. There are about 150 reproductions here (by my rough count), most of them full-page and in full color, and a number of companion smaller illustrations, with the sculptures in the round photographed from more than one angle when appropriate. The reproductions are excellent in clarity and color; some of the colors, especially those of the painted terracottas of Donatello, Nanni de Bartolo and Luca della Robbia, are striking.  It is an extensive collection, including many of the "usual suspects" and some much less commonly encountered pieces (the exhibition drew on some seventy-five sources worldwide), all of which are illuminated by commentary from the editors and contributors and provided with specialized bibligraphies. The last two reproductions are, appropriately, Desiderio da Settignano's marble bust of Marietta Strozzi (c. 1464) and Giuliano da Sangallo's wood carved model  of the Palazzo Strozzi (1489).  The volume concludes with an extensive general bibliography, but,  unfortunately, no index, which severely limits the book's usefulness as a reference.  Nevertheless, this is a major contribution to the study of early Renaissance sculpture, especially in its larger cultural context and its relation to other arts, and it is highly recommended.

This is a small booklet of about sixty pages (but handsomely and well produced, with sewn binding) that was issued to accompany an exhibition at the Coe Kerr Gallery in New York in November and December 1987.  It had been known for some time that Prendergast worked in pastel; he had exhibited four in Philadelphia in 1918, and there were a few scattered about in various museums and private collections.  The assumption was that these were merely random and occasional pieces, the products of a desultory occupation in the studio of an artist known for his experimentation.  What was unknown--and this is the fact that justifies the somewhat exaggerated title--is that the artist actually produced a distinct body of work in this medium during the decade surrounding World War I, and that some of the later pastels are the least realistic, most abstract pieces of his whole oeuvre and thus in fact the culmination of his Modernist style.  It is a peculiarity of Prendergast that he did his boldest and most avant-garde experiments in media for which he was far less well known than for his signature watercolors: in this case pastels, or, as Elizabeth Kennedy recently asserted, "when working with his monotypes" (p. 104 in the exhibition catalogue "Prendergast in Italy"; see my review on this website).  In any case, this systematic occupation with pastels was unsuspected until, some seventy years after their creation, the artist's very much younger sister-in-law brought them to the attention of Warren Adelson, at that time Director of the Coe Kerr Gallery, who arranged the exhibition and wrote the catalogue.Mr. Adelson comments that the aesthetic impression of the pastels is fundamentally different from that of either the watercolors or the oils of the same period, that they seem to "synthesize the fluidity and clarity of watercolor with the density and impasto of oil, thereby gaining a new and quite different effect" (5).  I am quite willing to take this at face value, for it makes sense that these works should have a special brilliance: Prendergast's usual technique in these pieces was to apply pastel over a base of watercolor, producing an unusual  chromatic result, a "texture that is startling, [. . .] both translucent and impastoed [. . .] a suffused shadowless radiance, a luminous effect that records not the effect of light on color, but pure color untouched by light" (13).  This sounds both convincing and intriguing, but the pity is that such chromatic and textural nuances simply cannot be replicated on paper, even though in every other way the reproductions are excellent.  The paintings are beautiful; the compositional rhythms and perspectives and the wonderful colors familiar from the watercolors are there, but unfortunately the very special qualities that the author so eloquently adduces and that make these works stand out in the artist's oeuvre are not obvious in reproduction, and I (for one) cannot always discern the difference between them and similar works done in pure watercolor.  Fortunately, that does not detract from an appreciation of the paintings themselves nor from understanding the kind of temporal compression they represent: Prendergast's career went from the representational and anecdotal increasingly toward the abstract and nonrealistic, and this trajectory can be followed in these works also, even though they represent only a scant decade of his work.  The dating of these pastels is difficult and uncertain,  but the first of the twenty-two paintings exhibited, "Boat Landing, Nahant, Massachusetts" (the cover illustration), is dated 1910 on the reverse and is still largely figurative and pictorial.  The last of them, "Distance Hills, Maine" and "On the Rocks, North Shore," both from ca. 1918, are a world away from the beaches of Boston and the parks of New York; here, the figures are practically one with their background, almost absorbed by the shore they are pictured on and seemingly woven of the same material: interior, almost dream-like apparitions that Mr. Adelson aptly calls "arabesques of the imagination" (17).  Clearly, one will need to see these paintings in the flesh to appreciate them fully, but in the meantime we can be thankful for these beautiful reproductions, the several black-and-white illustrations that accompany them, and a concise and expert introduction to this little known aspect of the artist's work.

This is the volume that accompanied the exhibition of the same name at the Williams College Museum of  Art in Williamstown, Massachusetts, from July to September 2009; at the Peggy Guggenheim Collection in Venice from October 2009 to January 2010; and at  The Museum of Fine Arts in Houston, Texas, from February to May 2010.  It is not a catalogue in the strict sense, as there is no actual "catalogue" of the exhibited works.  Instead, the works are reproduced among the many companion images accompanying the essays.  The book is lavishly illustrated with, by my rough count, over two hundred reproductions--mostly of Prendergast works and many printed full-page--in excellent  color, which is especially important for this artist, who quickly became known as one of the outstanding colorists among the early Moderns.  Prendergast spent most of his time in Italy, during both of his two sojourns (1898-99 and 1911-12), in Venice, which means there is a lot of blue in his works (dress, flowers, etc., and especially sky and water), and some of the reproductions, such as of "Grande Marina, Capri" (ca. 1898-99; CR 758 recto) and "Steps of Santa Maria d'Aracoeli, Rome" (ca. 1898-99; CR 749), are surprisingly good in their ability to capture some very nuanced tones. The companion illustrations include maps, a number of period photographs of people and locales, and well chosen comparison paintings from Veronese and Carpaccio to Sargent and Klimt.The art works are accompanied by several interpretive and historical essays.  Nancy Mowyll Mathews, who as Eugenie Prendergast Senior Curator at the Williams College Museum was the major curator of the show and the volume's major editor, has written an excellent discussion of the artist's Italian work, pointing out what was new to him and how he incorporated his new experiences and impressions into the Modernist grounding he had already acquired in his years in Paris and further developed in Boston.  She is very good in indicating the thematic and technical innovations that made his work so attractive to the American avant-garde and ensured a positive reception to his Italian work upon his return.  This is a much longer and more detailed consideration of the work than the one she contributed more recently to the catalogue of the "Prendergast By the Sea" exhibition at Bowdoin College (see my review).  Next to watercolor, which was Prendergast's preferred medium (there are only three oils in his entire Italian oeuvre), he created many monotypes on his first Italian trip, and these are the subject of an excellent essay by Elizabeth Kennedy, the Terra Foundation's Curator of the Collection, who assisted with both exhibition and catalogue.  She underscores this medium as the one in which Prendergast was most experimental, creating spatial ambiguity and manipulating color in such a way as to earn him her designation as "America's first Modernist artist" (125).  A few other essays are less specifically analytical of the work and are intended more to provide background information on the Venetian ambiance that Prendergast encountered: the belletristic activity of writers from all over the world drawn to the city; his absorption and use of the paintings of the great masters he studied in the museums (especially Carpaccio); the conflict of tradition and modernity in the early days of what eventually became the Venice Biennale (a gouache Picasso sent from Paris in 1905 proved a bit too much for the conservative crowd and was taken down and returned to the artist after three days); time as an element of great importance on the second visit, etc.  Although somewhat tangential to the artist, these essays create a good sense of the atmosphere in which he was working and the influences to which he was exposed.  The volume concludes with a fourteen-page checklist of the entire Italian oeuvre (updating the catalogue raisonne), a chronology of the artist's life, and a good index.  Prendergast's Italian paintings were central to his entire body of work, and this very competent and comprehensive presentation of them is an essential addition to the literature about him.  It is also a very handsomely produced volume and highly recommended.

This volume is the catalogue of the exhibition of the same name at the Bowdoin College Museum of Art in Brunswick, Maine, from June to October 2013.  It is edited by Joachim Homann, the Museum's director.  The show is co-curated by him and Nancy Mowll Mathews, the former Eugenie Prendergast Curator at the Williams College Museum of Art, who curated the 2009-2010 exhibition "Prendergast in Italy" in Williamstown, Venice, and Houston, and edited its catalogue (see my review on this website).  Whereas that presentation focussed on the results of Prendergast's two trips to Italy in 1898-1899 and 1911-1912, this exhibition is the closest thing the artist has had to a retrospective in over twenty years and gathers together works from some thirty collections.  "By the Sea" might seem to disqualify it as a broad overview of his artistic career, but in fact wherever Prendergast lived and/or painted--be it New England, New York,  France, or Italy--he was never far from the ocean, and the depiction of people disporting themselves at the water's edge was his lifelong occupation, amounting to over a thousand images (two-thirds of his entire oeuvre).  This catalogue presents works spanning his whole artistic life, from 1891 to 1923, in all the various media in which he worked (primarily watercolor, oil, and monotype).  There are seventy-four plates of the exhibited works, printed either full-page or, for the horizontal format he often preferred, over two pages, and these are accompanied by over thirty companion illustrations.  Given the unusual  breadth of his palette, it is sometimes hard to judge the color quality of the reproductions, but I believe they are generally quite true to the original, and they are in any case sharply printed.  The reproductions are arranged chronologically, so it is easy to follow Prendergast's evolution, in both theme and technique, from the elegantly dressed Boston boardwalk strollers of the 1890's to the very undressed and surprisingly erotic bathers of the later paintings, when impatience with the prudishness of the Boston public prompted his and his brother's move to New York in 1914, after forty-six years in the Massachusetts capital.This is the trajectory traced by the five essays in the catalogue, by Drs. Homann and Mathews and other scholars who have written before on Prendergast and aspects of early American modernism.  Some of the topics covered are his importation into the American art scene of themes and techniques that he discovered on his European trips; his stylistic ancestors among the Impressionists and Post-Impressionists (chiefly Renoir and Cézanne); his participation with other Americans in group exhibitions of early modernist painters (Glackens, Sloan, Bellows), etc.  These essays tend to provide more general information than specific aesthetic analysis; they mostly locate him in the making of American art and highlight his role as a bridge between European and native developments. The discussions are augmented by scholarly apparatus in the form of a chronology of the artist's life, a bibliography, and a checklist of the exhibition with relevant curatorial data.  The informative text and abundant illustrations combine to make this catalogue a thorough and competent overview of Prendergast's oeuvre, short of the catalogue raisonné the most comprehensive one we have at the moment.

This is the eighty-page catalogue produced to accompany the exhibition at the National Gallery in London from June to September 2013.  The NG owns two Vermeer paintings of a young woman playing a muselar virginal (one standing, the other seated), and when they received "The Guitar Player" (ca. 1672) on loan from English Heritage, it was decided to mount a show on the subject of music as a theme in Golden Age painting.  Two additional Vermeers and some representative musical instruments and songbooks were borrowed and put together with paintings already in the NG's permanent collection, and the result is this small but informative presentation.  "Vermeer and Music" may be a bit exaggerated as a title (the exhibition is much broader than that), but there are indeed five Vermeer canvases in the show, and to see five Vermeers together under any circumstances is not an experience to disparage. Marjorie Wieseman, the Gallery's Curator of Dutch and Flemish Paintings, who curated the 2011 exhibition "Vermeer's Women: Secrets and Silence" and edited its catalog (see my review) has written both the introductory essay and the catalogue notes for this show also.  Her thirty-page introduction briefly discusses the historical background to music appreciation in the new United Provinces, the locales of public and private performance, and the kinds of music and songbooks available.  The essay is well illustrated  with companion pictures of paintings, instruments, and music books.  The exhibition featured twenty-five paintings, seven instruments, and five songbooks.  Not all the books or instruments are illustrated in the catalogue, but all of the paintings are, in reproductions in small format but large enough to be easily legible, and in good color and detail. The Dutch in the seventeenth century were not known for their musical culture, and so it is quite surprising to see the extent to which musical themes permeated the visual culture in which they were preeminent. The range goes from riotous hoedown fiddling to tender duets in the service of courtship--and everything in between; it is estimated that some twelve percent of the paintings created in that century have musical themes of one sort or another, and fully one-third (i.e., twelve of thirty-six) of Vermeer's extant paintings depict musicians or musical instruments.  Dr. Wieseman's individual notes comment on the instruments in the paintings, and the volume concludes with an illustrated glossary of instruments and some suggestions for further reading.  This is in no way intended to be a definitive or comprehensive survey of the subject, but it is a very nice overview of the National Gallery's extensive collection of Golden Age genre paintings and a thoroughly competent and handsomely produced introduction to one of the most important sub-genres.

This is the catalogue of the exhibit of the same name organized by the Mildred Lane Kemper Museum of Art at Washington University in St. Louis and shown there from January to April 2013 and at the Phillips Collection in Washington, D.C., from June to September 2013.  There are forty-one exhibition paintings, each reproduced full-page and with excellent color and clarity, as well as some forty-odd additional supportive illustrations and a few pages of photographs of Braque and his studio.  The paintings are not given any specific commentary, but they are discussed in a general way in the several accompanying essays.  Karin K. Butler, who curated the show in St. Louis and edited the catalogue, provides a general overview of this period of Braque's career and elucidates the aesthetic bases of his political quiescence in these tumultuous years--especially in view of Picasso's highly visible political profile--which was a very sensitive point in the critical reception of his work during that time.  Her conclusion is that his still-life paintings "are about the war precisely by being not about the war" (29).  Renee Maurer, Assistant Curator at the Phillips, contributes an essay on Duncan Phillips's predilection for Braques, while everyone else was collecting Picasso and Matisse, and there are further essays on the role of the German publicist and cultural critic Carl Einstein in the early appreciation and popularization of Braque's work and on the characteristic "tactility" of his way of seeing.  There is also an extensive report on the technical analysis of  twenty-one of his paintings.  That kind of documentation is apparently becoming obligatory in exhibition catalogs, but here it makes a great deal more sense than it does in many others: Braque paid almost obsessive attention to the texture of his surfaces, which he considered at least as important as color and form, and, as the technical examinations clearly show, he was a masterful and imaginative manipulator of his materials, mixing all kinds of things into his pigments and then applying them in ingenious ways to the supports.It is a peculiarity of Braque's reception that the paintings of his middle years--precisely the Cubist still lifes presented here--have received less attention either than his early work, with its tighter association with Picasso, or the post-war paintings. As the foreword points out, this is his first major museum exhibition in twenty-five years, and it seems to be the first exhibition and catalogue to have concentrated on this period altogether.  For that reason, it is a particular merit of this volume to reprint, in excellent translations, both Carl Einstein's introduction to the catalog that accompanied the first retrospective exhibition of Braque's work (in Basel in 1933), and Jean Paulhan's 1945-1952 essay "Braque le patron."  Paulhan, editor of the Nouvelle Revue Franaise from 1925 to 1940, was one of the most influential critics of the time, and this is the most substantial of his pieces on Braque.  The volume concludes with a chronology juxtaposing the artist's life with the major historical events of the time, a checklist of the exhibition with pertinent curatorial data, and a comprehensive index.  A very substantial and handsomely produced volume, an absolute must for anyone interested in Braque or the issues of Cubism, and highly recommended in general.

This volume was published to accompany the exhibition of the same name organized by the Cleveland Museum of Art and mounted at the Museum from December 2012 to April 2013; it will be shown at the Museu Picasso in Barcelona from October 2013 to January 2014.  The sole author, William H. Robinson, Curator of European Paintings at the Cleveland Museum, has written extensively on Spanish and Catalan modernism and is thoroughly acquainted with the political, social, and cultural environment that gave birth to the works of that couple of generations of artists from Antoni Gaudi to Joan Miro and Salvador Dali.  Here he has brought his formidable learning and analytic skills to an elucidation of one of Modernism's most enigmatic paintings, "La Vie" (1903), the culmination of Picasso's Blue Period.  The result is one of the most comprehensive and informative studies of an individual painting that I have ever encountered--and it is also compulsively readable.  Rather than explicating the finished canvas as a whole, the author seeks to establish the painting's "meaning" by reconstructing the process of its creation and tracing the crucial alterations that Picasso made to its iconography in pursuit of his changing conception of the work.  In doing so, he discusses themes, subjects, and other artists who were important in Picasso's formulation: the genre of "the artist's studio"; the desperate women of the St.-Lazare prison that the painter started visiting in the summer of 1901; the artist as both bohemian and martyr; the suicide of the artist's close friend Carles Casagemas and the notion of the "femme fatale" and the role of "Germaine" Gargallo in all that; Nietzsche, Rodin and, especially, Gauguin, etc., etc.--the range of reference is so broad that the book actually approaches an intellectual biography of the young Picasso centered on his creation of this one work. One engaging aspect of the narrative is that Dr. Robinson never insists on "influence" as such--just as a pool of water cannot be said to "influence" a sponge placed in it, yet the sponge (in this case, Picasso and his painting) is profoundly altered by absorption from its milieu--and our understanding of this much more elusive process is superbly facilitated by the material he presents for our own absorption.  All this discussion is duly informed by the results of the technical examinations now made possible by the array of instruments at the conservator's service: infrared reflectology, stereomicroscopy, etc.The volume is lavishly and beautifully illustrated with over 175 excellently chosen reproductions.  In keeping with the small format, these are also for the most part small, but they have excellent color and clarity.  There are also a dozen or so detail blow-ups of "La Vie." The book is very conscientiously annotated and concludes with a short but useful selected bibliography. The conclusion of the discussion is that what the painting "means" is the accretion of meanings that it acquired in the course of its creation; it is a merging and mingling of its many diverse themes: an allegory of sacred and profane love, of the cycle of life and death, a commentary on the assorted vulnerabilities of the proletarian class, and on many other things.  What emerges clearly from the study is that virtually everything Picasso altered in the course of the painting was aimed at expanding the original theme of the artist's studio into an increasingly multilayered and mysterious image, until the painting, rather like "la vie" itself, finally raises more questions than it answers. About the same time Picasso was painting this canvas, Gustav Mahler made his famous comment to Jan Sibelius that the symphony "must be like the world, must embrace everything."  Neither symphonies nor paintings are infinitely capacious, but apparently they can be inexhaustibly suggestive.  To his friend Jaume Sabartes Picasso once said that "a finished work is a dead work, killed" (140), but an unfinished work is still alive.  So perhaps it is also with interpretations: the great merit of this volume is that it hones our understanding and provides us with meanings but leaves us with the realization that the painting's meaning is still unfinished, still alive.

This is a fun story with beautiful illustrations. Dr. Hedgehog does get a bit gruff with Martin Mouse when he still tries to refuse to jump onto the head of Henry the Horse. Poor little Martin Mouse is frightened, and the impatience and sternness of Dr. Hedgehog was a bit rough. At the end of the book is a pull out poster. Disclosure: I won a copy of this book in a Goodreads giveaway

This is one of those continued series that really needs to be read in order to understand what all is happening.  This story picks up from Shawna’s Choice and now Shawna and Vilnek are on the run from Falsen and had to leave Trellian under false murder charges. Falsen has gone off the deep end and there is no reasoning with him. The plot kept the pages turning and more mystery and suspense unfolds. The story is full of characters from the first book and new ones are added. Many of the Miners and their Companions are now married too. These stories have no sex scenes but are full of multiple spanking scenes.  The Companions/wives always seem to stay in trouble all the time.

Another wonderful story of grace and forgiveness in this Brides for All Season series. Jedediah was a Godly man who loved the Lord, his daughter Annabelle and did the best he could for his wife. Marylyn was a self-centered woman who never was happy with what she had and her evil deeds end her life.  What happens when Jedediah is broken, has lost so much and must make decisions? He prays to God asking for a miracle. Salone Newton is seeking answers and her last place to make peace is at the Starry Stud Ranch of Jedediah.  God answers prayers in His own way, it isn’t a coincidence, He answers the prayers of our heart. The plot is emotional, with so many lives affected by one evil man.  The dialog and characters are heartwarming. There is good in everything that the Lord allows to come our way. Disclosure: I received an e-copy of this story for an honest review.  All thoughts, opinions, and ratings are my own.

Wow, this was an amazing story, a journey into the BDSM lifestyle from an innocent girl, Laura, who roommates at the home of a Dominatrix, Amanda.  The plot kept me captivated and is so well told that you feel as if you are a voyeur in this journey.  The dialog is open, honest and witty, with great characters and realistic scenes. The more Laura learns, the more she wants to know. Meeting Matt and the double entendre leave her wondering if he is dominate, something she is seeking. The education from Master Noah and Mistress Amanda guides Matt and Laura into this new lifestyle and strengthens their budding relationship. Be careful what you wish for, because your dreams might just get to come true.  This story does have scenes of f/f, f/f/m, m/f/m, multiple spankings with different implements.

I found this story very unique and interesting with likable characters and witty dialog. The minesteads are run by various men and they bring in a companion to help with some of the reports and tend the stations. This is a world with multiple dangers and men are an implant that gives warnings and also is used for communications.  Men control the law and order of the Companion Program and the woman or companions must abide by the rules and regulations set forth of they will be punished under the Peace Initiative Adjustment. This was the first book in the series and full of adventure, mystery, suspense, danger and correction.  I can’t wait to read book two of this page turning story. What will happen with Shawna and Vilnek next?

This is a very short but sweet story of two people who were in love and planned to marry, but an evil man caused trouble and broke several hearts. Trey Lawson has never stopped loving Aida Hollingsworth and she had loved him, now she is out for revenge. Hell hath no fury like a woman scorned. Can true love triumph over evil? Will the truth of their separation be revealed and broken hearts mended? This has been a fun series and shared the message of forgiveness, second chances, and redemption. Disclosure: I received an e-copy of this book in exchange for an honest review.  All thoughts, opinions, and ratings are my own.

This is book two and continuation from Lightning Switch and it would be best if they are read in order to fully understand what all has happened and continued to happen. Hugo Wylde was transported from 1640 to 2004, swapping lives with Duncan Miller, after being struck by lightning.  He is so out-of-place in the modern world and with the help of Duncan’s friend Louise, decides to move to an Amish community in Ohio where he can live a Plain life, which in reality is closer to what he knew in the seventeenth century. He meets a widow, Rebecca, falls in love and married her under the Amish faith.  He is renamed Luke Wylde to conform to the Amish tradition of Biblical names. The plot kept me captivated as Hugo/Luke and Rebecca’s marriage grows, she learns to submit and accept his discipline. The dialog is heartwarming, the characters entertaining and the storyline unique.

The series continues with a new bride, Carrie for a rancher, Miles Donovan.  Carrie’s brother was friends with Rev. Shepherd and together they made the match. Carrie comes with secrets that are hindering her marriage and believing she can give and receive love.  Lies and deceit from a male church member have caused the church in her hometown to shun her and call her a harlot. Carrie is so nave and innocent, she has no knowledge of a relationship between a man and woman, so she believes she is a harlot. Miles believes a man is head of the household and that the wife will submit and Carrie agrees to that. They face many rocky roads with harsh punishments, but when trouble comes calling; will Miles believe and support his wife? How far will a man go for the woman he loves? The plot kept me captivated; the mystery kept the story in suspense, the dialog is open and the cast of characters entertaining.  I look forward to more stories in this series.

What a sweet and clean second-chance romance story.  Franzi Mueller comes home every year for Thanksgiving to Freedom Valley and to assist her family with a show for Veteran’s at the VA hospital. She lives in Houston and works as a fashion designer, her dream job. This year, things are a bit crazy and everyone seems to be involved in a matchmaking scheme between her and her high school sweetheart, Dietz. When they are together, sparks still happen.  When a conference call with her job disrupts her dream, an offer for a new job closer to home, and romance in the air for her and Dietz, will she come back home? The plot is sweet, the characters charming, the match-making blatant and the dialog heartwarming. Disclosure: I received an e-copy of this book through eBook Discovery Read & Review Club in exchange for an honest review.  All thoughts, opinions, and ratings are my own.

What a sweet short and clean Christmas time romance. What happens when a doctor who is a surgeon has his hand injured to the point his surgical career is ruined? He seeks all types of medical help and then becomes bitter and grieves the loss. Sometimes a mother has so much love that she will do whatever it takes to help, even if it is meddling. Throw in a petite, sassy grief counselor and you have a charming tale, full of raw and honest emotions. Sprinkle in hope, happiness, and falling in love. The plot kept me captivated and the pages turning with dialog that is heartwarming.

I loved this story, with mystery and suspense, a murderer/arsonist, a new romance, making changes in her life and moving forward.  The chemistry between Lexa and Jules keeps the pages turning. His dominance to her submission feeds both their desires and fantasies. The plot kept me captivated, the cast of characters were entertaining and the dialog was witty. The steamy romance between Jules and Lexa sizzles on the pages.

This story is a contemporary romance of two people, in two separate states, who never had met before but had become friends over the internet, phone calls and Skype.  Austin Tyler is a man who has a terrible track record with three ex-wives and an ex-fiancé, great with horses and is a smokejumper. Kimberly Moore, a screenwriter, has hit it big with a number one rated program, but the stress of an ex-husband and work are getting to her and she needs to chill. Cybil, a meddling friend/cousin throws these two together and sometimes the sparks that are flying isn’t just physical attraction/chemistry, but attitude.  Two people, a strong attraction, but two different worlds, how can they make it work? The plot kept me captivated with a great cast of characters, witty and snarky dialog and just enough emotions and heartwarming moments. Unlike what most readers expect in Blushing Books stories, there is no domestic discipline, just a few playful swats, but there is a steamy romance with explicit sex scenes.

I loved this fascinating story that combines historical facts within this enchanting tale of a young woman named Grace Cummings who became Dancing Fawn.  Little Elk may have been present at the murder of her family and capture of Grace, but he was not the one responsible. When she is placed with him, at first he treats her as a captive but over time it changes, eventually turning to love. When Fawn is captured by soldiers and taken to Fort Sully, what will become of a white woman, carrying an Indian baby? How can she escape and get back to her Lakota tribe and family?The story paints a picture of the life, struggles, and greed of white men as they chase after dreams caused by Gold Fever. The lives of the Lakota Indians, who just want to live on their homeland, hunt buffalo and live in peace.  But white men’s greed and lack of respect for what belongs to the People brings about war, death and a constant battle of wills. The plot kept me captivated and the story is so well told with the history and description of scenery that as a reader you can envision the sights and smells around you. The dialog and emotions are open, honest and heartwarming. The sentiments and animosity of how the whites feel towards Indians and Indians towards white are well described.  How far will Dancing Fawn be willing to go to return to the people and the man she loves, Little Elk? With true love, the eyes are colorblind to what the heart sees.  Disclosure: I received an e-copy of this book in exchange for an honest review.  All thoughts, opinions, and ratings are my own.

This is the second story in the Spy Games series but can read well as a standalone. Now Kassie and Robert are working together for The Firm. Their mission is to take down billionaire Alex Weber, a smuggler of booze, art, contraband, and worse of all, human trafficking.  Alex takes an instant liking to Kassie and she becomes the prize. Will Robert be able to keep her safe? This story kept me captivated and the pages turning with all the twists and turns in this high-risk game of cat and mouse. The characters all add to the intrigue and mystery, the dialog is entertaining and the story has just the right amount of suspenseful action, erotic scenes. and danger. This is a wonderful new series and I can’t wait to see more of Robert and Kassie.

This story kept me on the edge of my seat as the plot unfolds. Kassie Shannon has been hired by The Agency and trained to be a spy and uncover secrets. Her target, Robert Redmon, is said to be selling secrets to the enemy. As part of the cat and mouse game, she must enter his word of BDSM and that opens up a new world she has only every imagined. The plot twists and turns kept me in suspense. The dialog is raw, the emotions honest, the chemistry sizzling. What he’d offered her was a roller coaster world of danger, intrigue, and pain.  What an amazing start to a new series, and I can’t wait to read book two, Stolen Love.

I enjoyed this heartwarming story of faith, acceptance and forgiveness. It is a reminder that in a split second, life can change. Accidents happen and placing blame or feeling guilty won’t undo what has happened.  You must accept, adjust, amend and more forward. I love how the characters in this story have a deep faith in God. They are human with emotions that include self-doubt, seeking redemption and trying to move on. The plot kept me captivated, the characters are delightful, realistic and the dialog heartwarming and encouraging.

This is a well-written and educational story of the solar system.  I loved the beautiful illustrations and all the fun facts on each part of the solar system.  I would highly recommend this book for reading enjoyment and educational purposes.  What a wonderful way to teach young children about the sun, moon, and planets. I am sure parents and grandparents will enjoy it just as much as the children will. Disclosure: I received an e-copy of this book in exchange for an honest review. All thoughts, opinions, and ratings are my own.

This third story in the Eagle Harbor series can read as a standalone. I love series and seeing people we find in previous stories and meeting new ones.  This story did not fail to share so many emotions of love, forgiveness, and acceptance. This story has a strong lesson and reminder of seeking God first in everything and waiting on his guidance in our life. The story kept me captivated and the pages turning. There is a great cast of characters, witty and enlightening dialog and just the right amount of angst between characters. This isn’t a preachy story, but a gentle reminder of seeking God.  I love how when God and His will is placed first everything else seems to fall into place. This story does not leave on a cliffhanger.  I look forward to many more books in this wonderful series. Disclosure: I received an e-copy of this book in exchange for an honest review.  All thoughts, opinions, and ratings are my own.

Mirror of Love (Mirrors of Time Book 1) by Samna GhaniPENETRATED MY HEARTWhen the bride, Emma Miller, decides that she and her bridesmaids need that one last girls trip before the wedding, they go to Bolivia to Salar de Uyuni, and they start on an exciting adventure.  Staying at Palacio de Sal and touring what is known as the world's largest mirror and going to Isla de los Pescadores, known as the Island of the Fish.  Emma climbs some rocks to get a better picture and disappears and meets a wizard Amaru who says many strange things to her. Giving her an antique mirror, she is transported back to sixteen century England and there she meets Lord Ashton Colyns. He finds her shocking but refreshing. These two strangers, from different time periods, are drawn towards each other. Can Emma visualize her past, stand still and let the time roll forward from behind her? Don't think about tomorrow, look forward to yesterday.TIME TO LOVE (Mirrors of Time Book 2) by Angela FordLISTEN TO YOUR HEARTWhen the bride, Emma Miller, decides that she and her bridesmaids need that one last girls trip before the wedding, they go to Bolivia to Salar de Uyuni, and they start on an exciting adventure.  Staying at Palacio de Sal and touring what is known as the world's largest mirror and going to Isla de los Pescadores, known as the Island of the Fish.  When Emma climbs some rocks to get a better picture and disappears, Maggie goes looking for her.  What happens next when Maggie wakes up and she is in 1737 England and found by Sir Heth Manning. What a shock for each of them, clothing, dialect, and so many unanswered questions. Can two strangers, from two completely different eras find a common ground? Maggie has given up on men, being a Veterinarian, she prefers animals, rather than being hurt again by a man.  Heth stirs feelings inside her that she has never had before, and the feelings are mutual. Is finding true love worth giving up on what you have always known?  But what about her friends?Timeless Honor (Mirrors of Time Book 3) by Amber DaultonSHOULD I STAY OR SHOULD I GOThis is the third story in the Mirrors of Time series.  This book focuses on Jaye Ramsey, a 28-year-old, single librarian from Seattle who has gone to Bolivia with her four friends to Salar de Uyuni before the wedding of Emma Miller.  Jaye's grandmother, Leonora begged her not to go after telling her all her life about how she had traveled forward in time from 1725 to 1960 in Bolivia. Now, 2015 and Jaye is thrown back to the eighteenth century, Hawksatter, England, in the year 1735, She is found by Lord Lucas Kenway, a gruff and bitter man who avoids town and townspeople.  How can Jaye survive in the eighteenth century and what about her four friends? She has been searching for Emma and Maggie. She is approached by Amaru who gives her a silver mirror that she can communicate with her friends, and tells her she has a certain amount of time to decide if she wishes to stay or return to her old life.  She has strong feelings for Lucas, but does he feel the same for her? This is an enchanting time-travel story with delightful characters, witty dialog and a plot that kept the pages turning.  I look forward to the next two stories to see what will happen to the rest of her friends and their future, even if it is the past.Mountain Mirror (Mirrors of Time Book 5) by Alison Jean AshJOURNEYS END IN LOVERS’ MEETINGSThis is the fifth and final story of the Mirrors of Time Books.  Some of Juliet’s friends will decide that their time travel to the past is where happiness will be found.  For Juliet, she has been grieving for three years the death of her husband, Nick Desimone, and believes if she can just go back to that tragic day, she can save him.  In reality, Juliet will come face to face with the real man Nick is, and it isn’t pretty like she has tried to believe all these years. David Brennan is Juliet’s boss, but he also is in love with her.  How far is he willing to go to prove his love?  In life, we can’t undo the past, but we can make the future a better place.  Disclosure: I received an e-copy of this book in exchange for an honest review.  All thoughts, opinions, and ratings are my own.

This is the fifth and final story of the Mirrors of Time Books.  Some of Juliet’s friends will decide that their time travel to the past is where happiness will be found.  For Juliet, she has been grieving for three years the death of her husband, Nick Desimone, and believes if she can just go back to that tragic day, she can save him.  In reality, Juliet will come face to face with the real man Nick is, and it isn’t pretty like she has tried to believe all these years. David Brennan is Juliet’s boss, but he also is in love with her.  How far is he willing to go to prove his love?  In life, we can’t undo the past, but we can make the future a better place.  Disclosure: I received an e-copy of this book in exchange for an honest review.  All thoughts, opinions, and ratings are my own.

This story will keep the reader captivated and on the edge of their seat as it unfolds with all the twists and turns.  The murder of her 17-year-old sister, Lisa, has Constable Brianna Wilson of the Special Victims Unit, determined to solve the case. This story kept me in constant suspense as she finds her sister's killer, but what an unexpected nightmare will be revealed. This short read has an interesting cast of characters, witty dialog and heart-stopping moments. This is a novella, but it packed full of mystery and suspense that will keep the pages turning.

What a fun story and beginning to a new series.  This story is loosely based on a historical couple whom both wrote to the Missionary Board to go west and serve. Dr. Johnathan Shepherd is both a medical doctor and minister and needs a wife and helpmeet as he travels to the western frontier. Esther Richardson has attended seminary and want to serve out west, but must be married, so the mission board pair these two up.  The plot kept me captivated, I loved the sassy spunk that is Esther, and she actually had me laughing at her antics. The dialog is entertaining as are the characters in this story. I look forward to more stories in this series.

This is a wonderful series that has dominate men, submissive women, mystery, suspense, kidnapping, crime with a drug cartel with a long overdue beautiful erotic romance. Captain Anthony Rossi could never indulge in a long term relationship while he was away so often on missions as a Green Beret. Since changing his lifestyle, he is ready for a more permanent relationship and Megan is his dream woman. Megan is 31-years-old and never been in a serious relationship, she has been in love with Cap for fifteen years and no one could hold up to his standards in her eyes. When these two finally get together they are explosive.  This story will take the reader on a wild roller coaster ride of emotions and action filled pages that involve mystery and suspense. This is a very steamy romance with explicit sex scenes, spankings and punishments, as well as erotic play.  Always safe, sane and consensual.  This is part of a series but I have read books out of order and they will read well as a stand-alone.

I love reading box sets, a great way to revisit authors I already like and a wonderful way to meet new authors.  This set did not disappoint.  If you are looking for sweet stories, they look no further.

This is an emotional Christmas story of dealing with loss and heartache. Wanting to avoid Christmas, as if it will make the pain go away. Laurel is suffering PTSD and goes into the Smoky Mountains to get away from noise and life, seeking solitude. Chance Adams has done the same after the death of his fiancé.  He helps her see that even the worst losses in life don't cancel out the good memories. Life can go on. The story keeps the pages turning and the emotions are heart wrenching. It's also a reminder that everyone has to deal with loss at sometimes in their life. Do you grieve and shut out the world or to you celebrate the life of those you loved and loss? Disclosure: I read this story in the Sweet Christmas Kisses 2: Nineteen Heartwarming Holiday Romances box set

I enjoyed this second chance romance story that takes place in Serendipity, Indiana where Jim Standish and Melissa Singer are planning their wedding.  High school sweethearts who broke up but reconnected twenty years later. At time,s I would have liked to knock both of their heads together for their stubbornness when it came to the wedding and where to live.
