I have a 10 year old Beagle who is a "walking garbage can". I like to say that he will eat anything that "is or ever was food" if you know what I mean. No matter what I do, he will eat anything. As a result, he gets terrible diarrhea and occassional vomiting. Since it doesn't go away on its own, I end up having to take him to the Emergency vet frequently, to be given fluids and anti-diarrheic meds (like Metronidazole which he has taken many times). This has happened multiple times while away on vacation, requiring for me to end my vacation early which was not ideal for both my dog and myself.While at the vet one visit, my Vet suggested that we try this product - Forti Flora for dogs. I purchased one box from my vet to try it out. One box is a 30-day supply. The box comes with 30 individual packets inside. Each day, you simply rip open the top of one of these little packets and sprinkle the stuff on your dog's food before eating it. It's light brown in color and has a few white speckles in it. My dog is NOT picky (of course) and he gobbles it up on his food like it wasn't even there.The most notable thing is this...this stuff actually WORKS. My dog continues to eat "garbage" on a daily basis, but as long as I am giving this to him each day, he can get through it. He has not had diarrhea since the first day that I started giving this to him! Since that was 5 months ago, that is a HUGE success in my book! He has no side effects at all from this. And, I know that it's working because I ran out of it and he had to go for 2 days before the next shipment arrived. During those two days, he was definitely feeling it - upset stomach and loose stool. As soon as he took this again, he was fine!Yes, this may be expensive for use on a daily basis for some people. But, for me, it's worth it. I now have confidence that I can take my dog on vacation and actually enjoy it and not have to go home early because of his intestinal issues.Fantastic product that I have already reordered many times and plan to continue to this every day going forward.  They sell a 3-pack of this product which I have also ordered here - I vary depending on which has the better price at the time of reorder.

I had low voltage landsape lights (4 Watt bulb) that were made from Malibu - I purchased them at Home Depot about 10 years ago.  These lights were made of plastic, and were set up outside in my mulch beds to provide accent lighting.  After years of fighting with the lights staying in their post (and not falling over), I decided to purchase new lights.I liked the style of my old lights, but wanted something in metal with tops that connected securely to the ground post and that were bright and durable.  I found nothing, but really liked these lights as they met all of my criteria - bright, metal, same style, and well made.  But, they are supposed to PATHWAY lights (instead of accent lights for your mulch bed, for example).  The difference is that pathway lights are brighter (which is great, what I wanted) but are a lot taller than accent lights (these come with two connecting posts that make the light about 10 inches high (off the ground).  They use the standard low voltage lighting but the plastic is very transparent and thus, allow for a brighter light.I purchased these lights initially in Home Depot to test them out and then ordered them here as Home Depot did not stock the quantity that I needed (and I find ordering from Amazon very easy and reliable).  Thus, I ordered the majority of the quantity from here.I installed these in my mulch beds earlier this Summer and they are holding up well.  These lights are not solar - you need to purchase the low voltage lighting wire and power station separately.  If you are not sure what to purchase, I would suggest that you ask someone at your local Home Depot or other similar store first.Overally, very pleased with my purchase - good quality lights.

I work in a corporate office, and also work remotely (from home) a few days a week.  As a result, I need a very good speaker phone to use for my conference calls that I take from home.  I bought the starter set for this phone from my local Target store - it included the base station (which is your answering machine and charger for one of the phones) and three additional individual phones.  I purchased this product which is an additional phone to go with the starter set.  Note:  This does not work on its own - it allows you to extend the existing grouping to another individually operated phone but it needs the overall starter set to work.This phone is great for many reasons...first, it has light up numbers.  I find this very helpful if I am working at night, even if the desk lamp is on.Also, the battery life on each individual phone is excellent - on my last cordless speaker phone, I was lucky if I got 3 hours out of it.  This can last for twice that time - up to 6 hours of non-stop usage.  The phone display includes a battery icon so you know how much battery life is left.  When/if I run out of the battery on one of these phones, I just replace it with one of the other phones located in another rooms of my house and replace the other to its charging station to recharge.Most importantly, the audio quality is excellent.  I often use the phone in speaker phone mode (just press a button on the individual cordless handset to turn it into a speaker phone!) and the audio quality is great - crystal clear audio quality.The phone also does your standard stuff like show you call waiting list, allow for you to adjust the volume on the individual handset, the ringer tone, Mute button, etc.  All of these features work as you would expect.Also, if you haven't ordered a new cordless phone recently, it is important to note that the phones these days do not require you to connect to a phone line.  To be specific...only the base station needs to be connected to a phone line.  All of the other individual cordeless phones (like the one that you would be purchasing  here) connect to the base station wirlessly to talk on the phone.  How awesome is that?  Now, you can put the phone anywhere you like, as long as there is an electrical outlet there (since each of the individual phones require for their charging station to be plugged in).As noted, I retired the two other phones that I had in my house and ordered this product to expand the individual phones in my house - love this product.

I have a 9 year old Beagle who never had an issue with noise or thunderstorms.  But, two years ago, during the summetime, we had terrible weather with very heavy thunderstorms every night for a week.  They were so loud, that I was even scared!  He started to pace back and forth across the room, whimpering and shaking in fear.  I tried to sit with him on the couch or the floor, holding him with my arms around him and putting a blanket on him - it didn't work.  I even let him sleep in my bed with me (instead of in his bed on the floor next to mine) to try to comfort him, with no success.  He would cry and pace around my bedroom all night - keeping me awake and basically comatose for work the next day.After two days of this, I asked a few friends if they knew anything that would help and they suggested this product (I had never heard of it before then).  Since he takes medications for various medical conditions, I did not want to give him any kind of meds in fear of a conflict with his current mediciations, so this was a good option.  I was skeptical at first, but after multiple sleepness night due to his pacing and crying, and his ongoing discomfort, I would have tried anything.  I found it on Amazon and ordered it for immediate delivery.The product is made from a heavy-duty fabric - it's cotton with a bit of stretch in it.  It has super wide velcro straps, which you use to wrap around the dog like a coat.  The first strap goes around the neck/chest area and the second one around the middle in order to have a tight but comfortable fit.  Since the material is stretchy, it can be tight but still comfortable.The idea is that the tight wrap makes the dog feel secure.  The instructions tell you that you are supposed to put it on when they are calm (before they get scared), to prevent or minimize the fear when the thunderstorm starts.  But, in my case, I put it on him after an hour of him crying and shaking during a thunderstorm (again, keeping me awake all hours of the night).  Within 15 minutes of putting this on him, he stopped crying and shaking and laid down and fell asleep!  I absolutely cannot believe it.  I don't know how it works, I don't know why it works, but I am telling you, it works great.  I take this with me every time that we travel just in case.  I have told everyone that I know with a dog about this and it's fantastic!One important note:  My Beagle is about 35 pounds (with a very muscular chest) and he fits just perfectly in the Large size.  My cousin has a 100 lb Lab and even the XXL doesn't fit him which sucks.  So, if you have a mid size dog or smaller, this is the product for you.  Try it, you will not regret it!

I work in a Corporate office and my desk in located in an area that is quite loud.  Thus, I was looking for a headset that would help reduce the noise level and would allow for me to listen to music on my computer.  I occassionally create audio recordings as part of my job using my computer, so I wanted to purchase a headset with voice recording functionality, as well.This headset is wireless - meaning, you don't plug it into your laptop like you used to - you plug the small black receiver into one of the USB ports on your compueter and that's it.  Since many of the new laptops no longer have plugs for microphone and headset anymore, this is ideal.In order for this to work, it has a battery inside of one of the ear pieces.  This product also comes with a charger which you plug into an electrical outlet and then connect to the port on one of the ear pieces.  The end of the port which connects to the ear piece is transparent, and changes color when it is charging (orange means charging in place, green means that charging is complete).  It takes about 2 hours to fully charge the device.  But, it lasts for a very long time - my best guess is that it lasts about 50 hours before you need to charge it again (when used for listening to audio only, without the microphone).The microphone is a heavy thick plastic that can rotate up and out of your way when you are not using it, and want to just use the headphones.  The clarity of the audio from the microphone is very good.Regarding the sound quality, it's very good.  Very clear and noticably better than your average headset.  This is not advertised as noise cancelling, but it does a decent job at that, too, minimizing background noise when you have them on your head (whether you are listening to music or not).The ear pieces are made of with thick foam, which covered in a soft, rubbery type of plastic coating.  They are comfortable, but I find that after wearing them for more than 30 minutes, my ears start to hurt and get red.  I have to readjust the fitting of the ear pieces which is not ideal.Overall, a good product which I use on a weekly basis.

I purchased this product prior to a trip from the US to Germany, as you need an adapter for any electrical devices in order to use them in Germany since their outlets are different from ours.  This product includes 2 of these adapters.As shown, they are pretty simple - they take a regular three-prong plug and convert it into a three-prong plug which fits into German electrical outlets.  Note:  Although this is intended to convert a three-prong plug, you can also use this with a two prong plug which is great.Overall, the plastic is a good quality - seems to be a well built product.  The product worked well on my week-long trip and I purchased the product for a good price here on Amazon.

I am 42 years old, with very fine brown hair (just above my shoulders cut in a layered bob) that I have colored blonde. My hair has a natural wave to it. As a result, it's never as shiny as I would like for it to be. I use L'anza hair products which I really love, and try to get it shiny with the InStyler which does a good job. But, it never looks as good as when I leave the salon which is what I am always trying to achieve.I saw the infomercial with Allysa Milano and figured, why not? I read all of the reviews here before purchasing but figured that it was worth a shot - I purchased the Sweet Almond Mint scent first (which is supposed to be for all hair types). When this was very heavy and made my hair feel greasy and too soft (beleve it or not, that is possible), I decided to try to Cucumber since it was designed for people with Fine hair.I agree with many of the reviewer comments - the smell is very strong when you are applying it but it's faint when your hair is dry. It looks and feels like you are washing your hair with conditioner. I used less than the recommended number of pumps for my hair length due to how fine my hair is (I typically use less styling product, as well, due to my fine hair) - total of 15 pumps which sufficiently covered my hair with no issues. I massaged it in for 2 minutes, used a wide tooth comb to evenly distribute and left it on for 5 additional minutes. I rinsed it off well and then used 1 pump as a leave-in conditioner.My hair is super soft and shinier than usual, and it feels clean but a bit greasy. But, in my case, it's almost TOO SOFT. I will need to use a ton of additional styling products in order to have any kind of control over my hair. I can say that if my hair style was loose and wavy, it would be perfect. But, my layered bob with bangs does not do as well with this product. I would never be able to make my hair straight after using this as it's just too soft.As I did with the Sweet Almond Mint bottle, I gave this to a coworker with longer, thick hair and she loved it.  I think that this product is just not designed for people with fine hair.

I bought this product because I was looking for a squirt gun that I could put into my dog walking bag and use in case a runaway dog came as my dog and I during a walk (believe it or not, this happens quite often in my neighborhood).  This product comes with 12 of these very tiny squirt guns - they are onoy about 3 inches wide.  They hold very little water, and after about 3 or 4 squirts, they are empty.  They squirt the water only about 6 inches and it's not a strong stream.  I should have returned them, but I just decided to donate them instead.In summary, if you are looking for a throw away gift for kids at a birthday party, for example, this is perfect.  But, for anything else, I would suggest that you look elsewhere.

I live in the suburbs of Philadephia, in a heavily wooded area.  Even though we live in a highly-populated area, due to the extensive trees and shrubs, we have a lot of wildlife that is not shy about walking through or even living in our backyards. This would not be an issue, however, I have a Beagle who will chase anything that comes in our yard.  Of course, once, we chased and cornered a skunk and that was a disaster.So, in order to avoid any unwanted animal encounters in my backyard, I wanted a very bright flashlight that I could use to check the yard before letting my dog out at night.  Over the years, I have purchased dozens of flashlights (most recently, the Mag light - in 3 different sizes...) and all of them were lousy.  Big, heavy, not bright enough.  I found this flashlight at my local hardware store.  I chose to buy it because in the store on the shelf, it had packaging that let you test it out right there.  When I turned it on, even in the well-light store, I could barely see - it was so bright!  If it was that bright in a store in the daylight, I figured that it had to be bright at night.This flashlight is like your own personal sunlight!  It is so small - it's only about 4 inches long and 1 inch wide.  It takes AA batteries which go inside the handle.  it is made of a high-quality metal and heavy duty plastic cover for the light.  You press the button at the bottom of the handle to turn it on and off.  When you turn this thing on, it's like it's daylight!  Wherever you shine it, it's literally like you are looking at daylight.This is the best flashlight that I have ever used.  I have already bought more of these to give to my family, and to keep in my car in case of an emergency.  It's so small and light, I should also buy one to keep in my purse.  It is expensive, but based on the quality of this light, you will use it for years to come - it's worth it.

live in the suburbs of a large city in Northeast US. We have a lot of mature landscaping in our area, which makes it very appealing for wildlife of all sorts. About two months ago, two skunks moved into our neighborhood. I am an animal lover, but after a few close run-ins by my neighbor and I with the skunks (I almost stepped on one going out my front door!), I decided to find a way to encourage them to stay away from my home area. I have a dog, and based on their proximity and frequency (we were seeing them on a daily basis), it was inevitable that I and my dog would end up with skunk spray which is not good. I did not want to hurt them, just did not want for them to feel so comfortable in the immediate area.I did some research on the internet, and found out about this product. I would never use chemicals to hurt them or any animal, and this seemed like a good solution. I read the reviews, which seemed to indicate that it worked as long as you read the instructions. Needless to say, it works! I have not seen the skunks since the first day that I put it out. Previously, we were seeing them daily!It's been about 4 weeks since I started using it. It comes in a plastic can that looks almost like a parmesan cheese container. It opens just like that, too. You are supposed to shake it out lightly around your property. Since I didn't think that the skunks were living in my yard (I could smell them in the next block when I walked my dog each morning, so I think that they live there), I used it around my property line. You are supposed to use it twice a week for two weeks and then twice a week after that. It worked great with the skunks. And, my dog (who is a Beagle and has a very sensitive nose) didn't seem to mind it at all, although I used it on the property line where he does not hang out often.One point...it really stinks, so I would recommend that you keep it in an outdoor location. Also, it says that it's supposed to work on bunnies (which I didn't care about being in my yard) but I have seen two bunnies since putting it out so I don't know that it would work as well on them. But, as I said, it's been 4 weeks and no sign of the skunks. Five star rating from me!

In order to prevent wildlife from getting into my garbage and recycling cans outside, I replaced my old plastic cans with these metal cans from Behrens (made in the USA, which is great).  I bought them at my local Home Depot store.  They are very light weight and durable - I keep them outside at all times to store garbage and recycling.The one thing that I don't like about them is that they do not have wheels.  Even though they are lightweight, as a female, it is difficult for me to lift the cans when they are full of garbage to take them out to curbiside for garbage pickup.  Home Depot didn't carry the cart, so I ordered that here from Amazon.First, the cart comes deassembled - you need to follow the directions in order to put it together.  I hate doing this, but it's logical that it would be shipped like this due to the size of it.  It took me about 15 minutes to put it together.  It's not heavy duty - the metal is made of a thinner aluminum.The two cans fit inside the cart and sit on two of the thin aluminum metal rods at the bottom, which suspend it about 2 inches above the ground.  The two cans fit, but often slide forward and hit the wheels which makes the cart get stuck and not roll properly.Also, in order for it to roll, you have to lift the end of the cart with the handle off of the ground.  When the cans are filled and heavy, this is difficult to do as you have to keep it elevated in order for it to roll.  I think that this would have been a lot better if they had made wheels on both sides of the cart and put a locking device to keep it in place if needed.I still use this on a daily basis as I haven't tried to find a better replacement.  But, if I had to do it over again, I would find something else.

George Perez isn’t exactly a name comics fans link with the Fantastic Four. When he served as the main artist for that series in the late 70s/early 80s, he was still learning his craft. The second volume of the “Fantastic Four Visionaries” series focusing on Perez features some charming comics from his run, mostly written by Lou Wein. These are fun comics and the art is excellent. But, without any context, the plots can fail to hold readers’ attention. There are some excellent reproductions of pin-ups by Perez. Honestly, as good a job as Perez does here, Marvel made a mistake by focusing on an artist as opposed to a writer. This book should appeal more to Perez fans than Fantastic Four ones--and even here the artist had not yet his prime.

Alan Davis tries to offer a conclusion for a classic Marvel team in “Fantastic Four: The End,” which is odd since Stan Lee attempted to do the same thing earlier. Davis is a solid writer and artist and he wraps things up for the team. There are some fine moments to be sure and some knowing asides and tributes to other comics and sci-fi stories. Davis gets most of the themes that make the Fantastic Four great: family relations, pushing the boundaries of the imagination, having the heroes explore look ahead to the future. But there’s one plot element undermining the book. Davis keeps the team members apart for too much of this book, leaving to less banter and humor than what could have been offered. Going through this book, it appears Davis is preaching towards the converted instead of trying to appeal to new fans. Fantastic Four fans will enjoy this book--it really is geared towards them--but some comic fans will simply shrug it off.

A quarter century after it was first released, Tom Petty’s “Full Moon Fever” remains one of the best rock albums of its era. “Free Fallin,” “I Won’t Back Down” and “Runnin’ Down a Dream” remain in rotation on rock stations across the country but there are solid, deeper tracks on the album including an excellent cover of the Byrds’ “Feel a Whole Lot Better,” “Yer So Bad,” and the criminally underrated “A Face in the Crowd.” Petty was in a bit of a transitional phase with the Heatbreakers and the Traveling Wilburies when this album was released but the core musicians--Perry on vocals and various instruments, Mike Campbell on lead guitar, Jeff Lynne on bass and keyboards, Phil Jones on drums--do a strong job. The supporting players--including George Harrison and Roy Orbison--also do well on this album. After 25 years, the bonus “Hello CD Listeners” feature still amuses and entertains. This is still a great album after all this time. Highly recommended. The supporting players--including George Harrison and Roy Orbison--also do well on this album. After 25 years, the bonus “Attention CD Listeners” feature still amuses and entertains. This is still a great album after all this time. Highly recommended.

Francois Furstenberg offers an interesting take on the Atlantic world and early American history in “When the United States Spoke French.” Tracing the lives of five men who fled the French Revolution (the only major name here is the great diplomat Talleyrand) and settled in Philadelphia, Furstenberg offers glimpses in social history, the shaping of the frontier, art and economics. Furstenberg relies heavily on primary sources, including letters, but he also ties in secondary sources and presents some memorable insights and offers some interesting side tracks through history. This is a unique look at early America and offers an interesting look at a very different and overlooked side of the Age of Federalism. The writing is somewhat inconsistent as Furstenberg often shifts from a dryer, academic style to much more vivid and engaging writing. This usually works but there are some admittedly dull pages. Despite this, the book carves its own niche in a increasingly crowded bookshelf, no small achievement. Recommended.

The core of the “Fantastic Four” focuses on family and pushing the boundaries of the imagination. Both are on center stage in this collection of comics as Mark Waid continues his solid run as writer with Mike Wieringo doing a solid job as he leads the art team. Waid takes longtime nemesis Dr. Doom in a different direction here, playing up his sorcerous abilities and how Mr. Fantastic, a logician who embraces science, has to respond to it. Included in the mix is how Doom threatens the Richards family and how the various Fantastic Four members respond to it. The result is a solid, exciting story with memorable moments, some humor, interesting plot twists and excellent character development. The story also includes a remarkable epilogue which ties up various elements. This ranks as one of the best Fantastic Four collections out there. Highly recommended.

Rush’s “Presto” was that band’s last album in the 1980s and my first exposure to the band when I was 15. A nice blend of strong guitar by Alex Lifeson, drums and lyrics by Neil Peart and bass, keyboards and vocals by Geddy Lee, “Presto” is a bit of an overlooked album in Rush’s collection, probably because many of the songs simply did not achieve the airplay and fame of some of their other efforts. “Show Don’t Tell,” the first track on the album, is probably the most well known of the songs here. Despite being somewhat wary of authority in the lyrics, it’s a catchy song. There are some other ear worms on the album like “Hand Over Fist,” “Scars” and “Superconductor.” Some of the songs hold up very well including the title track, “Chain Lightning” and “Available Light.” Others-- “War Paint” and “The Pass”--are more forgettable but certainly not bad. After a quarter of a century, this album remains fresh and extremely listenable. Highly recommended.

Mark Millar and Bryan Hitch turned their attention to the “Fantastic Four” after their run on the “Ultimates”with decidedly mixed results. Hitch’s art is subtle and always interesting, even engaging. Millar is--usually--a fine comics writer but there are major problems with the start of his run on the FF. Millar certainly has some good ideas, ranging from a created world and what the powerful want to do with it (though a scene with George W. Bush and Condi Rice connected to it simply doesn’t hold up). But the execution stalls. An insanely powerful robot shows up, beats up all the Marvel heroes off screen and (spoiler) only loses thanks to an underwhelming plot device. The characterization seems a bit off on some of the heroes--the Human Torch is played up as too idiotic, the Thing rushes into a serious relationship in the blink of an eye without his usual doubts and fears--though Millar does a fine job with Sue and Reed Richards. There are two key elements to the Fantastic Four: they are a family and they push the boundaries of the imagination. Millar does a fine job with the second but not the first. As such, this book is average, even slightly forgettable and disappointing based on Millar’s previous hits.

In "The Land That Never Was: Sir Gregor MacGregor And The Most Audacious Fraud In History," David Sinclair looks at one of the great con jobs of all time. Gregor MacGregor won same fame as a minor military figure and adventurer in the New World after Napoleon's fall. From there, MacGregor conned hundreds of English and Scottish settlers to invest their life savings to buy land on the Mosquito Coast, claiming he led a utopian like nation. Sinclair shows how MacGregor pulled off his con and, with a few minor problems, essentially got away with it.  Sinclair is a sharp writer about money and offers a solid biographical account of MacGregor. Still, there are points when Sinclair relies on large chunks of primary source material. That works to some extent, especially when the focus is on MacGregor's victims. There are lessons to be learned from the strange career of Gregor MacGregor and Sinclair offers a readable and valuable account of it. Recommended.

Taschen hit another home run as it continues its series on major artists. “Van Eyck” by Till-Holger Borchert is an excellent introduction that the great Flemish artist. There is of course much than remains unknown about van Eyck but Borchert offers a strong overview with insights into the great painter and his times. The paintings--from devotional pieces to portraits--are reproduced with clear and often large pictures included in the book. There is a thorough, almost 20 pages, look at the Ghent Altarpiece. Purists might grumble about a chapter included on van Eyck’s workshop but it is informative and offers some context into the artist’s entire career. Readers, especially those wanting a good introduction to van Eyck, would do well to read this book. Highly recommended.

More than 30 years, when I was attending second and third grade in the suburbs of Philadelphia, I would rush home to watch “Star Blazers,” an epic space opera featuring a brave crew of adventurers traveling across the universe to save Earth. Having recently watched the entire first season, I find it holds up very well--and certainly much better than your humble reviewer has over the last three decades.Despite animation which is unimpressive by today’s standards, the first season of “Star Blazers” presents an engaging story which will draw viewers’ interest. The exciting plot and sweeping story will still appeal to younger viewers. So will the characters. One of the major themes of the series is the maturation of young Derek Wildstar who goes from a brash loudmouth to a responsible commander. Even the supporting cast make an impression. So do the villains, including the rash Lysus and the enigmatic but engaging Desslok.There are many themes here to be sure: courage, sacrifice, commitment, love. Younger viewers may be troubled by the battle scenes (though there is no gore) and not all of our heroes come back alive. There’s certainly more to the story and it’s pretty clear that Dessolk is a stand-in for Hitler with Lysus as Rommel and other German commanders. Still, most viewers between the ages of 8-12, perhaps a few older ones, will appreciate this epic series. Some of the scenes and the music have been imprinted in my brain for more than 30 years; it’s that memorable. Highest recommendation.

Neil Jordan hit another home run with the “Borgias” and the second season proves as strong as the first.This excellent historic drama focuses on the Spanish family that held the papacy and the Papal States in its grasp at the end of the 15th/start of the 16th centuries. While the music, sets and costumes are all excellent, this series is held together by a wonderful group of actors including the masterful Jeremy Irons as Pope Alexander VI, Franois Arnaud as Cesare Borgia and Holliday Grainger as Lucrezia Borgia. Two of the stars from the first season-- Lott Verbeek as Giulia Farnese and Colm Feore as Cardinal Della Rovere--get less screen time and that is a problem as both of them are excellent. The writing is fast-paced and generally comes together along with fine drama, tense moments and an epic feel. The special features continue to underwhelm but the second season has more than the first. Still, this is a great show. Highly recommended.

“Captain America: The Bloodstone Hunt” is a fun collection of comics but extremely unoriginal. Mark Gruenwald is a strong writer for Captain America and the art team led by Kieron Dwyer does a fine job. But while these comics have some fine moments--including the debut of Crossbones--this story is familiar, perhaps overly familiar: a pursuit against Nazis for a lost ancient artifact, snake filled pit in Egypt, made South American tribe chasing our hero, trips through Asia, squabbling romantic leads.....yeah it’s pretty much Captain America in the first three Indiana Jones movies. Despite some fun moments, it simply doesn’t work. Not every hero can be inserted in every story. Captain America simply doesn’t wear Indiana Jones’ shoes well just as Indiana Jones doesn’t fit into sci-fi stories (as viewers of “Kingdom of the Crystal Skull” can attest). It’s nice to see Cap battle classic foes like Bartoc and Baron Zemo II and Diamondback was fine as the sidekick but this story simply underwhelms. Recommended to only the most passionate Captain America fans.

Love it, we sleep on a pillow top mattress that just needed that little bit of extra plush to soften the mattress contours. I can see that this might not be adequate on a lower-end mattress as the plush offers a distinct softness but limited support when lying down. The sides are long enough to fit the mattress without over stretching. The cloth material is a polyester that does not retain heat like some plush mattress pads (Pinzon Basics Overfilled Ultra Soft Microplush Queen Mattress Pad, though this one does offer more support).Overall, I am a happy sleeper. P-)

It seems there are a number of hubs being clumped together here in the reviews - this review is focused on the 7 port USB 2.0 Desktop model.The power cord is adequately long, as is the USB cable to the computer (each about 3 feet). It is powered, which makes it usable to charge even the most piggy of devices. The form factor on the desktop version is a small 2-3 inch square with 2 ports per side (except the side with the power connection that has only 1 USB port). I am not 100% enamored of the form factor as it tends to look like an octopus on my desk when I have more than 2 devices plugged in and clutters the desktop.Overall, it is functional for the purpose, but tends to clutter my desktop surface with wires everywhere (ah, here's a use for those 6 inch USB cables - Rerii [3-Pack] Premium 15cm 6 inch Micro USB Cable, 8 Pin Lightning USB Cable, Mini USB Cable, High Speed USB 2.0 Sync and Charge Cables - Fast Delivery Guarantee(Fulfilled by Amazon, Normally can receive in 3 days) - (Black)). P-)

A nice little bit of technology. My wife and I can use it to leave little messages. I had originally thought it might be useful for taking notes, but the lack of any means to transfer the notes (yes, I know I can use my phone to take a picture, but then why not just take the notes on the phone's note app). The device is not very portable either, while light weight, any bump is likely to mark the screen or at worst accidentally erase anything you might have written.Overall, the writing is a bit dim, and the device impractical for much more than use as a simple note pad for communication at home (something a text will do just as well). P-)

I've been a PaintShop user from way back when it was a JASC product. It has always been the less expensive alternative to Photoshop with much of the functionality. I have had mixed feelings about the Corel versions as they tend to be slower loading with a fairly large system footprint and in the more recent versions almost as cumbersome and confusing as Photoshop.This current offering continues to suffer from those flaws (but only enough to cost them one star in the rating) though still offering the features that I have always valued in Paintshop. The tool is easy enough to use, once you pass the initial learning curve, and priced to make it accessible to the non-corporate user. Installation was easy and uneventful, startup on my dual-core system was slow as expected, but ran smoothly once up.One feature that continues to improve over the years is the shape fitting selection (something that used to be the shape or outline wizard and is now being called Magic Move), still not perfect and does require a little help with touch-up, but leaps and bounds over what used to be required to cut and move a non-standard shape within a picture. I still love the layering (originally discovered it in Photoshop, and loved when introduced to PaintShop).Overall, a solid set of improvements on the previous version, maybe enough to warrant springing for the upgrade if you still run version 7, any version earlier than that is a definite candidate for upgrade. P-)

Very reminiscent of Heroscape (yes, the tiles are compatible).The components: decent quality plastic miniatures (only the planes walkers are painted) the monsters are divided among the familiar MtG colors - blue, green, red, white and black, the map is cardboard large sections with smaller plastic tiles. The cards are not to the quality of the MtG playing cards but will suffice.Game play: so much like Heroscape with a flavoring of Magic the Gathering. Essentially, this is a dice battle game, any number of which exist on the market, I won't deride the randomness, MtG had it in the card draw, but I prefer the fixed damage of the card game versus the dice rolling. The game plays well and can be either fast paced or strategic depending upon the players' moods. I cannot say that the game plays well in 3 or 5 player games or a 4 player free for all. The game plays best with 1 vs 1 or team play.Overall, this is an entertaining game that will probably disappoint hardcore MtG players and Heroscape fans alike. That said, the vast majority of other players will find the game entertaining and a reasonable variation on the exisiting dice combat games already on the market.

The game is fun to play, not excessively burdened with complex rules - essentially you play a card, move your piece and draw a card (truly it is a bit more complex than that but not a lot). The board and pieces are of good quality including wooden meoples, cardboard tokens and decent quality cards. The game will last well through repeated playing.The game plays quickly, my group of gamers is a set of adults, and while we don't always pay complete attention, the game progressed quickly after the initial trial that included repeated reference to the rules. Randomness plays a large part in the game, but there is an element in the card play that requires planning and strategy in opportunity management for card draws.Overall, the game is more suitable for younger audiences, but we may still play this game when we are in the mood for more of a beer and pretzels type casual game. P-)

I have two cats, in their tween years, edging toward old age, and I thought this might be good for them. I vary dry food constantly and the cats don't seem to be too picky. One is a long hair and does tend to get more hairballs, especially at the start of the hot season when she sheds more. I have noticed, anecdotally, that there seem to be fewer for me to clean up lately, but can't really conclude that it is the food over other factors. I like that the food is healthy and protein based. Price wise it compares to most other minimal ingredient foods, a little higher than some like Iams and lower than some I've seen in the pet store. Overall, the cats eat it and that's good enough for me.

I used the compressor from from a prior job (hardwood bloors in the master bedroom. Being designed for use with hardwood flooring I found this to be a better tool overall. The nylon shoe did its job and I saw no damage to the finish of the flooring. As with any new power tool it took a little getting used to, but once the trial and error period was done, it worked as expected. The finished project of engineered hardwood flooring turned out very well and I will use this for the remaining rooms as I finish the upstairs.

This is our fourth wine aerator so I figured I would extend my head to head comparison of wine aerators. Thinking of the things I want in an aerator - ease of use, clean-up, aeration and design/flash - so, those are the categories I will use for comparison. The four aerators in question are the Tanors Wine Decanter Aerator, the Metrokane 6127 Rabbit Super Aerator, Clear, the Soiree bottle-top Wine Decanter & Aerator and the Vinturi Essential Wine Aerator. Two free holding aerator and two in the bottle types.Ease of UseFor ease of use, I favor the two in the bottle models: the Rabbit and the Soiree, both fit into the bottle top snugly and pour directly to the glass, no coordination required other than hitting the glass with the wine, minimal mess though both tend to hold onto that last drop so it can drip down the bottle or onto the counter, so keep a drip cloth handy. Note that with the Soiree has a pliable rubber collar for fitting into the bottle, the Rabbit has a tapered hard plastic like collar that needs to be wedged firmly in the wine bottle to avoid mishaps. Both the Tanor and Vinturi are hand held models and workable with a regular 750ml bottle as you pour and hold the aerator at the same time, I'd hesitate with magnum or larger bottles. The Tanor and Vinturi have their own holders for placement when not in use that catches the drips once use is done, but I still find myself keeping a drip cloth handy to prevent messing up the counter top.Clean-upAgain, I tend to favor the in bottle single piece aerators for ease of clean-up. Hot soapy water for all three, the Soiree is glass and rubber, the Rabbit is acrylic and plastic, the Vinturi is again acrylic and plastic (you will need to clean both the aerator and the base, and the strainer insert if used), the Tanor is acrylic as well and requires minor dis-assembly to pull out the aeration part for thorough cleaning (note: I only do this every 5 bottles or so, finding rinsing adequate on the average)  . I have not needed to scrub any of the devices, just swish around some hot soapy water and rinse thoroughly. Then dry. The Soiree comes with a base for storage that can also double as a drying base (I dry the Soiree upside down on the base then turn it over for storage). The Tanor and Vinturi each have a base, though I tend to dry them upside down on a towel, as the base generally needs drying as well. The Rabbit is minimalist, having just the device, which I tend to dry in a shot glass (I store it that was as well, though it can be stored on its side in a drawer just as easily).AerationFor the purists, this is what it is all about, and why we buy these little devices in the first place. I'm not trying to make a $6 bottle taste like a $10 bottle or make two buck chuck taste like a fine Bordeaux (I know, my wine snob is showing); I'm using the device so that I can open the bottle and enjoy it without needing to allow it to breath for 30-60 minutes, bypassing the wait for the sulfite oxidation and the first rush of ethanol evaporation. This allows me to focus on the character of the wine and enjoy the richness of the aromas. Functionally, the Rabbit and Vinturi use the same technology, they each have an air hole and use the flow of the wine to provide a suction that draws air into the stream of wine; some may argue that the Vinutri provides a somewhat bigger cavity to allow for better mixing of the air and wine than the Rabbit. The Soiree is somewhat simpler in that it is a glass bulb and allows the pouring of the wine as it passes through the bulb to create a turbulence exposing a greater surface area of wine to air. The Tanor model incorporates and aeration fixture composed of a wide convex head for spreading the wine and then a screen or sieve below to further separate the wine for exposure to air. Ultimately, even head to head with the same wine, I'm not convinced that any of the devices works better or worse than the others. They all seem to do the job they are designed for.Design/FlashThis is where you get to be subjective, as despite the functionality, you may want something to wow your friends as you explain to them just why aeration enhances the wine. The Rabbit makes a nice little hissing sound and displays the wine as it pours, though of the three is the most minimal. The Vinturi, gurgles as the wine is poured through and while somewhat cumbersome is not likely to be ignored by onlookers. The Tanor is like the Vinturi, but without the gurgle, just wine sloshing and draining to the glass, still, being hand held and clear acrylic it is likely to be part of the show. The Soiree, in my opinion, wins hands down for flash and design as the glass bulb, with a ruby colored wine sloshing through it is very eye catching and sparkly.Ultimately, I see selection of an aerator as a subjective item. If you can't tell the difference between two buck chuck and a Bordeaux blend out of the Rutherford sub-region of Napa, you are wasting your time and money on one. If, however, you are in it for more than just the alcohol and you want to appreciate the full character of a good wine, an aerator can help bypass the breathing period of freshly opened bottles. That said, functionality being equal, my preference tends to the Soiree for ease of use and clean-up as well as the eye candy aspect. Enjoy.P-)

Functional, inexpensive and not unattractive these scissors will do the trick for most simple cutting jobs.I have to agree with the sentiment that when buying scissors you get what you pay for. Here is my assessmentPros:- Eco friendly in that they use some recycled material for the plastic handles- Economically priced- ambidextrous- cuts standard paper effectivelyCons:- handles are not very comfortable for long term cutting jobs- cutting anything thicker than 2-3 sheets of paper is not smooth and hard on the hands- don't expect precision cuts, these are neither sharp enough nor smooth enoughOverall, I have a pair of left-handed Fiskars that offer more comfort and better cutting ability. The perfect niche for these Westcott scissors is the office where cutting is occasional, doesn't tend to require great precision and can benefit from economical pricing. You are getting, perhaps, a little more than you pay for here, but not a lot more. P-)

Having come into possession of two different products for auto headlight restoration, I thought I would try a head to head comparison, The two products are the 3M Headlight Restoration System (PN 39008) and the Meguiar's Perfect Clarity Headlight Restoration Two Step Kit (hereafter know as Meguiar's).The headlights on my car had started to show the telltale opaqueness characteristic of sun damage and oxidation. I started with the more involved system by 3M - the process is to use a series of disks to first sand off the opaque layer and then imperfections in the surface left by the first disk to finer and finer scratches until you get to a frosted appearance and then polish the headlight cover with polishing compound until you get a clear surface. The Meguiar's product requires less steps in that you start with a rubbing compound and then after achieving the frosted appearance spray with a clear protective coating.Effectiveness- the 3M product left a clear un-yellowed headlight cover- the Meguiar's product left a clear un-yellowed headlight coversurprise, essentially they were in my opinion equally effective at restoring the headlightsEase of use / Effort- the 3M product took roughly 60-90 minutes to strip and buff a single headlight, note that this was done using a cordless drill (you may need an appropriate chuck as the kit attachment is smooth and round where my drill required a hex shank) making several passes and wiping down to assess progress before advancing to the next disk [ note that the instructions caution you to mask around the headlights to prevent damage to the paint, I would suggest multiple layers in the areas where the paint is most likely to get damaged, varying by car - I suggest this because I cut right through a single layer of tape in one area and scratched the paint ]- the Meguiar's product took roughly 15-20 minutes, this was through intense side to side rubbing of the headlight with the applicator pad, adding more buffing compound as the surface became dry and wiping down to assess progress before the final spray on step [ note that you need to mask here as well, but now to protect against overspray from the protecting coat, also, be careful in your spray technique as it is possible to end up with drips due to too much spray application ]Overall, as you can see from the attached before and after the both systems worked well, the difference being mostly in the length of time required to achieve the effect. Overall, I like the Maguiar's product better due to the reduced time (though the manual effort was more intense). P-)

Not just another dry history book, you don't hear that often, even the best authors struggle at times to make history entertaining. Mr. Dickey does a very good job of keeping the narrative moving around the focal point of the text, Robert Bunch, British consul to Charleston, South Carolina. While the focal point of the text, Bunch is not the be all and end all of the story. The author ensures that the reader is fed a steady stream of events current to the times, providing an excellent backdrop for framing his biographical efforts on Bunch.I found the work to be an easy and entertaining read, and a novel insight into a period and locale in American history that I was not previously familiar with. Definitely worth reading. P-)

We are in the process of replacing our upstairs carpet with engineered hardwood flooring - a project that pretty much requires a nail-gun to fasten the planks (read about toenailing the flooring). The kit comes complete with 1 1/4" brads, which are unfortunately too short for the job (I had to pick up some 1 1/2" brads), but it is gratifying to find that the nail gun can handle up to 2" brads. We have started with the master bedroom and I was able to set the compressor at one end of the room and use the included 25 foot hose to access the entire floor, not needing to move the compressor the entire time. It took a little bit of practice to get the technique down (I took one flooring strip outside and set it on some scrap wood and used about a dozen brads to adjust my technique).You have to love the attached tank for holding compressed air; I've used tankless compressors in the past and the constant noise get to you after a while. I wouldn't call it quiet, but since the compressor only runs when the tank pressure gets low the noise is not constant. The nail gun is satisfyingly sturdy and thankfully not hand specific (i.e. just as easy to use left handed as right).Overall, a very nice nail gun / compressor kit, reasonably priced. You won't be building any houses with it, but for normal household projects like mine this fills the need. P-)

A better than decent electric shaver, but let me be honest, I am happy to use a two bladed disposable razor and basic shave cream (think Barbasol), and feel that I get a good, close, comfortable shave. I have yet to find an electric razor that offers the closeness or quickness of that standard - the razor being reviewed included.I have used the gamut of electric razors over the years, cheap and good quality, and given the above caveat, this Remington stands up with the best of the lot I have tried. The closeness of the shave is adequate, though it requires repeated passes from different directions to ensure full coverage. Cleanup is easy, pop the head off and brush off the residue, pop the head back on, done. It is nice that the razor is wet/dry and usable in the shower (though in our drought state here in California, I don't think I could justify the length of time it would take me to shave under running water). The charging cradle is somewhat of an oddity, I'm not sure whether it is meant to simplify carrying for travel of stowage, but it just seems ill-designed. A couple of other nice features - the hair trimmer on the back side of the unit, and the remaining minutes of charge display.Overall, one of the better electric razors I have used, but it still doesn't beat a blade for closeness. P-)

Upfront, align your expectations, this is a budget system, not some uber-gamer system. It is assembled from basic components to provide a functional product at a low cost. Keeping that in mind let's take a look at the specifics:- Weight: surprisingly light, given the 15.6" screen, I at first thought they might have left the battery out of the system- Size: 15.6" screen again, but in wide screen format, ~10"x15" case, seems a little on the bulky side if you plan on carrying it around to classes, should fit into most normal sized knapsacks though- Display: 1366*768 pixels in wide screen, not 1080p but acceptable and delivers a good image- Processor: 2.16 GHz Celeron N2840 (dual core), remember basic system, you won't be doing heavy duty graphics rendering or speedy compiles on this system, but to stream some videos or music, play some basic games, or word process, the chip is capable, just don't expect anything miraculous (it can run games like World of Tanks, in minimum resolution reasonably well)- Network: I was a bit disappointed that the system would only connect at 2.4GHz, but remember, basic system, this will limit your streaming or online gaming, though it seems to work fine here in my house with top of the line multi-channel routers- Memory: 4 Gb, basic for Windows- Storage: 500 Gb @ 5400 rpm, basic again, expect to use either cloud storage add a passport drive- Connections: the usual network and VGA ports, 1 USB-2 and 1 USB-3 port (expect to need a USB portal or splitter, I use one port for the mouse - sure the case comes with a finger pad but you can't get real work done with one of those, and if you want to plug in a set of USB speakers you are done) I was surprised to see an HDMI port for connecting to a larger screen or TV (nice)- Software: preloaded with Windows 8 (yes, the abomination, the horror, and no touch screen, <soapbox> seriously, IMO, Windows 8 is a barrier to getting anything useful done, especially without a touch screen </soapbox>), and the plethora of trials and advertised crap (I spent my first couple of hours with the system going through the configuration of Windows that requires you to setup or provide an email account, and removing all of the preloaded trials, then installing Open Source protection software and the Chrome browser among other favored software)So those are the basics and my impression. Overall, the system is usable, though it seems 'cheap' to me, especially the keyboard (it just sounds and feels flimsy. Also, given the limited amount of 'guts' inside the box, you would have though ASUS could have used a thinner case. So, usable, functional, a great selection for that teen that might need to take it to class or for anyone on a tight budget that has a need or desire for a computer. P-)

Fun, easy to learn games in a box. The board and dice are good quality items that should last through numerous plays. The closest thing I can come up with to compare the main game play to is scrabble, but without the letters and based upon creating sets of three dice ( a set is based upon the parameters of color, shape and number on each die - all dice must be either the same or different in each parameter ). The rules for actual play were a bit confusing, but once we got to actual play, it all seemed to fall into place (trust me I know rules, being a graduate of the old Avalon Hill university of rules reading for games like Squad Leader, Tobruk and 1914, just to name a few).The rules contain variants for two other play modes - Crossword and Scramble (which offer solitaire play mode as well as group play). Ultimately, this is a fun game to play with the family (educational for kids in teaching pattern recognition) or friends, though I tend to something a bit more involved. P-)

Lower your expectations if you buy this product. No one will ever mistake this log set as real or even a quality imitation for a fire. The set is constructed of resin (think plastic), includes a power adapter and is operated by an On/Off switch for the light and another controlling the 'crackle' noise. The set is light weight, textured and colored to look vaguely like a fireplace log set. I assume that it is intended to be used in an actual fireplace setting, given the single viewing angle (back side is where all the switches are).Assembly requires a Phillips head screwdriver and is pretty simple - just attach the legs (don't over tighten as this may strip the threading or break the main assembly. Plug it in and turn it on and you have a red glowing log shaped piece of plastic. The glow cycles low and high to simulate (albeit badly) a burning fire. The 'crackle' is little more than a joke perpetrated by what sounds like a ratchet gear (think - 'click, click, click, klunk', repeat) at three speeds.While the packaging seemed adequate, the unit was still broken and cracked in multiple locations, requiring super glue to reattach one piece and left something rattling around inside the unit. There was one spot that appeared to be a sloppy resin repair performed at the factory and another where the unit was cracked around a screw that had been over tightened at the factory.Ultimately, if this weren't a review unit I would have returned it. I can only think that Duraflame has not done their brand name any favors by claiming this as their own. Personally, I'd look for products that offer better quality.

The game includes three of each card numbered 1-16 and three of each of the Karma cards: Give the Pile to a Friend, Play a Table Card, Bottoms Up and Five or Below. The game play while somewhat different in mechanics from other card games, still seems a little reminiscent of Uno. The object of getting rid of all of your cards, though it offers the twist of a single looser rather than a single winner in that game play continues until only one player remains with cards. The play is simple to learn and simple to play for any age that understands how to count. There are ample opportunities to tweak the play with the Karma cards.If looking for a simple party game that allows for social interaction and fun, this is a good choice. I docked the review one star due to the thin card stock; I want my card games to last through years of play. Ultimately, this game was entertaining and easy to play. P-)

Okay, let me do a head to head for a couple of the more moderately priced Bluetooth speakers - RND Ripple Wireless Bluetooth Speaker with two front speakers subwoofer and microphone (Gun Metal Grey) and NYNE Multimedia Inc Cruiser Portable Bluetooth Speaker (Grey/Green). First off these are not the high end products like Bose, Sony or even Beats that can cost in excess of $200. These are more moderately priced items costing $30-$60. Your expectations should be appropriate for the price range.Sound: first and foremost among what you probably want from a speaker. Both speakers offer good sound for the small size. The Ripple is a touch fuller on the bass, but both offer good sound across the volume range (better at higher volumes, a little tinny at lower volumes)Portability: these are after all designed to accompany you mobile device. The NYNE is a bit bulkier, but is mountable on your bicycle (brackets and such included). Both units weigh in about the same when held, one in each hand, at less than a pound.Charge: both are rechargeable, both come with a USB cable (you can use the plug adapter from you phone to connect the cable and charge), the Ripple is rated at 8-10 hours, I get about 6-8; the Cruiser does not seem to have an official rating on the Amazon product details and I have not run the battery enough to wear it down in the 4 hours of play time I've been using it.Misc: the Cruiser is equipped with an internal microphone and can be used to answer calls, both are equipped with Aux input plugs so that you can play from non-Bluetooth sources, though that sort of defeats the purpose of buying a wireless speaker.Pairing: both paired easily with my iPhone, nothing special here.Overall, the Cruiser is nice as a casual bike mounted speaker for when you want to be 'mobile.' The Ripple is the less expensive of the two and a good solution for those times when you don't have your stereo with you and want to listen without a set of head phones. Neither measures up to our Bose, but then we expected that, these best use by giving them to the kids. P-)

Sharing these around the office, I have been informed that the Matcha flavor is the current rage with the 20-30s crowd. Personally, I've run across Pocky before and found the chocolate version tasty, though not compelling in the way I might feel about a toll house cookie, but I can chalk that up to a cultural preference from my childhood.What I do like about the Pocky is that I can grab two or three and have a quick little snack without feeling the guilt of eating too much. The Match flavor reminds me of a white chocolate / yogurt covered pretzel consistency with a little flavor (I'll assume the green tea, though it does not taste like any green tea I've ever had). These are not nearly as sweet as the chocolate Pocky, having what I would consider as a subtle sweetness.Overall, I'm inclined to say that they are tasty and while I may not buy them for myself, I can see eating them without complaint. P-)

Once again, as with Katabasis I felt lost during the first few chapters as I picked up many of the characters and back stories without the benefit of having read the first three books. Comparison to Katabasis does not favor this book and while I will not pan this book, I'd drop the rating a half star because it lacks some of the depth that I had so enjoyed in the prior book. This text seems to verge even farther into religious mysticism than the last book, and stretches the believability of an otherwise good piece of historical fiction.All of that aside, the author does a good job of story telling and provides a fairly entertaining tale. P-)

Not having read any of the previous books, makes the early stages of the book a little confusing, but not hopelessly so. I was easily engaged in the storyline within the first 100 pages, and had little trouble keeping up with the disparate groups. The authors make ample use of scene/group changing to maintain literary tension, but aside from the initial confusion over characters that I was not familiar with this was not cumbersome and actually helped keep me reading.The characters, even as a first reading in the series, are well developed. I found the use of religious mysticism well placed and not so heavy as to verge over into fantasy. All in all, I found the book very readable and entertaining. P-)

I'm relaying comments from my wife, who has been using the product.Following the directions as printed, application is pretty simple, my wife uses about two pumps for hair a little past shoulder length, working it into the hair and letting it set for 5 minutes and rinsing. The result is, subjectively, softer hair that after drying does appear to have more volume and retain the volume throughout the day. Seven days may be a bit of a stretch for duration of effect, especially, given that she washes her hair daily (your mileage may vary depending on washing). As an aside she noted somewhat more retained control on days when we get a slight mist in the mornings than before.Overall, my wife is happy with the results and not unhappy with the cost for the product.P-)

The dog loved it at first, then got tired of it near the end of the bag. Admittedly, I only use a 1/4 - 1/2 cup twice a day (small dog) and it may have started to get a little stale by the end of the bag, which may explain the limited interest in the last few days of use. Despite what others may have noted, my dog remained healthy during the weeks she ate this food.Will I buy more? At about $5 a pound (making it higher priced than Blue, which I consider over priced), probably not.

Beer and pretzels or maybe wine and crackers, that's about the way I would characterize this game. The luck/random factor is too heavily involved to make it a true strategy game.The game is extremely free form, as an example it does not start with a goal and there is no way to win until someone plays a Goal card. Likewise that rules are simple to start - Draw a card, Play a card. The rules are all out on the table, nothing to remember, just be adaptable. The game is best played with a 'fun' group (more being better), too much seriousness would just make the game really frustrating.The one complaint (ignoring the luck factor, because, every now and then it is fun to just play something without having to strategize) and why I dropped a star is the cheapness of the card stock, truly thin. I have not played enough games (half a dozen so far) to see any degradation of the cards, however, the cards are thin to the point of making them difficult to shuffle well and I fully expect that the useful life of the cards may be under 100 games (I have standard playing card decks that have survived 5+ years of solitaire play, these wouldn't make it a single year).To recap, fun game, no really strategy or skill to winning, cheap card stock.P-)

I had played Munchkin in the past, so many of the cards were familiar, though they have been re-purposed to work with this game's format, and they add a whimsical element to to panic side of the game.The game pits the players against a tightening ring of monsters similar to Castle Panic, that requires a certain level of cooperation to stop from reaching and breaching the castle walls. A failure to cooperate can force the entire group to lose the game. Enter Munchkin with it's stab the other guy in the back and tongue in cheek Dungeons and Dragons mentality; the result is a game that would have made John Nash proud. Players have to balance the desire for the brass ring and the risk of everyone losing.The game is well made with sturdy pieces, quality cards and a suitably opaque bag to hold the monster counters. Overall, the product is durable. The random element is powerful, but not necessarily overpowering to the point of eliminating the need for strategy and prioritization.This is a suitable beer and pretzels game for adults or a nice family game that just might spark some learning as children face the quandary noted above.

Picks up right where the first book left off. While there is some concession in the way of back history, I would not recommend picking this volume up without having read the first book. Much of what I said regarding the first book, Children of Fire, still holds true."The author is good at his craft, with good character development, good conflict and tension building as well as a well thought out plot line. Overall, I enjoyed the read."The author has continued with the story, I was gratified to see that the story has spread the focus to flesh out all four of the main characters as well as their associated supporting characters. The story still took a little effort and time to get fully moving, but I was easily engaged by the 100th page. The tension continues to build in preparation for the final book in the trilogy.P-)

Works great for what it is designed for, a reading light for your basic Kindle, but beyond that it is, also, an acceptable reading light for books, the clip is wide enough to clip (with softer plastic grips inside) to either the hard cover or soft cover plus pages to give a firm attachment.I'm not altogether sure why people are complaining about battery expense. The device uses CR 2032 coin batteries x2 (for example: Energizer CR2032 3 Volt Lithium Coin Battery 10 Pack (2 packs of 5)) ultimately at about $0.50 per battery. My use (admittedly, I only read most nights and only for an hour or so) allows for 1-2 months of battery life.Overall, the device is practical and works for my needs as an occasional reading light, the one complaint I have is that it is actually a little too bright, a softer light would be preferable for me.P-)

This is my first entry into the AC world, so I wasn't 100% sure what I was getting into.My impressions:Graphics are superb, smooth action and detail on my 360.Story, I'm only part way in, but the story line is involved enough to keep my interest piqued and keep me playing, and not so convoluted that I get confused or frustrated. Ultimately, the plot is entertaining.ESRB of Mature 17+ is reasonable, if I had tweens and early teens at home they wouldn't be playing this.Controls took a little getting used to but were not by any means difficult of counter intuitive (as a 5th installment I would have expected this to be pretty stable, and it is).Essentially, a fun game and worth the investment for the entertainment value.P-)

This is my second WiFi range extender. I, also, own a D-Link Wireless AC750 Mbps Compact Wi-Fi Range Extender (DAP-1520).The setup on the TPLink is fairly simple using either method (WDS or temporary access point); I tried both. I did have some troubles getting the device to reset and forget about the initial configuration, but otherwise the device was easy to work with.Overall, the device performs as advertised in that it does indeed add range to you WiFi network. The only downside that I experienced was the lack of a 5 GHz connection ability (the DLink extender mentioned above has both 2.4 and 5 GHz capability), a throughput speed I have gotten very used to in a house that runs multiple devices (Roku, Smart phones, tablets, PCs, TVs, BluRay players). Other than that, I found this device quite capable.P-)

Sweet and simple, this little tool is a savior for those of us that don't finish a bottle in one night and want to preserve some of the quality of the wine for the next night. The tool and included caps help to pump out some of the air in the bottle (which would otherwise oxidize the wine) forming a nice vacuum to seal the bottle. The seal is not perfect, but you will get some vacuum and be able to drink the rest of the bottle the next night with reasonable assurance that the wine will not have turned.Operation is fairly simple as you insert the cap into the opened bottle, place the pump over the cap, forming a seal by applying light downward pressure with the hand holding the body of the pump (don't get over zealous with the pressure as you may over balance the bottle and spill or break the bottle if you have tile floors like I do), pump the handle up and down 4-5 times and you should have created a vacuum seal on you wine. The caps are easy to clean with warm water and soap.Overall, the device works well, and performs adequately to preserve an open bottle of wine for at least one more night (your mileage may vary).P-)

This is our third wine aerator so I figured a head to head comparison of the three would be in order. Thinking of the things I want in an aerator - ease of use, clean-up, aeration and design/flash - so, those are the categories I will use for comparison. The three aerators in question are the Metrokane 6127 Rabbit Super Aerator, Clear, the Soiree bottle-top Wine Decanter & Aerator and the Vinturi Essential Wine Aerator. One free holding aerator and two in the bottle types.Ease of UseFor ease of use, I favor the two in the bottle models: the Rabbit and the Soiree, both fit into the bottle top snugly and pour directly to the glass, no coordination required other than hitting the glass with the wine, minimal mess though bottle tend to hold onto that last drop so it can drip down the bottle or onto the counter, so keep a drip cloth handy. Note that with the Soiree has a pliable rubber collar for fitting into the bottle, the Rabbit has a tapered hard plastic like collar that needs to be wedged firmly in the wine bottle to avoid mishaps. The Vinturi is the hand held model and workable with a regular 750ml bottle as you pour and hold the aerator at the same time, I'd hesitate with magnum or larger bottles. The Vinturi has its own holder for placement when not in use that catches the drips once use if done, but I still find myself keeping a drip cloth handy to prevent messing up the counter top.Clean-upAgain, I tend to favor the in bottle single piece aerators for ease of clean-up. Hot soapy water for all three, the Soiree is glass and rubber, the Rabbit is acrylic and plastic, the Vinturi is again acrylic and plastic (you will need to clean both the aerator and the base, and the strainer insert if used) . I have not needed to scrub any of the devices, just swish around some hot soapy water and rinse thoroughly. Then dry. The Soiree comes with a base for storage that can also double as a drying base (I dry the Soiree upside down on the base then turn it over for storage). The Vinturi has a base as well, though I tend to dry it upside down on a towel, as the base generally needs drying as well. The Rabbit is minimalist, having just the device, which I tend to dry in a shot glass (I store it that was as well, though it can be stored on its side in a drawer just as easily).AerationFor the purists, this is what it is all about, and why we buy these little devices in the first place. I'm not trying to make a $6 bottle taste like a $10 bottle or make two buck chuck taste like a fine Bordeaux (I know, my wine snob is showing); I'm using the device so that I can open the bottle and enjoy it without needing to allow it to breath for 30-60 minutes, bypassing the wait for the sulfite oxidation and the first rush of ethanol evaporation. This allows me to focus on the character of the wine and enjoy the richness of the aromas. Functionally, the Rabbit and Vinturi use the same technology, they each have an air hole and use the flow of the wine to provide a suction that draws air into the stream of wine; some may argue that the Vinutri provides a somewhat bigger cavity to allow for better mixing of the air and wine than the Rabbit. The Soiree is somewhat simpler in that it is a glass bulb and allows the pouring of the wine as it passes through the bulb to create a turbulence exposing a greater surface area of wine to air. Ultimately, even head to head with the same wine, I'm not convinced that any of the devices works better or worse than the others. They all seem to do the job they are designed for.Design/FlashThis is where you get to be subjective, as despite the functionality, you may want something to wow your friends as you explain to them just why aeration enhances the wine. The Rabbit makes a nice little hissing sound and displays the wine as it pours, though of the three is the most minimal. The Vinturi, gurgles as the wine is poured through and while somewhat cumbersome is not likely to be ignored by onlookers. The Soiree, in my opinion, wins hands down for flash and design as the glass bulb, with a ruby colored wine sloshing through it is very eye catching and sparkly.Ultimately, I see selection of an aerator as a subjective item. If you can't tell the difference between two buck chuck and a Bordeaux blend out of the Rutherford sub-region of Napa, you are wasting your time and money on one. If, however, you are in it for more than just the alcohol and you want to appreciate the full character of a good wine, an aerator can help bypass the breathing period of freshly opened bottles. That said, functionality being equal, my preference tends to the Soiree for ease of use and clean-up as well as the eye candy aspect. Enjoy.P-)
