Nothing worse than serving an overcooked piece of expensive steak.

Temperature test: To test how well the adhesive stood up to heat (it doesn't get that cold here), I put one of the clips on the metal frame of a south-facing window that gets sun for most of the day. After many days in the 80s and 90s, I could detect no deterioration of the adhesive.Cord size: The clips are seem designed for cords that are 1/16-inch to 3/16-inch, the former being the gap in the resting state (narrower cords will slip out) and the latter being the widest I could get the clip to open.  The body of the clip is 3/8-inch wide, allowing the cord easy play (repositioning).Supported Weight: The specifications don't give a weight supported. However, the advice "1 clip for every two feet of lights" implies that these clips won't hold much weight. Wrong. These clips will support *far* more than that. This is important should various critters see your string of lights as providing an alternative climbing route. I would expect that these clips would have no problem with the weight of a rat or squirrel (extrapolation, not experimentation)."Transparent": The clips themselves are transparent but the adhesive strips themselves are white. This is OK if you are putting the clips on a white background, which is what is pictured on the package. However, when mounted on other color backgrounds, the white "pops" out and even makes the transparent clip more noticeable.Horizontal runs: The adhesive strips are rectangles that don't match the contours of the clips. When the clip is installed to hold a cord horizontally and the clip is facing up (natural positioning), there is a pocket about 1/8-inch tall above the strip (and behind the top of the clip) that can collect debris. The adhesive strip must be installed length-wise behind the clip and thus when the clip is horizontal, the pull (release) tab sticks out to one side. To my eye, this looks very wrong. However, it can be mitigated if you are willing to plan carefully enough to ensure having a light positioned in front of it.-- Douglas B. Moran

The "easy set" mechanism is finicky. When it works, it is truly "easy set". But I have encountered extended periods where I pull down the easy-set handle and the trap refuses to stay set. I have been unable to determine what the difference is (and I am mechanically inclined). What *tends* to work for me during such episodes is to hold the easy-set handle down and use my other hand to lift each of the doors in turn to fully-open: This is only a fraction of an inch higher, but it lets the cables go slack. When I let the doors settle back into position (with the cable taut), this usually fixes the problem, and if not, repeat of this does.Advantages in locating the trap:--------------------------------I use live traps for mice and rats. While one can be reasonably successful setting traps for squirrels and chipmunks in relatively open spaces, my experience has been to be successful with mice and rats, you need to locate the trap in sheltered locations. This poses two basic problems:1). You need to be able either to position the trap without triggering it, or set the trigger with the trap in position. The trigger on the small Havahart traps are so sensitive that they will be set off by even slow movement into position (no sudden changes in direction or speed, no bumps). This model is no exception. However, the Easy-set handle makes it easier than sibling models to reset in a location that is awkward or hard-to-reach.2). There needs to be suitable clearance around the trap for the mechanism to move to release doors. The classic Havahart design has a rod that swings out and up from the side of the trap, requiring too much space to be located behind furniture (such as a couch). On this model, you need very little clearance on the sides, but you do need clearance above the trap for the handle to swing through. This is a potential problem: Years ago, I had rats in my attic and the trap was constantly being triggered without catching anything. I borrowed a surveillance camera and what I saw was that the rats, being cautious, would climb on top of various platforms to look and smell for danger. They used that Havahart live trap as such an observation platform, and while getting on top (before venturing in) they were triggering the trap -- sometimes by bumping the mechanism and sometimes simply by jiggling the trap. Putting something like a single sheet of newspaper over the top of the trap *might* discourage this behavior (It didn't impede the trap springing shut in my experiments).Construction Quality--------------------Excellent. Heavier duty than my earlier model (with which I never had a problem).One issue: There doesn't seem to be a reasonable way to replace the cables (between the doors and the lever) if such should become necessary (each cable terminates inside a part riveted to the door).Issues with baiting the trap----------------------------If you read the instructions and/or watch the videos, there is very little about baiting the trap for mice and rats, yet this is one of the most difficult aspects of setting up this type of trap. With a one-door model, you can put the bait on a tray in the back of the trap (enticing the critter to climb over the trigger plate to get to it). Even this is not simple because the tray tends to spill if you need to maneuver the trap into a hard-to-reach location. With a two-door trap for rats and mice, the only real choice is to suspend the bait above the trigger plate -- this encourages the critter to put its full weight on the trigger plate, to jiggle it, and if this isn't enough, the additional weight of some of the bait falling on the plate can help. My practice is to use tissue paper to create a small bag holding some nuts or sunflower seeds (remember you want a material that lets the smell of the nuts/seeds reach the critters). On some models, I can push a narrow metal rod from one side of the cage to the other just under its top and suspend the bag from it (the rod passes under the string that ties off the top of the bag). I haven't been able to do this with this model because the clearance between the top plate (with the handle) and the cage's mesh is very narrow -- too narrow for any of the rods I have on hand. I have thought of adding a loop on each side to hold the rod up high enough (using wire, string, cable tie,...). However, for my first deployment, I ran string from the bag through the two holes in the top plate. For me, this is unsatisfactory: The bag doesn't hang as high as it would with a rod, and it took too much readjustment to set up. See photo under "Product Images from Customers" (not at the top of the page, but to the right of the beginning of the reviews).For a single-door trap, you can temporarily remove the door at the back of the trap to insert and position the bait. With a two-door trap, both doors are spring loaded -- when your hand is inside the trap, the door is pressing down on your forearm. The pressure is annoying but not painful, but it does impede the free movement of your hand inside the trap. One solution is to latch the door in its open position. The manufacturer provides no instructions on how best to do this, or any mechanism to make it easier. What I did was slide a metal rod across the cage just under the door, using the mesh to hold it in place.OK for long-tail critters-------------------------When the doors snap shut, there is a fraction of an inch at the bottom left for the animal's tail. Note: if you trigger an empty trap, momentum takes the door all the way to the bottom, but I stuck various small objects there to confirm that it would crush or hold something similar to a rat's tail (my neighborhood has Dusky-footed Woodrats and their tails are very long -- 150% of body length).Explanation of my rating/my priorities--------------------------------------I down-rated this product primarily because the "easy set" mechanism failed to engage too often. I saw the advantage of that mechanism as being better suited for hard-to-reach locations. With earlier models, one often couldn't maneuver the trap into such locations without triggering it, and resetting it in place was difficult/unpleasant. If the easy-set mechanism were reliable, it would have eliminated much of this problem of putting traps in such locations.A lesser part of my down-rating this model was the difficulty noted above about baiting. This review is targeted at a typical consumer, not the professional trapper, and thus *their* ease-of-use is important. Many homeowners are unlikely to have readily available the metal rods I mentioned above. Many will not have the mechanical experience to quickly recognize what should be done. Tiny improvements in the design and instructions could have alleviated this issue.Caveat on "Live Trapping"-------------------------Note: Many people mistakenly think that live-trapping an animal and releasing it in a distant location is humane. I have been told my knowledgeable people that it typically isn't. If you are releasing an animal in a location suitable for that species, other members of that species have almost certainly claimed it as their territory and will attempt to drive off the intruder, with injury or death (immediate or deferred) for one or both. Consequently, there are often laws against relocation of wild animals (the bottom of the product's instructions advise the purchaser of this possibility, but without explanation).I use live traps to relocate mice and rats from inside my house to my yard immediately outside. The rats occasionally find a way into my attic and after I plug the hole, I use live traps to catch any that might remain in the attic. Also, I get mice in my house when my cat get irritated at being ignored for too long -- he zips out to the yard, grabs a mouse and drops it in the middle of the living room. His notion of "quality time" with me is not catching the mouse, but the cooperative chase. Sometimes I catch the mouse, sometimes not. However, I do know where mice like to hide and I leave a live trap there. Aside: Before you say anything negative about my cat's behavior, recognize that his need for "quality time" is part of what makes him so lovable.Live traps can be useful in the office as well as the home. I once worked in a building that had an infestation of rats -- they had relocated from an adjacent building that was being torn down after sitting empty for a decade. One morning as I was about to sit down at my desk, I noticed a large snap-wire rat trap where I normally put my feet. I negotiated with the Facilities Dept to let me use a live trap in my office area (and save my toes).-- Douglas B. Moran

The primary test of this product is how well it lasts and performs when much of the water on the windshield is sprayed up from the road surface and thus is contaminated with dirt and oil and being rubbed across the windshield by the wipers. I live in a locale where winter is the rainy season and unfortunately this review sample arrived two days after what was likely the last non-trivial rain for many months so I have been unable to do this primary test before this review was due.I use this type of product outside the rainy season because it makes cleaning the windows faster and better. Since I try to park under trees for shade, bird droppings are not just inevitable, but almost immediate. And then there is dust from unending construction in the area. So far, this has been doing an excellent job. For comparative testing I left some window areas untreated -- a strip on the far side of the windshield and on the rear window, and I treated only one of my station wagon's back panel windows. Substantial positive difference.Application was easy. From the instructions, I expected a significant haze to form -- and be buffed out -- but there was a barely perceptible one (not complaining -- it means that there is little product being wasted).The cap on the bottle has two minor problems:First, it pours sloppily. This is not a problem when treating a windshield because you don't need to be precise in wetting the cloth. However, if you want to do a small job, such as the outside mirrors,...Second, that the cap is to be pulled up to open the center hole is not obvious to some -- it takes more force than people expect and the label on the cap is difficult to spot and almost impossible to read (small print, minimal elevation produces negligible contrast in many lighting conditions). Consequently, some may treat it as a cap to be unscrewed.--- Douglas B. Moran

I used this on a passenger car to finish drying it.* It had more than enough capacity to complete the task itself. It had excellent absorbency, quickly picking up the beads/droplets.When I tried to wring it out before hanging it up to dry, I got very little water out of it. It was at the point where it had absorbed enough water to *start* to impede its picking up all the water during the first pass, but it was still far from soaking wet. I put it through a brief spin in my washing machine, but it was still more moist than I expected.  Since wring-and-reuse was not important to me I didn't experiment further, but if it is to you, you should look to other reviews.My perspective is that strong absorbency is a perfectly acceptable tradeoff for not being easy to wring-out.I didn't find the pockets to be useful when wiping down horizontal surfaces (hood, roof). Pushing the towel around with my hands in the pockets was little different from just have the hands on the back of the towel. In fact the latter often offered more comfortable positioning of the hands. Since I was using the towel on a regular passenger car, I can't say how useful the pockets would have been on a taller vehicle with side panels to dry (a van, a bigger SUV, ...).I have used this towel twice during the time allotted for submitting reviews.====* The car's finish was still in very good conditions, so most of the water ran off, leaving only smaller bead/droplets. No squeegee or similar was used.-- Douglas B. Moran

Note: Amazon has combined the reviews for all the different colors of this product. The colored versions have lower ratings, especially the Burgundy one which has many reports that it bleeds badly. I have the white ones. Amazon also lists this product under "Automotive", which may also bear on the reviews.This is a very thin towel, but turns out to be very absorbent. For 1-3 person-days of dishes that had been given time to drain/air-dry on a rack, a single towel easily handled removing the remaining water, and did so with a single pass of the towel, and seemed that it could have handled more. Being thin may be an advantage because the towel more easily conforms to the contours of the dish, glass or utensil being dried. And they are easier to wring out. They *might* also air-dry more quickly, but I didn't do that experiment -- my climate and usage pattern allows these and my other dish towels enough time to air-dry.For those who care about such things (I don't, but know people who do), this towel is smaller than (my) traditional dish towels. The towels came with some loose threads along the edges and there were a few more after washing--enough to notice, but not enough to impair functionality.-- Douglas B. Moran

The "Lay-Flat technology" is better described as the hose relaxing to flatten out on the ground. This seems to happen best when the hose is largely extended. The last remnants of the loops flatten out into meanders. If you are dragging the hose and there are still full coils, those coils seem to even out in both size and spacing, unlike many of my other hoses, and this may be a result of the hose "relaxing" into this state.Several of the other reviews here report that they had a problem with kinking. I have seen no evidence of situations that lead to that. It may be because I have been using the hose in warm weather (mid-70s to low-80s). Or it may be my usage pattern. When I want to extend the hose to a set position, I don't drag it, but carry and uncoil. When I am dragging a hose during watering, I am moving slowly, which gives the "Lay-Flat technology" time to balance out the coils and avoid the situations that I see leading to kinking with other hoses.When I am done using the hose, it has curled nicely -- it has memory of being curled, but little bias about the diameter (I have done a medium and large diameter).The female hose connector is wonderfully large. I had no problem gripping it even with muddy hands.Experience: I have used (deployed) this hose about 6 times in the month I have had it (I received the product in exchange for an honest, timely review).Update: After just over 2 months a kink developed.-- Douglas B. Moran

I have had occasional problems when connecting this cable to *one* of my two USB 3.0 external drives, but not to the other. I could see no difference in the micro-B connector on this cable and the one that came with that drive (Seagate). However, it doesn't seat quite as firmly as the cable that came with that drive, but it does seat firmly on my other drive (Western Digital). My current thinking is that the lesser flexibility of this cable (below) results in the connector being pulled ever so slightly out, resulting in a failed connection. Note: It is irrelevant to the purchaser which connector (cable or disk enclosure) is to blame for the loose connection -- the purchaser has to adapt/suffer.The hood on the Micro-B connector is thicker than those on my other Micro-B connectors. The body itself barely thicker, but the plastic inset logo item makes it noticeably thicker. If you have a device where hood clearance is an issue, you should look closely at the picture on the product page. The logo inset starts 3mm from the front edge of the hood and I expect that it can easily be pried out of the hood (typically attached with mediocre glue).----Performance: ExcellentAs a proxy for a direct test of the performance of this cable, I connected it to one of my external disks (Seagate Expansion 2TB Desktop External Hard Drive USB 3.0 (STBV2000100)) and downloaded a 7GB file from that disk (to an internal disk). Using the 4ft USB cable that came with that disk, I saw speeds of 114MB/sec. Replacing that cable with this 6ft cable, I saw speeds of 112 MB/sec. Additional cable length inherently produces some YMMV degradation in performance, and I regard this as excellent. I speculate that some of the negative effects of additional length were offset by the better quality of the cable.----One of my external drives runs off power from the USB connector and I have seen no problems. However, other reviews here stated that they did have problems, so that is something that you (the reader of this review) may want to explore.----Cable size:The cables that came with my USB 3.0 external disks were 3/8-inch and 1/4-inch in diameter (4 foot and 1.5 ft long respectively). This cable is 1/2-inch, indicating it has some combination of larger gauge wires (better transmission) and better insulation (electrical and physical). This cable is substantially stiffer (less flexible) than the thinner ones that came with those drives.----My usage:I move my external drives between several computers and having an additional cable saves me the hassle of plugging/unplugging from the cluttered back panel of my primary deskside computer. However, for a cable that one uses with a laptop and that one throws into a bag, the thinner, more flexible original cable is more convenient for me. Combined with the potential loose fit problems noted in the opening, this product is probably not a good candidate for such situations (but you are also unlikely to want a 6ft cable for such).----Grip: Both connections have on one side a clear plastic rectangle with the "amazon basics" logo (see their photo). I am of two minds about this. As a positive, it provides a good visual marker of which side is which (if you can remember). As a negative, it is a bit more slippery (if you have a USB port that is overly tight). And my experience is that that such insets tend to fall out after a year or two (the glue fails), which may not be bad because that leaves the depression for either improved grip or a custom label.-- Douglas B. Moran

One of the common problems with using an extension cable is that it can expose design limitations of the cable it is being used with. The situation is analogous to household power extension cords: A standard cord may be adequate for a 6ft length to an appliance, but for 50ft, you need a heavy duty cord.Advice: Rather than connecting an extension cable to your existing one, you are often better off replacing a short USB cable with a long-enough one. First, short cables often scrimp on materials to save costs -- they are good enough to work that that length, but not with an extension. Second, connectors typically introduce some YMMV degradation -- a single cable is better than two connected ones.Advice: Don't buy a longer extension cable than you need: Length itself introduces degradation of performance.----Charging cable? Dicey:Other reviews here complain that this is *not* a good charging cable (I didn't test it myself). Many devices that use USB for recharging are capable of drawing 10W (2 Amps), but the USB 3.0 spec is for only 4.5W. Short USB cables, with less resistance, can often accommodate the larger power draws than the spec, whereas a longer cable may not.- Also be aware that the limit may not be in the cable, but in the port supplying the power: Some are designed to only supply the rated power (one of my computers has one USB 2.0 port designed to supply 10W and the rest supply only the specified 2.5W).- Be aware that USB 3.0 ports supply more power by using additional wires within the cable. If the device you are charging uses a USB 2.0 connector, it cannot make use that additional capacity.----My usage: My deskside computer has two USB 3.0 ports that are closely spaced. When I have a flash drive plugged into one of those ports, it blocks the other port. I want to be able to use both ports, one for an external disk and one for a flash drive (both USB 3.0). Having an extension cable also brings out the connector for the flash drive from the back of the computer (in the middle of many cables) to the top-front of the physical desk top -- much more convenient.----Performance: ExcellentAs a proxy for a direct test of the performance of this cable, I connected it to one of my external disks (Seagate Expansion 2TB Desktop External Hard Drive USB 3.0 (STBV2000100)) and downloaded a 7GB file from that disk (to an internal disk). Using the 4ft USB cable that came with that disk, I saw speeds of 114MB/sec. Adding the 9.8 ft (3m) extension cable, I got 108MB/sec (5% decrease) which I regard as excellent, for both the additional length (245%) and the additional connection (between the two cables).Note: I would NOT use this extension cable with an external USB 3.0 disk for the reasons stated in the opening "Advice". I used it for testing because it provided the highest transfer rate.----Grip: Both connections have on one side a clear plastic rectangle with the "amazon basics" logo (see their photo). I am of two minds about this. As a positive, it provides a good visual marker of which side is which (if you can remember). As a negative, it is a bit more slippery (if you have a USB port that is overly tight). And my experience is that that such insets tend to fall out after a year or two (the glue fails), which may not be bad because that leaves the depression for either improved grip or a custom label.---Cable size:The cables that came with my USB 3.0 external disks were 3/8-inch and 1/4-inch in diameter (4 foot and 1.5 ft long respectively). This cable is 1/2-inch, indicating it has some combination of larger gauge wires (better transmission) and better insulation (electrical and physical). This cable is substantially stiffer (less flexible) than the (thinner) ones that came with those disks. For me, this is desirable, but you may have a situation where more flexibility is worth lesser performance.-- Douglas B. Moran

Adjustability: The base is heavy enough that you can easily adjust the gooseneck with a single hand. And the gooseneck more than sturdy enough to stay in position through modest bumps (which also suggests that it is durable).The gooseneck is rubberized: It is easy to grasp and it doesn't show smudges. However, that does mean that the gooseneck has a different (visual) finish than the base and hood -- not something that pops out at me, but more than shown by the product picture here (as of this writing).----The switch is a depression in the front of the base and is not readily visible from various angles, depending on the ambient light. However, for me it didn't need to be: It was right where I expected it to be and visible enough when I looked there. However, the switch is discreet enough that it is largely invisible for someone not looking for it, that is, as home-decor, it doesn't interrupt the lines of the lamp.The light has three levels. The medium setting was good enough for some reading, but I predominantly used "high". The switch steps from low to high. This is not a push-switch, but a proximity switch: I found that I could activate it when my finger was an 1/8-inch above the surface. You can trigger the switch either by (lightly) swiping your finger over it or bouncing your finger over it. I tended to do the former most, but that was simply because swiping was easier when I was reaching out to it. The switch is triggered only in the narrow area over the depression.If you are using the lamp for only brief tasks, the need to step through the levels may be an annoyance. I was initially annoyed that "high" wasn't first on the cycle--because that is what I wanted most--but came to appreciate starting at low. First, it was easier to cycle to high at the beginning of the task, rather than cycling to turn it off. And then I found that I would often stop at the medium level as good-enough.----Color temperature: There is a growing body of research on how different spectrums of light affects the brain, and is often expressed as the "color temperature" of the light produced. Daylight (bluish white, 5000-27000K) stimulates the brain. This is a problem when used during the evening because it takes the brain time to "calm down" and this delays the onset of sleep. This lamp produces light at 3000K, which is at the top of the "warm" range, equivalent to a Soft White Fluorescent and in the middle of the range for incandescent bulbs (2700-3300K). This makes it a good lamp for reading in the evening (I haven't found anything under 2700K).----The lamp has an external power adapter. Some people understandably dislike "wall warts", but I regard this as an advantage. My experience with other LED lights is that the failures that occurred were in the power adapter, not the LED bulb. If that happens, an external power adapter can be trivially replaced--the hardest part is plowing through all the listings for similar adapters to find the needed one. The label on the bottom of the lamp calls for an adapter producing 10VDC/350mA.The "wall wart" is horizontal -- it sticks out to the side of a wall outlet and can be used in the top socket leaving plenty of room to plug in something in the lower socket.In case you are curious, the power adapter that comes with the lamp is a "Constant Current LED Driver" model HLV3512T1 (I didn't find any online *retail* listings for that precise model, only wholesale ones, and under multiple manufacturer names: Waiberlon, Huibolong).-- Douglas B. Moran

The diameter of this speaker is a bit less than the typical soft drink can and thus makes it well-suited to sitting in a drink holder in a vehicle. Similarly for having sound come out the top. However, all the controls are around the base of the device, forcing you to pick it up to make any adjustments. One-handed operation was possible for me (5'10" male) but might be difficult for smaller people. The controls have very low visual contrast with the body -- a passenger had difficulty operating it at night (until she had it illuminated by the car behind us).I cannot see myself ever using this as a speakerphone while being a driver -- it is too awkward and requires too much attention. Nor would I bother to have it used by most of the people who are passengers with me: They tend to reject my directions of how such a device works in favor of their own intuitions of how it *should* work. And even for such simple functionality, I found myself repeatedly "experimenting" to get it to do what I wanted.However, as a portable speaker for around the office, house or yard, it did quite well. It has a good texture that makes it easy to carry. The weight and slip-resistant bottom kept it in place.I have given it a mediocre rating because of what I view as poor design of the controls and because the design of the connectors sacrifice what I regard as the more common and important functions in favor of functions I see no value for (chaining together multiple speakers).----Sound: The sound produced was surprisingly good, significantly better than other BT speakers of similar size that I have encountered (although most of those have somewhat lower prices). The produces a good range of frequencies and in balance (no need to adjust the player). I used it with various types of music and didn't encounter anything that was displeasing (in contrast to some others which are irritating to me on Rock and similar because they have far too little base and have too much treble).----Bluetooth: The range for this device is very similar to my other Bluetooth devices.Realize that this is BT v3.0 which doesn't include low-power capabilities in BT v4.0. My understanding is that the primary advantage of BT 4.0 for a speaker occurs when it is often in "standby mode" (connected, but no audio being sent to it).----Recharging: By a provided micro-USB cable. This is a standard cable, despite the connector on the speaker being non-standard (below), thereby making replacement trivial if it is lost, misplaced, or forgotten. The package also includes USB power adapters for both auto and wall-plug (much appreciated).I tended to use this speaker in shorter session, and thus would loose track of how much charge was likely left on the battery. It would have been very nice to have an indicator, but most of the competing products don't seem to have one either.----Connections explained -- as best I can infer:The physical USB connector is not wired as such. A conventional USB cable (provided) is used only to recharge the battery -- it does *not* provide a hardwired connection between a computer and the speaker. The data pins on the USB connector are instead used to provide an analog Aux-In stereo connector.Included in this product is a cable with a 3.5mm stereo connector and a micro-USB connector. The manual shows this as intended for chaining multiple CAN speakers together. However, it can also be used to connect the Line-Out of a laptop or similar device to the speaker (the manual makes a vague mention of this). However, with my computer, setting the volumes to max on both the computer and the speaker produces only medium volume (far less than when connected by Bluetooth).DISADVANTAGE: This arrangement means that if you are using a hardwired connection for the audio -- for example where there are competing Bluetooth devices -- you have to run the speaker on battery power (the connector is not available for the recharging cable).NOTE: The 3.5mm connector on the speaker is Aux-Out (vs Aux-In on many similar products).----FM Radio: The instructions are grossly inadequate for the radio. My first attempts to use it failed miserably. As I stepped through the stations, all I heard was loud static where the stations were, which I mistook for reception problems. When I turned down the volume way down, I could hear the stations. Because the speaker has no similar problem producing good output from a BT connection, this suggests to me that this is not a problem with the speaker portion, but noise being introduced within the electronics, for example, the speaker coil broadcasting to the antenna (feedback). On most stations, I found that I had to substantially turn down the volume to get rid of the noise/static, leaving a fairly narrow range where it was loud enough to hear without that static.The radio is of limited usefulness because you have to step through stations without any indication of where you are "on the dial", making it hard to get back to a desired frequency/station. The instructions mention "pre-set" stations without explanation of setting or accessing (and experimentation failed).When automatically scanning through stations, it pauses for 2-3 seconds before stepping to the next one. For me, this was a bit too short to recognize and respond. Although I could use auto-scan and then manually back-up, I found it more convenient to simply manually step through stations.My product came with a telescoping antenna for the radio, but the manual described the antenna as a wire that is combined with one of the provided cables. I don't know if mine is the new version, or if it is an old version being phased out.----MicroSD card slot: I didn't use this.----Douglas B. Moran

A major factor in my rating of a book is how well it meets its own description and advertising. This presents a problem for this book because the publisher's description is so broad and vague that I couldn't tell what was its intended audience or focus. But this reflects a failing of the book: It does a variety of things adequately, but none particularly well. If you are new to this topic, there is enough that the book will probably be an enjoyable read. However, if you already have an interest and have read news stories and magazine articles, there probably isn't enough to keep you reading (unless you are obligated to write a review).I am a scientist, and as such, I prefer a focus on the ideas: How they develop, the key hurtles, the missteps, the insights, how various threads came together (and some separated). There is some of that here, but it is no better than a secondary part of the book.Instead, the book is structured around the author's interactions with several research groups. You get biographic sketches, some cute stories, walk-throughs of the research facilities, overviews of those groups' research programs, and overviews of their key discoveries with some mentions of related ones by other groups. Unfortunately, none of this is particularly deep, although many of the important concepts and issues related to (animal) intelligence are touched upon. And in several sections (especially dolphins/porpoises and elephants) there is a lot of discussion of behavior that is peripheral to intelligence.Structuring the book around the visits and interviews not only expends considerable space on those aspects but largely precludes the range of quick mentions of results from other groups than would have provided a more complete and sophisticated account (again, my bias for an idea-centric account).The book makes multiple brief mentions of the revolution in thinking on non-human intelligence, but there is no insight and it seems unaware of much of what was happening, for example, it portrays the revolution as more recent than it was.* However, this is not unexpected -- most scientists I know are unwilling to talk about such aspects in detail to reporters, having been burned and seen colleagues be burned.There could have been an interesting book about "Doing Science" in this area -- the personalities, the design and analysis of experiments, the politics, ... Or there could have been a book about animal intelligence itself, weaving together what had been discovered by disparate research groups. But this book tries to do both, and winds up doing neither. The book is well-enough written that many may find it moderately enjoyable, but given all the competing writings available, I can't recommend deliberately choosing this book.--* I was a grad student in Artificial Intelligence in the 1970s and there was a lot of interesting interactions between the fields.-- Douglas B. Moran

I have some experience with options and was interested in understanding more sophisticated strategies. The first part of this book assumed a novice investor -- someone who was far from ready for the later portions of the book. It was tedious reading because the incessant repetition of basic points such as you need to limit/control downside risks. This was made worse because many of the relatively simple examples had explanations that weren't, and I had to pause to convince myself that the problem was with the explanation and not my understanding. This did not bode well for the meat of the book.The book lost credibility with me when I found myself reacting that it was badly oversimplifying. This was not the simplification that occurs as part of a phased presentation, but presentations that could mislead the reader because they don't realize what they don't know. My biggest objection was that the advocated approach seemed to badly understate its costs: the costs of the options and other financial products and the cost of your time needed to manage this approach. The approach doesn't seem practical for those who seem to be the target audience for this book.-- Douglas B. Moran

This book poorly represents the source material on which it is built, and only infrequently gives the reader links from the text to the relevant item in the alphabetized list of sources at the end of the book. Most of the interesting details, complexities, ambiguities, speculations and conflicts do not make it into this book. Composites that were created hundreds of years later are treated as if they were originals (example, the myth of Merlin of King Arthur).The story telling is very poor. This feels like the preliminary stage where an author is talking about what he knows as a method of finding coherent story lines and deciding where to focus what he will eventually write.Most frustrating is the backwards storytelling. The book often starts a topic with a point in modern culture, such as a recent movie, and then muses about that "monster", then declares most of what was said to be wrong, that it was different in the past. This is a valid, and often interesting, approach if you are trying to untangle the various threads leading to the current version, but his book simply jumps back to an earlier version without any of that. It turned out that I already knew something about many of the "monsters" in this book, but even that was enough that I found myself constantly saying "He doesn't have this quite right" and "Doesn't he know about ...".He repeatedly gets cause-and-effect reversed. He repeatedly assumes that stories were based on preexisting monsters, ignoring the possibility that the monster was created in service of the story. Even when there is substantial, even incontrovertible, evidence against that assumption.For example, he offers Frankenstein's monster as an expression of existing human fears, and only weakly acknowledges later that it was the novel that created the fears (of what science might eventually make possible). Similarly, he claims that the movie "Jaws" was merely an expression of innate human fear of sharks, rather than a mild concern that became a major cultural phenomenon through brilliant visual storytelling and musical scoring.Similarly, he treats H.G. Well's "The War of the Worlds" as representing an innate fear of space invaders, only to retreat into saying that it might have been intended as an allegory on colonialism/imperialism. But the book then continues to use science fiction monsters as arising from the human psyche rather than being literary creations to facilitate the exploration of the ideas that are the real theme of the book.For dragons, his starting points include Harry Potter (the movies, not the books) and "How to Train Your Dragon". Although the book acknowledges that there were dragons in various places around the world, most of the types of dragons and their locales are missing from this book's consideration. And even for the dragons included, it only gives a hint of how different they were, mentioning only two of the optional features: fire-breathing and flying. Aside: I worked for a company considering dragon themes and was amazed by the number of different types of dragons from all around Eurasia, and that many weren't monsters but rather protectors of the human household where they resided (and cat-sized or smaller).The book reports little of the considerations about how these aspects may have come about from distortions in retelling. For example, the book mentions the poisons in the bite of some dragon-like lizards, but doesn't take the next step: The pain and other symptoms from such a bite could be reported as analogous to being burned by fire. And the darting tongue of these lizards has been described using an analogy to flames (both "flicker"). From either, or both, it is a short step to "fire-breathing". Instead, the book focuses on instances where the cause might have been on ignition of gases (coal mines and decomposition).At only one point do I remember the book bringing a measure of analysis to ancient legends: For Beowulf, the book separates the reported _observable_ actions from the _interpretations_ of the events. In many other places, the book is incredibly credulous. For example, in another case of "dragon fire" being speculated to be from gases from decomposition of bodies, the book repeats an account where the opening of a single coffin "incinerated hundreds" (pg 114).Similarly, the book offers earthquakes as an explanation for the Minotaur. I have been in (medium) earthquakes that sounded like a big train coming at me from a distance, which the Minoans could easily have thought sounded like a big stampede of big bulls. But not a single bull. And not one running a twisting and turning path in a very restricted area (a maze under the palace). Nor is the frequency and pattern of earthquakes a good match to an animal that needs to be fed with periodic offerings. Earthquakes are at best a small fragment of a possible explanation.In analyzing Medusa's gaze turning men to stone, the book treats this as arising from people frozen with fear. It ignores other legends from around the world where people are turned to stone (example, Lot's wife in the Bible). Many of these legends are speculated to have originated as ways to explain rock formation that looked human, and possibly as part of stories to help people remember navigational details.The book's notion of "monster" is often loosely applied. For example, unlike the book, I wouldn't classify the dinosaurs of the movie "Jurassic Park" as monsters just because they were large and predatory. Similarly for the demons in the "Ghostbusters" movie.So if this isn't in the book, what takes up so much space? Musing about human nature. Musings about the use of monsters in literature and art and the transformations, for example, from the original vampires to the literary Dracula to idealized lovers for teenage girls (eg "Twilight"). And lots more of movie monsters and aliens, but surprisingly none of the radiation-created monsters of the 1950s and 1960s ("Godzilla", "Them!",...).Although the book mentions and briefly considers a number of the very interesting explorations of what might account for various historical monsters, that treatment is far too shallow to be satisfying, especially considering the available sources. Some of these monsters are attempts to rationalize processes that people of that time didn't understand, for example, germs, contagion, plagues, sleep atonia, flammable gases from not-understood sources. Other monsters seem to have been storytelling creations in response to fears. The book touches on the latter, but never deeply enough for me to call it "the science of". And the book gives examples of some steps in the cultural evolution of individual "monsters", but again without the detail, discipline and analysis to qualify as "the science of".If you have a budding interest in the science of monsters, this book has enough to further pique your interest and is just good enough to put up with the fluff and natterings. However, the inadequacies of the pointers to more detailed accounts may discourage many readers from any additional pursuit. Much of the listed source material is unavailable to the typical reader. For example, among the first 13 source listings, there are dates of 1810 (a chart), 1895 (NY Times article), 1912 (French language book), 1921 (two translated books) and specialized professional journals.-- Douglas B. Moran

My usage: I used this to sharpen several mass market kitchen knives, a pocket knife and two larger folding knives.My background: I keep a sharp edge on my knives. I learned to sharpen knives with a whetstone (40+ years ago) and having be using it on my high quality kitchen knives (Wusthof, Henckel, Shun) because I haven't found a successor that I was happy with. I have not tried this sharpener with these knives because they haven't needed sharpening in the month I have been using this product.Summary: Very happy with the results.Usability: The handle is generously large. I am a 5'10" male and a much larger hand would have comfortably fit. The sharpener was stable and the feet kept it from slipping. In some other reviews here, there are complaints that this is not the case, but I suspect that they were using too much pressure (the instructions call for only "moderate pressure").Note: As with every pull-thru sharpener I am aware of, this is designed for right-handed use -- holding the sharpener in your left and the knife in your right.Durability: The case appears to be very durable plastic and is likely to easily survive being dropped. However, it is hard to judge the internal mechanism, which appears to be all plastic. I would advise being gentle in turning and setting the dial -- someone inclined to "just force it" may wear out or break the mechanism in a short time. The manufacturer lists the coarse and fine sharpening elements as replaceable.Instructions for general use: Simple and well stated on the packaging insert. However, I would fault them for not mentioning the use of sharpening steels/rods in addition to this product to reduce the loss of material to sharpening when re-alignment of the edge was all that was needed.Instructions for _specific_ knives: On the back of the sharpener is a listing of the *most common* angles for the basic categories of knives. Inside the folded insert is a table of the specific angles for various brands and subtypes of knives. Since you will probably want to keep this, you need to be carefully cutting open the package.WARNING: If you have been given good kitchen knives, do _not_ use the common setting but check this table -- many are _substantially_ different from the common settings.This same information is available from the manufacturer's website, but with two gotcha's. First, although the label on the sharpener lists the manufacturer's URL, it doesn't give its model number and the table is found on the page you get to via that model number (suggestion: write the model # on the bottom of the sharpener). Second, the table on the web page is badly formatted for both onscreen viewing and for printing. I reported this shortly after receiving my sharpener, but haven't heard back.Aside: The reason I want to be able to print this out is that people know I know how to sharpen knives and so part of a dinner invitation is the reminder that part of my helping with prep is to sharpen their knives. I would like to be able to take an easily folded copy rather than the original (which is on cardboard).Note: The angles in the table are the ones specified by the knife manufacturers and may not correspond to the available settings, but are typically close-enough. For example, some of the specified angles are odd numbers, but the sharpener allows only even numbered angles.Note: The Cronidur line of Henckel knives -- the extra hard steel -- has a recommended angle of 12.5 degrees, which is below the listed settings. I have been able to set the mechanism to what appears to be 12 degrees, but it didn't want to let me turn it below 14 without some jiggling.-- Douglas B. Moran

I really like this flashlight because it so nicely goes in various of my pockets and yet provides brightness that I associated with much bulkier lights. When out-and-about, the Fingertip Speed Control Focusing feature changed how I use my light -- it makes zooming into a spotlight so fast and easy that I routinely do so to check out noises and movement, whereas the more common twist-to-zoom has a much higher threshold for doing so: It takes two hands, time and often taking light off the area of interest.The core deficiencies of this flashlight arise from it retaining the proportions of the much larger models in the HP series -- while this model may be much smaller, the fingers of its users aren't. This is the basis for my 1-star deduction: In the smaller HP5 this was an acceptable failing, but not so much here.Coverage/Range--------------Without context, the range given in the spec is of little use except for comparing models in the same series. This is an attempt to provide some practical metrics, but they are very much a YMMV -- my eyesight, ambient light, ...For a sense of illuminating the path in front of me, I used a section of street well away from street lights because it provides a known, consistent texture and easily estimated distances (10 ft wide lanes).In Flood mode, an oval 30 ft wide by 50 ft long. In Low Power mode, what I regard as the usable oval shrinks to 15 ft wide and becomes too dim about 15 ft out.In Spot mode, the bulls-eye is about 2 ft diameter, and the overall oval is about 10 ft wide.For judging the ability of the Spot mode to illuminate distant objects, I combined three tests: ability to show gross texture of a fence (such as larger knots in the boards), ability to show the type of construction of a garage door (slats, panels,...), ability to show details of sidings of houses (eg shingles, and type).100 feet on the Normal (high power) setting; 60 feet on Low Power.Grip----The body has conventional texturing of a small diamond pattern. The flat areas on opposing sides  is not cosmetic, but improves both the grip and comfort for me. The diameter of the barrel is too small for me to grip for long with my fingers simply wrapped around it. Instead, I pinch the light between my thumb and first two fingers with the butt near the base of my palm. This has the advantage pointing the flashlight with a more neutral wrist position. And because of the light weight of the light, I didn't find this grip to be tiring.HP5 vs HP6: The HP5 and HP6 are siblings with the same physical profile, except that the HP6 is longer to accommodate a second AA battery, which supports a brighter light, 170 vs 121 lumens (spec), and slightly longer runtime, 5 vs 4.5 hours (= 11%) (spec). This length difference does noticeably affect my grip. With my preferred grip (above), my third (ring) finger barely touches the butt of the HP5, but all 4 fingers engage the HP6. Although it feels like I don't have a good grip on the HP5, I have not had the slightest problem -- its lighter weight make the pinch grip more than adequate. For me, the choice is one of the easy "pocket-ability" of the HP5 vs the brighter light of the HP6.Switch------The protective ring around the switch is poorly designed. Inherited from the larger models, it has opposing gaps seemingly intended to make it easier for your finger to press down on the switch, especially in one-handed operation. However, when the overall design was scaled down, these gaps were not adjusted upward to accommodate fingers comfortably. They are too small for when I am holding the light with my thumb over the switch. They are barely adequate when using my forefinger, and even then I tend to arch the finger to press _down_ on the switch, rather than _across_ it. (I am a 5'10" male).Additionally, the gaps have the wrong alignment for me. I like to hold the light with my fingers on the flat section, and this has the high points of the ring under my finger or thumb. I have tried holding the light with the gaps aligned to the finger on the switch and found that the diminished grip on the barrel isn't worth the tradeoff.The scaled down protective ring also fails to adequately protect the switch from inadvertently being activated when being carried in a pack, suitcase, ... If pressing on a flat surface, the switch enters Momentary Mode somewhere between 14-16 oz (2-3 times it own weight).Focusing--------Focusing with one hand was easy and natural for me. I can push the head forward (for Spot) with my thumb. The "Fingertip Speed Focus Control" ring also allows one to pull the head backwards (to Flood) with my thumb and forefinger. However, the small gap in front of this ring reduces my ability to grasp it firmly enough to easily pull backwards. Usually I am able to uncomfortably pull back using the ring -- the problem grasping occurs at times such as when my hands are sweaty, but may also be a problem for people with weaker grips. In those circumstances, the hood is short enough that I can easily hook my forefinger over the front of it and pull it backwards. Recognize that going from Spot to Flood mode is something that you rarely _need_ to do quickly and easily -- unlike going from Flood to Spot. Consequently, I would classify this design issue as an inconvenience, rather than a problem.The manufacturer's claim of "Focus provides superior beam consistency from spot to flood, with no dark rings typically associated with focusing flashlights" is misleading. The flashlight _does_ provide great beam consistency in both spot and flood positions -- which are the ones that matter to me. However, in the intermediate positions, the center will be much darker than what you have in flood mode, and it will be surrounded by a bright ring. I don't see these intermediate positions as having any utility.The "Beam Lock System" did not work well (which it does on larger models in this series) -- it is strong enough to hold the position if the light is standing on its hood, but not good enough for normal bumps and pressures, for example, when it is in my pocket. Plus, there is no tactile feedback to tell when the lock is engaged. However, I regard this as insignificant because it is so trivial to reset the focus between Spot and Flood.Holster and Lanyard-------------------This flashlight is small and light enough that I just slide it in my pocket. There are relatively few circumstances where I would want to use a holster, and the provided holster makes that less likely. The holster is bulky because it is made of the same thick, heavy-weight, durable material as the holsters for the larger flashlights in this line (for which such materials are appropriate and welcome).The flap on the holster is fastened with Velcro. The belt loop is also fastened with Velcro, but with the addition of a snap. This snap is a useful addition in situations where the Velcro may be incremental loosened by the holster being jostled, for example by underbrush. Other holsters address this problem by having a second belt loop that is permanently sewn to the holster underneath the Velcro one so that you can select which to use. I don't have the means to test the tradeoffs.The provided lanyard is similar to what you get with Point-n-Shoot Cameras and similar consumer electronics. With the HP series, the lanyard is round and soft (vs on the G series where it is flat). The diameter of the provided attachment cord is 1/32-inch, but the rectangular slot can accommodate much larger (5/32s **xy** 3/16s wide by my measure).Rechargeable Batteries OK-------------------------I have used it not only with the provided Alkaline batteries, but NiMH LSD batteries (Eneloops, "precharged", ...). Simply confirming: I didn't expect this to be an issue with a Coast product.I asked Coast Customer Support why the product literature didn't mention rechargeables and got the response that although they did not anticipate problems and had successfully tested with a "handful" of NiMH rechargeables, they have not "properly tested" the full line. They correctly added the warning that "Light output and run time will vary depending on the batteries used." In searching the Web, I found claims that rechargeables could shorten the life of the flashlight itself, but this appears to be confusion with potential shorter _runtime_ from a set of rechargeable batteries.I like using rechargeables in this light to accommodate the relatively short runtime -- I am less likely to defer putting in a topped-off battery.Background: There are various formulations of white LEDs and the common ones require over 3V or 4V to operate (which is why cheap versions are designed with 3 batteries). Flashlights using one or two batteries require circuitry to boost the voltage to that level. Because rechargeable batteries provide an inherently lower voltage than disposables, this circuitry needs to accommodate a wider range of voltages from the battery. When you don't see rechargeables explicitly mentioned as acceptable in an LED product spec, you want to confirm.-- Douglas B. Moran

I love this flashlight and gladly overlook its deficiencies (below) because it so nicely goes in various of my pockets and yet provides brightness that I associated with much bulkier lights. When out-and-about, the Fingertip Speed Control Focusing feature changed how I use my light -- it makes zooming into a spotlight so fast and easy that I routinely do so to check out noises and movement, whereas the twist-to-zoom has a much higher threshold for doing so: It takes two hands, time and often taking light off the area of interest.The core deficiencies of this flashlight arise from it retaining the proportions of the much larger models in the HP series -- while this model may be much smaller, the fingers of its users aren't.Coverage/Range--------------Without context, the range given in the spec is of little use except for comparing models in the same series. This is an attempt to provide some practical metrics, but they are very much a YMMV -- my eyesight, ambient light, ...For a sense of illuminating the path in front of me, I used a section of street well away from street lights because it provides a known, consistent texture and easily estimated distances (10 ft wide lanes).In Flood mode, an oval 20 ft wide by 25 ft long. In the Low Power setting, the illumination is decent to only about 6-8 feet and suitable for walking on relatively smooth surfaces and similar.In Spot mode, the bulls-eye is less than 1 ft diameter, and the overall oval is about 6 ft wide.For judging the ability of the Spot mode to illuminate distant objects, I combined three tests: ability to show gross texture of a fence (such as larger knots in the boards), ability to show the type of construction of a garage door (slats, panels,...), ability to show details of sidings of houses (eg shingles, and type).40-50 feet on the Normal (high power) setting; 30 feet on Low Power.Grip----The body has conventional texturing of a small diamond pattern. The flat areas on opposing sides  is not cosmetic, but improves both the grip and comfort for me. The diameter of the barrel is too small for me to grip for long with my fingers simply wrapped around it. Instead, I pinch the light between my thumb and first two fingers with the butt near the base of my palm. This has the advantage pointing the flashlight with a more neutral wrist position. And because of the light weight of the light, I didn't find this grip to be tiring.HP5 vs HP6: The HP5 and HP6 are siblings with the same physical profile, except that the HP6 is longer to accommodate a second AA battery, which supports a brighter light, 170 vs 121 lumens (spec), and slightly longer runtime, 5 vs 4.5 hours (= 11%) (spec). This length difference does noticeably affect my grip. With my preferred grip (above), my third (ring) finger barely touches the butt of the HP5, but all 4 fingers engage the HP6. Although it feels like I don't have a good grip on the HP5, I have not had the slightest problem -- its lighter weight make the pinch grip more than adequate. For me, the choice is one of the easy "pocket-ability" of the HP5 vs the brighter light of the HP6.Switch------The protective ring around the switch is poorly designed. Inherited from the larger models, it has opposing gaps seemingly intended to make it easier for your finger to press down on the switch, especially in one-handed operation. However, when the overall design was scaled down, these gaps were not adjusted upward to accommodate fingers comfortably. They are too small for when I am holding the light with my thumb over the switch. They are barely adequate when using my forefinger, and even then I tend to arch the finger to press _down_ on the switch, rather than _across_ it. (I am a 5'10" male).Additionally, the gaps have the wrong alignment for me. I like to hold the light with my fingers on the flat section, and this has the high points of the ring under my finger or thumb. I have tried holding the light with the gaps aligned to the finger on the switch and found that the diminished grip on the barrel isn't worth the tradeoff.The scaled down protective ring also fails to adequately protect the switch from inadvertently being activated when being carried in a pack, suitcase, ... If pressing on a flat surface, the switch enters Momentary Mode somewhere between 14-16 oz (4-5 times it own weight).Focusing--------Focusing with one hand was easy and natural for me. I can push the head forward (for Spot) with my thumb. The "Fingertip Speed Focus Control" ring also allows one to pull the head backwards (to Flood) with my thumb and forefinger. However, the small gap in front of this ring reduces my ability to grasp it firmly enough to easily pull backwards. Usually I am able to uncomfortably pull back using the ring -- the problem grasping occurs at times such as when my hands are sweaty, but may also be a problem for people with weaker grips. In those circumstances, the hood is short enough that I can easily hook my forefinger over the front of it and pull it backwards. Recognize that going from Spot to Flood mode is something that you rarely _need_ to do quickly and easily -- unlike going from Flood to Spot. Consequently, I would classify this design issue as an inconvenience, rather than a problem.The manufacturer's claim of "Focus provides superior beam consistency from spot to flood, with no dark rings typically associated with focusing flashlights" is misleading. The flashlight _does_ provide great beam consistency in both spot and flood positions -- which are the ones that matter to me. However, in the intermediate positions, the center will be much darker than what you have in flood mode, and it will be surrounded by a bright ring. I don't see these intermediate positions as having any utility.The "Beam Lock System" did not work well (which it does on larger models in this series) -- it is strong enough to hold the position if the light is standing on its hood, but not good enough for normal bumps and pressures, for example, when it is in my pocket. Plus, there is no tactile feedback to tell when the lock is engaged. However, I regard this as insignificant because it is so trivial to reset the focus between Spot and Flood.Holster and Lanyard-------------------This flashlight is small and light enough that I just drop it in my pocket. There are relatively few circumstances where I would want to use a holster, and the provided holster makes that less likely. The holster is bulky because it is made of the same thick, heavy-weight, durable material as the holsters for the larger flashlights in this line (for which such materials are appropriate and welcome).The flap on the holster is fastened with Velcro. The belt loop is also fastened with Velcro, but with the addition of a snap. This snap is a useful addition in situations where the Velcro may be incremental loosened by the holster being jostled, for example by underbrush. Other holsters address this problem by having a second belt loop that is permanently sewn to the holster underneath the Velcro one so that you can select which to use. I don't have the means to test the tradeoffs.The provided lanyard is similar to what you get with Point-n-Shoot Cameras and similar consumer electronics. With the HP series, the lanyard is round and soft (vs on the G series where it is flat). The diameter of the provided attachment cord is 1/32-inch, but the rectangular slot can accommodate much larger (5/32 inch wide by my measure).Rechargeable Batteries OK-------------------------I have used it not only with the provided Alkaline batteries, but NiMH LSD batteries (Eneloops, "precharged", ...). Simply confirming: I didn't expect this to be an issue with a Coast product.I asked Coast Customer Support why the product literature didn't mention rechargeables and got the response that although they did not anticipate problems and had successfully tested with a "handful" of NiMH rechargeables, they have not "properly tested" the full line. They correctly added the warning that "Light output and run time will vary depending on the batteries used." In searching the Web, I found claims that rechargeables could shorten the life of the flashlight itself, but this appears to be confusion with potential shorter _runtime_ from a rechargeable battery.I like using rechargeables in this light to accommodate the relatively short runtime -- I am less likely to defer putting in a topped-off battery.Background: There are various formulations of white LEDs and the common ones require over 3V or 4V to operate (which is why cheap versions are designed with 3 batteries). Flashlights using one or two batteries require circuitry to boost the voltage to that level. Because rechargeable batteries provide an inherently lower voltage than disposables, this circuitry needs to accommodate a wider range of voltages from the battery. When you don't see rechargeables explicitly mentioned as acceptable in an LED product spec, you want to confirm.-- Douglas B. Moran

The only difference I could detect between this and the original is that the original was smooth and shiny and this has a slight texture resulting in a somewhat matte surface. This casing appears to be solid, both in thickness and quality of the plastic. I have been using mine for 6 months now without problem.My original remote casings fragmented from age -- the plastic wearing out -- inferred from both sets dying at roughly the same time even though one spend much of the time hanging on the wall.-- Douglas B. Moran

If you like to read military history, most of the book is fast-paced and well-written, with lots of interesting tidbits, and at one level, highly enjoyable. On the other hand, if you like to read military history, you will likely already know much or all of the episodes here (I expect that my knowledge is somewhat above average for the likely audience for this book). I found myself repeatedly disappointed by mediocre renderings of situations: They left out some key aspects and slid over others. Worried that I might be being too harsh, I compared several to the corresponding Wikipedia entry and found the Wikipedia sections did much better within similar limited space.The big disappointment of the book is that it doesn't get beyond the mantra of "Generals need to be relieved, but with potential of a second chance", and at various points the repetition of that mantra becomes tedious. The book not only fails to attempt to reconcile various perspectives on generalship and relief, but routinely fails to even recognize that it is advocating contradictory perspectives (details below). And many of the big issues of this period are not mentioned or dismissed in a few sentences.I term much of the book as "cataloging" because it provides synopses of the examples, but rarely ventures into providing true insight. In the case of multiple generals who were not fired, or were belatedly fired, I got little sense of why. And in the final example of a firing (Col Dowdy in Iraq), I got to the end of the tactical description and thought that the book's assessment would have been that the general (Mattis) had made a bad mistake, but the book went on to praise the general.I was highly disappointed in the treatment of the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq. I suspect that since the author had cataloged much of this in his previous books, he didn't want to repeat it here. However, the thinness of his mantra didn't give him enough of a base for a new perspective.This book's perspective on management and leadership is so simplistic, abbreviated and constrained that someone with real-world experience is likely to dismiss it outright. It is based on a false dichotomy between distant, hands-off management and "micromanagement". It ignores that training is rarely good-enough to fully prepare you for a job, and that there is a lot that can be done to get a new job-holder up-to-speed faster. The sink-or-swim approach wastes decades of training and experience where the person has deficiencies that are readily fixed or compensated for (eg by teaming). Sink-or-swim requires a ready pool of replacements, but the book argues that generalship is a rare commodity and documents that failing generals were not relieved (eg Mark Clark) because there wasn't a viable replacement available.The latter portion of the book undermines its own thesis by placing the root of the problem much earlier in the pipeline, with who becomes field officers and how they are trained. Disappointingly, this is but a brief recap of much discussed points, with no value-added. The book fails to consider that if/when the potential replacements are similarly unqualified or unprepared, firing is largely pointless. Or worse, if the current general happens to be the best of a sorry lot.In idealizing the "Marshall system", the book tends to minimize the situations where generals were not fired, and thus fails to seriously explore them. The highly dysfunctional situation in Italy was a prime example (eg Mark Clark decided to parade his army into Rome rather than try to cut off the retreat of the Germans). And for those generals that got a second chance, what had changed? Were they now better prepared, or given a better fit, or less demanding circumstances, or...? The book doesn't even attempt to answer this.To those who would argue that this book has an important message, the mediocrity and ineptness of recent Army generals has been widely covered, including the author's previous books. And the need to have better follows automatically from that. What is largely missing from this book are sophisticated whys and hows.Summary: This book was like a reception line full of old friends -- it felt good to shake their hands, but there was nothing meaningful exchanged.==== Appendix: Details on above opinions ====The "relief with second chance" does not seem to be uncommon among armies -- I recollect multiple instances of such for both the Germans and Soviets on the Eastern Front in WW2. The book doesn't give me a sense of whether the "Marshall system" was a different policy, or more emphasis on certain existing policies, or just a name used to distinguish those policies from the current situation in the US Army.----The rise of the officer as technocratic manager: Many histories date this to the 1960s under SecDef McNamara, but this book puts it in the 1950s. I would put this even earlier, with the heavy adoption of Operations Research during WW2. The most famous was Strategic Bombing under Gen Curtis LeMay, partly because of its association with McNamara. During the latter portions of the Korean War, command staffs were often able to accurately predict the resources needed in a battle. This became the subject of the M*A*S*H episode "The Grim Reaper" in which the doctors become angry with a staff officer whose job is predicting the casualties for offensives (he gets the number exactly right, but it includes him). This highly quantitative approach to conflict has been crucial to US military dominance (although not as much as superior training). In failing to acknowledge or appreciate this, the book presents this as simply a bad development rather than one that has tradeoffs and needs to be accommodated.---One of the big issues during this period was the military's attempts at dictating various aspects of foreign policy to the US government. For example, in the aftermath of Vietnam, the Army closed down its Counterinsurgency (COIN) training. The book simply notes that this would be missed in the Iraq occupation. However, the need for COIN hadn't gone away -- The Army was simply pulling a bureaucratic maneuver to try to avoid being assigned that task by arguing that it was incompetent to carry it out. Similar games are played with weapon systems. A common comment by outbound Secretaries of Defense has been their frustration with getting the military to prepare for the wars the country needs them to fight, instead of the wars the military wants to fight. Former SecDef Gates talked repeatedly of the need to reorient the Pentagon to "fight the wars we are in".Note: In one of the interviews promoting the book, the author made the point that the Pentagon focused on planning for future wars and neglected actually fighting wars. However, this is not in this book.Many historians and analysts believe that Gen Douglas MacArthur attempted to force the US into a full-scale war with China. This book presents too small a fraction of the evidence for the reader to understand that perspective. While the book mentions the deployment of UN forces near the Yalu that virtually guaranteed the success of the Chinese attack, it doesn't mention that MacArthur knew how provocative the troop movements were (they threatened to cut off electrical power for China from a large complex of dams) and that those movements violated very explicit direct orders from Washington. And the retreat from the Yalu has been called a "fabricated rout" -- troops were retreating so fast that they not only lost contact with the enemy, but could send out ground and air patrols for tens of miles and not see any sign of the enemy. Units were moved not to consolidate positions, but to positions that left other units vulnerable, justifying orders to those other units to retreat (and continuing the cycle). Commanders who made successful stands against the enemy were berated and ordered to retreat.The book mentions the problem that firing a high profile general can raise unpleasant questions about the conduct of the war and undermine public support. However, these mentions are very brief (a few sentences) and fail to give the reader even a jumping off point for thinking about this aspect.----The book is inconsistent in what it portrays as the proper relationship between the civilian authorities and the JCS. The book reports an episode where Pres Johnson literally cussed out the JCS after they presented him with two extreme options on Vietnam, neither of which was credible. The first was withdrawal. The second was to so expand the war into the North that it might well provoke China's entry into the war as well as provoking military confrontations with the USSR (in retaliation for sinking Soviet ships). The book presents this as intolerable abuse of the JCS, but if a similar interaction had occurred between generals, the book's perspective was that the superior would have been derelict to not have immediately fired such subordinates.----In a significant fraction of military failures, a key factor is the subordinate not understanding the intention of the commander (often the fault of the superior, but usually the subordinate gets the blame). For example, the Charge of the Light Brigade (1854). While the book's perspective on proper communications between generals is inconsistent, it seems to mostly favor a practice based on the occasional galloper carrying orders of a few sentences (low information, low interactivity). Eisenhower, following von Moltke the elder, said "Plans are useless, but planning is essential" but history indicates that too often the wisdom gained from the planning process doesn't get transmitted to those executing the plan.In the Battle of Chosin Reservoir (Korea), the book mildly criticize the HQ for not giving the heavily engaged units better info about the wider picture. But it also criticizes the practice in Vietnam of battalion commanders using the view from helicopters to coordinate their units. Note: the book's criticism of much higher level commanders also becoming involved seems reasonable. But then the book seemingly praises a general for walking into a front line position and talking to soldiers in their foxhole without even announcing his presence to the platoon commander.I would have expected the book to try to deal with the effects of technological change (beyond the helicopter as observation platform) on command relationships. I worked for a defense contractor, and the military's emphasis was on being able to operate "inside the enemy's decision cycle" (keep him off balance, staying several steps ahead,...) by having better information faster (acquire, analyze, distribute). (details: eg OODA loop: Observe, Orient, Decide, Act).[Added 2013-05-02]: In the 1990s, I worked on InfoTech projects for a defense contractor. One of the interesting comments about the Gulf War was that InfoTech had allowed the US to execute various maneuvers that would have been unthinkable a few years earlier (because of the high risk of friendly fire, congestion,...). This allowed the US to make more intensive use of the road network and to get troops to where they were needed on the battlefield, thereby enabling the US to have decisive advantages in firepower. This was a result of providing units with better situation awareness and of providing commanders with info so that they could more finely orchestrate -- not micromanage --- their units. The old model of command was rooted in the early and mid 1800s -- von Moltke the elder's theories and strategies inspired by Napoleonic practices. This was dictated by the technology of that time: communication was very slow, sensors were very limited, and the ability to create and update packages of information was slow and labor-intensive, most troop movements were slow (on foot). It severely limited not only the ability to coordinate combat units, but the ability to coordinate logistics for those units.----The book advocates that someone in command of a combat unit should have had combat experience at the next lower level. The term "combat unit" is ambiguous -- in some case it simply means a unit in the combat _arms_ (infantry, armor, artillery, ...) and in other cases it means a unit that is in combat, potentially including units not in the combat arms. However, from context, it seems this book means both, a combat-arms unit in actual combat.The book fails to recognize that this formula is what has led to the pattern of rapid rotation -- especially in Vietnam and also currently -- that the book decries ("ticket punching").
