I first used this tape to repair a big hardcover book, and it worked great!  The tape is wide (nearly 3 inches wide!) and thick (it's not at all thin like the dollar store junk).  We're moving soon, and this is going to be the tape we use for those boxes that need extra strong reinforcement!  Recommended!

What can I say?  This is a nice white shower curtain.  The only reason I gave it four instead of five stars is because the picture of the white lattice design isn't exactly correct.  The curtain is more sheer/see through than the picture shows.  It's not totally see through, but if you want one that is not at all see through, don't get this one.  For us though, it is fine.

I suppose the quickest way to review this recipe binder is to say we expected a lot more of it.It's basically a regular white binder with a recipe cover and a small handful of clear pages to go with it.  The (free) online Avery template isn't overly easy to use; my wife found out the hard way that you can't just cut and paste a recipe from a website on to the Avery template.  It takes some time and energy to get it done nicely.For the same amount of money (or less) you could get a regular white binder, print your own cover, and get some clear sheets to put your own recipes in.Again, all in all, it's not that great of an item.  We are underwhelmed.

My 9 year old son likes to read, and enjoys adventure books like those of Gary Paulsen, Jean George, C.S. Lewis, Jim Kjelgaard, and so on.  I knew he would like this one, and sure enough, he did!  Here's what he said about it:1) He wanted me to give it 5 out of 5 stars.2) He liked the part that takes place in the sewer (no spoilers here though!).3) He did not have a least favorite part.4) He wants to read more of this author.5) He thinks his friends would like this book too.In summary, it's a hit!

This is a very versatile storage unit!  You can use it as a trunk organizer, cooler, camping buddy, or picnic buddy.  It is solid and well made; both my wife and I were impressed how tough it feels.  You can fold it and tuck it behind a seat easily, or fold in the sides and use it as a cooler, or extend it out and even put things in the small mesh pockets.The reason I deducted one star is because the cooler section doesn't have much insulation.  It is basically a thin foam-type insulation with a special silver lining.  I realize a collapsible cooler can't do it all, but a bit more insulation would have been nice.Other than that, I do recommend this product if you need a versatile cooler/organizer for your car, van, SUV, or camper.

(UPDATE: Oct 5, 2015: this monitor is still working perfectly for me.  FYI)  I've had several average flat screen monitors before - in fact, this HP replaced a similar sized off-brand flat screen monitor that was a few years old.  I could instantly tell the difference in build quality and picture quality.  This HP monitor is absolutely outstanding.  I'm thoroughly impressed!PROS:1) It looks nice - trendy rather than clunky and old.2) It has a clear, sharp picture that can be viewed at various angles.3) It is highly customizable - the color, effects, rotation, saved setting for certain uses/programs, split screen, etc.4) It was easy to install - just use the disc provided, and a few minutes later it's finished.5) You can use it via HDMI (x2), or VGA.  (As a side, I'm going to see if I can use a Chromecast stick in the HDMI port; will report on that later.)CONS:1) The software works fine, but takes a little to figure it out (not much though--minor critique).2) It comes with a VGA cord but not an HDMI cord (minor critique again, but wanted to point it out).Though I mostly use this monitor as an extended screen for typing/research, a live MLB game looked great on it, as did pictures.  Again, I'm thoroughly impressed, and would recommend this monitor if anyone asked my opinion!

Warning: This review is rated Laundry PG-13.We "field tested" this on socks, handkerchiefs, and underwear so far.  I wore the socks for an afternoon, and surprisingly, they don't stink too bad; in fact, I can smell a faint trace of the Downy scent.  I really like using handkerchiefs washed with this Downy!  It's nice for allergy season - blowing my nose in fresh smelling hankies!  I didn't smell my underwear, and I won't (didn't want to give this a Laundry R rating!).In seriousness, my family noticed right away when using this fresh scent Downy.  It is nice wearing clothes that smell fresh - and stay smelling fresh - for more than a few minutes!

We were in the market for a new car seat, since our almost-4-year-old daughter out grew her old one.  And, in a word, this Diono Monterey car seat is exactly what we needed!  She really likes it too, and wanted to go sit in it even before we went on a ride.  She's all proud of the two cup holders (one for milk and one for snacks, she says!).  Here's a list of my pros/cons:Pros:1) It is a solid and sturdy seat - there's nothing flimsy or cheap about it.2) It will "grow" with the child - meaning you can also just use the bottom (booster) for older kids.3) It is somewhat adjustable - the headrest goes up/down and the sides go out/in and you can lean it back a little.4) Attached to anchor points in our Town and Country minivan, it really provides protection in case of accident.5) It is soft and comfortable.Cons:1) As a seat, it is quite heavy (the fine print says 20lbs).  If you're taking it in/out quite a bit, the weight may become annoying.2) The sides of the headrest do limit the child's sight - ours has to lean ahead to look sideways or slightly behind her.I realize this is a spendy car seat, but think of it this way: 1) It is well built and should provide protection for your child in an accident, and 2) your child should be able to use it for a few years (maybe more), so it's an investment of sorts.  And I'd say it's an investment worth making!

We have the "adult" version of this water bottle, which is probably too big for some kids.  So when we opened this one, our 3 year old girl immediately noticed it was like mom's, and quickly (and excitedly!) filled it up.  It does fit in her car seat cup holder, so we like that.  Also, the lids/bodies of this water bottle interchange with the bigger one just like it.This is a really good water bottle.  It is not cheap!  In fact, it has a life-time guarantee against defects.  It might cost a few dollars more than some other bottles, but I'd say it's worth it.  I'd for sure recommend this to others!(By the way, though it is advertised as a "kids" water bottle, since it is 17 ounces it wouldn't look funny for an adult to use it.)

I'm a DIY home owner, and for some time I've been thinking about getting a laser measure to replace my tape measure.  This "Dimension Master 130" is exactly what I was looking for!  It is small (about the size of a thick multi-tool), easy to carry around (it comes with a pouch and carrying lanyard), accurate, and has a two year warranty.  I've messed around with it a bit at home and in my office, and am impressed so far.I like the fact that you can simply measure the square feet of a room with just a few pushes of a button.  I also like the fact that the two AAA batteries are supposed to last for more than 3,000 measurements, and I am happy to see a battery level indicator on the screen (I won't have to worry about dead batteries when I'm out and about).  It didn't take too long to figure out how to use it - the instructions are pretty good.  My wife even tried it and figured it out quickly; I can see her using this when figuring out room arrangements and the amount of paint needed for a room.So far, I'm super happy with this laser measure!  I'm sure my friends will like it as well - I can already hear them asking to borrow it for their DIY work!

We've used this in a few laundry loads now, and are generally pleased with it.  It does smell great!  The only issue we have with it is that you have to use more than 1/4 cup (or so) in a regular load if you want a noticeable scent.  The first load we used about 1/8th cup, and couldn't smell much, so we upped it to 1/4 cup, and the smell was only slightly stronger.  My wife says she might prefer the cheaper brands since this one is quite expensive and since we don't have a young baby.

I’ve often found that Christian parenting books begin to sound the same after you read a handful of them.  I wouldn’t quite say, “If you’ve read one, you’ve read them all,” but there is significant overlap in quite a few Christian parenting books.Motivate Your Child by Scott Turansky and Joanne Miller is not exactly like other parenting books.  It is a Christian book written from a Christian perspective, but it is different in that it gives parents practical and biblical advice on getting children to do what they’re supposed to do without being told over and over (and over!).  That does sound impossible, I realize.  (I think I’ve told my three boys to brush their teeth around 10,000 times in their lives, and they still don’t quite get it!)  This book helps in that area.Motivate Your Child is divided into two main parts: 1) Moral development in children, and 2) Spiritual development in children.  Here’s a brief summary of each part:Part one discusses internal motivation and parenting strategies for motivation.  Strategies include right words, proper tone, and discipline/direction.  Part one also talks about conscience, choosing what is right, and dealing with mistakes kids make.  Furthermore, the authors mention compassion towards others, initiative, and consequences in part one.  I appreciated this part of the book because it didn’t just talk about external obedience, but it also discussed a child’s heart and how God’s word directs and shapes a heart.  The little section on goal setting for children was also helpful; we should teach our children about goals in life and attaining them.Part two is where the authors talk about spiritual development in children, including family devotions, the importance of Christian teaching in the home, and teaching kids to apply God’s word to their life (by the parents’ example and by parents’ teaching).  Basically, this part of the book gave some good advice on passing down the faith in such a way that kids are motivated to live it, not just hear it.  I was happy to see the authors mention the importance of the church in kids’ lives.  The authors were also wise to mention how spending time with kids, discussing real life issues and the faith, is good for our kids.  There was even some mention of what to expect as far as roadblocks in passing down the faith.While I don’t agree with everything in this book, there are many strengths.  I liked the emphasis on patience, love, forgiveness, and moral compass and direction.  The book encouraged me to keep working hard to be a better Christian parent.  It’s easy to get discouraged when parenting, and this book reminded me to stay focused and deliberate while parenting in our Christian home.  I suppose one weakness of the book is that there is a lot of info in these 250+ pages.  You’ll have to take notes or mark the book up well to remember all the good advice and biblical principles!  But it is for sure worth the read.

We put the Ipod touch away and let our four-year-old girl use this instead.  She was really excited, and for the most part she figured out how to navigate around this LeapPad2 quite easily.  She used her full hour of daily "screen time" yesterday and today playing on this LeapPad2 (her older brothers checked it out for awhile too).  Here is a summary of my thoughts on this:PROS:1) The screen is vibrant, responsive, and clear; overall, the LeapPad2 is well built and sturdy (note: an attached stylus is included).2) It is safe for kids to use: they can't go online, buy apps, mess with personal info, or find adult content at all.  LeapFrog is very kid friendly.3) The apps are (mostly) very well done and easy to use.  Our girl likes the camera, pet dog app, and drawing app.CONS:1) It goes through 4 AA batteries in 2-4 hours. I recommend rechargeable batteries or an AC adapter (which cost extra).2) While the apps are well done, most of them are expensive.  For example, we wanted to put kids music on the LeapPad2, but first we need to buy a $5 app to play mp3s on.  I noticed some single apps that were around $25-$30!3) It doesn't have a timer or password for parents to limit time/usage.  Would be nice to have these things for parents (like me!) who limit screen time each day.If the apps didn't cost so much, I would have given this product five stars; I don't mind paying for apps, but I don't want them to hurt the wallet so much!  If you're wondering, you have to connect the LeapPad2 to your computer, create a profile, then using the internet to get apps and such from the LeapPad website, which in turn will be automatically transferred to your LeapPad when you connect it to your computer.In a word, we really do like and recommend the LeapPad2 - it is a good thing for ages 3-9.  You may want to research the app situation (purchasing/downloading) before buying if you're not familiar with LeapPad's methods.  Either way, we're glad we got this; I don't think we'll give the IPod back to our girl now that she has this.  Thankfully, her screen time now will be at least somewhat educational!  Thanks, LeapPad!Feel free to ask questions if you have them.

Not much to say except for "as advertised!"  These make nice baggies for snacks like granola, cookies, or popcorn.  Even younger kids can open them, so we appreciate that.  The reason I took one star away is because they do seem thin, but not terribly so.  Finally, don't forget: these are NOT freezer bags.

I'm totally happy with this lamp/light!  Actually, I have to admit I'm even surprised it is as nice as this!  I was expecting something a bit more cheaply built, flimsier, and a bit more disposable (i.e. it breaks, you throw it away).  But it is solid, built well, large (around 10 inches tall), and useful.  It's a keeper!PROS:1) It has a 5 year warranty.  Five years!2) The LED is supposed to last a life time.3) The carabiner/hanger actually works well.4) It's great for outdoors - hang it on a branch or set it on a table, let it glow, and don't worry about a little moisture.5) You can dim it (three clicks) and the push button switch is easy to use (my 3 year old can use it easily).6) The LED is bright but not blinding, and doesn't drain the batteries very quickly.CONS:1) The base is wide, and it stands well, but there are no rubber grips, so it can slide on flat surfaces.2) I wish it would have an AC power source (that is, I wish I could plug it into the wall if I wanted to).3) It is too heavy to hang in most tents - the 4 "D" batteries aren't light!  (Actually, this is really more of a "note" than a "con.")The "cons" I've listed are minor to me; I've been a camper/hiker for some years now, and I can tell right off that I'll use this lamp a lot this summer out in the woods.  (NOTE: I'll update the review if it turns out not to work well through the summer.)  Recommended!

Here's what my wife said about this brush (FYI, she has hair a little longer than her shoulders): 1) It's nice, has a comfortable handle, and brushes well.  2) It does help speed up drying, but not by so much.  3) It's nicer than other brushes she has, and she's glad she owns this one.  In summary, recommends it!

I was around 10 years old when Reagan finished his two terms as President.  I can still remember my parents and others saying how much they appreciated Reagan, and that they were sad to see him go.  Over the years I've learned a few things about Reagan by reading or listening to his speeches.  I haven't read much else, but am glad to be "schooled" by H. W. Brands in his new biography, "Reagan: The Life."  While I do appreciate Reagan, it didn't seem like Brands painted too rosy a picture of him; Brands was fair in my opinion.First of all, the book is well written.  There are quite a few details (names, locations, dates, etc.), but Brands writes in such a way that the details don't bog down the reading.  I haven't read anything by Brands before, but having read this one, I think I'll seek out more of his work!  Here and there the book slowed down a bit (in my opinion), but over all I enjoyed reading it very much.  It read more like a story than a textbook.  Note: it is BIG - my copy has 737 pages of the story, followed by around 50 pages of end notes.  It's not a weekend read, but it is worth working through.Secondly, the book basically follows Reagan's life. The first two chapters cover the first 22 years of Reagan's life (starting in Tampico, Illinois, Feb. 6, 1911).  The next section of the book (around 100 pages) talks about his years in California (1935-1962) where he worked in Hollywood, with the Screen Actors Guild, and for General Electric.  His time as governor of California and his political life up to 1980 is the topic of chapters 16 through 32.  Reagan's two terms as President take up pages 239-706.  The last short part of the book (p. 705-737) covers the rest of his life (to his death in 2004).The only disappointment I had with this book is that it spends very little time discussing Reagan's first years and his last years.  I realize it is a minor critique, but I was hoping to learn more about Reagan as a child and a young man.Aside from the minor critique, I wholeheartedly recommend this book!  It was engaging enough for me that I underlined in it, took some notes, and will no doubt refer to it again in the (near!) future.  Bravo to H. W. Brands for this work on one great American President.

Before this toaster, we had a very cheap one that we got about five years ago.  I'm glad we were able to upgrade to this B&D Rapid Toaster.  It looks nice, is easy to operate, and gets the job done quick!  It does have higher heat than an average toaster, so it takes a few pieces of toast to figure out the best setting (we like #4 or #5).  We also like the "stop" button, which makes the toaster shut off and the bread pop up.I also noticed it had a two year warranty; with that noted, I have to give this toaster five stars!
This is the first smart phone holder we've used in our van, and I have to say it is nice!  We put it on the center vent, and it holds just fine even after several hours of traveling.  Recommended!

I've had meal/protein bars before, so I sort of know what they taste like.  I know that it's impossible for them to taste like a candy bar, so I'm not expecting perfect flavor.  Indeed, when I first opened this Vega One Chocolate Cherry bar, it smelled like a regular meal bar.  However, the taste was a little better than others I've had - my wife even thought it was pretty good.  This bar and a glass of water or milk is a good meal replacement for those trying to lose weight or maintain weight.  Recommended!

First of all, our 3 year old loves this comforter! She spreads it over the floor and loves to play on it.From a parent's perspective, it is nice, and is a decent size - it isn't small at all!  However, it's not overly warm (you'd need some layers under it in the winter), and it does feel a little cheap and thin (it is made in China), so we took a star off for that.Overall, this is an average comforter with a neat bright pink girl theme.

Our three-year-old girl was pretty excited when we put this cardboard castle up (it's easy to do with two adults - it comes with simple instructions).  She does like it and puts her dolls in there quite a bit.  Also, it looks neat and is reversible.That being said, it is pretty thin cardboard, and the castle is pretty flimsy even after we taped it a bit.  In fact, it's too flimsy for our girl to color on with crayons while it is standing up.  I'm not sure it's worth what it's selling for right now (just under $40).  Again, we like it just fine, but it's probably not going to last too long!

We weren't sure what to expect when we selected this knit bin, but we are pleasantly surprised!  It is made very well, looks very nice, and is not cheap in any way.  In case you were wondering, it isn't huge (check the measurements above) and it is soft and sort of flimsy (it doesn't hold its shape perfectly, but is plenty strong).Right now our little girl uses it to lug her stuffed animals around - it is perfect for her!  It would also work in the bathroom for towels or maybe even to hold a baby's toys.  Basically, if you need a strong and soft bin that's not huge but looks great, I totally recommend this one!

I try to be a positive Christian with a positive outlook on life.  Generally speaking, I look on the bright side and press on in the Christian life with hopefulness because Christ is on the throne.  But sometimes I fall into a rut of gloom, cynicism, and I think the cup is “half empty,” so to speak.  From time to time I can identify with Christians who are always gloomy, pessimistic, and critical.  The question is, how can we get out of the rut of gloom?  We should want to, since the Christian faith is not one of gloom, doom, and extreme cynicism!David Murray answers this question in his new book, The Happy Christian.  In ten chapters, Murray tackles gloom armed first with Scripture and secondly with some helpful scientific studies and insights about pessimism and optimism.  If I can make a generalization, Murray is basically calling God’s people to a Christian optimism, or a biblical optimism based on the truths of Scripture.  The book is just over 260 pages.The chapters go like this: To gain a more positive outlook on life 1) focus on facts more than feelings, 2) avoid so much bad news and focus on good news, 3) focus on the fact that Christ’s work of salvation is finished, 4) focus on the strengths of other Christians instead of their weaknesses, 5) focus on the blessed future we have in Christ rather than the past, 6) Find God’s common grace in the world instead of sin and evil, 7) Find things to praise people for instead of critique them, 8) give money and things away instead of hoarding, 9) View your work as a calling instead of a job, 10) be around people of different ethnicities instead of one ethnicity.Overall, I enjoyed the book and much of it made perfect sense.  I appreciated Murray’s call to focus on the facts rather than be led by feelings (I’ve learned that over the years!), and I appreciated his emphasis on the gospel (chapter 3), which leads us to joyful freedom and service instead of a constant negative guilt for sin.  I also appreciated Murray’s call to stay away from so much news/media, since the news tends to focus on the negative and then makes us negative (I agree; I quit following the news years ago and it has helped me be more optimistic).  Murray was also dead-on when he encouraged churches to aim for joy, grace, and a spotlight on the Good News.  His chapter on praising others was also a good reminder for me to work harder to encourage and bless people with my words.There were a few things in the book about which I was less enthusiastic.  First, Scripture citations are endnotes rather than written in the text or as footnotes (minor,  I know, but endnotes kill my reading optimism!).  Second, there was a ton of information covered in this book.  I was almost overwhelmed at times, since Murray did quite a few bullet point type lists/paragraphs.  For one example, in his discussion on the benefits of Christian hope (p. 95ff), Murray lists twelve benefits followed by eight ways to grow in hope.  The notes were good, but it was almost an information overload for me since there were many lists/paragraphs like this (e.g. ten parts of constructive criticism, ten ways of learning to praise others, nine ways to give biblically, eight ways to pursue diversity personally, ten ways for a church to pursue diversity, five truths about giving in leadership positions, etc.).  I realize all readers are different, so perhaps this is subjective, but those lists sort of bogged me down in the reading.One other question I had about the book is the chapter on diversity.  I fully agree with Murray’s emphasis on breaking racial barriers down, since Scripture calls us to love others and since Jesus died for people from every tribe, tongue, and nation.  However, I didn’t quite see exactly how diversity increases joy; does this mean that the less ethnic diversity there is in a person’s life, the less joy he or she has?  Many house churches in China can’t really be diverse; the same can be said about a church in a tribal jungle location or in some rural parts of other countries.  Also, if I have a handful of good Christian friends, can’t they increase my joy no matter what ethnicity they are?  Maybe I’m missing something; and I am honestly open to correction here!  And again, I agree that Scripture does call us away from racism and it calls us to love others based on the gospel and God’s love for all sorts of people.In summary, I’m glad I read this book, The Happy Christian.  The church for sure does need more emphasis on the true, the beautiful, and the good since she usually talks too much about what is wrong with the world.  I’m going to incorporate some parts of this book into my own actions, conversation, and Christian teaching.  It’s always a good thing for me to be pointed in the right way of Christian optimism, since Jesus does reign!  God treats us, his people, like sons and daughters, therefore “lift your drooping hands and strengthen your weak knees (Heb. 12:7, 12)!”NOTE: I received this book from the BookLook program, and am not required to write a positive review.

If you want to draw or sketch well on your touch screen (tablet or phone), this is a good stylus to get.  It's a bit bigger that its little brother, the Adonit Jot Pro Mini.  Actually, with the cap screwed on the back, it is the same size as a regular pen.  It feels solid, looks nice, and draws/sketches well.As others have noted, the disc will fall off or break if it is dropped or handled roughly.  Also, it does roll, so don't let it roll off your table!  I don't recommend using this as a regular stylus; if you use it like you'd use an expensive drawing pencil, it should do well.  Also worth noting is the one year warranty.  This stylus isn't perfect, but it is very good!*FYI - I use it primarily on a Samsung Galaxy Tablet 7 inch with the "Autodesk Sketch" app.  But it will work with any touch screen on any good app.

Elizabeth George, a writer I admittedly never heard of a few years ago, is rapidly becoming one of my favorites of her genre. Comparisons have been made to others--PD James, in particular--and they are close to the mark. "Missing Joseph" is another feather in Ms. George's cap. Few writers capture the psychology, not just of the characters involved, but of the places they inhabit and create--the geography. Without recapping the plot (see other reviewers for that), suffice to say this talent for creating a landscape as secretive and hostile, as cold and muddy and icy as the crime itself is well-presented here.So why only four stars and not five?First of all, keep one thing in mind, I now hold Ms. George to a higher standard than other mystery writers. Giving her four stars is like giving five stars to less gifted writers. That being said, I found the going a little slower than the other novels by Ms. George that I have read. The ongoing struggles between Lynley and Helen, while always intriguing, bogged the story down as much as the muddy roads did. I found myself getting impatient a few times. At one point, I said to myself, "Alright, already, I get it. I get it. Can we move it along, please?" Okay, that was my only negative mark against the book. "Missing Joseph" has a beginning that will grab you and a conclusion that satisfies. I just wished that the middle didn't get so cluttered. I still recommend this book, along with the others in this series!
David Baldacci is rapidly becoming my favorite suspense/thriller writer. True Blue is a perfect example why.

Elizabeth George's "Payment in Blood" is a suspenseful, keeps-you-guessing mystery in the tradition of the "country-house murder mysteries". For almost half the book, the reader is cloistered, as are the suspects, in a fledgling country hotel where a horrific murder has been committed. Lynley, Havers and the local police interrogate and inspect as objectively as possible. I would like to stress the "as possible" part. There are a lot of preconceptions and prejudices that seem to hamper the investigation--or, at least, derail it for a while. The other problem the police have is that the majority of suspects are theater people who know how to act, especially act innocent.Ego conflicts, jealousies, insecurities abound to confuse things even more. All this adds up to a nicely-paced whodunit with a very satisfying solution! Ms. George is rapidly becoming one of my favorite mystery writers.

Daniel Silva's "The Unlikely Spy" is a classic WWII spy novel that is both purist and in the purest form. For me, it was a relief to read such a thriller in an atmosphere uncomplicated -- and oversimplified -- by technology and  high-powered weaponry. Silva has not only read his Follett and LeCarre but he has also read his history. His depiction of the cities and countrysides of England and Germany are remarkable, as are his descriptions of the historically-based characters.The main characters, Alfred Vicary, "Catherine Blake", et al, are given dimensions and a depth that one rarely finds in the typical novels in this genre. At the same time, I never felt overwhelmed by any of the background information about them, the main thrust of which was that neither Vicary nor Blake wanted to be in the positions they were in, and yet, they were extremely efficient and credible. The action and suspense is marvelous. This was Silva's first novel, and the promise of good things to come was fulfilled.

Love him or hate him, John Corey's acerbic wit and look at life is unique. At times, his comebacks made me wonder if he did improv comedy on the side; he's that quick. Maybe too quick to be believable. Whatever. I think the difference between DeMille's writing in "The Lion" and the earlier "The Lion's Game" is that there is a good deal of self-conscious writing here. You could almost sense DeMille's thinking, "Okay, people are expecting Corey's wise-cracks but I gotta satisfy the action-hungry reader." To be fair, he succeeded for the most part. I thought the initial sky-diving scene was thrilling. And his depiction of New York City immediately after 9-11 was on the mark.But there was something suddenly two-dimensional about Khalil. His single-mindedness detracted from any third dimension. Corey's my-way-or-the-highway obstinance wore on me. The fact that Kate was, for a good deal of the novel, out of the way, suggested to me that she didn't really belong in this sequel. In fact, she only seemed to be there to be fodder for hospital food jokes.I don't want to be too harsh. The book is fine; it's okay. I just expected so much more after "The Lion's Game". This was a stalemate.

Admittedly, I struggled through the first 100 or so pages of Elizabeth George's "A Traitor to Memory". However, there was enough going on to hold my attention. I am glad I held on because the complexities of the novel and the psychological intrigues were gripping. (Ms. George is to be admired for her uncanny insights into the male psyche--warts and all.) Lynley, Havers and friends are in frustration mode as they attempt to solve a hit-and-run (which  become a few hit-and-runs). Like a snowball going downhill, this book grows on you as it moves more and more swiftly. By the end, I was grateful I was able to hang on.So why not five stars? While Gideon's journal entries were gut-wrenching and poignant, I felt they came at inopportune times, often slowing the narrative pace a little too soon for a little too long. Also, the crime that takes place at the very beginning--and then is not mentioned for pages later--made me think it was much more significant than it actually was. This was a huge disappointment.Still, if you are a fan of psychological dramas and murder mysteries, this book has everything to recommend it.

John Corey, the protagonist of DeMille's "Plum Island," has a new job with the Anti-Terrorism Task Force. Struggling with the bureaucracy of the feds is just as daunting to John as is the elusive terrorist, Kalil. From the opening sequence of a mysterious jet landing to the final face-off in California, "The Lion's Game" is filled with action, cat-and-mouse pursuits, brutal revenge, and Corey's self-conscious acerbic wit. Because of DeMille's swift writing, this hefty book reads quickly, so when you purchase it, be sure to purchase another to back yourself!

Lawrence Block is most effective when he reaches into the dark realm of possibility and makes it probable. "A Dance at the Slaughterhouse" is embracing and terrifying because it is so plausible. Snuff murders and murderous husbands propel Scudder into a two-pronged investigation. While Block depicts a New York of not so long ago, the crimes are still happening today. As always, the secondary characters--TJ, Chance, the boxers--are as well-conceived as the main characters.

This is the third novel I have read by Nelson DeMille and I am hooked--I am late to the party again.Growing up just a couple of hours away from Plum Island, I had heard all the stories and rumors about the place--none of them were good. I had also grown up hearing about Captain Kidd's supposed nearby buried treasure. Taking these two pieces of local folklore, DeMille has crafted another tour de force filled with mystery and suspense.In John Corey, DeMille has also found a perfect voice and vehicle. He is a wise-cracker and a smooth-talker, depending on the circumstances. He has a quick sense of humor. On one level, he is the typical, jaded New York cop but he is self-conscious about it. He often challenges himself to get away from that sort of thinking but not from the instincts that come with it. What I find about DeMille is that while he spins an intricate and grabbing tale, he sprinkles it with insightful and, occasionally, devestating looks at  love, pop culture, politics and life itself.Where do I get my official Nelson DeMille Fan Club card?

This is the first novel I have read by David Baldacci and I am definitely going to read more. "Stone Cold" has a little for everybody and a lot for anyone who is a fan of this genre. Mobsters, spooks, secret societies within secret societies, black-clad assassins, a serial killer on a mission and, of course, The Hero and his moll (in this case). I had a lot of fun with this book. My only reason for not giving this a five-star rating was that the main characters are so well-developed that it is at the expense of the secondary characters. One of these characters (I won't mention who) is killed in the process of doing good. However, there was not much given to him, in terms of character development, that I didn't feel like much was taken away. I had the feeling that he was only killed off to (a) show how bad the bad guys were and (b) to show that Oliver Stone isn't so stone cold. Does that mean you should not buy the book? Of course not! There's so much else going for this book that any reader will enjoy it.

I had no expectations going into Keith Greenberg's "December 8, 1980: The Day John Lennon Died" except that it would be about December 8, 1980: the day John Lennon died. Parts of it were. The rest of it was a kind of Reader's Digest/Monarch Notes summary of the careers of The Beatles and Lennon/Ono, and the developing mental disorders of Mark David Cahpman. To be fair, it would be a morose task to focus primarily on the events of that day. Those of us who are old enough to remember it--and cared about it--have our own personal histories of that night. For many of us, we read about it for days, then years, afterward.The problem was, for me, that too many irrelevant doors were opened for too long, and the relevant ones closed too quickly. There were several accounts of the perceptions of what the guy-on-the-street was doing and thinking on that night. I understand that this was an attempt by Greenberg to give us people with whom we can identify. The problem was we didn't need it. Like I said, the people who remember that horrible night have their own private mental museums about where they were and how they felt when they heard the news.This isn't to say that I disliked the book or wouldn't recommend it. This is about as "Okay" a book as you can get. Don't go into it expecting to get too much out of it. It will satisfy but only just.

Coming away from Robert Ludlum’s “The Prometheus Deception” reminded me of my first day in high school gym class, when I was an overweight teenager. I was self-consciously struggling through every minute; I was amazed at what others could do; I was somewhat certain that some good might come out of it; and, in the end, I was exhausted and glad it was over. The first fifty pages or so went by at a good clip. The next hundred pages were filled with cool gadgets and weapons, vicious fights and a deception, and the death of somebody that the main character, Nick Bryson, knew well. The hundred pages after that were filled with wild technology, wild guns and bombs, incredible action and a betrayal, and the death of somebody that the main character, Nick Bryson, knew well. The next hundred pages were filled with computer razzle-dazzle, fantastic weaponry, double-dealings and explosive battles, and the death of somebody that the main character, Nick Bryson, knew well. Eventually the book ended with tremendous action, super-duper computers, lots of deaths, and a deception and—finally, the end of the subterfuge!Or is it? Ooooooooo!I can hear the question now: “What did you expect? This is a suspense/thriller, after all.” I know, I know. Ludlum follows a successful formula here: lots of action, lots of intrigue, some sexual tension, good vs. evil, etc., etc. I don’t mind that, at all. It’s just that this particular novel belted me one too many times over the head with the formula. How many close-calls, narrow escapes can you have before you say, “Oh come on! Seriously?” How many different double-crosses and triple-crosses by two, three, four different people can you have before you lose your patience or focus? Like another reviewer wondered, "Was there an editor here?" By the end of it, I was struggling to care about Bryson because (a) he became almost superhuman and (b) it’s hard to root for the good guys or bad guys when you—like Bryson—don’t know which side is which. I’m sure that’s the point: Bryson is struggling with that issue. However, that doesn’t mean the reader should, too.I can't wait for gym class to end.

I received the MEElectronics Sport Fi M6 Noise-Isolating In-Ear [enough adjectives?] Headphones as a Christmas present and I love them. I do an enormous amount of walking in a noisy city during my normal day. These headphones do a great job of blocking out the external noises you often hear in New York, from car horns to people asking, "Got any change?" I don't know how well they will hold up under severe physical workouts but for my purposes, I just want to thank my friend for the gift!

Just from DeMille's introductory comments, I knew I was in the hands of someone who not only mastered his subject but had also mastered his craft. It is a poignant essay in its own right. "Word of Honor" is a success on so many levels: as a courtroom drama, as a character study, as an examination of a marriage under a huge strain, as a look back at the sixties through the eighties, and as a moral exploration of combat, in general, and the Vietnam War, in particular.The narrative of "Word of Honor" has been explained and summarized in so many other reviews that I won't bother with that here. What is mandatory to acknowledge is DeMille's understanding of war and his ability to convey its effects and results. The reader becomes an unwitting sympathizer in Ben Tyson’s plight. Even before we learn why he did what he did, you understand him and, even when he appears to be pig-headed, you get the notion that there are reasons for all his stubbornness and actions.The peripheral characters surrounding him present the reader with articulation for what the reader may be thinking. Not only is this a brilliant hook to keep the reader interested, I believe it is also DeMille’s way of acknowledging that there are so many ways to interpret that which is barely understandable. The references to Kurosawa’s “Rashomon” are both expected and essential.I found myself both exhilarated and, at the same time, sobered by the end of the book. This was a novel that takes the wind out of you, like a punch to the gut.

By accident, I have lately been reading mystery novels in which the writers have used the distant past as part of the settings for their plots. Tess Gerritsen's "The Bone Garden" reached back to early 19th Century Boston. Lisa Scottoline's "The Vendetta Defense" used Mussolini-era Italy as a backdrop for most of that work. In "Killer Smile", Scottoline once again skips back through the decades, this time to the internment camps for Italians that existed contemporaneous with the Japanese camps during WWII. To me, this was the most successful of the three novels.Part of the reason for why I feel this was the most successful was that Mary DiNunzio has more at stake here and more closeness to the events than the protagonists of the "The Bone Garden" or even in Scottoline's "The Vendetta Defense". Her psychology rings true. She is still grieving, though to a lesser degree, for the loss of her husband. This makes her vulnerable to the plight of a young Italian man,  Amadeo Brandolino, who lost his beloved wife during his incarceration at an internment camp. This leads to his alleged suicide. Mary's grief ties in with Amadeo's to the point where she imagines she can hear his cries and pleas. This was as convincing as it was heartbreaking and haunting.Another element that helped the novel was the depiction of the elderly and their own ties to the past. The residents of Montana who had interracted with the Italian detainees have their own stories and secrets. All this created a melancholy texture to a mystery that was, in its own right, credible and engaging.

For me, the SanDisk Cruzer 16 GB, etc., does what I need it to do--simply store my Word and Excel documents which it does quite nicely. My wife needs storage space for her photography work. This same flash drive handles that very capably as well. The speed is fine. The cost is more than reasonable, so what more can I ask?

The intriguing thing about histories written long ago is learning about the times of the historians who wrote them. Joel Headley's "The Great Riots of New York: 1712-1873", published in 1873, tells us as much about the author's world as it does about the times he is examining. Whereas the descriptions of the "Negro Riots", the "Doctors' Riot", the "Astor Place Riot", the "Draft Riots," and so on, are interesting in their own right, it was Headley's writing and attitudes that grabbed me more. They were so revealing.Headley and his circle believed they lived in an enlightened time but his depictions of class and race are hardly enlightened. Certain equations are repeated:* Irish--drunk, brawling, dull laborers* Germans--peaceful, industrious, keeping to themselves* Black--innocent (meaning uneducated), industrious, victimized but potentially dangerous* Upper and middle class--philanthropic and sensible* Poor--let's no even go thereThis being said, however, Headley's attitude about crowd control and the police are remarkably progressive. He believed that the club was more effective and less destructive than the gun, and that gunfire not only killed the rioters but also provoked further rioting. He believed more in trained, disciplined "riot squads" who would know how to specifically handle disorder than the existing (at the time) last-minute gathering up of untrained volunteers.Headley's writing style is also typical of the period. It is loaded with journalistic grittiness but interwoven with some flighty poeticism. (How he loved to describe bayonets "gleaming in the moonlight" or "shimmering in the sun".) In this regard, Headley's "The Great Riots of New York" is a fascinating document.For further study on the specific riots, I would recommend:For the "Negro Riots", Jill Lapore's New York Burning: Liberty, Slavery, and Conspiracy in Eighteenth-Century ManhattanFor the "Astor Place Riots", Nigel Cliff's The Shakespeare Riots: Revenge, Drama, and Death in Nineteenth-Century AmericaFor the Draft Riots, Barnet Schecter's The Devil's Own Work: The Civil War Draft Riots and the Fight to Reconstruct America

Toward the end of Edward Rutherfurd’s “New York”, Charlie Master muses, “Novelists liked to imagine the interconnectedness of things—as though all the people in the big city were part of some great organism, their lives intertwined.” With this sentence, Rutherfurd is describing exactly what he did in this epic novel which spans four centuries in the life of one of the most complex places (if not THE most complex place) on Earth, in which the generations of a half dozen families crisscross and sometimes collide.For me, the enjoyment of historical fiction is derived from the author’s ability to populate a historical place and time with fictitious but credible characters which enhance both. On that plane, Edward Rutherfurd’s “New York” works well. What also makes the book successful is Rutherfurd’s unobtrusive style which some other reviewers seemed to regard as uninteresting or just plain. My feeling is that if Rutherfurd had employed a more ornate, intrusive or crafted style, it would have added, unnecessarily, several more pages to an already enormous book and distracted the reader from the storytelling. I appreciated the fact that Rutherfurd stayed in the background and let the characters do most of the editorializing and provide most of the “color”. For me, “New York” worked best when it focused on specific events (The Draft Riots, The Blizzard of 1888, etc.) rather than when it tried to capture the general atmosphere and mood of a period. This is not to say those chapters were bad; they just weren’t as good!So why not five stars? Perhaps the attempt to capture four centuries of New York history would prove a little unwieldy for any author. At times, the exposition of events was awkward, just a little forced. When the chapters skipped a few decades here and there, one character was obligated to fill in the blank. I don’t believe that any other writer would have succeeded in performing such a task smoothly, it’s just that some background information came across as historical footnotes disguised as dialogue or interior monologue.That being said, I would strongly recommend Rutherfurd’s “New York” to any reader who appreciates American history, New York City and well-crafted historical fiction. This is among the best to have emerged in a very long time.

This is it! For years, I have been using other brands of cat litter, some of which were okay, others not so good. The other week, I switched to Scoop Away Multi-Cat and I have no need to experiment any longer. The scent is not overpowering but at least I can scratch litter box "deodorizers" off my shopping list now. More important, the urine clumps cleanly (there is no crumbling) and the feces are neutralized. I admit there is some dust but that is not unique to this product. Anyway, the trade-off for keeping my small apartment odor-free and for the better clumping is well worth it.

It is refreshing to see an author take a break from an established and successful routine and see him or her branch out. Tess Gerritsen’s “The Bone Garden” is a fine example. She must have welcomed the chance to put aside Rizzoli and Isles (although my copy of the book had the misleading graphic that this was part of the series) for another day. Still, it must have been difficult; writing a stand alone novel must be a daunting taskThe really hard work, however, is left to the reader who is used to her Rizzoli/Isles formula. Admittedly, this was tough for me; I kept making the inevitable comparisons. After getting a few dozen pages into the book, however, I began to enjoy “The Bone Garden” on its own terms. I didn’t expect the back-and-forth between eras. Considering I had read this hot on the heels of Lisa Scottoline’s “The Vendetta Defense”, which does the same thing, I didn’t find the structure to be too distracting. I enjoyed it as much here.The historical aspect of the novel (in a way the book is a tribute to Oliver Wendall Holmes Senior and the pioneering doctors of the time) was a welcome surprise. Early 19th Century Norris Marshall and Rose Connolly are intriguing and credible characters, and far more interesting than the somewhat drippy Julia Hamill and the stereotypical crusty loner, Henry of the present. To be frank, the present day element of the novel was weak, almost to the point where I wished the novel had taken place entirely in 1830. This cost the book one star. Still, it made for a great diversion.

While I am a big fan of the standard murder mystery, where the sleuth is a detective, cop, lawyer or private eye, I also enjoy the adventures of the amateur sleuths. Carolyn Hart’s “Death Walks the Plank” is an excellent example of the genre. This is my first foray into the “Death on Demand” series so I got a lot of catching up to do. And although I’ve started here, Ms. Hart has an efficient way of letting you know who the characters are and what makes them tick.The Darlings are an extremely congenial couple who embark on a cruise that mixes pleasure and business. The relaxed atmosphere doesn’t last long. Ms. Hart smoothly but with suspense leads the reader along the path to solving the crime. The Darlings have their hands full with this one and Henny and Lauren don’t make things any easier.All told, “Death Walks the Plank” is fine light reading and an entertaining mystery without the jaded, gloom-and-doom despondency that seems to haunt the hardboiled detective. The Darlings live up to their name. Now, I have to pick up the books that came before this one!

In Lisa Scottoline's "The Vendetta Defense", Judy Carrier went and did it: she took on a case that she had no business (as in it was not part of Rosato & Associates' legal business) taking. Judy agreed to defend a man accused of murder who admits to killing--not murdering--his lifelong nemesis, in fulfillment of a vendetta. Pigeon Tony freely confesses to the crime but sees no crime in it. There are mitigating circumstances which go back to Mussolini-era Italy and reach out to a crime committed just a year before the action of the novel takes place. (Ms. Scottoline is to be applauded for vividly bringing to life this tense period.) However, none of this will matter in court if Pigeon Tony testifies, which is what he wants to do. He fails to see why he should be punished for administering a justice he so clearly sees. This is not a murder mystery so much as a "How do you defend the murderer?" legal thriller.All this creates an extremely tense, frustrating and frightening case for Judy. The threats are everywhere from the aggrieved family of victim Angelo Coluzzi and its heavy-weight goon, Jimmy Bello.The writing is fairly swift, occasionally getting bogged down with a little too much exposition into the intricacies of pigeon raising and racing. The juxtaposition of the romances--one in the 1940s and the one Judy finds herself in--is well balanced and works.Some elements didn't work so well. I found the depiction of Italians and Italian-Americans to be a bit over-the-top. (I almost expected Chico Marx and Mr. Bacciagalupe to appear.) It was far from offensive, however, because (a) some of the stereotypes are quite true (I can attest to this as an Italian-American), and (b) these characters are generally presented in a good-natured way. My last nitpick has to do with the ending of the legal component of the case which I will not give away here.Still, this is a four-star review which means I sincerely recommend the book for the many things that Ms. Scottoline achieves here.

Michael Connelly's "The Narrows" (the sequel to "The Poet") is a unique mystery that moves from 'whodunnit?' to 'what will he do next?' to 'how do we catch him?'. Appropriately enough, the settings switch along with the plot thrusts: from city to exurb, from a boat in the sea to the 'Titanic' in the middle of the desert. The culmination of all this being 'the narrows': a roaring river, of sorts, in the heart of the city. Complementing this is the shift in narration which others have described and which I think works well.Connelly gives more or else equal time to his two seekers of the truth: old reliable Harry Bosch and FBI agent Rachel Walling (who, I think, deserves her own series of novels). Both Bosch and Walling are professionals who are dedicated to obtaining justice for victims and to protecting society. In this case, however, both investigators have a personal stake in catching 'The Poet'. Walling was mentored by 'The Poet' early in her career and has always regretted her failure to capture him in that novel. Bosch's motivation is to get justice for the murder of his friend, Terry McCaleb (the protagonist of Connelly's "Blood Work").As she sparred with Jack McEvoy, in "The Poet" so does Walling initially resist Bosch's help. Of course, the two establish a common goal and work well together. While this may seem formulaic, it is positively credible here. And it was at this point, when the two work as a unit, that the novel became irresistible. I couldn't put it down. The wild crescendo will satisfy any reader of suspense/mystery fiction.As is the case with the rest of the Bosch series, Connelly relies on the same major character in "The Narrows": Los Angeles. His disappointment in the city for its vanity and cruelty is balanced by his incredible love for it.

Over the years, Carole Rich's "Writing and Reporting News" has been the standard for my News Writing class. It has gone through several editions and updates, and with each succeeding update it stays relevant and well-presented. What has always impressed me was the text's way of being basic without talking down to students, while being insightful and complex without losing the student. This is a remarkable balancing act. I have had several students comment that they will keep this book to assist them with their general writing skills, especially when it comes to organizing ideas and paragraphs. That is how encompassing this book.

About a quarter of the way through Michael Connelly's dark, yet brilliant "The Poet", protagonist Jack McEvoy arrives at the following conclusion regarding the death of his twin brother:"...the picture of my brother kept coming back to me. Now that sterile, lifeless photo bothered me. For I had believed the impossible. I had let [my brother] down and now felt a keener sense of guilt. It was my brother in that car, my twin. It was me." These simple, economic sentences alone convey everything the reader wants to know about McEvoy--his deep sense of guilt and frustration. But they also prepare the reader for what will follow: these feelings will drive him to pursue the truth, and his dogged determination will lead him through terrors he could not imagine. It is this attention to character that lends so much credibility to Connelly's work, that makes his novels so absorbing.Of course, plot is just as essential to the success of any good novel. The plot more than twists in "The Poet". It does pirouettes and handstands without falling down or looking awkward. Yet Connelley keeps a firm grip on our hands as he leads us down the dark and twisted roads of criminal pedophilia and serial murder. The murderer, in this case, is hunting down cops obsessed with unsolved cases. (But there are plenty of other reviewers who will tell you the basics about the story.) The labyrinthine world of FBI behavioral analysis is convincingly portrayed (as well as the love interest that emerges from it).While I am a big fan of the Harry Bosch series, Jack McEvoy was just as engaging as a narrator. Perhaps this has much to do with Connelly's own history as a crime-beat journalist. Whatever. "The Poet" is as good a mystery novel that has been written in the last 20 or so years than any other.

I don't own a home; I rent a small urban apartment. I am not a gifted mechanic; I am a klutz. Still, I figured I would need a set of tools--beside a hammer--to do minor things around the place. This Black & Decker set is easy to use and has about all the functions you would ever need or want. More important for me, this comprehensive set folds up neatly and is easily stored. Considering I have two closets the size of egg cartons, that is important. I have owned this set for almost two years now, and, so far, it has been both a convenience and necessity.

One of the advantages of being a hoarder is that you don't lose things like NES' Genghis Khan. During my bachelor days, I conquered Mongolia and the then-known world. (While anachronisms abound, I ignored them. This is a game, after all, not a history course.) While the preparations for attack and defense were standard enough, I enjoyed the responsibilities that came with being a ruler: trade, morale, seasonal demands for builders and farmers, etc.  This game was way ahead of its time, as later games would adopt some of these same principles. Now, 20+ years later, I still have this game and my original Ninetendo box, and I still enjoy taking on the Holy Roman Empire.I imagine the younger generation will be off-put by the graphics--or lack thereof. No guts, no blood, not even moving images of sword-swinging soldiers. Well, times have changed. What hasn't, however, is the strategic nature of the game that I think will still grab their attention, if they are willing to give it a try. Meanwhile, I will continue to dust off the old video games in my attic.

When the head of the department announces that a new textbook will be used for the freshman writing course, I normally gnash my teeth, break out in hives and make a great moaning. "Oh, no, I was just getting used to teaching from the other one," I groan. Sometimes my despair is justified because the new book just doesn't work for me. Most of the time my grief is unwarranted because the new book is pretty much the same as the old. It's a pleasant shock when the new textbook is actually an improvement. Professors Eschholz and Rosa's "Models for Writers: Short Essays for Composition", in terms of content, style and practicality, has won me and my students over.The first thing that struck me was the size of the book. In spite of its 700+ pages, it is quite portable, unlike some other writers' guides that are about the size of a car battery and just as heavy. My students appreciated this, as well. Of course, it's the insides--the guts--that count. I like the arrangement of topics and most of the samples. (While all of us who teach English composition have our own fantasy textbook in our heads, in which we compile what we consider to be the best essays, we have to make do with what we are offered. *Sigh*) I will agree with one reviewer, however, that there are too many excerpts and not enough full-length essays. As far as the short shrift that is paid to MLA style, I can live with that since it is not part of our curriculum. In terms of what my students do need, I found the section on Process Analysis to be especially helpful.And speaking of students, I would be lying through my formerly gnashed teeth to say that they have embraced this textbook. What I can say is that they recognize that the writing neither talks down to them nor is too obtuse to follow. More than a few of them said that (heart be still) they went ahead and read other sections on their own and "really liked" them. This is high praise, indeed.

About two years ago, my cat, Bart, had fleas for the first time in his life. After giving him a flea bath, the vet recommended the Bayer Advantage II and told me to stay away from the less expensive brands. Did I listen? Nope. Poor old Bart had fleas again within two months. After another flea bath, I bought the Advantage II. Lo and behold, it worked. It was easy to apply and Bart hardly struggled throughout the quick process. My only disappointment was that the six-month control it advertises lasted only about four and a half months. Tell you what, I didn't quibble or complain. If I have to use the Advantage II only three times a year to keep my wonderful cat happy and healthy, the cost is a non-issue.

I had neither heard of Daniel Silva nor this book, for that matter. When I started reading it, on the recommendation of other readers, I was taken in. At first I was a little overwhelmed by the number of characters that were thrown at me in the first 30 pages or so. But Silva has a knack for constantly referring back, in brilliant ways, to keep you on track. Once the characters were established, I was in for the ride of my year. "The Rembrandt Affair" is a frenetic and yet, thoughtful, book that I will recommend to my friends, and, now, to other Amazon readers.I won't rehash the plot, and plenty of other reviewers have done a great job of giving you the gist of it. What made this the treasure I allude to in my title is Silva's portrayal of each character, their motivations, their quirks and their personal histories. Combine this with the mix of history, intrigue, action and mystery--each credibly rendered--and you have one of those rare books that is both an adrenaline rush and, dare I say it without sounding corny?, art.

In his engrossing "Honor Thy Father", Gay Talese proves that four decades ago, The Mafia was not what it used to be, which was basically a monopolistic almost exclusively Italian criminal empire. It is a strange nostalgia. Outside of a few loose canons (like Albert Anastasia), it was comprised of men who were dedicated to secrecy and, especially, order. The trauma that was Appalachia, and the exposures by the Kefauver Commission and Joe Valachi, permanently crippled The Mafia. It is at this point where Bill Bonanno grapples with his new-found and unasked-for position at the top of one of the major crime families of New York and the nation. When his father, Joseph, is kidnapped, the spotlight really falls on him and his family, and where Talese begins his narrative. Talese does a fascinating job juxtaposing the problems of the Bonanno family with the problems of The Bonanno Family. While Bill Bonanno tries to keep things together with lawyers, trusted "soldiers", contacts and his father's enemies, he is less successful with his ability to keep his wife and children secure and happy. The agonies and frustrations of Bill Bonanno's wife, Rosalie, is very poignant and credible. I felt sorry for her.And, it is at this level that the book really succeeds, even now as a history. This is not your typical "Mafia/True Crime" book. Although there are a half dozen murders and bombings described in the book, there are no detailed, graphic, for-the-thrill-of-it sequences of vendetta killings and murders. The violence is surprisingly low-key, except in one or two key passages. Talese was not in for the shock value. He was describing the frustrating, dangerous and, surprisingly often, tedious (in terms of constant waiting) existence of a mob boss during those years. The stress, the occasional frustrations, and rare moments of success are intriguingly written. There will always be debate about whether Talese's "New Journalism" is creating fiction out of history but there is no denying that the book rings true on many points. While one might wonder, "Did Bill Bonanno really remember what he was thinking twenty years ago?" when he told his story to Talese, there is little reason to think otherwise. The personal dynamic between Bill and Rosalie or the rest of the family members is given the same attention as that given to the criminal activity. This is what makes "Honor Thy Father" so unique in the genre.

I have the pleasure of teaching a college-level class called "Career Interest Review". For the students, it is a reminder of the tough time most of them will probably have in the job market out there. On the other hand, I try to convey the point that the struggle would be worth it if they obtain the career or, at least, the career path that they desire. While the required textbook, Making Career Decisions that Count: A Practical Guide (3rd Edition) is fair, I supplement it with Jonathan Milligan's "Career Manual." There are several reasons for this. While the other textbook discusses the personality/career dynamic in a superficial and more "workbook" manner, Milligan's approach is more detailed without becoming esoteric. It is uniquely written in a way that neither overwhelms readers nor talks down to them. I also use this book because it tempers objectivity and reality with potential and inspiration."Career Manual" also explores many of the other elements of identifying a career path and the work environment. Such topics as identifying the different and observable personality types and management techniques, the work environment in general and some of the potential lateral career moves were well-received by the students. The job satisfaction survey was not so well-received because they had seen similar evaluations before. This is forgivable since such surveys can only go so far. Still, Jonathan Milligan's "Career Manual", whether you are a student, newcomer to the working world, or a battle-scarred veteran, is a reasonably priced and valuable tool.

Almost dead-center in Michael Connelly's "The Closers", there is a line that goes something like "Redemption is the brass ring that everyone reaches for." And this is in keeping with Harry Bosch's thinking in the novels of this period. In the immediately preceding novels, "Angel's Flight" and "Lost Light", there was a great deal of discussion about Bosch's struggle to fight the good fight, and how there were too many gray areas involved that make the struggle even more difficult.In "The Closers", Bosch, now back on the LAPD after a brief retirement, finds himself partnered with his old friend, Kiz Rider, to investigate a case that is 17 years cold. ("Closers" being the police slang for detectives who close old cases.) As any reader of Connelly's fiction has come to expect, the path to the truth of the case is often twisted, contradictory and dangerous. (And Connelly, as usual, writes in a way that goes above and beyond what one would expect from the genre.) In this novel, Bosch and Rider have to jog the memories of witnesses and participants in the investigation, view incomplete files (if the files hadn't been 'lost' over the years) and make sense of evidence that point in different directions at times. This was no easy task. The perpetrators aside, Bosch's old nemesis, Irvin Irving, is still sniping from the sidelines, making the mission more difficult.But that's the issue!Bosch realizes, by the end of the novel, it is the mission itself, the journey toward the truth, that provides the redemption that he had obsessed over. Although Bosch remains loyal to his belief that everyone counts or no one counts, he is also discovering that the desire to seek the truth for those who cannot find it themselves, is just as important. That is the mission. That is the brass ring.

Labor Day is quickly approaching which means my summer of reading murder mysteries exclusively is coming to an end! I have gotten acquainted with a few writers I had always wanted to read, and Tess Gerritsen was one of them. Without realizing it, I had saved one of the best for last."The Sinner" was fundamentally different from several of the mystery novels I had read in one particular way: It focused on two investigators--Medical Examiner Maura Isles and Detective Jane Rizzoli--working on the same case but independently, for the most part, of each other. In most crime fiction, you have one investigator who either works with a partner (who is really a glorified side-kick) or works alone. "The Sinner" is structured around two women, each with their own personal agonies, investigating a murder and an assault in a chapel which may or may not be tied into the murder of a homeless woman in an abandoned building. Even when they are apart, Isles and Rizzoli work along parallel paths. The novel is its most interesting when those lines cross and the pair have to work together.I liked the fact that Gerritsen avoided the "buddy" approach to Maura and Jane. They do like and care about each other, but they are not close, dear friends. (Since most of the action takes place just before Christmas, and at a point where each woman is faced with a personal crisis, I shuddered with dread that the book would end with them slogging a mug of egg nog and singing carols together on Christmas Eve. Whew, they did not.) Gerritsen allows us to view the crimes from two perspectives: the distant forensics of Maura's medical science and Rizzoli's in-your-face interrogatory style. But even if their styles differ, their dedication to solving the crimes is exactly the same. They don't step on each other's toes but neither do they stand arm-in-arm as "buddies to the death". They respectfully work together and diligently work apart.I had to shave off one star, reluctantly but I think justifiably, for the resolution and denouement. Not that they were incredulous: they were very logical. However, they were just so rushed. In less than eight pages, the villain is revealed, the villain is pursued, the villain takes a hostage, and the villain is caught. Later on, in one page, the villain's motive is explained. I felt just a little cheated. Still, this did not take away from my overall enjoyment of the previous 300+ pages. This was an engaging mystery well-told, and a great study of two women who would and should become friends but not "buddies".

When I add up the cost of going to a car wash/gas station to get my little car cleaned and compare it to what I paid for this decent vacuum, I am way ahead wallet-wise. No, it's not powerful but I live in Brooklyn so I don't track in much sand, mud or leafy things. Once in a while, I may track in some city grime but the wet mode gets it up for the most part. Yes, if I track in something very greasy or vile, I need the car wash. Otherwise, this is just fine!

Andrew Vachss' "Two Trains Running" was just that: at times, it was a rollicking runaway express train, at others it was a slow moving but hugely powerful freight train. Vachss knew just when to slow down for some blistering social commentary and when to stoke the fire to get the plot moving again. Needless to say, I enjoyed the ride.In the novel, a seedier, smaller version of Las Vegas, called Locke City, is threatened to be pulled apart in 1959. The older regime (political, criminal... it's all the same) is run by "mountain man" Royal Beaumont and his long suffering sister, Cyn, who can never seem to complete a sentence without her brother interrupting her. For years Beaumont has run the vice, rackets and, basically, the town. But now The Mafia (recently exposed by the Kefauver Commission) is looking to expand into this midwest border town. Represented by the vicious lummox Sal Dioguardi, the Mafia has big plans for Beaumont's domain.What's a poor mountain man to do to protect his assets? Hire outside muscle. Enter Walter Dett, a calm, methodical, uber-sociopath who, in the course of committing a couple of murders, falls in love with a local waitress, Tussy. Another criminal enterprise, an all-Irish gang, run by Mickey Shalare, watches from the sidelines, seemingly neutral. Finally, there is Detective First Grade Sherman Layne trying to make sense of it all, and wondering how much of his own corrupt activity is affecting and being affected by recent events. Right there, you have the elements of a fiery, gripping novel. The climax of this volatile mix is complete and credible.So why did I shave off a star? To belabor my earlier metaphor, the train had one caboose too many. Street rumbles, Black activists, Nazi-wannabees, shady journalists, rogue G-men, meander in and out of the main narrative. Subplots are fine with me but when I invest in them, only to have them disappear, I get the feeling that the author didn't know how to wrap them up. I know that life can be like that, novels shouldn't be, at least, not so many characters and situations simply abandoned after they have caught your interest.In spite of all this, there is so much to redeem this novel. It truly is unique in many ways and, for the most part, a book that stays with you long after you've finished.

I have dedicated this summer to reading nothing but mystery novels, and I am loving it! Case in point:Harry Bosch, in Michael Connelly's "Lost Light", is now retired from the LAPD, and yet his search for the truth still compels him. In this case, the theft of $2 million dollars from a movie set and the trail of corpses before, during and after the violent robbery is the focus of Harry's investigative skills. In particular, the cold-blooded murder of Angella Benton, an employee of the movie studio, is haunting him and has been for years. As always, Connelly's writing moves well-beyond expertise and craftsmanship; it is an art. I have finally come to realize that there are few as good (and none better) at the genre than Michael Connelly.The mystery and action elements aside, "Lost Light" is a great read for other reasons. Fans of the Harry Bosch series may be jarred by the use, for the first time, of the first-person narrative. Although Harry's voice had been so close to the third-person narrator's voice (or is it vice-versa?) in previous installments, we get Harry's immediate responses--his spontaneous reactions--to comments and situations that were only reported in other novels, leaving us to decipher the feelings behind them. This new approach worked well here.Another intriguing element here, and I believe it has much to do with the title and its explication toward the end of the novel, is the exploration of the gray area, the clouded, unclear directions that life presents us. In Connelly's "Angel's Flight", Bosch realizes that angels can fly both ways: they can ascend to heaven or become fallen angels. It's one way or the other. In "Lost Light" Bosch realizes that things are not that simple. He muses that there is a Paradise Road in LA but also a Devil's Punch Bowl. "There is no sign leading to Paradise Road," Harry realizes. Paradise may have no roadsigns but the path to The Devil's Punch Bowl is just as tricky. While LA may be the City of Angels, Bosch is all too familiar with its evils. Yet, Las Vegas--one of America's largest "Sin Cities"--holds what may be the key to Bosch's paradise. The novel is filled with such dichotomies.Sad, to say, my summer of reading mystery novels exclusively is coming to an end. But I could think of no better novel than "Lost Light" to cap it off.

My students want to kill me: bottom line. After spending part of the summer semester complaining about how I have battled cigarettes for thirty years, what my students picked up on was the ONE time I griped about a cheap-O lighter that wasn't working. At the end-of-semester party, my students conferred this lighter upon me as a farewell gift. It was thoughtful. It is sleek and elegant, stylish and black. Perhaps my coffin will be like that once my lungs blacken.But that should not detract from the quality that goes along with the "Zippo" name, and this lighter in particular. All the romance (as in "history and associations", not lovey-dovey stuff) that is attached to it makes it a keeper. Of course, it works well. My only complaint was that the one and only time I dropped it on the sidewalk, a bit of the black coating chipped off. Maybe it was just bad luck--the way it landed. But I will of course continue to use the Zippo. And as for my students, maybe they'll visit me in the cardiopulmonary ward.

Having her car incinerated, her apartment firebombed, being shot at, lunged at with a knife... that's all child's play to Stephanie Plum when compared to the threat of an old Italian woman giving her the "malocchio" or evil eye. In the case of Janet Evanovich's "Four to Score" the curse may come in the form of bearing Joe Morelli's baby. As if she doesn't have enough trouble with fugitives, jealous boyfriends and/or girlfriends, a six and a half foot transvestite, rival bounty hunters, Mafia wives, and a killer with a penchant for removing fingers, Stephanie finds herself embroiled with the Morelli family--the old women in particular. Like Macbeth's three weird sisters, these old crones fall into trances, have visions, and make predictions. One of those visions have to do with Stephanie bearing Morelli's son. Horrors! (Well, at least they give her a lasagna casserole to munch on.)As always, Evanovich surrounds Stephanie with the usual ensemble cast: Lula, Connie, Grandma Mazur, Ranger, etc. But Joe Morelli gets the spotlight in this installment, and deservedly so. After all, Stephanie has to camp out in his place after her apartment is burned out. More important, their relationship takes a very carnal turn. Joe and Stephanie have a real stake in this now. When thoughts turn to kitchen curtains and cookie jars, both shudder at the potential of commitment.In the long run though, it is crime that glues everyone together. Who is passing around funny money? What did an angry young woman steal from her ex-boyfriend that is ticking him off and why is she leaving cryptic clues as to where the thing is? Who strangled a convenience store clerk and is scalping and chopping off women's fingers? Who is threatening Stephanie's life? Who might be placing Stephanie's hamster, Rex, in danger? All these questions (well, with the exception of the last one) keep the plot moving at a swift place. And Evanovich's ear for the right humor at the right time is pitch perfect here. "Four to Score" is another great installment in the Stephanie Plum series.

My small urban apartment has very little cross-ventilation. However, it is too small for an air conditioner which would turn my place into something between Arctic tundra and a morgue. The Lasko fan sits perfectly on my bookcase and, more important, keeps a nice breeze going. This compromise between a brutal New York August and Antarctica is not the only one. Being a klutz and as proficient with tools as a gerbil, this was simple to assemble. Right now, I am enjoying the breeze as I type. I also don't have to worry about my electric bill going through the roof because of an air conditioner and because the Lasko didn't set me back a whole bunch of money. I love this compromise.

Janet Evanovich's "Plum Lucky" is a bit of a departure from the Stephanie Plum series only in the sense that our heroine is taken out of her comfort zone for most of the novel. In this case, most of the action is focused on the casinos of Atlantic City and not the back streets Trenton (although it's still Jersey). The other comforts that are, for the most part, missing are Ranger and Joe Morelli who figure only marginally in "Plum Lucky". On the other hand, we spend a lot of time with the intriguing Diesel, who may or may not be from another world. That's okay: other characters are possibly losing their minds or are leprachauns or can speak to animals (a la Dr. Dolittle).
