Fortunately, Stephanie is grounded by the relative sanity of Lula and Connie. ("Relative" being the operative word.)But the glue holding "Plum Lucky" together is the cantankerous, curmudgeon Grandma Mazur. Even when she is not there--like when she is snoring fitfully in another room or stowed away in the trunk of a car--she's still there. I don't have a problem with her stealing the show from her granddaughter in this novel. How can you argue with an old woman who finds a million bucks in a duffel bag in an alleyway on St. Patrick's Day and believes it is the pot of gold at the end of a rainbow? And what better way to invest that money than by haunting the slot machines of Atlantic City? Stephanie Plum has a lot readers and devoted fans among mystery readers but so does Grandma Mazur. And, in "Plum Lucky" she hogs her moment in the spotlight!

Most of my home and kitchen product reviews center around the fact that I live in a small (2-1/2 rooms), urban (New York City) apartment which I share with a cat. Every square inch has to count, and common sense must dictate its usage. Since I am considerably lacking in "square-inchage" (and common sense), I found Heather Lane's "How to Organize Small Spaces" to be quite useful. Did I use every tip? No. Did I use even half? No. But I have to admit that many of them did apply, some better than others. For the first time in years, I have seen the back wall of my hall closet. One thing that I did on my own (and I was surprised that it isn't emphasized enough in Ms. Lane's book) was donate a lot of stuff to charities. My stockpile of murder mysteries was donated to a senior citizen's center. And several items of clothing which haven't fit me in years made their way to Salvation Army bin. What did remain, however, is now neatly arranged for the most part. I found the sections about clearing bedroom clutter to be the most useful.Now, if I can only clean up my cluttered writing style.

One of the main difficulties in teaching a mandatory course called Language, Thought and Critical Analysis is giving the students an opportunity to see its practicality. My job, of course, is to teach the material--deduction vs. induction, rhetoric, premise/conclusion,etc. Fortunately many students begin to see how these elements can influence their ways of thinking and their every day applications. What Professors Morrow and Weston in "A Workbook for Arguments: A Complete Course in Critical Thinking" have done is to provide teachers and students with exercises that are not only relevant to the course but relevant to their lives.The discussions about media and popular culture (although a bit dated) allow students to see how these elements have made an impact in the "real world", in "real life". Also, the book is written in a fairly easy to understand style which is another plus. The more accessible and less cerebral the style the better.  The solutions in the back are clearly explained which saves me a lot of work. Thank you professors Morrow and Weston.

The Evanovich/Hughes collaboration, "Full House" is, in a nutshell, one part "I Love Lucy", one part "Sex and the City" and one part "Criminal Minds". The parts aren't always as good as the whole, and vice-versa. Billie is a divorced, mother of two, who meets playboy millionaire, Nick. Right off the bat, the book becomes a kooky romantic comedy of the 1950s sitcom type, including a horse stepping on Billie's foot. Within hours, Billie is hoodwinked into "baby-sitting" the ditzy redhead, married-many-times sister of the playboy, DeeDee. (Her favorite expression is "EEYUEEWW!") Then the sexual tension between Nick and Billie kicks in, and the novel becomes a kind of "Sex and the City UltraLite". Before you know it, a series of home break-ins, arsons and explosions rock the neighborhood. These become amplified in the end when the bombings become more intense, and the book ends in an abduction, murder and attempted murder.There is just enough for everybody here and, at times, too much for anybody. Billie's spontaneous turn at striptease outdoes anything Lucy Ricardo might attempt, but in the end proved to be just one of too many distracting and unnecessary episodes. Some sloppy editing (Billie's son, Joel, inexplicably became Joey at one point) didn't help. And where the criminal element was supposed to intrigue me, I was growing impatient instead. I dunno. I'm no expert on light romances but I doubt that anything here will satisfy fans. Pass on this one.

In Lawrence Block's "A Drop of the Hard Stuff", Matthew Scudder recounts a tale from his early days of sobriety. While attending meetings, Matt encounters a childhood acquaitance, Jack, who is working his Eighth and Ninth Steps of sobriety, in which the recovering alcoholic must list the people he has hurt and make "amends". Well, Jack had not been a good boy and some of the people he had hurt may just be looking to hurt him back. One does, and another may have killed him because Jack dies sober--of a bullet in his head and mouth. The message is "shut up". From there, Matt (and the reader) is taken on a wild but sad ride. The outcome will surprise you."A Drop of the Hard Stuff" is interesting for another reason. By setting the novel somewhere in the very early 80s (there is a discussion about the "new twin blade razor" and a scary "gay cancer"), Block seems to relish the old fashioned detective work. At the very end, there is talk about how easy it is to Google things and get information off the internet. "A Drop of the Hard Stuff" takes us back to the day when walking the streets and pounding on doors for answers were the only ways to crack a case. There were no emails, AFIS, criminal databases... everything was dependent upon a cop's wit, energy and determination: things that Scudder has in ample supply. It is apparent that Scudder was comfortable in that world and, I suppose it's safe to say, so is Block. I think he misses that old school of mystery writing. I can't say I blame him.Like some of the other novels in the Scudder series, there is a lot of talk about alcoholism and recovery. In this novel, however, these elements are key to the plot, so they may not seem as distracting. It was also fun but sad to see some of the old characters--some dead since the early 80s--come back. Everything about this novel--the dialogue, the scenes of a lost New York, the booze worshippers and the Step Nazis--ring so very true. This one of Block's best in recent times.

As I mentioned in a previous review, one of the pleasures of my teaching job is that I am sometimes called upon to teach a class that is out of my "jurisdiction", and "Film and Literature" is one of them. The last two times I taught it, I used Dennis Lehane's Mystic River followed by Clint Eastwood's adaptation. This summer I thought I would change things up and use Lehane's "Shutter Island" with Martin Scorcese's adaptation. It turned out to be a great decision; the class ate them up.Many of my students remarked that they were chilled while reading the novel; one even compared it to reading a Stephen King novel. And this jibes with my impression (and the impressions of many reviewers here) that "Shutter Island", at its core, is a Gothic/horror novel. My students were equally engrossed with the film. Scorcese follows the novel up perfectly. He uses his classic techniques--the long tracking shot, the split second editing and choppy points of views--to make a truly tense and often horrifying nightmare come alive on film. Several episodes involving "migraines" are bleached white to enhance the photosensitivity of those headaches. These blanched scenes are often surrounded by shots of haunting darkness or blood red phantasms. The performances all around are on the money: DiCaprio, Rufalo, Kinglsey, etc. are all perfect. The result is a strangely sad film--there is that haunted melancholy that is so characteristic of Lehane's novels that translate so well into film--given the right director. Scorcese was the right director in this instance. This is a terrific film.

I have always been a big fan of the mystery genre. For years I have been reading Lawrence Block, Harlan Coben and Michael Connelley. However, I dedicated this summer to reading the mysteries of writers I had never read before: Janet Evanovich, Lisa Scottoline and Sandra Scoppettone. Now, I have added one more writer (who also happens to be a woman), Barbara Parker. Her "Suspicion of Guilt" just added to my summer reading of delightful skullduggery."Suspicion of Guilt" has plenty of the elements that we expect from a novel of this genre. It has a murder (which leads to other deaths), some poltical intrigue, and loads of money in the balance. The (very slowly) simmering romance between Gail and Anthony adds some neurotic spice, although it is a bit detracting at times. It also has the classic battle between an old-timer's fantasy (Sanford Ehringer) about what life should be like versus a young idealist's version (Patrick Norris), and the means by which they will attempt to acheve their visions.What, to me, sets "Suspicion of Guilt" apart from some of the other novels is the non-stop office bickering at heroine Gail Connor's law firm, Hartwell Black and Robineau. Although Lisa Scottoline's novels center on a law firm that is always debating about what is legal and what is ethical, Connor's firm wrangles over public relations and the bottom line. To me, this dollar-and-cents element rings just as true as the moral concerns--perhaps moreso. You might ask, "What does that have to do with murder mystery?" Answer: "Everything!" Read it and see. Another new dimension is the involvement of Gail's moody (but not disturbed) 10-year-old daughter, Karen. Her appearances and participation are breaths of fresh air throughout the novel. And speaking of fresh air, I am heading to Coney Island's wonderful beach with a new mystery in my book bag. I'll get back to you about it later.

Now, there is no doubt that I will teach exclusively from the Folger edition of Shakespeare's plays when I have the good fortune to teach a Shakespeare class, as I did this summer. As I have written in previous reviews of editions of Shakespeare's plays, the Folger Shakespeare Library is the most accessible for students to use and for me to teach from. The Folger "All's Well That Ends Well" went over very well with the class.Of course, there is the play itself which my students didn't think they would enjoy as much as "Othello" or "Macbeth". I could understand their preconceptions; they knew "To be or not to be" and "Tomorrow and tomorrow and tomorrow". There are no very famous quotes from this play. In any event, they equated Shakespeare with tragedies. They were surprised by "All's Well That Ends Well". They were shocked by the sexual references and the entire "bed-switching" concept. They loved to hate Parolles and laughed with satisfaction when he is undone.What makes this edition preferable for students are the face-to-face footnoting and explications. Students appreciate not having to flip to the back of the book or have the bottom of the page (and, therefore, the flow of the reading) cut through by footnotes. And finally, there is the price. The Folger Shakespeare Library is always reasonably priced. This is a major factor when you consider what students are already paying for their college education.

I mentioned in some other health care product reviews that my hair is the only good thing I got going for me. I wasn't kidding. My teeth are always gnawing back at me. I brush, floss, see the dentist regularly but there is no way to get around the sensitivity I experience. My dentist recommended this Sensodyne Repair and Protect product and I went for it. After four or five tubes--pricey tubes, I might add--it was no better than regular Sensodyne or similar products. I mean, it's okay, and it lasts for a couple of hours, but then I feel I need to brush with it again, even if I haven't eaten anything or had any hot or cold beverage at that moment. I'll keep using it until I find something else. Anyone have a recommendation?

One of the pleasures of my teaching job is that I am sometimes asked to teach a class that is out of my "jurisdiction", and "Film and Literature" is one of them. The last two times I taught it, I used Dennis Lehane's Mystic River followed by Clint Eastwood's adaptation. This summer I thought I would change things up and use Lehane's "Shutter Island". It turned out to be a great decision; the class ate it up.Many of my students remarked that they were chilled while reading it; one even compared it to reading a Stephen King novel. And this jibes with my impression (and the impressions of many reviewers here) that "Shutter Island", at its core, is a Gothic/horror novel. The elements are all there: the lunatics; the killers; the evil doctors; the raging storm, etc. Lehane does a wonderful job of making an island feel claustrophobic and a mind wide-open to possibilities--not all of them good ones. Unlike many of Lehane's other works, especially the Patrick and Angie series, this is not really a whodunit. This is more of what exactly is happening and why. Like all psychological thrillers, the path is dark, frightening and full of unpleasant surprises.

...some people might need a box of tissues handy. "A League of Their Own" is not a sad movie--far from it--but it has its nostalgic zings at the end, as well as a couple of heartbreaking moments. Yes, this is a movie about baseball, and it succeeds at that level--just read the other 300+ reviews. But it is also a movie about the struggles American women went through during WWII: the shortage of eligible men; husbands dead, dying or maimed overseas; the challenges of being taken seriously; manipulative employers and owners, etc. (And, once the war was over, things would not get better for many of these women, as they would be pushed out of the spotlight and into some suburban, kitchen-appliance-filled, anonymous Eisenhower-era home. Although this is not depicted, we know their fates.)The film is shot fairly conventionally, which I thought was appropriate. Penny Marshall allowed her very talented cast to take the ball and run with it, so to speak. (I know, baseball not football.) Hanks and Davis spar each other nicely. The Madonna/O'Donnell sideshow has a lot of appeal. For my money, though, Lori Petty gave a much-needed electrical charge to the screen. She is the most vulnerable, most frustrated character in the film.There are some nice extras here but some were throwaways. I liked the "Nine Memorable Innings" documentary--I, especially liked what Geena Davis had to say. Some of the edited scenes were good, other scenes deservedly wound up on the cutting room floor. I could have done without the Madonna video--not one of her best songs or videos. All in all, though, this "A League of Their Own" set is a great addition to any movie lover's (or baseball lover's) collection.

It was time to get old Bart a new litter box, especially since I put down new linoleum. (Yes, I still use linoleum.) Anyway, to keep the floor protected and to keep my small urban space from getting too dirty or odoriferous, I picked up the Pureness Giant High Side Litter Pan. It's not too high, so Old Bart doesn't have to strain his old bones and muscles when he enters and exits. But it is just high enough to keep out most of the kitty litter. Clint Eastwood, consciously, has created or participated in dozens of films that have defined the word "male", warts and all. This doesn't mean he ignores women or downplays their role in the world--far from it. But from the spaghetti westerns to "The Unforgiven", from the "Dirty Harry" movies to the one being reviewed here, "Gran Torino", the focus is on men and how they behave (or misbehave)."Gran Torino" is about a "last man standing" in a sense. Walter Kowalski (are we supposed to think of Walter Chrysler?) is the last of a generation of white men who supported his family and defined his life in the auto works of The Motor City. But the complexion of the city (pun intended) has changed over the decades. His Gran Torino, which he rebuilt, is his link to the past. How he defends it, and by "it" I mean everything he has ever stood for, is a polar opposite of the weak-willed young man next door, Thao. In fact, Walt goes out of his way to teach him "guy" stuff, whether it's guy talk at the barber or buying hand tools (not power tools--important difference) or defending himself against thugs. Walt didn't get this message across to his own son but he tries with Thao, which I thought was important. Walt's continued dispute with Catholicism only emphasizes Walt's sense of rugged, male individuality.Now, Thao's sister, Sue... she's another story. No fear of confrontation for her. She is as in-your-face and brutally honest as Walter. And this is what I meant earlier, when I said that Eastwood doesn't downplay the role of women. Think of Maggie in "Million Dollar Baby" or Annabeth in "Mystic River". Toughness is a universal in Clint's world, it just seems that men need to be reminded of it and how to use it correctly. In any event, "Gran Torino" is a great tour de force, a movie that came out with little fanfare, but a huge heart and lot of grit.

The history of the interactions among the Dutch, the British and the Native Americans of the New York region is a grim but fascinating one. Most historians tend to focus on the tribes (Lenape, Algonquin, Delaware) who occupied Manhattan and New Jersey. The most successful of these, I believe, is Robert Grumet's First Manhattans: A History of the Indians of Greater New York. Professor John Strong's "The Montaukett Indians of Eastern Long Island" completes the picture by giving us a scholarly and, at times, anecdotal account of the peoples who occupied this region long before any European set foot there.The book focuses on the many treaties, promises and agreements made among these groups over the centuries. Some were kept but, sadly, most were vacated. However, the sections I found most valuable were those that concerned the cultural differences not just between the Montauketts and the Europeans but among the Montauketts and the other tribes, including those across The Sound in Connecticut and Rhode Island.On a personal level, I have familial ties to Montauk, and I found the histories of Hither Hills and Napeague to be especially engaging. This book, while scholarly in tone, is not inaccessible to the casual reader; Professor Strong has done a great job in making this arena, this history very accessible. I think anyone interested in the period and the milieu will enjoy this book.

There is a poignant element to unsolved cases, a haunted quality that goes way back in literary tradition wherein the ghosts of the wronged and murdered cry out for justice. "Avenge my death!" they seem to howl--think of the ghost of Hamlet's father. "Swear!" This sort of case seems tailor-made for Detective Harry Bosch, a man haunted by his childhood, by his experiences in Vietnam, and by the countless dead and victimized L.A. citizens. Couple this with Bosch's belief that "Everybody counts or nobody counts," and it is little wonder why these cases absorb him so.Michael Connelly, in "Echo Park" has Harry searching for the answers to a case that has gone and stayed cold for years. (Connelly's most recent installment in the Bosch series, "The Black Box", is also in this vein.) Like echoes of a distant cry, Harry keeps returning to his case file on a murdered girl, Marie Gesto, hoping to "hear" something different. (I noticed how often the words "hear" and "listen" were employed when other sensory verbs could have been used.) When a break seems to come, in a van filled with grisly cargo, it seems too good to be true. And like all things that seem to be too good to be true, they usually are. From there, Bosch goes on his mission in his own unorthodox manner. "Echo Park", for me, is one of the better novels in the Harry Bosch series. All the elements of the crime and its solution are credible, frighteningly so. Most important, Connelly, early on in this series, was creating a full-length, all-around character, surrounded by equally believable minor characters. And speaking of echoes, I am going to have to echo what other reviewers have said, Connelly exhibits absolutely none of that complacency, none of that weariness, with a character who has been a proven success for decades.

97 Orchard Street in New York City, now home to The Tenement Museum, is both an enlightening and sobering place to visit. Visitors cannot help but feel in their bones the thousands of moments of joy and desperation that went on among its walls. At the same time, there is a comfort in the ordinariness that the immigrants who had once occupied those rooms strove to and did maintain. The best way for these new arrivals to achieve this sense of "home" was through their cooking. In her book, "97 Orchard Street: An Edible History of Five Immigrant Families in One New York Tenement", author Jane Ziegelman (who is also the director of The Tenement Museum's culinary center) traces the dietary needs and desires of the Glockner, Moore, Gumpertz, Rogarshevsky and Baldizzi families.What emerges from these stories is the larger picture: the culinary back-and-forth between the immigrants and their new home in the New World. As Ms. Ziegelman explains, food was a source of comfort and a link to their old customs when times were tough: "Their dream of a better life gone sour, struggling immigrants had nothing to look forward to, so they looked back instead, savoring the foods of a former existence." And yet the ubiquitous fruit, meat, poultry and vegetable vendors offered the immigrants with affordable new American foods--can you imagine an immigrant from Latvia seeing and eating a pineapple for the first time?--while simultaneously providing them with the ingredients they had known in Europe.The abundance of meat and poultry in America stunned most of the new arrivals, as well as the American way of cooking them. (Many immigrants had never seen a stove before; they had cooked over small fireplaces.) In exchange, the immigrants provided Americans with new spices and new uses for old ones, and new ways of preparing new dishes. It was humorous to see, through Ms. Ziegelman's writing, how immigrants and Americans approached each other's cooking with, first, repulsion, then curiosity, then acceptance, then assimilation. In some cases, especially for the Jews who required kosher meals, centuries of traditional cooking and religious dietary laws were modified to accommodate the American workweek and mealtime schedules. At the same time, restaurants in New York were putting more and more immigrant dishes on their menus. This is the give-and-take, the two-way street I am suggesting.Finally, Ms. Ziegelman provides the reader with a generous sprinkling of recipes for the curious. Admittedly, I found the recipes intrusive, as I wanted the narration to continue. Perhaps they would have been better off as appendices. Nonetheless, I enjoyed this book and recommend to anyone interested in food and/or the immigrant experience.

A wrestling match is the appropriate metaphor for what transpired between Jane Jacobs and Robert Moses, and their respective camps. It was one of many matches--but probably the most famous--between city planners/developers and the public they would affect. (The issue was recently examined by Michael Sorkin in his "20 Minutes in Manhattan" which makes a good companion for this book.)In his "Wrestling with Moses: How Jane Jacobs Took On New York's Master Builder and Transformed the American City", Anthony Flint does an admirable job of introducing us to the combatants, describing their strategies and analyzing the results. What I especially admired about the book was that it revealed that Moses was not alone among developers in riding shotgun over what was claimed to be "in the best interests' of their cities. Other cities were undergoing the same banal, superblock ugliness. As a New Yorker, I tend to be myopic; I thought that "The Master Builder", Moses was alone in his desire to bulldoze and replace neighborhoods with hideous apartment complexes and highways. Not so! Also, as a New Yorker, I had not realized how much Moses' reasoning was initiated by the Eisenhower administration and its love for the automobile. (Heck, even Disney got involved in this movement, as Flint tells it.)Also, I must give a nod to Flint for defending some of Moses' motivations and actions. While Moses has been quite vilified, and deservedly for some of his works, he cannot have been a total monster, as he has been represented in many books about 20th Century New York.As for Jane Jacobs, Flint gives us a fine depiction of a dedicated and resourceful woman who was not easily intimidated. She was dedicated both in terms of energy and time for the causes she supported. She was resourceful not only in legal and community activism, but in her use of the press--and children! The scenes describing children circulating her petitions were marvelous. Jacobs was indefatigable, it seems. She accomplished all this while writing a book that would soon become the textbook on understanding the dynamicas of city life.So, there is much to recommend this book, as an introduction to this colossal wrestling match. Just be advised that this is a slender volume, made for a quick read.

If Dr. Martin Luther King had written nothing else, he would be remembered for his "Letter from Birmingham Jail"; that is how great this document is. It would and should be up there with "The Federalist Papers" and Lincoln's Second Inaugural Address, among other monumental tracts of American history. I have always said this to my students who, after reading this, ask me "Why wasn't this taught to us in high school? Why do we only know about the `I Have a Dream' speech?" Good questions.Part of the reason has to do with the word "overshadowed" that appears so many times in reviews and analyses of this document. Dr. King had done so much, and said so much, for the cause of civil rights that his letter, while never ignored,  never really got center stage or the bright spotlight. Nonetheless, as Professor Reider justifiably reminds us in his brilliant "Gospel of Freedom: Martin Luther King, Jr.'s Letter from Birmingham Jail and the Struggle That Changed a Nation", the civil rights cause never got a more effective, erudite and emotional voice than "Letter from Birmingham Jail". The historic importance and background, as well as the literary merits of the letter, have finally been given a well-deserved and long-overdue analysis. (The section entitled "Everything the Nazis Did Was Legal" was espeiciall revelatory to me.)Students of American history--and literature--as well as future generations will appreciate this book. On a personal level, I know that I will bring much from this book to my classroom and encourage my students to read it.Rocco DormarunnoThe College of New Rochelle

I feel like this is a Highly Recommended product that I think everyone should invest in for their overall safety and security wherever they go.

This treatise on how the brain works, how it can go haywire, and how to fix it begins with the author explaining that he is primarily talking about the imbalance between the Prefrontal Cortex and the Limbic system composed of several parts in the brain, as the anterior cingulate, basal ganglia, the amygdala, and the thalamus all of which are involved in some aspect of defining your emotions. The right side of the brain primarily deals with emotions, while the left side deals with things like language, logic, and problem solving. This translates into things like when adults have a stroke presenting in the left hemisphere it causes the person to become more negative and depressed while a stroke [whether due to a blockage or hemorrhage] affecting the right side of the brain commonly leaves the person perpetually giddy or even laughing at inappropriate moments, often times resulting in mania.The implicit or non-plastic type of memory [not easily changeable] is based in the amygdala, while the explicit memory system [defined by past experiences] is based in the hippocampus and is more amenable to change since as we gain new experiences it has new things to consider before allowing us to form a course of action. Think of the amygdala as responsible for the FIGHT or FLIGHT response we have all heard about. Since the amygdala is pretty well established early in life and the hippocampus isn't fully developed till later in life, say up to the age of up to 25, by some authorities, we should not judge the crimes committed by children and adolescents as harshly as we would adults committing the same infractions because logic and control develop later in life than raw emotions. Basically the rest of the book deals with this imbalance and how to correct it.The author includes several indices with the first on nutritional supplements, the second on drugs, and then an annotated bibliography. I find a major shortcoming here in that there is little is no mention of negative effects of taking the various supplements let alone the drugs, and in what combinations they might be harmful.Another problem I saw was that the author who works for the AMEN Clinic in Reston, VA and the foreword by Dr. Daniel G. Amen of the same clinic who both give the impression that SPECT imaging is primarily the forte of the Amen Clinic when it is done in many other clinics and hospitals as the Mayo Clinic and Cedars Sinai  to name just two. A further problem is that neither doctor goes on to define the term SPECT Imaging right after it is first used at the beginning of the book. For those interested in what it stands for and how and why it is used; it is an acronym  for SINGLE PHOTON EMISSION COMPUTED TOMOGRAPHY. Basically it follows gamma rays given off by a radioactive substance placed in your body. It gives a functional 3-D image of an organ like the brain as opposed to just a linear view. Therefore you can see how the thing [say the brain] works in real time while it is doing something rather than at just one point in time, say as with an x-ray. It can help to identify people suffering from ADD, as opposed to anxiety, or depression by seeing how a person reacts to different stimuli. This type of imaging is also used in cardiac care and in treating various bone diseases among other things. As far as the brain is concerned it can HELP differentiate among those suffering from dementia, clogged blood vessels, epilepsy and seizures, and traumatic brain injuries now commonly diagnosed in many NFL players among other athletes involved in contact sports.

I got this scooter to review with two of my grandsons in mind. The oldest is 6 and about the 70% in height and weight while his little brother  recently turned 3 and is in the 99% in height and about the 95-96% in weight. They already had a three wheeled scooter, so were somewhat familiar with riding a scooter although a three-wheeled scooter is easier to balance on. The older had little trouble, while the three yo took a couple days to adjust to it, but still got the hang of it by about the third day. It was a good fit for the 3yo who is very big for his age, while it seemed a little small for the 6yo. But It only took about 15-20 minutes to assemble and it was rather intuitive.The deck you stand on is plastic but is supported by steel struts underneath. The handlebar are adjustable up and down so can fit kids in a modicum of height ranges with a simple adjustment. The wider than normal tires help with stability issues, especially with the younger kids. While the larger front wheel makes it easier to steer and not lose balance going over sidewalk imperfections. Both of the kids liked the foot brake on the rear wheel.I thought it seemed durable and should last a couple years. My only criticism is I would have liked to see the deck made of metal rather than just plastic supported by a metal frame and I think it would be a little small for a larger 6yo. It brought back nostalgic memories when I was a kid and had an all steel Radio Flyer wagon in red, of course, and my own kids had a Radio Flyer wagon with detachable wooden side railsBut considering the price, I thought it was a good buy and would therefore recommend it.

The author delineates each chapter with particular type of con artist and then expands from there. She begins with one of my favorites, Ferdinand Waldo Demara, born in Lawrence,MA on 2/21/1921. One of his wildest impersonations was as a ship's doctor on the Royal Canadian Navy destroyer, Cayuga, when he got tripped up for being too good at the medical profession in saving 19 wounded North Korean servicemen the Canadians picked up in a small boat during the Korean War in September of 1951. Who knows how long he could have pulled off this masquerade, with absolutely no formal medical training had the newspapers not broadcast his medical achievements thereby revealing his phony identity. He also got a job as the warden of a men's prison in Texas, among many many other borrowed identities. There is a fine movie detailing his exploits called THE GREAT IMPOSTOR starring Tony Curtis as a young Fred Demara.The author interjects neat quotes throughout as one attributed to Voltaire on page 6 of the proof edition "Religion began when the first scoundrel met the first fool." And soon thereafter states "The true con artist doesn't force you to do anything; he makes us complicit in our own undoing."I have two minor criticisms of the book, the first being a lack of cites when quoting figures, at least in the proof edition, thereby rendering them as mere conjectures as with the reference to con artists, "A third were seen as extroverted, and 35 percent present as quite friendly. About 40 percent were also highly respected by their colleagues."  [ page 36 of the proof edition] The second point being, I thought the book belabored some points, but all in all a quite enjoyable light read.Having worked with sociopaths/psychopaths/antisocial personality types for 40 years i have generally found the successful con artists who get away with their scams for numerous years are always likable, while the disagreeable types quickly land in prison. They are also  very to extremely intelligent or they couldn't pull it off for so long, although some may disagree with both personal observations. Read the book to find out who and how some of the big time cons got away with it for so long and what ultimately tripped each of  them up.

A work of historical fiction devoid of 4-letter word exclamations with a steady pace and fairly predictable outcome yet with enough minor suspense to keep the reader engaged throughout. The story was simple and written in the style of a century ago, which is when the events took place.The story begins in 1914 with the three Kopp sisters, Constance, Norma, and Fleurette [or are they really sisters] driving to Patterson, NJ in a horse and buggy when a car driven by the inebriated Henry Kaufman, scion of the Kaufman Silk Dyeing Company, runs into them with his motorcar accompanied by an equally inebriated group of thugs/friends. He denies responsibility for causing the wreck in which Fleurette sustains a broken leg and to which the burden of trying to collect the damages for the buggy repair falls on oldest sister Constance, while middle sister Norma tries to mediate the situation.  The story later involves a kidnapping of a baby boy, denied parentage by the father, and attempts of bodily harm and murderThe story sets up well for a sequel with a love interest between the sheriff, Bob Heath, and Constance. The author does a nice job of character development  of the three Kopp sisters, the sheriff and the all important secondary characters. The plot isn't a hard core mystery and not suspenseful, but is so engaging that you'll want to keep reading just to assuage your own feelings that things will come out rightfully in the end. The author became one of my favorites when I also reviewed  one of her earlier works, THE DRUNKEN BOTANIST, which was far different in tone but just as delightful in its own way.Not as much suspense as some crime novels, but still engaging in a pleasant manner with a lack of offensive language so rare in most of today's story-telling. A really delightful read!

This is my first George Foreman Grill. I Found the grill to be quite light weight, making it easily portable and able to be switched from its standard pedestal base to use on a table or counter-top. I tried three different foods on it before doing this review - Steak, Shish-Kabobs, and Chicken quarters. It did a good job on all of them, and all were cooked outside on my rear deck. However, it did not cook as fast as a charcoal or propane grill. But I couldn't fairly compare it to my large stainless propane grill, as there was a tremendous price difference also. Yet it did fine for grilling up a meal for 2 to 4 persons. And, I could see how it would be quite handy for apartment dwellers, especially those with small patios due to the minimum amount of space it takes up.It did a good job of cooking the different meats I tried while leaving them still juicy, but allowing the fat to drain off. For serious chefs think of the difference between a gas stove and an electric range; for everyone else does it really matter? Most grilling is about the camaraderie anyway. I found some of the same negatives that other reviewers have mentioned, as a plastic drip pan rather than metal and the pedestal base felt a little flimsy to me. Yet it was easy to put together and take apart, if you wanted to carry it to an off-site gathering, assuming you had electricity available. One other negative was that it was missing two screws of the four that used to hold on the legs for tabletop use. I realize that is merely a quality control issue, but still it happened. BTW the screws appear to be #6 semi-pan head Phillips 3/8 inch long. The rest of the assembly was quick and uneventful.All in all a nice grill considering the cost and the negatives versus the positives that I mentioned, and quite useful for those living in an apartment.

Nice all around work shirt with plenty of room to spare. The shirt has extra long tails with an even bottom length rather than a scalloped bottom cut so that it can be worn tucked in or out, depending on your employer's preference. I am 5'10" tall and weigh about 182. In a LARGE, it would still fit someone 30 pounds heavier and 4-5 inches taller.The back is neatly vented with a cloth mesh piece sewn in the inside upper back and shoulder area to wick away moisture [sweat]. The shirt has seven heavy duty well sewn on buttons. It has 4 pockets and two added loops. There are 2 standard covered breast pocket with cover flaps attached by Velcro rather than buttons. Sewn onto each regular pockets is a smaller attached pocket which is also flap covered and attached by the same Velcro as the larger breast pocket. I am not sure of the purpose of the smaller pockets. It seems to be more of a fashion statement than utilitarian. There is also a smaller loop to the center edge of the left breast pocket and a much larger loop attached to the bottom of the right breast pocket. I am not sure of the purpose of these, except maybe to attach an alligator type clip on name tag where required, say in a medical/government facility. Again, I think this is more a matter of form over function, as I think name tags could be attached to the standard breast pocket flaps. But it is an option for those personnel required to wear tags, which is certainly less expensive than having each shirt personally embroidered.The shirts are well tailored with close stitching. I've worn the shirt two days now. Once before washing and today after washing. It looked neat and fresh after washing on permanent press with NO wrinkles. The button hole loops are also nicely reinforced and fit tight. The shirt gives a nice overall appearance and should look good after many washings.  The synthetic fabric did not keep me too hot, although I made it a point not to purposely stand out in the sun yesterday or today with the heat index hovering around 110.

This 7 piece knife set came with the following: 8" chef's knife, 8" bread/slicing knife, 5.5" serrated blade utility knife.3.5" paring knife, heavy duty kitchen shears, and a 600 grit sharpening steel, The set came in a simulated wood block wrapped in a pretty candy apple red painted metal. The block with knives weighs right at 10.5 pounds according to my balance beam scale and it has two semi-sticky rubber strips on the bottom to prevent the whole thing from moving around once set in place.The knives seemed sharp right out of the box, but the sharpening steel was a nice bonus, as most people could definitely use it to sharpen up a bunch of old knives they have in their drawers, as I already did. It did wonders for them. Also there are 4 unused slots in the block in which to place some of your older favorite knives.All in all a very attractive and useful addition for the kitchen counter.  The set comes with a lifetime warranty for the original and any subsequent owners with the original proof of purchase; much better than a time limited warranty - too bad my cars don't have such warranties.  There is also a separate 800 numbers for the company in the USA, Canada and Ireland in case of problems or to get some edges sharpened that you cant do yourself. Of course, there will be a charge for that, but did you really expect otherwise? :-)

The author quite ably describes his sexual experiences and failed attempts to lose his virginity from about age 6 to 18 in this humorous memoir,occurring during the mid 80s through the mid 90s or thereabout. The author grew up in a nicer middle class Jewish enclave just outside the Bronx, but when trying to develop his bad boy street creed he was sure to state he was from the Bronx.The author, Eytan Bayme, makes liberal use of profanities, so if you are offended by that sort of teen age boy talk, stop here and skip this book, If, however, that doesn't bother you, you will find this book humorously captivating and which quite typically describes the average teenager who might be too embarrassed to discuss such subjects as openly as the author did. He takes numerous jabs at making fun of himself in the same sort of self deprecating way as Woody Allen; so if you think Woody Allen is funny, you will enjoy this book, if not, there are millions of others to choose from.A couple of quick quotes which I found somewhat cute but accurate follow.  These are from a review copy, so the the page numbers or even the lines quoted may not appear or be revised in the finished release. '[P]eople like us knew that God wouldn't put things like Pizza Hut and Burger King on this earth if he didn't mean for us to try them...[L] is so unfair when you are a six year old Jewish boy.' [page 2] That goes doubly for one whose family is definitely trying to keep Kosher in all things. Then in describing a fight he had with his 3 year younger brother who was still bigger than the author  He says after kneeing his brother Yehuda, "[H]e let out a shriek unlike any I had ever heard before, It was as though an air horn were crying over the death of his too young air-horn child." [p42]I found the book enjoyable light reading  which means you can read some and come back to it later and still find it easy to pick up where you left off and still get a laugh out of the protagonist's antics.

Fairly Rugged but pricey considering its primary competition, Armorbox, is 17.99 on this date.I found this case to be ruggedly made for people requiring a lot of protection for their phones, as those involved in the construction trades or those expecting to engage in a lot of outdoor activities.  Yet aesthetics is not the strong of this product. This product stresses durability and ruggedness not eye appeal.The outer case is made of some silicone type material as a protector, which it would seem to do its job quite well, while the inner case surrounding the phone itself is made of a softer polycarbonate, as is the shield for the face of the phone.  For those not that familiar with this type of polycarbonate, it is supple and will bend readily protecting what is under it, while at the same time it will scratch quite readily, especially when submitted to grit and sand on most construction projects and outdoor activities, think hiking, camping, or a sandy beach. To better understand my point, think of the lens on a cheap pair of sunglasses and how long they looked good after wiping them a few times. BTW, although this product may have been designed in California it was definitely manufactured in CHINA, as stated on the outside packing.The product also comes with a plastic belt clip on a swivel allowing you to orient the phone both in portrait and landscape mode and on either your right or left side. The clip and the entire product is somewhat bulky, but appears to be rugged.  It is substantially larger than what most people would like for typical office work, but may be indispensable for outdoor activities.Although the product appears rugged, I could only give it 3.5 stars based on the unpleasing aesthetics, especially due to the inexpensively made belt clip and the very soft polycarbonate screen protector, which is sure to scratch in a short period of time used in the applications for which this product is being promoted.

My two dogs, Leo and Sherlock, have each brushed their teeth with Greenie products for several years now. They have always enjoyed the green colored, toothbrush shaped biscuits, but seem to really love the blueberry flavor judging by their devouring of them. I normally give them one each near evening TV time while I snack on human snacks.The treats seem to do their job as neither dog has noticeable doggie breath and both have sturdy teeth with Leo being almost 14 yo and Sherlock at 8.5 yo. They are somewhat more expensive than competing brands, but both my dogs seem to love them and it keeps their teeth healthy, which is a lot cheaper than having the vet clean their teeth. They each gave this product their 5 WOOFS of approval. :-)

Have used the original electrodes for about 20 applications before they quit adhering as well as I would like.  To get a per use cost, if you divide the price by times of application, you can see that for a replacement medical product they are still inexpensive although by no means the cheapest. Yet there could be a material difference in the resistance level in different brands causing an increase or decrease in the intensity level of your unit. I would consider a divergence of plus or minus three intensity levels or 10% on Zewa's scale to be considered material. I will report on any other brands I later try and as an addendum to this review should I find such a variance, as cheaper isn't always better.

Have used this for about five days now and it works for me with spinal stenosis and sciatic pain.  I have used the original Maxell batteries that came with the unit for eight hours and they are still good. I normally use program four with an intensity level of 18-21 depending on where I place the electrodes. It has two separate channels each with 30 intensity levels which can be adjusted separately. I have moved the electrode pads to various body areas about 20 times and they just yesterday didn't seem to stck that well. You DO NOT need the gel to make the pads stick so save your money on that.You can use any replacement electrode pads that have a male RCA miniature type connector. The OEM Zewa electrode pads were good for about 20 applications for me. I have purchased another less expensive replacement pack and will report my experience with themThe unit is definitely powerful enough to make you jump on the highest settings so there is no reason to buy a more expensive unit, and with 8 different program settings which offer different pulse rates and duration, you get as many or more programs as more expensive units. The cost of the three AAA batteries is negligible, and if you are worried about that, maybe your pain isn't as bad as you say. Try paying the 175/hr at the physical therapist's to do the same thing plus the cost of waiting and travel time and you quickly see that electrodes and batteries are insignificant. And I have worked in rehab in a VA hospital so actually have some experience in this field.The sending unit is about the exact size of a pack of cigarettes only a few ounces heavier. As this has made a tremendous difference in pain relief to me, I can wholeheartedly recommend this product.

Have used the cane for about two months and found it very durable. It will stand up by itself on very level ground and even sometimes on uneven ground, but don't count on that. It is much sturdier than canes having an articulating pod for stability and those canes normally come with only three feet rather than Hugo's four feet. It is very light weight with a large rubbery grip handle. It is also somewhat less expensive than the articulating pod canes. In fact, I can see no real benefit to the pod articulating, as most people needing a cane are going to do very little hill climbing, so I see that feature as more of a sales gimmick than a utilitarian feature.

OEM part that fits perfectly with an approximate 5.5 year til expiration use life.  Another bonus was the price was about 20 bucks less than ordering direct from Phillips 800 number, although it is the same part number. I assume Phillips customer service doesn't want to be bothered shipping single orders. This was purchased for my wife's gym after the original battery expired after five plus years. The Phillips units beep once they have insufficient battery power letting you know to change the battery.

A little pricey,but cheaper than buying direct from Phillips and they had more than the required 2 years til expiration date. They are from Phillips and I did verify that they are only sold with a TWO year til expiration date not the THREE year date as I had incorrectly assumed. Why an electrical gadget in a sealed foil wrapper would go bad if never used is another question I cannot answer, but they are OEM so fit perfectly.

This is third shirt of same style that I have purchased and all look good and fit as expected. The color on the others didn't seem to fade after several washing nor did the shirts shrink on permanent press washer and dryer settings. You can also hang them on hangers and not have the shoulders look distorted from the hanger outline. Very happy with the shirts for the money.

Let me  first say that adult assembly is definitely required, but no tools are needed.  The platic pieces fit together very nuggly, ao the little ones shouldn't be able to pull them apart once assembled  It also takes 3-AA batteries but they are supplied.  The batteries are needed to make the various sounds and the little peoples' voices.  The on/off and 2 position loudness switch is nicely recessed on the bottom of the toy,  I didn't notice much reduction in volume on the lower setting and the loudest setting should be loud enough with even a TV going in the same room. The plastic edges were adequately buffed "rounded" so scrapes from sharp edges shouldn't happen.  When you first turn the toy on, the little voice says "Welcome to little people place." Pause  "Let's discover." pause "It's time for Miss Hug's magical rug."  Pause "What can you find?"  Very long pause with plenty of time for the kids to push one or more of the other side buttons on the rug. Then it says  "Come back soon." and it starts over or by pushing the center button it will tell you to push various buttons to make the various sounds or to play the instruments.The animal noises it makes are Tweet Tweet for the bird, Squeek Squeek for the hamster, ROARRR for the friendly looking dinosaur, and Bubble Bubble for the fish in the aquarium.It comes with two little people named Eddie and Mia plus the teacher who is differentiated by wearing a dress and having her hair up in a bun, since all the little figures are the same size.I waited to do this review until my grandchildren had played with it and they loved it.  It says it is designed for kids from One to Five, although Five may be a bit old for this toy.  But it is sure to create many hours of imaginative and creative play for the youngsters.  It also comes with a yellow table and four green chairs for either studying or make believe parties with your little people.

This is just a neat wooden block design toy for the very young. It reminds me of some toys I had and my own kids had rather than what is more commonly available for my grandchildren today. The train consists of an engine and two cars with 21 removeable pieces that will instill imaginative thinking for the younger set.  Sure some of the very youngest won't be able to get all the blocks back the way it came [which is a very good reason to keep the sturdy box it came in with a big picture of the train on the side showing how the pieces go together].  It says it is designed for kids 12 months old and up, but if a 12 month old could put it all together immediately where would the stimulus/challenge be for when he/she is a 2 and 3 year old?The colors on the wooden block pieces are bright and shiny and the finish is uniformly smooth throughout.My only concern is that there are several pieces about the size and shape of a Tootsie Roll which may be enticeing for the very youngest to put in their mouth.  For that reason alone I didn't give it 5 stars, yet that problem can be easily rectified by withholding those few pieces for the very yougest, at least until they get a little older.  You can still put all the other pieces on the cars, besides kids will put the blocks on the cars in their own imaginative ways, while thinking outside the so called box.Cute well-made retro type wooden toy that both oldsters and the really young will relate to. It made me feel decades younger just playing with it. :-)

According to the fabric tag, the entire pet bed is made of 100% polyester. It has a well concealed zipper across the entire back to remove the outer cover for washing. The wrap around the inner filler feels fairly thick and the outer covering is quite thick to prevent destructon by nails.However, in my case neither of my dogs want to go near it, as they are fairly old and set in their ways. One sleeps on a throw rug at the top of the stairs guarding the bedroom at night and the other sleeps on one of two huge doggy pillows in the bedroom. I assume with other animals or at least younger ones, they would be more inclined to try a new bed. It is sort of like staying in a fancy hotel, and yet your own bed feels so much more comfortable when you get back home.My only complaint is the same that others have made, which is that this seems rather pricey for a pet bed. However, it is well made regarding the filling and stitching although somewhat stiff while new, so if you have no objection to the price then you should consider this a good choice.

The fire truck/resuce unit is made of a softer more malleable plastic so it can take some abuse without immediately cracking..  The unit comes with 2 -3V #CR2032 batteries used in lots of watches & pedometers for instance, which are included, and are used to run the emergency roof top flasher and a siren. There are no talking voices so the batteries should last a while. Little kids are pretty imaginative, so that shouldn't be a problem. There is a seperate button to push for both the siren and flashing light rack. The roof unit comes off to put in new batteries and the whole top of the cab comes off so you can put one or both men inside. The unit is fully assembled except for putting the men inside the truck if that is where you think they should be.  The men have removeable firemen type hats, plus articulating arms and legs to hold a bullhorn, hand held fire extinguisher, the hose nossle and truck teering wheel.  You do need to attached the hose to the reel mounted on the right rear of the truck.  The ladder goes up in the air and has a basket at the end to hold your firefighter.  The ladder moves around but does not extend beyond its fixed length.It should povide hours of fun for the younger set from four to eight or so. Just be sure to warn them not to put the pieces in their mouth as the men are only three inches tall and the other pieces are represented in scale so much smaller.I think it is a good buy for the dollar and is one more toy for our grandsons to play with when they visit. The extinguisher mounts inside the truck cab and the other pieces can be put in the cab or attached to the hose or in the railing for the basket/bucket.

Just love thios album as I have with other Billy Jo Albums. A most talented songwriter whose songs have been covered by many other greats including Waylon Jennings, Willie Nelson, and Johnny Cash.The signature song of this album also entitled LONG IN THE TOOTH with Tony Jo White on the electric guitar and helping out with the vocals, was one of my favorites and you could tell from the performance that the songwriter/recording artists simply had fun doing it as he did with LAST CALL FOR ALCOHOL with Leon Russel on the piano, which Billy Jo pronounced as alky-hall.  I also really liked I'LL LOVE YOU AS MUCH AS I CAN with Pig Robbins on the piano.  Its a rather short album time-wise at a little over 32 minutes, but you won't be disappointed as the enjoyable beat throughout makes up for its brevity. And it just goes to show you, the old guys [we're close to the same age :-), can still put out a fine album.Thanks to Billy and may he still have a couple more in the bag for the upcoming years.

The shirt [Large] fit well and definitely gave a slimming appearance. It was the correct size for me at 5'9" and just under 180 with broad chest, shoulder, and back.  I would definitely recommend it, and at a  little under 20 bucks you can't beat the price. I do have a couple Intelliskin shirts also, and I am not sure they are worth almost 5 times the price, although they do have more of a compression fit.  This shirt is much more comfortable for casual everyday wear.

The first public orphanage in our nation officially opened its doors with a new building on October 18, 1794, although it was first authorized in 1790. It was located on the penisular part of what is downtown Charleston, SC today and stood a magnificent 4 stories high with a center section measuring 40x40 and two side wings each measuring 65x30. One wing housed the boys and the other the girls with administrative offices and the school in the center section. It was the largest building in the city at the time.This institution was designed to take in the poorest White children only. The children were housed from preschol age until old enough to be bound out into an apprenticeship program, often beginnning at age 8. Children too young to be admitted were referred to the Poor House or to a private wet nurse if still a baby. The children were given a most basic education meaning they at least learned to sign their name.  Considering many of their parents were completely illiterate as was much of the general population of the country as a whole, this was actually an upwardly mobile step. The education opportunities for boys was always more than for girls, as most of the girls were trained as seamstresses of domestics and eduction was not thought to be the most necessary part of either of those two jobs.On the fringes of some cases were two interesting but most shadowy groups of women caring for some of the children the Orphan House couldn't or wouldn't accept, and these were women of color, often working as wet nurses, and also prostitutes. At its peak in 1820 about 1 in 25 girls and 1 in 12 boys from the Charleston area lived in the Orphan House. [p69]"Over much of the antebellum era, Charleston's facilities for the mentally ill were the basement cells in the Poor House.  Persons confined to these cells were fed and protected from the elements, but received little else." [p76]For much of the period prior to the Civil War the word destitution could be used interchangeably with alcoholism, and in this regard women were on a par with the men.  However, the most common reason for binding over a child was the inability to provide financially for the child commonly due to widowhood, as these were the poorest of the poor and barely scraping by when there were both parents, especially when the parent left alive normally had no skill or trade and was most likely illiterate.The author tells us that  "Almost three-fifths of the 2000 plus children who came through the Orphan House before the Civil War left to enter a master's house [apprenticeship]...[Yet] in each decade the average trended downward..the share returing to the family increased." [p142]"When Charleston established the Orphan House in 1790, it was the richest city in the nation...per capita wealth of Charleston was twice that of New England and the middle colonies, even including the slave population [which amounted to over 50% of the the entire poplulion] [p146]  Charleston's fortunes were basically built on cotton and the slave trade to pick it before the cotton gin was invented. "in 1810 South Carolina produced half the cotton grown in the South; by 1821 that share had fallen to 28 percent and by 1834 it had fallen further to 15 percent.' [p147] Yet by late in the antebellum period Charleston was still the third most industrialized manufactring center in the South only superceded by Richmond and New Orleans.But as all things eventually change, "In 1951 all the children in residence moved to a new facility at Oak Grove in North Charleston, which continues to the present as the Carolina Youth Development Center." [p202] Shortly after the move, the Orphan House, Chapel and out buildings were torn down to make way for a new Sears Roebuck & Co. store, which itself was shuttered in 1981.The book provides a nice history of early life in the South of the period and especially a look at how the children of the poor were cared for at the time.  The author provided a most thorough and lengthy section of notes divided by chapter at the end and a complete indes of names of various persons used throughout with page references along with a seperate subject index. Well worth the time for the serious student of southern history and/or of orphans in colonial times..

What I really liked about this book in addition to its informative aspects was that the story was told in a conversational manner as if the author's were sitting down with you, the reader, and simply having a friendly discussion about all things neurological. In fact when the authors did slip into medical jargon they backed up and explained it in plain English, so you won't need a medical dictionary to accompany your reading of this book.I want to state that since I am reviewing from a  pre-release or galley copy, the page numbers of any cites are subject to change in the first and subsequent editions.An example of the plain language used is "How do you begin to understand a sick brain...you do it by engaging the person inside and you do it on a case by case basis.." [p7] That was the central theme of the entire book - listen to what the patient had to say before rushing to a diagnosis.The authors further explain some basic concepts from medicine and psychology as spheres of orientation written on charts as ORIENTATION  X 1,2,3, and sometimes x4 meaning the person knows1. Self - who they are in reality2. Place - where they are, the city, state, building, and etc.3. Time- the month, day, year, and approximate time of day4. Situation - why they are where they are, their purpose of being thereSince Aphasia [inability to speak] is a common place symptom of several different brain disorders, the authors discuss the difference between the two most common types WERNICKE's and BROCA's and how they differ and what causes each of them. This part is especially interesting to those wishing to know more about strokes.Again, to make clear their main points of always listening to the patients, the authors say "Symptoms are what a patient reports. Signs are what a physician sees in an examinaton." [p87]There is a great discussion of epilepsy and status epilepticus [continuous seizures occuring for hours or sometimes days until total collapse from exhaustion].The chapter on ALS was the most emotionally moving as all the patients realized the end result. just not the time of its occurrence.The chapter on Parkinson's Disease was informative, especially in light of the fact that Michael J. Fox was the doctor's patient some years ago. As PD sufferers know but others may not, L-dopa benefits wear off the longer you take it.  They also discuss various surgeries to help cure it and Deep Brain Stimulation with electrical devices.The chapter on Alzheimer's made clear that dementia can be caused by various diseases, it is just that Alzheimer's is the best known.On a more philosophical note, the next to last chapter discusses brain death and how or does it differ from biological death of the entire organism. "But Mike was not dead yet, not legally, not biologically, not until we said he was. He was still warm, still breathing, still digesting his last meal." [p227]

A treat for history buffs in general and specifically for those interested in Tsarist/Czarist history as am I.The three stories are:1. A story of the intimate lives of the Romanov family itelf2. A description of the events from the worker strikes of 1905 until Vladimir Lenin took power in 19173. An observation of the life of the average man/ a peasant at the turn of the 20th century and how it contrasted with the lives of the very wealthy, particularly the Tsar and his extended family.The book is of moderate length with two seperate groupings of approximatley 70 Black & White plates showing the most interesting characters discussed in the narrative.  The chapter lengths are quite short with easy to read narrative and a derth of long and obfuscative words, so that it would be suitable for ate middle school readers andothers expecially interested in Russian History.  This narrative history is further divided into four sections:Part One: Before the StormPart Two: Dark Clouds GatheringPart Three: The Storm BreaksPart Four: Final DaysThe author thought to include a rather extensive bibliography, a more than adequate index, and a page of references for internet sites that also enable further study and a lot more pictures of the times and characters discussed.Most people would agree that the murder of the Tsar and his entire family and some of his entourage along with Anastasia's pet dog was a heinour and brutal crime, yet the author takes great pains and showing that Tsar Nicholas and his wife Tsarista Alexandra or Alix in German [she directly came from the house of ZHesse in Germany] and both she and Nicky were grandchildren of Queeen Victoria of England and also cousins. Actually most of European nobility was quite closely related at the time. Nicky and Alix lived a life that was so far removed from the common man that it is hard to describe. Alexandra thought the main palace at St Petersburg or Petrograd in Russian was too barren and cold, as it along with its outbuildings and servant and other family quarters stretched for approximatley three miles along the Neva River.  So she opted that they move into the more modest  dwelling of 800 acres with only 100 rooms about 12 miles away. Now, that really is roughing it, isn't it?  As a direct contrast we find out that "most peasants had never slept in a proper bed, never owned a pair of leather shoes, eaten off a china plate, or [ever] been examined by a doctor.As the 20th century began, the blue bloods or BELAYA KOST, comprised of about 870 extended families of the Tsar made up about 1.5% of the population of Russia's 130 million people at the time, yet they controlled 90% of the wealth of the country. Talk about your income inequality. At the time, factory workers in the cities earned about 80 Kopecs/day or 40 cents for a 12 hour day.  Women only had to work 11 hours, so they could get home in time to prepare the meals and clean house for the rest of the family, yet they earned 1/3 of men's wages, and if you think that bad, young children who were forced to work the same 12 hour days as their fathers earned a mere 1/2 kopec/hour or 3 cents for a 12 hour shift.  If anyone complained they were fired on the spot.To put this more into perspective, at the time Nicholas was placed in captive exhile with his family, they took with them "two valets, six chambermaids, ten footmaen, three cooks, four assistant cooks, a clerk, a nurse, a doctor, a barber, a butler, a wine steward tow pet spaniels, and a bull dog, p;lus later joined by tutors for the children, all of which was paid for by the average factory worker and peasant who were all starving at the time. When the family moved from one location to another it took 50 soldiers to move their personal belongings.  The grand duchesses wanted their bed linens changed daily as it had been in the palace, so they hired and outside laundry service racking up a laudry bill of 428.00 dollars for the first few weeks.The author does a nice job of covering many of the events of WWI and Russia's participation plus the relationship of Father Gregory Rasputin, the so-called STARETS or holyman and emperess Alexandra, who was trying to save young Alexei from death due to hemophilia. There is a nice background story to Lenin's rise to power, but the most mesmerizing part was the stark contrast of how 84% of the populace who were peasants lived as compared to the royals and their extended family. Most people know that the family took their own jewels with them and sewed them into the girls clothing,but what most people didn't realize is that those precious jewel weighed 19 pounds and were worth 14 million at that time.  Reading both sides of the story lets you come away with a different perspective of the tragic events.Well worth the read.

The author attempts to fill in a lot of minor facts left out by other biographies of Poe, especially in regard to getting some of his works accepted and published by the big name publishing houses of his era.Yet the author does manage to cover the necessary facts of Poe's life for those not having read another biography about him. Poe's parents were David Poe, Jr. and Eliza Arnold married in 1806; both were actors, with his mother considered quite attractive and the more accomplished of the pair.  They quickly had three children  with Henry (1807), Edgar (1/19/1809), and Rosalie (1810). The father forced to take bit parts and always considered the lesser of the pair succumbed to alcoholism shortly after the birth of their last child, and Edgar's mother considered beautiful but frail died shortly thereafter. Edgar was then adopted by a wealthy, but childless, merchant couple John and Frances Allan of Richmond, Virginia from whom he derived his middle name. Although the adoption was in name only never having been legalized, Edgar spent his rather tumultous life with them until 18 when he ran away to Boston. He would have been considered a delinquent by today's standards, often getting in fights, drinking, and engaging in forgery and other petty crimes.  To avoid the bill collectors and others looking for him, he joined the army, whose strict discipline agreed with him, and rose from the rank of private to Regimental Sergeant Major in just under two years. Realizing he cold go no further as an enlisted man, he asked for an honorable discharge and attended West Point where his antics got him kicked out in a mere six months.Edgar spent most of his life dodging bill collectors and creditors due to his various and numerous misdeeds acquiring at least 5 aliasis, the best known being Henri Le Rennet, but at other times publishing articles under his brother Henry's name. To flee the cops he went to live with his paternal aunt Maria Clemm in Baltimore and promptly fell in love with her young daughter, Virginia. They lied about her age and were married in 1836 when he was 27 and she a mere 13. She turned out to be the love of his life and he of hers, with both being mutually suportive of each other until her untimely death from tuberculosis, of which there was no cure at the time, leaving Edgar more depressed and prone to drink than usual.Poe most likely suffered from Bi-Polar disorder, which explains his prodigous output at some times and his deep dispair at other times. He alienated friends and foes alike engaging in physical fights and by slanderous and libelous things he said and wrote about them. These actions cost him numerous jobs and writing assignments resulting in his never becoming a wealthy man.  As an example he earned only 166.00 for the entire year of 1848, which was quite pitiful for a learned man of letters, even back then. Poe also favored poetry over prose, which several publishers told him was far less popular with the general public.  He finally succumbed to the effects of alcoholism  at 5am on 10/18/1849 at the young age of 39.I have but touched on the general facts of Poes brief life, with many more incidents revealed in detail by the author, espcially his relationships with colleages and publishers.  Easy to read and certainly worthwhile for those with an interest in the man who is preeminently famous for the macabre and poems such as THE RAVEN and ANNABEL LEE..

Bob Saginowski had worked at his cousin Marvin's Bar for about 20 years, since the time Marv had a crew and Bob was part of it, but Bob's life was pretty much short of anything interesting happening in it in 40+ yars. Even Bob describes himself as a "never-been loser". [p10 -since this review is from a pre-release edition, the page numbers in the final edition are subject to change]. This short novel is a reworked short story from a 2009 anthology called Boston Noir and was originally titled ANIMAL RESCUE.Although nothing much exciting has happened in Bob's life the past week, as the story opens, has been different as he explains, "[I]n the past seven days, he'd found the dog, met Nadia, been robbed at gunpoint, adopted the dog, and been visited by a gangster who tortured men in the back of a van." p65-66]The book gets its title from the fact that Cousin Marv's turns out to be a money drop for the Chechen Mafia run by one, Chovka Umarov.The pit bull, actually an American Staffordshire Terrier, puppy Bob rescues, gets him acquanited with Nadia Dunn, a presently reformed druggie with a bad ex named Eric Deeds, who keeps popping in an out of her life and was also the previous owner of the dog and who left him bearten in a garbage can where Bob heard his cries and saved him. You see, although Bob leads a boring life, he has scruples ad moral principles and is a protector of abused animals and women. Bob is a contradiction in that he ia a devoted Catholic, yet hasn't taken communion in as many years as he can remember, yet attends mass regularly.  He even names the puppy Rocco, after the patron saint of dogs, St. Rocco.I felt the writing was fairly crisp but with a lot of gutteral slang and slurs to racial/ethnic/and gender groups alike, so if that sort of thing would offend you, then you might want to skip this short novel.I liked it and thought it was page turner with a surprising twist to the ending. Just be assured that Bob doesn't like people who would ever beat a dog, and really dislikes anone who would harm his dog, especially if that person is his girlfriend's ex..

The author tries to explain how aniamals are basically driven mad by the actions of humans, and that if we learned to compassionately coesixt with other species we would all be better off.Early in the book the author does a nice job of showing how Alzheimers in humans and dementia in dogs are closely correlated, with the primary difference being that due to the shorter life span of dogs they don't have time for plaque to build up in their brains but instead suffer dementia from atherosclerosis [hardening and narrowing of cranial arteries].She also points out how anxiety occurs among the lower ranking animals of a pack or group with their brains being constantly bathed in stress hormones as opposed to the higher ranking members who suffer from much less stress which can correlate nicely to the differences in human society between the very well off and the middle and lower ranking members of society trying to make do.Something that I never realized before is the primate mothers who were raised in isolation as babies, say in old time zoos and circuses do not know how to nurse and will often push their young away.  They are now provided with lactation consultants by watching other primates nurse theier young and sometimes even human surogates, this use of human females as surrogates more frequently done in poorer countries.We are also told that as late as the later 19th century, it was thought that animals contracted rabies as punishment for some evil act they had done, and throughout the 19th and well into the twentieth century homesickness was considered a physical illness with the terms nostalgia and homesickness being used interchangeably. [p71]Trichotillomania [pulling out your own hair] an anxiety reaction and now considered as a form of OCD in the latest DSM-V affects about 1.5% of males and 3.5% of females in the USA. It is also present in six other primates besides humans as well as among mice, rats, guinea pigs, rabbits, sheep, musk oxen, dogs, and cats. [p144]The author documents some animal suicide behavior with the most famous member being a dolphin named KATHY  [the mani one of six] that played the part of FLIPPER on the 1960s TV show of that name. She literally died in the arms of her trainer, Ric O'Barry on 4/12/1970. [p166] I loved that show, and who didn't love FLIPPER?We are told that 14-17% of all the dogs in the USA suffer from some degree of separation anxiety.. [p220] And how elephants become so attached to their mahouts that they are jealous of all other human companions of the mahouts to the point of being aggressive towards other humans, which can lead to a very celebate lifestyle for the mahouts. :-0And last but not least we learn that 10-15% of the gray whales who come to the lagoons off Baja.Mexico to calve and mate prefer human company to associating with their own species and will actually come up to small boats and make eye  contact and let people pet them. LIke, how cool is that!This is a great book, easy to read, full of facts of which I have merely brushed the surface, and t goes a long way in showing the interconnectedness of mental process between humans and other species. HIghly recommended.

A poetically told story of how a young black wolf first befriended a few humans, then a larger group, and finally much of the town of Juneau, Alaska. He was seen by some as the natural personification of the wild self-sustaining indivdualism, while hated by others who only thought of him as a natural predator. This is the story of how a wild creature changed the preconceived notions about how a wolf should act. Ultimately it is the story of life and death of one creature, a wolf named ROMEO.The author first spotted Romeo on a frozen lakebed outside of Juneau in December of 2003.
