He wa still quite young and not fully mature, with the author guessing his age at 2 years or less. He was wary, but never threatening to humans or their four legged companions. In fact, he took a special liking to all the female dogs,without ever mating with any, at least not in anyone's presence, which is how he got his name. He would often steal the toys that human would throw to their own dogs seemingly acting like just another dog.As the author tells us there are less than .02 wolves per each of Alaska's 500,000 square miles, so that many Alaskans have never really heard a wolf howl in the wild and fewer still have actually seen one, regardless of what the movies imply..Although I would like to quote a few lines, I would also caution the reader that I am reviewing from a  pre-release version of the book and the pages cited may be changed in the official editions thereafter."[I]n the entire recorded history of Alaska, there has been just one confirmed fatal attack by nonrabid wolves on humans...On March 8, 2010, a young, first-year teacher from Pennsylvannia, Candice Berner, was killed two miles from the remote Alaskan Peninsula village of Chignik Lake." [p79]The author further tells us that "According to biologists, a ripe old age for a wild wolf is between seven and ten years, though most don't live that long...Even within the boundaries of Denali National Park, where all human hunting and trapping is banned, one study found the average life of a wolf spans just three years." [pp92-93]Romeo had a habit of disappearing for long periods of time especailly from late spring to early fall often leaving people to think he died.  But Romeo seemed to have had a particular affinity for another photographer, Harry Robison, and his female black Lab mix, Brittain. "Harry reported that he, Brittain and the wolf found each other and all was as it had ever been. Romeo had once again risen from the dead." [p144] However, on or about 9/23/2009 Romeo seemed to disappeared for good, at least no human could locate him. So what happened, did he run off with a small pack of wolves who had recently invaded Romeo's territory, had he finally set up housekeeping with a friendly female wolf and started a family of his own, or had some onerous act befallen him? As the author spends the last few chapters explaining this part I won't spoil it for you.I would like to sum up this review in the author's own words. "His survival was not due to the actions of a few, but the tolerance of many, and the restraint of state and federal agencies - not to mention the actions of the wolf himself.. he might still be there, waiting by the Big Rock for his adopted pack mates to appear." [p228] At least we can all hope!Captivating and a real tear-jerker for all canid enthusiasts.

Ida Minerva Tarbell was born on her maternal grandparents farm in Hatch Hollow, PA on 11/5/1857 and died of pneumonia in Bridgeport, CN on 1/6/1944. Both of her parents were literate, having each been schoolteachesr for parts of their respective lives. So the idea of educated women was not as novel in the Tarbell household as it was in most other families of the era.  Ida grew up near Titusville, PA where the first oil well was discovered in 1859 and her father was later in the oil business as an independent producer, meaniong he didn't belong to any compaies owned by John Davison Rockeller whose Standard and Excellsior OIl Works was founded in Cleveland, Ohio in 1860..  This later morphed into the Standard Oil Trust [1882] and today is known as EXXON.  By 1877, Rockefeler controlled 90% of all the oil production in AmericaIda attended Allegheny College in Meadville, PA from 1876 to 1880 and accepted the job as the prioress or headmistress at the Poland Union Semenary in Poland, OHio as her first job after graduation.  After two years, she left and began her writing career in earnest, first doing free lance work in Paris and later being hired as a staff writer and finally senior edition for McClure's Magazine when it was an investigatgive journal and not the romance magazine of the mid 20th century.  She found time early in her career to write a well received biography of Abraham Lincoln, before embarking on her true passion, which was exposing what she considered to be the illegal and immorl business practices of Rockelfeller and his business partner, Henry Flagler which was entitled THE HISTORY OF STANDARD OIL.Although she and Teddy Roosevelt were somewhat friends they disagreed sharply on what Ida wrote, as Roosevelt thought she should accentuate the positives of life at the time rather than raking up the muck and thereby causing a big stink as the man did in John Bunyan's classic novel, PILGRIMS PROGRESS did, according to Roosevelt..  Ida openly challenged Roosevelt that he had misinterpreted the novel, which certainly did not further any amicability towards one another.Ida also was not a friend of the suffragette and feminsit movements of her time or today, as she felt women would be more easily corrupted by being allowed to vote and that although she was a working woman herself, she felt  the place of most women was in the home taking care of their families.The sentence structure throughout seems age approprite with a most liberal sprinkling of black and white photos to illustrate many of the points and show Ida from her time as a young gril until just before her death. A well written book with a quite liberal bent to it.  Definitely worth the read for the young adult group for which it is intended.

This was a suspenseful tale of several gristly murders neatly woven together in the main and subplots. Some may have figured out the twisted and convoluted paths the story takes as it  jumps between subplots, but I, for one did not, until the author explained it in complete detail in the final few pages.The story begins with a stray bloodied Sheltie being found in the woods in the company of a bearded vagrant, called the Walking Man by our hero detective Jack Caffery. It seems the Walking man found a partially torn note around the dogs collar asking for help and explaining it wasn't a joke or ruse. About the same time a middle aged couple Oliver Anchers-Ferrer, his wife Matilda, and daughter Lucia are being held captive in their own home by two seemingly deranged men, but for what apparent motive, plus and their cleaning lady has suddenly gone missing also.  Somehow, these events tie into a horrific, savage and gristly murder of two young lovers some 14 years earlier. The male turned out to be Lucia's ex-boyfriend, Hugo Frink, and the girl his new girlfriend, Sophie Kitson. A supposed serial killer named Minnet Kable originally confessed to this along with other murders, but the evidence tying him to the crime was slim at best; yet the author manages to bring the whole story together in a most fanciful way.The story used great prose throughout as this line from page 347 of the pre-release edition, "Her eyes fall on the scissors- they drift from her line of sight and she feels their loss the way she'd feel a parting lover." How cool is that?Indulge yourself and get caught up in this story, you'll be glad you did.  It is a real page turner. It is the first of this author's works I have sampled and I look forward to future mysteries by this author.

Thw story concerns Maxine [Max] Revere an attractive 31yo investigative journalist, who has come to the San Francisco Bay area for the funeral of a childhood friend, Kevin O'Neil, who committed suicide, after being accused of murdering his ex-lover and Max's best friend some 13 years earlier. She is met by an elderly couple as the Frisco airport who have watched her TV show and who then ask her to help solve the murder of their grandson. She verifies their facts and decides to do just that. Somehow this murder occurred on the campus of the prep school Max attended and where her best girlfriend, Lindy Ames, was killed some 13 years earlier.  While investigating the murder of her friend, Lindy, and the young man, Jason Hoffman, she discovers the bones of another body on the construction site of her old Alma Mater, which is having a new school gym built. It seems these three murders and the suicide are linked together and she is the only who seems to be able to find the link.  All the while the bad guys and gals are trying to first scare her off and then ultimately to permanently silence her for good.The story is filled with intrigue of numerous sordid affairs, drug dealing, large multimillion dollar construction contracts and Max's single minded resolve to bring a final resolution to this matter.Max is a thoroughly modern woman who uses sex the way some men do, but while being raised by an extremely wealthy family, she is a successful TV personality so isn't ependent on any man. Yet she never knew who her father was and was abandoned by her mother at age nine left to be raised by her grandparents, so she can still see life from another angle besides that of the privileged few.A great and fast paced story line that should appeal to both the male and female audience equally. Highly recommended.

As with most other reviewers, I have used Scott products for years for both my plants and turf needs. This products with a NPK formulation of 12% Nitrogen, 4% Phosphorus, and 8% Potassium in the form of soluble potash with a nice addition of micro-nutrients, makes it ideal for use on indoor as well as outdoor plants. A lot of people forget to fertilize their indoor plants, yet they have no other way of getting new nutrients to grow by with years of repeated waterings.  Just be sure to water after applying , especially on the indoor plants.  O used it on all our indoor plants six days ago and noticed fresh green appearing on both a 6 foot tall rubber plant and a Christmas cactus, which really surprised me. The other plants were of more common varieties and also had the beginnings of greening up.Because of the high 12% nitrogen, this is best used in Spring and early Summer or else you will cause the grass or plants to green up to close to cold weather after which a frost might come and kill them since the greening causes water to flow into the leaves and they will freeze and break off or become diseased, as opposed to brown leaves which have no or extremely little water so can fall off without hurting the plant. Of course, the last statement doesn't apply for indoor plants in climatically controlled conditions. Fall fertilization should have no or very low nitrogen [N] percentages and much higher on the phosphorus [P] and potassium [K] in the NPK label you see on the front of each fertilizer package, as these promote root health when leaf growth is not necessary. The micronutrients  are also needed to balance some other plant needs and to help it fight diseases. On cheaper brands of fertilizer these so called micro-nutrients are missing and the plants suffer because of it.A good and well balanced product for the price with an easy to use applicator included and specific directions for potted plant container sizes.

This is simply the generic version of the popular heartburn/GERD treatment drug called Prevacid, just like omeprazole is the generic of Prilosec.The active ingredients in each is exactly the same as the name brand product, the other ingredients and the percentages of each such as coloring material and filler are what changes, as does the price, which in this case is very reasonable.  Both Lansoprazole and Omeprazole fall into a class of drugs called proton pump inhibitors or PPIs, which have different mode of action from older style drugs called histamine or H2 antagonists [meaning they work against allowing histamine to form in your stomach] such a Pepcid, generically know as famotidine, or Zantac, generically known as ranitidine. You should be aware that you must take the PPI drugs for several days before they work, as opposed to H2 antagonistic drugs which will work in minutes.  Both classes have advantages and drawbacks, so the perspective user should ask his/her doctor or at least check the literature to see if you might be taking another drug that could interfere with your new drug or vice versa.  But I like generics and have used all four drugs mentioned over a period of years and feel they all have their place. Since, IMHO, the drugs in a class are generally interchangeable one should look at the price and the price of this generic is quite reasonable and I would recommend it.

This is a fictionalized account of a real person named Albert Dadas, who lived in 19th century France.  He was about 20yo at the time the story takes place.  Albert was hospitalized in a mental hospital named St. Andre in Bordeaux, France, in real life.  The story takes place before much of what we know of mental illness in these times had yet to be  uncovered, and believe me there is still much more to learn. Albert suffered from a Dissociative Disorder called Fugue. The author does a great job of explaining this disorder and all the other ones of the fictional characters who interact with Albert and the doctor treating him in the story. The basic manifestations of a Fugue state are that you wander about, sometimes for a few hours sometimes for months or intermittently for years as was the case with Albert. The problems is that the person seldom remembers much or anything that happened while they were in this fugue state. It should be stated that the person seems generally normal if not a bit strange to most people.  Albert did engage in some rather strange behavior, but his biggest worry was that no one think him a vagrant as he saw that to be the lowest of the low. Let me give one brief quote from page 22 of the pre-release edition "He walks for days without stopping, without eating, without sleeping in order to feel the gift of astonishment." The problem is that the person experiencing this disorder, normally set off by some tragic occurrence as was Albert's case, is running away from something and never towards anything so that he can therefore never arrive.The story revolves around the interplay between his psychiatrist and himself with the intermingling of other psychiatric patients stories woven into the main plot line.If you are interested in a fictionalized story of a rare mental disorder [fugue occurs in about 20/10,000 people in a general population] this will be up your alley, if you are looking for a fast paced thriller you may be left somewhat wanting. This is a nice book to read at your leisure over several days. I would also like to mention that the fugue state is occasionally found in severe alcoholism and somewhat in some forms of epilepsy.

An intelligent collection of short stories in which the central theme is the possibility of exorcising personal demons from the past.The following is a brief synopsis of the eight short stories in the order presented:1. The Old Priest - This old Jesuit priest is a rapt raconteur, a bit of a provocateur, and outwardly gay. He is particularly fond of booze, hallucinogenic mushrooms, and his ever faithful Camel cigarettes, which he always smokes in a silver tipped holder.  The entire story reverberates with recollections of past memories and as the quote on page 36 from Flannery O'Connor goes, "All is sacred, nothing profane."2. Snow Behind the Door - the second story in this series concerns the remembrances of an aging Irish grandmother named Rose, who moved to the NJ Shore-from Philly. A poignant line from this story says it all, "At my age, all you can do is think of the past." [p49]3. The City of Gold - the story center on weak and hustler Charlie and his 19yo girlfriend Amber and there relationship with a black/Indian blackjack dealer named Maurice Baltimore. Quite a surprising ending to this story.4. Jack Frost - this is another story set in Jersey and concerns Bobby a blackjack dealer and an interesting player an old Polish Jew, who was concentration camp survivor and to escape his demons renames himself Jack Frost upon coming to America in the 1960s.5. Upstairs Room - another story taking place in Atlantic City in which our protagonist Joe reminisces how he chucked his real life away to be with his current squeeze named Irene Smith.  Joe says of Irene "[Y]ou've seen women like that, attractive but a little passed it...like they're trying to outrun whatever life has in store for them, and they know they can't, but that doesn't stop them running all the same, and it doesn't stop them from enjoying it either." [p106]6. Have You Seen This Girl? - in this story, the story concerns Christine, married to Howard, whose sister Darcy, a most attractive tramp comes to live with them and totally turns there lives upside down. In describing Darcy, Christine a cocktail waitress says, "She is a quick one, little Darcy is...No moss. Strictly teflon: a non-stick surface. Text without content." [p113]7. The Unexamined Life - Miles Dell, a 44yo, craps dealer in Atlantic city is bored with wife of 20 years Claire, his son Jack and his girlfriend Alison Six and at midlife takes up with an outcast prostitute named Patsy Kogod and her young daughter Stevie, thinking he can save them and himself at the same time - but can he do both or either?8. The Burnie Can - is what I thought the strangest of all the stories and the title refers to an old rested metal barrel used to burn trash in.  Our protagonist recalls the memories of his childhood when one day his mother and grandmother, while working in the backyard coming running in and telling the whole family that they captured and real live dinosaur of small stature under the clothes basket as he tried to escape from under the burnie can. As the story is recounted over the years with family memories added to each subsequent telling the story takes on a life of it own.The book is filled with great descriptive prose and well framed stories that are believable and we have probably all known people who if names were changed could fit many of the characterizations portrayed.Highly recommended.

A definite must for lovers of the Louvin Brothers sweet harmony. This collection consists of 7 prior albums in one 3 Cd pack collection totaling 84 songs.The original 7 Albums are:1. The Family Who Prays [12 songs] all gospel Blue Grass with a religious bent featuring the good side of believing2. Satan Is Real - [12 songs] another album of religious/gospel type Blue Grass this time featuring the evil side of life.3. My Baby's Gone - [12 songs] - heartbreak to the max  yet done with their famous lilting harmony4. Encore 1 & 2 - [12 songs] - part of a mild change up  for the brothers5. A Tribute To The Delmore Brothers - [12 songs] the Louvins cover the Delmore's hits and well known country and Blue Grass favorites as Blues Stay Away From Me, Nashville Blues, Freight Train Blues, The Last Old Shovel, plus eight more songs of longing and despair.6. Country Love Ballads [12 songs] - another album of love attempted, sometimes gained, but often lost7. Ira and Charlie - [12 songs] the brothers renditions of country and Blue Grass classics as Tennessee Waltz, Too Late, Don't Let Your Sweet Love Die, I Wonder Where You Are Tonight, Making Believe and seven more classics.As a Louvin Brothers fan I can recommend this as a nice addition to this genre with a good quality of transfer and at a reasonable price.

The authors begin with the premise that dogs, although descended from wolves do not act strictly like wolves especially, when considering a few years ago, the vast majority of what we knew about wolves was from captured animals and was far different from how wolf families lived in the wild.Let may say that if you are a fan of the Cesar Milan school of dog training, you are going to have some trouble accepting the ideas the authors put forth in this book.  They simply do not believe in the ALPHA Dog theory.  For those novice trainers or those who maybe got their first dog recently the acceptance of what the author say isn't hard to accept, for intermediate trainers or advanced trainers, they may have some doubts about the theories postulated. Often the various authors quote various studies, but do not go into the hard data to back up their claims or for even the serious student in this field to see the protocols of the research.  Let me say this is an edited book, so that each chapter is written by a different veterinarian[s].  They are all vets and are trying to promote essentially what is the field of animal behavioral psychology to which only vets may belong, so it is no wonder that the book is sanctioned by the American College of Veterinary Behaviorists.  I am not saying I disagree with the various chapter authors only that the people doing the chapter reviews are the equivalent of union members reviewing the propriety of actions by other union members.  I do agree with the VAST majority of what the individual authors espouse.The book starts off a little slow but fairly rapidly finds its stride and makes for interesting reading.  The way the chapters are presented allows one to stop at the end of a chapter and then begin again a different day without missing anything, as each chapter covers a particular area as chosen by that author, who is as I said earlier also a veterinarian.One of my favorite chapters was Chapter 7 in which the authors go over:1. Dogs don't jump up on you t establish dominance, but to show interest, recognition, and affection2. The authors advise not to do what the dog wants without FIRST making them do something or some behavior you want to establish or fortify first3. Don't vary the length of the leash while walking your dog by extending your arm, simply walk at a brisk pace but don't let the dog pull you. If he/she starts doing that stop and begin again.  This probably varies some from what many dog training classes I have participated would direct, which is to make the dog walk around your right side, come to a sit and when it is paying attention to you begin you walk with a heel off the left foot.4. Dogs were meant to hunt or find their food in the while, so putting some food in a Kong toy or some other brand, slows down their eating and actually gives them something to do to get their food in a more natural semblance of feeding in the wild.All in all a quite nice book with unified themes by all the authors in general. It should probably be considered a welcome addition to the training library for most people. And it was written in easy to understand language.

Our story begins on 8/2/1930 in Belgrade Lakes, ME, at the summer cottage of Judge Joseph F. Crater, recently appointed to the NY Supreme Court and his wife of 13 years Stella.  She confronts him about his affair with his mistress Sally Lou Ritz, affectionately referred to as Ritzi, and in the process slams the car door on his hand. Soon after on 8/6/1930 the judge disappears from sight supposedly as he entered a taxi outside a fancy club called Club Abbey, owned by the notorious gangster Owney Madden, who bought the judge his appointment through Tammany Hall. What really happened to the judge, his mistress, his wife, and the maid is what the story is all about.I should mention that much of the story is true and was followed for many years by various newspapers.  The fictitious characters and their back stories are explained at the end by the author, so that a brief read of that short section will clue you in on what is fact and what is fiction.  If you don't want to know simply don't read the final chapter until the end.The story was easy to follow as each chapter is given a date and place where the action takes place and is further identified when either of those two things change.Sally Lou Ritz originally named Sarah was born on dairy farm in Wisconsin but moved to NYC at age 19, three years before our story begins, to find fame and fortune, but ended up working as a high priced escort for the infamous gangster Owney Madden, who put her in touch with the judge so he would have an inside person to let him know what the judge's plans were at all times.  He backs some Broadway shows and gets her the starring role in one musical, but she accidentally gets pregnant shortly before the judge disappears and she can tell him he is about to be a father. Obviously Madden isn't thrilled with Ritzi's condition, so she takes a powder.The maid is a very attractive Castillian named Maria de la Luz Tarascon Simon and is married to a detective  named Jude Simon, the lead detective assigned to investigate the disappearance of Judge Crater.  It turns out that she asked Stella to get her husband the promotion to detective through the judges connections. In the meantime she finds out about the judge and Ritzi and torn between her obligation to the judge and her friendship with his wife.  We also find out that she can't have kids and becomes involved with Ritzi and her condition.  She met Madden at her other job as a tailor for Smithson's where Madden has all his clothes made.It seems that a special commission has been set up to investigate the bribing of politicians and wants Stella to testify about what she knows about her husband's affairs, so she disappears,: Ritzi disappears to avoid Madden, and the judge simply disappears.It all sounds convoluted, but the author does a great job to fit the pieces together with many parts I have purposefully left out.It should keep you enthralled for the entire length and if you are even vaguely familiar with the real story it will make for a very  plausible story to what could have happened..

Have used this product on horses in the past and at present on my dog to add in supporting the vet wrap over padding to cover a malingering wound from a sarcoma removal on his leg. It comes in handy as with many dogs they simply tear off any dressing as the wound begins to heal and itch, just as it begins to itch with humans. My vet finds it a necessary part of treatment for this type of wound treatment and so do I. Great product and it is the original J&J product not a generic substitute. One caveat is that the product is made of dried natural rubber, which is what allows it to stretch, so should you have an allergy to latex, please take that into account.

The story concerns a child psychiatrist named Owen Lerner, who is struck by lightning while feeding a parking meter as he takes his family out to dinner at Rehoboth Beach, DE in the summer of 2008. The other characters of significance are his wife Antoinette, aka Toni, his twin sons Will and Ricky, aged 21 and his 16yo daughter Brooke, plus Will's girlfriend Kyra, who may or may not have slept with both Ricky and Owen. I can already see the humor in that from Will's point of view.Since his "electrifying" moment, Owen wants to give up his practice and barbeque, maybe turning that hobby into a restaurant of sorts. Other humorous ideas he has are barbequing the cat, Mittsy, who wants to run away and roasting their now deceased dog Sparkle, who wants to please so much he would willingly allow it.  And if that is your idea of good clean fun, wait there is more. [p52]  There are more humorous moments poked at the expense of disabled people, like Owen after he is struck by lightning. Toni says to him, "'You'll be back to normal in no time.' He has no intention of returning to normal. How you going to keep them down on the farm after they've had a transcendental experience...Normal is for *ussies." [p55]The book is filled with an overabundance of cutesy modern expressions as, ""He wondered who belled [called]her." [p113] and "The woman in the picture had a Monroe, though Abigail told her that the hole closes up pretty fast if you take out the stud." [p114]Some more mildly humorous lines were, "Unless she want to have sex or talk about barbeque, she can't keep his attention." [p145] and "You know what's weird...I've lost weird. Some people lose weight or their keys. I've lost weird." [p161]I found some of the analogies mildly humorous but still strange as, "The news would have made the Fitzgerald crowd uncomfortable, like baby *oop in the neighborhood pool." [p208]For those not knowing what Lichtenberg figures are, like myself, I would suggest looking that up early as there is considerable mention of that scientific term.I found the reading somewhat tedious with an inexplicable constant use of unfamiliar phraseology as, "Our perturbation would be soothed should your peregrinations lead hither for the impending gratuitous holiday." [p235] and "[H]is sister's scrambled call for help makes it through his own insecurities: the enormity of your analogue's exploits requires kinship, as do I." [p238] And yes I did read the entire book with the page quotes to prove it. There you have it. As Miranda Lambert intoned on one of her Pistol Annie albums, "Bein Pretty Ain't Pretty!"

The author demonstrates how a hole might be found anywhere with actual example of a real hole in the middle of all the pages.Our male figure in this black ink drawing set of panels begins the story by moving into a new apartment. Our main character is a male as the drawings are fairly anatomically drawn and he is neither a human nor a directly recognizable animal, but to me looks somewhat like a mouse.  That is the nice part about this book in that the figures and story can be what you want them to be inspiring creativity for young and old minds alike, as nothing is totally spelled out in this book.After unloading his moving boxes and making himself breakfast, our main character suddenly notices a hole clear through the kitchen wall leading into the laundry room, but when he goes into the laundry room to investigate, the hole isn't where it was but has moved. As he goes back into the kitchen the hole moves again from the wall to the floor.  He is perplexed by these strange events, so calls a science lab to tell him more.  They tell him to bring in the hole so they can examine it.  After a while he succeeds in capturing the hole in one of his used cardboard boxes and takes it to the lab, where they exam it. They tell him to leave it so they can do a more thorough examination of it.  He goes home to wait for the final verdict as to what the hole may mean, how it got there and why it keeps moving around.  But lo and behold when he gets home, what does he find but?????Since the figures are somewhat anamorphic and there is a bare minimum of printed text, your young reader can make the story into whatever he/she wants it to say.  In psychological terms, this would be considered an open-ended exercise.  It is a neat concept for kids to exercise their minds and be creative.  The other thing is that the kids can see a different story with each perusal through the book. This is a fine example of thinking outside the box.

This is a significant part of WWII history that is quite important in understanding how society functions, yet has taken a back seat to the battles and the deeds and misdeeds of men of the same period of time.Since the author's reporting is so engrossing I have chosen to primarily quote her as summary points of the entire book.  Although I have given page cites, this is from a pre-publication copy and thus the page numbers may not be the same as in the final publication copy.As the author recounts, "[T]he list of teachers and other female Nazi Party activists that I had found in 1992 Ukraine was the tip of the iceberg...Hundreds of thousands of German women went to the Nazi East...and were indeed integral parts of Hitler's machinery of destruction. [p3] In further delineating the number and actions of the participants,"There was no divide between the home front and the battlefront.  Women could decide on the spot to join the orgy of violence...they melded into hundreds of thousands - at least a half million - women who went East.' [p6]"The German Red Cross trained six hundred thousand during the Nazi Era, and some four hundred thousand were placed in War time service...The German army trained over five hundred thousand young women in support positions...and two hundred thousand of those served in the East." [p6] "The average age of a female concentration camp guard was twenty six; the youngest was a mere fifteen years old when she was posted at Gross-Rosen camp in Nazi-annexed Poland." [p15] "[B]y war's end, about one tenth of camp personnel was female...At least thirty five hundred woman were trained as concentration camp guards; mostly at Ravensbruck [the largest training camp for females]." [p21]"The Party's biggest supporters...were people like Erna [Petri] - lower middle class Protestants and farmers." [p70]  The women volunteers saw joining the party as upward mobility considering their typical backgrounds. "Over time it was expected that that any woman who desired a position in the Party's upper management  would complete some training in the eastern territories. In 1943 more than three thousand young women went to Poland to prepare for their careers." [p34]In explaining how she felt about her time in service the author states one person's account, "[S]he saw in the streets at the edge of the ghetto two long rows of charred Jewish bodies. Like Schucking and Struwe, she could hardly avoid witnessing the mass murder. She did not condone it, but she could not stop it either." [p96]Although after the war very few females as a percentage of those who served the fatherland were tried, those who were were generally treated far more leniently than the men. "F]emale defendants could exploit the latter prejudice to their advantage. Interrogators and investigators judged women based on their emotion response. Court officials noted when women cried during questioning or proceedings." [p168] The author puts that last statement into perspective, "[I]n the first decade after the war - twenty six women were sentenced to death for crimes committed in medical facilities and concentration camps." [p169]The book is filled with individual stories of a select few women or their families who agreed to talk to the author about their war time experiences.  It is understandable why not more were willing to discuss this topic. But as someone much more learned than I once intoned, "Those not willing to learn from history are doomed to repeat it!"This was simply an intriguing history that dispelled the biggest misconceptions about the female participants of this Nazi regime and those were that their participation in number was small and that they were NEVER willing participants in the cruelty met out. Very Highly Recommended for those interested in the history of the period!

As the distance that the units correspond with each other is determined by what is between them it is good to know some practical limitations or distances at which it will work.  The baby's unit and parental unit worked well about 75 feet apart on the same floor and about 50 feet apart on different floors, and there was a large steel support beam separating them that could have caused interference, but didn't seem to in our instance.The main features of the unit are:1. It has 4 sensitivity settings - We only used the the two highest settings, but, hey, we are also grandparents - maybe that explains it :-)  a. Highest - you can hear everything going on in the baby's room  b. High - you can hear the softest sounds but not extraneous background noise  c. Medium - you can hear definite vocalizations, but normally not burbling  d. Low - the baby has to cry or yell for you to hear him/her2. It has a temperature range setting which gives both a visual warning and auditory alert if the temperature were to get outside the range you set.  We found that it went off a few times when set near lamp as the heat from the bulb caused it to get higher than we had it set for, so don't set the unit under a lamp or at least don't have the bulb on. But that function did work as advertised and would be a blessing in case a fire just starting.3. It comes with a built in nightlight.4. It is supplied with 5 different lullabies to which you can adjust the loudness.5. You can talk to the baby to reassure it or simply to communicate with it by pressing a button on the parental unit, like an old fashioned walkie-talkie!6. It is comes with a rechargeable battery pack for the parental unit which can also be plugged in, in which case the batteries aren't needed.  Be aware that it does take a full ten hours to charge the battery pack the first time or if it gets totally run down. You could keep it plugged in and then only need to use the battery pack when moving about in which case the batteries would hardly get run down at all.  The base or baby unit also runs off electricity but takes 4-AA batteries, which can be the standard type or rechargeable if you prefer those.  They are not included with the unit. The parental unit does come with a removable wrist strap.6. A really neat item besides the temp sensor was the automatic count down feeding timer.  You can set it for a one time use and change the time periods each time or it will repeat on a set schedule.  It gives both a visual and auditory alert telling you it is time to feed the baby.7. It gives complete directions in English, Spanish, French, and Portuguese.A worthwhile device for both parents or grandparents taking care of a little one [even on a part time basis] as are we.

The author constructs eight moderate length short stories concerning the lives of typical blue collar workers who simply do the same job day after day with little real expectation of hope for a brighter future although they may mouth such things to others for appearance sake. These are basically stories of people who either never had much of chance or through a series of their own bad choices ruined whatever chances they had. There is no light at the end of the tunnel for the main character, who acts as a narrator of each tale.  Most of the stores have the undercurrent of some unnamed war running through them without the exact war ever being named.The stories give a different if depressive viewpoint than most stories you read and because of their nihilism they really lack the resolution most people desire in reading fiction, even when it closely approximates real life events. I would like to offer a brief synopsis of the eight stories:1. Cartography - Rex gets fired from his job as a cartographer for an internet design studio when he rejects the unwanted sexual advances of his male boss. Yet some time after being unemployed he accidentally runs into his old boss and ....2. Paranoia - A white guy named Dean is walking through a rough black neighborhood, when three tough looking blacks call to him. What can this mean and should he run and run to where in this neighborhood.3. Appetite - A short order cook named Ike tires to get a raise from his boss to take out a waitress and impress her more, but is shot down when the boss complains about several meals being sent back. Ike feels that this isn't the night to ask for a raise, but when WOULD BE a good time in his situation?4. Associate - Nick McDonough is an assistant manager at a Wal-Mart store but has sticky fingers to make ends meet. He is also trying to impress the daughter of the guy buying his illegally gotten goods.5. Brief Encounter With the Enemy - the only actual war story. Luke is on the final day of a one year tour of duty in which he has escaped actually encountering an enemy combatant. He has hours to go before being shipped home when he spots something or someone.  "A tall, bald, fat man, maybe fifty, maybe younger: The enemy...He was walking with something, a sheep or a goat." [p119] Luke takes aim through his rifle sight and what then?6. Enchantment - Jake Mattingly returns from his deployment with the military to his old job as a sixth grade teacher and also to continue his affair with a wealthy married woman.  His life has had ups and downs, but mostly downs.  His boss asks him to house sit his rather large and expensive house while he goes on an extended vacation for several months. Jake loves the idea of entertaining his paramour in these surrounding rather than his 15'x15' efficiency in the slums, but Jake makes one crucial error in judgment.7. Operators - Zeke starts out after high school as a mailboy for a large concern.  After three years he works his way up to online sales and recommends a high school buddy for his old job.  His friend Wally joins the military after three months, then comes back a hero after a year of deployment.  Wally was nothing when he left, and Jake is somewhat jealous at the reversal of how people see each of them now.  So what does he do?8. Victory - Max, a janitor at a large grocery store is attracted to a 22yo moderately attractive shoplifter, Amanda, and against better judgment frees her from the store detective before she can be arrested.  He falls for her but has a partially crippled left arm that embarrasses him, preventing him from engaging in any prior romantic interludes. His real ambitions in life are to consummate a sexual liaison with Amanda and move up in the store restaurant to the coffee bar.The stories were enjoyable but still depressing, dyspeptic and somewhat dystopian although still entertaining.  Just don't expect to feel happy after you finish the book or you won't enjoy it near as much.  The last story is the only one with much resolution and that is only because Max sets the bar to success so low.

The story concerns a 75yo widow named Ruth Field and her caretaker Frida Young.It seemed that one day Frida simply showed up on Ruth's doorstep claiming she had been sent as part of an Australian government program providing limited assistance to people handicapped in some way and needing assistance with daily living chores.We recognize early on in the story that all is not right with Ruth when she claims there is a tiger that invades her house on some nights, but that he has never threatened her YET.  She knows it is a BOY tiger because of his smell and the type of noises he makes.  This would appear to be the ramblings of a senior with dementia except the Frida shortly after speaking with Ruth claims to have heard, then seen, and finally fought with the mysterious tiger herself. She even produces three supposed claw marks on her forearm from the fight with the tiger, who she managed to chase off that night before he could harm Ruth.When Frida first arrives [p5 of the advanced copy] she tells Ruth, "I'm not a guest. I come for an hour every morning same time every day...I'm not a stranger, and I am not a friend.  I am your right arm. I'm the help you're giving yourself." But very quickly her duties expand to 3 hours/day and then to seven days a week as a live-in health care provider. The strange part is that she takes on all the extra duties for a mere pittance of an additional salary beyond what the government pays her. Ruth feels somewhat embarrassed by the salary she pays, but can't afford to look a gift horse in the mouth. But maybe she should because when something seems too good to be true, it generally is. As Frida offers to do more and more, Ruth becomes ever more dependent.  In fact Ruth has a weekend liaison with old lover, Richard Porter a doctor now aged 80, she has not seen for 50 years. Frida seems very protective of Ruth with Richard and even with Ruth's own sons, Jeffrey and Phillip, yet by now Frida has taken to calling her "Ruthie" and treats her in a childlike manner.  Since we won't find out the true motivation for Frida's actions until the final quarter of the book, I won't spoil it.  But I can say that the final denouement is worth the wait.A well written story with very good character development that slyly turns itself into a page turner keeping the reader in suspense as to each character's motivations and psyches.  Highly recommended

I had the opportunity to try it out at the range today and liked it a lot.  As typical this time of year down south, the sky changed from bright sunlight to deeply overcast in minutes and then back again a short time later, but we avoided rain.  The point being that I liked the optical characteristics in all light conditions experienced today.  The sun was not in my eyes at any time, thankfully. I felt the optics were bright and the contrast sharp at all optical levels. I did notice some aberration at the highest zoom levels and also had to remove my glasses to get the whole field at that level, but not at the lower levels; for those not wearing glasses this will never come into playI felt that both the coarse and fine adjustment knobs worked smoothly throughout their range with very little resistance and were as good as with scopes costing three times as much. The fog resistant and water resistant lens were definitely a plus as was the lens shade to help eliminate glare from the sun.  It was also easy to mount it to my camera tripod, which is an intermediately priced Ambico. Due to the weight distribution design of the scope, the tripod never gave the feeling that it might tip over.  It also has an easy lock adjustment to allow you to turn the scope for viewing from either side once mounted so that you don't have to look straight down.  I tried it at 15meters, 50 yards and 100 yards plus about 200 ft in my back yard later. I liked it all those distances and feel it would do well at much further ranges. In fact at the 200 feet in my backyard, I soon discovered what I think was a vole scampering through the bushes, as the dogs were inside at the time.As other reviewers have mentioned, I think the case could use a little more padding, but plan to keep it in the box it came in except for taking it from the car to the range stands/benches, but that takes nothing away from the scope.  I also liked the major optic end cap and found it very easy to get on and off as was the eyepiece. The other caps were simply the slip on rubber types, but fit well.It also has separately purchased adapter rings to mount either 52mm or 58mm objects as a camera to it. Basically everything worked as it should, the lifetime warranty is great with a no questions, hassles or fault claims meaning no proof or date of purchase is necessary if it ever gets damaged or quits working, simply a 10.00 fee to cover return shipping. When is the last time you saw such a warranty. The company is located in Whitmore Lake, Michigan, although the scope is manufactured in China.  Great scope for the money - what else can be said.

"'Today girls,' said Miss Renshaw, we shall go out into the beautiful garden and think about DEATH.'" [P3] From the opening we know that sinister things will happen.The vast majority of the story takes place at a private school for girls in Sydney, Australia during 1967 while the Vietnam War was going on.  Our story concerns the teacher, Miss Renshaw, and the eleven girls in her elementary class named Cubby, Icara, Martine, Bethany, Georgina, Cynthia, Dierdre, Elizabeth, Elizabeth, Elizabeth, and Elizabeth.  The four Elizabeths are given no last names, and only differentiated by physical characteristics as height and hair style.It seems that Ms. Renshaw has more than a passing interest in Morgan, the groundskeeper at the Ena Thompson Memorial Gardens where she regularly takes the girls on nature trips. She makes the girls complicit in her romantic diversions by telling them, "We won't mention these meetings with Morgan or other stuff will we girls...We won't mention Morgan." [p19] But the girls were a lot smarter than Miss Renshaw gave them credit for, as "They all knew...the real reason Miss Renshaw want to go out into the gardens that morning. It was not to think about death. Miss Renshaw wanted to see Morgan."Soon after Miss Renshaw takes her class, with Morgan leading them, to some nearby Aboriginal caves supposedly to see the cave drawings at which time she and Morgan vanish. Yet as the girls pledged not to reveal anything about Morgan, they can't fully tell what happens to the authorities.  The rest of the book is about just what happened and how it affects each of their lives.The book is a close copy of an earlier book along very similar lines which was originally released by another Australian author Joan W. Lindsay in 1967 and was called PICNIC AT HANGING ROCK Picnic at Hanging Rock after which a 1975 movie also titled Picnic at Hanging Rock (The Criterion Collection) by Peter Weir was made.  The only major plot difference between those two items and the current story is that in the PICNIC version the story takes place on Valentines Day of 1900 and two girls plus a teacher go missing. That book and the movie are also highly recommended.Later in this story the girls get into a lively discussion about whether ghosts really exist, and if they do, can they live outdoors or must they be confined to interiors.  The relevance of this doesn't become important until near the end of the book, so I won't spoil it for you, but do pay attention to who says what about it. Here it differs from the PICNIC book version.The current story is very well told with a somewhat feminine and romantic writing style that imparts enough mystery to attract adults interested in some good clean scary storytelling. Highly recommended.

This is a wonderfully told humorous road trip story about a couple, the author David Rosenfelt and his wife Debbie, plus 11 true friends who helped them moved their 25 rescued dogs of various lineages from Orange County, CA to near Damariscotta Lake, Maine using three rented RVs in 2011.As the author says early in the story on page 4, "[T]he difference between an ordeal and an adventure is attitude. That's how I knew I was in for an ordeal."In self-deprecating and humble style the author states that 25 is probably the smallest number of dogs they had at any one time in the ten years prior to their cross country adventure, with 42 being the maximum number and 31/32 being about the average.  He also gives full credit to the other males in his party as being real men, while he generally portrays himself as a bit of a nebbish in the vein of Woody Allen.The author and Debbie started a non-profit dog rescue called the TARA Foundation in honor of Debbie's best dog of all time, a golden she still longs for.  David and Debbie keep Tara alive by writing her into his Andy Carpenter  series in which Tara started off as a 7yo Golden and elven years later has only aged to 9yo.  The author says she will never get serous sick or hurt in his novels, nor will she ever die, but she may miraculously get younger if it suits him. :)An idea of the clean type of humor told throughout the book is the experience the author had in trying to book some rooms outside Salt Lake City prior to the move back East. When the motel clerk told him there would be a 50.00/pet cleaning deposit for each dog under 30 pounds and 75.00 for each dog over 30 pounds he said, "I hadn't done the math, but I was pretty sure we would be traveling with over a ton of dog, so the cleaning deposit would probably be the GDP of a third world country." [p64]I personally liked the chapter in which Charleston Heston adopts Willie, a chow mix from the author, as I also rescued a chow/golden mix as a puppy, I named Leo, and who is now 12+yo. As with all animal lovers, a picture of Leo is visible on my profile page.This is simply a heartwarming story of love and caring for animals told with insight and humor sure to warm the hearts of all dog/animal lovers and well worth the read.

This is a story of multiple seductions, but in many of the cases you begin to wonder who seduced whom.The basic story involves Calvin and Kristien Stevens, a couple in their fifties who are forced to leave California when Kristin's job is lost due to budget cuts in 2010, and she is offered a new administrative position at North Shore State College north of Boston. Cal, who is small time builder figures he can build and repair homes in MA as well as CA, so readily agrees to the move.The book is simply full of great lines as when Kristen apprises her current situation, "Clearly she'd cut her own losses settling for less than she sought in every respect, becoming an administrator rather than the professor and literary critic she set out to be, and leaving a top-tiered university for a third rate state college because she had no other choices.  She'd lost the man she loved and married another one for something less than love." [p107] A great summation of the basic plot line by this character.A little later a humorous reference to HARD TAFFY, which turns an otherwise bland character into something much more. I won't spoil that reference with further comment.Another great line is attributed to Matt Drinnan, the somewhat younger lover of Kristin, who conjectures, "The stolen car [his] didn't worry him nearly as much as the message from Kristen.  The automobile was insured, The relationship wasn't." [p201]As the story winds down and Kristin contemplates the choices she has made in life, she conjectures, " She knew that when she returned home and went into the bathroom to wash off her makeup, she'd see the face of a woman for which life has no more surprises." [226]As this review is from a pre-publication version of the novel, the page number cites may or may not be different in the official publication version.In reading this novel it was easy to suspend disbelief as all the characters and their various personalities were very well developed and could have been your next door neighbors or even family members.  Highly recommended!

The story takes place in the area around Sussex, England with two central characters. The first is our narrator, a boy of seven who is never named and the second is his companion and protector named Lettie Hempstock, who says she is eleven and has been that age for some time.Our narrator in remembering his boyhood home says, "I stared at the house, remembering less than I expected about my teenage years: no good times, no bad times. I lived in that for a while as as teenager. It didn't seem to be any part of who I am now." [p4] "I was not happy as a child, although from time to time I was content.  I lived in books more than I lived anywhere else." [p13]The story begins with someone apparently trying to give money away with disastrous results. The narrator remembers he awoke choking one night and somehow found a silver shilling had gotten stuck in his throat, but can't figure out how that could happen.We get the idea that the Hempstocks, [Lettie, her mother Ginnie, and her grandmother] really are an OLD English family when our narrator asks Lettie's grandmother, who is referred to as Old Mrs. Hempstock, how old she is and she replies, "Old enough...I remember when the moon was made." [p33]But then the story takes a different direction when narrator's mother has to get a job due to financial necessity and therefore hires a housekeeper/nanny, named Ursula Monkton to look after him and his 5yo sister. But it turns out Ursula is more than what she appears to be. The narrator's sister gets along fine with Ursula, but Ursula seems to wish harm upon the young boy for reasons he can't figure out.Somewhat well into the book we get further guidance as to just how unique the Hempstock family is when our narrator sees the grandmother sleeping a long while and asks Lettie if they shouldn't awaken her, to which Lettie replies, "It doesn't wok like that...When she gets tired she sleeps till she wakes up on her own. A few minutes or a hundred years. There's no waking her." [p150]With a unique ending which explains the whole situation this is great adult fairytale reminiscent of Stephen King.  With an absence of four-lettered words this makes a great read for everyone old enough to understand the nuances. Kudos to the author.

This was an inspirational work of fiction that somehow rang true and was believable.The hobo, Barfield, our human protagonist of the story loses his farm, his wife, his son, his farm, and finally after many bad turns in life his will to struggle on. He is saved by Hobo the dog, whom he affectionately calls either dog or Mr. Dog. He prayed to God to send him a sign and he sent him Hobo the dog.The anthropomorphisis of Hobo the dog was cute and endearing, especially as the dog thinks of how to overcome each obstacle of his life which has a corollary in human existence. Most people can relate to the trials and tribulations of both Hobo the dog and Hobo the human and probably to the decisions that each have made with the knowledge they had at the time.Devoid of any four-lettered words, one can surely enjoy the book and its inspirational message as well as being a tear-jerker at times.  I personally loved the part where Hobo the dog pledges to return to the young female vet who saved his life regardless of what and how long it takes.One of my favorite lines is where the trucker, Big Al, in describing another dog he rescued says, ""[His] mother must have been a dance hall girl and the father a 'travelin' man." [p242]It was simply a pleasant story to read and I especially liked the afterward in which the author explained where he got the idea for each of the characters in the book.  It simply seperated the fact from fiction and was duly appreciated.

This was a rather twisted psychological tale of the intertwining of two opposite personality types. The two were Tess, a 38yo dark haired beauty with severe Bipolar disorder as we learn fairly early in the story; while her doppelganger, at least on the internet was Leila, a blonde 24yo rather dowdy loner, whose main interest seemed to be spending all her time on an internet forum site called RedPill.com.uk that was a place to discuss all things philosophical. One other character of importance in all this is Adrian Dervish, who is the originator and moderator on Red Pill.One of the topics discussed on the site was "Do we as individuals have the right to commit suicide." Leila thinks - YES!  She expresses this opinion on the site and Adrian arranges to meet her in person and then asks her to help him help another person on the site, Tess, to disappear from sight so she can commit suicide but not hurt her parents with that fact. I am not certain that disappearing from sight with no one knowing what happened to you is better than knowing you committed suicide. I say NO, but that is a personal opinion and goes along with the debate about euthanasia. So Leila takes months to learn all about Tess's past with help from Tess and Adrian. If that makes sense to you, then I fear you might also believe Reality TV represents reality for most people. Let us not forget to mention that Connor Devine, a 30-something lawyer, who had a torrid affair with Tess some years ago, at least in his mind, now has another affair online  with Leila posing as Tess. It's the internet, so they never have to meet in person, therefore, he doesn't recognize the difference between the tall thin brunette and the shorter blonde. We learn fairly early that Tess really likes sex, and she saw Connor as more of a multi-date hookup that went on way too long rather than the love of her life. In reversing the lyrics to an old C & W song, he got more out of it than she put into it!As Tess suffers from Type I Bi-Polar, she loves being manic and hates being depressed - which is the way it normally is, and why so many people with this disorder go off their meds. Leila is an extremely immature and lonely dependent personality type; Adrian appears to suffer from Antisocial Personality Disorder, and many of the other characters seem to be hippies living in a bygone era of thirty years ago. Plus the descriptive paragraphs in this book add about fifty unnecessary pages.You really have to suspend ALL disbelief to get into this story. It was not a page turner, chilling or intense as the back cover exclaims; what it was was an overly long psychological study of the extreme differences between Tess and Leila. So why did I give it two stars; I simply thought the plot line was original. The author has potential if she can lessen the descriptive narrative. One other character of some importance was named Ava Root. Don't you just love the originality of all those names? Sort of like a WASP Directory, just not in alphabetical order!

This is a rather fast-paced horror thriller with Zombies seeming to have wiped out the earth's humans except for some meth-heads living around St. Paul, MN. How and why this came about is the main point of the story, so I won't spoil it for you.In the first opening scene a little girl, with umbrella designs on her socks, appears to be down on all fours playing with her rottweiler. We hear a whine and whimper and as the little girl turns around we see she is covered in blood and rottweiler guts. Hey, I'm an animal lover so I don't think I would have picked on a dog as my victim, but don't worry, as these zombies get much more gross as the book moves forward.The story concerns our protagonist, Chase Daniels, the head meth-head, his girlfriend, KK or Kristen, his best friend Typewriter John or Type for short, and during the first part their main supplier affectionately known as the Albino. Don't worry as there are more people, places, and things to be insulted or mocked as we move along. In this reincarnation of the Zombie myth, they seem to giggle or chuckle just before attacking; thereby earning the soubriquet, the Chucks.Normally one would be for the meth-heads over the zombies or Chucks, but I'll let you decide who to root for. It would seem to be the lessor of two evils with no real winners.  The story does have a neat ending which, I think, will surprise most readers, me included. The book is full of obscenities and campy language in which a character might say, "It sucks you in like your Hoover gone psycho." ;-}It was a fun read, not to be taken seriously. But still, I'm not sure I would turn my back on someone or something giggling in a dark room!

This is a great piece of drama in which you don't have to injection a suspension of disbelief to envision the events as true or actually happening.  As others have said the film is beautifully photographed with great acting by Saskia Rosenthal.  She plays the 14yo daughter Hannelore Dressler, LORE for short, whose Nazi parents abandon her and four siblings as the Allies close in at the end of WWII, and the parents realize they will be prosecuted and imprisoned. The father simply disappears without further ado, while the mother gives LORE a feeble explanation of being sent to some camp. She leaves Lore a small amount of money and the jewelry she acquired over her lifetime, imploring her to use it to buy food, shelter and transportation for her and her siblings to reach their maternal grandmother's in the country near Hamburg. Considering that Lore's youngest brother was still breastfeeding when his mother abandoned the children, it is up to the now 14yo matriarch of this five person band to see them through.  Ms Rosenthal gives a superbly believable and highly emotionally charged performance.  That is the basic plot, but what happens along the way to Lore and her siblings is what truly makes this story come alive. Her ingenuity in employing  ways of keeping her family alive is amazing.  For all those loving drama this will keep you enthralled from beginning to end.

We find out that, "[B]y the late nineteenth century, people were swearing in much the same manner as we do today." [p230]But the author discusses swearing and taking of an oath from way back in ancient Roman and then brings us up to date while discussing a fair amount of neuroscience along the way. As we find out that most speech is a function of the cerebral cortex yet swearwords are a formed in the limbic system a much lower order part of the brain and is one reason why when some people suffer from dementia they may not be able to speak except for swearwords. [p5]But some parts of the history lesson just seems gross by today's standards as when we learn of the Roman latrine called a FORICAE which was a unisex arrangement with up to a hundred seats with no dividers for people doing the same thing at the same time. [p23] That may even gross out the members of Animal House! ;--0  There is much more revealing about the Romans that the author tells us about, but I don't want to spoil all the details for you.As we move to the middle ages in Europe we learn that "Medieval people would be much less likely to see representations of sex acts, but would be much more likely than modern ones to witness the actual performance of these acts." [p106] This was primarily due to two things, they generally slept in the nude and due to a lack of separate rooms males and females slept in the same room often with the kids and even servants of both sexes sleeping on the floor next to the bed. Hey,, somebody had to empty that chamber pot in the middle of the night.As we quickly move up in time we are told that "[T]he lower classes swear more than the upper and middle class...[as] modern attitudes toward swearing and social class are the legacy of Victorian social climbers who were afraid to look working-class." [208]There is an entire chapter devoted to just the F-word and it is interspersed with examples throughout the book, so if you don't want to see liberal mention of it throughout your read, this may not be the book for you. I found the book informative and worthwhile but some may see it a prurient.

Henry Ford was born on a farm in Dearborn, MI on 7/30/1863 and hated farming for as long as he could remember, while loving all things mechanical. He died of a cerebral hemorrhage on 4/7/1947 at his 56 room estate, which he called Fair Lane.  Although that is the beginning and end, it is what is in between that makes this so interesting.William Ford, Henry's father, married Mary Litogot O'Hearn, the daughter of a neighbor in 1858 when he was 35 and she was 21. Henry, in turn met his wife Clara Jane Bryant the eldest neighbor's daughter who had nine siblings.  They met in late 1885 and married on 4/11/1888. They had one son named Edsel Bryant Ford, who helped run Ford for a number of years until he died of stomach cancer on 5/26/1943. Henry always thought Edsel was never tough enough, but still seemed to love him, without ever giving him much in the way of praise. Yet Edsel was the likeable son who got along with everyone at Ford, and everyone seemed to like him, except for some internecine factions trying to curry Henry's favor by encouraging his feelings of Edsel being somewhat of a softy. It should be noted that people always addressed Henry as MR. FORD, and that extended to his wife and son.Henry's method of success was to hire the best man for each position he needed to fill, yet he was such an egotist and paranoid individual that he became quickly jealous if anyone besides him received praise for the their job.  If they did they were soon fired, and no one ever talked back to him or dared say there might be another way to do things including changing the Model T and stayed employed. Henry produced the first Model T on 9/24/1907 and the millionth one in December of 1915.By 1917, Ford had become the largest employer of African Americans in the USA. [p209] Yet this seemed to be negated by the fact that "At the end of 1913, the Ford managers discovered that that were having to hire 963 workers to be assured that 100 of them would stay with their jobs long enough to learn them." [p210]He started a company sociology department to help primarily poor and undereducated workers, which seemed beneficent until it was realized that the rules were extremely paternalistic so that he would only hire married men if they were under age 22.  They even had to get permission from Ford to buy the very car they helped manufacture.  And it was no joke that if you were seen driving another make of car you were fired immediately. "In 1914 the average Ford worker had 207.10 in savings. For those who stuck with the company the next five years, the average has risen to 2171.14." [p235]  This came about primarily because on 1/12/14 Ford reduced the standard work day from nine to eight hours, and at the same time increased the minimum daily wage from 2.34 to 5 dollars per day, thereby forcing all other automobile manufacturers to do the same.Ford certainly had his shortcomings and among the most severe was his EXTREMELY anti-Semitic stance, which he made public by buying the Dearborn Independent newspaper for that sole purpose. He ran 91 successive weeks of  anti-Semitic articles, before stopping by claiming he didn't know what was being printed in a paper he owned, and also paying millions in libel damages. [pp270-272]But Henry wasn't the dour faced Episcopalian one might think for he seemed to have kept a mistress for thirty five years, actually flaunting her presence at times. Evangeline Cote began in the stenographic pool in 1912 at age 16; three years later she was its head. To help dissuade casual outsiders from suspecting any shenanigans he had her marry another employee named Ray Dahlinger, who worked in various minor supporting roles. Evangeline eventually ran Greenfield Village. He bought her harness racing horses and too many other things to mention. He bought the Dahlingers a house as a wedding gift, a cottage on Lake Huron, then a 300 acre Tudor estate a mile from Fair Lane with 100 head of cattle, and on top of that a Curtiss Flying Boat. Not bad for a stenographer, huh??? He thought she produced him a son named John Cote Dahlinger on 4/9/1923. Although there was no DNA back then Henry treated the boy as his and showered him with too many gifts to list. This part of the book was some of the most interesting.As the author said of Henry near the end, "When I got to know him better, I liked him more, and less."  A very interesting read of the man who remains somewhat of an enigma beyond his public persona. BTW Mrs. Ford invited Evangeline to come and see Henry for the last time as he lay dying, so he could be with each of them. Mrs. Ford died in 1950.  Now that is one helluva lady.

Let me begin by saying the author has certainly done his homework on this subject. I am slightly familiar with this subject as I also collect first editions and antiquarian books. The story takes place in the 1920's and 1930's primarily, although some earlier material is included to set up the background for the main points discussed.  The geographical area discussed, colloquially referred to as Book Row, consisted of the six blocks on Fourth Ave from Astor Place to Union Square on Manhattan.It seems that the most important triumvirate set of book thieves consisted of Charles Romm, a savvy book dealer well known to deal in sophisticated first editions [meaning altered books, which had the effect of eliminating bad pages and removing library marks with a bleaching agent called Javelle Water]; Ben Harris, a Dane dealing in erotica, which was truly banned at the time; and Harry Gold, who was the primary recruiter and hands-on trainer for the actual thieves who stole the books from public and private libraries.We are introduced to Wilberforce Eames, who the New York Times called, "The greatest living scholar of books in America."  Another important figure was A. S. W. Rosenbach, PhD, who wrote regularly in popular magazines and papers about books and was a rare book dealer himself.  There were too many others to discuss them each.  But the main storyline concerns G. William Berqquist, a librarian, turned sleuth and who became an official member of the NYPD specializing in book thievery while his salary was funded by the NY Public Library.  He ended up breaking up the ring by assisting Sgt Warren Liese by getting Boston's most famous thief [Harold Borden Clarke] to give up his associates by promising immunity for the charges against him. It seems that Clarke and his associates stole from 34 Libraries in and around Boston, including Harvard, and then tried to blackmail them into buying their own books back to stop further thefts. He was also a well known second hand dealer and wanted to write a book about how book thieves worked - that is simply too weird to make up.The problem with the book as others have noted is that there are simply way too many characters to keep track of and most were discussed with great background detail, which seemed to make the book drag after about the tenth one.  Remember that these incidents happened over 80 years ago and none of these criminals were as well-known as say Al Capone was at the same time.  They were fairly successful, but didn't have anywhere near the same name recognition of the violent criminals of the era. It is a fairly short book that was very well researched, but one must truly be a bibliophile to appreciate it.  For those people it is highly recommended as it should keep their interest, but for most others, they will probably not finish it.

The book is about the author's love of dogs and her efforts to train psychiatric service dogs and eventually found a non-profit called Possibility Dogs, Inc to do just that.In the first chapter we a introduced to Bob, a burly ex-firefighter suffering from PTSD and helped along the way with his service dog Haska. In the very next chapter we learn of the author's own battle with PTSD, after coming upon a gruesome scene during a search mission she and her partner were not expecting and how this changed her life goals.Ms Charleston seems to have a houseful of mixed breed rescues of various sizes from tiny Pomeranians to her main search dog Puzzle, a female golden retriever. Although she dearly loves Puzzle she realizes that she is simply not cut out to be a psychiatric service dog, so she begins her quest to secure one wanting to train it herself.During chapter eight the author documents the traits she is looking for in potential service animals and how she goes about testing for them. In the very next chapter, which I found particularly interesting, she discusses some rather inexpensive modifications to the home environment that would allow a service animal to help with both physical and psychiatric task assistance. e.g. changing door knobs to door handles, which can also be very helpful to those with severe arthritis; adding a sturdy rope to the refrigerator so that the dog can open it and bring things from inside to the human companion; and adding inexpensive masking tape to a portable phone to make it easier for the dog to grasp and so that its teeth don't mar the phone. There were others but I found these simple and most beneficial.In chapter ten one of her Pomeranians, Misty succumbs to congestive heart failure, and just as the author is experiencing hopelessness and despair, serendipity happens and a neighbor who is allergic to animals has found a starving pit bull mix that very same day and knowing the author's fondness for dogs, asks if she will take in this poor bedraggled puppy, which she does and names Jake Piper [that's him on the cover photo].  Since the rest of the book is about her adventures with Jake and how he becomes a major part of her life, I won't go further. If you love dogs or ever wondered if you, a family member, or friend could benefit from a psychiatric service dog and what it takes to train one, this is the book for you.  Highly recommended.

Brontosaurus never was because lexicographically it should have been referred to as an Apatosaurus, since the name Apatosaurus was used first and the Brontosaurus existed as only a minor variation of the Apatosaurus. Of course, whatever you called it the animal itself did exist, however, in science, naming is a really big thing.There many things I liked about the book and a few, I saw, as negatives. First and most importantly of the positives, the author exhibited a deep knowledge about his subject matter, which is dinosaurs in general and his favorite member of that species the Brontosaurus or more correctly referred to as the Apatosaurus, in particular. The author described many facts that made the book interesting as:1. "Tyrannosaurus lived closer to us in time - 66million years ago than it did to Apatoaurus, which died 84 million years prior." [p29] Therefore the fight scenes between these two giants, most of us have seen in movies over the years, could never have occurred since they didn't live at the same time.2. "For all those stunning forces to exist, though, dinosaurs had to have sex." [p57] He describes how this theoretically occurred in a chapter titled THE BIG BANG THEORY. :)3. It also seems that we know more about about female dinosaurs due to their fossilized pelvic bone structure than male members of their species, since male sexual apparatus would be soft tissue and not become fossilized. [p65] But inquiring minds still want to know!4. It seems that paleontologists can estimate a dinosaurs age at time of death by bone growth rings similar to dating trees. [p69-70]5. We also learn that female dinos did protect their young hatchlings, at least for a short while, and this would have varied with different members of the species.6. Another interesting point made was that TRICERATOPS also never existed as a separate species but was the juvenile form of of a two horned species called TOROSAURUS. [p92]These were just a few of the many interesting points made in revealing a lot about dinosaur lives, but there were some things that would have helped dramatize the overall theme better and the first would have been more drawings or correct photos of the various species the author tried to explain with just words. He gave detailed explanations but as others have said a picture is worth a thousand words, and such photos or drawings these could have been used especially in pointing out the differences between say the Triceratops in its juvenile and adult forms, as the bone structure of the head also changed, which would change the way it looked.But my biggest concern was with the writing and extreme use of descriptive paragraphs as filler to make the book at least 25 pages longer than it needed to be. Let me just cite one example from page 140. "I remember exactly where I was when ARCHEOPTERYX [a bird like predecessor] was threatened to demotion from its place as an evolutionary icon. I was sitting at an Exxon station in the middle of nowhere Montana, waiting for my rented SUV to finish fueling so I could continue my journey from the isolated town of Ekalaka (where I had been looking for dinosaurs with paleontologists Thomas Carr and Scott Williams and their field crew) down to Thermopolis, Wyoming. After running into a convenience store to buy the requisite snacks and caffeine for my seven hour trip, I checked my messages to see if I had missed anything important while I was in the field."  I would consider NONE of that germane to the story of ARCHEOPTERYX but the type of trivia that might be shown on reality TV, which is an oxymoron itself. The worse part is that that wasn't the complete paragraph.  There were many other descriptions of roads leading into Dino digs and other useless trivia that simply took away from the flow of the story.The overall story was interesting, the author seemed to truly enjoy telling about dinosaurs, but the descriptive passages were far too numerous and way too long.
