Jordan and Kendrick do an amazing job with the music, as good if not better than Norton and Scott did, but I could only give it 4 stars because Anna Kendrick's lip syncing left a lot to be desired. I think also this movie can be really confusing for people who aren't aware of the literary device that Jason Robert Brown uses, so I'll explain it here. (Not exactly a spoiler!) Cathy's part is sung in reverse chronological order, so when she's singing, it's slowly tracing back from the present to the beginning of their relationship. Jamie's part is sung in chronological order showing how their relationship develops from beginning to end. Their two stories intersect at their wedding. I guess that's a spoiler, but we all know this is a love story, right? It's really helps understand the movie if you understand this, especially that the stories are intersecting at that point - the wedding.

For me, bright yellow balls are the easiest to spot on the golf course. These used to be labeled for older golfers and for women (i.e., people with slower back swings), but I guess the older men didn't like buying a ball advertised to women, so now they've begun labeling the pink ones for women and these for "men with slower back swings," (Marketing - gee whiz!) This is the same ball in yellow as in pink, so buy the color you like best and forget the labeling. I've tried the yellow Titleist (too hard) and Bridgestone (too soft), and these are just right.

Most of these ball washers are designed for you to carry in your pocket, leaving you with wet pants and people making jokes about your not making it to the restroom in time. This one clips onto your bag and comes in different colors. As someone who enjoys accessorizing, I like how the pink contrasts very nicely against my navy and white golf bag. Oh yeah, it also does a great job washing your balls after you drag them out of a pond, sand trap, or mud hole.

These short little tees are great because they have a color line that makes it very easy to sink your tee into the grass to just the right depth for your tee shots at par 3 holes. Of course, they are wooden, so if you get off a great shot, you often break the tee, but who cares? I just strut off the tee box saying, "Yeah, broke another tee with that shot."

This cord is so much better than the cable that comes with Apple products because it is almost twice as long. The standard cable is not quite 3.5 feet, I believe. It works fine with my iPhone, iPad, whatever.

This cord is six inches from the end of the plug to the other end of the plug. Too short to do much of anything other than connect to an iPod outlet in an automobile glove box (and I already have a short cord for that). I guess I was thinking the cord itself would measure six inches long. And it's so difficult to ever return things on Amazon, I'm stuck with it. Not the manufacturer's fault. My bad.

This ball washer does what it's supposed to, according to the other reviewers. However, it does not attach to your golf bag, which I think is more practical, especially for a woman who usually won't have a large pocket to put something like this in. I've already got my balls and tees in there. I don't want this big ole wet thing in there too. It seems more practical to hang it from the outside of the bag, near your towel, rather than having to get it out of a pocket. You can get a similar one from Ball-Brite that clips onto your bag. I rarely need to wash my ball when I'm on the green, (which is good because I couldn't do that anyway since my bag would be off the green and in the cart), so other than that, I don't know what benefit there is to having it in your pocket.

I am a great fan of the HBO GoT series, and re-watch all seasons every year while waiting for the next one to premiere. After the first season, I tried to read the books, but got lost trying to keep up with the myriad of characters and their back-stories. But as they say, the book is always better than the movie, as books reveal so much more of a character's thoughts and motivations, and this is certainly true of Martin's saga. Plus there are characters and events in the books which are left out of the HBO series. So after watching the series for a fourth time and now being very familiar with at least the main characters, and still having weeks before Season 5 aired, I again determined to read these tomes. While shopping for the Kindle versions of Martin's books, I came across Waiting for Dragons: Re-reading A Game of Thrones, and am using it as a companion book. It is very helpful at reminding me whom certain characters are and why they are important as the author often reveals back-stories and where they appear in future event(s). These are blatant spoilers, but the author assumes that, like him, we have previously read the books.The book is a blog compilation and many of the reviewers have complained that it reads like a, well, like a blog compilation. Other reviewers complained that the author is always whining about when A Dance with Dragons would be released. Except uh, wasn't that the exact and whole point of the blog? The Kindle version is even titled Waiting for Dragons. I don't understand people who give negative reviews because someone they don't even know didn't write a book the way they wish it had been written. And actually, now that Martin fans are all waiting impatiently for Winds of Winter, I find myself completely identifying with the author's comments about waiting for Dragons. And I found his sort of self-deprecating style of writing kind of humorous.I kept my review to 4 stars because I felt there was so much more and more important trivia that the author could have included and didn't. I find myself frequently going to the ASOIAF Westeros.org website to fill in things that this book only references.Also, I think this book would not be nearly as enjoyable were I not reading it along with GoT, so I strongly recommend it in that light.

I read the reviews of the different carousels and was concerned that with some of them, the bottoms of the Keurig cups pushed against each other so that they didn't fit properly. This carousel does not have that problem. The cups fit perfectly. It twirls easily. Enough said.

We bought this just as a backup coffee maker for when one of us didn't want to prepare a whole pot of coffee. We had previously bought a Tassimo, but never could find any decent tasting coffee for it. The Tassimo was like drinking colored water. However, the Keurig lets you select your cup size which of course affects the strength of the coffee. I researched the different models and this was the best buy. It turned out to be a timely purchase. The same day we got this, I was in an accident that left me with a broken collarbone and shoulder blade, so could only use one arm. But I was able to set it up and make myself a great cup of coffee with very little effort. There's no doubt that it creates a lot more waste than a pot, so we will probably continue using a full size pot most of the time, but when you have company and one person wants dark roast, another wants decaf, another wants tea, etc., the Keurig has cups for all that. Who says you can't please all the people all the time? I recommend researching on the internet the many different types of coffee offered because there are so many, no doubt you can get exactly what you like.
Fun Christmas song for country music fans
I think Dale's made this for people who drink decaffeinated coffee and cut their scotch whiskey with water. If you think Dale's regular is too salty, I suggest a shorter marinade time.

When I was a little girl, on special occasions, we would eat dinner at Dale's Hideaway, in Homewood (Birmingham), Alabama. The restaurant had this huge treasure chest and kids could pick out a free plastic toy after dinner - to a four year old, that was incredibly cool! Back then, if you wanted some sauce to use at home, they would put it in a coke bottle for you. Enough nostalgia; Dale's eventually began selling their famous sauce in the local grocery stores and then it spread across the Southeast. But we ran into problems when we moved up north and had to depend on care packages from family or packing it in my suitcase which always resulted in a look-see by the TSA. Somehow recently, we ran completely out. I tried a couple copycat recipes I got off the Internet, but there wasn't anything remotely as good. Then I wondered if Amazon would have it online. Of course, they did. The bottles arrived quickly and in perfect condition.For those who are new to Dale's, note that people mainly use it for STEAKS and it's for MARINATING, not dipping. It is also excellent for pork tenderloins. It is not so good on chicken. Haven't tried it on lamb... Marinate your steaks in a large baggie with just enough sauce to barely cover them. Flip them over about every five or ten minutes, depending on how long you're going to leave them in the sauce. If you aren't used to Dale's, don't marinate more than 20 minutes. If you love it, leave them in for several hours. If you think it's too salty, I suggest trying a shorter marinade time. Or you could try the low sodium version. I tried it once when the store was out of the regular. Bleah! For someone who cut her teeth on Dale's sauce, it was rather like drinking decaffeinated coffee. But it might be a good choice for beginners. Kind of like when people cut their scotch whiskey with water...

After years of recharging batteries, our cordless phones would barely hold a charge for an hour. We looked up the serial number for our batteries and found these matching ones on Amazon. They worked great and our phones now hold a charge all day again! The way to make these batteries maintain their chargeability (sp?) longer is to keep your phones off the hook and let the batteries run down during the day and then recharge overnight.

This book is continually compared to Gone With the Wind, but the writing is way below Margaret Mitchell's. It's more like a bad romance novel just without graphic descriptions of the sex. Amber is not a very likeable character and has none of the personality or intellect of Scarlett. It's mainly about a whiny, materialistic woman whose only good feature is her beauty and who chases after and clings to a man who cares nothing about her; he just uses her for sex now and then, and goes on his way when he's done. Come to think of it, he's not very likeable either. They both marry other people and cheat on their spouses. Truly, none of the adult characters in this book have any redeeming values except perhaps one old man that Amber tricks into marrying her. And be prepared for the ending which is so completely abrupt and without resolution that you will be throwing things against the wall because of the time you invested for such a cheap trick conclusion.One other thing I found annoying is that parts of the book just jump in and out of telling the history of King Charles II, as if it's a totally different novel. Then it will abruptly return to the story of Amber and Bruce again. Bad editing, I guess.Bad writing, bad characters, bad editing, bad ending, bad use of my money.

Has your experience in church been that women of the Bible are largely ignored? Churches have teaching series about David or Paul or any number of men, but sermons based on biblical women are few and far between. So this study had the wonderful opportunity to help Christians learn about some unique women in the Bible who faithfully followed God. Unfortunately, it has a lot of error and outright fabrication and that prevents me from giving it any more than one star. I like the way the material is presented and the application questions are very good, but if the lesson is not biblically correct, how can I recommend it as a Bible study?The workbook begins very promisingly with several good lessons on Ruth, Abigail, and Gomer. It first falters with the lesson of Mary and Martha where the author blames Martha's failure on a difference in "spiritual gifts." However, this is prior to Pentecost; spiritual gifts have not yet begun. Even if they had, there is nothing in the text to support this idea. Christ was explaining about his upcoming crucifixion in about a week and he wanted everyone, including Martha, to listen. This passage is a narrative, not a general prescriptive teaching about the gift of worship versus service; although it does teach us about the importance of choosing the appropriate thing to do at a specific moment in time. Too bad the author missed that.Kelley also inserts her own ideas into the lessons as if they came directly from Scripture. While introducing the second week of the study, she says, "most women develop their fullest potential in the marriage relationship." This is an opinion shared by the evangelical Christian community, (and has resulted in some pretty poor treatment of the singles within that community), but it is a cultural idea not taught in the Bible. Women reach their fullest potential through the imitation of Christ. And Paul teaches in 1 Corinthians 7:7-9, 32-35 that it is better to be single because then we are fully dedicated to the Lord rather than being distracted by the responsibilities of a husband and family.I was ready to overlook all this except I then read the lesson on Sarah and it bears little resemblance to the actual account found in Scripture. Kelley praises Sarah's submission to Abraham and glosses over how Abraham allows Sarah to be taken as wife by the Pharaoh - an act that is severely punished by God (Gen 12:17-18). Kelley shows either a blatant ignorance or disregard for the culture of that day and with classic "blame the victim" philosophy actually faults Sarah for "disobeying God" rather than noting that back then it was the men who made these arrangements and then subjected women to them.Kelly then moves to the Hagar/Ishmael episode and accuses Sarah of interfering in God's plan and manipulating his will. She states "Sarah experienced ... the consequences of disobedience. When she rebelled against God's authority, her life was shattered. When she repented of her rebellions and submitted to God's authority, Sarah was blessed beyond her wildest imagination. Women can learn about real-life submission from this strong-willed wife." The problem is that the Bible never accuses Sarah of any of these things or describes her in this way. Her decisions and actions are not criticized. Sarah is the only woman to be listed with the Heroes of the Faith in Hebrews 11. In God's original promises in Genesis 12 and 15, it is stated that Abraham will have many descendants, but it is never stated that Sarah will be the mother. So she and Abraham can't be blamed for thinking that this promised child was to come from another woman. It was a sacrificial and submissive act, not a manipulative one, for Sarah to allow her husband to have a child with another woman. Never does the biblical text indicate the birth of Ishmael was outside God's will or a "mistake." It is many years later before God promises specifically that Sarah will have a son and that he will be the child of the covenant.Another lesson that Kelley gets wrong is Eve's. Kelley states that because of Eve's rebellion against God, her children faced the power of sin. She twice calls her the "first sinner," and states that "through her life and lineage, both sin and grace entered the world." Kelley also implies that God banished Adam and Eve from the garden because he was angry at Eve for "tempting Adam." What the Bible actually teaches about the fall is that they sinned together at about the same time (Gen 3:6-7) and regardless of who ate first, it was through Adam, not Eve, that sin first entered the world (Romans 5). Adam openly rebelled - Eve was deceived (2 Cor 11:3, 1 Tim 2:14). Perhaps it was rebellion in his heart through the desire to eat the fruit that was the first sin (Mt 5:28). Finally, they were banished to prevent them from eating of the Tree of Life (Gen 3:22-24).In Kelley's world, husbands are blameless. If we women will just submit, God will bless us. There are hints of Job's friends here: Is your life not hunky-dory? Then it's because you're not a good enough Christian wife.Less important, but still annoying, there are occasional errors that are just sloppy research. For example, Kelley says that Jacob worked "for seven more years" after marrying Leah to marry Rachel. That's a common misconception, but actually he marries Rachel a week after marrying Leah and then works another seven years to pay off her bride-price. She says Eve had three sons and that all future generations came from them, but Genesis 5:4 says that Adam and Eve had other sons and daughters. In the lesson on Huldah, she incorrectly states that the Babylonian exile occurred in the first century BC rather than late in the sixth century. And she misstates Huldah's prophecy about King Josiah's death.Another problem is that she randomly assigns virtuous attributes to different women without any real biblical or historical basis. For example, she says that Elizabeth was the mentor of Mary, the mother of Christ, with no other evidence than the fact that Elizabeth is older and Mary spends some time with her during her pregnancy. She even says that Jesus praised Elizabeth's life when in fact Jesus never spoke of Elizabeth at all. This falsehood is unnecessary as the Bible does praise Elizabeth in Luke 1. Kelley creates an entire lesson around the "integrity" of the prophet, Huldah, who is never once described in that manner by the Bible. Kelley could have just have easily said Huldah was self-controlled, humble or faithful, or anything else from a grocery list of attributes one would expect to find in a prophet. The point is there is no biblical basis for pulling out this specific attribute and applying it to her.It gets worse with the servant girl Rhoda in Acts 12:12-17. Although the text is clear that Rhoda's joy is specifically and only related to Peter's escape, Kelley arbitrarily ascribes joy as Rhoda's permanent persona and attitude toward work and life in general. Again with no evidence, Kelley says that Lydia (Acts 16:12-15) "successfully balanced the priorities in her life." And she pulls from thin air the idea that Paul admired Priscilla's competence as a tentmaker. These things are never stated in the biblical text, meaning these attributes described by Kelley are pure fabrications. This kind of thing is simply inappropriate for any biblical study.Another problem is the failure to do the word studies necessary when using literature that is translated from a foreign language. For example, Kelley makes a comparison of Leah's and Isaac's eyesight by comparing two verses which both use the word "weak." However, the Hebrew word translated "weak" in Genesis 27:1 about Isaac is "kahah" which refers to poor eyesight while the word used in Genesis 29:17 for Leah is "rak" which means soft or delicate. (See Genesis 18:7 where Abraham selects a "tender" and choice calf.) Rather than the generally accepted nearsightedness that Kelley propagates, Genesis 29:17 appears to be complimenting Leah: "Leah had beautiful eyes, but Rachel had the whole package." Why does this matter? Because it changes the way one thinks about Leah, the mother of Judah, the ancestor of Christ. Oh yeah, and because it's simply inaccurate.Another example is how Kelley gives the word "helper" as it applies to Eve the usual American connotation of subservient assistant when the original language of Scripture carries no such implication and has been wrongly used to support wifely submission for centuries. The word means someone who comes to the rescue of another - it is most often used to refer to God himself as he comes to the "help" of Israel. It is used 11 different times in the Psalms, always as a reference to God, for example, Ps 33:20, God "is my helper and my shield."This failure to exegete also results in Kelley applying verses inappropriately. For example, while praising the Proverbs 31 woman's "discipline," meaning diligence, she refers us to Hebrews 12:11, "No discipline seems pleasant at the time." However, "discipline" here is the Greek word, "paideia," which has a completely different meaning than what Kelley intends. In telling us to be diligent and persevering, we are referred to a verse about instruction and chastisement. Compare its use in Ephesians 6:4 about children, "bring them up in the training [paideia] and instruction of the Lord." Not a big deal, but it's still Scripture applied incorrectly.My final complaint is her presentation of the Proverbs 31 woman as a "role model" for women. Proverbs is poetic literature. This is not a real woman, but the heroic ideal. Kelley misses the context of the passage. The Psalm says this is an acrostic (an alphabetical teaching) from a mother to her young son (prepared by Bathsheba for her son, King Solomon, the author of Proverbs, using the pseudonym of King Lemuel). Kelley misses that this passage is not directed to women; it is advice to young men on how to recognize a godly wife. Fortunately Scripture doesn't tell women to aspire to be this woman. It would be like trying to keep the Law. You can't. No one can be this perfect, so the Pro 31 woman points us to the grace of God (Gal 3:23-29, Rom 7:24-25). Trying to be all that is impossible for most women and neglect of husbands or children or home will be the fallout. However, studying the Proverbs 31 woman can lead us to humility, repentance, and the grace of Christ - the one person that the Bible does give us for our role model. God grant us to follow in his steps. (1 Peter 2:21, Heb 12:1-3, 1Cor 11:1, 1 Jn 2:6, 2 Cor 3:18)

When John Grisham was contemplating a sequel to his great novel, A Time to Kill, his wife warned against it with the prophetic wisdom, "They rarely work, you know." He should have listened. This story is so predictable, but it meanders toward the foreseeable climax like a lazy Mississippi backwater swamp. Halfway through the book, I wanted to scream out loud, "Just get to it, would you?" Other than that, it was a typical Grisham legal thriller, just not up to par with some of his other stories. The one thing I hated most and could not understand was was the completely different relationship that exists between Jake and Lucius. I don't want to give anything away, but this nearly ruined the book for me. So unless you're a die-hard Grisham fan and have read everything else already, check out his earlier books first.

These songs are all great, including the new songs that were added for the musical. Actually, some of these new songs were originally written for the animated movie, but cut due to timing issues. And there is at least one completely new song that I think was written for the genie. What I didn't like were the vocals of the original Broadway cast. They are good, just not as good as the voices used in the movie - hence the four rather than five stars. Easy solution - I will simply create a playlist that includes the songs from the movie plus the additional songs from the musical. Just as a FYI, we recently saw the show (August 2014) and it was your typical lavish, extravagant, over-produced Disney musical. In short, it was great! Not as good as Mary Poppins, but splendorific, nevertheless, as is the music on this album.
Exactly as described. Able to hold large toothbrushes. I was tired of buying holders with stainless steel or pewter stands that corroded over time. This holder washes up beautifully.

I bought this book and waited a few days before I finally started reading it. Big mistake! Once started, I could hardly put it down. It's a gripping story that wraps up very nicely after more than a few twists and turns. Perhaps this is a spoiler, but I appreciate a book with an ending where justice is served. Those who were disappointed by the ending of Gone Girl will know what I mean. While some might not call it a completely "happy" ending, this ending does not disappoint.The book has an under-lying and barely noticeable sub-theme about whether God is active in the world and brings about justice. As a Christian, this made the book even more interesting. If you're not a Christian, don't misunderstand - this is by no means a novel from the "Christian" genre of barely disguised tracts hidden within a story; in fact, I don't think the author meant it to be a "Christian" novel at all. This sub-theme is not explicit. It is merely explored through the thoughts and dialogue of a few of the main characters and never gets in the way of the story itself.****SLIGHT SPOILER**** Some reviewers have complained about an important "coincidental" incident - yes, it may seem contrived - unless you are following that underlying sub-theme I mentioned of whether God plays a role in the world and brings about his justice in the end. As some like to say, "There are no coincidences." However, when you put this incident with the running sub-theme about whether God is active in the world and brings about justice, the ending may cause you to ponder whether perhaps God's hand was at work throughout...

I was part of the beta testing team for this product and, in my opinion, it was released way too soon. It has lots of bugs plus it has less features and a lot of differences from the Quicken Windows version which most people are used to and expect to find on the Mac version. I think Intuit released it early because so many people have asked for a product for Mac, but that's no excuse to release it before it's ready. Perhaps, some may say it's better than no Quicken for Mac as it's at least better than Essentials. That's like saying a three legged horse is better than a two legged one. My recommendation is that it's only going to get better, (because it can't get much worse). If you're already using Quicken on a Windows computer or have something else that works for you, I wouldn't purchase it. Wait about a year and I predict it will be much improved.What really stinks for the beta testers is that we set up our accounts on the beta version and was never told that the software would terminate at the end of the testing. (It was probably buried in some legal terms and condition doc that I agreed to.) So I assumed I would be allowed to keep the software since I was expected to use it for all my accounts. Not so. The software has now "terminated" and I am left with either buying this crappy version for my Mac Quicken file or going back to the Windows version and filling in all the missing months when I was using it on the Mac.Intuit's attitude towards its Mac customers is breathtaking in its level of arrogance and neglect.

This book presents two parallel stories of women who lived in different centuries in Afghanistan. The young woman in the 21st century is inspired by stories she hears of the life of her ancestor. At times, I got tired of going back and forth between the two women, but that was because I was more interested in the modern woman, Rahima. The saddest part of the story is how the cycles of cultural, economic, and domestic abuse toward women continue to repeat themselves in outlying villages where modern technology and education is still relatively nonexistent for the majority of families.Although the novels are completely different, this book has a similar theme and feel as "A Thousand Splendid Suns," a book written by Khaled Hosseini, author of "The Kite Runner." Both books are a revealing look at how the Islamic culture found in third world countries allows and even encourages abuse and oppression of women and the indomitable spirit that is found in some women who refuse to submit to the outrage and who struggle to escape and overcome their fate, even though it invites greater levels of torment by the oppressors.It also exposes how the practice of polygamy pits women against each other, the jealousy creating mistrust, thereby precluding women from joining together to fight for better treatment. Also, there is the heartbreaking irony of how these uneducated people - both men and women - blame and torment any woman who fails to bear sons when modern medicine shows that it is the man's sperm which determines the sex of a child.

Great until the ending which leaves most readers wanting more. This book was a little slow getting started, but then I couldn't put it down until I finished it. Except there was no real conclusion to the story. The author is quoted somewhere as saying she wanted it to be like Rosemary's Baby, leaving you with the feeling (SPOILER ALERT) that the devil was still out there in the world. Let's hope the movie rewrites the ending and provides a balanced books ending where justice prevails. I think we'd all like a sequel where a certain someone gets what's deserved.

I read this book because I was interested in the history of Scotland. Here's an outline of the book. Sexual voyeurism, brief character development, sexual tittilation, brief plot development, more tittilation, sex, sex, sex, exciting battle to rescue hero and castle, abrupt ending, regret for wasting time reading this book instead of something better.The story has potential, but too much attention was given to developing the sex scenes rather than to the story, the historical background and culture of that day, and to the personality of and relationships between the characters.

I bought the Kindle version after watching the first episode on Starz, which was great. I had to know what happened next. The problem with this book is whenever the storyline starts to falter, the author falls back on graphic descriptions of sex or torture or the two combined. I guess some people must enjoy reading this kind of stuff, but I'll be darned if I know why. I'd rather use my imagination and stick with the motives behind the characters' actions and the drama within the story. The time travel is an interesting element. If you like romantic fiction, it's worth reading, I guess. Frankly, I could do without the homoerotic masochism (or any masochism for that matter)  and probably won't bother with  the sequels.

I enjoyed the Native American perspective which was something unusual, but the story has a few unbelievable elements that distract from it and the conclusion is very rushed and ultimately left me wanting to know more details about what happened at the end. The story jumps from right at the climax of the story to three months later and neatly packages it in a too brief description. SPOILER ALERT! You don't even have a final scene with the main character and his love interest.I will probably skip the second book, but will definitely see this film. And could somebody please get an editor in here who understands that possessive pronouns don't contain apostrophes? The word is "its" not "it's."

I bought these so my phone and iPad would be hands-free. I often stream Netflix, etc. at night on my iPad and I need earbuds so I don't disturb my spouse. With these, I don't have to worry about getting tangled up in a cord if I fall asleep. When I first got these, I had many of the same complaints as you see in the other reviews. I didn't receive a small set of buds and they wouldn't stay in my ears. I contacted Jarv and they sent me a new pair for free with smaller buds that stay in my ears much better, especially when I took off the rubber stabilizers. Because the cord goes around the back of the neck, long hair can pull them out when you turn your head; using the hooks that come with it will prevent that. The range isn't very far on the blue-tooth, but that hasn't been an issue for me. If you get these and have any problem, check with Jarv as they will try their best to make you a happy customer. I am very satisfied with my buds and with the prompt service I received.

My husband and father are both huge Vince Flynn fans. After his death, they have searched for a new author to fill the void. The Hawke series by Ted Bell has been the best so far. This is the first book of the series and introduces the main character, Alexander Hawke, and provides the backdrop for future novels. The genre is a blend of espionage and terrorism. If you like Vince Flynn's novels, you will probably enjoy this one too.

I have an old generation one iPad that I mainly use in the kitchen to watch videos while cooking. The problem was always having to prop it up against something. It looks much better now that it stands on its own. (The Jets logo is only in the back.) This is just a plastic stand, but the dark black looks nice enough. Also, it rotates for when I am reading a recipe and want a profile rather than landscape view. Great price, too.
Amazon has made many of Baroness Orczy's books available in the Kindle store for free, in fact, El Dorado was, at one time offered for free here. This book is available for free at classicly.com.

Amazon has made many of Baroness Orczy's books available in the Kindle store for free, but there are a few like this one here that have a charge. This book is available for free in pdf form at Munseys.com.

Amazon has made many of Baroness Orczy's books available in the Kindle store for free, but there are a few like this one here that have a charge. This book is available for free at the Project Gutenberg-Australia website (gutenberg.net.au).

Amazon has made many of Baroness Orczy's books available in the Kindle store for free, but there are a few like this one here that have a charge. This book is available for free at the Project Gutenberg-Australia website (gutenberg.net.au)
Amazon has made many of Baroness Orczy's books available in the Kindle store for free, but there are a few like this one here that have a charge. This book is available for free at classicly.com.

Great catfood for indoor cats.  I have a few cats that kept coughing up hairballs, especially during the summer months when they seem to shed more.  I gave them this food and they seem to have a better time with the hairballs.  I also see that their coats seem very glossy and lustrous.  They also seem to love the flavor. No complaints from this cat parent.

Great set of cargo shorts. Well constructed and they seem durable. Plentiful pockets.  They have waist adjustment bands so you can adjust the waist without using a belt, though my son wears one anyways.  Nice pair of shorts.

A great read for those who are Agatha Christie fans, or just science and general knowledge fans.  Each chapter is dedicated to a poison and follows the A is for Arsenic, B is for Belladonna, etc.  Very thorough with references to Ms. Christie's books, it breaks down the history and science of the various poisons and really tells you how  a lot of the poisons work, many are very gruesome killers.  Not for the faint of heart.

This is a great academic/work planner, good for work too. I work in a place that the fiscal year runs July to June, and this is perfect. The paper is nice to write on with generous spaces for writing appointments. The rear has time zone and area code maps, a nice heavy duty plastic pocket, holidays and major events calendar.

This is a great smelling and clean burning candle in a very attractive jar. It is very heavy for its size, and we intend to clean it out when done and repurpose it.  The lid is also very nice.  It is a clean smell that engulfs the whole room without being over powering and without a chemical and fake smell. Very nice.

This is a lot of fun for kids. There are plenty of ways to play with this, and it is a big set, so it will occupy your child with loads of fun. Putting it together is something to be desired, and pieces you put on tend to fall off now and then. I already lost the rope ladders. Who knows where they are. But overall this is a big and fun playset. Sure to entertain your children for hours.

I was once a huge college football fan. I went to Penn State, marched in the band there, I named my cat Nittany. Over the past years, though, I've become disillusioned with the sport. It grew so big it was no long something I could root for.  I really had a hard time expressing what was the problem until I read this book.Point by point, but without casting judgement, this book illustrates just how big college football is, how much money it brings in, and what led to this.  And all of this really only happened in the last 10-15 years.  It's relatively new in its scope.The author does a great job of discussing stories and interviews, and even how it personally touched him with his family considering re upping their season tickets at Penn State.His writing style is smooth and polished and accessible.As I mentioned it really is a historical look at the big money in football. It does not really pass judgement, instead allowing the sheer volume of money to speak for itself.  He does go on to mention how college football is not only a cash cow for itself, but also has sparked a growth of non-revenue sports, and women's sports in particular.The closest that the book comes to really condemning the college football are in the final chapters, discussing how presidents of schools will not, and often cannot do things to make changes. A strong case is made for college football ruining higher education.Taking the good with the bad, this is an informative read for any college football fan, or detractor.

A decent enough product.  You insert a citronella insert and a fan blows the aroma around and you are supposed to have up to a 15 X 15 foot area of bug free living. Though it does work, it doesn't offer near the 15 X 15 area promised.  The light isn't that  bright, but does add a nice ambiance.  I don't like a super bright light when I am sitting out at night, that is the purpose of sitting out at night.Overall not bad, but doesn't work as promised.

First really good sleeping bag I've owned and it is worth the price, and it's really not that expensive.  it is a true 3 season sleeping bag, good for chillier fall or warmer winter nights all the way to sweltering summer sleeping.  By removing the hood and blanket lining you can control your level of comfort and warmth.The material is comfortable, stitching is well done, and overall this has a very well made feel to it.

Simple elegant beauty on a budget.  For the price do not expect huge diamonds, they are small, but made to appear bigger with the silver facets it is mounted in.Overall it is a nice size and good for when you want to look elegant without being too dressed up. It would look equally nice in a cocktail dress or just weekend date wear.

I used this when I was a bit jet lagged after a plane trip. It provided restful sleep. As with melatonin, it really doesn't' put you to sleep, but instead promotes a more restful sleep. This contains some extra ingredients that assist in calming down and getting to sleep.It is not habit forming, though I never use it for more than a few days at a time when I do use it. As I said it really helps in aiding in sleep when traveling, or when you are just out of wack with your sleep cycles

Tasty stuff. I fell in love with sweet chili sauce when I had them at a soup dumpling place. This is a good version of it. Sweet, with a subtle chili burn that isn't too hot, and good for most everyone, even those who dont' like "hot stuff".  It is great on chicken, or with dumplings.  My favorite way to make it is on grilled chicken wings, toss to coat when done cooking. Very very good!!
Smells great, leaves a fresh clean scent, very warm and spicy. It doesn't dry your skin either, and is good for hair and body.

This is great for dry skin.  You put it on right out of the shower when you are still damp and you'll have soft, smooth skin.  It is great for sun dried summer skin. It goes on smooth and is absorbed quickly.  I use it on my kids right out of the shower and no complaints for them. My wife used to use baby oil, now uses this as it smells better and doesn't drip in the shower and make a slippery mess.Great smell too

Smells really good, fresh and clean. It doesn't dry your skin either. I used this after a week in vegas and it really made my skin feel better from the dryness out there.  The bottle is a nice size to fit in your shower, but I did have a bit of trouble getting the pump to unscrew, once I did it worked perfectly.

he Keurig 2.0 is a big step in quality over the older models, but comes with a few annoyances.First off, this gives you options. With this machine and an approved K cup you can choose 6,8, or 10 ounce coffee size. You can also choose between standard and strong. These choices do make a difference. The coffee tastes more properly extracted and less like brown water. It tastes closer to drip or press.Where older K cup machines were loud and brewed everything the same, this brews much quieter and adapts to your tastes. I like a 8 ounce strong cup, while my wife likes a 10 ounce regular cup.  Now you can have that. This machine will give it to you with easy to use touch screen controls.The reservoir is decent, though can be bigger. It also is removable for easy cleaning or filling.  It also has a built in water filter, great if you have treated water. It also comes with a bottle of descaling solution. Better than using vinegar.The part of the Keurig 2.0 I hate, and the reason it is getting a 2 star review is because of the feature on this machine that only allows you to use approved kcups, made by Keurig of Green Mountain Coffee. Even some older pods made by Keurig aren't good.  It gives you an annoying "OOPS" message. Not good when I need my morning coffee.You can work around that, but you shouldn't have to. Shame on Keurig for making this with the DRM features, but you can forgive them for the step up in quality that you get with this machine. The coffee is much much improved over earlier machines and the options for sizes and strength make it a winner.

A fun, though redundant, game where you bang the hammer on a hard surface (not daddy's head!) and it gives you a score. Think of it like the hammer game at carnivals, except there is no one trying to milk you out of your money based on your performance.After a while the sounds and game itself get a bit old, though children and other simple minded among us will find the game fascinating for hours.Seems well constructed, though you'll need to provide the batteries.

The caddy part is nice. It comes apart from the handle for storage and cleaning. The compartments also come out of the caddy. All are dishwasher safe.The bottles, there are two of them, are an elegant  vessel for your accouterments . One bottle has a large pouring spout for a thick liquid, perhaps a ranch dressing or other non-newtonian fluids. The other one has a small spout with a trigger release, good for vinegrettes and other liquids.The bottle have measurements on them. Not a big fan of the rubber washer on the bottles, food gets caught in them, and if lost, the bottles will leak.This is a nice set. Good for summertime outdoor dining and entertaining.

This stuff works pretty well. It smells good. The shampoo/conditioner leaves your hair manageable and smelling nice. The body wash smells good too and cleans with a bit of a tingle. The deodorant is nice, but could do a bit better job. It advertises as being 48 hour, and I don't necessarily agree. I've had anti-persperants that worked a bit better.Overall nice smelling man care products
These smell great!  You add to your laundry and it makes a great smelling laundry that lasts a long time, even if you tumble or line dry your clothes!! Great for towels and sheets!!

This is a wonderfully small and portable keyboard for use for windows machines and android. Easy to sync, it has a great battery life and will make using your tablet, phone, or phablet much easier.It has a notch on the top to snap your device into.  The buttons are a bit small and it's slightly uncomfortable using for extended periods, especially if you have large hands, but otherwise is great for travel or taking extended notes
What is there to say, it is a good price for a headlight bulb. Came quickly and is easy to install. Bright enough for safe night driving

I didn't do my best at keeping the grass seeds watered, but I was seeing little shoots of green within about a week and all over coverage in about 3. Still in it's infancy, but the grass grew up consistently and evenly, We did have a heavy storm a few days after I planted and the rain didn't damage the seeds too much.  I like to sew by hand so the blueish covering came off on my hands, but was easily washed off.Good size for patching or starting a small plot of grass.

This would be a good beginner set for someone, or a set for someone who doesn't use tools a whole lot, I would not recommend this for a professional. They are of only so-so quality. Seem a bit cheap.The "Ratchet" mechanism is basically a design that allows you to slip past on the bolt or not the opposite way you are either tightening or loosening.  It works fairly well, and is a fairly good time saver for working on bolts and nuts, though sometimes you end up slipping off what you are tightening. Kind of a pain.Another drawback is these are dark. I lost one already because I was working on my car and dropped it into the engine compartment, I shone a flashlight, looking for it but because they were blackish, I couldn't see them. I would prefer shiney steel color; easier to seeOverall only an OK set.

Took these to a cookout, and were a lot of fun. They are well made, and though there is no net, you could probably play them with a net if you had them, it's perfectly fun to just bat the shuttlecock back and forth.The rackets are nice and well made and the shuttle cocks are a bit sturdier than the ones you probably had used in high school gym class.A great thing is the included glow sticks you can put in the shuttlecocks to play at night. They light up nicely and make for fun evening fun

This Drive is good for a variety of uses. You can store you videos, pictures, and more on here. It's plug and play so you simply plug in and it shows up, much like a thumb drive. A LOT of storage, so you won't need to worry about running out of space.It's also fast enough so you can use it as the storage device for a plex server and you can cast right from it. Not bad for the price

Thick sturdy gloves. These would be good for a variety of uses. I have many. I use them when I am spraying pesticides on my tree farm. I used to use traditional surgical gloves, but they always seemed to rip or fall apart, and what's the use of wearing gloves then. These are much more sturdy. They don't give up dexterity, though. so if you are doing things like working on a car, and you need to pick up smaller bolts and nuts, you won't be deterred.They offer good protection and long lasting durability. Only downfall is they are a bit hard to put on if your hands are a bit wet, otherwise these are great gloves!

A nice pot holder/trivet. It's smaller than you'd expect. Please look at the dimensions, it's fairly small, but that makes it good for a pot holder and so/so as a trivet. It is easy to grip surfaces, and has a slot to put pot handles, great as I use cast iron a lot, and this feature makes it even better to grab the pot.It's well constructed, and seems like it would last a long time.
These sound very good. Great bass response with little distortion and good all around sound. Fairly comfortable too. These sound much much better than their $14 price tag.
This is an excellent grinder. Very heavy and well constructed. Seals nicely. Has two compartments for the grindings and for the pollen. comes with pollen scoop. Can't complain. Very nice grinder

This is good for the young child interested in geography. The map is smaller than I expected, though big enough to see the images on the map and easy enough to manipulate the pieces. The pieces are thin cardboard and have a magnetic backing that can stick to refrigerators or other things.I mentioned it is thin cardboard. I think it may be a bit flimsy, and may not stand up to repeated use. This would be good for a one or two child household, and don't think it would stand up well to use in a classroom.

This works well to laminate things. One of the best features is the ability to select 3,4,or 5 mil thickness. The default is 3, and the unit comes with 10 sample laminating sheets for you to try.It heats up quickly. The feeder has guidelines for traditional 8.5 X 11 or photos, so you know exactly where to insert your paper. It has a feed release on the back to quickly remove pieces if you need.  You can also laminate cold, by selecting that option on the front.

This teaches your kids about anatomy and the parts of the human body, bones, nervous system, muscles, skin, etc. The template of the body allows you to put the wooden and magnatized pices in any order you wish and learn about where the parts are.  Though kids will start putting girl parts with boy parts, it's still alot of fun and gives the youngest kids practice with dexterity while teaching them a bit about anatomy.

This is a very detailed model for its size. It;s about 14 inches long when finished, and a great benefit is that it is pre painted, so if you do not want to deal with paint and all that mess, this is a god choice.  Now it's smaller than most models, so be aware of that. It's not for first timers or people with little patience.  I had to break out my craft goggle to work on the pieces.It's fairly easy to put together, the main difficulty other than the size of some of the pieces comes near the time of final assembly wen you have to put the main deck, forcastle deck and poop deck all together on the hull. Plus some of the pieces are so small, you can easily break them when you are taking them out. Use an exacto knife, and you'll need tweezers and/or small pliers for the construction as well

Vega one shake gives you plenty of vitamins with a healthy dose of protein to boot.  One scoop, one very LARGE scoop goes in 12 ounces of water so you'll only get about  10 servings from this container. It makes for a thick, viscous liquid that is quite gritty. I chocked a bit on it, as it was very thick. I wasn't expecting it. I mixed one level scoop with about 12 ounces of ice cold water.  I think that people who maybe have trouble swallowing may want to avoid this.The flavor is fine, but there is sort of an acrid aftertaste that I didn't care for. It's vegan, so it doesn't suggest you drink it with dairy, but you can mix with other smoothies you make, which is the better way to drink it as it makes it easier to get down and hides some of the grittiness.

Nice small backpack good for kids. Boys and girls. My 2 year old son loves it and puts his toys and books on it. Has multiple pockets for pens, notebooks, books, and other things. It is also good for overnights and trips, small enough to take as a carry on for airlines and trains.The inside is lightly colored so it's easy to see things inside.  It also has a name label sewn into the backpack for you, or your child, to put their name and contact information on .

This is great for multiple cats, it's lightweight, though not as lightweight as some other on the market, and has a light scent, and is not overpowering. I have a cat that doesn't like heavily scented litters and she doesn't mind this.  It is scented enough to absorb litter box odors and is scoopable.  As I said, it's good for multiple cats.

This is a cute simple book for kids. It's short, so you keep your kids' attention. My 2 year old loves the drawings and loves that the panda looks like his panda doll. My 7 year old can read the book by himself, so we can get the whole family involved.The point of the story is to teach manners, though it IS a bit easy to miss, they could do a better job at that, as initially Panda comes off as a bit of a jerk, but if you read WITH your child, and teach them about manners, it can be a fun tool to teach the importance of saying please and thank you.

I think this is a bit overpriced. As  the corresponding cologne isn't that long lasting, and at $20 for a stick of deodorant you really don't need it.  The spray alone would be fine to coat your in fragrance. The deodorant is a bit sticky and has a bit of an alcoholic smell, not as clean smelling as the cologne.It's not bad, but I don't' think it's worth the price.

This is a great way to get some extra veggies in your diet. It cooks like regular pasta. 7 minutes to al dente, but I cooked it for a bit less. I cooked for 5 minutes and then drained, cooked with olive oil, garlic, red pepper, spinach, and lemon juice in a large skillet until heated through, and it was perfect. You can't even tell it was made with spinach puree.Very tasty.

Okay Argan Oil. I use Argan Oil for a great number of things. I use it to moisturize, to make bath and body products, in the tub, etc. It really does have a lot of uses, so I really like having a bunch of it in the house. I've tried several products from this brand and have usually been pleased, but this one isn't a favorite.It came in an okay size. It's about half the size of others I've used with a similar price, so that's a bit of a let down. I didn't really like the consistency either. It's much more sticky than other Argan oils I've tried before, so that's not really good. It's not a horrible oil, but it also isn't a good one either. I wouldn't buy again. (I received this product for free in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.)

Great facial lotion! I have tried several products from this brand and have really liked the ones I've tried. This is actually one of my favorite skincare brands. After cleansing and toning, I just apply this lotion to my entire face and neck. I am even able to apply my makeup over it with no issue, but I prefer using it at night. Great rosehip seed oil! I have tried several rosehip oils and although this isn't my favorite, it is definitely a good one. I really like this brand. Great vitamin c serum! This has truly been the summer of discovery for me as sun care goes. Not the best.. I have tried several different products from this brand and have always been pleased. For this reason, I was VERY interested in testing out this new facial oil cleanser. I have used cleansing oils before, and love how hydrated they leave my dry skin so I was really excited to see how this one works.That interest and excitement soon faded when I tried it the first time. The scent was immediately strong. It isn't a bad smell at all, but I'm not fond of that much fragrance on my face. In theory, it was easy enough to use. Rub the oil onto your face, then rinse. Simple right? No, not exactly.The oil absolutely refused to rinse off, and I was left with an oily, shiny looking face that even the water beaded off of. I have combination skin, so this was definitely not a good thing. I had to wash my face with soap three times to finally get the oil off. Then the next day, I had an odd combination of acne irritation from clogged pores, and dry skin patches. I will definitely not be using this again, and I surely don't recommend it to anyone. (I received this product at a discounted price in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.)

Great hand therapy cream! I am plagued with some serious hand dermatitis. I can never have enough lotion, and tend to always carry some with me wherever I go. (I received this product for free in exchange for an honest and unbiased review.)

Nice eyelash curler! I have been using this eyelash curler for quite some time. My last one kind of exploded on me, so I really needed another to replace it. This one is a nice one. Neat Hyaluronic Acid Serum! I really like Hyaluronic Acid serums and moisturizers. With my dry skin, I'm always on the lookout for products with very hydrating results. Great personal lubricant! I've tried several products from this brand and have always been highly pleased. Their formula is fabulously water-based, and goes on slippery smooth. Really neat LED speaker! Please be advised that this is NOT a Bluetooth speaker. It is actually a really cool LED speaker that works well with an audio cable. GORGEOUS babydoll mini dress! I LOVE this style of lingerie. This is my usual comfort zone when I'm trying to be a little more attractive in the bedroom.
