This review is for the 8 oz. sized bottles.These sounded like a good idea when I asked the Birthday Chicken to lay these on me: Refillable food safe spray bottles that didn't have to be pumped in order to spray. Well, the BC came through, and now that I have use of them for almost 6 months I must say am a bit underwhelmed.The GoodThe bottles themselves are nice design and a good size. The round shape means that they stay put and don't fall over like the Misto pump style sprayer that only lasted a little more than a year. The short height means the bottles fit well on the shelf near the stove and are comfortable to hold and use.The dip tube is long enough so it bends to the outer edge of the bottle. This means you can position it so that it will spray as the contents get low even with the bottle tilted. I have yet to have either sprayer clog, which is more than I can say about the Misto.The Not So GoodIts usefulness is a lot more limited than I anticipated. The sprayer does not spray a mist, only a course wide fan shaped spray. You can adjust it so the fan is vertical or horizontal, but it's still a wide fan shaped spray. To get that fan shaped spray you need a fairly strong pull on the trigger giving you a forceful spray. Pulling more gently does not get you a narrower fan shaped spray, but a stream.While the course wide spray is fine for spraying a grill or a large frying pan, it is really easy to over spray a smaller frying pan. Holding it closer to a smaller pan doesn't really work either. Because you have to pull so hard on the trigger to get the fan spray, the force of the spray will cause more of the oil to splash out of the pan. This really needs a softer spring.If you're used to using Pam or similar aerosol spray on a baking pan, this bottle is not for you. The spray is too course and too wide to be effective.The UglyAs for cleaning, their website [www (dot) evooilsprayers (dot) com (slash) about] says: "Cleaning the Evo Oil Sprayer is quick and easy. The bottle section can either be rinsed with water or put into the dishwasher." Well, technically they are correct. The bottle can be put in the dishwasher, but what they don't tell you is the bottle will shrink, even without heated dry. See the attached pictures. It's a good thing these come in packs of two. I sent a message to the company via their website but haven't heard back yet.The Bottom LineThis is a great idea that needs better execution. The wide fan shaped spray is useful for some things but a fine spray option would really be welcomed. Since it comes in a pack of two, why not one course and one fine? I also don't have a problem with handwashing the bottles, but don't advertise them is dishwasher safe when they obviously are not.I'll continue to use the one good bottle I have, but am still searching for spray bottle nirvana.Update 8/16/15Shortly after posting this review, I received an email from Seth at Evo/Delta Sprayers. After exchanging a couple of emails a replacement bottle was quickly mailed to me, and it arrived a couple of days ago.I also mentioned my concerns about the course spray and the spray pattern. He was receptive to my comments and indicated he would pass them on to the appropriate personnel.So 5*'s for Customer Service.

This was my first experience with Boost, and I have to say I was not disappointed. The cocoa flavor is not bad, but it will never be mistaken for milk or dark chocolate. The consistency, as expected, was smooth and fairly thick but not unpleasant. It was neither chalky nor "grainy." Mrs. Boilermate said she detected a slightly metallic aftertaste, but I detected no aftertaste at all. Another reviewer said they detected a Sucralose aftertaste, which is odd, because there is none in Boost Compact.I didn't expect to feel any "boost" after drinking this (sorry, it was there… I had to use it) so I wasn't disappointed when I didn't get any. But there were no negative affects either. I do like the extra vitamins and minerals I get in a short shot.Overall, Mrs. Boilermate and I think Boost is a good way to get some extra nourishment in a reasonably good tasting format.A note about the packaging: I try to recycle my empties as much as possible. My county currently accepts plastic containers labeled "1," "2," and "5." These bottles are "7" ("Other") and therefore must be tossed in the trash. I would prefer a product in packaging that I can recycle.A note about Customer Service: I called Customer Service with my concerns about bottles that could not be recycled. The lady I spoke with was professional and polite, said she understood my concerns, and would pass my concerns onto management. Though I wasn't looking for anything (scoring coupons, free samples, etc.) I was somewhat surprised that they weren't offered. Neither did she ask my name" for their records."(Neither of these affected my rating of the product.)

I have used a FoodSaver in one form or another for the better part of 30 years. I prefer the horizontal (clamshell) style models as opposed to the vertical models with the slot you stick the bag into to seal it. I currently use a FoodSaver V2860 that I like so well that, even though it was working fine, when Bed Bath and beyond had a special deal on a V2860 I grabbed it to I would have a spare in the event this one died.With that in mind, I jumped at the chance to try this new top-of-the-line model. I like the idea of using wider (15 inch) rolls and having the ability to do multiple seals. I don't hunt or fish, but I use it often enough that I appreciate the added features.The first thing you discover about this FoodSaver Gamesaver Titanium is how huge it is. At 26 inches wide and 12 inches deep it takes up quite a bit of counter space. You also notice right away how heavy it is. I didn't weigh it, but it's got to be right around 20 pounds or so. Everything about it feels heavy duty. It has big rubberized vacuum and seal only buttons, as well as a big sturdy latch on the front. Though it doesn't show it in the pictures on the Amazon product page, there is also a smaller button to toggle between single seal and double seal mode. Unlike some of the new upright models, the accessory vacuum hose is not permanently attached. The lid is also large and heavy.As with many FoodSavers, it has a compartment to hold a roll of bag material. The bag cutter is built into the lid, as opposed to being on a separate piece under the lid like on my V2860. There are advantages to both arrangements. It's a little easier to gauge and cut the bags with the cutter underneath, but this definitely requires two hands. With the Gamesaver, the heavy lid with the built-in cutter makes for easy one handed cutting.As with all horizontal style FoodSavers, you can make bags with the bottom seal is close to the edge as you want.This unit is not only longer and wider than my V2860, it's also a huge step up from the counter to the sealing edge, approximately 3 inches. Unless you put something in front of the machine such as a thick book or a piece of scrap lumber you will need about 6 inches of extra material between what you're sealing and the end of the bag. If you do put something in front to elevate the bags you'll find you'll need about 2 1/8 inches between the end of the bag and the seal plus another inch or so between the seal and the product you are sealing. This compares favorably with my V2860, and considerably less "tail" on either end then you would get from some of the vertical models.It takes a fairly firm push on the latch to lock the machine for vacuuming, but the latch feels substantial. (It also has a "store" position to lightly latch the top so you can store the unit standing on its edge.) A touch of the big black "vac and seal" button and it quickly vacuums the bag. It also has a nifty little LED "progress meter" next to the buttons. I don't think it's any noisier than my current unit. This unit has an internal fan that runs continuously when the unit is plugged in. Like most FoodSavers, there is no on-off switch, so you have to unplug it between uses. The instructions warn you not to leave it plugged in all the time.By having two sealing strips the machine alternates between them, which allows you to do multiple seals without having to wait for the machine to cool down. Okay, waiting 20 seconds between seals isn't big deal, but it's still a nice touch. I also like the option of having the machine do a double seal, though the instructions advise against doing it continually. I did several consecutive seals just to try it out, and it worked as advertised.As with many of the current FoodSaver models, the tray inside the vacuum channel removes for easy washing. Unlike the Silver model, it does not have a 12 V power option.A quick (OT) note about the bags: While there are less expensive alternatives to using FoodSaver brand bags and bag material, it is been my experience that using FoodSaver brand is cheaper in the long run. I have never had a FoodSaver brand bag fail to vacuum properly. The same cannot be said for other brands. I have had particularly bad experiences with the WM brand rolls.The Bottom LineThis is a very good machine, and feels every bit like the top-of-the-line model that it is. It vacuums quickly, seals well, and accommodates wider bags than any other model. The limited lifetime warranty is an advantage.But at the time of this review, it is 2 ½ times the price of the "Silver" model. So, is it worth it? The answer is a definitive, "It depends." There is definitely added value to this model. Dual pumps, two heating strips, double seal capability, and wider bags all have advantages. These added features may make it a worthwhile investment if you do a lot of hunting and/or fishing, or butcher your own animals. But this unit is also considerably larger and heavier than any other FoodSaver model. For the average homeowner this could be an issue (counterspace during use and storage space). If I were spending my own money on a replacement for my V2860, I would probably opt for the Silver model over this one, which also has a limited lifetime warranty. That said, this is still a five-star machine.

Mrs. Boilermate and I evaluated Cafejo's Signature Blend K cups.While the coffee was brewing there was a nice coffee aroma in the room, and there was a nice aroma from the finished cup. As this was listed as a "medium roast" we brewed 6 ounce and 8 ounce cups. Though the coffee is listed as a "medium roast," we both thought it was more toward the "light roast" end of the "medium roast" scale.I like a fuller bodied cup of coffee, and when brewed with 6 ounces of water this blend met my expectations. Mrs. Boilermate also thought it made a fine cup of coffee with 6 ounces of water. When brewed with 8 ounces of water, however, we both felt it lost enough body and tasted a bit watered down — especially when I added half-and-half to mine. (Mrs. Boilermate drinks hers black.) Hence the four-star rating. (Actually 4.5.) My Keurig Brewer allows for a 10 ounce cup as well, but 10 ounces of water would be too much for this particular blend.Though not as economical, we often enjoy a medium roast blend by making two 6-ounce cups in one 12 ounce mug, using two capsules. While (for some reason) some blends don't translate well from one capsule per 6 ounces to two capsules per 12 ounces, this coffee is perfect for this method.Neither one of us detected any harsh, bitter, or off flavors, neither did we detect any nasty aftertastes.In general, I don't care for cold coffee. And cold coffee re-warmed is about as bad as it gets. As a testament to the smoothness of this blend, I accidentally let a cup get cold when I forgot to turn on my little mug warmer on my desk. Without realizing it had gotten cold I took a big swig and it was still palatable. I bet this would make a fine iced coffee.As the title says, this is a coffee we could enjoy every day. We are pleased to have had the opportunity to test this coffee through Vine, and I expect this blend to be added to our rotation. The packages we received are not Keurig 2.0 compatible, but that just means more for the rest of us.

I installed two of these on the rear legs of a wheeled walker. After approximately two weeks use, indoors only, both tips are showing significant wear. Not only that, but the tips list black marks on the floor. Out of the box they smell like burned rubber. Other tips I have used have lasted for months and left no marks. I returned these for a refund.

These were purchased in purple for Mrs. Boilermate. The size charts say "small" is 3 to 6 shoe size and "medium" is 6 to 9, and Mrs. Boilermate wears a size 6. Since other reviewers said these tend to run small I ordered a medium, and Mrs. Boilermate says they fit perfectly. She also says they're very comfortable and the grippy part is effective. She said she would recommend them and would welcome additional pairs.

I like the idea of using products that are "natural" and/or contain recycled content, but often times these products range from "almost as good" to downright awful. This is not one of those products. You don't have to sacrifice quality, as these sponges are every bit as good as their "unnatural" counterparts.Just like its "unnatural" counterparts, this two-sided sponge/scrubby cleans well and doesn't scratch. It absorbs well and easily rinses clean. It feels like it's a bit denser and stiffer than the conventional product but that is not a drawback in my opinion. Both products seem to have equal longevity.Another nice surprise was the price. Oftentimes natural products or those containing recycled content are sold at a premium compared to conventional products. Not so with these. They are priced competitively, and in some cases priced less than the equivalent "conventional" Scotch Bright products.So why only four stars? Out of the package the sponges have a decidedly "industrial" aroma to them, and that aroma hangs around for quite a while after the sponge has been in use. Despite the aroma I will continue to use these, and you should as well.

I purchased these for Mrs. Boilermate for her birthday to complement the matching necklace that I got through Vine. She loves them! She said there are a good size and weight and they dangle nicely, and they look good on her. I recommend both the ear rings and the necklace.

Our household has two vehicles, a 2011 Kia Soul and a 2005 Chevrolet Colorado. I selected a 20 inch blade and a 22 inch blade for evaluation, to put one on each vehicle for a side-by-side comparison with the wipers already installed.I've been using Bosch Icon wiper blades for about 10 years, so I'm already partial to the Bosch brand. These did not disappoint. Installation was super simple and super easy, and and the blades contact the windshield perfectly.The recent rainy weather provided an ample trial period. The new blades wipe well, but as they say, "the new broom sweeps clean." Longevity is always a question with wiper blades, but other Bosch blades I have used lasted well. The blades installed on both vehicles remained in contact with the windshield "at speed."Since other Bosch products I have used lasted well, I have the expectation that these will too, hence the five-star rating. If anything changes I will update this review and the rating accordingly.The Bottom LineBosch wiper blades are priced at the "premium" end of the market but as they say, "You get what you pay for." With these you get wiper blades that are easy to install, contact the windshield properly, wipe clean, and stay put at highway speeds. Highly recommended.

In my opinion, the purpose of a shower is to remove odors, not exchange one odor for another. As such,  I normally don't like personal care products with any kind of a lingering fragrance, but the description of the fragrance for this hair and body wash was intriguing, which is why I selected it from my Vine list. I was not disappointed.Though this product is described as a body wash and shampoo I only used it as a body wash. It dispenses from the bottle as a clear thick liquid, but not as thick as a gel. If you're used to lots of lather from your body wash or shower gel you might be disappointed, as it doesn't really lather. Despite the lack of a noticeable lather, however, it does clean well and doesn't dry out the skin.Though I'm not good at describing fragrances, I can say that this product has a nice masculine fragrance that is not overpowering. Some "men's care products" that I've used have a post-rinse fragrance that is so powerful it announces to the whole world, "HE'S JUST AROUND THE CORNER!" This is not one of those products. What remains after you've rinsed this off is pleasantly subtle. Mrs. Boilermate liked the fragrance as well.The Bottom LineDoes this "high end" shampoo/body wash work any better than "ordinary" products? Not really, but it has a sophisticated masculine fragrance that both Mrs. Boilermate and I like. I have tried other "men's care products" and promptly discarded them after one use due to their lingering fragrance/odor after they were rinsed off. This one is different. I expect to use this occasionally for some "personal pampering" until it's gone.

Some things are pretty basic, like body wash, shampoo, and deodorant. So how do you differentiate your products from everyone else's?The body wash: The marketing hype says, "Dove Men+Care Extra Fresh Body and Face Wash with MICROMOISTURE technology is clinically proven to fight skin dryness better than regular men’s body wash. This ultra-light formula delivers extra refreshment with a cooling agent, then rinses off easily for total skin comfort." I'm not sure what any of that means but for a body wash it was generally better than most I've used. I like the consistency, the way it lathered, and the way it completely rinsed. I didn't notice any difference in "skin dryness" after using this body wash. The fragrance in the body wash does tend to linger after you get out of the shower, a feature that I do not care for.The shampoo: Of all the products in this package, the shampoo would make the biggest difference. I don't particularly care for two in one haircare products because I really don't need the conditioner aspect. Having said that, I didn't deduct points for the combination. While it seemed to clean quite well, it did dry my scalp, which is not a good thing. Caffeine in my shampoo? It seems like more of a gimmick than anything else as it didn't seem to make any difference in the final outcome. When all was said and done, however, I did not see any difference between hair washed with this product versus my normal shampoo. Mrs. Boilermate didn't notice any difference either.The deodorant: This is the product that I'm least likely to use on a daily basis. I normally prefer a roll-on deodorant and normally don't care for a stick type deodorant. Having said that, consistency of this stick is better than many have tried and goes on smoothly. What I don't care for, however, is the fragrance. Based on how long the fragrance lingered, though, I would tend to believe that the "48 hour protection" claim.The Bottom Line: Neither the body wash or the deodorant seem to work any better (or worse) than the products that I use on a daily basis. What seems to differentiate these daily care products is there fragrance, and that fragrance, in the deodorant particularly, lingered far too long. The shampoo/conditioner didn't seem to make any difference on my hair but left my scalp dry.When I exit the bathroom following my morning routine I don't want to smell like anything. For me, the purpose of showering, shampooing, etc. is to remove dirt and odors, and not simply replace one odor with another. I don't mind a bit of fragrance while using the shampoo or body wash, but I want that fragrance to wash off when I rinse off. The lingering fragrance of these products is enough to cause me to pass them by, particularly the deodorant.

I waited until the last day before submitting this review to try and give this treatment every chance.I applied it twice a day on a thumbnail that had developed nail fungus. I wasn't expecting any miracles and I certainly didn't get any. There may be a small improvement in the appearance of the nail, but the yucky stuff under the nail is still there.The good news is there were no undesirable side effects. I expect to continue to use this as long as the bottle holds out and will update this review accordingly.

Mrs. Boilermate's Comments:This is a nice piece of jewelry. The pendant itself is a good size, and comes with a fine, delicate chain which is the right length to complement it.The Celtic knotwork around the outside lends just the right amount of intricacy to highlight the tree in the center. The price is reasonable, and matching earrings are available. (Mr. Boilermate ETA:I wonder if that's a birthday hint.)

Fabric oven mitts, while fairly flexible, don't protect well against steam burns. Silicone mitts protect against steam burns but are often inflexible and slippery. Enter this new oven mitt from All Clad Textiles, which tries to take the benefits of each and eliminate the drawbacks of each.I have large hands, so when putting the glove on it is a tight squeeze at the glove/cuff line, but once on its fairly comfortable. But even with my large hands the "mitt" part still seems a bit big and uncontrollable The cuff protects my arm almost all the way to the elbow.While loop handles on pots were difficult to grasp, I was surprised at how easily I was able to grasp and control the thin, long handle on this Cuisinart Skillet. (But this handle normally stays cool and doesn't require a potholder or mitt.)  For me, this All Clad mitt better suited for taking a roasting pan or baking sheet out of the oven.While it won't be the first mitt I reach for when I need protection from a hot pot or pan, it will always have a place in my kitchen.Mrs. Boilermate's Comments:This is a good, sturdy, well-insulated oven mitt. It protects the hand and forearm quite well. The strips of silicone make it easy to grip and hold on to hot items.One disadvantage is that it comes in one size. This may fit many, but it was too small for Mr. Boilermate and a little too big for me. With the mitt being a little larger than my hand and the heavy padding, it is difficult to get a solid grip on smaller, more delicate items. It works quite well for pulling large roasting pans out of the oven. If I need a surer grip, my Anti Steam Ove Glove still rules.

The Smoky Applewood BBQ Chicken variety of McCormick Skillet Sauce is a fairly quick and easy way to make a barbecue flavored chicken dish.First of all, I reviewed the ingredients list and nutrition panel. While I am not a believer of the "HFCS Will Be the Death of Us All" fear mongering, I do note that it is second on the ingredients list, with water being the first. The rest of the ingredients are fairly typical for barbecue sauce, and indeed, tasted directly out of the pouch the sauce tastes like a thin sweet barbecue sauce. A standardized "serving" will give you 8 grams of sugar and 320 mg of sodium (13% RDA).Preparation couldn't be easier: a pound and a half of browned boneless chicken breasts or thighs, with or without onions as you desire, and simmered with a packet of the sauce until hot. There is also a slow cooker preparation method.I prepared it with a pound and a half of skinless boneless chicken breasts. After sautéing some diced onion and green pepper, I browned chicken breasts as directed, poured in the pouch of sauce, covered, and simmered until everything heated through. I served the chicken with rice and spooning some of the sauce over each.The resulting supper was judged to be "just okay" by both Mrs. Boilermate and me. There were no strange, unpleasant, or offputting flavors in the sauce before or after heating, and there were no unpleasant aftertastes.But how does it compare to a similar dish using regular bottled barbecue sauce instead of this product? First off, we both thought the sauce was a little too sweet and lacked the "punch" of our two favorite barbecue sauces, Bone Suckin BBQ Sauce and Dinosaur Bar-B-Que Original Sensuous Slathering BBQ Sauce. Despite a fairly high sodium content, we both thought it tasted a bit bland, and neither of us detected any bacon flavor.The first ingredient of the Bone Suckin and Dinosaur sauces are tomato paste and crushed tomatoes respectively. Neither sauce has any added water. It should also be noted that both of these alternatives have about one third of the sodium that this sauce has per serving.Bottom LineWhile the preparation was easy and the resulting dish was reasonably good, for us it was not enough new and different for us to use this product instead of our favorite barbecue sauce. Overall score: just short of 3.5 stars.

I don't impress easily, especially when it comes to "every day" products such as this, because more often than not, claims made by the manufacturer don't hold up in the real world. This cream is different. Its claim to "instantly relieve dry, itchy skin" is valid. I have recently developed a tendency to have spots of really dry, itchy, and flaky skin. I've tried several different brands of cream to relieve these flareups with limited success… up until now. This Curel Itch Defense cream really works. I applied the cream to a couple of itchy patches and the itching immediately stopped. I also applied the cream to a very dry but not itchy patch and noticed an immediate improvement.The consistency is just right so you can easily dispense a small dab or a large amount depending on your needs. And, as advertised, it is truly unscented.Mrs. Boilermate has also been impressed with the performance of this cream.The Bottom LineIf you have dry itchy skin you owe it to yourself to try this Curel Itch Defense. I know it will always have a place on the shelf in my household.

Power toothbrushes have been shown to do a better job cleaning your teeth than manual brushing. When I switched from a manual brush to a power brush my dentist and hygienist both noticed the difference.For this evaluation I compared this Sonicare toothbrush with the battery-powered Oral-B 3d I've had for a while, and the Oral-B 5000 I received from Vine, evaluated previously, and has become my daily driver since.First the physical comparison. Both Oral-B units have a smaller diameter, but the Sonicare is still easy to hold and maneuver. The Sonicare has a flat bottom so you can stand it up, and also molded so you can lay it flat, bristles up, and it won't roll off the counter, a nice touch.The Oral-B 3d runs on one AA cell, and this Sonicare brush is powered by two AAA batteries (included, thank you).Unlike the other two battery-powered brushes, the head on this one is long and slender.Set up with stupid simple. Pull off the end insert the batteries put the end back on and you're good to go.When you turn on this Sonicare it makes a pleasant buzzing sound. If you have used in Oral-B powered toothbrush, the sensation from the Sonicare feels a bit different. The slender, narrow head means you can reach the back corners of your mouth better than with either Oral-B model.The Sonicare definitely feels gentler than either of the two powered brushes that I have used previously. The other sensation is a bit more disconcerting. Since the entire head vibrates (as opposed to the brushes rotating with the Oral-B models), when you move the brush in your mouth and touch the back of the brush head to your teeth, it will vibrate your teeth. The brush has a two-minute shutoff timer.The elephant in the corner for all power brushes is the cost of the replacement heads. If you have kids, replacing the heads as directed can add up pretty quick. Here on Amazon, a 3-pack of replacement heads is just under $10 at the time of this review. That's not too bad, in my opinion. In contrast, a three pack of Replacement Brush Head 3 pack for the Oral-B 5000 is almost $22 as I write this.Bottom OneIf you are in the market for a power toothbrush, and you should be, this Sonicare deserves your serious consideration. It is reasonably priced and the replacement heads are also reasonably priced. In my opinion there is no added value to buying the more expensive rechargeable models.

Mrs. Boilermate's Review:This is a really handy little gadget.With the cable included in the box, it is easy to charge up this battery pack from a USB port. It takes a while, but it does the job. If you happen to have an adapter to plug a USB cable into an outlet, the battery pack charges much faster. There are four indicator lights which make it clear how much of a charge is remaining in the battery pack.Once charged, it did an excellent job recharging my smart phone, Kindle, and Nook. It is very simple to operate. Just connect the USB cable, push the one button, and start charging. One charge of the battery pack can recharge my phone multiple times.This battery pack is small enough to easily stash in a tote bag or glove compartment. It could come in handy if my phone is low and I don’t want to sit in my car with the power on while the phone charges.It will also allow me to recharge my phone overnight, and leave the phone on top of my purse, so I won’t forget it in the morning.

I don't eat a lot of energy bars, but when I do I usually reach for one of the many flavors of Balance Bars. So this is the yardstick I used when evaluating these Vega One bars.The first thing you notice is how heavy the box is. Even the individual bars seems to feel "heavy" although it actually weighs just over 2  ounces. The bar measures approximately 1 ¼  wide by 3 ½ inches long and has a smooth dark chocolate coating.Reading the ingredients, I'm impressed at how many of them are organic. There is nothing artificial or unpronounceable here. Vegan and gluten-free are bonuses. I'm not going to waste space in this review rehashing the rest of the ingredients list or nutritional numbers. If you're interested in that information you can find it on Vega One's website, vegaone dot com.Considering how heavy the bar feels before you bite into it, the bar is not really dense. For me the density and texture are about the same as a Balance Bar. The dark chocolate and peanut butter flavors are prominent and the crispy rice bits provide a bit of a crunch. There are no unpleasant or off flavors. Overall this is a very nice bar.One comment on the packaging. I prefer the box with closable flaps as opposed to the perforated opening on the front of this box that doesn't stay closed. This means you can't stand box up in the cupboard without the remaining bars falling out. And guys, don't be put off by the pictures on the box. This isn't a "girly bar." If you like the Balance Bars I think you'll like these, too.Bottom LineI can see having one of these bars as part of my breakfast or my midmorning snack. If I saw these in the store and they were competitively priced with Balance Bars, there is a good chance these would end up in my shopping basket.

The first thing you notice about this beverage is how thin they managed to make the can. When you pop the top, you also notice that the can has a widemouth opening for easy drinking.For me, the mildly carbonated beverage has a pleasant berry flavor, but no almonds. For me, this is not a bad thing because I like the flavor as it is. Since there are no artificial sweeteners there are none of those nasty "artificial sweetener off flavors." There are also no other off flavors and no unpleasant aftertaste.Overall, I like this beverage even though for me there was no boost. I don't blame the beverage for that though, because I seem to be immune to the ingredients in all these energy beverages.

A bit of background. When I bought my house in 1989 it was over 100 years old, and as such was built without indoor facilities. The date stenciled on the bottom of the toilet tank top indicated the bathroom was installed around 1962. I also knew the septic tank was under the forsythia bush in the side yard and where the drain field was because the grass over it was always much taller and greener than the rest of the yard. From the size of the bush, I was pretty sure the septic tank had not been exposed (read "pumped out") in quite a while, if ever.Shortly thereafter, I was browsing the aisles in my local Grossman's when I came across Roebic K-37. After reading the bottle I decided to buy some and try it out. While the instructions said "once a year" I added to the system it twice a year, "just to be sure." I also did the "common sense" stuff associated with septic system. I chose the toilet tissue the dissolved well and never flushed anything "inappropriate." I never had any problems, except when the tall grass over the drain field choked my mower.Fast-forward 14 years. One day I said to my bride, "That septic tank's been there since 1962. I don't think it would hurt if we put a new one in." There is an "old-timer" in my neighborhood with a backhoe and a dump truck with an excellent reputation when it comes to installing septic systems, so I made arrangements with him to replace the system. On the appointed day, he scoops out the forsythia bush, and carefully scoops down until he reaches the metal top of the septic tank. To my surprise, it is not attached to the tank. After pumping the tank, the sides and the bottom each came out separately. It also turns out I only had a 10 foot long drain field. We then proceeded with the installation of a 1000 gallon (properly baffled) concrete tank and 70 feet of drain field.I give Roebic K-37 credit for keeping an ancient, poorly designed, and dilapidated system functioning long as it did. Therefore, I started using K-37 twice a year immediately upon putting the new system in service, and the first 11 years of use have been uneventful. I trust that it will continue to keep my septic system healthy as long as I own this property. If I am still alive when the house gets sold I will also recommend this regimen to the new owner.If your septic tank also receives laundry and kitchen drains, and in addition to the bathrooms, you need to be aware that laundry bleach and most automatic dishwasher detergents are lethal to the bugs in your septic tank, and the other soaps and detergents don't help it either. Therefore you should also check out Roebic's other products. (I put K-87 in the dry well that my kitchen drains to.)Bottom LineIf you have a septic system you owe it to yourself to keep it in good condition. My experience has been that Roebic K-37 will help do just that.

It never ceases to amaze me how hard it must be to design a proper "rubber" spatula. While Rubbermaid's spatulas have been the gold standard for years, even those don't seem as good as the ones they made back in "the good old days."Over the years I've come to like OXO products. With few exceptions, they are well engineered well designed and well made.Enter this silicone spatula from OXO. Once again, OXO has gotten it right. The head is a good size, not too big, not too small, with just the right amount of flexibility. It's the perfect size and length scraping the last of the mayo out of the jar, and because it is rated for 600°F, it is perfect for getting the last of the sauce out of the pot or sauté pan.The rest of the spatula is all one piece plastic, so unlike those Rubbermaid spatulas with the wooden handles, this one can go right in the dishwasher.The other end of the spatula is a bit larger in diameter with grippy rubber surface. This is a bit of a two-edged sword. While it makes it easy to grab and maneuver, it also makes the spatula a bit difficult to store. I store my rubber spatulas, along with my other kitchen utensils, handle side down in a canister. This larger diameter handle takes up much more space, and the grippy surface makes it more difficult to insert and extract. When pulling it out of the canister, the grippy part usually drags at least one other thing with it. Though not a dealbreaker, it's still annoying nonetheless.Overall, the spatulas the keeper and I would recommend it to a friend without hesitation.

Most of the reviewers have compared this spray favorably with WD-40. For me, that's not saying much. I gave up on WD-40 years ago. The mainstays in my toolbox and workshop have been CRC products Power-Lube and 6-56, as well as PB Blaster. Those products blow WD-40 right out of the water. So, how does this new 3M spray compared to the heavyweight champs I'm used to?Quite well, I am pleased to say. I've only tried a few things so far, and I've been happy with the results. The only unknown here is how long the protection will last. Hence, the four-star rating. With any luck, it will last so long that I will forget that I applied it in the first place. In any case, I plan to report back on the spray's longevity.The only con, in my opinion, is the way the plastic straw is attached to the side of the can. It never ceases to amaze me that in the last 50 years nobody has come up with a way to hold the straw on the side of the can so you don't lose it. They taped the straw to the side of the can with scotch tape 1964, and they still tape the straw to the side of the can with scotch tape 2014. This virtually guarantees that the straw will be lost before the can is empty.

Me (Who uses Excel infrequently.): "Look what I selected from Vine." (Showing Mrs. Boilermate "101 Ready to Use Excel Formulas.")Mrs. Boilermate (Who uses Excel every day.): "Why do you need something like that?  All that stuff is already built into Excel."Well, it turns out all that stuff really is built into Excel... If you know where to find it. That's not easy, considering Microsoft's legendary "not much help" files. That's where the useful information in this book comes in.I have been using spreadsheets since the late 1980s, beginning with SuperCalc before migrating to Quattro Pro, and finally Excel. While my spreadsheet needs have been fairly modest, I know enough to build some basic formulas and set up some conditional formatting. However, I knew could do much more than what I used it for, and this book has helped me discover some of the things I can do with the program.Starting with a basic explanation of how formulas work in Excel, the book continues on with examples of various types of operations. With each formula there is a more detailed explanation about how the formula works. There is also a link where you can download samples of the formulas they use.While many of the formulas are beyond what I would normally use in Excel, one of the first formulas, in the chapter, "Manipulating Text with Formulas," allowed me to combine several columns of text into one column by using the formula containing "&'s." By combining columns I was able to create a spreadsheet that I could actually print. As single columns, the sheet was too wide to print on a single page, even in landscape mode, unless I shrunk the font until it was virtually unreadable.While this book is not an in-depth "everything you need to know about Excel" book, and that is a good thing. Sometimes those books can be so overwhelming that your eyeballs ache as you try to sort through the information. On the other hand, with this book I was able to find the information that was pertinent to what I wanted to accomplish.Bottom LineWhile the dead tree version of this book was on the house courtesy of Vine, I thought this book was so useful that I actually purchased the Kindle version so I could load it into my Kindle app on my computer, and follow along on the screen.

Mrs. Boilermate's ReviewThese are pretty little earrings. I was expecting them to be bigger, but I must concede that the actual size is in line with the small illustration showing the earrings against a silhouette. The pictures and the video give the impression that the earrings are larger, not to mention the information from Amazon's website: Product Dimensions: 4.5 x 4.1 x 0.4 inches; 0.3 ouncesAccording to my ruler, the dangle is about 5/8" across and 5/8" from top to bottom. The full length from the top to bottom is about 1 1/4". From front to back, the depth of the dangle is about 1/4" .Before you wear them for the first time, check to make sure the loop holding the dangle onto both earrings is completely closed. I had to fix one right out of the package. The dangle itself appears well constructed, and the stones all appear to be firmly set. However, these are very light. I would suggest adding a backing to the earrings, since they fall out easily.

Reviewing this UPS has been somewhat of a dilemma for me and in fact it was not submitted until the very last day, as I tried to figure out a good way to review it. Then the lights went out.Almost 3 weeks earlier...Out-of-the-box, this is a nice looking device. It has clean lines, and the three top mounted switched outlets are widely spaced to accommodate power bricks. I noticed the outlets are only two prong, but as I read up on the device I can see the reason for this. It is designed for low-power devices, which tend to have power bricks. It is not designed to backup things like computers and monitors, which would normally be provided with a three-pronged cord. In fact, it will shut itself off if it detects a draw more than 75 W.At first I thought, "What good is this? Sure the modem and the router stay on, but everything else that uses electricity goes out. How is this helpful?"I was brought to my senses last week by a power outage. There I discovered a very nice feature: When the power goes out, the unit beeps once and then stays silent. The other two UPS's I have beep constantly until I turn them off or they die of starvation.I am disabled, and therefore having communication to the outside world at all times is essential. I still have a traditional landline, and as such I normally still have phone service during a power outage unless the outage was caused by downed wires on my street. But the landline only works on the desk phone in my office, because the rest of the house phones are cordless, and therefore don't work when the power goes out. By plugging the base station into this unit I had working phones (for a while - see below) during the outage.My cell phone is my "I've fallen and I can't get up" device. When the lights went out I reached for my cell phone only to discover that I had left it on for an undetermined amount of time, and the battery was nearly dead. I was able to plug my cell phone into this UPS and recharge the battery.I have to confess I don't know how long it will really last. After I let my phone charge for about an hour I turned it off just in case we needed to recharge something else. In the end, the outage lasted for 12 hours, and the UPS wouldn't have powered the phones for the entire outage, but this device gave me the peace of mind I needed.

When we Americans think of "instant cereal" we usually think of a pouch of instant oatmeal mixed with boiling water to to make a fairly thick porridge-like breakfast. That is kind of what I thought I was getting when I purchased this. However, this, according to the package, is "nutritious, digestible and a delicious beverage suitable for everyone."This product is finely milled grains (wheat, corn, soybean, and rice,) with nondairy creamer and sugar. Adding one pouch to 200 mL (approximately 6 ounces) of hot water produces a creamy, sweet, grain flavored beverage. If you're looking for something with the consistency of instant oatmeal you really need three packets per 6 ounces of water. When prepared this way you get a smooth, creamy, sweet cereal. Be aware, however, due to the added sugar and nondairy creamer you get a stiff dose of calories as well... about 400.Overall I like the flavor of this product. The corn flavor is most prominent for me.I'm glad I had the opportunity to try this product. While it wasn't what I expected, it was a delicious new experience for me. I'm not sure if I will purchase this again, but I will definitely enjoy the rest of this package.

I am pleased to see that TENS unit finally gone OTC.This is a well designed portable TENS unit. It was easy to put together, and the Quick Start guide is excellent. It also comes with a comprehensive manual.The placement guide for two or four electrodes is clear. There is also a more detailed explanation of exactly where to place the electrodes in the manual (pages 18 – 21).Translating that guide into actual placement is a bit trickier in reality. I expect it will take a bit of trial and error to precisely locate the electrodes.This TENS unit has a total of twelve different programs. There are programs for the shoulder, hand/wrist, lower back/waist, joint – knee/elbow, leg – thigh/calf/ankle/foot, or neck. For each of these areas, there are two variations on the type of stimulation.It is easy to select the program and intensity. There is a comprehensive list on page 25 of the manual.Handle the electrode pads with care. While the pads are reusable, they should be replaced if you break one of the wires or they fail to stick. A replacement set of pads (at the time of this writing) will set you back almost 25 bucks here on Amazon.The unit itself is small and easy to handle. The backlit LCD display is easy to read, and the controls are easy to set.In use, it is just about what you would expect from a TENS unit. The only question is how many sessions we get out of one set of batteries.Bottom LineIf you're looking for an OTC TENS unit this one is worthy of your consideration. It's instructions are good, it's easy to set up, and easy to use. Battery life is yet to be determined, hence the four-star rating.

For me, this LaraBar Renola sounded like a good idea. The individual packages are just the right size for a quick snack. Gluten-free, dairy free, non-GMO, etc. sounded good. The result, however, falls somewhat short.First, the appearance. If you're used to seeing nice clusters of granola when you open the package you will be disappointed with this product. The product in these little bags looks like all the little crumbs left in the bottom of your granola after you've eaten all the big clusters. The best way to eat this is to snip off the top of the bag and pour it directly into your mouth.The taste a bit bland. The bag says "Cinnamon Nut" but I don't taste any cinnamon. Similarly, though almonds are the first ingredient I don't taste them either. I do taste the raisins, sunflower seeds, and the pumpkin seeds. This product really needs oat and nut clusters. Two stars.However, Mrs. Boilermate said:"I enjoyed this "granola." It was tasty, and the package was a good amount for a mid-afternoon snack. I especially like that this product does not contain peanuts. Since I am allergic to peanuts, a granola snack that I can eat is a rare find.Some of the pieces at the bottom of the package were a bit small. When I tried to pour them into my hand to eat, some of the pieces were so small and light, it was hard to keep them from scattering on to the floor. Four stars."Bottom LineSplit decision. Three stars overall.

I think that LED light bulbs are the wave of the future. Previously I tested two bulbs courtesy of Vine, and purchased an LED floodlight, in addition to this floodlight that I am reviewing today. In all cases, I have been impressed with the brightness of the bulbs and how their light output mimics the light that I'm used to from an incandescent bulb. Most of my criticisms of these bulbs has been the aesthetics, and how they don't fit into current fixtures. This is not one of those bulbs.Though the buy-in price per bulb can seem a bit stiff, you soon forget that after you've installed one of these in a hard-to-reach area. Like all new technologies, over time the cost of the bulbs continues to drop. At the time of this writing these bulbs are only about 12 bucks apiece (when bought in a two pack) so the payback time is not that long. But don't expect to be able to take a Caribbean Vacation with the money you save by using these bulbs. I expect the decreased energy usage will soon be offset by higher electricity prices, as the electric utilities raise their prices to compensate.The instructions for this bulb say that it can be used indoors or in a sheltered area outdoors. I put this bulb in a holder that's under the eaves outside my back door. The light from this bulb is pretty impressive. The color is similar to what I get from an incandescent floodlight and the flood pattern is good. The shape of the bulb is virtually identical to an incandescent floodlight, and fits perfectly into the lamp holder. I did not test the dimming capabilities of this bulb because I do not have any places where I would need a dimmable floodlight.There are currently LED floodlights on the market that are designed for "outdoor use" and not "sheltered outdoor location" like this bulb is. That's the only reason this bulb gets a four-star rating.Bottom LineThis floodlight bulb has all the attributes I look for when buying a floodlight, but primarily that it can be used outdoors, albeit in a sheltered location. It looks just like an ordinary floodlight, and the light output is similar to that of a comparable incandescent floodlight. So unless you need a floodlight in a non-sheltered outdoor location, this bulb is a worthy choice.

I've probably gone through a half dozen or so pairs of kitchen shears, trying to find a pair that worked right for me. I think I finally found it with these shears.First of all the shears have a good comfortable grip, the handles are big enough for my ham hands, and the angle of the handles is about perfect. They also take apart for easy cleaning and can go right in the dishwasher. But other shears I have had also had comfortable handles that have been correctly angled, came apart for easy cleaning, and go right in the dishwasher.What sets the shears apart is the micro-serrations on the blades. I often use kitchen shears to cut up something soft and slippery such as chicken or chicken gizzards. I also use them to snip garlic scapes, which are round, firm, and smooth. When I try to cut these items with smooth bladed shears the shears tend to squeeze the item and push them right out of the blades and across the room as I try to cut them. The micro serrations on these blades grip just enough for me and I get smooth cut every time. Since I put the shears into use I have not shot a chicken gizzard across the kitchen.I highly recommend that everybody purchase a pair of these shears. Not only that, I like them so much I bought a second pair. So save yourself the trouble of multiple orders and order two pairs at once.

I've been a fan of Bounty Paper Towels for going on 30 years. To me, they were worth the extra money because they absorb well and hold up to heavy use. And the Select-A-Size variety has been our style of choice.With that in mind I was pleased to have the opportunity to try these Viva Vantage paper towels. I particularly like the "choose a size" option when buying towels. With a good paper towel, you can do just as much with a smaller sheet then you can with more than one full-sized sheet of a "value brand" towel. The Amazon description seems to indicate these would have a performance similar to Bounty.The first thing I noticed when I open the package is how rough these towel are. While Bounty towels aren't exactly facial tissue soft, by comparison these feel downright industrial. These towels are also "stretchy." They almost feel like that stretchy material they make stretchy blue jeans out of.Because of the way the first sheet on the roll is glued down, more often than not the first sheet gets shredded, and therefore not usable. This is never the case with Bounty towels.Mrs. Boilermate commented that when she went to pull one sheet off of the roll from our Paper Towel Holder, more often than not the sheet tore and she was left holding with just a little tab of paper towel rather than an entire sheet that she gets when ripping off a sheet of Bounty in the same manner. I don't know if it's due to a weaker towel or stronger perforations, but it's annoying just the same. She said tearing off a sheet of these towels in a two-handed task. I have experienced this on occasion as well.When you get to the last sheet on the roll, it, too, is seriously glued down, so you are unable to use that sheet. Again, the last sheet of Bounty is always usable. It may not seem like two unusable sheets per roll is a big deal, but that's 3% of every 66 sheet roll, and 24 sheets out of this 12 pack that were unusable.I often use a paper towel (or two) to sop up leftover grease after browning hamburger or cooking bacon in a frying pan. I even use a towel sop up grease while the hamburger is browning (rather than trying to drain the grease from a frying pan full of ground beef) so less grease ends up in the finished product of whatever I am making. Compared side-by-side to Bounty,  these don't seem to absorb as much as Bounty. They also don't "lock-in" liquids as well either. That is, when you sop up a mess with Bounty there is virtually no dripping from the towel as you transfer from the pan to the trash can. These Viva Vantage towels tended to drip a lot more during the same operation.I put three slices of bacon on this microwave bacon plate, and covered it with a single sheet of these towels. The next batch I did the same with a Bounty towel. At the end of both three-minute cooking cycles I compared the two towels. The grease stain on the Viva Vantage towel was much larger, indicating it needed more of the towel to absorb approximately the same amount of grease.Mrs. Boilermate used these towels in conjunction with Mr. Clean Liquid Muscle to do some general cleanup around the kitchen, including some tough gunk on the stove. She reports the towels held up well, though she did say she didn't do any really hard scrubbing.Advertising vs. RealityThe advertising hype says, "See for yourself why more people prefer new Viva Vantage towels. (vs. the leading national brand)" Maybe we're just "going against the flow" but we don't prefer these over "the leading national brand."They also say, "Viva Vantage offers the perfect combination of strength, stretch and softness." Again I disagree. The towels have decided industrial feel to them which is definitely not soft, and when it comes to paper towels, "stretchy" is not a term I've ever used to describe my ideal towel."Stretches to scrub." I'm not sure what they mean by that, but neither I nor Mrs. Boilermate have ever said, "These paper towels are nice, but I wish they stretched more."Bottom LineThese paper towels perform reasonably well, though not as well is the Bounty towels we use every day. For us, we consider these a step up from "value brand" towels but not much more than that. We certainly wouldn't pay the premium price they are asking for this towel. We would use these over the Bounty Basic Paper Towels we tried a while back, but as a replacement for the Bounty towels we use now? Not so much. We'll continue using Bounty, thank you.

I love oatmeal, and I'm always up to trying a new brand or variety. So when this Gluten Free Chex Oatmeal was offered on Vine I selected it right away. I'm glad I did. And in the process I learned something, which is always a good thing. First of all, when I saw the name of the product, "Gluten Free Chex Oatmeal," I thought, "Sound like marketing hype to me. Isn't all oatmeal gluten free?" Well, instead of just writing up a snarky comment along those lines I went out and did some research. It turns out that, no, all oatmeal is not gluten free. Yes, oats themselves are gluten-free, but apparently most oatmeal contains oats that have been cross-contaminated with a tiny bit of wheat, barley and/or rye. (Thanks, Google.)So, let's try it out. This is a very good oatmeal without a lot of added nonsense. It doesn't even have added vitamins and minerals that most cereals have nowadays. There are three flavors in this variety pack: apple cinnamon, maple brown sugar, and original. The original tastes like, well, plain oatmeal. If you like plain oatmeal you'll love this. The nice oat flavor with no off flavors or strange aftertaste. The same goes for the flavored varieties. The apple cinnamon had discernible chunks of rehydrated apples as well as a nice aroma and flavor. Maple brown sugar was equally tasty.I prefer a thicker porridge, so the recommended amount of water per packet, two thirds of a cup, was about double what I would normally use. The instructions even say you can use an empty pouch to measure the COLD water for pouring it into a microwave-safe cup. For my preparations, I went a simpler route: I poured two packets into a Sistema Soup Mug and added 6 ounces of water from my Keurig machine. It came out perfect. I liked it so much I hogged it all to myself, and didn't even offer Mrs. Boilermate any.Bottom LineThis oatmeal is what the Nature Valley Oatmeal I recently tried should have been. It has simple ingredients, no artificial anything, is easy to prepare, and is delicious. I would definitely purchase this product. Even if you don't need to maintain a gluten-free diet, this oatmeal deserves a spot in your pantry.

Mrs. Boilermate's review:A little of this really goes a long way. I attacked baked on grease on the stove top, and a couple of drops of this on a paper towel cleaned it quite nicely. This worked at least as well as Lysol disposable kitchen wipes.I was impressed, since the scrubbing power of a paper towel is non-existent.  The cleaning compared favorably to the results obtained using the textured Lysol scrubbing wipes.

I have used a variety PDF programs over the years including Adobe, Foxit, PDF-Xchange, and the predecessor to this program, PDF Create. Though each has its advantages and disadvantages, I preferred PDF-Xchange for my everyday use.Converting documents to PDF format is no big deal these days. I currently have four PDF programs on my computer, and each one sets itself up as a printer. To save to PDF I simply tell my document "Print" and the print menu will open up and I get to choose what program I print to PDF from. In that regard I haven't found any real difference in the resultant PDF when printing to PDF from Word, Excel, Publisher, WordPerfect, or any other program.InterfaceThere seems to be only one "theme" which is black on gray with purple highlights. I can find no other option to change the color scheme.Love it or hate it, it seems the ribbon interface is here to stay, but Nuance seems to done a reasonably decent job when populating the tabs. What they haven't done, however, is given you the ability to collapse the ribbon, which takes up a fair amount of screen space.Power PDF has a Quick Access Toolbar as well, but unlike Microsoft Office products (or their own PaperPort), the bar cannot be relocated below the ribbon. Since there is only one theme, the QAT is black and purple on dark gray with tiny little icons you can barely see.Following the Microsoft example, it also puts the document information on the same line as the Quick Access Toolbar. This means if you add a lot of items to the toolbar the document information will be pushed right off the screen. (At least with MS Office you can relocate the QAT so this doesn't happen.) Another interface quirk: If you use a "Windows Classic" theme this program will place the document information in the Classic Theme title bar on top of the QAT, rendering it useless.There is also a toolbar along the left side of the screen that cannot be turned off or collapsed, as well as a status bar on the bottom of the screen. And if you click on one of these sidebar icons, another sidebar opens next to it which gobbles up even more screen space. By default, these two alone occupy approximately a quarter of the screen width.All in all there is too much wasted screen space with this program.Many modern programs have a tab for each open document within the program window. Not so with Power PDF. It still has the same old-fashioned multiple icons clogging up the Taskbar. PDF-Xchange Editor has such a tabbed interface.The Program ItselfThis program seems to have all the features of other PDF Creator programs, along with most of the same bells and whistles. Since other reviewers have gone into detail about some of the features of this program I won't bore you with a rehash. For the parts of the program I have tried it accomplishes the tasks fairly well, but nothing really sets it apart from other products on the market at this time.Customer ServiceWhile I have not needed to contact Customer Service concerning this product, I have used Nuance products for many years. Buyer beware. Their lack of customer service is legendary. Their response times are slow (if they respond at all) and often times the answers are inadequate.Bottom LineThis program is like a Mitsubishi Outlander. The Outlander is a fairly competent vehicle with love it or hate it styling. But the fact is there better vehicles in its class for less money. The same is true For Power PDF. In my opinion, there is no compelling reason to purchase this program. It does the same things as every other PDF program I have tried, and while it does them competently, it doesn't do them better.The dealbreaker for me, however, is the interface, and since that's what I have to look at every time I use a program this is a real big deal. The black and purple on dark gray for the QAT, combined with the small icons and its inability to be relocated below the ribbon makes it unusable in my opinion. It is also intolerant if you use a "Windows Classic" theme as I described above.You can always go to Nuance's website and download a free trial this program. But while you're at it, Google PDF-Xchange Editor and download the free trial of that program. In my opinion, it's a better program for less money.

If you're the handy person in your house you know how nice it is to have things that will make your project go a little easier. You know, something you don't absolutely need, and wouldn't use every day, but when you do use it you appreciate how much easier can make your life. This is one of those things.If you're about to do a major project and you need a quick and easy way to calculate a room size so you know how much material to buy, this laser measuring device is perfect. Not only will it give you measurements, but also calculate square footage and, if necessary, volume. It's no replacement for the traditional tape measure, however, once the project begins. For instance, this would be perfect for calculating how much crown molding to buy to finish off that room renovation you just did. But once you have the crown molding you really need a tape measure to accurately measure each length of wall. (This is only accurate to about 1/16 of an inch, which is not sufficient, IMO, for trim work.)The unit itself small enough to fit easily into your hand and comes with a lanyard. It also comes with a belt holster that's basically useless. That's because the instrument has a grippy rubber surround which makes it comfortable to hold. But it also makes it difficult to insert and remove from the holster with two hands, let alone one.Overall, it's fairly easy to use and the operations are fairly easy to understand. The manual, while not extensive, clearly tells you what everything is and how to use it, with one exception. There is a small hinged tab on the bottom of the unit. Not sure what it's for, and the manual doesn't tell you, but I'm not confident it would last very long in the real world, whatever it's for. There's a threaded connector on the back so it can be attached to a standard tripod.If you have big hands you may find some of the buttons a bit small. To me the buttons have a fairly quality feel to them. The screen is easy to see, and the backlighting is handy. Repeatability of measurements has been spot on.Bottom LineI was very happy to be able to test this instrument, courtesy of Amazon's Vine program. Would I have bought one on my own? Probably not, but it's one of those "nice to have" things that I would have asked Santa for. You should ask Santa for one to.

While reading the reviews for the Lindt Chili Dark Chocolate Bar, one reviewer suggested trying this bar as a better alternative, so I thought it would give it a try. Reading the description, it sounded like the right combination: dark chocolate with cinnamon and chili added. Sure, the nine bucks I paid for this is a lot of money for one candy bar, but one from a small chocolatier is a luxury I can afford occasionally... if it's a really good chocolate bar.What an expensive mistake! The bar I received had partially melted and re-solidified. The chocolate was more akin to milk chocolate rather than dark chocolate and the chili flavor was inconsistent throughout the bar. Some bites had a mild chili flavor at the end, while others had none at all. It really lacked any serious spiciness. I thought maybe I got an old one, but the "Best By" date is July 21, 2014, so that didn't explain the lack of flavor.Since I ate the whole thing, it's really not fair to ask for a refund from Amazon, but I certainly will not be buying this brand of chocolate bar again.Bottom LineAvoid this candy bar at all costs! If you really want a dark chocolate bar with chili (and you know you do) I suggest you go with the Lindt.

I like a good dark chocolate and I like "hot stuff." I wasn't sure, however, about the combination of the two. I always heard that chocolate was a good way to counteract the spiciness of chili peppers so I didn't expect much heat. Much to my surprise (and delight) the chocolate didn't wipe out the chili pepper heat.Overall, I like this candy bar. The dark chocolate is smooth without being bitter, and it has a nice spicy finish without being overpowering. The best way to enjoy this bar is to let a square melted in your mouth. That way you get the nice dark chocolate flavor with a bit of spiciness in the back of your mouth. The spiciness is less pronounced if you just pop a square in your mouth, chew, and swallow.If you want a "true chili-head experience" that will melt your teeth this probably isn't the bar for you. But if you want a nice dark chocolate taste with a mild spicy finish give this one a try.

These have a smooth milk chocolate flavor however, I expected more caramel flavor. I thought it would be more like a Rolo, but instead it was mostly milk chocolate with only a mild caramel taste.Overall, they were okay, but I don't think they are worth paying a premium price for.

This Iron Grip tape is a step up from the traditional silver duct tape that is so ubiquitous. This is noticeably harder to tear and even resists cutting cleanly with scissors. It does seem to grip well on a couple of places that I stuck it. While the longevity of its stickiness is still to be determined, so far it works pretty good.So what's not to like? At the time of this writing a 35 yd. roll of this tape costs over 15 bucks here on Amazon. A 60 yard roll of 3M Scotch Pro Strength Duct Tape is about 10. Three rolls of silver duct tape costs under nine bucks. Time will only tell if this tape is worth the premium price.

Unlike some traps, these are very easy to set. You squeeze them like a clothespin and they lock in the open position. You really need something sticky like peanut butter to bait these with, as there is only a small spot to place bait, but something like cheese or fruit probably won't stay in place.I don't know if it's the traps or the Motomco Mouse Attractant Gel bait that I used, but I have caught no mice with this trap even though I've seen evidence that they've been around.Based on my examination of the trap, I am not too impressed with the build quality. I would be leery that these traps are strong enough to actually kill the mice.I will keep trying these, and will update if I have any new information.

As I write this review, I can hear little critters scurrying around between the floors above my office. I have also seen mouse droppings on my kitchen counter. I baited a Tomcat Snap Trap and a Victor Electronic Trap with this attractant, and placed one trap in each area. So far no mouse has taken the bait.Up to this point, I'd say this product is a dud.

While making rice on the stove is not that hard, and I usually get pretty good results, I  occasionally will burn a bit on the bottom because I'm not paying attention. I thought this rice cooker would have the advantage of turning off after the preset time and not overcooking the rice. I expected the results to be "okay" but not as good as when it was done properly on the stovetop. I was wrong. Not only the results as good but the rice was done in half the time.When I make basmati rice stove I normally put one cup of rice and 1 3/4 cups water in the pan, bring it to a boil, and simmer for 20 minutes. Using the same proportions in this rice steamer rice is done perfectly in 10 minutes.Cleanup was a breeze too. Everything can go on the top rack of the dishwasher. The only improvement they could make, in my opinion, is to put some kind handles on the bowl so was easy to take out of the microwave when it's hot. Otherwise this would be a five star product. As it is now, 4.5.Update July 17, 2014Last weekend I used this to make Lotus Foods Madagascar Pink Rice using the recommended amounts of rice and water. The package says 20 minutes, in this cooker it was done in 15. It was perfectly cooked with just the right amount of moisture. (Note: I buy all of my Lotus Foods rice directly from them at lotusfoods dot com.)

I've had a flow control aerator on my kitchen sink faucet for years but have never been able to find one with the smaller diameter to fit my bathroom sink until now. I'm not sure why, but I've never been able to find one locally in any hardware store.Installation was a snap. I simply unscrewed the aerator on my Peerless faucet, inserted the thin gasket into the top of this control valve, and screwed the valve into place. It functions properly with no leaks. Now I get to control the flow without having to change the temperature. The reduction in flow rate is only noticeable when you run the water to get it hot, as it will take longer. Other than that it is a nice soft aerated flow.Be aware, however, this valve may add up to 2 inches to the end of your faucet, so if you have a low flat faucet spout and a fairly shallow sink this may be an issue for you when you try to put something like a tall cup under it.Bottom lineHighly recommended.

If you suffer from a condition that requires you to avoid certain foods you often have to settle for alternatives that are "almost as good" to downright awful. If you need to be gluten-free this is not one of those products. To us, these elbows were every bit as good as Barilla's elbows made from wheat.The instructions say to cook the product for seven minutes for them to be al dente. We tested them at 5 1/2 minutes and they were almost overcooked at that point. It was no discernible difference in taste between these and elbows made of wheat.We made a batch of macaroni and cheese with this package and the elbows held up perfectly. Again, there was no difference from the mac & cheese we've made with wheat-based pasta.Bottom lineThese gluten-free elbows are good enough to stand on their own and not something that is "almost as good as the 'real thing'." Another winner from Barilla.

I made an amazing discovery after I attached this to the side of my Toto Drake elongated toilet… The toilet doesn't have holes around the entire circumference of the bowl rim. It only has holes about a third of the way around on the front and back. When you clip this to the side of the bowl it doesn't even get wet so it has absolutely no effect on the cleanliness of the toilet. If you clip it to the front it will get a bit wet but it's really ineffective keeping the sides of the bowl clean.If your toilet has holes around the entire circumference of the rim these might work for you, but it was totally ineffective on our toilet.

This is a unique, lovely flower silver bangle. It's about 8 1/4 inches around, which is great for medium and small wrists. It fits my wrist which is 6 1/4"It is stamped with a 925 which normally means it's entirely real sterling silver, but it doesn't look it, nor does it feel smooth to the touch like real silver. This page now says it's plated silver, which means it should not have that stamp.  At the 5 dollar price, you can't expect real silver, and plated is getting more popular these days as silver increases in price.Getting it on/off if you have larger hands can be an issue as it took some doing to bend it to fit the hole over the flower for me. Every time I slip it on/off, it becomes misaligned.I received this product for an honest review.It still is a lovely design and has a very delicate and feminine style.

These are large (11-12 mm) genuine, white freshwater pearls, with a beautiful glow; with cream and peach undertones. You know they are real as well because the back of the pearls are shaved to make a smooth surface for the posts. They are not heavy at all, and don't pull on the earlobe.The posts and butterfly clasps are real sterling silver and are stamped with 925 (as in 92.5% silver the standard in jewelery.) I am allergic to nickle and get itchy on cheap jewelry, especially on earrings, and when wearing this for a couple of hours, they felt fine.It came in a cute box with a lovely red velvet small pouch.I received this product at a discount for an honest and unbiased review.

This tablecloth has a box, slight open weave that is so thin, it's practically see through (A reviewer named "RLC" shows how easily you can their hand through the fabric.) This looks cheap, but presentable on a solid very monochrome wood/color table, whether light or dark. But if the wood has more color fluctuations that is normal to the grain, or the leaves of the table aren't tight, you'll see the separation easily, making it more obvious and look like it's stained. On the plus side, it doesn't look or feel like the 100% polyester it is, but more like a cheap cotton or linen, and because it's polyester, stains would come out easier then if it was cotton or linen.Where the white meets the taupe/tan bottom had a more designed, even more open weave that already looks like the threads have been pulled & don't look like they will survive even a gentle cycle without the threads being pulled to the point of looking representable. Reviewer James Huff shows a great picture of how badly damaged his looks even before use.The stitching at the border looks fine and strong enough. It's a nice design, too bad the actual manufacturing of the weave is done so cheaply. The instructions say you can machine-wash cold separately using the gentle cycle, and tumble dry low, and use a low iron, but I'd be worried it wouldn't get past even a couple of washings with that. I'd maybe even hand wash it & line dry it.I don't think this is worth 30 or so it's selling now, this is more a outlet or liquidators, but not as bad as a dollar store product. This is more worth 10-15.

This is a 16.9 fluid oz. / 500 ml thin plastic bottle with a stylish silver colored bottom, plastic black arm pump top. The label is stylish as well as the silver/black pump.It has a strong scent that fills the room when you first open it, then dissipates fast. It does have a lovely, very natural lavender scent, not synthetic perfume smell that will stay on your hands if you put your nose to it. It pumps well, though kind of loose with a good amount of soap coming out. It is almost a bit watery, not thick, rinsing off with barely any attempt, with no extra reside. It seems like it cleans well enough. It rinses faster then the thicker "Trader Joe's Trader Jacques French Liquid Orange Blossom Honey Hand and Body Soap" B002UW41WY (much cheaper in store) that I use that is mostly all natural & inexpensive.The reason I took of two stars was that for the 20 dollars a bottle it charges, I expected mostly all natural ingredients. Unfortunately the ingredients are as follows: (info in parentheses are info I looked up)Aqua (Water), Potassium Cocoate (me: potassium salt of coconut oil), Parfum Fragrance (me: synthetic? most would label it essential oil if it was to show it's an expensive ingredient), PEG-40 Hydrogenated Castor Oil (polyethylene glycol derivative), Peg-7 Glyceryl Cocoate (synthetic polymer is based on PEG {polyethylene glycol} and fatty acids derived from coconut oil) , Glycerin, Hydroxyethylcellulose (modified cellulose polymer; used as a gelling and thickening agent), Cocos Nucifera (Coconut) Oil, Linalool (natural? fragrance), Benzyl Benzoate (solvent & preservative, can cause dermatitis), Geraniol (natural plant oil), Limonene (natural fragrance), Citronellol (natural plant oil), Farnesol (natural or synthetic fragrance), Citral (natural or synthetic plant oil), Coumarin (can be a natural or synthetic fragrance).

Comes in a stylish book like box with a strong magnet closing door, this 6 inch./15 cm long cord is perfect if you hate long cords getting tangled or for travel.The one I received is gold colored braided cord (like the braided fabric from the olden days) with gold ends. Feels very sturdy even at the junctions where the ends meet the cord. It has an aluminum shell which I believe because though it's flexible, it does hold a shape you bend it in like a pipe cleaner for kids.It comes with a two year limited warranty, no included instructions other then on the box.Go to Belkin. com /support for details. Made in China.Use:Charging by outlet while my iPhone 5S was about 30% every 30 minutes.Checking if it syncs to my desktop Win7 PC worked flawlessly.Checking issues others had, I tried connecting it first to my iPhone, THEN to the PC or to the outlet & had no issues at 4 different checks. If I have issues in the future, I will update it. I plan to keep this in my purse with an external battery for emergencies.

This is an elegant style off-white box for putting on a bookcase of other shelf where it will be exposed for company to see. With the diamond weave like texture & added reinforced silver metal corners, it looks beautiful on a shelf.It has a sturdy tight weave cloth bottom that slides easily/smoothly on a shelf keeping it from damaging your shelf & braking the box if it's heavy by one gripping it too hard. It has a foldable, very thick, black cardboard bottom that slides down for use with a short ribbon tab to pull it back up to fold the box. The black interior contrasts in an elegant way to the off-white outside & adds to less worry about stains on the inside. It says it's heavy construction and stackable, but does not say how much weight it can hold.This is their medium box version. They do have a document size box (12.75x9.5x3"sjrt), medium document box (12.75x9.5x6" deeper), essential box(15.5x8.25x6"), and mega box (155.5x13"x8).

This small size version at exactly 2" wide diameter is a good size for smaller dogs, most balls are much bigger that I find. It's a very thick, heavy textured style with TWO squeaker holes. It has very deep channels for the change of color from blue to orange areas. The name brand is also stamped very deeply in it. Because of all this, I found bouncing it straight up to be very difficult without watching it to make sure it's not on any grooves or holes. I get about a 5-6' foot initial bounce, on the second bounce it drops off to only 3-4' feet tops.My two Shih Tzu/Poodle mixes are very picky. He (about 20 lbs) only likes to chase balls, she (25 lbs) on the other hand, only likes to catch balls in mid bounce and is very good at it.
