He likes the very soft ones, preferably ones with nubs to massage the gums. She likes the tiny ones, these toy tennis balls the size of ping pongs. Neither chews them for more then 5-10 seconds before getting bored, they only like to chew real food.Neither cared for it, and I can't get him to chase it. She is VERY skiddish, afraid of the squeaker & even on a good day is kinda scared to catch it possibly because it's much heavier then what she's used to.I think other dogs may like this ball though, it is made well, I just don't like all the grooves that get in the way of the bounce.

Pros:* It came fully assembled* 12 AMPs* 23 ft long power cord* 12 inch nozzle* Lightweight (about 20 lbs) with a great center of gravity & has a carry handle* Vacuum handle folds down completely to make storing in small places easier.* Hose has a 9-10 ft reach with added stick wand* Come with a crevice tool, corner brush, and air-powered roller brush all have spots on the vacuum so available at all times.* Vacuum can go almost fully horizontal (it can go full, but then the front of the bottom will rise up) to get under taller furniture.* Great suction* Quick-Rinse Filter made with HEPA Media - Traps 99.97% of dust and pollens down to 0.3 microns.* Easy to empty dirt cup* Easy to reach & rinse filter from top of the dirt cup & the exhaust filter on the top of head of the vacuum.* Hose can be dislodged from vacuum completely to clean any clogs.Cons:* Button to fold handle down is cheap, very difficult to press enough & a pain.* Hose is way too floppy when using it for above your arm areas & putting away it flops all over.* Manual is in English, Espanol & French & makes understanding the very short instructions very difficult. The tiny pictures & lack of amount of pictures doesn't help either.* Can be a pain to push around, not smooth.* Has many settings for higher pile of carpets, but as you go higher, the suction suffers greatly.* No headlights or lights of any kind.* Louder then other vacuums I've own (owned many)* Using only your foot to put weight on the vacuum to fold the main part down to get under furniture is cheap & seems like it would loosen over time.* There are 5 Philips screws to protect the bottom roller brush, cleaning that brush if it has long hair, etc. is  an unneeded pain.  Shark uses flat plastic screws that are large & much better.For anyone who doesn't have an owner's manual:Belt style: 19Filter Type: F87Exhaust Filter Type: F89But going to Dirt Devils site, you can download the manual & buy any of the parts.

Specs:  Hi-Definition Sound - dual (2) speakers  Bluetooth Speaker 4.0  Output: 6W  Up to 8-10 hours of playtime  1000 mAH Built-in Li-Ion Rechargeable Battery  NFC for One Touch Pairing  CSR Chipset Range Up to 20 Meters  Built-in microphone for hands-free speaker phone calling  Compact and Lightweight.  Plays all Audio devices through 3.5mm Aux in Jack.  S/N: >70dB  Frequency: 50 Hz - 20 KHz  Size: 120mm X 70mm X 56 mm or 4.7 x 2.8 x 2.2 in.  Weight: 10-12 oz.PROS:* Diamond version with piano sleek black top & silver metal sides is gorgeous* Real stereo in one piece, it's great to have a portable stereo, most units are mono.* Lightweight & small to go anywhere* Has a MicroUSB cable for charging (but it's only 1.5m long)* Comes with a 3.5mm cord (male on both ends) to use for any devices with a headset jack (also a bit short)* Pairing with iPhone worked simply every time, no thinking involved* Battery lasts for many hours on use* Battery sitting around not in use can last many weeks.* Very rich sound, speaking voice (tv/movies) is very clear, and with music, the highs, middle & bass were better then I ever expected. Bass on music actually vibrated my desk. Sounds clear even at high volumes, I was happily surprised. It can go to VERY loud levels, much louder then any speaker of similar size.* The touch panel looks great* LED indicators - green for 3.5mm jack on, blue/red flashing for pairing, Blue for Bluetooth & red when battery is low w/a low-battery sound.CONS:* Can only be about 20-30 ft between the device & your player on bluetooth.* Control panel dims so much, you can't see it if in a very dim or dark room.* Control panel needs to be hit 2x to "wake it up"* Speakerphone of the other person sounds a little muffled, like cheap cellular sound, but better then some other speakerphones.* Your voice to others on speakerphone will cut out or sound too far to understand if more then 3 feet away.* When the battery is low, having a sound indicator is great to let you know, but it chimes too often making it VERY annoying as it cuts out music until you charge it or it fully dies.

Pros:* Looks like decent quality, not cheap* 2 jackets in 1 & can be worn together for warmth or separately which are zippered on (red fleece inside lining, purple rain-resistant outside shell)* 2 zippered outside pockets with easy to grab ribbon zipper in red to give a pop of color* Pockets are lightly fleece lined, but could be warmer* Sleeve cuffs have an adjustable Velcro closing to make it tight on your wrist or however you want.* Extra Velcro stripes to close the extra strip of fabric to cover the main middle zipper* Cinches by cord & plastic holder at the bottomCons:* No inside pockets* Fits a bit small for the size* Purple is on the dark side looking a bit mannish* Hood cord & plastic adjuster are a bit weird & hard to get used to & unattractive when pulled to tighten* Velcro strips to help cover the main zipper are only glued on & part of one has a loose flap already* Fleece is very thin, even with both the liner & shell, if you tend to feel chilly easily, this jacket is only good for 50* weather & aboveSize:The medium fit perfectly a woman who's 5'4" & 110 lbs., when ordering I suggest ordering half a size larger

Contains:Brief manual and the USB Hub.Build quality/Appearance:The 4 Port USB 3.0 Hub is small & compact (4.3" x 1.3" x 0.9"). It has a smooth, glossy black plastic shell. There is a thin blue LED strip along the top indicating power. The cable to the USB Plug appears to be thick and sturdy.Performance:I tested the hub out on my Desktop PC which is an Asus motherbooard w/rear & front panel USB 3.0 ports. I used two USB 3.0 portable hard drives to test out the hub. One, a Seagate 500GB drive, and the second is a new Western Digital Metal 2TB Drive. They both work fabulously connected directly to my computers USB 3.0 ports but when testing out the HUB on various ports on my computer the results were abysmal. The hub worked poorly to the point of not working at all with the Western Digital drive. And while I did get the drive to work only ok for read speeds on the Seagate drive, the write speeds were barely USB 2.0 speed. Bottom line is this is a really bad product, or it may simply be a defective unit.Bottom Line:While compact and sturdy looking, the performance was bad to the point of assuming I got a defective unit. If the unit is not defective & maybe just too finicky with USB 3.0 controllers to the point you may want to think twice before considering purchase. This device would get 0 stars if I could, but since I can't it's a 1 out of 5.

Well-made 18" X 12" basketball backboard & hoop with included basketball for the price. Everything is metal, the door braces, the screws/bolts, the entire 9" hoop including the breakaway part & it's large spring. The only thing that's not is the polycarbonate backboard (good choice to reduce weight & injury) & 1/2" inch foam around the perimeter of the board & on the door braces to reduce noise & wear & tear on your door.  The about 5" in width ball is a very mini version of a NBA, even has small nubs, but def on the cheaper side, but still thick enough to take some wear & tear & to do some damage if you're not careful. If the ball is too heavy duty, you can always buy a cheaper one or any foam ball under 8".Setup:Almost all of it was already installed, even the over the door metal braces that the included instructions went over. All that was left was to slide in 3 bolts, tighten 3 nuts with included cheap wrench & put on net. Unfortunately, it didn't include a even a cheap hand-pump for the ball to inflate, so you'll have to ask a friend or buy one.Use:Depending on your doors, like mine, the newer ones can't close with it on, but the very old doors can. It still rattles loudly when you use it, but since it's not a so cheap plastic it can't be used other then by a 5 year old, it's to be expected.Conclusion:For the price, already nearly finished installed items, good design, good materials, this is a great product.

Our tap water used to be VERY hard, within months, large amounts of limescale, etc. I could never use tapwater on water fountains & I always hated the taste of the water.  I've been drinking distilled or if spring water, Poland for years. Dasani water gives me an instant headache due to either the substandard filtration of their tap water or the other ingredients they put in.We have a refrigerator with a water/ice dispenser on the door. It uses a $40 GE filter. The water from there tastes smoother then tap, but not quite as good as Poland or distilled. Family members use it, but I keep to distilled.Setup:The picture is somewhat stylish.  The lid is also cool, it has a spout cover that flaps open with water so you don't splash everywhere when pouring & a slider to open a hole on top to fill the pitcher with more water so you don't have to remove the lid to do so. Grabbing the plastic sealed filter, I noticed it has day/month on the back of the lid with a black slider so you know when to replace the filter. Great idea, except the slit for the slider was so ragged, the black slider was rubbing off plastic EVERYWHERE. I had to quickly clean off all the little bits of black plastic off the lid both on top & under the lid, it was everywhere. I cleaned out the pitcher & lid completely, soaked the filter & filled & rinsed the pitcher twice before actually drinking the water per instructions.Use:I was VERY surprised how quickly the water went from the top to filtered bottom. Seemed almost too fast, I didn't time it, but seemed like only take 30 min, maybe even less to filter the pitcher full.Taste Test:Two family members & I did a taste test of *tap, *Aqua Optima, *GE dispenser & *distilled. We all hated the tap immediately & could easily taste the chlorine & other things we couldn't identify. The Aqua Optima was only slightly better & we could still taste the chlorine & was nowhere near smooth like distilled. I knew it wouldn't be, but I was expecting halfway there. We tried the GE dispenser & surprisingly it tasted smoother then the Aqua Optima with little chlorine taste.I saw reviewers here question the filtration on the bacteria & if I can still taste chlorine, I seriously have doubts about the rest of the claims.

I have used tension rods for years for my curtains. They are easy to use & you can place them anywhere.this one is about twice the thickness of those white or gold ones (not sure if ever seen another color) with very large ends.One end plastic, not metal, and is screwed in with a plastic screw so you can remove it to place even the smaller holed curtain in.Mine arrived with it already loosened, and was able to glide wide or narrow easily. The instructions are terrible, it's the same blue background diagrams you see here. I didn't know which direction to twist it, but after about 3 minutes, I was able to twist it the right way long enough to get it to hold.I put up a slightly heavy 72" curtain up that has an extra pretty layer on top with tassels & it's holding fine. My windows are very old, single plane, with a separate screen, and separate storm plane from the 1930s, so I could not fit it as close to the window as I could with regular tension rods in the window groove, so it's on the outermost side & a bit wide for that as well, so part of it is hanging out closer to the groove.

Once I opened the shipping box, I looked at the 2.25 x 9.25 x .25 inch padfolio and could clearly see an indentation on the cover outlining inside front pocket. The leather like material looks expensive & very soft to the touch, but when I picked it up, it flopped all over like a dead fish.The front pocket is tall, but very thin, it won't hold that many papers.The graph paper pad is thick & looks like you can replace the pad once you use it up. It's interesting they chose graph, but seems a good decision as you can still just use it as notepaper & still people who want graph paper have it to.When I laid about half the sheets over & resting on a table (so the weight of the sheets wouldn't bed the padfolio) while holding the padfolio in my hand, I tried writing & the padfolio was so bent, it would be impossible to write.All it needs is more cardboard on the front and back covers, an extra pocket in the back, an elastic loop for a pen and this would be five stars.

Contains:Manual - in English, French & Espanol.Pole/Tube - 32" which can be used without the floor attachments & just the main hand vacuum part to reach up to ceilings, etc.Detachable clip to the pole - can slide up/down to where you want & holds 2 hand tools, one on top, one on the bottom, though this will make the hand tools in the way a bit.Main Vacuum part - has 2 power settings slider switch & dirt cup & is great for hand vacuuming. Has one, very strong LED so you can really see where you're cleaning.Carpet motorized revolving floor brush - has FIVE LEDs so you can see where you're cleaning, low power will spin the brush slowly for bare floors & delicate rugs, the higher power will spin the brush faster for carpets.Crevice tool - long narrow attachment to get into tight spaces.Upholstery brush - helps clean pet hair, lint, etc. from furniture, etc.Dusting brush - for baseboards, small areas on the floor, windowsills, small areas on the floor.Hard floor genie - for vacuuming & has a washable microfiber pad w/velcro (only comes with 1 pad) to wipe fine dust at once. It's not to be used on damp floors or sticky messes.Hanger - very cheap plastic piece that has to be screwed into the wall.Large drawstring bag - 24"X12" to hold all the tools, including the floor ones easily.Storage:You can detach the main hand vacuum part & hang it on the bottom of the pole just right over the motorized floor brush. If you don't, you have to lean it on a wall, etc. or it will fall. Or you can also use the cheap wall hanger.Maintenance:Simple foam filter in vacuum has to be rinsed & air dry completely about once a month. You can also tap loose dirt from the foam filter between washes. Floor microfiber pad has to be cleaned with warm water in the washer or hand w/detergent & tumble dry low or line dry. Floor pad will have to be replaced every 3-4 months. If the rotating floor brush gets jammed, part of the bottom can be removed to get at the objects that are clogging it.Use:The ability to vacuum is about 80% as good as any upright or canister vacuum we have. We have a Mighty Mite 12 AMP canister & Hoover Windtunnel 3 Pro. But what the others don't have is this unit is so light & easy to use, easy to clean, and has a hand only use, or a hand & pole use to reach areas the other might not because it's so light. The only con/issue I had was to use the motorized floor brush, you put your foot on the floor brush itself to release it from the pole (held on by notch/tab only, so it angle forward like any other vacuum. But if you pull it too far back towards you, it will catch & lock back into the tab & be stuck to the pole again, and you have to put you foot on it again to release it again.

Flexible, seems well made, 4 ft long cable in more of a pepto bismo pink then bright neon pink. Charged properly both by computer or outlet (with a USB to outlet dongle not included). Synced & backed up my iPhone with iTunes without a problem.If it stops working, I will update this.

I bought this in early 2009 & it still works, EXCEPT the LCD display. That started getting lines disappearing within about 6 months, first 1 line, then 3, 4... now only 5 lines barely work & only a few dashes of those lines. That means nothing can be programmed, no date, time or caller ID. This is not due to the AA batteries & the display never had backlight.  When it did work, it worked fine, though it did eat batteries. Now that the LCD isn't working, I barely ever replace the AA batteries that are needed for the speakerphone.The rest still works, all the buttons, etc. The speakerphone is very slightly distorted but very loud. The is one of the only phones I see with a HOLD button. Not sure why newer corded phones are missing this key button when you want to switch phones.

Pros:Safety tip-over switch & overheat shut-off protectionVery smallStylish designKept cool to the touch after several hours useBuilt-in deep handle recess to easy carryLED light when on4 hour timer buttonVery quiet while in use.2 Heat Settings - low (450 watts) & high (900 watts) which is much lower electricity use most heatersFan only optionKeeps feet/legs nice & warm under a small, fully enclosed desk w/o burning the legs.5 year warranty- I have used Vornado's customer service (very nice people) before for an out of warranty heater. And if you're not happy with how they fixed it, they will repair it again w/o paying for shipping. They used to have amazingly great heaters even 5 years ago, but lately I haven't been happy with the quality of the units on the shelves or how they "fixed" it.Cons:No thermostatCould not keep a 9'X13' room warm that has 3 large, original pre-1930s windows w/winter curtains (room was already warmed to over 70* with a higher power electric heater {room is also heated with oil heat}, but within an hour it dropped almost 8*)Fan is a bit weak, only good enough right by your face when the weather is warm.Conclusion:Only good for tiny rooms, small bathrooms if it's over 50* out. Or else a small desk area that has enclosed sides right by your legs to keep your legs/feet warm w/o using a lot of electricity. That's why I even gave it 3 stars - low heat output, but at least low wattage usage.

Includes:Only the printer, 6 ink cartridges, and a power cable are provided. That's all, nothing else, not even a printed quick start manual. One of the ink cartridges is a large black container in addition to a smaller black one for photo prints. This helps reduce cost for printing.Main Features:All in one printer / scanner / copier. Capable of very high quality document and photo printing.Wireless Network And Mobile device Printing Support.Touch Screen display for ease of use with no computer required.Support for SD Cards and Sony Memory Stick.Duplex Printing for printing on both sides of the page.NFC Printing Support for Android devices.Airprint Support for iOS devices.How To/Troubleshooting:Instead of including a manual, on Canon's site, they have over 15 youtube videos about setup & troubleshooting which is new, and great, though using youtube is very unprofessional as google could take it down. There are also pdf basic manuals in several languages for both windows & macs. Two video on how to setup your wifi & several pdfs on airprint, google cloud & wifi printing.Initial Setup:First remove all of the packaging and orange tape on the printer.Initial Setup is simple and straight forward, especially help with the 3.5” touch screen LCD prompting each step you need to do. Plugging the printer in and opening the top cover reveals the carrier for the ink cartridges which simply and easily snap into place with a solid light on each cartridge confirming they're working and full.You have three different connection options to access the printer from a computer: 1) USB 2) Wired Ethernet or 3)Wireless Network. If you choose Wireless network connection to your main network which most people will likely do, you can do an automatic WPS connection, or manually connect by having the printer search for nearby wifi then manually entering the password.Paper Trays / Feeding options and CD Tray:There are two paper trays and a CD Tray. The bottom most paper tray without changing the default configuration will accommodate letter or A4 sized paper. If you take the paper tray out, press a button on the bottom you can extend the tray out for legal sized paper. Doing this will cause the paper tray to extend outside of the printer and no longer be flush. The paper Tray above that can be used for different sized paper in addition to traditional photograph sized glossy paper. Underneath this tray is the tray intended for CD Printing which you would front load in to the printer. When you pull out a tray and reinsert it, the printer will prompt you on the LCD display asking to confirm what paper type is in the tray, such as letter, legal, plain, glossy, etc. You can also disable this option if you never expect to change the paper types.Unfortunately there isn't a large manual paper feeder so all you get are the two relatively low capacity paper trays. This also means if you need to scan multi-page documents with the scanner you need to sit there and manually change each page at a time as opposed to it being an auto process if there was a paper feeder.Mobile Device Printing Support:Good news for iPhone / iOS / Mac users as this printer supports Apples Air Print. This printer is by fair the easiest to print from a mobile device if your device is an iPad, iPhone and so forth as with Airprint you can print directly from most apps on the device which makes life much easier, needless to say.You Can print from Android devices using the Pixima apps in the Google Play store called "PIXMA/MAXIFY PrintingSolutions". There are two main apps you will be using. One for Photo's and Documents and so forth. And another app for printing documents from web pages. For printing from a web page you can either copy and paste the URL from your browser of choice into the Canon Web Browser app, or you can do your web browsing directly within the Canon Web Browser app. Printing Photo's uses the other app which you can use to access photo's or documents on your device. You can also select the paper type and how many copies to print.If you have an Android Device with NFC built in, you can print by holding it up to the printers front right side. You still need the Pixima apps installed. I am not sure how well this feature works though beyond this as I did not have an NFC enabled Android device on hand to test this with.Some features available directly from the touch panel:You can do quite a few things on this printer without the need for a computer using the 3.5” color LCD touch screen display. Using the touch screen was easy and intuitive. There are menu options for each feature category you want to use. The first thing I ended up doing on start up was updating the firmware of the printer which is nice you can do this directly from the printer interface.The most common features people will be using is the copy function and the ability to print a photo directly from an inserted memory SD card or Memory stick. Unfortunately there is no USB memory support.Copying a document is incredibly easy, you lift the top cover over the flat bed scanner, place your document and choose copy and the number of copies. You will then see two new buttons appear on the black panel to the right of the LCD one for black one for color.If you insert a memory card into the printer you can browse through the pictures on the memory card and then directly print it from there.You can also scan a document without a computer, saving it instead to an inserted memory card, which eliminates the need for a PC.Using the *Advanced Print* You can print template forms, such as: lined paper, notebook paper, handwriting paper, graph paper, checklists, weekly & monthly calendars/schedules, etc. on A4, B5, or letter-sized plain paper.There are also various informational and diagnostic functions available through the LCD panel which include the ability to check printer ink levels and do print head alignment if necessary. There are also cloud printing services which I have not had a chance to try out.The Scanner:A big part of what makes this an all in one is the built in scanner which allows you to both copy and scan. As mentioned above you can scan directly to a memory card without a computer or you can scan a document from a connected PC. The top lid of the scanner can raise up to allow room for thick books, or removed completely if necessary. Scanning is very easy, you do a preview copy to outline what you want to scan and at what resolution, Then you do the final scan to save it.Photo and Document Print Quality:I have to say that photo's printed on this machine don't get much better than this. Printing some photo's directly from my phone directly to the printer looked exception with very clear vibrant colors and excellent detail. I couldn't ask for anything more and from using various different printers models in different brands, I have never seen anything better in terms of print quality. Documents also print out very nicely with good detail. The main downside of this printer is it's basic document printing speed is average to below average for printers of this type. And the small paper tray sizes mean printing large documents will mean having to change out the paper one or more times. On the plus side, you do have a duplexer, so you can do two sides printing which saves paper and will allow you to print a larger document while using less paper and the hassle of flipping pages manually. Also one other downside to this kind of printer is the cost per page tends to be higher than that of more business oriented printers. Although, on the flip side you will get better print quality. If you plan do do a lot of web page printouts you may want to consider using a generic ink for the large black ink canister which costs only a fraction of the price. Please note though that I've yet to try one of the generics personally, but I plan to at some point in the future to see how it works out.Summary and Conclusion:This Canon printer is a really nice overall package. From the touch screen color LCD which makes navigation and use without a PC a breeze. The photo printing quality is top quality and will not leave anyone wanting for more. Printing regular documents is average in terms of speed or maybe somewhat below average, so keep that in mind if you plan on printing many large documents. Also consider the somewhat small paper trays as very large documents may use up the paper quickly requiring you to do a refill before it is finished. The scanning and copying on the printer is excellent overall with the main downside being no manual page feeder so scanning large multi page documents will require you doing one page at a time. I am also not thrilled that there isn't a slot to use standard USB memory cards. Support for AirPrint has been a great addition though, and will allow Apple device users to easily print from most application without the need to install anything further.

Had this type of pen when I was a kid. Used to have a button on top to reset the ink choice. This new way of just sliding down the color you want works almost flawlessly. The black one for one of the pens would get stuck, letting the new color button go only halfway, and I'd just push the new color back up to reset the black.The ink flow is smooth enough, not the best, but so far no skipping, and much better then the really cheap pens.Made in France, the inks are refillable for 50 cents each plus shipping at Bic's website: WheresMyBic. com

Included:The unit comes in a sturdy, black, hard-shell, plastic case. It opens and closes nicely and doesn't feel flimsy. In the case you get your hand held meter, 4 AA batteries and multilingual instruction manual with registration card.Features:Checks Carbon Dioxide (NOT Monoxide or any pollutants) in PPM as well as Time Weighted Average, Air temperature, Dew point and humidity and Wet Bulb. Wet bulb temperature can be described as the lowest possible temperature you would feel if your skin was wet and wind was blowing against you.Optional PC support:There is a mini usb connector on the side of the unit as well as a DC jack to plug the unit into a wall plug (9V DC cable is NOT included). There is no software on the Amprobe website specific to this unit. The main purpose of the USB port is for downloading recorded log data of your readings off the device and onto your computer or spread sheet.Operations/use:At it's most basic, using this meter is easy to get it up and running inside a minute to find out your rooms C02 levels. You just insert the 4AA batteries and press the power button. There is a 30 second warm up time. After you see the warmup time the LCD displays the C02 and other readings. These reading will be high at first, so you need to let the unit settle for a minute or two after power on to show the accurate CO2 levels in PPM (Parts Per Million). If you're in a dark room or out doors you can turn on the LED backlight by pressing and holding the mode button until it activates.The LCD is split off into three sections with the largest section showing the CO2 PPM as well as the TWA and so forth. You can press the DP/WBT button to cycle between other displays and there is a min/max button to cycle between the lowest and highest readings you've gotten over the time the meter has been on.There are also built-in alarms if the CO2 levels rise over a given setting. Default is 1,000 PPM which the manual considers the minimal safe C02 levels without any reported problems. You can go into the settings by holding down the set button and reconfigure the settings. The manual describes a “enter” button of which there is none, you will be using the DP/WBT button for that function.Instruction and Calibration:The instruction manual is a bit lacking. It doesn't give very good descriptions of what the actual functions are and things like wet bulb temperature, so you're going to be finding yourself doing your own research to find out how to use the meters other functions more effectively. The manual also gives a basic idea on how to calibrate both the CO2 sensor, and a separate calibration for the humidity sensor, and using some kind of 20% salt bag which is not explained at all and most people will find themselves clueless as to how to do it. In all you really don't need to worry about calibration out of the box unless you see an obvious problem with the readings you're getting.It's a nice unit, but it's instructions are inadequate to say the least, the buttons/UI are not the most intuitive, and it could use a backlight on the buttons. It seems to work well enough and after checking my house readings, seeing it average 400-600ppm, I now have peace of mind as to the air quality in my home.

Speck produces very well-made cases in different styles, textures for different phones for a while now, and this one is no different.I love the galaxy design, but my case had more a mauve pink & purple colors with NO blue. The galaxy image itself looked blown up and blurry compared to the pic shown here.The case has a snug fit that is a bit difficult to put on/off, but not too horrible. It feels very sturdy without adding too much size or weight to the phone, certainly smaller then the well known durable Otterboxes.The candy style has always had a very smooth finish that can be a little slippery in the hand, but not too much. It's still a lot less slippery then an iPhone without a case.It has a small lip edge on the front edge to protect against falls that would normally result in breakage of the glass display. It could be higher, but it's high enough for flat floors, or sidewalks with no pebbles.The only other con is the size of the headphone jack hole. It's too small for most jacks other then the included Apple headphones which have a very slim jack.Pros:Snug fit/slim case, good protectionCons:Small lip edge, Photo on case looks blurry/colors washed out, too small a hole for most headsets.

I have a much older all metal Swingline stapler. This one is a bit taller, but it is MUCH smoother & requires only a light touch to use & it quiet too. It's a difference of night/day. I never expected it to be so easy, and other family members were very pleasantly surprised as well. It is plastic and made in China, whereas our old one was made in America.The Swingline LightTouch stapler is 1.9 x 7.1 x 3.1 inches, it can do 20 sheets & uses SF4 which are standard staples. We have some staples from a VERY old box, and they installed fine & we've used at least 10-15 staples without anything getting stuck or stapling wrong.

This is a basic black, stiff, vinyl pouch with TWO pockets with a velcro closure. It's tall & thin & barely fits an iPhone 5 w/it's case. But amazingly it does what it claims. I tested this by putting a phone in the back pocket where it would be covered on all sides by the gold mesh & did a test call. No ring or voice mail sounds. When I opened the pouch, I quickly looked & the network was just starting to find a signal, and then showed the voicemail indicator. While there's an airplane mode for that, what I liked was that the front pocket isn't lined on both sides & therefore can get a signal. This will protect a person from radiation being absorbed in their body as they wear it.Cons: Stiff vinyl, too small for bigger smartphones, no beltclip.Pros: actually works as claimed, small profile.

Each pet towel is about 34" long & 13" wide. It has a cute dog print with bones design with a large pocket on each end to put your hand it to make drying much easier.They are much thinner then a hand towel, or any other cotton towel, but because they're microfiber, they are very absorbent.If you have dry hands or sensitive to synthetics, the fibers feel they "catch" on your skin, and cotton still feels smoother to the touch.When used on small/medium sized dogs, it did dry them faster then a regular bath towel, and it's much lighter in weight when wet. The pockets came in handy, and the dogs showed no preference over cotton over microfiber.These towels don't have to be used only on pets, they can be used on people or for cleaning, etc. At the price it is, for such a large size towel and a three pack as well, this is a great price.

Color - very nice color for light/med/dark blondes, depending on how much you apply. Looks realistic color, no red tones.Application - A little draggy, but adding a drop of water adds more intense color. Lasts most of the day without a problem.It's great that it comes with a tiny sharpener for on the go with a great design.Compared to Revlon & Covergirl (12 dollars), both thicker pencils, Vincent Longo has a more realistic color & is less gloppy then Revlon.

I wanted this to work, but felt no difference. Bach's Rescue Remedy also doesn't work for me, unfortunately.The only thing that's ever worked was Historical Remedies' "Stress Mints" which family members use and love, including an older man who doesn't believe in natural remedies & certainly not homeopathic stuff.I did expect Dr. King's to work since I had a dog that was near death from kennel cough with fluid in his lungs and Rx from the vet was only making him worse. When I took him off that & used "King Bio Lungs & Bronchial Relief" & "Cough Relief" my dog was running around like crazy within a week.This may work for others though, everyone's body is different.

I rented this & only quickly scanned this once I saw the babbling brook.This DVD has different kinds of new age music, but it's mostly seeing videos of water flowing, nature landscapes & then suddenly a man or a woman in a yoga pose outside & then back to the nature videos. You do not see them going in or out of the pose either. There is no narration which is not relaxing to be staring at nature for several minutes & suddenly you're suppose to be in a modified bow pose.

This is a duo set that has 2 brush heads on each handle. The product says, "the brushes are soft, cruelty-free bristles, has a recycled aluminum ferrule & sleek bamboo handles."The brush set look well made, stylish w/bronze finish & the bristles do feel very soft to the touch.The "bag" can be reused with it's flap, but the bag is so narrow, it's difficult to put in/pull out the brushes without feeling you'll damage the bristles.The brushes are labeled on the handles:Shade & Define Brush: Shading (wide/thin/fluffy) - to apply shadow all over the lid, Defining (thin/angled) brush - to add depth to the eyes.Blend & Smudge Brush: Blend (round/fluffy)  - shadow to eliminate harsh lines,  Smudge (short/tapered) brush - to create soft definition/smokey look along the lash line.I tried these and compared to the brush set I got at a drugstore, these held on to the eyeshadow longer and blended it much better. Not perfect, but much better. For around a six dollar price, these are definitely a great buy.

Shiva Rea has many DVDs & even audio CDs & books. There are many youtube videos, etc. to look at if you don't know her. Her style is always a more fluid one movement goes to another style and in the past ones have incorporated freestyle dance. She's about listening to the body, but even her beginning yoga dvds are challenging to anyone who doesn't have strength, endurance & flexibility. If you don't have one of those, be prepared to pause the DVD for rest, or figure out how to modify the movements for yourself. Shiva's should not be for anyone new to yoga, as she doesn't explain how to do poses in depth that a person new to yoga needs to avoid injury. Don't get me wrong, her workouts are challenging, but she & her movement style really inspires you to listen to what your own body needs to stretch, and that is the most important.Production (music/lighting/camera/outfits, etc.) is professional as always, and Shiva sounds soothing in voiceover. Greece looks gorgeous and the music is soothing without being boring.There is a 2 minute advertising for other workouts clip that is unskippable before you reach the main menu which is really unacceptable.Introduction - Shiva talking about Greece, the workout, etc.Audio Options - Music & Instruction or Music OnlyBonus Material1 - A 26 minute interview with Shiva Rea about the program & Greece more in depth.2 - Prana Danda Yoga Movement Meditation - 10 minutes of Shiva & another man mirroring each other on a mountaintop with a long pole in their hand doing slow standing poses.3 - Shiva Rea Biography - Just a quick paragraph of text.4 - CreditsYoga Matrix - you can pick 1 or as many as you want sections to tailor your own workout pace.MEDITATIONS - Seated to work on your breath/calm the mind1 - Mudra (6 min. on the mountains), 2 - Lunar (10 min. near the water), 3 - Solar (10 min. on rocks above the water)LUNAR - tend to be slower1 - Backbending Flow (20 min. relaxing/easier hip openers), 2 - Moon Salutations (20 min. Outside above the water, greys/blues Luckily not too fast, classic w/more a lot more backbends in the poses & ends with seated twist) 3 - Water vinyasa (20 min. fluid standing poses, back/forth with no feeling of aerobics with twisting)SOLAR1 - Sun salutations (20 min. classic style speeds up to power style speed, vigorous) 2 - Earth Vinyasa (20 min. All standing poses with single leg balancing & hip openers & ends with seated wide angle stretch.)  3 - Solar backbending vinyasa (20 min. A mix of standing, kneeling, standing twists, tabletop, bow, etc. that will stretch everything.) 4 - Earth Water Vinyasa (22 min. Another mix like the Solar backbending that really has many poses standing, kneeling, etc.) 5 - Solar Core (10 min. hip opening/light ab work all done lying on the back)SHAVASANALunar (10 min.) - the only one which is filmed indoors by poolside, she talks only a minute or two before letting just music play..Video ClipsTotalFitnessDVDs has on Youtube a long clip with a little of all the sections - "Shiva Yoga In Greece"Acorn Catalog has on Youtube the entire Solar Core shown here  - "Shiva Rea Yoga in Greece"More clips from CollageVideo & AcaciaFitness

If you were expecting basic ballet movements, there are other great DVDs to look for. This program is more about stretching, lengthening, toning & body awareness using smaller movements, in standing with or without a chair for balance, and some floor work on the second workout.The outdoor setting is beautiful with water in the background. The music is basic jazz that somewhat melts in the background, but has a good upbeat tempo that goes well with Sadie Lincoln's voice over to keep you going, not make you bored. The production, sound/lighting is high quality and professional. Sadie Lincoln has a very pleasant, encouraging voice without being overly perky & even mentions once in a while that some moves can be difficult.Burn & Firm - 34 minutesAll standing movements with some semi-fast back/forth leg movements to warm up at first, then toning of a lot of quadriceps with squats, hamstring & standing balances. You're mostly working just the legs, but the core & some arm movements are incorporated to get a full body workout & lengthen everything. For those with balance issues, Sadie shows modifications, but know this program is based on squats, and one legged balancing & body awareness.Lengthen & Strengthen - 33 minutesThis has some easier toning of the legs, but goes right into hands/knees, then side laying floor work with some additional twist sitting & side stretch poses. It starts with some easy standing back/forth leg movements, and then some easier basic standing toning/balances. You then go for the floorwork into balancing on hands/knees, the side laying leg diamond pose, very small bridge pose for a while. You use a towel under your hips for lifted leg movements, regular bridge pose, plank/slight pushups, side sitting stretches & standing forward bend to end.These programs won't make you sweat, they are more about toning, but they are deceptively difficult, and you'll feel the muscle aches the next day, especially in your quadriceps from the Burn & Firm workout.You can find three different clips on Youtube by: CollageVideo, TotalFitnessDVDs, AnchorBayFitness, or going to their respective websites.

Works well on the 360, Windows 7 was able to install drivers automatically when plugged in & able to play games on Steam.The 7 blue LEDs are VERY bright, you can have them on all the time, off all the time, or on only on vibration by pressing a small button on the back.The cord looks just like the wired MS controllers, in terms of looks/thickness/style, even has a breakaway portion near the usb plug, and has an added bonus of the cord being longer then the MS ones.The stylish, thick, sturdy, clear, simple plastic casing is very smooth, but not slippery. It seems very similar in overall size, buttons & sticks. I love that I'm able to see inside to the board/circuits of the controller, it makes you appreciate how it works.The button/stick layout are the same except the back & start buttons as you see are on a diagonal. The guide button is a picture of the logo, but the 4 outside quadrants light up green just like MS. The buttons are not all tall with no resistance, so those feel a little different, but work well. The sticks feel more snappy, yet loose compared to the slower/smoother MS ones, but they work just the same, just take getting used to.The vibration ability is strong/satisfying.The headset port works well just like MS ones, works well with 3rd party headsets as well.What's great about wired controllers is no alkaline or rechargeable batteries to worry about.I have been using this for a month on/off for several hours & have had no issues yet.

This is instructed by Ashley Turner alone who does voice-over at a beautiful yard of a home or hotel by the water.There are two programs:Yoga for Strength - 33 minThis has a fast tempo piano music that doesn't quite fit with the session. I felt some poses she repeated too many times back/forth like a pilates program instead of holding them longer. I understand the back/forth to add flexibility, but felt she did it too much here, such as planks to low push-ups, or raising on your toes & down in chair pose. It can also be physically demanding with holding planks, push-ups & side planks all at once. This class is better for those who work out at least a little semi-regularly or more often.Yoga for Flexibility - 31 minI enjoyed this music more, it had some piano, but had a good tempo for the movements & had more Enigma feel to it then jazzy. Here, she really focuses on opening up your shoulders, spine, pelvis & hips in a more relaxing way, but not boring, nor so easy you don't feel anything. Her program is unique (I have viewed over 100 yoga dvds at minimum), and I really felt the difference in my joints after, the muscles felt more stretched out/looser.Meditation - 7 minI didn't care for this short meditation, though others might. The music was fast tempo jazzy & she repeated herself too often, saying the same thing over again, many times not even changing the wording.Overall, her style is a combination of the old, true style of yoga with saying the Sanskrit pose names, teaching Ujjayi breathing before each session, and a few spiritual ways of saying how to move your body, and words of encouragement to enjoy the moment and where you are. She also names muscles in their common Western way, and can be very descriptive on how to move your body, and where to feel the stretch, but also leave out some important information for those who are truly new to yoga. I'd say her style of teaching is 3/4 Western & 1/4 Eastern in .This DVD is best for experienced beginners or more of yoga, and those who workout semi-regularly or more.Collagevideo & Totalhealthdvds both have clips on their site, or you can also view them on Youtube.

This unit is advertised as having a 4 amp charge rate, though I suspect that's spread between it's two ports, making it 2 amps each. It has a nice Y stye design and does charge my iPhone 5 twice as fast as the Apple's cable which charges at 1 amp.It did not feel in the way & easy to install & remove.Overall I give this unit a 5 of 5 stars, it looks nice and works right.

Menu:The new navigation is totally revamped from the old, but once used to it, it's very easy to navigate (which you can do by controller as well.) It has a "recommended" song in the middle, the online multiplayer "World Dance Party" at the main top left, the Sweat mode at the main top right, the Shop on the main lower right & the Just Dance TV on the main bottom right. If you go to the right, you'll access the song list, which plays nearly the entire song if you stay on a selected song long enough.Uplay:Is located at the very top left which will take you out of the game & requires an internet connection. This Ubisoft interface isn't user friendly, but to unlock more songs on the disc as rewards for getting achievements you earned, you will be forced to deal with it. It's Ubisoft's way of forcing people to use their software/website for online multiplayer/content already on the disc that you paid for.Settings:You can change your avatar & check your progress at he the very top right where it says your name. You can also turn on/off Autodance (seeing your video clip of you dancing & can add special effects), Help, lyrics, pictos, share (your video dancing to the world), etc.Mojo points:You earn them as the same, but you can get extra for random songs the game selects, for singing while dancing, for dancing online (especially during daily "Happy Hour.") Instead of randomly unlocking things, you can decide which song you want to unlock at your desecration in the "shop" area.Shop:You unlock content on the disc you earned w/mojo points & to buy DLC w/real $. Katy's "Roar" is free & waiting for you as soon as you pop in the disc.Sweat Mode:There are no long list of playlists, instead you decide the time (10, 20, 40 min.) which you can do the selected songs or just change one or all, or do "Free Mode" & just use the regular song list to choose your songs one by one.JTV:Just Dance TV wasn't working for about a month, but witht he new update, it is now. You can share with the world your video of you dancing & see everyone else who shared. It allows you to follow people, like a video, etc.Songs:The songs are listed left to right, when you click on a song, the song keeps playing (great addition), and you can choose the (1-6 different) modes you want, there are many new additions!Classic - the main choreography with more amazing backgrounds.Sweat - new choreography higher energy version which is great, more new choreography for these new songs.Mash-up - takes clips of old videos of dance moves of this game's & JD's 1-4 to make new choreography. I didn't like this as much as clips weren't always edited well enough to flow right & felt disjointed in the choreography to follow well at all. It's better then nothing though, but LOVE the other modes better as it's not clips smashed together.Sweat Mash-up - higher energy mash-upBattle - takes dance moves from 2 songs to battle against a friend or now allows you to battle the AI!Extreme - new choreography that has more complex dance moves then the rest, though you can still get a decent score if you're a beginner.On Stage - 3 person choreography to feel like you're the star with 2 backup dancers that has very easy choreography for the star & moderate choreography from the backup dancers, a great new addition! More new choreography for the star or follow the backup dancer.Mode w/a name of a month -  you have to unlock that mode in the shop during that month, if you miss it, you have to wait 'til next year.Party Master - DO NOT use any mojo points on this yet. This is to have a friend who doesn't want to dance be the DJ, etc. But so far it's not working on the xbox 360, wait until there's another update or Ubisoft says they have this working, it automatically is working on the Wii U which people have posted on youtube which shows, instead of the static pictograpms in this/past JD games, a moving smaller dancer previewing the next move. This was in Ubisoft's Hip Hop Dance experience & Black Eyed peas Dance experience, WHY is this not in ALL the dance modes?World Dance Party:Ubisoft finally added online multiplayer (even the Wii gets it). You will join in mid-way of a song when you start or be in a lobby voting for a song. You see your scores & those in your lobby on the left w/cartoon noises when someone enters the song. If you have "share" on & "autodance" on, clips of you dancing will be shown to everyone if you are #1 in scores for that lobby.Pros:* Still has VERY talented, ENERGETIC dancers (the most important thing in any dance game/fitness dvd)* Has online multiplayer!* New & MORE Modes - extreme, battle w/AI, on stage mode, sweat mash-up* Good menu system* Allows you to choose which song you want to unlock w/your mojo instead of being pre-chosen.* Sweat mode gives you more control over the song choices* Great background graphics, but rather choose more choreography content per song, over graphics* Songs in other languages, opens up more choices, good choices so far that are energetic & not too different from mainstream songs.* They added a song from an animated movie, very cute, opens up more possibilities.* They added a few great 60s/70s song classics.Cons:*Though I don't miss the boring music in sweat mode for the warm-up, cool-down, I do miss the choreography & wish they could have kept those from previous JD's in this one.* I had some issues with the game saying I was one dancer when it was actually tracking me as the other, especially in pre-timed sweat mode (where you can't decide which dancer you are once you start the timer/sequence.)* Possibly some tracking issues, I got perfects when I thought I didn't deserve it & Xs when I knew I should have gotten at least a good.* Some of the moves didn't flow like they always used to, I understand if they run out of basic moves, but I'm not against them redoing moves with the new dancers/songs so that the choreography flows.* They added a slow song like "Careless whisper" which wasn't fun, why add such a slow song??? There should never be any slow songs in a dance game.* Some jumping moves & others seemed WAY too advanced & was hit/miss if you can fake it enough to get a good score.* Loved the extreme choreography, but needs a tutorial or at least an ability to play at 1/2 speed to learn it. Having 1/2 speed on all songs to make it easier to learn wouldn't be a bad & easy to program option.

Speck CandyShell Grip Case iPhone 5/5s - No slip w/great protectionThe design of this case in my opinion is really nice with great aesthetics. The case has a smooth glossy finish with grippy ribs in the back which creates kind of an hour glass look. The black and white color combo of my case offers a great look that will contrast perfectly with either a black or white iPhone.The case fits the iPhone 5 absolutely perfectly offering a seamless fit. Both the volume and power buttons are protected and function well through the case. The cut outs for the mute switch, headphone jack and lightning connector offer ample room. I have no trouble using the mute switch in the case and can use any of my headsets or power adapters with the phone.The Case offers a good lay on the table design with a small lip around the sides of the phone increasing to a larger sized lip as the screen ends which is nice as it doesn't hamper use of the touch screen. The texture to the black portions of the case have more of a rubbery grippy texture so no accidental slips while holding the phone.Drop protection is also fabulous, the iPhone in the case is like wrapping it in a rubber ball, providing a bit of a bounce if dropped even from a short distance.Edit 11/2014:Though the black silicon inside has held up, the outside white smooth plastic is so thin, it has cracked in pieces and fallen off on many of the edges and especially where there were any cutouts for the buttons or bottom. It also has hairline fractures alone the ribbing on the back as well. The silicon edge has even pulled away from the hard plastic rim of the camera hole. This has all happened within 8 months. An older version a friend has of the exact same model has held up perfectly for almost 2 years without any cracking.

Workouts:* This is for working on stability & strength in your workouts.* Having balance/stability is important to keep you from falling in daily life.* Having an unstable surface will strengthen MORE muscles & the small muscles & tendons/ligaments that aren't normally getting a workout when using free weights or weight machines in static poses.* This will create a more functional, powerhouse strength at a faster rate then static poses.* Using an unstable surface will also create a more FUN, LESS BORING workout because you'll be concentrating on keeping your balance, instead of being mindless.* This will increase your awareness of your body, which areas are weak/strong & natural imbalances we all have.* Like any other item, if you are feeling pain or feel it's too hard to use, you may need to strengthen those areas in other ways in between/before using it again to avoid injury.Sitting:* This cushion can also be used on your chair to workout your abs/obliques, erector spinae & small muscles/tendons as you sit.* Using this a short time every so often can help with tight, weak muscles in your lower back & help with pain. Like any exercise, don't use the cushion for a long time every time you sit on a chair as it will cause pain just like anything you exercise too much.Product Points:* Great Price* Has one mostly smooth side & one with fingers on the side to choose from to set down.* Easy to inflate w/any sports needle, or even a cheap hand pump w/needle.* Once inflated, you cannot get the air out other w/time & use.* No instructions, you have to go to: harbingerfitness. com/ product/ 364060* If your disc is a little dirty, you can wipe it down with a damp cloth.Harbinger put out many youtube videos showing use (very low volume on many) under channel Harbinger Balance Trainer:"Harbinger Balance Trainer Core Variations Walking""Harbinger Balance Trainer Core Stabilizer Variations""Harbinger Balance Trainer Pushup""Harbinger Balance Trainer Plank Progressions""Harbinger Balance Trainer Single Leg Hold Progressions ""Harbinger Balance Trainer Hip Bridge Progressions""Harbinger Balance Trainer Side Lunge""Harbinger Balance Trainer Squat Progression""Harbinger Balance Trainer Squat + Side Crunch""Harbinger Balance Trainer Reverse Lunge By Paradise Nutrition Inc"All these videos can be also found on their site:harbingerfitness. com/ category/ balance-resistance/ balance-trainerI haven't had any troubles w/it deflating, I only wish it had instructions with it.

Pros:* Form factor: Stylish, small profile (H 180mm x W 180mm x D 115mm)* Very light (290 grams)* Easy to use w/4 front buttons & 2 small side ones* Beeping tone starts low & progressively gets louder which helps to wake you up & keep you awake much better, all alarms should be like this.* Beeping sound tone is not as jarring as most alarm clocks* Clock display is dimmable to 4 settings* LED arc of lights really helps to wake you up, the yellow color temp is great, not an annoying blue* Light can be used as a normal table lamp at 10 settings, from a nightlight, to VERY bright 200 lux.* Easy to tap on top 9 min. snooze alarm* Military or 12 hr. choice of clock displayCons:* NO battery backup of any kind, unplug it for a SPLIT second, or quick brown out & all info is GONE! I don't care if it eats up a battery after a year or so even if not needed, you need an alarm to be reliable.* Only one beeping sound* Alarm starts still a bit too loud & goes to full volume too fast.* No ability to have the lamp go off w/o the sound going off as well.* Only 1 alarm choice at a time* LED is NOT replaceable* Instructions are poorly writtenConclusion:* All alarm clocks should have progressive loudness sound/light alarms to wake you up in a more soothing way to keep you feeling rested throughout the day.* Overpriced considering no battery backup or choice of beepingSpecs:* Cord Length EU/US: 150/180 CM* Frequency: 50/60 Hz* Insulation Device: Class III* Insulation Power Plug: Class II (double isolation)* Power Input: 7.5W* Power Output Adapter: 5.4W* Type of Lamp: Liteon SMD Lamp LED* LED lamp:  16,000 hours* Voltage: 100/240V* UV-free* Made in China

Belkin 30-Pin Charge & Sync Cable foriPhone 3/3GS/4/4SiPad 3GiPod nano 6GiPod touch 4GThis is a stylish silver chrome plugs w/a black cable to charge your above Apple products.It looks more stylish then Apple's, the wire is less bendable then Apple's which means the cable might be more durable. It's also about 6 inches longer (4 ft/1.2M) then my iPhone 4 Apple cable which is a nice added feature.It can sync to my computer & iTunes just fine.The only issue I have is that when connecting the plug to my iPhone 4, it was a bit tight.It works fine, charging seemed the exact same as Apple's charging cable.

NOCO Genius G7200 12V/24V 7.2 Amp Smart Battery Charger & Maintainer ReviewThe Noco Genius G7200 is a 12V/24V 7.2 amp smart charger. I got it mainly to use as a battery tender for my motorcycle battery, or to top the battery off if I accidentally let it die.Includes:Charger & two quick disconnect cables that use an eyelet style plug.The first cable has alligator style or jumper cable style clips. The second cable is meant for direct connection to your battery battery and includes metal connectors for the battery screws to mount through with a rubber base that shows + and - in case you're color blind.Both cables have in line fuse for additional protection.I had to cut off the included battery connectors from the wire and attach my own because I could not get the screw mounted to my battery, because they were too short and the rubber base with the + and - symbols made them too bulky.Charging modes & battery compatibilities:The Noco Genius is a very versatile unit in it's capabilities.* It supports both 12v and 24v batteries along with most battery chemistry types including Wet, Gel, MF & AGM batteries.* The Nico can be used as a basic battery tender or 13.6v power supply.* It also has a 16v burst mode for quicker charging.* Recovery pulse charging mode to recover deeply discharged and sulphated batteries.* Cold / AGM mode for cold weather or AGM batteries and more!* There's also a safety mode if you should reverse polarity but this only works when used in it's basic charging mode.Switching between modes is a simple matter of pressing and holding down the "Mode" button for a few seconds, then switching between what you want.For using as a basic charger to keep your battery topped off or charge your weak battery, you first plug the charger into one of the eyelet connector cables that's connected to your battery, followed by plugging in the unit. You then tap the mode button to toggle between 12v and 24v battery. There are labels on the top of the unit indicating all the different modes. My battery was already fully charged so all four indicators lit up indicating 100% charge.Overall this is a nice unit with nice many capabilities. I like that it comes out of the box using Eyelet connectors which are very easy and quick to use and can't be plugged in the wrong way by accident. The battery connectors could use a slight design change as I had to cut them off and use my own.

Duracell Powermat PM1PB1 TravelMat Charger reviewThe travel mat is a cell phone sized black magnetic base with built in 15.5WH battery that can charge Pads, tablets, phones, anything via USB at up to 2.1 amp charging rate.To activate, or display the remaining charge (visible via 4 LEDs), you press a button on the side.There's a micro USB plug to charge the device itself.You can keep the Power Mat plugged in all the time, or when on the go, you press the side button to activate charging.When used in conjunction with a Duracel PowerSnap product (such as the iPhone 5 case/backup battery Duracell Powermat PowerSnap Kit - Wireless Charging Case and Backup Battery for iPhone 5 (Black)) you can do wireless inductive charging by simply placing your phone that's within the Powersnap case on to the Travel Mat surface and you will hear an audible sound from the Travel Mat indicating charging. If the travel mat is not plugged in you simply press the side button to activate.Pros:Up to 2.1 amp fast charge through USB portNice designCons:Could be smaller if only used as a USB portable chargerNot thrilled with design of the power snap products designed to work with thisOverpriced for just a product who's main use is just to avoid wires

Duracel Powermat Powersnap iPhone 5 Case/Detachable BatteryThis is an inductive charging case for iPhone 5 made to work with the Duracel Powemat or Travelmat products Duracell Powermat PM1PB1 TravelMat Travel Charger - Retail Packaging - Black.Included:Three part case - the main body, a small detachable bottom (added pic), and the battery.Case:The case itself is pretty poorly made, and designed. It's cheap plastic, it provides no lay on the table design (no protection to the screen if dropped on it), and with no texture, it's slippery in the hand, which is worse when the battery is attached. The cutout for the power button on top could be better as I feel it could allow for a little more space between the plastic cover and the button but it's okay.Bottom Piece:The bottom piece which inserts into Apple's lightning adapter wraps around it, leaving like a 1/4 inch gap at the bottom of the phone. I feel that there would be little shock protection in the event of a drop. The bottom piece also will give you problems using any other headphone jack then than something similar to the standard Apple Ear Pods.Battery/Charging:There is no way to charge the battery without a Duracel powermat accessory. You will need to remove the bottom piece to charge your phone without the power mat.  The cut outs for the side buttons are okay and give you decent access.  To use the inductive charging you simply place the phone while in the case onto your Duracel Powermat and you will hear a confirmation sound that it's charging. You can charge both your case and battery at the same time, or remove just the battery and to charge by itself on the power mat. With the battery installed it adds quite a bit of weight to the phone, easily near double. To charge you press the button on the back of the battery and you will hear a chirp indicating charge. To stop you press and hold down the button for a couple of seconds. I was able to fully charge my iPhone 5 and easily had around 20% left in the battery.Pros:Removable BatteryGive your iPhone full charge with power left to spareInductive charging is convenient/easyCons:Poor design of casePoor Shock and overall protection of your iPhone 5No way to charge battery or phone without buying a Duracel PowermatMust remove bottom piece of case to charge without powermat or when using certain headphones

My grandmother had these when I was a kid & thought they were very cool. They are 2 1/4" wide, but as a kid, I would cut them to make them narrower to fit & they still floated well. They last a long time just like a tea-lights, probably longer if you keep the oil filled. The length of a burn is more due to how much fuel (wax/oil) & how quick it burns down & if it's refilled, not how large the container is for say a wax candle.Also, most candles for the past couple of decades or more are made of paraffin (a sludge waste product from the petroleum industry), not animal fat or vegetable oil like 50+ years ago & therefore are toxic when burned.Paraffin is the major ingredient in most conventional candles and is a sludge waste product from the petroleum industry. It releases carcinogenic chemicals when burned. The soot/fumes are similar to that released from a diesel engine and can be as dangerous as second-hand cigarette smoke. This can contribute to serious respiratory issues like asthma.Other toxic chemicals, benzene and toluene, acetone, Trichlorofluoromethane, Carbon Disulfide, 2-Butanone, Trichloroethane, Trichloroethene, Carbon Tetrachloride, Tetrachloroethene, Chlorobenzene, Ethylbenzene, Styrene, Xylene, Phenol, Cresol, Cyclopentene are also found in the sooty residue from burning candles. Benzene is cancer-causing and toluene affects the central nervous system.

This is a great idea to reduce neck/shoulder pain & keep you from slouching which will also improve your posture. But the design could be much better.Size & Monitor use:This is 20" wide total & 8.5" deep.But since it slopes a lot upwards on the sides for style, that only leaves 12" barely straight for your monitor stand.My monitor is 22" w/a Y shape stand & it barely fits. The weight of my monitor also indents a bit the middle smoke gray piece making me worried if my monitor was slightly heavier, it would break the smoke gray piece away from the rest of the white frame.Also provides an extra storage area underneath:For your stapler, tape dispenser, etc.But the opening height is short at 2.5" On the side where the legs are, it gives more clearance of 4" from the desk which does not including the legs. So I can grab my office size stapler from the middle, but to get my heavy office tape dispenser, I can only reach it from the side.Great idea, but the design leaves much to be desired because the sloping restricts stand use & the plastic doesn't feel sturdy enough for larger monitors.

I've been looking for a stylus that responds well that has a smaller tip & though this works better then only one other stylus I tried, this is just a basic one.Size of Stylus/Abilities:About the width of a slightly fatter cheap pen, only a little bit shorter at 4" including tip.It does NOT contain a cap for the tip (to keep it dust free), nor does it function as a pen at all or any other ability.Tip style/size:The tip is the usual rubber ball, wide large marker size & a bit squishy.Performance:I tested this back/forth with an "iHome 2-In-1 Pen Stylus" which has the same type of tip, but it's length is the size of an average pen, but very slim in width of both the shaft & tip compared to this Belkin stylus & has an ink pen on the other side.Using an iPhone w/protective screen film (film made the iphone less responsive since I installed it) & using the Sketchbook app, it was hard to see a difference in script or print handwriting. Both responded about the same (well) it terms of knowing you pressed down, though the iHome squished a noticeable amount more then the Belkin & squeaked across the screen sometimes. Both styli worked much better then my finger though.Overall, it's 6 on one hand, 1/2 a dozen on the other. The iHome felt better since it had a smaller tip, but the squishiness of the tip got in the way. The Belkin felt like it had more control with less squish, but it's tip felt way too wide like most stylus.Considering the price, there's no reason it couldn't have a cheap ink pen on the other side & a cap. But the stylus does respond well & doesn't have too much squish of the tip.

The Amprobe AM-570 industrial multimeter offers just about every feature imaginable in this type of product. It is truly geared to the seasoned pro but (with at least some basic knowledge) can be useful for the hobbyist as well (certainly in terms of some of the features). The applications for this meter are extensive (this is why it is primarily intended for advanced, professional use).It provides true RMS (can be considered essential) voltage readings, can detect stray voltages, can take accurate measurements on variable frequency motor drives (incorporating a low pass filter), and has a multitude of ranges (both automatic and manual).It can measure AC/DC voltage (up to 1000v), resistance, capacitance, frequency (Hz) and temperature (even differential temperature, since two temperature probes are included).It has a dual display (which, for example, can be used to monitor voltage and frequency simultaneously). This can be a very useful feature.Provided with the meter are:Test leads, temperature probes (with an included adapter which needs to be inserted into the meter prior to use), a Velcro strap (for the option of hanging the meter), a backpack material zippered carrying case, and even included, a 9v battery (already inserted). The user's manual (which, although somewhat concise, can be helpful to those unfamiliar with the extensive features provided) is written in six languages (including English) at 25 pages each.The meter has a retractable stand which has rubberized feet to prevent it from moving around as you manipulate the controls.The LCD display can be backlit (a very useful feature) and it even has an LED "flashlight" (for use in limited light situations). The LED bulb provides more light than I anticipated (a nice touch). Although it has no beam adjustment, it's still quite handy. It is accessed via the "REL" button.The safety ratings include: Cat IV-600v (for low voltage applications) and CAT III-1000v (for building related applications such as circuit breakers, distribution boards, outlets, etc.)My primary experience has been with Fluke meters (considered the standard against which other brands are measured). I was intrigued with this particular Amprobe meter, as it had so many useful/valuable features at a very reasonable price! Even though Amprobe is a reputable company, in all honesty, I was still skeptical (I tend to approach most products with a good deal of "healthy" skepticism).The AM-570 is about average in size (for a meter such as this) and weighs under a pound. It measures 7.2" H x 3.5"W x 1.8" D. The rotary switch has enough tension to prevent accidentally moving past a desired setting. The various buttons are "rubberized" and there is adequate spacing between them. The tension on the buttons is adequate. The overall layout of the controls is good.The LCD display was adequate in size, but wish it was a bit larger. It has a back-light feature (which is essential). You will need to hold down the "HOLD" button (no joke intended!) to turn it on, but it only stays lit for 10 seconds (even if you continue to hold down the button). However, I did find that the LCD display maintained good contrast at various angles to be able to read the screen. The plastic window covering the LCD display is capable of reflecting quite a bit of ambient light, so that can be an issue. The display will turn itself off after being idle for more then 15 minutes, and you can move the dial to "OFF" to reset it.The test leads are designed so that a minimal amount of the tip is exposed. This degree of insulation is very useful when testing tightly spaced circuit boards (and in various other scenarios). However, it would have been a nice feature to be able to remove the plastic insulators (so as to expose more of the tip) and then be able to re-insert them. This would come in handy for me, as I sometimes need to test AC at an outlet. These test leads make that option impossible. At least you can purchase accessory Amprobe test leads that will do the trick for this (or perhaps other) purposes.Pros:Extensive applications (includes true rms and temperature).Very accurate readings.Dual LCD display (which maintained very good contrast) and backlight.Sturdy, retractable stand with "rubberized" feet.Built in flashlight.Good control layout/controls have a positive feel.Durable construction.Includes (adequate) carrying case (which holds meter, test leads and temp. probes/adapter).Includes hanging strap.Test leads can be stored on rear of meter.Relatively lightweight.Cons:Would prefer larger LCD display.Backlight reduced contrast of display.Backlight remains on for merely 10 seconds (multiple button presses required for sustained backlight, which can be annoying).Rear cover would have to be removed (unscrewed) in order to change fuse.No individual covers for tips of test leads.Soft carrying case offers somewhat limited protection.Fortunately, these are relatively minor criticisms. Overall, I was impressed at the accuracy of this meter and the overall functionality. It appears to be well constructed and, hopefully, will withstand some bumps and bruises. It is encased in rubber (or a rubber like material) which should prevent it from damage upon dropping. The carrying case is of decent quality but is of the soft variety. I would have preferred a hard case but it will certainly suffice. Everything provided fits well inside the case and there's even a slot for the user's manual.In terms of "bang for the buck", this meter passes the test with flying colors! What it offers at the current price of $ 80 cannot be duplicated. I was reluctant at first, but eventually was very pleasantly surprised.

What's in the box:The Jot Touch pen, which includes an extra tip, the USB Megnatic charger, and in the back of the box you get the manual in the form of small cards (which is very strange).What it works with:This device WILL WORK with ANY capacitive touch screen as a BASIC stylus ONLY just like any other "fat tip" stylus, the buttons will not work, nor the pressure sensitivity ability. It won't require Bluetooth, nor use the stylus's battery, so you won't have to worry about that.BUT, to take advantage of the pressure sensitive function & buttons, you need to use with an iPad/iPad Mini that MUST have Bluetooth 4 support on/working. That means you can't use the 1st gen iPad with it.Design & Use:Feel:This is a nice looking stylus and mostly metal construction. It feels well made, sturdy, and has a nice feel in the hand. The Stylus has a cap which screws on or off both ends of it so you wont loose the cap. Because of the metal construction, if you're looking for a feather weight stylus you'll need to look elsewhere.Tip/Disc & Buttons:The difference with this stylus is the tip is very, very fine compared to almost all other stylus, and it also has a thin plastic disc around the tip so it can slide smoothly over your screen, and is attached via a spring loaded pin. It has two buttons on the bottom side of the pen, and a single status light which shines red, green or flashes to indicate what mode it is operating in.Charging:The end of the stylus magnetically attaches to the charger, and the LED turns on indicating charge & then plug the other into a USB port on a computer or USB power plug.Use with Bluetooth:I tested the Adonit Jot stylus on an iPad Retina using the Procreate app, making sure the Bluetooth 4 was on & linked to the stylus. You then go into the settings in the app to enable Jot support. You can then can define what function either of the side buttons will perform. By default it works as an Undo feature.Pressure Sensitivity:The pressure sensitivity is great when it works, allowing me to transition from thin to thick lines with slight changed in pressure as I write or draw. In addition to just drawing thin to thick lines I would draw patterns and increase pressure making the design get ever so much darker, adding a sense of depth. Even using this stylus in programs that don't support the pressure sensitivity had a boost in usability. I could much more precisely write, sign my name or draw far beyond what would be possible with a lesser quality stylus or your finger.Small Issues:From time to time, I had problems with the stylus not responding when I first started drawing/writing & would have to pick up the stylus & try again. I also had frequent problems with the side buttons not performing their pre-defined functions in Procreate. I wasn't able to test within other programs so I could not say if this is a problem with the Jot stylus or Procreate, but I'm more inclined to think it's a bug in the program itself.Conclusion:Overall this is a very good product, and it's fabulous to use. It's a serious disappointment that I can't use the pressure sensitivity with my iPhone 5 as there's no technical reason I can think of as to why it should not. I would give this unit 5 stars, but between the occasional glitches where the device wont work properly, and no iPhone, and only iPad support, as well as the price point, I take off a star.

Pros:* Eco-friendly in terms that you don't have to throw it out after every use, but can but used up to 20x* Saves you money* You can use any ground coffee you want* Strong BPA free plasticCons:* Unless you pack it deep, it can do weak coffee (due to the tight weave), but if filled to the top even without packing it down will produce a good cup of coffee as you expect.* Lid can be hard to open, but worth it knowing it won't open too easily* Rinses easily, but still has some residue (I only used water/light touch clean fingers)I did 1 cup for a family member as I don't like coffee & he likes it w/a good amount of milk/sugar. I used a new Free Trade organic medium blend & filled it nearly to the top w/o any spilling. He said it tasted great, not weak.

OverviewThis web cam is intended to be run without the need for a computer, although you technically need either a computer, or a smart phone for initial setup, and access to a wired network jack. You can use this camera as a monitoring, or security device and it works in day or night time conditions. The software has motion sensing capability and notification. It's not weather proof so don't install it outside. The base of the camera is wall mountable and the camera can be positioned in any direction.
