There is also a built in microphone and speaker for two way conversation capability from the camera.Setup and Installation* The camera is powered by the included power to USB cable and USB to AC plug.* An Ethernet cable is included and needed for initial installation, although wifi can be used there after if you can get it to work. In my case the built in wifi would not connect to my Linksys 4200v2 router, but would work with a hotspot feature on my smart phone.I used the device on both my iPhone and my PC.To downlod the smart phone app search for "eview" in their respective app stores.If you will be using a computer to setup the camera, you need java (java. com), then login to www.Q-SeeEView.com to register an account. Make sure you say yet to the security prompts that come up for java or it won't work.Once I registered an account in the iPhone app I added my camera to the app by scanning in the bar code on the back of the web cam using my iPhone. Alternatively you can enter the serial.You can have multiple cameras added to your account.Camera Quality & General UsageVisual:The video quality is OK at best. It's only standard 480 VGA, doesn't have wide screen & doesn't have any focusing ability so nothing can ever get very sharp.At least the camera can auto selects between normal & night vision (b&w look) and that works well.Mic:It can turned on/off within the app so you can hear. You also have a mic button so you can speak to the person on the other end, though the speaker volume is not very loud & wouldn't be be heard in a noisy environment.Storage/Playback:If you buy/install a micro SD card, you can play back video from any specific time. The camera is supposed to work with up to a 32GB micro SD card. I installed a 4GB card into the camera but could not get the camera to record or get it's reply function to work.Pros and ConsPros:* Descent design, nice mount for easy positioning.* Does not require any port forward or configuring of your home router to work.* Good Night Vision* Motion Detection* Microphone so you can see and hear the video.Cons* Randomly goes off line on it's own* Wifi does not work reliably* Image quality is subpar* Recording playback did not workFinal ThoughtsGiven it's problems, glitches, the price & that there are better HD alternatives available from other company's that will work/setup more reliably than this camera I can not recommend this.

In the boxYou get the car (12" long X 8 1/4" wide), remote, antenna pole & some extra clips.The car takes 6AA batteries and the controller 2 AAA batteries (uses a screw, not an easy tab to close the cover).You can control the car via 27 mhz frequency on 3 different selectable frequencies as A, B, or C.SetupAntenna -The antenna on the car is a long black wire, you unwrap the wire and push it through the clear pole and insert the pole in the middle of the car. You can also get away without using the antenna pole and instead use it with the antenna wrapped around the car but you'll get better range with the antenna wire propped up through the pole. The body of the car is attached to the car with 4 plastic clips, extras included.Batteries -are installed on the bottom of the car without having to remove the body where you also find the A/B/C/OFF switch. There is also a TRIM lever by the front of the car to adjust the steering of the car so it drives in a straight line. You can use up to three of these cars using each on a different channel.CONS* There is an off mode on the car but not on the controller which can eat up batteries.* Uses a VERY small steering wheel on handle design to turn left/right instead of the common 2 stick control. This is too small even for a short woman, much less an adult man.* The car is a bit slow by today's standards going maybe 3-4 mph tops which can be frustrating.* The turning radius going forward is terrible, requiring the full width of my driveway to do a full circle, though the car does turn more tightly in reverse.* Speed & steering is only on/off, no variation control at all, which makes it much less fun & almost tedious to control.PROS& Full suspension & 4-wheel drive.* Great Off-Roading ability - I can easily hop over 2" curbs though slightly higher curbs will require me to enter at a slight angle to hop them. I can easily go on/off different forms of terrain and through thick grass.* The range is excellent even to the point where the car became too small to see & navigate well.* The car also drives straight and true with the trim set straight in the middle.Final ThoughtsThe car overall is okay, the off-road driving and radio range is the main reason I will give this car my 3 of 5 star recommendation. Otherwise the poor steering and slow speed may be a let down for many.

The Spigen Slim Armor iPhone 5 case features a slim design, with a look intended to match that of the iPhone 5. It comes in two components, a plastic back & a rubber body. The plastic back can be switched out with different colors. The metal slate looks like a modest, understated almost black, similar to a black iPhone 5, though not exact. The gunmetal has more pop/style w/modern metal style.Installing the case onto my iPhone 5 is very easy. I simply start by putting the button side in first then pop the remaining portion in.The overall fit of the case is good & it offers a lay on the table design for flat surfaces. All of the buttons are protected and easy to use. There are cut outs over the ports, camera and speakers, though the cut outs are only just large enough to provide access & doesn't have much room for larger the very slim headset jacks or any docking stations, etc. This also can make getting to the  vibrate toggle as the cut out could stand to be a little bit wider.The feel of the case in the hand is okay, but the smooth plastic/rubber surface leaves me with a not very satisfying feel when handling the device in the case. The slimness & form fitting is good for those who don't like a bulky case, or have small hands.Overall this is a descent case, looks nice & offers you good drop protection if your phone lands on it's back or sides, though with the barely raised lip on the screen side, it offers minimal protection there.

Contains:30 Pin plug dongle heart monitor that connects to your iOS deviceEar sensor clip (w/shirt clip) cord w/2.5mm jack that plugs into the heart monitorA small cloth travel pouchGuide telling you what app to downloadCompatability:Works with 3rd & 4th Generation iPod Touch, iPhone 3GS/4/4S, all versions of the iPad. You can use this on your iPhone 5 if you buy an adapter from Apple that let's you use any iPhone 3/4 accessories. It's called a 30 pin to Lightning plug adapter (converts the old iPhone/iPad large plug to new iPhone/iPad small size plug).Setup:First thing you do is download the free "Inner Balance" program from the iOS App store.  Plug the 30 pin dongle to the bottom of your phone, then the ear sensor plugs into that via a headphone type jack.  The end of the cable then clips to your earlobe.  When you run the app for the first time it well ask you to allow the program to use the sensor.What it does:The purpose of the HeartMath sensor with Inner Balance software is to use controlled breathing techniques in conjunction with your heart rate to promote improved health, reduced stress, increased relaxation and well being, among other benefits associated with meditation.How the App works:You have no other choice in order to use this program but to do it in sessions.START a SessionTo start a session you single tap the screen, to swipe between the different screens you swipe left or right, to get a help screen you press and hold your finger on any screen, and to end the session you double tap.  When you first begin a session you are asked to start a journal entry for the session, beginning with your mood, represented by a smiley face icon.FINISH a Session:You can again select the mood, or optionally you can choose "not now" and skip creating any journal entry.Monitoring Screens:The main/(1) screen you will see consists of a Heart rate graph on top, a circle with a meter that lights up around it representing time, and how well you're doing, called "coherence" and inside is a breath pacer which looks kind of like a flower that grows larger and smaller and you pace your breathing accordingly.  You can also go into options changing how fast or slow the breath pacer works.Swipe to page (2) & you will see a different representation of the breath pacer.Page (3) is an "inspirational photo" (can be changed in the options), and the breath pacer is now a dot that goes left and right.Page (4) has your Coherence level, current length of time in the session, your achievement level in the session, heart rate and a graph of how your coherence has changed over time.The (5th)/last screen shows you your actual pulse rate, a computer graphical spectrum of what the sensor is reading, as well as your current coherence, length of time and current achievement level for your session which will continue to rise until you stop the session.Result Logs:You can review your prior sessions by clicking on the "review" tab on the bottom, it will show your sessions by date & give you the results page of each of those sessions when you select it. You also have the "Journal" tab on bottom to review or delete past journal entry's and see what your mood selections were.HeartMath Tab:It explains what Inner Balance is and how best to use it.  They recommend using it on a daily basis at least until you reach 300 achievement points or more for the day, increasing your difficulty level when your coherence goes above 80 to 90 percent.My impressions and final conclusion:Pros:The HeartMath sensor was easy to connect & use.You can see your heart rate change/your heart beat wave change as it happens.I can send the results screen to facebook, twitter, or email.I could see immediate results and feedback from the program in the form of audio and visual ques if my breathing was off or I become distracted.It's great it has 4 difficulty settings to further challenge myself and ability to breath and focus.As someone who's used meditation and focusing techniques most of my life I can attest to the effectiveness of this program and general advise it provides.Cons:There was some difficulty navigating around,  a bit clunky, but you'll get used to it.If all I want to do is quickly see my heart rate, I can't without starting a session.There is no multi-user support (no user login.You can't change the breathing rate without ending a session.All the prior result logs are bunched into one profile & the only way to differentiate is to note it in the journal entries when beginning a session.The results logs don't list time of day, only date & don't show the heart rate.Other that that it's a nice overall package, it could be a 5 if they did an update to address the cons. It's a good purchase for anyone looking a way to ease stress, relax, improve your overall health and ability to sleep.Youtube video showing the unboxing & use:"HeartMath Sensor For IOS with inner Balance Review and unboxing" by Ben7Seven7youtu. be/ 7rmWcr3GXuU

IncludesThe packaging is very nice seems inspired by Apple inspired in it's simplicity and design.You'll find the cute little Wireless UnitA short USB Mini CableA USB Wall chargerA short RJ45 Ethernet cableA mini CD with the PDF documentationBasic Specs:Supports Wireless B/G/N up to 150 Megabits.on 2.4ghz only. As well as every security option currently available including WEP, WPA and MAC filtering. Acts as a wireless Access Point, Bridge, Repeater, Router or wireless adapter.This unit supports different operating modes as I will list below. By default the unit is in AP or wireless Access Point mode. Access Point mode is what I think most people are likely to use this device for. Access Point mode turns any wired network into a wireless capable network. This is also the easiest way to use the device as it requires no configuration or setup on your part. Lets say you visit someones home or hotel room and they only have a wired network. All you would need to do is plug the RJ45 cable from the wired connection into the unit. And the USB connector can plug either into the wall plug adapter or into a computers powered USB port. That's all you have to do, now connect to your wireless AP / hotspot with your laptop or tablet. The default IP address, SSID and Password are printed on the bottom of the device. Please note that the password is Case Sensitive.Additional operating modes are listed below. If you want to change the mode of the device you will need to login to the configuration page of the router. The default IP for the router is 192.168.0.254 the ID and Password by default is Admin and Admin. If you can't access the configuration page for the unit with it plugged directly into your home networks router, you will need to plug it into your computers wired port directly, and configure your TCIP network adapter from automatic to manual and set your IP address to192.168.0.120 (120 can be 2-253) and SUBNET mask of 255.255.255.0Performance of the unit in AP mode was very good. I tested it in conjunction with a TP link USB network adapter on my laptop and tested it throughout the house. I was able to get the full 150 megabit connection most everywhere I went and was able to make full use of my Verizon Fios Internet connections download speed of 43 megabit and upload of over 30Megabit.Overall this is a nice little device, multi-functional and very simple to use out of the box for the main function most people will be using it for. I give it 5 of 5 stars. You can read below for information on the additional modes of the device and how they work.The different wireless modes you can select and choose from and how they work.  AP - The wireless access point mode. You can set its parameters on the Wireless Basic Settings page and the Wireless Security page.  Router - The wireless Router Mode. The only wired port works as WAN.  Repeater - The Repeater Mode. It could extend the range of wireless network.  Bridge - The Bridge Mode. It could communicate with another wireless network.  Client - The Client Mode. The computer connected by Ethernet could get access to an AP by Client mode.AP mode is already explained above.Use ROUTER mode f you want to set up your own discrete wireless network with its own separate IP range. This is the only mode the devices built in DHCP server will be on.Use REPEATER mode if you want to rebroadcast the signal of an existing wireless network to extend it's range. In this mode you can use the default SSID of TPLINK or change it to the same SSID as the wireless network you're extending. You login using the same network security password as the network your extending. In repeater mode you can also access the internet by plugging your computer into the wired network.Use BRIDGE mode to turn an existing wireless network into a wired network. When you configure BRIDGE mode you will connect your computer to the wired network port. You can also connect wireless clients to the device while it's in BRIDGE mode, they will login using the same credentials they would with the device in Access Point mode.Use CLIENT mode if you want to use the unit only as a basic wireless adapter without it broadcasting or rebroadcasting it's own SSID for other people to connect to. Using the device in this mode requires you to manually set the TCPIP address of your computer to 192.168.0.0 the last 0 can be any number from 2 to 253. For example 192.168.0.110 And you would set the SUBNET mask to 255.255.255.0 You then login to the units configuration page via your web browser and using the "site survey" option select the wireless network you would like to connect to.

System RequirementsMac OSX 10.4 or betterWindows Vista/7 or newer, with 1GB available HDD space & at least 256MB RAM(though I wouldn't suggest using any Windows Vista/7/8 PC w/less than 1GB of RAM for a half decent performance)I used this on a Win 7 & installed the available updates before using the program, it seemed to run fine.Corel Essentials 4 brings the joy of painting to your PC without the expense of paints or the mess. Essentials 4 is a complete redesign from previous version and incorporates many features of their higher end Corel Painter X.Manual & Video TutorialsThis comes with an easy to read 120 page manual with full color photos. The program includes many videos showing you how to use the program AND step by step guides on many projects & other ideas on the many things you can do with the program.New/Photo LayoutsWhen you start the program you have a couple of layout choices. One simply brings up a blank canvas for you to paint on. The other allows you to use a source image to work with, or paint on top of as a layer.BrushesThere are many types including thin/think paint, water, pens/pencils, calligraphy, charcoal, chalk, pastels, crayons, and MANY more!You now have brush "drawers" that allow you to open different paint brushes in a tabbed interface. You see a sample of how the brush stroke will look for each given brush. Recently used brushes are displayed outside of the drawer for quicker access.A new feature is the 6 Corel Trademarked brushes called RealBristle. RealBristle brushes reproduce and simulates the way a paint brush works in real life. Another nice new feature is a Brush Ghost cursor. It creates a visual representation of the paint brush, where it is on your canvas and how much paint you're using. You can toggle this feature on and off.Mixer PaletteThe new mixer palette includes 88 color presets of colors with the additional ability of you mixing different colors together to create new ones as you would in the real world.Overall this is a nice program, it's not perfect but goes a long way to bringing real world painting to your computer work space. You'd also do well to buy a drawing tablet to use in conjunction with this program to enhance your results and experience.

These 34 AA mercury-free alkaline batteries came in the small, easy to open cardboard box you see, with 2 smaller thin cardboard trays wrapped in shrink wrap inside.I tested the batteries with a multimeter & they came out 1.61-1.63 each. To know if they last 10 years which is more then the usual 2-4 years, would take too long to test.Knowing it's mercury-free helps, as well as the packaging is a little more environmentally friendly/less expensive & much easier to open.The price listed is ($) 28, so they come out to be less then a dime each which is much cheaper then retail.

Contains:A lightweight, plastic trimmer (size of an electric toothbrush) with the trimmer head attached, small, medium & long sized combs, and a brush. Also included is a second head that works as a conventional shaver & a single AA battery.Usage:Setup and usage is a breeze, you turn the shaver on by twisting the bottom piece that holds the battery into the ON position.Whomever said two heads are better than one got it right with this trimmer. The two heads easily twist then pull off.Trimmer:You get the trimmer head with which the 3 different combs attach. You trim your beard to varying lengths by stroking the comb up through your beard. It can take a little practice as holding the trimmer at different angles will alter the length of the trim so try to find the sweet spot and be consistent. Unfortunately, the size of the small and medium combs are virtually the same size, so it would have been nice to have a more significant difference between the two in terms of length options.Shaving:The unit has a conventional shaving head that will allow you to do a close, fine shave in areas surrounding your beard. The top of the mini head easily removes by pressing two side buttons together for easy cleaning.Battery:Using a AA is great as you can always find one around & using rechargeable are great. You can always toss a rechargeable AA once it can't hold a charge, unlike a lithium which would have made the unit unnecessarily expensive.Final ThoughtsBoth the trimmer and shaver heads work very well, it's inexpensive & it's a nice travel size.

I've used many Symantec / Norton Products for years. And in the last few years, Norton has rewritten and improved their anti-virus and security software from the ground up, removing the bloat and improving performance greatly. This latest rendition is no exception. Norton 360 multi device gives you a license to install on up to 5 different devices using your single license. Devices include: MS Windows or Apple Mac OS computers, or mobile devices (Android or Apple iOS).Installtion takes a minute or two depending on the speed of your computer. Once installed on my Windows PC and open Norton 360 you are greeted with a start screen featuring 4 different primary tasks: Securty, Identity, Backup and Tuneup. In addition, you have options on top to change the settings and preferences of the program.Security:This tab is where you will run your virus scans. Ranging from a quick scan of your computer checking virtal areas or a full system scan checking all of your files. It also has a facebook scan which checks your walls for potential virus infected links. You can slso have access to the Live update function which keeps your program up to date. Manage firewall if you're a power user and want to manually configure the firewall setting which blocks or allows specific types of internet traffic to and from your computer. And lastly, Norton insight which is feedback from other Notron users as to the safety of specific programs.Identity:This category allows you to configure Norton Safe Web, Antiphishing and Identity safe. Safe web checks the security level of web sites while anti-phishing can prevent you from surfing to known fraudulent web sites. Identity Safe is a password manager it can store your various passwords, and website login and other info including notes. Just be careful not to loose your password as there is no recovery option beyond a password hint. Identity safe is also available as a free standalone program.Backup:Allows you to backup files on your computer. When backing up you have the option of selecting where to backup to, dvd, external hdd, flash drive, cloud storage, etc. Once you've created your backups, in the event of a disaster, or simple accidental file deletion, you can easily restore any backed-up files or programs. An added bonus of Norton 360 Multi Device over the regular Norton 360, is it gives you 25GB of cloud storage versus 2GB on the regular version.Tuneup:This is where you go to defragment your hard drive, cleanup your registry, startup items and old temporary files.Mobile Apps:There are both some iOS and Android apps available, though the iOS apps have little value over what functionality is already built into the device. There is the identity Safe app, so you can use that to access you stored passwords and such.The Android apps on the other hand have far more value than the iOS apps. One being that the Android app has actual malware / antivirus scanning, which is more important for Android than iOS as iOS has fewer malware and vulnerabilities due to it's closed Apple ecosystem. The Android app also included the ability to remotely locate your device should it be lost, backup your contacts to the cloud, block unwanted texts and calls. If it's lost/stolen, it can also remotely lock and or wipe your device, as well as a sneak peek option which uses the front facing camera of your device to snap a picture of the person using your device.In conclusion Norton 360 Multi device is a really great product and a great value to those of you using more than just a couple of computers / devices. It is programmed well and not overly demanding of your computers resources. I've yet to get viruses on any computer running Norton. It's packed full of many features to keep your computer running it's best, and files backed up should disaster strike. I would give it five stars if not for more robust iOS products.

If you need a high speed wireless adapter in your desktop pc look no further than the TP-Link TL-WDN4800.In the Box:Quick install guide.TP Link PC Card.3 screw on antennasMini Driver CDBasic Specifications & System Requirements:Runs on Windows XP, Vista, and 7. 32 or 62 bit.Dual band 2.4ghz and 5ghz Wifi up to 450mbps on either band.PCI Express interface (only needs smallest size PCIX slot (but will work in a larger slot).Supports Wireless 802.11 A,B,G and N so you've got all your bases covered.Supports all wireless encryption standards, WEP, WPA etc.Detachable RP-SMA Connector for the antennas.Setup & usage & performance:I used a custom PC with an Asus motherboard running an Intel Core2 Duo CPU and Windows XP SP3 with 4GB of memory. The PC (located in the basement) will be connected to my Linksys E4200v2 dual band access point located on the 2nd floor.1) The wireless card itself is very small and also includes a low profile bracket for installation in very small home theater style cases. I installed the card into an available PCI Express slot, then screwed in the 3 included antennas to the back of the card.2) I downloaded the drivers from the website versus using them from the CD (usually the software on a CD is out of date). The software installed smoothly and required a restart upon completion. After reboot I now see a signal bar icon on the lower right of my task bar.3) Clicking on the icon, I go to the middle tab and create a new profile by doing a "scan" of wireless networks and entering the security type. I created a profile for both my wireless 2.4ghz and my 5ghz bands.4) Overall performance was better on the 2.4ghz band as I had full signal strength and approximately 80% signal strength from the 5ghz band. I used a speed test site to measure my download speeds and on the 2.4ghz band I was getting my full 43mb download speeds while on the 5ghz band I topped out at 31mb. And in the status bar I would range between 160 and 250mb connection speed versus 54 to 108mb connection speed while on 5ghz. 5Ghz is only better when there is a lot of interference from 2.4ghz devices in the area. Usually 5ghz band is less congested and will offer a more reliable signal. Also if you're close enough to your router where you can get a full signal or if you get high gain antenna's that will also boost your reception making using the 5ghz band more viable.Conclusion:I really like this product overall. It works great, it's 3 antenna detachable design offer you the choice of using higher gain antennas for improved reception. The low profile design of the card and included bracket make this card an easy fit in any PC with an available PC express slot. Software install was smooth and painless. It will run on any version of Windows from XP on up. Just make sure you have the latest service packs installed.

This very small stereo product (about 3 & 1/2" in diameter all around) is great for on the go when you need speakers. It has a short (12" including the jack itself) 3.5mm headset cord to plug into any MP3 player, feature phone, smartphone, tablet, PC, etc. that has a headset jack port.Approximate Dimensions: 94mm W X 94mm D X 81mm HPower Options:There is a blue LED indicator when the power is un underneath the mouth.It can run on either 3 AAA batteries or or MINI USB cord (neither is included.) There is no ability to use a regular universal power adapeter. You can buy a MINI USB cord from their site, impeccaUSA.There is no power level indicator.I like using rechargable batteries as opposed to a rechargeable lithium battery because you can always carry another set of batteries should the power be low.There is no power level indicator.Use:The power switch is on the bottom & the volume disc is on it's right side.The small manual is in English, French & Spanish.The 3.5mm headet cord is only 12" inlcuding the jack itself which is quite short wraps around the unit & the jack tucks in the back which feels it could slip off easily over time.Speakers:The speakers are the units eyes.Total RMS power:1W each 1KHz 10% THDSignal to noise ratio: > 90dBFrequency response: 150Hz ~ 20KHzDriver: 1.5" high-excursion driver40MM full-range neodymium driversSound Quality:The sound is a little bit tinny, but has great bass & doesn't sound muffled. It suprisingly sounds really good for such small speakers.Warranty:1 year limited warranty (on the box) - for details you have to register your product at impeccausa, there was no warranty info in the manual.

I like these mitts.  I love the cheerful design of bright red apples against a dark blue background and the fact that the mitts are sold in pairs instead of the usual single one.  The mitts are made of 100% cotton; the color of the material lining the inside of the mitts is silver.  I have small hands, so these mitts feel roomy to me but sometimes, the large size makes picking up small hot items with them a little awkward. However, they are at least 2 inches longer than my old mitt.  They cover most of my forearms but don’t reach to my elbows.  Still, the extra length means more protection for my arms in case I accidentally bump into any hot surface while reaching into the oven.  Always exercise care when handling hot cookware. These mitts are thick, but they are not as heat resistant as mitts made with fancier materials like silicone.  For basic, standard quilted cotton mitts, The Kitchen Style oven mitts are nice to have around in the kitchen.

The book description of "A Cup of Water Under My Bed" caught my attention because of two reasons.  First, I thought that the author was too young to be writing a memoir.  For me, memoirs are autobiographies written by people over 70 years old.  The second reason I picked this book was its promise to be an insightful read on what it feels to grow up Latino in America.I won't grudge author Daisy Hernández for writing a memoir before she is 70 because after reading her book, I thought she had gone through life experiences worth telling no matter what age she is.  "A Cup of Water Under My Bed" is divided into three sections that cover Ms. Hernández's childhood, teen and college years and her employment with The New York Times as an intern and reporter. However, the book can be divided by themes too: language and religion, love and sexuality, money and class. Ms. Hernández's recollections do not follow a strict chronological order, but this should not be a concern to readers because the "jumping around" in time actually makes this memoir more poignant.The book doesn't disappoint in its insights, found through the author's thoughtfully described vignettes of family life in a house worth to be condemned, the memories of Ms. Hernández's mother, her tias (aunts) outspokenness, and her father's drunken outbursts.  If language is identity, then I can easily empathize with the author's feelings of displacement. By accepting English, she also internalized American values, but at the price of her own estrangement not only from the language of her parents, Spanish, but also, from their religion, values, cultural traditions, and beliefs. However, in spite of the cultural schism she experienced, her respect for--and sometimes awe at--the women in her family, her mother and her aunts, remained always strong."A Cup of Water Under My Bed" is Ms. Hernández's courageous confession about the multiple struggles she encountered in her quest for identity and belonging. This memoir is recommended to anybody who wants to understand what growing up in two worlds means.

I don't like listening to music really loud, but I was not happy with the sound quality of my laptop speakers.  Since I didn't want to deal with more wires, I decided to give Cyber Acoustics PS-2350 Wireless Mono Speaker a try.  The speaker is about 5 " long.  You can stand it on one end and its footprint would be less than 3" in diameter.  At the bottom, there is a plug that can be folded out and connected into a wall socket for charging the speaker. The other way to charge it is by using the provided USB cable. The speaker comes with instruction sheets in English, Spanish and French.Before pairing the speaker, it is recommended to charge it fully so I plugged it into a wall outlet, thinking it would take a couple of hours.  To my surprise, about 20 minutes later, the speaker's LED red light went off, indicating that it was ready for use.  When following the instructions for turning on the speaker and the Bluetooth pairing function, make sure you press and hold the button until you hear a melody.  I let go of the power button before the melody played and so I was not able to pair it on my first try.  The second time around, my laptop was able to find the speaker easily and they paired without a problem.  If you don't want to use the Bluetooth function or your device doesn't have one, but it comes with an AUX jack, you can then use the 3.5mm AUX cable (also included) to connect the speaker.For me, the Bluetooth connection worked well within 12 to 14 feet away from my laptop.  At 15 feet, the sound started to break down, so it is best to keep the speaker as close as you can to the source device.  The sound is surprisingly good for such a small speaker and it can fill a room, but it won't make the windows rattle. You can control the volume by pressing on the "-" and "+" buttons on the side of the speaker.I'm very happy with the Cyber Acoustics PS-2350 Speaker.  It is easy to pair (by the way, it pairs with only one device at a time).  It doesn't have to sit on my desk all the time. I can move it anywhere in the room as long as it's within 14 feet from my laptop.  It sounds good, and it can be plugged directly to a wall outlet for charging (no more cables, yes!).

I found "Rings" by Rachel Church at my local B&N store and I had to have it.  This is a handsome, small book featuring rings from the jewelry collection of the Victoria & Albert Museum.  "Rings" offers a look at the evolution of ring styles and designs from 1200 to the present.  I felt in love with this book because of the old rings.  The contemporary ones were too artsy for me, but it was interesting to see how artists and designers can push the limits with innovative and unexpected ring creations.The sections on rings from the Middle Ages to the 1940s, each gorgeously illustrated with color photographs, were like candy to my eyes.  Among the types of rings pictured in the book are diamond rings, gem-set rings, mourning rings, commemorative ones, posy rings, memento mori rings, and signet rings.  Accompanying the beautiful photographs is a wealth of information on how rings were designed, created, worn, and their significance both as sentimental and practical objects throughout history.  I was particularly moved by the inscriptions etched on some of the rings. They were reminders of love, loss, mortality, or of hope, like the one made for a 17th century child that said, "This spark will grow." In addition to the rings, there are portrait paintings showing how rings were worn at a particular period of time.Rachel Church's "Rings" definitely belongs on the shelves of those who are interested in jewelry history and/or in collecting vintage jewelry.  This is a book I'll return to over and over again.

Rating: 3.5 starsIn 1528, an expedition of about 600 men, headed by Panfilo de Narvaez, landed on what is now known as Tampa Bay in Florida.  Their goal was to claim the land for the Spanish crown and to find gold, lots of gold.  This ill-fated expedition is the subject of Laila Lalami's historical novel, "The Moor's Account."Ms. Lalami's story is told from the perspective of Estebanico, a Moor and slave to Andres Dorantes de Carranza.  Estebanico, along with his master, his master's friend, Alonso del Castillo Maldonado, and the treasurer of the expedition, Alvar Nuñez Cabeza de Vaca were the only survivors of the Narvaez expedition.  In the novel, Estebanico sets up to write his account of the events in order to set the record straight since, in his opinion, the official account of Nuñez Cabeza de Vaca left out important details about the loss of the expedition, of their encounter and treatment of the Indians, and of their own adventures and misfortunes during the eight years they wandered through unfamiliar lands until they finally reached an Spanish outpost in Mexico.I have heard of Cabeza de Vaca, but his chronicle, the stories of the Narvaez expedition and of Estebanico were unknown to me until I read this book.  The survival story that Ms. Lalami presents through the eyes of the Moor is astounding. However, if I was not much surprised at the cruelties the conquistadores committed--and Estebanico witnessed--it was because I've read enough about them in the past.  But the "Moor's Account" is not only the story of a tragic expedition, but also about Estebanico himself.  He is a man who struggles with his fate as a slave, and yet, he still keeps, in a way, his faith in God and men.  And the book, of course, entertains the possibility that his final fate was not the one attributed by history at all.I found "The Moor's Account" interesting and even educational but, unfortunately, it did not captivate me.  Perhaps, if Estebanico's revelations were about the conquistadores' injustices, cruelties, greediness, selfishness, and inability to overlook class differences, then, as I said before, they were not news to me. However, the book is a well told story (though I don't understand why the author omitted enclosing dialogues within quotation marks), and it shows that the author has researched it well too since though she claims that the situations are fictional, they seem to fit closely with the historical events. Those who love historical fiction and this particular period in history will, no doubt, enjoy this book.

Once in a while, I have knee pain or tendonitis, and was recommended to use a knee strap, so I decided to give the Ace Knee Strap a try. I usually hate knee sleeves and braces. Sometimes, they feel too tight and wearing them in hot weather, well, it makes you hot.  On the other hand, the Ace Knee Strap, which is 1 ¾" wide, is adjustable, and I could tighten the strap to a level where I never felt like it could cut my blood circulation, and yet it would not slide out of place either.  Also, the inside of the strap is lined with a soft material so it doesn't chafe or irritate the skin.  However, if you wear it under clothing and you have sensitive skin, it may feel a bit itchy.  Pressure over the patellar tendon is applied through a small, firm gel pad attached to the inside of the strap and controlled by rotating a dial.  This strap is definitely far more comfortable than a sleeve.  And it seems to alleviate some of the pain.

There's no doubt that reviews have become an influential and empowering tool for customers.  Business owners--big and small-cannot afford to ignore them.  Reviews may have a direct impact on their reputation, services and sales.  Today, it is not surprising that anybody with a business will seek them and fear them at the same time.Authors Gradiva Couzin and Jennifer Grappone have written "Five Stars" to help businesses harness the power of online reviews to their benefit.  Their book will help readers understand the importance of reviews as marketing tools and as sort of informal performance evaluations that will point them to areas where their businesses can make improvements. "Five Stars" also reveals the motivation behind those who tend to write and leave a review, and how potential customers and buyers are influenced by those reviews. The authors also have tips on how to get more reviews, on how to show them off, monitor them, and on how to deal with the negative ones.As a reviewer, I felt that Ms. Couzin and Ms. Grappone were accurate on what motivates people to review and on today's concerns over fake and unethical reviews.  If I were a business owner, I would certainly keep their book handy on my reference shelf.  If you have a brick-and-mortar business, this book will be especially helpful as it devotes a lot of attention on review venues such as Google+Local, Yelp, Angie's List, and TripAdvisor.  For online stores, there are suggestions on how to use ResellerRatings and Bazaarvoice.  And whether you're an online merchant or one with a physical presence, this book will introduce you to SEO (search engine optimization) to improve your business website's visibility to search engines.  "Five Stars" is a valuable guide that will help anybody navigate, understand, deal with, and use online reviews to grow their businesses and customer base.

When I first took the keyboard out of its box, I thought I had made a mistake because it didn't look like my Samsung tab 2 7.0 was going to fit in between the corner holders.  It was a good thing that I went to Belkin's website because I was able to find three pieces of information there that did not appear on the keyboard's box nor were included in the instructions card that came with it.The first piece of information was that the corner holders are attached to elastics that can be pulled out and stretched to the correct size of your tablet. The second one was that the keyboard needs about 2.5 hours to fully charge the first time you use it.  And the third one was the step-by-step instructions on how to pair the devices (this was my first time using Bluetooth).  I certainly would have appreciated it if all that information had come with the keyboard, but I guess it is common practice now to not include a manual or detailed instructions, and to expect the buyer to look for the necessary information on the Internet.  Once all the guessing was out and my tablet was paired, I'm happy to report that the keyboard works very well.  The keys are soft and responsive, and I like the fact that there are special keys to control functions such as volume, cut, paste and play/pause.  The arrow keys move the cursor around so that you don't have to use the touchscreen to select an app. The case is soft to the touch. When it is used as a stand, it is able to support the weight of my tablet with no problems.  The "on" switch, however, may be a little hard to reach if you have big hands.  I have small fingers, but I still have to use my fingernail to push the switch.Belkin's portable Bluetooth wireless keyboard is a nice device to have if you use your tablet to write a lot.  It has certainly made my typing long e-mails easier and more enjoyable.Note: the devices listed on the box as compatible with this keyboard are: Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 7", Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 8", Samsung Galaxy Note 8.0, Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7", Google Nexus 7" and Kindle Fire HD 7"

If you're a student of the English language or a writer, you should consider adding Orin Hargraves's "It's Been Said Before" to your reference shelf.  Hargraves makes it clear that his book is not a dictionary of clichés nor is it a comprehensive list of all clichés in the English language. But what his book does is to help you become more aware of the use and misuse of these common expressions.Mr. Hargraves organizes his selection of clichés according to how they are used in a sentence. The first four chapters are devoted to clichés that function as nouns, adjectives, adverbs, or predicates. In the last three chapters, clichés are divided into whether they introduce or follow a clause (framing devices), are used as modifiers, or appear in tandem.  He also rates each cliché on a scale of 1 to 5.  1 and 2 being a warning to the user to think whether the expression really says what he/she means. At the other extreme of the scale, clichés that rate 4 or 5 are considered ineffective and annoying by the author.As a writer, "It's Been Said Before" has helped me be more thoughtful about my writing.  Now I actually pause to ponder whether a phrase I've heard of or read in the newspapers and blogs is as effective as I think it is.  Many times, I tend to use them because they seem colorful and current.  "It's Been Said Before" may not be exciting reading, but if you're a writer, this book will help you become a more conscientious one.

Reading "The Book of Unknown Americans" left me with a lingering feeling of sadness because the stories in Cristina Henriquez's novel are not the success immigrant stories we all would like to hear about or would wish every one who comes to America could achieve.  And yet, the book is a testimony to every man and woman who has left their home country in pursuit of a better life.The main story in "The Book of Unknown Americans" is about two families, whose fates will be bound together by their teenaged children's Romeo-and-Juliet-like romance.  Mayor Toro has fallen head over heels in love with Maribel Rivera since the day he spotted her, shopping with her mother, at the Dollar Tree store.  The Riveras have recently moved into the same apartment building where the Toros live.  And it doesn't matter that the Riveras are from Mexico while the Toros hail from Panama, or that the other tenants are from Puerto Rico, Venezuela, Guatemala or Paraguay because what brings them together is their language, their dreams and their struggles to make it in America.As the Toros and the Riveras' story unfold, their neighbors, whom they occasionally meet on the street or in the hallway, are not just names for Ms. Henriquez.  They represent the "invisible" or the "unknown" Americans, the ones who have "disappeared" behind the American label of Latino. But Ms. Henriquez has structured the novel in such a way that every tenant in the apartment building has a chance to introduce himself or herself to the readers and tell their individual stories.  Some are illegal immigrants, others have already achieved U.S. citizenship. Some are earning their living by cleaning toilets while others are professionals.  Unfortunately, all are judged by their looks and subjected to discrimination.Though "The Book of Unknown Americans" focuses on the Latino everyman, it could speak for the immigrant experience in general too.  Many of those who have moved to the United States experience the ambivalence of missing the old country, whether it is Mexico or Vietnam, and the urge to fit in their new home.  They all must face ethnic stereotypes and deal with the limitations of their own cultures.  Ms. Henriquez's novel may end up on a tragic note but hopefully, readers will become more aware of the sacrifices made by those who leave their countries, families and pasts behind for the opportunity for a new start in America.

I found the Hogwarts Castle Snow Globe while I was shopping at B&N and I had to have it.  It is not really a "globe" because it is not spherical but it still looks great.  It is made of plastic not glass.  The snow globe is about 3" tall.  Inside is the picture of Daniel Radcliffe as Harry Potter, flying on his broom with Hogwarts Castle in the background. There is definitely a front and a back to this snow globe because only one side of the cutout figures is printed. What I like is that there is a lot of snow inside. A lot! So much that when you shake the snow globe, it looks like Harry Potter is flying through a blizzard. The little book has 8 stickers and all of them feature a view of the castle.  This is quite an affordable collectible that any HP fan will be happy to own.

I rarely read biographies but I became interested in Paul Rosolie's "Mother of God" (Madre de Dios) because I just had happened to finish reading about a journey made by two Englishmen in 1834. They ventured into the Amazon forest to test the possibility of reaching the Atlantic Ocean by navigating the Pachitea, Ucayali and Amazon Rivers ("Narrative of a Journey from Lima to Para, Across the Andes and Down the Amazon" by William Smyth and Frederick Lowe).  It is fortunate for us that what they encountered in the jungle and its rivers almost 180 years ago can still be seen today thanks to the interest, care, and concern of people like Paul Rosolie."Mother of God" is an account of Mr. Rosolie's experiences in navigating the Madre de Dios River as he searched for the Western Gate or the Garden of Eden of the Amazon jungle, a pristine area, untouched by men and modern civilization. He was only 21 years old when he undertook the trip and what an adventure it turned out to be!  But the book is not only about his amazing solo expedition but also about how he came to love and respect the Amazon jungle and all its inhabitants, human and otherwise, through his job at the Las Piedras Station.  But amid his vivid descriptions of wrestling down black caimans and of riding giant anacondas, there are chilling stories about the horrific effects that poaching, oil extraction, and human greediness and thoughtlessness have had on the delicate Amazonian ecosystem.  Because of the ongoing deforestation, he also emphasizes the importance of establishing national parks and of encouraging Eco-tourism in order to ensure the preservation and survival of the Amazon jungle.I'm glad that Mr. Rosolie decided to narrate this book not as a scholar but as a first-person account of an adventure. He brings to the readers both the breathtaking beauty and the rawness and violence of the Amazon forest and rivers.  You may be able to feel the adrenaline rush of his encounters with anacondas and jaguars or experience his surprise at the blue glow of the morpho butterfly wings.  But what remained in my mind when I finished the book was the thought of how fortunate the author had been that his thirst for adventure became united with a love for Nature in general and for the Amazon in particular in his teen years. At that age, his thrill-seeking needs could have turned him on to a very different path. Luckily for the forest and for us, he found the path that led to a cause and to a place of infinite wonder.

This freshwater cultured pearl pendant turned out to be larger than I expected.  It measures about 1 3/4" long from the sterling silver bead bale to the bottom pearl. The three baroque pearls are tightly threaded together with a wire and little silver beads are used as spacers in between the pearls.  The pendant is very stiff.  The 18-inch sterling silver chain is shiny but dainty. I think a thicker chain would have matched the pendant better. The pearls are very smooth but they look more like "pearl beads" than real pearls.  However, the necklace may appeal to those who like pearls and a look of classic elegance.  It is just that to me, the pearls appear to be a bit too costume-ish for a necklace advertised as fine jewelry because of the dye applied to them.Note: this necklace is made in China

When I first saw the Belkin Smooth Tri- Fold Cover, I thought it was quite a handsome notebook style cover.  It keeps all the control buttons accessible and there is a hole in the back for the camera.  The elastic strap keeps the cover closed safely.  The leather-like material feels smooth on the outside and soft on the inside.  The stitching is nice and even.  I like the tone of purple used for the cover. Not too light and not too dark.  The front flap can be folded into a stand to hold the tablet upright (in landscape position only) for hands-free viewing and reading.  I cannot tell how well it would protect your device in the event you happen to drop it, but this Belkin cover is a very classy, good-looking one to carry your tab around.

When I finished reading "The Crane Wife" I felt an urge to explain it to myself, which was kind of funny being that in the book, the mysterious Kumiko tells George that "a story is not an explanation" but a "net through which the truth flows." It is a net that "catches some of the truth, but not all, never all." I agreed with the latter but I gave myself permission to disagree with Kumiko about stories not being an explanation because if they bring to light a truth, however small it is, and we have an a-ha moment because of it, then hasn't something been explain to us through the story?  This is an instance, and if you allow it, an invitation to go beyond the surface and dig into Patrick Ness's new book for the deeper levels.On the surface, it is the story of George Duncan, Mr. Ordinary Nice Guy, divorced, father of a grown-up daughter, Amanda, who's also divorced herself.  One very cold night, George finds a beautiful but wounded white crane in his back garden. Putting aside his doubts as to whether he is dreaming or not, he frees the crane from the arrow that has pierced its wing.  The crane flies away. The next morning, a woman dressed all in white and wearing a little red hat walks into George's print shop and changes his and his daughter's life forever.  It is not hard to guess who this woman really is and if you love folktales as I do, it is easy to see how the plot follows the lines of those old tales where a deity in disguise stays on Earth to live with a mere mortal as long as a certain condition is met.  On a deeper level, for me, the "fun" of this book is in the uncovering of metaphors, themes and messages in the story Kumiko tells George, in the art they create together, and in their love relationship.  Yin and yang, Buddhism, Kwan Yin, as well as sacrifice, jealousy, creation, selflessness, and misericordia were a few of the words that came to my mind as I read this novel.For the first three quarters of the story, some readers may wonder where the book is going, especially in those parts where attention is shifted to Amanda's troubles, but the way Kumiko solves her dilemma makes up for the effort of staying with the book till the end.  "The Crane Wife" was inspired by a Japanese tale and it is in itself a tribute to folktales, those timeless stories that weave the fantastic with the human condition and to us, mere mortals who out of our imagination and dreams fashion them in the hopes to catch, as Kumiko says, some of the truth of who we are.

I ordered OXO Good Grips Three-Ring Trivet Set because when it's time to put these three rings away, they only occupy the space of one.  They snap together easily and as one, they make a solid trivet that won't come apart unless you unsnap them first.  The rings measure 7 1/2" in diameter; 6 1/4" in diameter and 5" in diameter. The tops of the rings are covered with silicone, which feels like smooth soft rubber and the underside is made of hard plastic with silicone "feet" that won't scratch your table or counter tops. One of the things I like a lot about this set is that as individual rings, they can be placed so that you can cool large cookie sheets and roasting pans on them. No more having to look for trivets that matches in height.  The surface of the rings do get warm after placing hot stuff on them so let them cool before handling them (though I have never experienced them to get hot enough to burn my fingers). These rings fulfill their purpose very well; they are cheerful-looking and great to have if you do not have much space for storage.

Reading "The Good Luck of Right Now" is like reading a fairy tale. You know there's a happy ending waiting for you and the characters at the end of the book, but this is a modern fairy tale where actor Richard Gere is Bartholomew Neil's fairy godmother, I mean, fairy godfather who appears to him whispering advice and encouragement.  Bartholomew is 39 years old and has lived all his life with his mother. When she passes away, he's left with the challenge of building a normal life. He has never lived independently nor has he been in a relationship with a woman.  But he's not without friends.  He has Wendy, his grief counselor, Father McNamee, his pastor; Max who spits the "F" word in every other word, the Girlibrarian, Bartholomew's crush, and of course, Richard Gere, to whom Bartholomew writes long letters. In them, he confides his thoughts, secrets, experiences, fears, dreams and hopes to the actor.To the world, Bartholomew may be "weird" and perhaps mentally challenged, but he's a kind soul with a keen perception of the human condition and a believer in his mother's philosophy, the Good Luck of Right Now. The philosophy is simple: When something bad happens to you, something good is happening to someone else. The nice thing is that Mr. Quick interplays it with Father McNamee's belief that nothing is a coincidence, that everything is God's plan.  And as the plot unfolds, I couldn't help but wonder if the message might be that both beliefs are more alike than what we think.  But readers should not worry. This novel is not a heavy-duty philosophy lecture. It is about compassion, about realizing that even people who are "damaged goods" have a wisdom to share and that sometimes you have to pretend in order to get over the bad times or as the saying goes, to fake it until you make it.  Mr. Quick has added plenty humor (my favorite moment is when Bartholomew and foul-mouthed Max have their first group therapy together) to this tale to make it both thought provoking and funny.  By the time I finished this novel and for one second, I saw Richard Gere, smiling and giving me the thumbs up for having picked this book.

It's been awhile since a yoga workout has left me sore.  When my tighs, calves and butt started to "complain" just after I finished the first workout of Ashley Turner's Yoga for Strength and Flexibility, I felt that this was one that has really worked my muscles.Yoga for Strength targets the core muscles, upper body and will challenge your balance. This workout lasts about 33 minutes and just right about from the start you will find yourself moving through plank pose, side plank with one arm up, push-ups and about three variations of abdominal curls. All of that is included in the first 11 minutes of the workout. Next come the standing exercises with crescent pose variations that transition into warrior 3 pose and move to standing split pose. From there, you will do traditional chair pose and a variation that requires you to do it on the balls of your feet.  The final group of exercises involve warrior 2, extended warrior pose, bow, boat and wheel poses.The goal of Yoga for Flexibility is to stretch the shoulders, hips, hamstrings and back.  This 32-minute practice starts with head rolls, then to doing backstrokes and butterfly strokes with the arms, moving to a gentle standing back bend and then to squats.  Half sun salutations bring you to all fours where you do the thread the needle pose, cow pose and hip circles. From there, Ashley leads you through side and forward triangle poses, seated spinal twists with one leg extended and the other one bent, and horizontal splits where you bend forward with your legs as far apart as you can.The bonus feature is a 7-minute guided meditation, which you do in cross-legged position.  In this meditation, Ashley encourages you to focus on the breath and be witness to your thoughts. Her pleasant voice is very calming on all the practices in this DVD.  Ashley's cuing is also great and as she demonstrates the poses, she explains what muscles are working and where you should be feeling it as well as reminding you about breathing, practicing affirmations, and setting intentions.Thorough the workout, especially during the first practice, the instructor suggests alternatives for those who are less flexible or are not strong enough to do the more challenging poses. For example, she recommends staying in bridge pose instead of doing the full wheel pose. The Strength practice is doable but I feel it is geared toward "experienced" beginners to intermediate level.  It is assumed that you already know what cobra or downward-facing dog is.  There were no new poses for me, but it is how Ashley combined them that made this particular practice intense for me.  I like this DVD a lot and I'm very happy that it's now part of my yoga collection.

I got the Harbinger Balance Trainer to strengthen my core muscles.  This soft plastic disc of about 13" in diameter and 2" high is ready for use right out of the box.  It is semi-inflated in order to provide a wobbly surface for you to work out. The first time I got on it, it felt like stepping on a couple of very, very fluffy cushions and that's why I like to refer to it as a my "exercise cushion."  If you have a pump, you can inflate it a bit more but the firmer the trainer disc is, the less challenge it will provide and you won't have to work as hard to keep your balance while sitting or standing on it.The exercises recommended by Harbinger in its online guide include squats, push ups, side and reverse lunges, walking, planks and core stabilizing progression.  This last one reminds me of boat pose, which is what I like to do on the trainer.  Some exercises require two trainers.  Harbinger warns against doing jumping or bouncing exercises with the disc.  Since the trainer provides an uneven and ever shifting surface, I would say to go carefully if you have weak joints or joint issues, especially when doing standing exercises.  After trying to do the walking, I felt it in my knees and ankles.  But using this trainer has certainly forced me to use my core muscles and my balance and posture are benefiting from that.  I don't even have to do an exercise move on it. Just sitting on it is a challenge and kind of fun.

I was surprised by this movie that though it lacks sweeping views and pyrotechnics (I mean, battle scenes), it makes up by its touching feeling of intimacy. It is 1856 and in the forgotten town of Paita, an old, disabled woman earning her living by selling tobacco and sweets hardly wants to remember her former glory days, thirty years ago when her name, Manuela Saenz was called on either in disdain or in admiration.  However, prompted by a curious young Herman Melville and feeling that death is near since unfortunately, Melville's whaler ship has brought the plague to Paita, Manuela recalls her relationship with the Liberator, Simon Bolivar.The movie moves back and forth between the elder Manuela whose scenes are filmed in sepia tones and the younger Manuela, which are in color.  Viewers are witnesses to her first encounter with Bolivar, the tension that her infidelity and defiance provoked in her English husband, to her many separations from and reunions with Bolivar as he fought for the independence of South America, and to her courage on the infamous night of the murder attempt against the general.  But it is the elder Manuela, reading out Bolivar's old letters at times or dishing out her poignant comments at others, the one who brings all these flashbacks together and gives them meaning while at the same time, revealing that under her toughness and disappointment, her love for him still burns strong.Beatriz Valdez makes for a very convincing Manuela, both young and old.  Mariano Alvarez plays Bolivar well, especially during the scene when he's alone under the bridge.  I couldn't help but feel the sorrow that must have started to creep in Bolivar's heart as the reality of the murder attempt hit him and his dream of a united Gran Colombia started to fall apart. The few things I don't like about this DVD are that the English subtitles cannot be suppressed. They also don't make justice to the lyrical voice of Manuela and whoever decided to cut the elder Manuela scenes out of the Scene Selection deserves to be booed.  The R-rating is for some brief nudity; otherwise, this movie would be PG-13 appropriate.  This "little" movie is a commendable effort toward redeeming Manuela Saenz. Those who have never heard her name will discover this important historical figure, but I think viewers who are already familiar with Latin America history and Bolivar will be the ones to appreciate this movie better.

It is rarely that I can play in my head the right song for the book I'm reading. Yet, with Andrew Sean Greer's "The Impossible Lives of Greta Wells," it came easily: Barbara Streisand's voice reverberated in my mind, singing the line "If we had the chance to do it all again, could we? Would we?"It is 1985 and Greta Wells is grieving the loss of her twin brother Felix to AIDS and the loss of her long-time boyfriend, Nathan to another woman. Alone and heartbroken, she longs to "live in any time but this one."  When pills do not lift up her depression, her doctor treats her to 25 sessions of electroconvulsive therapy. After each session, Greta wakes up to find that she has traded places with one of her other selves, one living in 1918 and another, in 1941.  Living in those years gives Greta the chance to experience not only different versions of herself (wife, mother, secret lover) but also of the people she loved the most in 1985: Felix and Nathan. In the past, she's married to Nathan; and best of all Felix is alive again.  Here is her chance to "do it all again" but with one difference: this is her opportunity to prevent mistakes and regrets, in other words, to  "perfect their lives."As I read Mr. Greer's novel, I decided not to be too concerned with the logic of how Greta was able to find herself in her other selves' bodies.  With that out of the way, I found Greta's challenge to face the social and cultural constraints of the times she found herself living in very interesting.  At times she irritated me, especially when with all her 1980s forward thinking and apparently insensitive to the social shunning his brother would suffer in 1918, she kept pushing him to acknowledge his sexuality.  I have to confess that I said "Duh" when it finally dawned on her that "the time we live in affects the person we are."  On the other hand, I also enjoyed slowing down and taking a moment to take in and ponder some of Greta's insights and questions she poses to herself and the readers."The Impossible Lives of Greta Wells" is a bittersweet story and a fascinating time traveling yarn with a twist. The novel is also a meditation on life, love, death, grief, relationships, marriage, authenticity to the self, and choices. For all of Greta's good intentions for a "world in which nothing slips through her fingers," whether in the past or the present, she and all the other characters must face the consequences of their choices.  There is no such a thing as a perfect world except as Greta finds out, for the one that needs you.

As someone who grew up with the "sanitized" and bland school textbook version of the wars of independence in South America, I can say that reading the first volume of Lord Cochrane's "Narrative of Services in the Liberation of Chili, Peru and Brazil" was quite an eye opener.Published in 1858, the first volume of Lord Cochrane's "Narrative of Services" is centered on his service to the Chilean government and his involvement as Vice Admiral of the Chilean Navy in the liberation of Peru.  Lord Cochrane wrote his book to clear his name from misunderstandings, malicious rumors and accusations; to set the record straight for his actions during his years in Chile and Peru, and to address the outstanding monetary debt the governments of those two countries owed to him.Anybody interested in South American history will enjoy Lord Cochrane's  first-person account as witness and participant in the war of independence (even though he reminds readers that he's owed money for his services over and over again).  Through Lord Cochrane's detailed accounts of his exploits, I was able to glimpse the soul of a pirate--and I said it as a good thing--because he was a man who was quick to jump at any opportunity to capture an enemy ship, with or without the approval of his superiors.  But what I found most interesting about "Narrative of Services" was his feud with General Jose de San Martin.  Back when I was a school student, our textbooks painted General San Martin not only as a war hero, but also as a man of impeccable character. Lord Cochrane's portrayal of San Martin's behavior, actions (and inaction) in Peru punched some holes in my schoolgirl remembrance of San Martin's reputation. And yet, Lord Cochrane's descriptions of San Martin's failures have added a touch of human dimension to his image as a hero.Readers might feel that the "Narrative of Services" was an excuse for Lord Cochrane to toot his own horn, but they must forgive him because without memoirs like his, precious details of such an important time in the history of South America would have been lost to us and to future generations.Note: Lord Cochrane's spelling of Chile as "Chili" is neither a mistake nor a mark of disrespect.  He's using the old spelling of the country's name and one that was in use at that time.

I've never worn a toe ring before so I was very excited to give this ring a try.  The ring is beautiful in its simplicity. The clear CZ heart is about 4/16" at its widest and it is in a open-back bezel setting.  The sterling silver skinny band is shiny and smooth. The ring fits well on my middle toe. I didn't have to stretch the band open nor did I have to resort to the glass cleaner trick to slip the ring over the toe pad.  Although I was aware of it for the first two or three days I wore it, the ring never felt uncomfortable.  What I like the most about it is how nicely the little CZ heart catches and reflects light.  I thought the ring on my toe looked great, but I've decided to wear it closer to eye level because this ring on my pinkie finger just looks gorgeous.

This is a fun app once I learned how to use it.  I needed a note app to jot down quick lists and random thoughts with my fingers. Handrite Lite fits the bill.  The first time I tried it, I had chicken scratches on the screen. It didn't work well with a stylus either so I went back to using my finger.  This time, it seemed to have "learned" or adapted to my finger pressure and though my finger writing was neither even nor perfect, it was readable. The more I use it, the better I get at it though.  It took me bit of a while to find my way around and figure out how to use the different toolbars. There are a couple of buttons I'm not sure what they are for yet. This is where I would have liked to see a help or tutorial section come with the app.  I would like to be able to look for what I need instead of waiting for the right tip to show up when I open a new note.  I'm sure there are features yet to be discovered (by me) but so far, this app has been great for my intended purposes. That it saves my notes in the SD card is definitely a plus.

"Get It Together: Organize Your Records So Your Family Won't Have To" is specifically targeted to seniors, caretakers, and people facing deployment or serious illness, to help them organize their records so that important information and documents are available to their families should they pass away or become incapacitated.  However, I think this book would be useful for anybody who wants to keep his/her papers together.The necessity of having all vital documents (or at least copies of them) in one place and readily accessible became very evident to me after a tsunami threat that forced us to evacuate to higher ground in the middle of the night.  Only after we returned home did I realize that I had run out of the house not only without important documents such as passports but also without even the contact information for our insurance company.  Setting up the planner suggested by "Get It Together" before a disaster strikes can help readers in cases of emergencies too because when you're trying to outrun a tsunami or a hurricane, it is not the time to try to remember where you stashed away your insurance policy."Get It Together" is divided in two parts.  The first part is comprised of 28 chapters or topics. The second part provides the blank forms to the 28 topics.  The book assists readers in identifying and arranging personal documents (such as birth and marriage certificates) and then documents related to their children and other dependents and even their pets. Documents regarding to employment, business interests, memberships, bank and brokerage accounts, retirement and pension plans, social security, insurance, credit cards and debts, taxes, real estate, and vehicles also have a place in the planner.  Estate planning documents that should be included are health care directives, wills and trusts.  End-of-life documents are filed in the planner under these categories:  Durable Power of Attorneys for Finances, Secured Places and Passwords, Organ and Body Donation, Burial or Cremation, Funeral and Memorial Services, Obituary, and Letter to Loved Ones. Each chapter gives a brief overview and/or basic information on the topic. The book also makes suggestions from how to choose a health care agent to how to write your epitaph.  It also includes additional resources such as websites and books.  These additional resources are not necessarily related to Nolo.I found "Get It Together" to be a very comprehensive organizer and helpful as it keeps me focus since it takes the guessing out of what documents and/or information should or should not be included in the planner.  Instructions to fill out the forms are provided under the respective chapters.  Readers can use the forms that come with the book or download them from Nolo's website.  Forms are in Word and PDF formats and according to the website, are available to download until October 24, 2015.

Let me say it straightaway:  This novel turned out to be way different from what I expected from the book's blurbs and description.  Let me be frank: Halfway through the book I felt nauseated.  Neither reaction had to do with "The House of Impossible Loves" being a "bad" book.  Technically, the storytelling is great. The writing is full of imagery that appeals to the senses, especially smell and taste.  What I could not stomach was how much the plot reeked of death and bitterness.Amber-eyed Clara Laguna is the latest girl in the Laguna family who must bear the family curse.  Laguna women are destined to be abandoned by their lovers and give birth to illegitimate daughters who will suffer the same fate as their mothers.  Unlike her own mother, Clara does not simply resign herself to her accursed destiny when her lover disappears, instead she exacts a revenge that will consume her and her descendants: her daughter Manuela, her granddaughter Olvido and her great-granddaughter Margarita.The first half of "The House of Impossible Loves" revolves around the dark side of the mother-daughter relationship.  For the women, each daughter is a bitter living reminder of the curse. As mothers, each of the women is brokenhearted and betrayed and as daughters, each is neglected and abused.  And so, mothers and daughters turn against each other, usually with deadly results. The garden of their mansion, Scarlet Manor, is a testament to the blood in their hands.  The second half of the novel is the story of Santiago Laguna, Margarita's son and the hope-for male who gives this family (and the story) and much needed break from their rancor.Author Cristina Lopez Barrios fills the book with abundant magic realism but what with incest and cannibalism and with people being shot, pushed out of windows, and poisoned, magic realism ceases to be "magical" pretty soon.  Except for a few instances, there is no sense of wonder to this novel.  Instead, magic realism serves to "pretty up" the dark bent of the characters' minds and makes their crimes the more gruesome.There is a lot of sexual desire but little love in "The House of Impossible Loves." For me, Olvido is the character that comes closest to gaining an understanding of what Love is.  They blamed the curse for their fates, but in reality they all had a hand in making it a self-fulfilling prophecy. As Clara haunted her descendants, I could not help but wonder if there is no worse curse than remaining a prisoner of one's own narrow mind.

"Relatos Mágicos del Perú" es un pequeño libro de cuentos compilado por Javier Zapata Innocezi. Es un libro para quienes estén interesados en leer historias que ponen los pelos en punta.  El libro contiene más de 60 relatos que provienen de diferentes partes del Perú y éstos son en realidad testimonios de gente que han tenido encuentros con duendes, demonios, espíritus, fantasmas y con las inexplicables fuerzas de lo sobrenatural. Muy entretenido,  interesante y  las ilustraciones son geniales.

Like most readers who have picked up "On Heaven and Earth," I did it because I was curious about the man whom the world now knows as Pope Francis. He has impressed millions with his humbleness, his approachability and down-to-earth personality. Basically, when I started reading his book-- co-authored with his friend, Rabbi Abraham Skorka, I was looking for an answer to the question lurking in the back of my mind, "Is he the real thing?"In "On Heaven and Earth," the then Monsignor Bergoglio and Rabbi Skorka enter in a lively conversation about issues that concerned their respective religious beliefs. Theirs is a friendly exchange of opinions on subjects such as God, the devil, atheism, religious leadership, prayer, guilt, death, euthanasia, the elderly, religious vocation, women, abortion, divorce, marriage, science, education, politics, communism, globalization, poverty, the Holocaust, and, of course, the future of religion. Together they find common ground and complementary views in all those areas and both emphasize the importance of sincere, respectful dialogue as the tool and the medium by which to bring about change at the individual and global levels.It is very encouraging to see how these two religious leaders validate religion as a personal, intimate experience with God and frown upon too rigid institutional structures and on those who claim to be the "one and only" true religion. Yet, they also see the mission of their institutions as passing on values, fighting inequality, bringing social justice, taking part in and being part of the culture.As for Pope Francis being the real thing?  After reading this book, I can say I'm impressed.  He and Rabbi Skorka agree that the main attribute of a religious leader is humility. He believes in opening dialogue with other religions.  He understands that pomp and rituals are not what religion is all about.  He is of the opinion that you must never turn a blind eye when sexual abuse occurs.  As for the expectation that women will be ordained as priests one day, from what I read in this book, I don't think it is going to happen yet.  Though religions adapt to the times, he believes that there is a legacy or patrimony that it is not subject to negotiation.  Having said that, however, I also feel that he is not going to leave women behind either.Although there are a couple of chapters that are specific to Argentina and the military government, most of the book is a must read for Catholics, Jews and for anybody who is interested in deepening one's understanding of our relationship with God and the role that religion may play in our lives today.Note: this review is based on the Kindle Spanish edition of the book that I purchased for my own enjoyment.

When art history student Menina Ann Walker ends up stranded in a dilapidated convent overlooking a village in Andalucia, little does she know that destiny is leading her towards the answers to not only her own mysterious past, but also to the story of five girls who had walked through the halls of the same convent almost 500 years ago.In "The Sisterhood," author Helen Bryan deftly alternates Menina's modern-day adventures with the vicissitudes of a sixteenth-century order of nuns, who defy the conventions of their time to protect women and young girls from exploitation, social ostracism, and political and religious persecutions.
