Through the Order of Las Sors Santas de Jesus' account recorded in their Chronicle, readers are taken from the Old World to the recently conquered New World.Reading "The Sisterhood" was like embarking on a grand adventure through time and history.  Pretty soon, I found myself drawing genealogical trees in my notepad to keep the characters straight.  The brisk-paced narration and the story of the nuns and their protégées held my attention to the end. Although the author does not name actual geographical places, by the historical hints she uses, I could imagine that part of the story could have taken place in Peru.  And so a few details made me squirm a bit like the characters seeing Chinamen at their arrival to an unnamed port and city in South America in 1552.  Even though there is evidence of Chinese contact in pre-Columbian times, it was hard for me to imagine a crowd of Chinamen in the City of Kings, seventeen years after its foundation.  However, such small details should not prevent anybody from enjoying Ms. Bryan's novel.  Beyond the mystery and adventure, the book is also a statement about the injustices women have suffered in the past and, unfortunately, still suffer today.

Como algunos de los lectores de "Sobre el cielo y la tierra" empecé a leer el libro con la curiosidad de llegar a conocer mejor al hombre que hoy el mundo llama el Papa Francisco.  El ha impresionado a miles de personas con su humildad y afable personalidad.En "Sobre el cielo y la tierra," en aquel entonces Monseñor Bergoglio y el Rabino Abraham Skorka conversan sobre temas y aspectos que preocupan a ambas religiones.  El de ellos es una amigable charla acerca de Dios, del Diablo, del ateísmo, la oración, del liderazgo, de la muerte, los ancianos, la vocación religiosa, las mujeres, del matrimonio, del divorcio, la educacion, el aborto, la política, la ciencia, la pobreza, la globalisación, el Holocausto y por supuesto, del futuro de la religión.Ellos juntos encuentran opiniones en común y puntos de vista complementarios en todos estos temas y ambos enfatizan la importancia del diálogo sincero y respetuoso como un medio para iniciar el cambio a nivel individual y mundial.Es muy alentador ver como estos dos líderes dan validez a la religión como una experiencia íntima y personal con Dios y al mismo tiempo desaprueban la religión cuando sus estructuras son muy rígidas y también denuncian a los que afirman que sólo hay "una verdadera" religión.  Sin embargo, Monseñor Bergoglio y el Rabino Skorka también sostienen que la religión como una institución tiene la misión de pasar valores morales, de fomentar la justicia social y de ser parte de la cultura.Después de leer este libro debo confesar que mi respeto por el Papa Francisco aumentó.  Él y el Rabino Skorka estan de acuerdo que la más importante cualidad de un líder es la humildad.  Monseñor Bergoglio cree en diálogos inter-religiosos. Él comprende que la pompa y los rituales no son lo más crítico de una religión. Él opina que uno nunca debe hacer la vista gorda cuando hay abusos sexuales. Pero en cuanto a la expectativa de que algun día las mujeres van a ser ordenadas como sacerdotes, por lo que he leído en el libro, no creo que va a pasar.  Aunque las religiones se adaptan con los tiempos, Monseñor Bergoglio cree que cada religion posee una herencia que no se puede cambiar.  Aún así, yo siento que él va a dar un rol de importancia a las mujeres dentro de la Iglesia.El libro tiene unos cuantos capítulos que son específicos a Argentina y al gobierno militar.  Pero este libro merece ser leído por los católicos, judíos y cualquiera que este interesado en aprender más acerca de su relación con Dios y acerca de la importancia que tiene la religión hoy.

It works quite well, but it is definitely a bit see through.  In my studio its fine, but on location it is very hard to find a spot that doesn't let in some sort of light (window, overhead, etc...) on the back side.  So I bring my old white backdrop and I hang both of them together, and then it works great.

For many years, I did not want to make the investment in this eye lighter.  I used instead a piece of sheet metal on a posing table, and I'd just push it up to my client and joke about it being sheet metal but tell them it would give them a bright glamour look.  Sometimes I'd have an assistant hold the sheet metal underneath the client in a curve to try to replicate the eye lighter.  And it worked well enough.  For 4 years I resisted.And then Westcott started making them and the price came down!  And one December I was looking for a few more business expenses so I treated myself to this, and I have to say I love love love it!  It just wraps beautifully around the subject.  And the catchlights in the eye are so cool.  And it looks way more professional than my sheet metal.  It is pretty big though, and not that easy to assemble, so it does take up some room in the studio.  But it is worth it!!
My daughter was ecstatic over this.  It is like a giant mouse pad, she just keeps it on her desk and it makes her smile every time she sees it...

This eyeshadow works great.  I have oily eyelids (eww, I know, too much information) and regular eyeshadow does tend to slide down into my creases, but this stuff stays put.  The colors are well matched to each other too, and a set of 4 is very versatile in terms of the looks you can go with.  I just wish the one I was sent didn't have shimmer -- at my age (50ish) I do prefer a completely matte eyeshadow.  I'll have to check out the stores to see if I can find a pure matte.

I've used this several weeks now, twice a day.  I use it under my regular moisturizer.  It is light, absorbs easily, and you only need a few drops.  After almost 4 weeks my bottle is still 4/5ths full.  And it definitely has made my skin softer and smoother.  My skin certainly doesn't feel as tight.  I really like it.  But alas, it has not turned back the hands of time and removed fine lines.  I don't know if there is such a product, perhaps to work real miracles one has to go to a dermatologist for treatment -- many of my friends are getting some very expensive laser treatment that removes the outer layer of skin or something. I really liked the smell until I read the reviews here and realized yes, it does have a citronella related scent.  But it fades quickly and is lighter than citronella.

I got this for my 17 yo old son, who spends a lot of time in front of the computer gaming and is not a physically active kid.  I thought if I put it above his bathroom door, he could just do a few pull ups a couple times a day for a little bit of exercise.  Hah, he can barely do one!  But he likes it and it is a simple and fun thing for him to just try to pull himself up when he walks by the bathroom.  Hopefully over time he will build some upper body strength.  Hmmm.  Maybe I should move the treadmill to his room too.
Flashlight part fell off on the first or second day.  And the leash didn't always lock when you pressed the red button.  So we ended up buying another leash and use this one as our backup.

I thought this might be cheap, but it is a very nice usb flash drive, it has good heft and is large and works great, and is very pretty.The USB slides freely out of the lock though, I wish there was a way to push and lock the usb section inside the lock.  If you wear it as a necklace, then the usb key will be pulled into the lock but if you just leave it laying on your desk, the usb section might be exposed.
love these.  I get so bored with the manilla folders.  you have to purchase file labels though, or a white/silver pen to label the folders.  Affordable and functional.

I wanted to love it.  I really, really did.  It is so cool with those little feet that add extra stability.  But I purchased TWO of them (one to replace the first one after I returned it), and both of them stopped working -- meaning one of the sections stopped collapsing -- you'd twist the black thing and wouldn't be able to extend or collapse the leg.  I have another tripod (Manfrotto I think) with the same sort of twist/release and I've had that for 5 years and it has never given me a day of trouble.  So I think there is a flaw of some sort with this monopod.  Three times might be a charm, but I am already out $30 to UPS to package up the returns (yes return shipping is free, but the first time, I couldn't collapse it so it wouldn't fit into original box and I had to purchase a larger box to return it, and the second time, it worked for two weeks so I thought all was well and tossed the original shipping box and then when it stopped working, had to purchase another box to return it).They say three times is the charm, but frankly I don't want to risk it....

Really warms a space quickly and quietly.  I'd love it to have a timer so you could set it to turn off in 4 or 8 hours, that would really save on electricity because I do forget to turn this off when my son leaves for school.  But we have 3 different space heaters in our home, and this is our favorite.

I messed around with cyber syncs from Paul Buff for years -- they worked fine most of the time, say 80%.  Eventually I got tired of not being able to use the cyber syncs and having to shoot with my camera tethered to the strobes so I splurged for these, and I love them because I can COUNT on them to work every time.  Pocket Wizards are all part of creating a better client experience.

I used other feeding toys with softer rubber and my dog ripped those to shreds.  This one she rolls around to eat the food, and will dig and lick at it as she bats it around the kitchen.  I really like it because it extends meal-time, and my puppy needs lots of engaging toys (and walks) or she will tear up the house.  This fits the bill...

LOVE Leonie's creative and beautiful planning books that inspire you and coax you into dreaming big and planning how to fulfill those dreams.  I mean, how do you not love a book that calls to-do lists "A book of Magnificent Possibilities"?  I'm visual-- I love the water color splashes on the edges of the pages, the swirly scrolls, the lovely lettering and bright happy images -- it all motivates me.  I was also concerned the paper might be cheap and thin like a coloring book, and it is not -- it is perfectly acceptable paper.My one little beef is that the book is not spiral bound.  To really write on the book it needs to  lay flat, which it does NOT.  So I am going to break the binding and bind it myself (I have a spiral binder, but you can also go to Staples and have it done for $5).

I hemmed and hawed over the price of this bag (even 20% off on Ebay) but I am so glad I got it.  No buyer's remorse here, and I am known for my buyers remorse!!!I've owned a photography business for 3.5 years, and have gone through a LOT of camera bags.  Most of my working camera bags were too small, even though they look attractive, by the time I piled my second camera on top of the extra lenses the bags would look like a giant, overstuffed sac and I might as well be carrying an LLBean canvas bag or something.  I tried backpacks, but the access to my gear wasn't quick enough.  I tried a Jill-E rolling bag, but I couldn't always drag it (for example through a field of horse or geese droppings), and it was bigger and heavier than this bag.This bag is perfection!  Holds my stuff, protects and organizes it, and it's easy to carry (well, it can be heavy with a lot of stuff, so I wouldn't haul my gear through an airport with this, but for short walks between portrait locations it is great).  I can fit a ton of stuff in it (two flashes, two cameras with lenses, 2 extra lenses (four if I use the two buckle pockets on the front, but I try to limit myself to 3-4 lenses in total if I am on a senior portrait shoot) as well as my ipad, wallet, memory cards, photovision target, hoodman, and more.  The quality is excellent too, gear is protected by water proof canvas, it is well padded, and has double protection from the top -- the zipper and the flap.  The size -- it is just a little longer (maybe an inch) than my Kelly Moore bag, twice as wide, and a little taller, and has a boxy shape, maximizing the capacity of this bag to carry stuff without looking like you are hauling around a piece of carry-on luggage.Also, that flap over the top of the bag is really important when you are working from your bag!  I was at the beach once, and my client's foot ended up in my camera bag which was on my shoulder (no idea how that happened -- she was a lively tween dancing around) and the bag didn't have a flap and it cost me very close to the cost of this bag to repair the lenses (fortunately no sand got in my camera).Anyway, I don't actually know many people who own this bag -- probably because of the price tag!  But I think it is a really good investment.
I really like this coffee, but I am a dark roast kind of person.  It is strong and smells great, not bitter either.  It's a great way to start the day.

This is more of a dessert coffee than a wake-me-up and start-my-day coffee, as it is pretty mild in flavor, but it's a good blend of mild coffee and chocolate flavor.  Definitely use the middle or small cup setting, the large setting will dilute the flavor considerably.  This is pretty much an instant coffee too, there is nothing left in the K-cup after the coffee is made.

I use this under my Keurig in my "office" (living room where I meet clients) and I really like it because it is discrete and tidy, rather than sort of cluttery-looking like the carousels.  One is enough to store my favorites, but you could stack two or three if you are obsessed with Kcups...

I've had this bag for almost three years, so it has really stood the test of time.  It isn't leather, it is some sort of vinyl, and in the first month, I got rub marks in the vinyl around the top edges of the bag which was annoying, but they never got worse.Like most camera bags, you can move the two dividers around to change the size of the three pockets.  It has a zipper pocket in the back, two side slip in pouches, and two pockets with flaps in the front.  It holds a lot of stuff, especially if you overstuff it like I tend to do.My main beef with this bag is that it has three snaps to close it, rather than a zipper. I know this was a conscious design decision by Kelly Moore so a photographer could have ease of access, but I can never get the snaps to stay closed -- I guess I overstuff my bag -- and when walking about town I feel like a pick pocket would have easy access too!  Although, knock on wood, I've never been robbed.The other thing is if you want a camera bag to actually protect your gear rather than just cart it around, I highly highly recommend a camera bag with a flap.  The bag feels very open if you are, say, eating at a restaurant and don't want anyone to accidentally spill a soda in your bag.  Plus, I took this bag to the beach once, and one of my daughter's friends was playing around and ended up putting her sandy foot on top of my camera bag which was on my shoulder.  The sand got in my lenses and it cost over $300 to repair them.  I thought I was being careful by making sure it was not a windy day, not setting my bag down or on the sand, and yet, I somehow ended up with a tween foot in my camera bag.I am finally replacing my Kelly Moore bag with a Billingham camera bag, but it has a flap, it has a record of excellent quality, and it isn't that much more expensive than this camera bag, actually.

But it still tastes pretty good.  A light coffee with a raspberry overtone that I find still needs a little cream to drink.  I recommend NOT using the largest cup size on your Keurig, but rather the middle cup size for a better flavor.

~ This compilation provides an interesting survey of 8 great lady blues singers residing in Austin at the time of the initial release of the CD (1992). Collected from a variety of recording sessions for Antone’s Records label, some of these tracks have been previously released while some are not available elsewhere (see note below).~ The vocal and instrumental quality is of the highest caliber throughout, featuring the cream of the crop of Austin blues musicians. By offering 12 tracks from 9 artists, the producers have managed to give us a single CD that shows the breadth and depth of the lady blues vocalists in terms of style.~ Liner notes provide a single-page biography of each vocalist and the collective personnel playing on the various tracks is summarized. Sound quality varies slightly from track to track as expected for this type of compilation, but is good to excellent throughout.~ My only complaint is the brevity of the disc (48 minutes) which could have easily been extended to 70+ minutes. Of course, this shortcoming is out weighed by the fact that 5 of the 13 tracks are not available elsewhere.1. Something's Got a Hold on Me = Angela Strehli, Lou Ann Barton, Marcia Ball (Dreams Come True)2. Hurtback = Sarah Brown, Angela Strehli, Lou Ann Barton, Marcia Ball (#)3. Big Town Playboy = Angela Strehli (Soulful Shack)4. Neighbor, Neighbor = Angela Strehli (#)5. Down South in New Orleans = Lou Ann Barton (#)6. You'll Lose a Good Thing = Lou Ann Barton (Read My Lips)7. I'm a Good Woman = Barbara Lynn (#)8. Queen Bee = Sue Foley (Young Girl Blues)9. But I Forgive You = Sue Foley, Angela Strehli (Young Girl Blues)10. Cuban Getaway = Sue Foley (Young Girl Blues)11. Twelve Bar Blues = Toni Price (Swim Away)12. Richest One = Toni Price (Swim Away)13. Wrapping up Your Love = Lavelle White (#)# = not available on any other CD.~ This CD makes a nice introduction to Austin lady blues vocalists of the early 1990's, and for that reason is recommended.

~ This compilation provides an interesting survey of 8 great lady blues singers residing in Austin at the time of the initial release of the CD (1992).  Collected from a variety of recording sessions for Antone’s Records label, some of these tracks have been previously released while some are not available elsewhere (see note below).~ The vocal and instrumental quality is of the highest caliber throughout, featuring the cream of the crop of Austin blues musicians.  By offering 12 tracks from 9 artists, the producers have managed to give us a single CD that shows the breadth and depth of the lady blues vocalists in terms of style.~ Liner notes provide a single-page biography of each vocalist and the collective personnel playing on the various tracks is summarized.  Sound quality varies slightly from track to track as expected for this type of compilation, but is good to excellent throughout.~ My only complaint is the brevity of the disc (48 minutes) which could have easily been extended to 70+ minutes.  Of course, this shortcoming is out weighed by the fact that 5 of the 13 tracks are not available elsewhere.1. Something's Got a Hold on Me = Angela Strehli, Lou Ann Barton, Marcia Ball (Dreams Come True)2. Hurtback = Sarah Brown, Angela Strehli, Lou Ann Barton, Marcia Ball (#)3. Big Town Playboy = Angela Strehli (Soulful Shack)4. Neighbor, Neighbor = Angela Strehli (#)5. Down South in New Orleans = Lou Ann Barton (#)6. You'll Lose a Good Thing = Lou Ann Barton (Read My Lips)7. I'm a Good Woman = Barbara Lynn (#)8. Queen Bee = Sue Foley (Young Girl Blues)9. But I Forgive You = Sue Foley, Angela Strehli (Young Girl Blues)10. Cuban Getaway = Sue Foley (Young Girl Blues)11. Twelve Bar Blues = Toni Price (Swim Away)12. Richest One = Toni Price (Swim Away)13. Wrappin' up Your Love = Lavelle White (#)# = not available on any other CD.~ This CD makes a nice introduction to Austin lady blues vocalists of the early 1990's, and for that reason is recommended.

~ This compilation provides an interesting survey of 9 blues slide guitar players. Collected from various independent record labels and recorded over the period 1960 through 1993, all of these tracks have been previously released albeit on hard to find albums and CDs. It is great to have these tracks collected in one place. Unfortunately, the entire CD is only 46 minutes long - I assume this is the result of licensing frees and limited budgets, but it certainly would have been great to have seventy to eighty minutes of music covering additional slide masters.~ The lineup of artists may not be as widely known as some of their more famous blues brethren (see "comments" for a listing), but the music is of a high caliber throughout - both instrumentals and vocals. By offering 12 tracks from 9 artists, the producers have managed to produce a single CD that shows the breadth and depth of the blues slide guitar in terms of style and the artists range from those of historical interest to some newcomers (or at least newcomers in the 1990's).~ This CD makes a nice introduction to blues slide guitar and for that reason is recommended.~ Liner notes provide personnel information for each of the recordings. Sound quality varies from track to track as expected for this type of compilation, but is good to excellent throughout.~ My only reason for 4 rather than 5 stars is the brevity of the disc.

~Recorded live in 2012 in front of a small but appreciative audience, the reunited Zombies perform 19 songs that span not only their time as a group but also songs from the solo careers of Rod Argent and Colin Blunstone.  In addition to all of the hits from the past there are some new songs.  While Rod and Colin are the only two original Zombies here, they are accompanied by three excellent musicians, including longtime Kinks bassist Jim Rodford.  I have attached a track listing in the 'comments' section following this review.~ It is reassuring to know that the voices are all in great shape, even if they have lost of bit of their youthful power.  Musicianship is excellent throughout, as is the sound quality.~ The DVD is the same as the CD with the added bonus of an interview with Colin and Rod.~ Highly recommended for Zombie fans old and new.

~ This compilation provides an interesting survey of 5 lesser-known Texas blues artists. This 49-minute collections consists of four tracks by Pete Mayers, five tracks by Robert Ealey, and one track each from Joe Hughes, Curly Miller, and Robert Syler.  The lineup of artists may not be as widely known as some of their more famous Texan brethren (see "comments" for a listing), but the music is of a high caliber throughout.  By offering 12 tracks from 5 artists, the producers have managed to produce a single CD that shines a light on some artists worthy of wider recognition.~ Collected from various independent record labels and recorded over the period 1981 through 1994, the sound quality varies from good to excellent.~ It is great to have these tracks collected in one place. Unfortunately, the entire CD is only 49 minutes long - I assume this is the result of licensing frees and limited budgets, but it certainly would have been great to have seventy to eighty minutes of music covering additional Texans.~ This CD is one of several CD's available that serve as an introduction to the wealth of lesser-known Texas blues artists. As such, it makes a nice introduction to the Texas blues scene.~ Liner notes provide personnel information for each of the recordings and a brief but informative bio on each artist.~ Recommended. My only reason for 4 rather than 5 stars is the brevity of the disc.

~ This compilation provides an interesting survey of 10 lesser-known Texas blues guitar slingers.  Collected from various independent record labels and recorded over the period 1981 through 1996, all of these tracks have been previously released albeit on ten hard to find albums.  It is great to have these tracks collected in one place.  Unfortunately, the entire CD is only 41 minutes long - I assume this is the result of licensing frees and limited budgets, but it certainly would have been great to have seventy to eighty minutes of music covering additional Texans.~ The lineup of artists may not be as widely known as some of their more famous Texan brethren (see "comments" for a listing), but the music is of a high caliber throughout.  By offering 10 tracks from 10 artists, the producers have managed to produce a single CD that shows the breadth and depth of the Texas blues scene in terms of style.~ This CD is one of several CD's available that serve as an introduction to the wealth of lesser-known Texas blues artists.  As such, it makes a nice introduction to Texas blues guitarists.~ Liner notes provide personnel information for each of the recordings.  Sound quality varies from track to track as expected for this type of compilation, but is good to excellent throughout.~ Recommended.  My only reason for 4 rather than 5 stars is the brevity of the disc.

~ This CD combines live performances of the Stray Cats' hits and favourite songs taken from a variety of concerts.  The performances are enthusiastic and exciting as one would expect from the Stray Cats.  The drawback here is that the sound is not great.  The sound is acceptable but far from the quality of sound one would expect for live recordings of the past thirty years.~ Liner notes that accompany the CD are informative and extensive.

~ There is something here for everyone.~ For people who are new to the music of RHH, the first disc offers a career spanning 22 "best of" tracks.  Longtime RHH fans may quibble with the selection of tunes included here, but overall the disc gives a great synopsis of 25 years of RHH music.  Considering that the tracks were recorded in different studios over a long period of time, the sound quality is good and consistent.~ For those already have a collection of RHH music, the second disc offers his first ever live recording with 20 tracks.  As with the other disc in this collection, the sound quality is good. Considering that RHH's reputation is built more on live performances than recordings, it is interesting that this is the first live RHH recording.~ The third disc is a DVD offering a "Live at Fillmore" concert with interviews injected at various points. The interviews provide the viewer with some insight into the personalities of the band members and background on some of the songs.~ Highly recommended for longtime RHH fans as well as those who are new to the psychobilly experience.  Although it should be noted that this collection is offered at a wide variety of prices on Amazon, so search for the best price.NOTE: A listing of the tracks on the three discs is given in the "Comments" below.

~ This music is a fun sleigh ride through a variety of Christmas tunes. Setzer and the BS Orchestra are in fine vocal and instrumental form throughout, even on the down-tempo tracks. For Setzer guitar fans there are a few choice moments on the CD, but for the most part this is a vocals plus big band CD. Sound quality is excellent, and for the low prices of this CD the playing time is suitable if not generous. The entire CD makes for uplifting joyous good times at Christmas.~ Highly recommended.

~ This music is a fun sleigh ride through a variety of Christmas tunes.  Setzer and the BS Orchestra are in fine vocal and instrumental form throughout, even on the down-tempo tracks.  For Setzer guitar fans there are a few choice moments on the CD, but for the most part this is a vocals plus big band CD. ~ This book, published in 2012, is an updated version of a book by the same title that was published in 2001.~ The layout of the book is designed to present a roughly chronological development of guitars made in the USA.  The book is well researched and well written as the author discusses the innovative designers and manufacturers who have developed guitars in America since 1833.  It is nice to see credit given to these innovators and see how these innovations fit into the timeline that has led to today's guitars.  It is also interesting to see how many guitar manufacturers have come and gone over the years.~ It should be noted that the book does not go into the technical details of guitar design and manufacturing.  So if you are interested in those details, you need to look elsewhere.  This book is for someone who wants to have a historical perspective on guitars.~ Perhaps the feature of this book that will attract most guitarists is the multitude of photographs documenting guitars going all the way back to the 1830's.  Amazing to see these instruments.  Indeed, reading through the book is like taking a stroll through a guitar museum.  That aspect of the book is what makes this an excellent coffee table book and an excellent gift for guitarists.

This book was updated in 2012 with new content, making this 2001 edition obsolete.  The new edition and reviews of that edition can be found at the following link ,,, History of the American Guitar - 1833 to the Present Day.

~ Originally released in 1949, Gibson's ES-175 reached its full potential in the 1959 model that included PAF humbucking pickups and a rounded neck profile.  At that time and since then, the ES-175 has gained a reputation as the working artists jazz guitar.  Since 2012, Gibson's Memphis plant has been recreating this vintage classic as a Vintage Original Spec (VOS) instrument that is period-perfect in every detail: tonewoods, electronic components, and constructional details.~  The body is made from three-ply plain maple finished in either Vintage Sunburst or Vintage Natural, both with Gibson's nitrocellulose lacquer finish that has been processed for a gently aged look.  The set neck is made from solid mahogany with a bound rosewood fingerboard inlaid with characteristic split-parallelogram position markers.  For me the neck has a comfortably rounded profile, but some players may find it "chunky".  All I can suggest is that you try the guitar before buying.  The headstock has a mother-of-pearl Gibson logo and crown inlay along with a set of vintage-style, single-line TonePros(tm) tuners with amber tulip buttons, which add to the nostalgic appeal of the guitar.  The "zig-zag" trapeze tailpiece also adds to the nostalgic look of the guitar, as does the "aged" finish of the "PAF" humbuckers.  These re-created PAF humbuckers deliver a warm sound as close as you are going to get to the originals without spending a small fortune.  To add to the warm sound, the guitar uses a floating rosewood bridge, just as it did in 1959.~ The guitar comes with one or two humbuckers, depending your preference.  I tried both versions of the guitar before opting for the single pickup, which delivers the sound I want through my small limited edition amp with a hemp cone.  I bought my ES-175 at a store that had 10 of these beauties in stock, which allowed me to examine wood grain details before selecting the one just right for me.  I strongly urge any buyer to try before you buy.~ The guitar comes with a plush-lined hardshell case with silkscreen tan exterior and pink interior.

~ The Temptations recorded two albums of Christmas songs for Motown's Gordy Records: "Christmas Card" in 1970 and "Give Love at Christmas" in 1980.  In total 19 tracks were recorded: 10 for the first album and 9 for the second album (although the initial release of the album only contained 8 of those tracks).  These two albums have been remastered and reissued numerous times in packages that contain some, but not all, of the 19 tracks.~ In the decade between the recording of these two albums, musical styles changed and the personnel that comprised The Temptations changed.  Consequently, any attempt to merge the two original albums into one collection results in a variety that only adds to the disc.  Any combination of tracks from the two original albums presents a nice blend of traditional, contemporary, and original tunes presented in a setting of strings, brass, and percussion. The arrangements are unique and refreshing, never overly sentimental, often fun, sometimes funky. As always, the Temptation harmonies are exceptional.~ "Merry Christmas: The Temptations" / "Christmas Celebration" contains 15 of the nineteen songs, which makes it one of the most comprehensive surveys of The Temptations Christmas output.~ "The Best of the Temptations: 20th Century Masters: The Christmas Collection" / "The Best of the Temptations Christmas" contains 12 of the nineteen songs.  The nice thing about this collection is that it contains "Oh, Holy Night", the out-take from the 1980 sessions - a track that is usually omitted from the other compilations.~ Amazon lists the songs on each of these collections, and there is considerable overlap.  So which CD you buy will depend on your choice of songs you like.  You will not be disappointed with any one of these collections.

~ It is hard to believe that the Four Tops did not record a Christmas album back in the late sixties or early seventies when their Motown contemporaries were doing so, but this 1995 Christmas album is a gem worth waiting for.  This 12-track, 57-minute CD consists of a nice blend of traditional, contemporary, and original tunes presented in a modern setting of strings, brass, and percussion.  The arrangements are unique and refreshing, never overly sentimental, often fun, sometimes funky.  A lot of credit for the success of this CD has to go to the arrangers and producer.~ One of the things that is special about this collection of songs is that the great Levi Stubbs shares the spotlight with the other members of the group who get their chance to sing lead.  Of course, there is also some fine vocal harmonizing that is reminiscent of The Temptations at their best.~ On three tracks, the Four Tops are joined by Aretha Franklin.  Her style clearly contrasts with that of the Four Tops, and whether you view that as adding to or detracting from the overall impact of this CD will depend on your taste.~ Note: this CD has been released as "The Best of the Four Tops: 20th Century Masters - The Christmas Collection", "Merry Christmas" and "Christmas Here With You", but the are in fact the same tracks.~ Highly recommended as an addition to any collection of Christmas music.

~ This 64-minute documentary has been released under two titles: "After the Gold Rush" and "Under Review: 1977-2006".  The "Under Review" title is appropriately descriptive of the content.  The documentary covers the music released by Cohen in the 1977-2006 period through a commentary by the narrator mixed with interviews with various well-known music critics.  The comments offered by all parties are honest in their assessment of Cohen's work during this period.~ The narration puts all of this in proper perspective relative to Leonard's changing life during the 1977-2006 period.~ Highly recommended for anyone wanting to gain some insight into the man and his music during period covered by this documentary.

~ Tony Joe White was in fine form for this 1980 "Austin City Limits" performance. Backed by Jeff Hale on drums and Steve Spear on bass, this trio stomps out sixty minutes of swamp boogie fun. Lots of rockin' blues expertly delivered by an under-rated guitarist. Thirteen of the fourteen songs come from Tony Joe's prolific pen including classics such as "Polk Salad Annie", "Rainy Night in Georgia", and "Willie and Laura Mae Jones". His sense of humor comes through loud and clear in songs like "Even Trolls Love Rock `n Roll", "Mama Don't Let Your Cowboys Grow Up to Be Babies", "Disco Blues", and "300 Pounds of Hongry".~This DVD can be summed up by the title of one of his songs "I Came Here to Party."~ Highly recommended.

~ This 2012 book is an updated version of Tony Bacon's excellent "Six Decades of the Fender Telecaster".  Like all of his books, this one blends historical and current pictures with detailed, well-written, well-researched text to cover the history of the Esquire / Broadcaster / Nocaster / Telecaster guitars.  Of course, any discussion of the history of the Telecaster has to be closely related to the history of the Fender company and it's ups and downs.~ Interesting choice of three Telecaster models shown on the cover - the most prominent model shown on the cover is not the traditional Telecaster.~ There is a useful detailed collector's guide at the back of the book detailing every Tele made up to the time of publication.  The book contains is enough technical details to satisfy most readers, but for those who need more details about wiring etc there are other books available ,,, Telemaster A Wiring Guide For The Fender Telecaster.~ The book discusses several of the artists who have used the guitar.  One could quibble over which artists are covered in the book and which ones are omitted (notably, jazz guitarist Ed Bickert who extracted beautiful mellow sounds from his Telecaster).  One could quibble of the choice of images.  However, overall this is a highly recommended, entertaining and informative book.

This book is listed numerous times on Amazon under slight variations of the title, but they are all the same book.  The best price is at The Telecaster Guitar Book: A Complete History of Fender Telecaster Guitars (Revised and Updated), where you will find helpful reviews.

Although this book is listed by Amazon as being by Hal Leonard, the book is actually The Telecaster Guitar Book: A Complete History of Fender Telecaster Guitars (Revised and Updated) by Tony Bacon.  Follow the link for reviews of this book and to compare prices.

While this is a good book, there is an updated version published in 2012 that is probably a better buy ,,, The Telecaster Guitar Book: A Complete History of Fender Telecaster Guitars (Revised and Updated).

~ The Stratocaster Chronicles provides the reader with a detailed history and accounting of the first 50 years of Stratocaster production.  This well-written book provides a great balance of text and photography to keep the reader entertained while learning the trials, tribulations, and triumphs of the development and refinement of the best-selling guitar of all time.  Spread over 280 large-format pages, the author uses interviews and extensive research to make sure all aspects of the Strato-history are covered.~ There is something for everyone here: discussion of the technical details of the guitar, discussion of some of the major artists who have used the Strat and their preferred idiosyncratic nuances with regard to guitar modifications, and plenty of photographs.  There is even a CD that includes interviews and guitar playing samples.~ Highly recommended for any Strato-fans who want to know a little more about the history of their favourite guitar.  The only thing that may have improved the book would have been an attempt to clarify the somewhat confusing Fender serial numbering system.

~ This 60-minute documentary is part of the excellent PBS American Experience series.  It documents the life and times of Roberto Clemente from his birth in Puerto Rico to his untimely death on a flight to Nicaragua. While his baseball career is of course discussed, that is not the main main purpose of the documentary.  The main focus is on his experience coming to America as one of the first Latin American baseball players to appear in the major leagues.  The documentary deals sensitively with the prejudice he endured and how he rose above that prejudice to become not only an excellent athlete but a role model and hero to people throughout Latin America.  Indeed, most of the documentary deals with how Roberto channeled his energies into serving his community and his family.  Even today, decades after he died on a flight taking supplies to earthquake victims, he continues to inspire others.~ If Roberto Clemente had played out his career and retired, he would be remembered by a few as a great baseball player.  Instead, because of his pride and social conscience he is remembered by many as a great man.~ Highly recommended.

~ While this 2-CD release is a nice recording of an historical concert, I think most people will be more interested in the 1999 3-CD version  From Spirituals To Swing, which has superior sound, more music, and more comprehensive booklet inserts.

~ This elaborately packaged 3-CD set documents two historical events - a pair of concerts at Carnegie Hall - and a seven-track studio recording that was used to supplement the original release of this material.  In total you get 2 hours and 51 minutes of historical performances by many of the luminaries of jazz, blues, and gospel music in the late 1930's.  Where else can you hear the only recorded encounter of Lester Young and Charlie Christian? Where else can you hear gospel singers and blues singers backed by the elite of jazz?~ The discs are accompanied by an extensive booklet commenting on the historical significance of the concerts and giving brief commentary on the individual tracks and artists.  A second booklet is an actual reproduction of the program that accompanied the original 1938 concert.~ If you are looking for modern recording quality, you will be disappointed, but if you want to be transferred back to 1938 - 1939 and get some sense of what was happening at that time in the world of jazz, blues, and spiritual music you will be pleased with this box set.~ If you are looking for a less expensive version of these concerts (with less music reproduced in inferior sound) try Spirituals to Swing: Carnegie Concerts 38-39.

~ While this 1990 2-CD release is a nice recording of an historical concert, I think most people will be more interested in the 1999 3-CD version  From Spirituals To Swing, which has superior sound, more music, and more comprehensive booklet inserts (unfortunately at a higher price.)

~ For the low price of this book (less than $7 at the time of this review), this book is a bargain.  There are other more-comprehensive books covering the first 50 years of Fender history, but at a significantly higher price.~ If you want a book that covers the history of Fender guitars / amps / etc with a balance of photographs and text this is a good book.  The author covers the plethora of models that were developed, introduced, and in many cases discontinued.  He does a reasonable job of discussing the behind-the-scenes management changes and shifting cast of characters who contributed to the rise, fall, and rebirth of Fender - all without getting into the nitty gritty details that might disrupt the flow of the narrative.~ The last eight pages of the book provide a reasonable chronology and index.  There are more detailed chronologies available in the more expensive books, but for most people the information provided here is probably sufficient.~ The books does discuss several key Fender-using musicians, and yes it is possible to quibble about the amount of ink given to some musicians and the lack of ink given to others (or omission of others) but for the price the author has touched on the majority of key players and Fender guitar models.~ Recommended as an introduction to the history of the Fender company - 1950 through 2000.  Perhaps it is time that the author consider "65 Years of Fender" as a follow-up book.

~ This book, published in 2013, is reminiscent of Leonard Feather's classic "Encyclopedia of Jazz" series of books from the 1960's and 1970's in terms of layout, subject matter, and attention to detail.  As such, Scott Yanow's book in time may very well take on classic status.  Especially if it is frequently updated, as Feather did with his encyclopedias.  In this day of digital publishing, frequent updating should be easy.~ The book starts with a 9-page introduction covering the history of guitar in jazz.  This section helps put the rest of the book in proper historical perspective.  The section also references several influential non-jazz guitarists.~ The next 210 pages covers "342 Great Jazz Guitarists".  Each guitarist is given a detailed write-up discussing style, influences, and impact.  The description of each guitarist includes a section "recommended CDs", "LPs to search for", and website (where appropriate).  Fortunately, the author has not limited the recommendations to sessions led by the guitarist, but has included recordings in which the guitarist appeared in a supporting role.~ The next 15 pages covers "175 Other Jazz Guitarists on the Scene Today".  The write-ups here are briefer than the previous section, but each description is informative.~ There is a four page section listing guitarists who were known for their contributions in other genres of music, but did record at least on foray into the world of jazz.  The books ends with some recommended videos and books that deal with the great jazz guitarists.~ So in this age of instant information on the internet, why should one purchase this book?  For me the advantage of the book is that it introduced me to guitarists that I may have never encountered otherwise.  I can read the brief description, be intrigued, and decide to explore this artists further.~ Yes, it is possible to quibble with the author about which guitarists were included, which guitarists were overlooked, the section of the book in which any given guitarist is included, or the recommended listening CD or vinyl LP selections.  However, these complaints or of minor consequence when viewed in the grand scope of this well-researched book.~ This book should not be confused with similarly titled Great Jazz Guitarists Part 1; Great Jazz Guitarists Part 2 (Great Jazz Guitarists 2); Fancy Fretwork: The Great Jazz Guitarists (Art of Jazz).~ A highly recommended reference book for jazz guitar fans.

~ This book covers the first 70 years of Gibson electric guitar history; through 2007.~ The author has based the book on Gibson production, shipping and accounting records, old sales literature, and interviews with former employees, so the book is well researched - or at least as well researched as possible for a company that has changed ownership several times and a company that is notorious for poor record keeping.  Wisely, the author does not try to make sense of Gibson's method of assigning serial numbers to it's guitars.~ The initial 127 pages of the book is evenly split between text and photographs.  While the photo is extensive, it is not all-inclusive - that would require a much bigger and more expensive book.  This section of the book is informative with regards to the many changes in management, ownership, and philosophy as well as the introduction, elimination, and reissuing of the plethora of Gibson electric guitar models of the years.  The author does not hold any punches and is not afraid to point out Gibson's several failures in design and marketing.~ Following the 127 page history is a 30 page "reference" section organized be model name.  This section is useful for looking up specific models and trying to make sense of the changes that were imposed on that model over the years.  There may be a few models missing in this section (perhaps models that had limited production runs) but overall this reference section is useful and informative.~ The author, Walter Carter, has published several other guitar history books that are worth reading: Martin Guitar Book (Softcover), The Epiphone Guitar Book: A Complete History of Epiphone Guitars, Classic Electrics A Visual History Of Great Guitars, and others.~ Recommended, but I only gave it 4-stars because like any "history" book it is out-of-date by the time you buy it, or at least by the time I read it in 2013.

~ Norman Granz: impresario, producer, manager, Civil Rights leader.~ Granz first made his mark on the jazz world by booking and promoting live jazz concerts, most notably his "Jazz at the Philharmonic" concerts from the early 1940's through the mid-1950's.  A key component of the JATP concerts was the "jam session" featuring several of the best known artists of the day.  Many of the JATP concerts and jam sessions were recorded and are currently available on CD.~ Granz carried the jam session idea from the stage into the studio on four occasions, resulting in the release of nine 12-inch LP's, all of which are collected in this 5-CD package.  While the live JATP recordings are exciting and a great historical document, they sometimes suffer from less-than-perfect sound, crowd noise, and histrionics by some of the participants.  The studio session do not suffer from any of these faults, but retain the excitement and historical significance.  The sessions that comprise this collection are often designated by the names of the most significant contributors to the sessions, and are discussed below.  Musicians vary from session to session, and an extensive 72-page booklet included in the package provides detailed accounts of each session as well as a brief biography of each participant.  The booklet also puts the studio session within the proper historical perspective relative to the JATP concerts.  For fans of artist David Stone Martin, the original cover art of all nine LP's are included in the package.~ Each of the sessions follows a format that had worked well with the JATP jams: A mid-to-up tempo blues, a ballad medley, and an up-tempo burner.  Granz always dictated the song selection and solo order, which always yielded good results in terms of featuring the strengths of each musician.~ "The Charlie Parker Session" was recorded on 17 June 1952 and originally released as "Jam Session #1" and "Jam Session #2".  This session, like the "Eldridge-Gillespie" session two years later, clearly demonstrates the penchant of Norman Granz to mix artists from the swing era with artists from the bebop era as Charlie Parker encounters fellow saxmen Benny Carter, Johnny Hodges, Flip Philips, and Ben Webster.  The combination works well because of the high caliber of the musicians and their willingness to listen.~ 18 August 1953 produced "The Count Basie Session" was recorded on 18 August 1953 and originally released as "Jam Session #3" and "Jam Session #4".  For this session the rhythm section of the Oscar Peterson Trio plus drums is replaced by Count Basie, Freddy Green, John Simmons, and Buddy Rich anchoring an all-star swing session.  The change in rhythm sections for this session adds a subtle change in the tone of the session.~ 2 September 1953 produced "The Lionel Hampton Session" was recorded on 2 September 1953 and originally released as "Jam Session #5", "Jam Session #7" and "Jam Session #8".  The presence of Lionel Hampton elevates the excitement of this session to a notch above the level of the other three sessions.  Indeed, this session is closer to the "cutting contests" that often emerged on the JATP stage.~ 30 October 1954 produced "The Roy Eldridge - Dizzy Gillespie Session" was recorded on 30 October 1954 and originally released as "Jam Session #6" and "Jam Session #9".  Like the "Charlie Parker" session, the meeting of swing and bebop styles on this session works exceptionally well.~ Highly recommended.  Having said that, I doubt that anyone is willing to pay the price currently listed on Amazon ... almost $800 as of August 2013.  Let's hope Verve re-issues the box set.

~ "Tristeza" features the Oscar Peterson Trio of the late 1960's to early 1970's with Peterson on piano, Sam Jones on bass, and Bobby Durham on drums.  Tempos range from slow to breakneck with the program containing eight modern standards.  While the focus is squarely on Peterson, he does prove himself to be a gracious and generous leader by giving his two partners sufficient freedom to swing.  The interaction between the three artists is outstanding.  The 1970 recording for the MPS label is "closely" engineered in that the sound is clear and crisp - so clear that you hear Peterson's trademarked vocalizations throughout.~ Highly recommended to fans of straight-ahead piano trio jazz.

~ "Hello Herbie" reunites Herb Ellis with his old mate Oscar Peterson - two thirds of the famous OP Trio of the 1950's.  In this case, Ellis and Peterson are accompanied by Sam Jones on bass and Boby Durham on drums.  The program is straight-ahead jazz with a strong taste of the blues.  Tempos range from mellow to rapid-fire but the music is always joyful as Ellis and Peterson are obviously enjoying this reunion after more than a decade apart.  Accordingly, Herb Ellis is given sufficient solo space, and the interaction between Ellis and Peterson retains all the magic and spark of old.  The 1969 recording for the MPS label is "closely" engineered in that the sound is clear and crisp - so clear that you hear Peterson's trademarked vocalizations throughout.~ Highly recommended.

~ Recorded in March 1962, this Count Basie septet session easily ranks at or near his best.  The front line of Thad Jones on trumpet, Frank Foster (tracks 1, 3, 5, 7), Frank Wess (tracks 2, 4, 6, 8), and Eric Dixon on various saxophones, flutes, and clarinet, and Count Basie on piano and organ is perfectly matched with the support of Freddie Green on guitar, Sonny Payne on drums and Eddie Jones on bass.  The septet is in superlative form on a variety of blues, standards, and originals.  The variety of voicings and textures provided by the multiple reed instruments provides an ever-changing quality to the music.  The drumming by Sonny Payne is outstanding throughout.* This recording is HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.~ Oh, Lady, Be Good (Ira Gershwin) 4:40 ~ Basie's 1938 version of this tune is famous for being the recording debut of Lester Young.  In this 1962 version, Basie sets a bouncing dance tempo over which Dixon, Jones, and Foster provide sparkling solos.~ Secrets (Frank Wess) 4:08 ~ This jaunty track features Wess on alto flute, Jones on muted trumpet, Dixon on C flute, and some great brush work by Payne.~ I Want a Little Girl (Murray Mencher / Billy Moll) 4:16 ~ With Jones on wa-wa trumpet, Foster on tenor, Dixon on clarinet, and Basie on organ, this track is tune is taken at a slow melancholy pace.~ Shoe Shine Boy (Sammy Cahn / Saul Chaplin) 4:07 ~  This is an updated version of a 1936 Basie clasic with great ensemble playing by everybody.~ Count's Place (Count Basie) 5:28 ~ Typical Basie ... a catchy riff-based tune featuring some fine Basie piano and Payne drumming.~ Senator Whitehead (Frank Wess) 4:12 ~ With the same instrumentation as "Secrets" this piece dances along at a swinging fast pace.~ Tally-Ho, Mr. Basie! (Count Basie) 4:28 ~ Another great riff-based Basie tune with more great playing from Basie and his band.~ What'Cha Talkin'? (Thad Jones) 4:59 ~ A distinctive Jones piece with excellent execution of the ensemble passages by Jones, Foster, Wess, and Dixon.~ A thorough search of Amazon will reveal that there are other versions of this CD that include "Trey of Hearts" (Thad Jones) 3:43 ~ A bonus track that was not included in the original vinyl LP, this track gives Count Basie a chance to shine on piano.  I rate the CD's with the bonus track at 5 stars because of the additional value.NOTE: This CD on the Impulse! Label should not be confused with a CD issued in 1980 on the Pablo label with an almost identical title Kansas City 7.

The variety of voicings and textures provided by the multiple reed instruments provides an ever-changing quality to the music.  The drumming by Sonny Payne is outstanding throughout.* This recording is HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.~ Oh, Lady, Be Good (Ira Gershwin) 4:40 ~ Basie's 1938 version of this tune is famous for being the recording debut of Lester Young.  In this 1962 version, Basie sets a bouncing dance tempo over which Dixon, Jones, and Foster provide sparkling solos.~ Secrets (Frank Wess) 4:08 ~ This jaunty track features Wess on alto flute, Jones on muted trumpet, Dixon on C flute, and some great brush work by Payne.~ I Want a Little Girl (Murray Mencher / Billy Moll) 4:16 ~ With Jones on wa-wa trumpet, Foster on tenor, Dixon on clarinet, and Basie on organ, this track is tune is taken at a slow melancholy pace.~ Shoe Shine Boy (Sammy Cahn / Saul Chaplin) 4:07 ~  This is an updated version of a 1936 Basie clasic with great ensemble playing by everybody.~ Count's Place (Count Basie) 5:28 ~ Typical Basie ... a catchy riff-based tune featuring some fine Basie piano and Payne drumming.~ Senator Whitehead (Frank Wess) 4:12 ~ With the same instrumentation as "Secrets" this piece dances along at a swinging fast pace.~ Tally-Ho, Mr. Basie! (Count Basie) 4:28 ~ Another great riff-based Basie tune with more great playing from Basie and his band.~ What'Cha Talkin'? (Thad Jones) 4:59 ~ A distinctive Jones piece with excellent execution of the ensemble passages by Jones, Foster, Wess, and Dixon.~ Trey of Hearts (Thad Jones) 3:43 ~ A bonus track that was not included in the original vinyl LP, this track gives Count Basie a chance to shine on piano.NOTE: This CD on the Impulse! Label should not be confused with a CD issued in 1980 on the Pablo label with an almost identical title Kansas City 7.

~ Bluesman Watermelon Slim has always added a slight country flavor to his excellent blues albums such as "Watermelon Slim and the Workers" and "Wheel Man".  However, with "Ringers" he has stepped almost completely into the realm of country and western.  Not the highly produced country coming out of Nashville and Los Angeles, but the good old county music that you will find in the roadhouses of Texas and Oklahoma.~ Highlights include "Please Take This Cup", a song about a man's struggle with the bottle.  On a lighter note, there's a bluesy honky tonk story of true love "I Appreciate That".  "Good Old Boys Never Change" is a bouncy barroom rocker.  "End of the Line" laments the death of our nation's railroads at the hands of big oil, and "If There Is Any Heaven" is a gospel-flavored cry of grief that takes a dark look at the world we live in while managing to find a glimmer of hope and light.  Slim also covers a few classics in his own style: Conway Twitty's "Tight Fittin' Jeans" gets a bluesy makeover; Moe Bandy's classic "Soft Lights and Hard Country Music" has a hint of swing; and Jimmy Buffet's "He Went to Paris" is given a melancholy reading.~ Highly recommended for people who like their country music shaded with the blues.

~ Bluesman Watermelon Slim has always added a slight country twang to his excellent blues albums such as "Watermelon Slim and the Workers" and "Wheel Man".  However, with "Ringers" he has stepped almost completely into the realm of country and western.  Not the highly produced country coming out of Nashville and Los Angeles, but the good old county music that you will find in the roadhouses of Texas and Oklahoma.~ Highlights include "Please Take This Cup", a song about a man's struggle with the bottle.  On a lighter note, there's a bluesy honky tonk story of true love "I Appreciate That".  "Good Old Boys Never Change" is a bouncy barroom rocker.  "End of the Line" laments the death of our nation's railroads at the hands of big oil, and "If There Is Any Heaven" is a gospel-flavored cry of grief that takes a dark look at the world we live in while managing to find a glimmer of hope and light.  Slim also covers a few classics in his own style: Conway Twitty's "Tight Fittin' Jeans" gets a bluesy makeover; Moe Bandy's classic "Soft Lights and Hard Country Music" has a hint of swing; and Jimmy Buffet's "He Went to Paris" is given a melancholy reading.~ Highly recommended for people who like their country music shaded with the blues.

~ Following on the heals of their multiple award winning "Watermelon Slim and the Workers" CD of 2006, the band returns in 2007 with and equally engaging "The Wheel Man", which was nominated for another six Blues Music Awards.  "The Wheel Man" went on to with the award for Best Blues CD of 2007 while the band won the award for Best Blues Band of 2007.  On the basis of this CD and the band's spectacular stage show, Slim won the Maple Blues Award for B.B. King International Entertainer of the year in 2007.  "The Wheel Man" also was No. 1 Blues Album in England's Mojo Magazine blues CD poll.  With that many awards, it is obvious that this CD and this band are something special.~ Watermelon Slim has found a way to bring something fresh to the blues genre in the 21st century by looking backward all the way to the field holler and looking over sideways to country music, rolling it all up into a smart synthesis that sounds fresh and sharp even though it is only a half-step removed from the sounds of Charley Patton or Jimmie Rodgers.  Slim's compositions are autobiographical and intelligent as evidenced by tracks like "Sawmill Holler".  "Jimmy Bell" is old-fashioned storytelling.  In addition to Slim's compositions, there are a pair of impressive blues covers: excellent renditions of Slim Harpo's "Got Love If You Want It" and Furry Lewis' "Judge Harsh Blues."  Slim's Oklahoma twang that binds everything together and gives all of the blues a slight country feel.~ "The Wheel Man" is on par with his previous outing in every respect.  Highly recommended for anyone looking for a slightly-country flavor to their contemporary blues.

~ Following his sparse and arresting "Up Close & Personal", Watermelon Slim formed a new band of excellent musician, recorded this CD, and hit the road as "Watermelon Slim and the Workers".  The music on this CD reveals Slim to be a contemporary bluesman with a scholar's understanding of the various genres we call "the blues".  The sound on this CD is spectacular, and it presents Slim's insightful songs and passionate delivery in an intimate setting, making this release one of the best contemporary blues albums you will ever hear.  Drawing on his service time in Vietnam, his years as a cross-country truck driver, and an academic career (he is a member of MENSA with several university degrees), his lyrics are always interesting and his music is delivered in a way that shows his passion for the blues.~ The music ranges from the shuffling and stomping "Hard Times", through a laid-back"Dumpster Blues" to a spooky "Devil's Cadillac" to the rollicking "Juke Joint Woman."  Not everything is written by Slim, as he takes time to pay homage to Fred McDowell with "Frisco Line".~ On the basis of this CD and the stage show by this band, Watermelon Slim and the Workers were nominated in 2006 for six Handy Awards in 2006 in a variety of categories, and for a Maple Blues Award from the Toronto Blues Society.  In early 2007, this album won in The 6th Annual Independent Music Awards for Best Blues Album.~ Highly recommended.

~ "White Trash Girl" by Candye Kane (released in 2005) is all out fun.  Nine of the fourteen songs come from Candye's pen; as such they are autobiographical and reflect her "live life to the fullest" attitude.  The remaining five songs are well selected to fit comfortably into the flow and attitude of the CD.  All of the songs are fun, insightful, and sometimes shocking.~ The musicianship is very good and Candye's voice is strong throughout the 14 songs.  Like all of Candye's CDs there is a broad variety of styles of music ranging from straight ahead blues, to a touch of country swing, to pop covers.  Compared to her earlier releases, this CD is perhaps a little more in the vain of straight ahead blues, but overall there is a little something for everyone here.~ As strong as the CD is, it just cannot live up to her dynamic stage show - especially with the wonderful Laura Chavez on guitar in her current band.~ Recommended 42 minutes of good rockin' fun.

~ "Dive La Grande" by Candye Kane (released in 1997) is pedal to the metal fun.  Eleven of the fourteen songs come from Candye's pen while the remaining three songs fit comfortably into the flow of the CD.  All of Candye's compositions are autobiographical and reflect her "live life to the fullest" attitude.  That makes the songs fun, insightful, and sometimes shocking.~ The musicianship is very good and Candye's voice is strong throughout the 14 songs.  There is a broad variety of styles on the CD ranging from straight ahead blues, to country swing, to pop covers, and there is even an instrumental track thrown in.  Compared to her more recent CD's there is a little more country feel to several songs in this collection, but overall there is a little something for everyone here.~ As strong as the CD is, it just cannot live up to her dynamic stage show - especially with the wonderful Laura Chavez on guitar in her current band.~ Recommended 53 minutes of fun.

This is a product by Belkin, which is a trusted brand of mine. This particular item has more than 2,500 reviews already on Amazon, so you have it all, from 5 stars (the simple majority as I write these words) to many 1 star reviews.The truth is that I could have given this an easy 1 or 2 stars review, but it would have not been completely fair. The problem -major problem though- with this dock is that depending on what phone case you have, it will not have the phone sitting and charging. This is, of course, a major concern, because the main function of this dock is for your phone to be charging while it sits. The current case I have in my iPhone case (both iPhone 6 and iPhone 6 Plus) is such to prevent this dock to accept my phone completely in, so it won't charge. So for me it is useless.I have an old case that did work, so I changed it and it works fine. You can also take your phone out of the case and have it charged without a case, and when finished, put it back. But this is a big pain in the b.This is a very beautiful dock, and when it works, it works very well, but be aware of my comments above, because chances are you have a case that will prevent your phone to sit properly in. Be aware and buy accordingly.

My mother always used to cook using a pressure cook. I am happy I bought this one, and although I admit I am not very good at it yet, I use it with great success with beans. I am in the process of learning other recipes, and I can tell you the time you save, AND the quality of its food, is worth every penny of this product.T-fal is a company I trust for kitchen houseware. This pressure cooker is very well made, and I believe it will last me many years. I highly recommend it!

I have always worn ASICS brand products for running. The very first running shoes (as an adult) I bought were ASICS Gel-Nimbus. Now the 17 is the new and best ever. I can't believe how comfortable these shoes are! I was lucky to get this shoes as a slick deal for below hundred bucks. I would recommend ASICS to anybody, they are made to last and to provide the support you need to run efficiently and safely, and more than anything else, to take you longer! I have run several marathon and half marathon with them, and I wear them proudly!These shoes were chosen by Runner's World Magazine as the BEST shoes in June 2015. That says it all!BTW, I did not know ASICS is anima sana in corpore sano, but I am surprised because the way I learned is MENS (mind) sana, not anima (soul) ... but anyway ... Go Asics!

I love RUSH, and this T-Shirt comes with all the different RUSH logos they have printed in every album, plus icon in the middle. The first time I wore this I got compliments. This T-Shirt is affordable, which leads me to talk about the ridiculous over price business of Rock memorabilia. C'mon guys, this is ROCK! It was 'invented' as a rebellion against the status quo, and now it is cheaper to go to the opera than to go to a rock concert. Do you really think a freaking cotton T-Shirt is worth more than fifteen bucks? At least this ain't. Great T-Shirt, I wear it with pride!

I absolutely love my new kindle paperwhite. I already was in love with my other paperwhite, but I decided to go with this one. I receive the kindle reader deals, and I always receive offers for junk books, romance and silly books like that, but it's still okay, I buy the books I like and read them in the dark!

Paul Hanson is a great instructor, and this book is a proof of it. Paul Hanson was the writer of the Guitar World magazine section "BOSS The Pedals that Make the Tone," which was among the BEST content I've ever read in this magazine (unfortunately, GW does not have this section any more, they just give you TABS but with no tips on playing, tips, etc which is too bad ... I'd hope they would read this review and reconsider!).I like Hanson way of teaching the examples, and the overall layout of the book. I feel I am improving, although this is shredding guitar, so don't expect gains overnight. The companion CD is a must, I'd say. It helps me listen to what I am supposed to play, so it is a great compliment to the TABS. This book is keeping me motivated (so far), and I'd recommend it to anybody who is interesting in shredding.

I use BRITA as my main system of filtering water, but to carry the water around, I trust Nalgene 100%. I bught in the past all kinds of bottles: cheap ones, expensive ones, ugly ones, beautiful ones, and Nalgene is the very absolute best. Full stop.I bought a couple of these, and I am so happy I did. They are exactly what they say they are, and more. Do not waste your time or time searching for other bottles. You want and you need Nalgene. Besides, for ten bucks, these bottles are a steal! All the time you need to waste is thinking about what color to pick.

I love these, I really do! This is a must at my household, where I have several electronic devices/computers with lots of cables and I had to use a lot of them. These are really reusable, super easy to put in and take off. I use them with computer settings, musical instruments, etc. I am very happy with this purchase, super cheap, super great product, I will buy them again and again as long as I need the. I recommend them to everyone! Perfect!

This is a huge poster, 22x34, but it is exactly what I needed. Because it is bigger than what I thought, I ended up posting it on my door (behind the door, in my practice room). It gives me quick info when I needed. All the info here is in every theory book, but if you want it quick, look up and there it is. It decorates my music practice room, and it's great. I love Hl Leonard instructional books, and this poster follows the same quality.

Some of the reviews I read are negative, which is surprising but, at the same time, something I do respect. IMHO, when it comes to sound there is nothing set on stone; it all comes down to personal taste. My very fist guitar pedal was a BOSS (actually it was a distortion pedal, but not this one), and I still have it and use it. BOSS builds quality lasting products. This company is owned now by Roland, which is mainly known for their keyboard line. I don't see any compromise in quality, though, and the tone (which is the most important aspect of getting a guitar pedal), is top notch. Again, this is for my personal taste. If you like other pedals, it's great, but trashing this product just because you don't like it, it's kind of not fair.I specifically wanted to add this particular DS-1 pedal to my pedal board because Joe Satriani and Tom Morello, two players I am into a lot lately, use them (or have used them in the past), and I am getting exactly what I was looking for.If there is one downside to pedals is the price. Once you buy 5 or 6 different pedals, you are looking at hundreds of dollars, and that kind of sucks, but as far as my taste goes, I like stompboxes better than other systems.

These strings are used by John Petrucci, which says a lot. I have them in my Ibanez 7 string guitar, and my guitar plays like butter! Awesome quality. I always have a couple of these in my guitar case and I change them every 5/6 months.

Just perfect. Every guitar player needs one of this, even if you don't do your setups yourself, at least you can know for the fact if your guitar action is too low, or too high. Very durable, and as others have noted, I don't think I will ever need to buy another action ruler gauge, unless I lose this one.

I don't know why it took me so long to find this product, but now that I did, I recommend it to everybody! This will save you tons of energy caused by vampire power, which is the electric company literally sucking your hard earned money by overcharging you for energy you don't really use. Just get one of each for every outlet in your household where you have a hair-dryer, a phone charger, a coffee machine, etc, and make sure you switch them off after you use your appliance. It's that simple. it works as advertised, and all the reviews are right on spot. Excellent!

This is an exciting gadget, pretty much indeed. I'd even say it's more exciting than 3D printing technology. However, as the 3D technology, there is still a long way ahead for these printers to work great and be consumer friendly.You may have read other reviewers giving up after so many hours of frustration with just the setting up. The frustration is real. I didn't want to give it up and, after 2 long days of fighting with it, I finally got this Curio think to do something for me. I printed letters some cool letters (big though) and was happy with it. The problem is, when I tried to do more sophisticated cutting, every time the paper was messed up by the cutter.So the setting up is very frustrating, and the results inconsistent, thus my 3 stars rating. The machine is not bad; I could not give it 2 or 1 stars and be fair with it, however, there is, as I said above, a long way for these companies to get this right. I was wondering if the company should have waited a little bit longer for the prototype to be released, so it gets more consumer acceptance. We will be definitely using this cutter, but we would only hope for all the things it says it can do, that would actually be possible to be done. Until then, 3 stars.

You get 184 total bags (4 packs of 46 each) for under fifteen bucks, which is 8 pennies per bag. They have a storage slider that is better than ziploc bags. These bags are a quart of a gallon in size (.94L, 7 in x 8 in). These are perfect for every day use. I like them because they are big so I can bag not only small items, but bigger, like vegetables for my freezer for example, or fruits to go as snack. Great price, you should give them a try!

I used to have a cheap shredder that kind of did the job, but it continuously jammed, and the bin was so small that I had to empty it every other day. With this Sentinel, all those issues are gone forever. Not only this Sentinel shreds everything ... yes, I tried 18 sheets of paper with staples, and no problem, CD-ROMS (this is important because I destroyed some old back-up CDs with info, so I want to make sure they are fully destroyed), and credit cards -obviously very important.I also bought some oil for shredders machines​, which I recommend, because I am planning on using this machine for the next 5 years at least. The operation is silent, very solid, and overall, and excellent solution for my office solutions which I highly recommend to all. This is the one shredder you need.

How can a watch be priced at $650, but be sold for 87% off? Because it is not worth $650. Is it worth $87 (current price while writing this review)? Maybe.The things I like about this watch are the leather strap (genuine leather strap, usually a $20 value at the mall if you want to have a new strap in any of your watches), and the dial color. It is a kind of black, grey, bluish ... hard to describe but definitely very beautiful. The size of the watch is perfect for my wrist (I have small wrist because I am kind of skinny). The watch looks classy once worn, really nice.The things I don't like much, thus my 4 stars rating. The clasp system is a little bit confusing. It takes some time to figure it out (no instructions provided for that), although once you get it, it is fine. Basically you lock the clasp in one position, and it stays in that position unless you change your wrist size. But why would you need a clasp system on a leather strap? The other thing I really don't like about this watch is the operation and function of the date, chronograph, etc. To begin with, the numbers and letters are so very hard to read because of the tiny size, and because of the color chosen in designing them. Also, because they distract you from the real beauty of the watch, which would be its simplicity. Bottomline, a watch that is worth something between $50 and $75, but that it is not among the watches I am planning on wearing the most.

I like this case very much, above all, because of its simplicity in design and convenience. Basically, this is a customizable case where you can make it be whatever you want. There is a dedicated website with more design for you to choose from. However, I see this more like a personal thing where you can create your own designs, or place any picture(s) you want in the back. Just by itself, the case is great because it basically sees through your phone so you can display the already beautiful Apple design of the iPhone 6 (be it gold, the new rose, or any other color you have). The setback of this case is the high price tag, thus my 4 stars rating.
