I love how easy it is to apply to a brandnew phone. I really like the touch of this glass screen protector vs the plastic screen protector. I use it with a really good case. This is just a nice screen to protect my phone from normal finger prints. I don't plan to drop my phone. If I do, I hope that it will protect the phone. So far, I love the lookand feel!

I've been using CoQ10 for a while now, every since a neurologist recommend it to me. It's kind of expensive (being expensive a really very subjective adjective), but the benefits of CoQ10 are many. "CoQ10 has been studied for use as an antioxidant to protect cells from damage. CoQ10 has been used in combination with other antioxidants. Early study suggests that it may have antioxidant benefits in people with heart disease." I noticed CoQ10 helping me with my cardiovascular function and my levels of energy and stamina. I am a very active person, by the way, and I find this to be in accordance with that level of activity and in resulting a more energetic me after a very long day at work and at home. This bottle is 150 pills of 100 mg each, which is the daily dose I take. It comes with Bioperine, which helps CoQ10 work better. It basically increases the bioavailability of nutritional compounds such as the one found in CoQ10. In other words: it's there to make double sure you get what you need from the active ingredients.CoQ10 is a great supplement you should consider looking into, and this Viva Labs is a great choice.

I don't know when the BRITA company came into business, but I've used BRITA filters for a very very long time. Every once in a while (about 2, 3 years), I replace my BRITA pitchers, so they are in prime shape. I have always been extremely satisfied with the water quality I obtain out of them, and I can't stress enough how strongly I recommend them. Bear in mind, though, that the quality of the water you obtain from these products depends in large part of the quality of your local water. Nevertheless, a BRITA filter will greatly help you obtain the best quality water you can get in your area, that is for sure.What I like about this particular pitcher:1. Its small size, only 6 cups. This is a positive aspect of this pitcher because I bought it for my office. I have a small refrigerator there, and this fits perfectly. Moreover, it assures me I get 6 cups while at work, where I spend about 8 hours or more every day. (I drink about 10 cups of water a day, so this is 60% of it, already. Before I go home every day I want to make sure this is empty. Then I refill it and it is ready for the next day).2. The colors. This is a black pitcher, but the combination of black with the transparent pitcher makes it look like a beautiful grey. A really nice touch in the design department!3. Locking lid for spill-free pouring. A nice improvement over old models.4. This comes with a filter change indicator that has also been improved over old models. However, I will admit I don't care much for this feature, because I always change the filter every 8 weeks, regardless of the use I give them. (I actually know that I could use them a little bit longer, but I rather change them more often than not). By the way, this is a new BRITA pitcher model, so it comes with the newly designed filters. I recently bought another BRITA pitcher, the Brita UltraMax Filtered Water Dispenser (which is absolutely AWESOME-A-MA-ZING!), and it also comes with the new filters, so I can buy a box of filters and change them every other month.I hope you found this review helpful. I you don't own a BRITA pitcher, I highly recommend you getting one. You may start with this one, or with any other of the other products available. You will sure find the one that fits your needs. I strongly recommend BRITA products, no hesitations, extremely long time satisfied customer!

Awesome instructional DVD, but ONLY for advanced​ players. Be advised, or else you will hate yourself and the DVD. Otherwise, an absolute must if you are into Satriani's music or shredding guitar. The six songs included in this DVD are Big Bad Moon • Cryin' • Flying in a Blue Dream • Friends • Rubina • Summer Song. Thanks !

This is an outstanding trimmer, which I mainly use for body hair. I used other products in the past, but this one is dedicated to all men's hair, including body, and I must say it exceeded my expectations. Legs and chest were a breeze with this Panasonic trimmer. I did buy the Panasonic ER-GN30-K Nose Ear Hair Trimmer in the past, as the number one hair trimmer for men. Obviously, that is for ear and nose, but this one is a beast for the whole body. You could probably use it to shave your head even!Panasonic has proven me they know what they are doing when it comes to trimming. Do not waste your money with the junk they sell at the cashier lines at you know where. Get a solid and durable machine like this Panasonic, and you are set to go. This product comes with a nice travel case, and power outlet for charging (it works without it, so perfect for traveling), and different size trimmers.I highly recommend this product to all men looking for the one trimmer to get.

Best organic formula around. Period. I buy this on a regular basis, and I couldn't be happier. If you need toddler formula and you are looking at this product, it is because you've already heard its wonders. You want it, and you need it. Go for it! 5 stars!!!!!
Awesome show, but this used to be included with Amazon Prime and now it is not. Dear Amazon, let me have a good reason to keep my Fire TV and let me have How It's Made FREE for Prime members. Thanks!

No nursery is complete without this heater. At least, no nursery in cold weather cities like mine! This is an exceptionally well-built heater that is all about safety and convenience. But safety first, that's for sure. This is finger-friendly, with no pinch points. It's got a curiosity-proof child lock switch, and the cord is hidden and covered. There is an automatic shutoff system by which the unit shuts off let's say if there is a blanket on top of it, or whenever excessive heat is detected. Also, it shuts off when tipped over for the protection of your child. The case is cool-touch, it's got 2 heat settings, auto or continuous fan, and the device heats up the air 3.5 times each hour in a gentle way so the air is heating around your baby, not on your baby. This unit is a superior model than others in the same line because it comes with an automatic control system. The system comes with a cribside (TM) temperature sensor that continuously monitors the crib temperature and automatically adjust the temperature as set. Therefore, the unit comes with a programmable timer that is technologically very sophisticated and that, in my humble opinion, totally justifies the price tag.The unit is guaranteed for 5 years, and it even looks super pretty, which again, makes this an absolutely in any nursery that needs extra heating. 5 stars without hesitation.

Swiss Legend is a company from Hollywood, Florida. As far as I can tell (nowhere in the box, instruction manual, or watch there is an indication where this is made), this watch is not made in Switzerland, although it uses Swiss quartz movement. I would describe this as a sports watch, a very bold, very heavy, very thick sports watch. This is 11.05 oz, which is very very heavy. The case diameter is 52 mm, and 19 mm thick, which is also large, so you probably get the idea considering these measurements. The picture available on Amazon makes justice to the watch. I find the orange dial very beautiful. It is also bold, the whole watch idea is bold I'd say, but the red dial is 'tricky' because it is a red going to orange, hard to describe. I like that ambiguity. The watch is also water resistant, 330 feet, which is triple of the average. This is good because as a sports watch, you want to make sure it can take anything. It is stainless steel, and the bezel is actually very elegant. The watch has the date at four o'clock, and it comes with a very nice and sturdy case, same red color as the watch. All in all it is a watch I can comfortably give 4 stars (not 5 because of its very large size and weight).

This is bulkier than a regular frontal baby wearing, but this child carrier is specifically design for very active families like mine. I can carry my baby to hiking and I know the baby will be safe. This has a max load weight of 30 pounds, I wish it was more than that, but still. The child seat has an adjustable-height seat to accommodate the child's growth, and the structure is padded and made of aluminum. I feel this is very sturdy, and it feels very safe and secure. For your peace of mind, this child carrier is JPMA certified and CPSC approved, so for your peace of mind.This is probably not an every day child carrier, but for long days, not just a walk in the park, and especially in our case for long hikes, this is a winner.

We use different brands of diapers, and I don't see why lots of folks say the best brand are p.ers. We love huggies, and use them, and have no problem whatsoever. They are great diapers, and this in particular give you a whole night of peace of mind and protection for your child. Can't give them less than 5 stars, and we highly recommend them.

Umberto Eco is one of the best writers of contemporary literature today (he does not have a Nobel prize, but who cares, Murano does and good luck finding someone in the U.S. who knows who Murano is...). He is Italian, and as such, writes in Italian. I am saying this because, unfortunately for the English reader, books in English translation do not abound (actually a meager 3% of books published in English are translation, and not even half of that number are fiction). I will not write about the reasons why this happens, but the consequence is a poor dialogue between English/American literatura and word literatura, some sort of isolationism that can't be good for the English letters.Among the actual books that are translated, though, there are plenty of them with outstanding quality. And Eco is among those. This book is really outstanding. It did make it to the best books of 2015 by the prestigious cultural supplement 'Babelia' in Spain. When I read that, I went "Oh, wait ... not available yet in the English market!" Not surprised, but certainly disappointed. Now, finally!, this is available for the English reader. It is a short novel, actually, especially considering how Eco books are usually long (The name of the rose, etc.). But don't confuse quality with quantity. This is an excellent satire, some sort of parable, of the poor shape in which journalism lives today. You have to read it, from beginning to end, to grasp what Eco is proposing. Quite an accomplishment!

Swaddle babies is, as far as I know, something original from the Paleolithic era. We have evidence that ancient Greek and Roman societies used swaddling, but this practice lost popularity in the Western world around the 1700s.Now it is so popular again, that it seems everyone -at least here in the U.S.- is doing it... Controversies aside (some people don't think this is a good idea), as popular as swaddling is, you have also many different products. This one in particular is one we highly consider as a first choice for several reasons. The design is proven to make swaddling easy AND safe. It has secure closures for safer sleep. This is 100% cotton, and adequate for toddlers up to 12 lbs and 26 inches. The design vary, so take a look at the picture and pick up the ones you like the most. The same company provides this item in packages of 3, or 2. They are the same design and quality, and we highly recommend them.

I am not going to rewrite what's available here on the site, which is all true to the best of my knowledge. I will just comment on how I feel this product deserves 5 stars, and why you should consider buying it.This is a professional muscle conditioner, NOT a pain reliever device. This is the first consideration you should have, because unless you are an active person, you should not be considering this device (IMHO). If you are active, as I am, then you may want to  give this a chance, because most likely you are already spending money in massage therapy someplace else. I do strength training (for maintenance, not to build up), and cardio training (long distance running). This is where I need my massages, and when I do, it's never less than $60. If you do the math, two visits to the massage therapist is what this device will cost you. Of course, once you buy the device, you can use it everyday, and the only maintenance you have to perform is changing the battery (Amazon brand are about $1 each, other brands may be around $2), and changing the gel pads ($14.99 for a pair).So moneywise this is a no brainer. But what a bout the performance? I went for a 6 mile run this morning, so my quads and calfs are tired. I used program 2 (30 minute active recovery) for my calfs and then for my quads, and I feel like new. This device has a total of 6 programs, 3 for post-exercise recovery (#2 is 30 minutes, and #2 and #3 are 20 minutes each) and three exercise programs (#1 is 12 minutes, a basic program to prepare your muscles for activity; #5 is endurance, 20 minutes; and #6 is muscle strengthening 20 minutes). One of the things I like the most about the device is that you have two gel pads (or course) but each one is controlled independently from the other, so let's say one leg is more tired than the other one, you may chose to have an intensity of 50 in one leg, and intensity 35 in the other leg. Intensity goes from 1 to 100.This device is totally portable, and it comes with a nice carrying bag (so I can take it with me to my running races and have a pre and a post massage!), quick start guide, the control unit, 2 adhesive gel pads and a replacement, the battery is included (9V, I know the expensive one, but it's worth it!), the cables, and the instruction manual. Please read the instructions carefully, and follow them verbatim. They are all in English, French, and Spanish.To summarize, I believe I can improve my overall muscle performance using this muscle conditioner with EMS technology. This technology stimulates the nerves surrounding the muscles by gently and effectively contracting and relaxing them. By doing so, it increases blood flow and reduces lactic acid to improve and to promote muscle recovery and rejuvenation. I feel I have my personal massage therapist anytime, anywhere, thus the 5 stars with absolutely no hesitations.

Not the Mexican kitchen, but the world class kitchen. This is a 3 stainless tool set with silicone heads. The heads are heat resistant up to 520 F, and they are safe for non-stick cookware and bakeware. This set is endorsed by award-winning chef Rick Bayless, whom you surely know because he is on TV a lot. The picture does justice to these tools, which we love and highly recommend.

This is a 72x72 100% polyester shower curtain with a very classy but bold and at the same time elegant design. The picture does justice to the item. Observe how the purple colors are faded at the top, and bolder at the bottom, which is exactly how it looks. It feels like the effect of rain on the ground, lighter above, heavier below.This is machine washable (cold water) and also you can toss it in the dryer and iron if needed. We are happy with this curtain, and thus recommend it with no reservations.

Excel·lent novel·la de Pep Coll que narra uns crims ocorreguts el 1943 a Carreu (Pallars Jussà). En la trama recorda "In Cold Blood" de Capote, però evidentment l'estructura narrativa i epecialment l'ús magistral de la llengua és genuí Pep Coll, en la que és segurament la seva millor novel·la. Tot i que el lector mínimanent informat ja sap com acaba la història (amb la descripció detallada dels crims), el narrador és capaç de mantenir el lector en vil fins al final.La novel·la aconsegueix no només de narrar uns crims, sinó de presentar el context de la guerra civil i postguerra en una manera altament suggerent, que fan de la lectura d'aquesta novel·la de Pep Coll un veritable plaer i que recomano a tothom.p.s. Els catalans que vivim a l'estranger agraïm molt la publicció d'aquestes obres de la literatura catalana en format kindle. Dono gràcies a l'editor i els animo a continuar publicant més!

Usually, I give a rating of fewer than four stars for incompetent writing, simple inability to put words on the page. Karen McQuestion's book is getting three stars for a more complex reason.Books planned to be the first in a series create a terrible problem for the writer. Every book needs a strong ending, series or not, but with a series the writer can't resolve all the issues that have created the plot in the first novel.I could see that McQuestion was hitting the necessary plot milestones, and became really curious to see how she would resolve the problems placed in front of the likeable protagonist: moreso as we got to the point where the chase scene ought to be, and there was no identifiable chase scene.That was because this book ended with a cliffhanger to buy the next in the series, a common marketing strategy among self-publishers. However, because she used it, I don't know whether McQuestion can, in fact, manage the powerful ending which every book needs.Also, reading the sample attached to the end of this book, I realized that the next book in the series asks me to invest emotionally in a totally different character, one marginal within the first story.Between that and the possibility that McQuestion cannot, in fact, write a strong ending, I'm not willing to buy any more books in the series, and I probably won't buy anything else of hers unless reviews indicate that the item is a stand-alone. Too bad; McQuestion's characters are well-rounded, interesting people, and she herself a pretty good wordsmith.Lesson for self-publishers: EVERY book in a series needs to stand on its own.

I really don't understand the high ratings this novel has gathered. It's a mess.I gave it a yank because the sample read well. The writing style, however, swiftly showed up the author's shortcomings.The writing is single-paced, if frenetic, the characters a collection of cardboard tics, the plot overly simple for the weight it is asked to bear. The "hero" is someone who does not earn that standing, just a schlub with a gift. The romantic subplot is a fourteen-year-old's vision of love. To top it all off, there are several errors throughout the book, including a large chunk of formatting code left in, and a few sentences are incomprehensible. The overall flavor is rushed and slipshod, and it's really too bad I couldn't rate the plot that way.Because he can't be bothered to catch his own careless errors (how hard is it these days to run a grammar check?), I won't be trying any of Barnes' other work.

We needed sealed containers for my son's work lunches. The Rubbermaid jobs we started with weren't lasting well, and have proven tempery over time: their lid gaskets remove, and become more and more inelastic, therefore more difficult to re-insert properly even when washed by hand. They also have a vent covered by a little detachable plastic thingy that has a tendency to follow the missing socks wherever they get off to. The gasket itself is partially responsible for keeping the lid in place.These, on the other hand, have two pieces: a heavy glass dish and a sturdy lid with an attached gasket. The lid literally clamps to the bottom, so the gasket is asked only to seal the container. Muuuuch better.How much do we like them? We have two, and will invest in another three.

I am very fond of the work done by Dorothy Sayers and Jill Paton Walsh. JPW completed Sayers' unfinished Lord Peter Wimsey novel, "Thrones, Dominations," to general huzzahs: well-deserved, in my opinion. Then she got permission from the Sayers estate to write three more, all original works using Sayers' characters, of which this is the first.When these books first swam into my ken, I was greatly suspicious. How could these books be any good? Sayers is a very tough act to follow, let alone share a stage with. But I find JPW more than adequate to this daunting task. Like Sayers a graduate of Cambridge, she absorbed Sayers' work in her own early teens, which seem to be the formative years for writers. So the pairing is not as disparate as one might fear.I find this novel the most satisfying of JPW's Wimsey-Vane continuations so far. The plot is just as complex, and the characters equally so: this is not true only of Harriet Vane and Peter Wimsey, offstage through most of the novel, but of the minor characters as well. JPW's hand with them seems surer than did Sayers', who must not have liked many people very much. She had something tart to say about everyone, at least in her novels. JPW, being of a later generation, does not use the racial perjoratives that Sayers threw around so freely, but also, she is a kinder writer in general than Sayers. Kinder to her minor characters by streets, which makes for some very satisfying reading.The situation in "Presumption" is fraught, as the Battle of Britain is being fought as the book opens. This may be the major reason that I find this book better than the rest of the Wimsey-Vane catalog; Paton-Walsh can likely remember at least the latter part of the war. The details she brings to this book ring true for having lived them.The plot revolves upon the fog of war. More than that I won't say; reviews are not a place to spout spoilers. If you are a fan of inter-war British mysteries, you will very much like this outlier, which of course happens just a little too late to be included in that genre. Read the Kindle sample and see if it cranks your scooter. It's that good all the way through.

These are low-quality stories by authors you probably haven't heard of. Trite, most of them; I couldn't finish a single story. Some had plot twists, but most were stale takes on overused tropes. If they weren't, they didn't do anything fresh and exciting for the first 40% of every novel.If I were trapped in bed with a nasty illness for a month, I'd read the whole book, but not until I'd practically memorized everything else on my Kindle.

Late-middle age me does not seem as fond of Roger Zelazny's work as teenage me was; however, this book was written with Jane Lindskold. Zelazny was, and remains, an excellent writer in my eyes, though I'd recommend both "The Doors of His Face, the Lamps of His Mouth," a short-story collection, and the novel "A Night in the Lonesome October" over this (and "The Dead Man's Brother," a wacko murder mystery which proves conclusively that Zelazny could write anything but juvenile lit - that genre didn't work for him).His plots are satisfyingly complex. Science-fiction characters are usually not as well-developed as Lindskold's and Zelazny's are here, but they still could not be called "complex." This was also written in first person, which is kinda variable with Roger: either laugh-out-loud funny, or too fast and not deep enough. This book is light on the former, though it doesn't go too far in the latter direction.Zelazny obviously developed as a writer over the years, and this book, the culmination of his writing career, is much better than most of the Amber series for which he is best-known.

Haven't tried parking my hefty posterior on the two I bought, so I don't know how they'd fare as actual seating. They're wonderful for storage: the inside is well-finished, so they can hold even fragile snag-prone items like afghans, though I haven't used them for clothing storage. If I feel the need for a third, I'll certainly buy another.

Functions pretty well for what it is, though its USB adapter needed an adapter. I was fortunate in that my tablet, a Dragon 7, came with such.Docked three stars for deceptive advertising: this is not made of leather. Somewhere, Chinese suppliers have picked up the idea that "leather" can mean "came from cows" or "came from a vat of polyurethane." And at this price point, really, leather would be an exceptional find.Still, the copy for the item specifies "leather" not once but three times, as well as in the item title. Nowhere in any of the copy is the word "polyurethane," or its initials (unfortunately, they are "PU") to be found. I actually tested this object with a little bit of mink oil, a leather waterprooofer which leather drinks thirstily. On the back of the "prop," it spread far too well, not absorbing at all: polyurethane.Amazon's been notified of this, so if it's corrected I'll come back to revise this review. If not, be warned!

I really like the look of these, and hope they last a long time. My first RFID shield had recently given up the ghost, and I wasn't sure that taping it back together constituted protection. I was very glad to find these little beauties.

Jill Patton Walsh has pulled off the near-impossible - taken another author's work and made it her own, and arguably better. That the author in question is Dorothy Sayers makes her accomplishment all the more noteworthy; Sayers' trust has given their blessing to four such books.I've been a Sayers fan for a while. Like most of us, I hope, I was somewhat offended by her free use of the then-current derogatory names for persons not British and not upper-class. Walsh does not use those terms, and indeed my only criticism of her four Wimsey/Vane novels is that the characters have become a little too modern in their outlook. Such people did and always have existed, but Sayers gave no hint that Wimsey was one such. Still, that's a very small quibble.This book is roughly of the same quality as Sayer's own "Five Red Herrings" or Walsh's "The Attenbury Emeralds." That is, for my taste the plot is overly complex. The two stars of the Sayer-Walsh collaboration, "Thrones, Dominations" and "A Presumption of Death," are both equally complex, but somehow I find myself returning to those two. This one and "Emeralds" are one-off reads, though I imagine that with some time passing between reads, both would again become enjoyable.The difference may be that the characters in both "Thrones" and "Presumption" are better-realized, or perhaps simply more likeable. But if you are thinking of diving into the Sayers-Walsh partnership, begin with "Thrones," by all means. And don't feel shy about this book, either. I vastly enjoyed it, and as you see I gave it five stars. But in my opinion "Thrones" and "Presumption" both deserve six.
This stuff works like a dream and is cheaper than my previous choices for essential-oil air fresheners. Takes care of everything - cat and human litter boxes, cooking fish - except cigarette smoke.
I read "The Flying Fifty-Five" with some enjoyment, but with this book, it became very clear that Wallace was a hack.
I used this in a non-typical manner: bought two three-packet units, and used all of them at once in a dye bath for one cotton and one linen item of clothing. I wasn't displeased with the outcome.
The clip on these is very weak. They may work on hair with a great deal of texture, curly or wiry, but on my straight, thick hair, they slide right out. Not recommended at all for that reason.

Four stars instead of five because I don't believe this bra will last very long. It is, however, extremely comfortable, and I say that as someone who hates, loathes, despises, and detests brassieres.The 2x fit my 46C self perfectly.I have taken the precaution of handwashing these bras, and whatever choice you make in that department, I certainly would not recommend you toss them in the dryer; they will rapidly lose all their stretch, which is what does the support work.I don't believe the bra will last long because of the snap fastening. No matter how gently you unsnap it, this closure strains the fabric it is attached to. However, this bra has sufficient stiffening and extra fabric in the closure that I could be mistaken about that. I'd really be happy if I were.

Three caps a night, the recommended dose, gets me a full night's sleep, something I'd fall a few hours short of without it. As with most herbs, no side effects of any kind. I don't feel groggy or dehydrated in the morning; the latter is my usual reaction to pharmaceutical sleep aids.Some cats will react to valerian as if it were catnip. This might be either a second use or a nuisance, depending.
A lot of crap and a George R.R. Martin story appended at the end. That the average writing quality is "poor" with Martin present tells you how bad some of the rest of it is.

Books written before the late 1960s have some disadvantages today. Their language is very stilted to modern ears (though this example suffers much less than many from pompousness), and slang has of course moved on. Don't get me started on sexual mores: this was a time when women were not expected so much as DEMANDED to delay loss of their virginity until their wedding night.Which, as you may well be thinking, is not a review of this book at all. I'd agree with you, but these are the social mores it does not contravene. Potential lovers remain potential until the knot is tied. They don't neck, tease, or even talk about the possibilities. Period. The fact that the Bad Guy propositions the Good Girl to be his mistress doesn't even rank as "sexual content" today, but it would have been extremely shocking in 1922, when the book was published.This is very likely the first romantic suspense novel, beating out Mary Stewart by a good twenty years. Not that much suspense attends it; everyone except the female lead can see the happy ending coming eight furlongs (a mile) off. It is set in the pre-war world of British horse-racing, and readers of Dick Francis may recognize something here which Francis later used in his own work.It's nowhere near as horsey as Francis, however. And it's clear to everyone except the utterly clueless female lead what's going on. Edgar Wallace was thought of as a thriller writer while a working writer, and was immensely popular - the Lee Child of his day.Your reaction to it may depend on your reaction to all the above. Try out Wallace's "The Green Rust," which is free on Kindle, and see what you think of his work. If you like it, try this.

Zelazny was a genius, and I'd read a cookbook if he wrote it. I wasn't disappointed in this, as it has a Zelazny plot, and his POV character's voice is just as much fun as John D. McDonald's Travis McGee.Zelazny was, of course, most widely known for his science fiction. It's a pity he didn't write more mysteries...very unlikely you'll be disappointed by this, if you like McDonald or Lee Child. This is not for those who prefer cozies, however.

Purchased off-site at bcoutlet daught calm (take out the spaces) for half what was listed here, though that's since been addressed. If you are planning a purchase, I suggest you check out the prices at that site first. Shipping there goes up with total price paid.Fabric content is linen-rayon, the two most wrinkly fabrics in the universe. Might you still want this? Yes. I have two, and am planning the purchase of a third; I soak-cleaned 'em flat in cold water and let them drip dry on a hanger, then ironed them. I wear them mostly for running errands, and they are perfect for that; I get to look (and feel!) like I'm neat and tidy in this jacket, T-shirt, and a pair of jeans, although I'm just slobbing around. I get multiple wears per ironing, because I'm not in them long.They aren't lined - the seams are bound. There are some details of construction that lead me to believe that they were made for a higher-end retailer; those seams, for one thing, and the button attachments, which are thread shanks. That said, I've had to re-anchor the buttons on one of them.These are nice, unconstructed, loose-fitting jackets, of sturdy fabric. You could do a lot worse for a summer coat, and being of two natural fabrics, they take most dyes well...which is why I have two of them.If you choose to be thought artsy, this is a perfect jacket to adorn with carefully-placed blobs of acrylic, so that you look as if you are always just about to rush off to your studio and paint. I stamped one of mine with paisley designs down the front (so that people think I'm always about to commit paisley). The plain colors are a wonderful blank slate for one's creativity.These brands, Jessica London, Woman Within, Roamans, and Bargain Catalog Outlet, all size their clothing TWO SIZES LARGER than most brands, as they cater to a plus-sized audience. Just so you know, if you normally wear a 20 you'll want this in a 16, and so forth.

I'm a fan of paisley, but didn't want to wear it all over, so to speak. I'm stamping my shirt cuffs with this in a very lightly-inked color, and I've been pleased with the result. The designs include three classical paisleys and six less-common interpretations, and the package includes the block you need to stamp with. It's all been made easy.This is my first time stamping. The absence of a fifth star indicates only my own lack of experience with similar products

I live in an apartment complex which is best described as "downtrodden." The idiot owner has skipped maintenance for years. Not until I got this surge protector did I understand that the outlet into which my computer was plugged was so worn that the grounding prong could not make contact. So I received an unexpected benefit with this Belkin product.I chose this product because it offered the highest resistance (a surge protector's job) within the $50-and-under price range.It's worked perfectly, and I anticipate no problems with it. I've been very pleased with other Belkin products, and expect long service from this unit.

We have to buy these about once every two years. They last very well, considering that every pair gets to take a lengthy bike ride with each wearing.They wash well, and do not fade. They don't get ironed, but I've heard no complaints about that, and my son tells me that they are "invisible" underwear: you put them on and forget they're there. He is tall and thin, so if you are built differently YMMV.

Tasted okay, but I would have liked a more intense flavor. Didn't meet my needs for reasons which have nothing to do with the product itself. If you like carbonation but want to stay away from the artifical ingredients of sodas, this may be for you, though be warned that if you are diabetic it is fairly high in carbs.

Excellent for fridge storage, and for lugging lunch to work on a bike. I'll be buying more, and I'm one of these people who expects her kitchen stuff to last a LONG time. These are doing much better than Pyrex sealable containers for wear, and they are much less likely to come open in a backpack because of their design. I'll be buying more. (Wups, I said that. I must really mean it.)

Very poorly proofread. The book was at one point obviously in first-person, but not all the pronouns were changed.So far as I am concerned, this novel has a terrible flaw in the writing: EVERY adult male the female narrator must deal with is presented as a possible sex parther, including the ones who, if they knew her history, would not give her the time of day. It's not merely unconvincing, it means that all these characters, including the narrator herself, are cardboad.Also, the central character is not presented as a very admirable person, though she lacks sufficient spine to be an anti-heroine.What passes for "romance" in this book is the usual obsessive wibbling. If that's your thing, enjoy, but I suspect the deficiencies of characterization will not please those readers either.

Dorothy Sayers' growth as a novelist throughout her career is made very clear in this first of the Peter Wimsey novels. It's far from bad, but not to the standard of her later works. Wimsey was never again such an ass as he is here in the scene of his first meeting with the abominable Grimethorpe.This particular cheap version may be one to avoid. The publishers had so little pride in their work that throughout the volume, you will find short [garbled] and [missing] sections, noted in precisely that fashion. Why the publishers accepted this, I don't understand; other versions of her work are widely available, and could have been used to correct the errors. Very slipshod.

The love story here is obtrusive into some very solid science and intricate plotting. The characters are so juvenile in their outlook that I stopped reading co-author Randy Ingermanson's writing blog because of it.I simply don't find it believable that persons with sufficient smarts to acquire a PhD would have remained at the level of the eighth grade in their emotional development.

I've noticed that in many really good sci-fi stories and novels, the hero's "reward" is love. Here, unfortunately, the love affair is right up front, again, as it was in "The Fifth Man."Why unfortunate? Because the authors have chosen to give their main POV character both a PhD and 13-year-old's emotional level of development. I found the character - whose name I cannot even remember, which tells you something - annoying in the extreme. So is her love interest. Neither one has the guts to speak out to the other. I made it through "Fifth Man," but a second dose was too much.The solid science behind some intricate plotting wasn't enough to compensate.

There is so much disappointing crap on Kindle that when I do find a gem, I tend to stand tall and shout about it. It says a great deal about this book that the "Most Helpful Critical Review" has three stars!I choose a book almost entirely for the author's voice, and Amy Bai's here is strong, assured, and virtuousic. She knows exactly what to leave out, which many don't - can't tell you the number of books I've booted off my Kindle because the author started off well but got busy attending to silly crap right at the end of the sample."Sword" is free of silly crap. This is a story where the stakes are raised wrenchingly high again, and again, and again. Lives are stake, a crown is at stake, and not one but three sanities are at stake. One is almost lost; I can see this book appealing to adolescents because that's exactly how I remember puberty.I had no problem with the multiple POVs - they are all in third person, and each one of those persons is worth investing in. The titular character has the roughest ride through the book, but all three childhood friends are faced with monumental problems.Someone who opts for this book is in for a great read. "Sword" is not only adventuresome, but very wise.
Didn't notice any particular difference with these in addressing depression.

The dose of vitamin C that comes in these is 417% of the RDA. That's enough to give a person the squits. I've had to stop taking all three at once for this reason, and since I can't take any vitamin B6 (1255% RDA) with a necessary med I have to have three times a day, that means I have six pill times daily to get through until I get rid of these.Edit one week after taking three a day at separate times: this solution is not working for me, so the vitamins are unusable. Docked a star for that.
They do the job, but the smell that rolls out of the bottle is far from appetizing. Also, they're only that sort-of fruit flavor that's got a definite under-taste of medicine.

Disclaimer: I am a member a writing group to which the author belongs, and critiqued this book in its early stages. I loved it then, and I love it now.M. L. John's sure hand with the story, a companion to "Lady of the Veils," shows in her tale of Beri Quintiniar's slow trek toward the throne he didn't expect to inherit. The characters and action are as well-drawn as they are in "Lady of the Veils," which tells a matching half of the story. I could smell the rain of the forest which won't allow you to settle where it doesn't want you, and I grieved the deaths of characters who had been made real to me. That's true again here, though the body count is lower. To make up for it, however, the dialog and narrative of the Summer Court's treachery sparkles and flashes.You don't need to have read "Lady of the Veils" to get this. I hadn't, when I critiqued it. But you'll want to after reading this. And if you read that and wonder what this one's like? Just as engrossing, but in an entirely different way. Don't miss it. Solidly worth your hard-earned.

Disclaimer: I was given a copy of this book by the author in thanks for proofing of her other book. (Don't miss that one, either.)When I opened this book, I divided the number of pages by four, thinking I could read ninety pages a night (yes, I am a pretty fast reader) and be disciplined about the whole thing. First night, no problem, though it was so engrossing I went over by a few pages. The next night I read HALF THE BOOK before I knew it. I got up this morning and read the rest.Depending on the number and kind of demands in your own life, it's pretty likely you'll find yourself doing the same. M. L. John's compelling tale of one Karen McGregor, ordinary kid, wanders through strange worlds, in which she meets all-too-human allies. Well, human: most are half-human, and a few are not human at all. The vampire, for instance, who becomes her playmate; the High King of Faerie, with whom she has been in love since she was a very small child.As rich in mythology as this tale is, it is also engrossingly human. In a war, there is loss, and John's Karen faces it squarely.This tale is not one of those deeply flawed self-pubbed files that may engross you until you get past page fifty. This one is solidly well-crafted all the way through, and you will not be disappointed if you sink your hard-earned into it.

I like this little apparatus very much. It really makes getting carpet cleaner into your carpets easy.Docked two stars, though, because it accepts only one kind of one brand of carpet cleaner, which is becoming hard to find.
Does the job, but the cans don't seem to last very long.
They were easy to install, and keep my USB and camera cables within easy reach. Like 'em a lot, will buy more if needed.
It works, it's purty, and it's not expensive to replace. Win, win, win.

I liked these books at first, but the writing voice got old for me pretty quickly. As well, I began to think that the author had no real idea how to plot, so I stopped reading. I don't know if I'll go back to read smaller bits or not, but big bites of this book were indigestible.

I'm struggling with this rating (a little, but not really), so I'll put my thought process out there for others to determine if the product is actually worth 4 or 5 stars. Here's why:  at the current price of over $30 for two 11.5 ounce bottles, it's just plain expensive. It's so expensive that you could probably convince people that being in possession of it would be a misdemeanor.So that skewed my perception. At first taste, I liked the flavor but I couldn't get the dollar signs out of my head. But the more I tried it (and in different scenarios), the more I fell in love with this sauce.  Now that I'm basically down to the last remnants of the first bottle, I'm hoarding away that second bottle like Golem in the dark recesses of the back of the kitchen pantry, hoping that my wife won't find it and start slopping it all over everything as if it's going to last forever... my preciousssss....Oh yeah. Back to it. This stuff is pretty great. I'm not one of those people that can pick out all of the separate ingredients of a sauce, but it definitely has a distinct Korean flavor, whatever that means. It starts out with a mild sweetness which slowly progresses into a pretty solid burn that lingers for quite a while. It's somehow not a "punch-in-the-face" sort of heat that you get from some hot sauce.  It's slow, simmering, and it builds in intensity over time.We've used the sauce for a few different things, including as part of a marinade with a soy sauce base, as part of a dipping sauce for hors d'oeuvres mixed with a yogurt-based ranch dressing, and mixed up with a light mayo for use on roast beef sandwiches. The transformation is incredible, even small amounts make a huge difference.I have to say, I think this is now one of my favorite sauces of all time.  People in other reviews have said that this can easily be made at home for much cheaper; I'm going to try my best.  But if I can't get it right (it's likely I won't), then I'm definitely okay with spending the money to have continued access to this sauce.  And THAT is why I couldn't take off a star for the high price -- because I would pay that much to have more of it.

I don't need anything more than this chainsaw provides.  It's perfect for around the yard, clearing out excess bamboo and felling larger tree branches that are bringing too much shade to the yard in certain areas.While the instructions were a bit vague at times, it was pretty simple to put the chainsaw together and get it working. I haven't yet had the experience that others had with the chain falling off frequently, but I'll keep an eye on it as I finish some of the other tasks that I have planned. If it happens, I'll update the review.Overall, it does the job. It's not too heavy. It seems plenty powerful for my purposes. It's built to pretty tight tolerances, no flexing or creaking or anything. At this point, I have no complaints.

I'm not going to get much into the marketing terminology, parroting the wording from B+W's website about the type of glass they use or the number of coatings they apply.  I only care about whether the product works, how well it works, and if it's worth the money. So let's get into that.To be clear right off the bat, I don't think the increased exposure hits a full stop as is implied by B+W.  At least, not compared to the other two circular polarizers I tested it against.  However, it is better. I tested against two other circular polarizers: The B+W MRC Circular Polarizer and the Promaster Circular Polarizer. At the current prices as of this review, the standard B+W is $10 cheaper than the Kaesemann model, and the Promaster is half the price.THE B+W's have the nicest mounts. While there's nothing wrong with the Promaster mount, the B+W's just feel better. They screw on smoothly and the front ring rotates with a nice damped feel.I did two tests to compare the light transmission. One was indoors in a consistently lit room, and the other was outdoors on a sunny day.  Both tests utilized the same incident light meter, which remained stationary throughout the tests.  A base reading (with no filter) was taken just before each filter test to ensure that the light had not changed between tests. The results were pretty consistent. The following is the number of stops that the polarizer increases the exposure in each test:Promaster CPOL: +1.9 stops (inside test), +2.0 stops (outside test)B+W (standard) CPOL: +1.6 stops (inside test), +1.7 stops (outside test)B+W Kaesemann CPOL: +1.3 stops (inside test), +1.2 stops (outside test)The B+W Kaesemann obviously had the best light transmission of the three, but the difference never quite reached that full stop compared to the Promaster (the actual difference was 0.6 to 0.8 stops), and it only reached 0.3 to 0.5 stops compared to the "standard" B+W.  I suppose that's close enough for most purposes, and it's enough to make a difference when you're losing light and you want to keep shooting.I also want to do some side-by-side tests for color accuracy and overall performance. However, the weather has not been cooperating for the last few days.  When I complete these tests, I'll put the results here and link to the images.

As far as my (admittedly untrained) ear can tell, the KA-SEM sounds exactly like the far cheaper Kala KA-15S that I was able to compare it with.  My neighbor has the KA-15S, and after switching them back and forth a bit, we came to the conclusion that the KA-SEM's improvements over the KA-15S are purely aesthetic.Does that mean it's 100% true?  No, of course not.  Neither of us are musicians.  Just learning the instrument for fun.However, those aesthetic differences are pretty significant.  The KA-SEM is beautiful, but a bit different than what you see in the product description. It looks much more like the picture on the Kala website (click the Products menu, select Kala Ukulele, then click on the link for "Exotic Mahogany Series), and I've added my own photos as well for reference.  The wood is a little darker, and the binding has a stripe down the middle of the back. The tuning pegs are sort of a pearlescent white, not black as in the product description.The finish seems a little nicer than the satin finish on the KA-15S, although the Kala website calls this "satin" as well.  It has a nice sheen on it that just slightly reflects light, while still allowing you to feel the wood grain on the surface.  It's really nice.  The black binding adds a nice touch around the edges, and the frets are nickel (on the KA-15S, they are brass).Both models come with the same Aquila Nylagut strings, which suit me just fine. As far as whether or not the KA-SEM is worth the extra money, that really depends on what you're looking for.  If you don't care about aesthetics at all, I'd say definitely get the KA-15S.  But if you want it to look as nice as it sounds, spend the extra on the KA-SEM.PS: I actually bought this great little ukulele from a different listing which includes a soft case for only an extra $2, with free (but not Prime) shipping.  Considering that the case included in that listing normally sells on Amazon for about $25, it's a pretty good buy.

If you're used to the slim cases (like one of my previous cases, a Spigen Hard Case) that provide minimal shock protection in exchange for a case that hardly increases the phone size at all, then this case will feel bulky until you get used to it.  On the other hand, if you're coming from a more protective case like the Speck Mightyshell, this feels about the same in terms of overall size.I feel like in most comparisons, this case would sit right in between those other two.  The Spigen was small, but a dirt magnet. No dirt ever got into the Speck and it was a real powerhouse from a protection point of view, but once you put it on it was nearly impossible to remove.  This OtterBox case is about the same size as the Speck, but provides not-quite-as-good protection.  And it's $15 cheaper, and it's way easier to remove.The major difference in the protection stems from the fact that the Speck case has an opaque soft interior for the back of the phone as well as the edges. For most people I doubt that this is really meaningful.The one down side that I've seen so far is the edges. Where the beveled face protection part of the case meets the sides is a pretty harsh transition, not soft and rounded like the Speck.  So gripping it is a little less comfortable.  But that's not a big deal, honestly.

I struggled with the decision for a while. This is my first ukulele, and I knew full well going in that I was probably never going to be considered a good ukulele player. I just wanted something to strum on and have fun learning without any pressure to excel.There are so many ukuleles out there, I had no idea where to start.  I didn't want a piece of crap, but I didn't want to spend a lot of money on it either.  I landed on the KA-SEM, and although it was a little more than I wanted to spend (considering the KA-15S is significantly cheaper even when it comes in the kit with the tuner and other goodies, and I'd have to buy the tuner myself), I pulled the trigger.So far, I'm incredibly happy with the purchase.  The build quality is really nice, and the wood grain is beautiful to look at.  The satin finish has a sheen about it that looks great, and the black binding really ties it together. It's loud when you want it to be, and soft when you want it to be. The strings included are Aquila Nylagut. At the start, I needed to tune the strings every time I played, but after a few days they stayed in tune.  Apparently you can stretch them to speed up the process, but I didn't bother; I didn't mind tuning them while they were breaking in.I was surprised at the quality of the case that's included with it for this listing (at the time of this review, you can get the KA-SEM without a case for only about $2 cheaper, which seems like a terrible idea). It's thickly padded, inspiring confidence in its ability to protect the instrument. For reference, the bag is the Kaces KUKS-3 model, which is about $25 on its own (mine has a slightly different patch design on the front, but the case manufacturer and model number is the same).So is it worth the money over the KA-15S? Well, that depends on what you're looking for.  The frets on the KA-SEM are nickel, while the KA-15S frets are brass. The KA-SEM overall looks way better than the KA-15S.  But they sound exactly the same to me, and they come with the same strings.  I brought mine over to a friend's house (he has a KA-15S) and we couldn't tell any difference in sound.  So purely from a price/performance standpoint, the KA-15S looks to be a better buy.  To me, it was worth that little extra money because aesthetically the KA-SEM is much nicer.

I bought this tuner for my ukulele. I like having the modes that are specific to each instrument, so it displays the note and the string number that you're plucking.  Then there's the chromatic mode, which will tell you what note you're playing, any string any fret.Of course, that just annoyed me by showing me how my uke gets slightly more out of tune the farther I move up the fret. But I digress.In "Clip" mode, where the tuner reads the vibration through the clip to determine the frequency, you don't need to worry about the possibility of ambient noise messing up the reading. "Mic" mode uses a microphone instead.  I think the Mic mode is primarily for the tuning of brass and woodwind instruments, although it can also be used for strings if you don't want the tuner clipped to the instrument.Dialing in the correct frequency is pretty simple, just keep plucking and adjusting while you watch the meter on the display.  When it hits the green center mark, the string is in tune. It can sometimes be difficult to get exactly in the center, but (at least to my ears) I can't hear the difference between dead on and one mark to the left or right.There are two things that annoy me a little.  First and foremost, this thing has the feel of a toy that came in a Cracker Jack box.  The clip and neck are okay, but the buttons feel extremely cheap. I'm concerned about its longevity because of this. Secondly (and this is much more minor) the display bleeds a lot into neighboring segments.  You can see the difference in my photos, where every segment in the display is easily visible even when it's not actively being lit.  It makes it a little less readable. But as I said, that's more of a minor annoyance.

There are some strange design decisions here (at least, strange to me), but overall this is a worthy system.The look of the unit is minimalist and clean, obviously the intended effect since it has no buttons -- only a display and a CD slot. There's a sensor on the top of the unit directly above the display so that when you touch it, it acts as a power switch.  When powering on, it resumes the last action. So if you're listening to a specific Pandora station for example, it will go back to that station and start playing.The sound is definitely impressive, more so than the various iPod docks and Bluetooth speakers that I've had over the years. It can sometimes get a little bogged down in the low end though, mainly at lower volumes. And there is no way that I've found to adjust the EQ to suit my tastes.  In fact, the user manual suggests listening to the demo CD at "80-85 volume" for best results.  But what if I don't want to listen to it that loud?  I'd say most of the time I listen at around 50-60.The phone app is pretty full-featured (I'm using it on the iPhone 6) and not very difficult to use.  You have access to various streaming services, CD, radio, any NAS drives that you might have on the network, and any computer on the network where you've installed the app to point to your music collection.I like the idea of being able to sync the music to play out of several systems simultaneously.  In the past, I've used this feature in iTunes to play the computer speakers in one room and the entertainment center speakers in the living room through the AppleTV, and it's great.  Of course, in this case I can't test it because it requires multiple SoundTouch units... and I'm not made of money, so I doubt that will be happening any time soon.Any wireless connectivity requires the lower dock piece. The setup for that is pretty easy.  There's a light on the back of it that changes color depending on the current connection status. On the back is an ethernet port, as well as a USB and micro USB port (both labeled "Setup").  These ports will charge any devices plugged into them, but even the manual is tight-lipped about what actual function they serve, if any. The manual claims that you can use the micro USB for "network setup using a computer" (but says nothing beyond that), and actually states that the USB port currently has no purpose.I have to admit, I'm curious as to why the wireless connectivity had to be added as a (quite large) separate component. The base piece increases the height by a good two inches, and there's a wired connection between the two in the back using some proprietary connector.  Couldn't the connection be built into the top of the base, so that the act of placing the system on the dock establishes a connection?  Or more importantly, why isn't this functionality built into the main unit? Why does it need to be a separate dock? That makes no sense to me. And why not allow the USB ports act as a way to plug in an iPod or other music device?Finally, there's the (admittedly minor) matter of the display.  Aren't we, as a society, now beyond the old 12-segment LCD display? Especially at the $600 price point.  I've got a streaming music box for my component system with a full-color display that shows all of the information I need, plus album art.  iPods have had full color screens for a decade. If you catch it at the very beginning of a song, at least you'll see the full song name scroll by if it's longer than 14 characters.  After that first scroll through, it stops and just cuts it off to the first 14 characters.So yeah, it's a good unit. Sounds great most of the time.  Some design decisions have me scratching my head, but overall I'm happy with it.

This cable seems to be the equal of the Apple branded cable in just about every way, except it's longer (great!) and the rim around the lightning connector is ever so slightly thicker than the Apple variety.  That may be not-so-great if your case has an extremely small opening for the charge port.  However, with the three cases that I have, this cable works fine.  It also works fine for my wife's case.In fact, it may work with every case in existence, I just don't know. But that plastic bit IS just a tiny bit thicker.

There is clearly some misunderstanding out there about what you're getting.  Have you ever had a drink like Perrier? It's like that.  First and foremost, it's a sparkling water. Think club soda. There is a small amount of flavor added to it, but it's very subtle. If you don't like Perrier (or if you prefer your water heavily flavored), you should pass on this because it almost definitely won't suit your tastes.You shouldn't rate a drink poorly because you don't understand what you ordered, or because you wanted it to be a different type of drink altogether. It's like buying coffee and then rating it poorly because it doesn't taste like tea.  On the other hand, for those that ordered from Amazon I can see the misunderstanding -- multiple uses in the product description of the term "bold flavor" are somewhat misleading.As a fan of citrusy flavors, the Mandarin Lime is easily my favorite of the three, but I like them all. The glass bottles were well packaged and arrived safely. I have no complaints whatsoever.  If the manufacturer were to consider revisiting the product description to ensure the correct expectations, I imagine the overall product rating would improve.

I don't know why I waited this long to find a legitimate meat slicer.  I've been using the wrong tool for the job for a long time (although admittedly, I didn't know that until I got this knife).  Smoked brisket slices would be necessarily thick to avoid tearing, as well as uneven and a bit awkward because the blade wasn't long enough to cut through in one slice. Buckboard bacon would be a similarly difficult, coming out more often like a thick ham slice than bacon, or maybe thicker on one end than the other. American-style (pork belly) bacon was even more difficult.Then I decided to look up meat slicing knives, and this one won me over due to the overwhelmingly positive reviews and the reasonable price. The day it arrived, my latest batch of bacon had finished curing and was in the smoker, so the timing was perfect. I'm attaching a photo (which I hope isn't removed because I forgot to put the knife in the picture) that shows how well the knife slices, even considering my questionable knife skills and the fact that this was my first time ever using it.I've since used it on those really thin chicken breasts that come in the 10-lb food service bags at big box stores, cutting them into clean slices along their thinnest dimension for jerky. I can't wait to pull another brisket off the smoker and get cutting!

The majority of my trips (business or pleasure) are for 5 days or less, and if flying, are within the US or Canada. And yet all I have is a small, inexpensive duffle bag and a backpack or camera bag, depending on the purpose of the trip. If I can't make my stuff fit, I have to resort to a checked bag. This is quite the carry-on upgrade for me.Without going into incredibly boring detail about every little thing, I'll stick to the most important stuff, as I see them.  Structurally, it's a very sturdy bag, orders of magnitude better than the cheap luggage I had previously bought from places like Target.  The fabric is designed to take a real beating without showing it, the zippers are heavy duty, the wheels and external structural detail look like they're going to last forever, and the internal components are far better than that flimsy plastic lining in cheap luggage that can flex or crack over time.It's a well-thought-out bag too, with an incorporated garment bag in the lid, big enough for a suit, or several dress shirts. In addition to the other standard interior and exterior pockets, it includes a mesh pocket on the outside that can be rolled up and zipped away into its own little pocket, useful for holding a jacket or other random bits while you're sitting in the airport. Then when it's time to board, roll it into its pocket so it doesn't get caught on anything as you're stuffing it into the bin.  There's even a long, narrow zippered pouch between the two rails of the extending handle on the back.  Although I'm not entirely sure what you'd put in there.The exterior bag dimensions are 21" x 14" x 8" (the wheels stick out a little, bringing overall depth to 9"), and if you zip out the extension, it will allow the depth to grow to 12". This puts it within the carry-on size restrictions of most airlines (22" x 14" x 9") unless you have it extended.Now, it is expensive.  For very frequent travelers, I'd say it's certainly worth the money.  Otherwise it may not be.  Of course, you do have the lifetime warranty which guarantees that they'll repair any functional problems with the bag regardless of how it happened or how bad the damage is. That's great news.  But for an infrequent traveler, how often are you replacing cheap luggage due to damage?  Especially considering that this is, first and foremost, a carry-on bag that won't often experience the higher levels of abuse of a checked bag. It's something to keep in mind.

There's not a whole lot I can say about this drive, but I'll start with this:  I've been using it for about a month and haven't yet had any failures as mentioned in some of the top reviews for the product.  Looking at the dates, those reviews are all several years old.  Could it be that the design has improved since then? Hard to say.I like the aluminum case on it, it has been operating without issue, and it's pretty cheap.  As with any review I post, if something changes I'll update the review to account for that, but here's one last thing to consider:  At the time of this review, you can get a 32GB USB drive like the HP x702w for one dollar more than this drive, and it supports USB 3.0.  Even if you're not currently using it on USB 3.0-capable devices, it's backward compatible to USB 2.0, so why not just spend the extra dollar and get that one instead? Then if you ever do decide to use it on a USB 3.0 device, you're good to go.

For the price, you really can't go wrong here.  As long as you have a reasonably competent machine, you'll find this to be a pretty simple, full-featured video editor that works with you rather than struggling against you.Previously, I had been using an earlier version of this software (VideoStudio Pro X4) which I found to be crash-prone and frustrating.  I had to save my projects after every single change I made, because I knew that crash was coming any second and I had learned my lesson many times before.  This new version, in addition to streamlining the interface, improving the workflow, and adding some new options, I've found to be far more stable and responsive.  It did crash on me once in the middle of rendering a 4.5 minute long video, but I had left the application running for about 24 straight hours before starting the render.  When I brought it back up after the crash, it rendered the whole video just fine.There are a number of premade templates available for video openings, endings, middle bits, etc. as well as scores of transition effects and video effects, and a couple dozen different styles of text overlay. Functionality also exists for some things that I have no use for personally, such as stop-motion video [actually... see update].There are two other applications included in the package. FastFlicks lets you pick a template, and then dump a bunch of photos and videos on it, and it will automatically create a video for you. The ScreenCap application lets you record video of your desktop for presentations, etc.  I have not had a need for these yet though.== Update 4/18/2015 ==When I thought about the stop motion functionality, it reminded me of a New Year 2012 party I went to, where as part of the party's theme I had a small video camera attached to my hat, set to take still images once every three seconds for the entire night.  I completely forgot about it and never did anything with the 4500 images, so I found them on my computer and used the stop motion capability to put them together into a video.  For the most part, this functionality (which also includes the ability to capture straight from a webcam or other device, if desired) made it easier to put the images together into a video, setting the time per frame and other things.  The only thing I didn't care for was that this feature opens a smaller window over the main application window, which cannot be resized.  Then there's only a single row of images at the bottom that you have to scroll through so you can toss the ones you don't want.  When you're doing them 1000 at a time, this can be quite tedious.  Overall a pretty minor complaint, though, considering how little I plan on doing that.

The Weye Feye looks to be a solid competitor for wireless control of a dSLR through a phone or tablet. For reference, I shoot primarily with a Canon EOS 5D Mk III and use my iPhone 6 or 3rd generation iPad for remote shooting.  I also purchased a CamRanger Wireless Controller a couple of years ago, which is a direct competitor to the Weye Feye, and which I'll be using as a point of comparison throughout the review.  So if you're wondering if you should plunk down the extra cash on the CamRanger, hopefully I'll be able to help you decide. If you already know you're not in the market for the CamRanger, you can skip that part of the review and save yourself some time.Side note: This review is specific to the information I have available to me at the time of the review.  These devices are firmware upgradeable, and obviously the apps can also be updated with new features and functionality. I will try to update my review as new features are added and bugs are squashed, but right now my review is current as of 04/13/2015.== On Its Own ==Physically, the Weye Feye seems to be pretty well made.  The black plastic unit comes surrounded by a flexible orange case that serves as protection from drops and as a connection point for the velcro straps that allow you to mount the unit to a tripod leg. There's a small button on the front that serves as the power button, as well as a battery check button.  It's slightly difficult to find in the dark but that's not a big deal.There are two LEDs on the front, one showing the charge state (green/blue/orange/red to show an approximate battery level, flashing while charging), and the other showing power state. A micro USB port on the side is used for charging (a cable is included for this purpose) and a full-size USB port is on the end for connecting to your camera (cable not included).Setup is straightforward. After charging the device, turn it on and wait for the lights to settle to a solid green state. Your phone/tablet will see it as a Wi-Fi hotspot. Connect to it.  Then connect the Weye Feye to the camera (order is not important here; you can connect to the camera at any time) and turn the camera on.  The phone/tablet app will show the name of the camera when the connection is set up correctly.  If there is a disconnect, it will tell you where (i.e., if your phone/tablet is not connected to the Weye Feye, or if the Weye Feye is not connected to the camera).Once the connection is made, you can control the camera or view the contents of the memory card.  Controlling the camera from the phone allows you to do the following:- View a live representation of the camera's viewfinder on your phone or tablet (similar to Live View mode on the camera, but the camera's display is blacked out and the phone/tablet used instead). You won't be getting a perfect 30fps instantaneous display, obviously, since there's going to be some latency involved, but the Weye Feye is surprisingly fast.  I'd venture to say that in the vast majority of cases, you'd hardly even notice the delay. It's really quite good in that respect.- Click on any part of the screen (in AF mode) to focus on that point. The speed with which this happens depends on the lens used and the light level, but will operate at the same speed as using Live View directly from the camera.- Control many of the camera's exposure features via button overlays on the screen. This includes: drive mode (i.e., single shot, continuous, high speed continuous, quiet mode), exposure compensation, white balance, ISO, and auto or manual focus.- If manual focus is selected, up and down arrows allow you to incrementally change the focus in small or large steps.- Set an intervalometer: Set the number of desired exposures and the desired interval between them (in whole seconds). Then tell it whether it should attempt to reacquire focus after every shot, or leave it where it was for the first shot.- Set a self-timer with any desired delay (in whole seconds)- Set custom aperture bracketing. You can choose any number of supported aperture values and it will take a photo for each value.  They need not be consecutive, so you can for example select f/1.4, f/4, f/10, and f/16 and it will take all four in succession.- Exposure compensation bracketing, this operates similar to aperture bracketing.  They don't need to be consecutive like they would be in-camera. You could set compensation values of -5, +0.6, +4, and +5.- ISO bracketing, as above.- White balance bracketing, as above.- Basic focus bracketing, select 3, 5, 7, or 9 photos with "small", "medium", or "large" focus steps between them.In the photo view mode, you can look at the images on the camera's memory card, zoom in on them, and share them with various social sites like Facebook or Flickr. I don't really see much of a use for this particular feature though, since I never upload anything without first running it through Photoshop for adjustments.  If you don't care to do this, then you may find the sharing functionality to be useful and convenient.I've had a couple of small problems so far with the use of the Weye Feye.- the +/- step buttons used for time (such as for the time interval in the intervalometer mode or the self-timer delay) are tedious for large values.  For example, if you wanted to set the interval to 30 minutes, you'd be holding down the "+" button for quite some time. This may be specific to iOS, I'm not sure since I have no Android device to test with.- On a handful of occasions, the connection to the Weye Feye never worked correctly. After connecting to it on the phone, it would still say I wasn't connected to it.  This would be resolved by restarting the Weye Feye.- There's a problem in certain circumstances where the Live View display on the phone/tablet goes black even though the camera still "sees" correctly (ie, it can still focus on an area when you tap the screen, it's just that your screen is black so you don't know what you're focusing on).- I tried to use the web server functionality, which is supposed to allow you to see the images on the camera's memory card without using the app.  I was able to view the gallery page on my laptop, but it didn't have any images on it even though the camera's memory card had several.  I haven't yet figured out how to get this feature to work. (Update: it occurred to me recently that maybe the web server functionality doesn't work for RAW files because a browser wouldn't support viewing them.  I will retest with JPGs shortly and update the review, but if this is the case, that's going to be a problem for RAW shooters such as myself)- Documentation is sparse, to say the least.  Aside from the most basic connection information, the rest is up to you to figure out on your own.  The website offered no additional help, offering only the same skimpy quick start manual as was included in the box. I could find nothing more in-depth than that.== CamRanger Comparison ==Okay, so the CamRanger currently weighs in at double the price of the Weye Feye.  At first glance, that makes it a no-brainer decision. However, the CamRanger does have some additional features that the Weye Feye currently does not have. This is not meant to be an exhaustive list, especially since the software and firmware updates frequently add new functionality, but some of these features include (keeping in mind my particular setup, your functionality may differ based on your camera model):- The CamRanger has a replaceable battery.- Supports real-time viewing by multiple client apps simultaneously (meaning, people can download a view-only client app, and you can allow those people to see, on their own devices, the photos coming off of your camera as you shoot them). Other users CAN connect to the Weye Feye as a basic web server, but it just lets you view the gallery, and at any rate, I could never get the gallery images to show up even though the web server was working.- Multiple camera support from a single laptop- Change image mode (i.e., JPG, RAW, JPG+RAW, and the camera-supported size options) is available on the CamRanger, but not on the Weye Feye.- Same goes for changing the metering mode (i.e., average, spot, center-weighted, etc)- Live histogram: a continuously updating histogram representation of the live view is a (defeatable, if desired) option on the CamRanger as well as the Weye Feye, but the Weye Feye only has a brightness histogram, while the CamRanger supports a more informative RGB histogram.- Grid lines can be turned on as an overlay if desired, and the color can be changed to suit taste.- Highlight and Shadow Clipping: when highlights or shadows are clipped in an image, you have the option to turn on a blinking display that shows you where those clipped areas are in the image.- Aspect Ratio: another screen overlay that shows you whatever aspect ratio boundaries you set (just an overlay for reference - does not crop the image).- Focus Peaking: another overlay that shows you, based on your aperture, a red outline around all of the portions of the image that will be in focus when you trip the shutter.- Supports the use of a motorized tripod head to allow for remote rotation and tilt. This can be incorporated into the intervalometer functionality as well (i.e., automated move-shoot-move-shoot-move-shoot for time-lapse panning).- Camera Mode thumbnails: As you shoot, thumbnails of the most recent shots are displayed in a filmstrip across the top of the screen while in camera view. The Weye Feye requires that you exit camera mode, enter gallery mode, and click on the folder to see your most recent shots.- Documentation.  It exists for the CamRanger. You can download a PDF file with all the information you need to become an expert on its operation.  The Weye Feye has a tiny book with about three paragraphs of useful information on it. I could find nothing more online.On the other hand, some things that might give Weye Feye the edge:- Better build. The Weye Feye looks the part, and the protective case is a nice touch. It's easier to mount to the tripod with the velcro, as opposed the the carabiner clip supplied for the CamRanger.- The CamRanger is slightly larger and heavier, and looks exactly like the TP-Link mobile router that it's based off of.- Security (entering a password for the Wifi connection) is required for the CamRanger, but can be disabled on the Weye Feye. It's good to have the security to ensure that no one can take control of your camera mid-shoot, but it's also good to be able to turn it off if desired.- The Weye Feye firmware update process can be completed from your phone by just clicking a button, and then restarting the Weye Feye. The CamRanger requires a software download to a computer connected to the device via Ethernet or Wifi.- It's half the price.- The phone screen real estate taken up by the live view is larger for the Weye Feye on my iPhone 6, because for some reason the CamRanger software doesn't let me switch to landscape view when I rotate my phone.  This is only a problem with my phone though, because on the iPad I can view the CamRanger software in landscape and portrait mode, and there's a button to expand the live view window to take up the entire iPad screen.=== Conclusion ===So I hate to finish up a comparison review with "it depends" because it seems like such a cop-out. However, in this case it really does depend.  I could totally see some people not caring about an RGB histogram, real-time client displays, and highlight clipping alerts.  Personally, I love the focus peaking feature of the CamRanger, but if I didn't have it, it wouldn't be the end of the world.Maybe you just need an intervalometer and a few other basic features sported by both units.  In that case, by all means save yourself 50% and buy the Weye Feye.  But if you think you might want those features, or you're itching to try out the remote control pan/tilt tripod head, you might be better off with the CamRanger.For me, if I had it to do all over again and I could use both of them before buying... I don't know.
