From a cost/benefit standpoint I'd probably lean toward the cheaper Weye Feye, only because all of the CamRanger's additional functionality is "nice" for me but not "necessary" since as a hobby photographer I don't have much need for things like client mirroring and on-the-fly display watermarking, and the $150 I save could go toward something I'd get more use out of.  On the other hand, I've never had a connection issue with the CamRanger and it does occasionally happen with the Weye Feye where it briefly loses/regains its connection to the phone, even when they're only two feet apart. So the dependability of the CamRanger might be worth some extra cash.So! Sorry about the (very) wordy review, but I like to be thorough with things like this because there's a lot for prospective buyers to consider. PLEASE feel free to comment on the review if you have any questions that I might be able to answer for you, or if you think I've said anything incorrectly that you'd like me to correct.  I promise to try to keep this review updated as new versions of the software and firmware are released.

I think the pictures that the manufacturer has put up for this speaker are a good representation of its uses on a bike -- namely, low speed cruising or something similar.  It seems perfectly suited to a standard bike or a beach cruiser, especially when not on the road.  If you're on the road and you can hear it well over the traffic, then you're potentially blocking audio cues from your environment, and that could put your safety at risk.I use this mainly as a tabletop speaker. In that regard it performs extremely well, better than the Cyber Acoustics PS-2370 that is my sole point of comparison for Bluetooth portable speakers. I appreciate this model's buttons for the most common functions (Volume +/-, play/pause, prev/next track, answer call) which means going to the phone less often.There's a mini USB port for charging the unit, a 1/8" headphone jack for non-Bluetooth devices, and if needed, a USB port in the back allows you to charge your phone off of the speaker's battery. I haven't seen any stats on the size of the battery so I don't know how much of a charge you'll get before you drain it, but it's a nice feature to have in case you need it.The speaker also comes with a water resistant form-fitting neoprene case that can be used to protect the speaker if it starts to rain (although if you have it on a bike, you need to remove it from the mount first).  The case has the buttons imprinted on it so that the speaker can still be used while inside it.The audio quality is great, for a portable speaker of this size.  The volume is good (though having not tested it on a bike while riding, I can't speak to how it performs in that regard) and the sound is clear. Build quality is excellent, and they make heavy use of that soft touch plastic that seems to be all the rage right now. All things considered, I haven't yet found anything to complain about.

The CSG-800 has all of the basic functionality that you'd expect from any grilling thermometer, including:- Choice of meat type and doneness level. Thermometer alerts you when the meat reaches the correct temperature.- Countdown timer, alerts you when time expires.- Monitoring of current temperatureThis isn't your best choice if you're looking for something to use with a smoker, because there's only one port for a probe. For a smoker, look for something with 2 ports -- one for the meat, and one to monitor the interior temperature of the smoker.  The build quality is pretty decent and most of the exterior consists of soft touch plastic.  Overall, it's solidly in the middle of the other two I probe thermometers I own in terms of build quality.  It is the only one to offer a way to store the probe though, providing an area to wrap the cord around it and lock the probe into place.Unfortunately, we've already reached the end of "Things I Like About the CSG-800".The display quality is not very good (see the photos). Under most lighting conditions, the contrast is extremely low and it can be hard to read. Almost like the battery is nearly dead, but it works fine and the battery gauge shows they're fully charged. Contrast is higher at certain angles under direct outdoor light, but it produces a shadow on the LCD that also affects readability. There is no backlight either, so it's not great in low light conditions.  The display stand doesn't put the unit at a particularly good viewing angle unless it's sitting at about the height of your chin. The magnet mount works fine on painted metal grills, but it might not be strong enough if you're using an enamel coated grill.I was initially impressed with the accuracy, but that quickly changed.  While it looks accurate at lower temperatures (like when reading ambient air temp), as soon as I started using it for real, I was disappointed and annoyed.  My first trial came when grilling some nice steaks. I should have been more wary of an untested unit, but foolishly I relied entirely on the probe to determine when the steaks were done.  Once the temperature read 140F (rare), I took them off the grill, expecting them to be closer to medium rare after resting a couple of minutes.  They ended up being on the high side of medium well, and the probed one was the most overcooked.  There's no way that steak was 140º when it came off the grill.The second (and officially the last, I think) time I used the unit, I was slow smoking some pastrami that had been several weeks in the making. I was aiming for a final temperature around 190ºF. When the temperature read 163º, I started thinking back to those poor, ruined steaks and got a little nervous.  So I grabbed one of my other grilling thermometers and stuck the probe in near the other one so I could verify the reading.  It read 180º.I can't trust it, so I can't use it. The quest for the perfect grilling thermometer continues.

The images associated with the product all show the same flat, perfectly square surface to set it on.  That doesn't really help those of us with less than ideal sink shapes. My sink, in addition to not having a perfectly square shape, also hangs on top of the counter with rounded, raised edges.  I didn't really hold out much hope for the colander being as stable as they claim.  But I was wrong.  It sits on the sink like a champ.  I can press down on the basket area to simulate more weight than I would ever need it to hold, and it's solid.  I've included a picture of the imperfect sink shape as well as one with the colander in place, for reference.Any part that touches a surface (the feet that touch the side of the sink, as well as the underside of the "shelf" part) are soft, grippy rubber. The plastic is thick and sturdy.  It drains things.  So in true OXO fashion, it does what it's supposed to do while being designed better than most other instruments of its type.

At the time of this review, the Sentry 6-pack is a little more than 25% cheaper than the Frontline Plus 6-pack, with the same active ingredients. That alone makes it the better option of the two, because otherwise they're identical.As far as how it compares to other competing products, that's a bit harder to determine.  I have always had more luck with this than with SimpleGuard (the product my vet started carrying after Frontline Plus went OTC) and Advantix.  Some may claim that this is due to the effectiveness of a given medication on the type of fleas and ticks in a given area.  So, the ticks that are most common here in Central Florida might be more resistant to a given brand than ticks found in North Carolina.  I'm not sure if this is true as I've seen no studies on the matter, but it would make sense.  It's for that reason that it would be extremely difficult to blindly recommend this product over any others.  All I can say is that it works for me, and the fact that it's cheaper than the lower-performing, higher cost brand prescribed by the vet is an added bonus.

After a couple of weeks with this case, I'm pretty convinced that it's one of the best you can buy for your phone.  I had previously owned this slim case for my phone, made by one of those questionable companies that keeps changing its name and puts the entire product description in the title, which drives me nuts.  That case is good, and far less expensive, but had some flaws.This one has only two flaws that I can see -- the price and phone removal.  $50 is a lot for a phone case.  I guess one could argue that you probably won't ever need another one until you get a new phone... but still, it seems expensive.  Phone removal is a problem too.  It can be done. but it's not easy and it involves putting quite a bit of pressure on the device.  If I were one to remove the case often, I would be more annoyed with this, so keep that in mind if you remove the case frequently to use with various docks, etc.It adds to the thickness of the phone, but it's not too bad, and it's worth it for the protection. The rubberized rim around the screen means you can place the phone face down on a table without worrying about your screen. Other than that beveled edge and the button covers, the rest of the case exterior is a harder plastic that so far has shown no signs of use in the time I've owned it.The volume buttons and lock button are fully covered by the same soft rubber that makes up the interior of the case, and the ringer switch and various ports on the bottom are open but surrounded by that same rubber, creating a sort of seal that keeps any dust from entering the interior of the case and causing potential problems with wear marks and scratches.  I still remove the phone every couple of weeks (with aforementioned difficulty) to clean it and the case off just in case, but I never see anything in there when I do. That is a definite improvement over my last case, which required cleaning out every few days because dust and dirt got in there so easily.The company makes a big deal about the raised ridge pattern in the soft rubber of the case interior, claiming it makes a difference in shock/drop protection.  I can't confirm that claim, but I suppose it can't hurt, and even without it this case would still feel like the most protective case I've ever owned for any phone.

So anxious was I to get my new mobile transceiver and antenna dialed in (a few days after getting my license) that I went straight to the SWR meter sitting in the garage to start testing.  That is, the SWR meter that I had bought for the *ahem* CB install, not knowing that it wasn't compatible.What's that smell?Anyway, lesson learned. I ordered this one minutes later.  It seems to work fine, although I don't have any way of actually verifying the readings. I used it to dial in the mounted antenna on the Jeep, and then set up a smaller glass-mount antenna in the other car that I can hook up to my HT.  If you're looking for more precision than one decimal place, this may not be the meter for you, but if you're okay with a reading like "1.3-ish" then this is a solid and reasonably affordable option. It seems to be built like a tank, too -- it's heavy for its size.

Simple and inexpensive.  It's exactly what I needed.  I'm using this to connect the antenna on my Jeep to my Baofeng UV-5Rv2+. As soon as the antenna arrives for my other car, I'll be using it in there as well.  Makes SWR and power testing convenient too, when coupling the Baofeng to my Signstek Power/SWR Meter.It seems to be solidly built so far, time will tell how well it holds up. It's cheap enough that I'll probably buy another one soon -- one for each car.

This antenna works beautifully on my Baofeng UV-5RV2+.  It's a significant upgrade from the antenna that came with the radio, and I've been surprised by the range so far.  I tested it recently from inside my house, logging in to an Echolink repeater (21 miles away) and recording my own radio check, it came back with a small amount of white noise but otherwise perfectly audible. With the original rubber duck, I could receive from that repeater, but I could never get out to it.I don't know if it's the best antenna available, but it's definitely the best of the three I've tried (this, the included rubber duck, and the Nagoya NA-701).For reference, I tested the SWR on a Nissei RS-40 and came up with 1.2:1 @ 144MHz and 1.4:1 @ 446 MHz.

I really like this pad (attached to a Griot's Garage 6" Random Orbital Polisher ) but I do wonder if I'm doing something wrong. After applying the wax using the Red 6.5" Foam Waxing Pad, I switched over to this pad and started removing it.  However, while it did remove some of the wax, there was still a haze on the paint in most areas. I didn't want to apply TOO much pressure, so after going over the whole body with this pad, I grabbed a dry microfiber towel and easily removed what remained of the wax.  This was clearly an easier process than removing ALL of the wax by hand with the towel, but it does have me wondering if I'm either applying it wrong or taking it off wrong, because I expected this pad to finish the job, not just start it.However, I'm not going to deduct any stars for something that is surely due to my own inexperience with orbit buffers. The pad itself is well-made, and after using it on a couple of cars, it shows no signs of separation or damage.  It looks like it's going to last quite a while.

Overall, I really like this spray. I feel like some of the bad reviews might be missing the point a bit, so I'll do my best to explain why I'm happy with it.First, let's get the scent out of the way. Yes, as so many have stated, it does smell like you're spraying piña colada all over your car.  An oft-overlooked point is that (at least for me) the next time I get into the car I can't smell it at all. It dissipates quickly, so the only time I'm really smelling it is when I'm applying it. Even if I HATED the smell (which I don't) it would be tough for me to complain about it since it's gone almost immediately.As far as the cleaning is concerned, it seems to do a very good job.  On a black interior, you may not see much of a difference (other than having removed the dust). What you won't see (I suspect this is the basis of some poor reviews) is ANY added gloss or shine, no matter how minor. None. I have often used Turtle Wax ICE Interior Care, and while one of the benefits of ICE is a significantly reduced "oily sheen" as is common with the much-maligned Armor All spray, there still is just a tiny bit -- enough to make the interior have that "just-cleaned" look for a couple of days. You won't get that with InnerClean.I'll admit it was a little disconcerting at first, and I thought maybe it wasn't working. That is, until I looked at the cloth and saw the gray from the dirt that it had picked up. Dirt embedded in the steering wheel from daily contact, dirt hiding in those tiny texture crevices in the vinyl and plastic, all that stuff. When you're done, the dash will look like it's supposed to look -- not any shinier than that.My only concern is the protection, and that's only because I only have the word of the product description ("...coating the surface with their patented solar fighter UV protection") to go by. Hopefully it protects surfaces at least as well as the competition.

I have several paste and liquid waxes in the garage right now, and I'd say that of all of them, this one may be the easiest to apply and remove by hand. It's certainly easier than any of the paste waxes.  If you're using an orbital buffer, you need to take slightly more care when pouring on to the pad, just because there's no real control like there would be with a squeeze bottle.  Otherwise, the process is the same and pretty simple. Generally speaking, my orbital didn't fully remove the wax once applied. It did most of the hard work, but I still had to go over it lightly with a dry cloth to finish the job. For reference, I'm using a Griot's Garage 6" Random Orbital Polisher with a 6.5" Finishing Pad to remove the wax.It looks great once applied, but honestly I've never been very good at actually being able to tell the difference between one wax and another visually, so I can't really compare it there.From a "feel" perspective, the Glanz Wax does score pretty highly on the slickness scale. I'd put it very close, but not quite as high, as Maguiar's Tech Wax 2.0. It definitely feels smoother to me than the Griot's Garage Premium Carnauba Paste Wax that I also use.The one test that I'm most interested in is how long it lasts -- currently the wax I own that wins the longevity race is the Maguiar's Tech Wax 2.0, which maintains that slickness for a good six months on my garaged vehicle.  Once I get an idea of the longevity of the Glanz Wax, I'll be able to update the review with a comparison.Until then, I can say that this is a worthwhile product with a good price point.  At the current price, it's about the same price per ounce as the Tech Wax mentioned above. Without knowing anything about the longevity of the Glanz Wax yet... I'd say these two waxes are otherwise equally good.

Okay, so the book to study for the exam costs more than the exam. It's worth it to feel well-prepared.  Before buying the book, I had started by looking around online for websites that would do the same job for free. Problem is, it doesn't exist.  You either pay to use the site (in that case I'd rather just buy the book) or you get free sites that aren't particularly well-suited to learning the material.After struggling with a couple of these sites, I bought the book.  It's just better.  Everything is laid out according to topic, and after reading each section you're presented with the related questions on the exam. Even while you're reading, if a sentence answers an exam question, that question's identifier is added in brackets at the end of the sentence.Once you get through all of the material, the entire question pool is available at the end of the book. They're the exact questions used in the exam (35 are selected out of the question pool). Basically, if you can test your way through the entire question pool at the end of the book and miss 9 questions or less, you're guaranteed to pass the exam.This is probably more due to my personality and learning style than anything else, but I did occasionally have a problem with some of the material because it would be glossed over a bit too quickly for my liking.  I don't have a lot of electrical knowledge so this wasn't a review for me, I was actually learning it. I had to keep reminding myself that the purpose of the book isn't to teach me the inner workings of everything from the ground up -- it's to prepare me for the exam. So after reading the entire book, I had to be okay with the fact that I'm not going to clearly understand the "why and how" to every concept presented.  I'll need to continue learning through other means for that.

This is my second SteelSeries headset, the first being the far less expensive and smaller SteelSeries 5Hv3. The differences are significant, as you'd expect considering the price difference. It's not ALL in favor of the higher end one, though.This headset has a ton of features, largely due to the included USB sound card. While the sound card is optional (and at any rate not compatible with phones, tablets, etc.), it's recommended because you need to be using the sound card in order to enable Dolby emulation, ear cup illumination, the EQ, microphone sound options, etc.  When using the headset with standard 1/8" jacks, none of these things are available and it works like any other headset.The build is pretty spectacular, feeling much nicer in the hands than the 5Hv3. The headband is great -- rather than the usual click-stop size adjustments, it uses a spring-loaded retractable system that automatically sizes itself when you put it on and retracts when you take it off. It works perfectly. The ear cups are thick and incredibly soft. I haven't had any problems wearing them for over an hour, although I haven't worn them longer than that. Some noise bleeds through, about the same as the 5Hv3, which is surprising considering the difference in the size of the earcups. It's not bad though, by any stretch. And if there's any sound coming through the speakers, the outside noise pretty much disappears.I started off using just the 1/8" headphone jack attachment, to test it out.  For music, I actually preferred the 5Hv3, which sounded a little more natural, while the Siberia was a bit "echoey" (can you tell I'm not an audiophile?). The vocals felt a bit more distant, with the background music more prevalent.  It still sounds good, but the 5Hv3 sounded better.Plugging the headset into the sound card changes everything. First of all, the configuration. Set the EQ using presets or customize each band. Set the microphone noise canceling, the "talkback" level (hearing yourself in the speakers when you talk into the mic), turn Dolby emulation on/off, and set the earcup illumination.For the illumination, you get the standard color swatch and slider to choose your color from, or if you really have a specific color in mind, you can enter an RGB triplet or hex value. And no, you won't be able to tell the difference between values that are near each other.  The actual output colors are an approximation at best.  Once you choose your color, you can select to have it steady on, "breathe" (fading/pulsating at a user-defined rate), or have it change the brightness based on the sound coming through the speakers (an odd choice, since you're either the person hearing or the person seeing, but never both).  Finally, there are a handful of multi-color fade options if you want your skull to look like the bar in some sort of ultra-lounge.Honestly, I don't see the point in the illumination. Sure, I picked a color and I leave it on, but I can't see it. My wife and dog don't care. Does anyone care? I doubt it. But that's just my thoughts on it.  If that's the reason you're looking at these, maybe ask yourself how much you really want that illumination since the only time you'll see it is when you take them off but leave them plugged in.Anyway, the sound card allows you to plug the headphones in using the special jack (required for illumination), or a standard 1/8" phone/mic combo. The sound when plugged in to the sound card is fantastic, both for music and games. Even the system sounds are better through the headphones because they sound "placed" on the screen.Now, these are pretty big.  Fine for playing at home but a bit unwieldy if you're planning on traveling with them. However, I do like the extra 1/8" jack at the base of the headset that allows another pair to be connected for a second listener. It seems like if you could cram these into your carry-on, it would be a good way to allow two people to watch videos on a tablet or listen to the same music. Of course, I suppose you could just get a splitter for that too.Both the Siberia and the 5Hv3 have good, clear microphones. The Siberia's microphone has a white LED that remains lit while muted so you can always determine your mic status out of the corner of your eye without taking your eyes off the screen. In very dark environments, if you're often on mute, the glare can be a little distracting. The mute/unmute is switched via a rubberized wheel on the outside of the earcup (on the non-mic side, the same rotating wheel controls the volume).Overall, I really enjoy these. I only wish that the sound when using the headphone jack was a little better.  It would be cool if they offered this exact headset, without the illumination, for a discounted price.

This thing is solid!  I have a stand whose purpose it is to elevate the rear tire for maintenance work, and it's FAR less stable than this stand is. Finish and craftsmanship is top notch, it's heavy duty all around. Its ability to fold means that I'm more likely to pack it when we take a weekend trip, rather than relying on the hotel room wall to support the bike.The only thing I would change about it is that while the bike is well-protected by the rubber coating on the fork, there is no such coating to protect your floor from the metal.  While it's not a problem for my application, I could see someone with wood floors looking to find something to put under it to prevent scratches.

This is my second bike storage rack, the first being the significantly cheaper but less interesting Stoneman Sports DBR-820.The build is simple, just a matter of putting the pieces together and locking them down with a few nuts. It took a few minutes and it was done. The instructions were fine for the build, although a little vague at the end when they showed a level being used to ensure that the unit is straight, and adjusting the feet accordingly. That's fine, but the rack never actually sits perfectly vertical -- it leans slightly back, I'm assuming to shift the center of gravity under load so that it's less likely to topple forward.The upper arms can be installed in one of two heights, and the lower arms can be installed at one of three different heights. Other than the wood panel, the rubber cups, and the plastic feet, everything is metal and feels solid.  That's another advantage over the Stoneman, which has plastic arms. They have been fine for over a year now, but they just don't feel as trustworthy as the arms on the Saris.So, I currently have the two city bikes on the Stoneman and the two road bikes on the Saris. It seemed like the natural choice, the lightweight, sleek road bikes looking perfectly at home on the modern, attractive rack.Here's a warning though, about the way the arms are spaced.  This is a non-issue on most road bikes and hybrids with a straight top tube (actually, the stance makes them feel very stable on the rack), but other bike styles like women's cruisers or possibly men's mountain bikes without a straight top tube *may* have some problems fitting on the rack. I can't verify because I don't have a men's mountain bike, but just by eyeballing it, it looks like it would be a problem.

I'm really happy with this tablecloth. It fits our dining room table perfectly when the extension is in, and does a great job of protecting the table surface. The fabric repels moisture well, and the understated pattern and texture on the surface adds a bit of friction. It's simple and attractive.

As others have said, it is more expensive than other competing solar panels. But there seems to be a couple of pretty good reasons why it costs more, so let's get that out of the way first.1) Some solar panels don't come with a rechargeable battery. This one does (with integrated flashlight). Without a battery, the instant you lose the sun, you lose your charge. With a battery, you can store charge for use later on, when the weather may not be cooperating.  There are options to buy the panel without a battery pack, such as this one.2) Some solar panels don't come with a quality interchangeable regulator. Some may be designed for charging devices, some may be design for charging car batteries.  This one supports the use of several different regulators, so you can charge just about anything.3) Some solar panels mention nothing about water resistance or ruggedization.4) This unit allows you connect multiple panels together to improve your charging capability.So, here's what I love about this panel:- Everything I mentioned above.- There are four points for anchoring the panel with clips, carabiners, etc.  They are heavily reinforced so you don't need to worry about accidentally ripping through the fabric.- With multiple panels, they can all be linked together in any configuration: lined up side by side, grid, etc. The heavy-duty velcro will hold them together as if they were one big panel.- The included 5V USB regulator has an integrated LED that tells you when there's enough sunlight available to charge.- You can either charge your device directly, or you can charge the battery pack and have backup power whenever you need it.- You can connect a device to the battery while it's being charged by the panel.- On an otherwise nice day, the regulator LED still shows available charging power even under the shade of a tree or building.- The flashlight is a nice touch on the battery pack.  While I wouldn't ever use it in favor of something like the Fenix LD22 (I usually have a couple of these on hand), this light is great for emergency use because it's easy to charge when no other power source is available.- It's a solar panel, and therefore awesome.The things I would change:- The cable for the regulator is only a couple of inches long. Look through the photos (ignore the ones with the really long red/black cable, that's not included here) and you'll see that with the panels facing up and the regulator is plugged in to the port, the regulator is hidden completely underneath because it's too short.  A few more inches would have been perfect to allow the regulator to be visible regardless of the position of the panels - that way you can more easily see the LED to determine if you're getting a good charge.- The user manual could probably use some work, although to be honest, it's not all that hard to figure out.- When the panels are folded up and held shut with the four velcro tabs, the tabs aren't quite long enough in the "fold" area, so they don't extend far enough to seal flat against the other side. It stays closed just fine, but it's kind of an OCD thing.

No issues so far!  As has been mentioned already in other reviews, avoid fakes by going through known sellers.  I've had the cable for a couple of weeks now.  It feels slightly thicker at the neck (and therefore less split-prone) than the Apple equivalent. Of course, I haven't yet had it long enough to tell for sure, but I'll update the review as time marches on.  At this point though, I actually prefer this cable to the one that came with my phone.=== Update 12/08/2014 ===This cable is still great. No changes to my rating, absolutely nothing has gone wrong.  Just got another one for my wife, because her Apple cable started fraying just like mine did.It's really unfortunate that some idiot selling fake cables can get lumped in under Belkin's legitimate product and completely destroy their ratings. At the time of this update, other sellers seem to have been removed, so hopefully the problem has been solved. Still, when ordering, make sure you're getting a cable from the Belkin seller (you should still have the option for Prime shipping).

There are several sizes available for this charcoal storage bucket, this is the 8-gallon size.  It's big enough to hold about 24 pounds of charcoal, more than big enough for the big 20-lb bags.  You can empty the charcoal bags into the bucket for maximum storage capacity, or simply drop a bag in.  If you choose the latter, there's an extended lip inside the lid that is designed to hold the bag open.  In practice, this may be more trouble than it's worth because it involves carefully cutting the bag down to the same height as the bin, which sounds less annoying than it is.Other than that, it's a good looking bin that seals up nicely to keep the rain out for storage outdoors. I'd recommend searching for it on the website for your local hardware store though, because I found it at a big chain store for literally half the current posted price here on Amazon.

Let's cut right to the chase. The sound quality is acceptable given the price point, but nothing that's going to blow your socks off. There is some help in the form of a basic bass/treble adjustment, but that will only take you so far -- and any adjustments there are exclusive of the X-BASS option, meaning you can either have your equalizer settings OR you can have the X-BASS turned on, but not both.I'm using this system in a small bedroom, not out in the middle of the house, so it doesn't really need a significant amount of power since it just needs to cover about 120 sq ft.  Well, I say that, but the bedroom has a small (~6 foot long) hallway in front of it that leads to the bathroom, and the room/bathroom/hallway are separated by a door to the rest of the house. We have visitors often, and I wanted the Sharp to be in the guest room since there's no TV. It does a pretty decent job of getting the sound out into the hallway, but the Bluetooth is spotty at best.  We're talking 2 paces from the bedroom door, phone in hand, and it's already starting to cut out - about 13 or 14 feet from the unit.I don't know too much about the various Bluetooth specs, and I'm sure that the bandwidth required for music is significant and particularly difficult due to its low tolerance for errors, but I'm sure they could have done better.  Hell, my phone can still communicate with the Bluetooth temperature probe on my smoker 100 feet away through several walls, one of which is exterior (of course, low bandwidth and high tolerance for errors, but still...).Anyway, back to it. The remote has too many buttons, and they are positioned awkwardly. For example, if you have an iPod docked physically on the unit, there's a play/pause button you can use. It's different than the play/pause button for Bluetooth connected devices. Which is different than the play/pause button for "CD/USB" mode (why CD and USB modes could share a play/pause button but the other modes could not is beyond me). It's simple. Whatever mode its currently in, the play/pause button should work on that mode, then you only need one of them!  These 3 play/pause buttons are located all in the same area at the bottom of the remote, and yet the prev/next buttons, which logically should be grouped with play/pause, are up in the top third. But wait, somehow the prev/next buttons ARE shared between modes - there's only one set of those.  Then you've got the one single line of mode buttons, for selecting CD, USB, tuner, and aux-in.  Ahh, but the buttons for iPod and Bluetooth are elsewhere.On the plus side, I definitely like the auto-on option in Bluetooth mode. The unit continues to broadcast itself as ready to pair even when it's in standby mode. So if you connect to it with your phone, it will power itself on and be ready to play music without any intervention from you.I guess the remote problem is pretty minor, it's just a usability issue. But this is Sharp, and you'd think that they have enough time in the game to how to design a remote. And other than the Bluetooth range, there really isn't anything particularly bad about this model if you're just trying to get music into a small space.

I'm docking a star for now, based on the info I've provided in the updates at the bottom of my review. Obviously I'm still using it, and I'll continue to update as I come across new issues or solve existing ones.It's not perfect and I briefly considered a 3-star rating, but in the end I decided to give them the benefit of the doubt and the reader can feel free to form their own opinions based on my reasoning below. I will also try to mention the main points of the two reviews prior to mine, as they relate to my own experience.First, let's get this compatibility issue out in the open.  Yes, this device requires Bluetooth v4.0 compatibility in order to work with your phone. No, the item description doesn't clearly state as much. It does say "... via Bluetooth Smart connectivity", which implies the BT 4.0 requirement, but I suppose that could easily be misunderstood. If you're not sure about your device, you can check the list of supported devices here: http://www.bluetooth.com/Pages/Bluetooth-Smart-Devices-List.aspxAs of today, there is no iPad version of the remote viewing software.  If you want to use your (supported) iPad, as of right now you have to download the iPhone app, which of course means that the resolution will be all wrong (and is very likely the reason a previous reviewer complained about the temperature not being displayed right on the iPad).  Hopefully they'll release an iPad version soon, but I don't know if they plan on that or not.The unit itself looks pretty nice and feels sturdy. It comes with the required AA batteries and a temperature probe. Right there, I was a bit disappointed -- one probe?  When I bought the Maverick ET-7 Remote Thermometer some time ago, it came with two probes. This is part of the reason I docked a star from the rating.  If you're using this on a smoker, you'll want to get an extra probe with it, one for the meat and one for the surrounding air inside the smoker. Luckily, the Maverick probes are compatible with this unit, so I was able to use one of those instead of buying a new one.The temperature seems to be accurate, within about two degrees of known calibrated sources. You can choose pre-selected meat types and a doneness level, and it will set the target temp for you, or you can set the target temp manually in 1-degree increments.  You also have the option of setting a timer, in case you want to monitor the temperature independently of the time required to cook.  All of these things can be done on the main unit or on your phone (or other BT 4.0 device, I'll default to phone here).  I'm using the AW133 with an iPhone 5, and the app looks and functions beautifully. It continuously updates the display with all of the pertinent information, from percentage complete (along with a graphical representation of completeness) to time elapsed, time remaining, etc.  The main unit's orange backlight changes to reddish-orange when the cooking is nearly done (5 degrees before target temp, if you're using a temp-based mode), and you get a notification on your phone. Then when the target temp is reached, the unit backlight turns red and it beeps several times.  You'll get another alert on your phone, but unfortunately there seems to be a bug that causes the "finished" alert to pop up several times in a row.The app also has an internal link to Allrecipes.com, if you're looking for ideas.  You can even take pictures of your cooking progress with a current temperature overlay (several different styles) for making people jealous.I've found the communication range to be exceptional. There's a transparent protective layer of some sort on the sliding glass door out to our back patio -- it was a major problem for the Maverick unit, because that film ruined communication between the base and the remote. Even 2 feet away from each other on opposite sides of the glass, there was no communication whatsoever.  With the AW133, not only can it communicate through that film, it even goes further, through several walls to the far opposite corner of the house. When I did finally find an end to the range (with the base at the far front of the house, inside by the front door, and me with my phone, outside in the back corner of the back yard), it was able to reconnect almost instantly when I got back in range.There are a couple of slight usability issues, and one of the previous reviewers touched on them. I do find myself occasionally touching buttons by accident because of how far out toward the edges the touch sensitivity extends. That's not a big deal.  The other reviewer also mentioned how turning it off (press and hold the Set button) only worked about 50% of the time.  This happened for me too, and it drove me crazy until I figured out what was happening: when you don't press a button for a few seconds, the backlight turns off and the buttons on the face go into a sort of standby mode. Touching any of the buttons turns the backlight back on, and puts the buttons in "ready" mode.  So when you haven't touched it in a few seconds, you need to tap it once to make it ready for input. THEN press and hold the Set button and it turns off.That's not in the manual anywhere, and yeah it's frustrating until you figure it out.  But now you don't have to, because I just told you about it.  Once you know about it, it's a non-issue.So overall, the AW133 works great.  One star reduction for: only one probe, alert bug on phone app when "done" (hopefully will be fixed in a software update), and I guess it would be nice on the main unit to have both probe temps visible without having to press a button to switch between them. Still, I can recommend the AW133 as a significant step up from the Maverick.=== UPDATE 08/19/2014 ===I'm sitting here right now, about 5.5 hours into smoking a brisket. The AW133 has been connected since I got started, with one probe in the brisket and another into the probe port on the smoker to measure the interior ambient temperature. Everything was working exactly as expected until just before the 5 hour mark, when all of a sudden my phone lost its connection to the main unit.  I don't know what caused it, but none of my numerous attempts to reconnect it were successful, including restarting the phone app. Finally, after every conceivable combination of pairing modes on the main unit and the phone, I was able to reconnect after a full reset of my phone. Unfortunately at that point I lost the elapsed time, since I guess if you're in "Temperature" or "Meat Profile" mode, the timer only exists on the phone and not on the main unit. Of course, the timer doesn't matter as much when you're in one of these modes, but it's still nice to have.  It's worth losing another star over if this connection problem happens again, but I'll wait until I can repeat it to make sure it wasn't a fluke.=== UPDATE 09/17/2014 ===I think I've figured out the connection problem mentioned in my previous update.  It seems that there's a bug in the iPhone app that causes the connection to go bad when you're constantly monitoring the temperature.  At least, that's what it looks like.  What I mean is that if I turn off the auto-lock on my phone, forcing the screen to stay on with the app active, eventually (after maybe 1-2 hours) the connection is lost and the only way to fix it is to reboot the phone.  However, if I check the temperature and then background the app (or lock the phone), then the connection is maintained. It would be nice if this bug was resolved in an update, but I don't honestly know how well-supported this app is going to be since I've seen no updates since I downloaded it.Also, I've noticed a pretty significant temperature differential when using the included probe versus the compatible ones that came with my Maverick.  At room temperature there seems to be about a 5-degree difference. I'm not sure yet about hotter temps, I'll be testing that soon. I can tell you this (keeping in mind that it *could* have been my fault as well): the first time I smoked a chicken (using a Maverick probe on the AW133), I took it off when the temp reached 170F and it was absolutely perfect. The second time, I used the included probe instead. I took the chicken off at 170F and cut into it only to find it was still pink in many areas.  Again, this could have been something I did, but now that I noticed the probe temp inconsistencies, I wonder if that had something to do with it.  I'll update again when I know better.=== UPDATE 09/30/2014 ===No resolutions so far to the existing issues, although the workaround for the connection problem that I mentioned in the previous update still works for me.  This morning, however, I've noticed a new problem that didn't exist previously. The probe connection has always been a little finicky, and occasionally the probe would stop giving readings, but I always assumed it was water entry into the probes or some similar issue. Maybe not. The new behavior is that when I try to use two probes, neither of them will read. If I take out either one, the remaining one will immediately start working again. Put them both back in, they stop working. I really hope it's not broken for good. At any rate, until I come up with a resolution I'm taking a star off.

I have to say I'm pretty impressed.  I didn't have particularly high hopes for the speaker, and although it's by no means perfect, it's better than I expected it to be.To start, this thing is lighter than it looks. I expected it to be denser feeling, but the weight is nice for something intended to be portable.  It's a pretty good size, too. Maybe a little too big to comfortably fit into a pocket, but easily stored in a bag or something without taking up much space. The build quality feels solid, and rubber feet are positioned for both setting on a table or attached to an outlet on the wall.The manual suggested allowing it to fully charge before use, so I plugged it in, and it was done charging in about two hours.  You're not getting top quality audio out of these 2W speakers, but you really can't expect that for something this size.  It is acceptable though, and the volume range seems quite good.  The box suggests that you can get "up to 8 hours" of listening time in on one charge, but surprisingly my experience suggests quite a bit more than that. The last several days, I've been pairing the speaker first thing in the morning and using it for music while working.  After 9 hours at medium volume, the speaker show no signs of quitting -- in fact, I haven't run it all the way down yet, so I don't know how long it will last.One nice feature is the built-in microphone, which allows you to use it as a speakerphone if someone calls while you're connected. There's an auxiliary input if you are using a non-BT device, and a USB port for a secondary method of charging.  Both of those cables are included. The pairing is easy. Hold the BT button for a couple of seconds and then select it on your device.  On subsequent uses, the speaker will reconnect to the previous device, if it's available. I'm not a huge fan of the voice status notifications though -- when you turn on or off the speaker or connect or disconnect a Bluetooth device, a loud obnoxious voice says, "POWER ON!" or "YOU ARE NOW PAIRED! ENJOY!". It's annoying because it's at a high volume (it doesn't seem to be affected by your selected volume) and its kind of jarring.

So up until now, our filtered water came from our two-pronged attack -- a Brita pitcher that we keep in the fridge, and a PUR Faucet Water Filter that attaches to the end of our kitchen faucet.  The pitcher has always worked fine, but refilling can be annoying since both of us drink a lot of water.  The PUR faucet attachment did the trick, as long as it wasn't too busy leaking through the threads or popping off the faucet into the sink.  But then our aging faucet developed a leak, and I decided to replace it with a much nicer Moen 7185CSL Brantford One-Handle High Arc Pull-down Kitchen Faucet. The PUR faucet attachment would no longer be compatible, but the new faucet's integrated sprayer meant there would be an extra port in the sink where the old sprayer used to reside. So I decided to splurge a little and buy this filtered water faucet.Boy, am I glad I did.  It's easily the most convenient option for filtered water delivery.  The filter (one is included) is good for 6 months, and a light will flash at the base of the faucet when it's time to replace it. In a perfect world, a green/yellow/red transitioning light (like the PUR had) would have been nice, rather than just the red "change it now" light, but that's not a big deal.The faucet is all metal, and the handle turns with ease while being nicely damped in a way that feels quality. The head pivots to any direction.  Installation was pretty simple, and a tool was included to aid in the tightening of the nut that locks it into place against the sink -- this tool was a huge time saver, because getting up in there with a wrench is an absolute nightmare.  Everything I needed was included in the package, so it was nice not to have to run out to get something at the hardware store.I was able remove the old faucet and install both the main faucet and this one in about 2.5 hours, not bad for someone that has never done any of that before! Although much credit goes to Moen's design for making it as easy as possible.*** Update 12/18/2014 ***Nothing new to add for the faucet itself. Still working great.  Just replaced the filter after the indicator light started flashing, which verified an approximate 6-month lifespan. Although it probably just sets a 6-month timer when you change the filter...

I bought this to replace the kitchen faucet that predates our ownership of the house, which had started to leak all over the counter every time it was used. Purchased on a Monday morning, the 2-day shipping estimate (Amazon Prime) was for Friday because of a possible "1 to 2 days for processing".  The faucet arrived on Tuesday, beating Amazon's own best-case scenario!Removal of the old faucet was the real nightmare, but once done, the install of this faucet was surprisingly simple. They even include a tool that allows you to easily tighten the nut that holds it down without struggling with a wrench in that really cramped space.  Much of the time savings was probably due to that tool. I don't care much for the fact that the nut is plastic though - I would have preferred something metal. The faucet is reasonably solid on the sink after tightening the nut down, but it's also not that difficult to grab the base and forcibly move it. I'll probably have to go back under the sink and try to tighten the nut a little more.Other than the plastic nut, the only other thing that bothers me a little is that the removable faucet head is plastic while everything else is metal. I suppose this may be for weight purposes - a heavier faucet head may not return back as easily.At any rate, I liked it enough to splurge a little more and purchase the Moen 77200CSL AquaSuite Filtering Kitchen Faucet for the port left open by the old faucet's sprayer. They look great together, and both were installed with zero additional required parts -- only what was supplied in the box.

Maybe my shaker is just a non-standard size (for reference, I have a 30-oz Winco shaker) but when I place this strainer over the top, there's still about a quarter-inch gap between the spring and the shaker lip.  This isn't a major issue because I just put a little bit of forward pressure on the strainer with my finger while holding it, and this keeps the spring in contact with the "correct" part of the shaker lip when straining.Other than that, I can find no fault at all with the strainer.  It's well built, sturdy, and the rubberized grip provides a good slip-proof surface for your finger.Even with the minor sizing issue, I'd happily purchase this strainer again before switching to another brand.

For the home or small business, this is a great bulk package of delicious hot cocoa. The mini marshmallows melt and add an extra creaminess to the texture, and the chocolate flavor lends itself well to water or milk.These packets are somewhat smaller than the Swiss Miss ones I'm used to getting from the grocery store, so I double my usage (two packets make a really rich mug of hot cocoa).Decent deal on great cocoa. 5 stars.

I purchased this to replace the saddle on a classic road bike I've been riding. Love the bike, but the saddle was SO uncomfortable. A literal pain in the ass and after 30-40 minutes of riding I'd start to get tingling / numbness in my, ah, 'pelvic' region.Upgraded to this, and I'm so happy. It's just wide enough to provide great support without being bulky. Just enough padding to support as well without being too squishy. The ergonomic 'relief' canal in the middle is appreciated -- it gives my 'boys' a little extra room.No complaints about this whatsoever. 5 stars.

These are the Hefty equivalent of Glad w/ Febreeze. I used to use the cheapest trash bags possible, but tried the scented / tie-straps ones on a whim, and never looked back.These scented trash bags fit your standard tall kitchen trash can. They're strong, convenient (with the tie straps) and the apple scent helps mask the smell of old vegetable scraps, coffee grounds, etc. that might be sitting in your trash a day or two.Note these are KITCHEN bags, not utility trash bags. It's not advisable to toss broken glass, sticks / screws / tacks, or other more rugged household trash. These are meant for paper towels, scraps, light cardboard, foam cartons, etc.These are nice and cheap here on Amazon and I've got no complaints with the product. 5 stars.

I've been using an old blue denim apron for years (it's a keepsake from a late relative) but figured this one might be a fun addition for my girlfriend to use alongside me for grilling out. It's a nice apron, boasting several 'updates' over the really old one I've been using:- the neck strap is connected to the waist strap, so you can actually adjust the neck strap length by pulling on the waist straps- a pocket in the front is a place to stash a kitchen towel, or the salt / pepper, or tongs... whatever you likeWell, that exhausts my list of the technological improvements made to the Apron in the decade or so since my relative's death and my inheritance of that old apron. All things considered, this is a nice apron with great utility, good for grilling or any other messy sort of cooking that might otherwise result in your shirt / dress getting stained. No complaints. 5 stars.

I received this as a sample item for review right after I'd cooked a multi-day supply of spicy Indian eggplant / lentil curry. You'll agree when I say that, with a serving or two of the curry every day, I have put this product through its paces in the bathroom. I have to say -- it works. That lady in the commercial isn't lying.The Juniper Woods scent is a very pleasing scent redolent of, well, Juniper Woods I suppose. Woodsy-sweet, sort of cedary. Not musky, but not floral either. Clean without being chemical or overly sweet. I have a reduced water consumption toilet so the initial surface area is pretty small. Three sprays and I am effectively shielded from any atmospheric effects during / after my daily bombing run.This really is a pretty ingenious product. If you didn't believe the claims they made on TV, take it from me -- this product works.At ten bucks for the 2 oz and fifteen bucks for the 4 oz bottles, this stuff isn't cheap. I doubt I'd pay those prices, so I'm docking these a star for being significantly more expensive than the tried-and-true method of lighting a match. I know lighting a match leaves a conspicuous scent and lets the next person know you've been dropping a deuce, but let's be honest -- the burst of Juniper Woods scent is just as conspicuous.

These little cans are all about CONVENIENCE -- with a 6-8 oz flask of tequila and a 4-pack of these cans, you can make 4 average-strength margaritas. Decent for tailgating or beach camping, but they're not as attractive if you're just making margaritas at home.FLAVOR-wise, these are on par with other margarita mixes. They taste decent but are very sweet -- after water, High Fructose Corn Syrup is second on the ingredients list. I'm not one of those people who's afraid of corn syrup, but would caution y'all that the flavor is sweet, almost syrupy, and needs to be cut with something (unless you like very sweet margaritas). Some soda water, a slice of lime, and salt are really needed with this mix to make the flavors pop and not become too syrupy.These are 130 calories per can -- not bad, except for the fact the cans are less than half the size of a soda can. So, really, these are packing a lot of sugar calories. Anyone who knows anything about margaritas shouldn't be surprised here. However, I again have to comment that they could have cut just a tiny bit of the corn syrup out (and I know Agave Nectar 'perfects' this margarita mix, but personally doubt there's much in there) and put a little more citrus in there.PRICE-wise, this is another one of those Amazon listings for a product that is sold at significantly cheaper per-unit prices at retail stores right by you. My local Wally World sells this same product in 24-packs for only a little more than double the price of this 4-pack here on Amazon. Per unit, that means Amazon charges nearly 3 times what this product costs in a normal retail store. I understand it's convenient having these mailed to you but -- if you already have to go out to buy a bottle of tequila, you might as well just pick up a 24-pack (or one of those quart bottles, which will also be cheaper) while you're out. You'll need more than 4 of these tiny cans to make enough margarita to go through a single bottle of tequila anyway.This is a decent product, convenient, tastes okay... but the flavor doesn't blow me away, and Amazon's current pricing is just flat-out uncompetitive at current rates. Currently these are over 2 bucks a can -- they should be in the neighborhood of a dollar per can (or less) in order to be worth getting vs. just buying some margarita mix at the liquor store where I have to go anyway to pick up tequila. 2 stars.

As soon as this arrived, I fired it up and setup Windows 10 with minimal issues. After going through the setup, subsequent boot-ups are amazingly fast thanks to the 128GB SSD. I've spent a good deal of time with Windows 8 / 8.1, and have to say 10 is a definite improvement. It improves functionality and really makes the most of the rise in touchscreens without trying to make itself in to an app-y cell phone screen. Speaking of touchscreen laptops -- if you're only used to touchscreen phones / tablets, but still have an old-style laptop, know this: the touchscreen vastly improves productivity and turns web browsing into a very fluid experience.As for the display itself, the screen color, contrast, and resolution are crisp with the only drawback being the finger smudges you’ll leave all over it. As we move into a market where touchscreen is common in laptops, I expect we'll see a lot more alcohol wipes being sold...Physically, the construction is solid with glossy brushed aluminum / plastic throughout. The keyboard is backlit with subtly rounded key surfaces improving the tactile feel. My only complaint with the physical design is the incongruous green indicators on the Caps and Num Lock buttons; I'd  prefer to leave Num Lock on, but the indicator is light is a distraction from the otherwise sleek aesthetics. The touchpad left and right buttons are part of the flexible touchpad with the left being redundant (the whole pad is a 'left' button) and the right I frequently find having to hit twice. I've experienced this issue before and am not sure how to get around it, outside of just using a normal mouse.Battery life is good, easily making it through streaming a few movies to the TV. It's sufficient for a movie night, doing work on an airplane ride (more about that later), etc. The ports are in the technical specs, but in short, there's plenty of connectivity with this laptop. If you find the connection ports lacking there are probably other reasons for you not to get this computer.Apart from the touchscreen, the defining feature of the unit is the rotatable screen. The flexibly and balance of the unit takes it from being a laptop to an anywheretop. It’s light enough and generates little enough heat that its comfortable using long term in any position.  Time will tell how the hardware holds up and if bloatware drags down the performance of the system but my desktop will be very lonely until that day happens. It's really nice being able to have a laptop at my desk or a large-screen, high-performance tablet on my couch or on an airplane -- without needing two different devices. The tablet orientation of this laptop is GREAT for plane rides, since you can lie it flat on your tray table and don't have to fiddle with balancing between tray space and the monitor viewing angle.Overall, this gets 5 stars. Tons of performance and convenience and a truly revolutionary experience with the rotable touchscreen.

As with other Wellness brand dog treats, these are formulated from MEAT as the main ingredient, with natural flavoring, and are made in the USA with no funky chemicals or additives.They're a little pricey, but very healthy and don't contain any concerning ingredients. The 'mixed Tocopherols' have a funny name but from what I've read they're actually important nutrients and can supposedly help prevent cancer in your pets? So... there you go.These are chewy enough to last a bit, but soft enough so even small dogs like mine can enjoy them. 5 stars.

I've had a fabric Samsonite carry-on for a decade or more and it's served me very well, but I jumped at the opportunity to try and review this Tumi one. The polycarbonate shell and prestige of the Tumi name really had me excited. Now that I've had time to play around with it I have to admit I'm a little underwhelmed. It's a good bag -- don't get me wrong -- but this thing is priced in the ultra-premium range. It's easily double or even triple the price for comparable polycarbonate luggage from other great brands like Samsonite, so I'd expect double or triple the performance...First, the positives:+ the 21" height is legit. For some reason, Tumi's actual website lists this as 22" high. Maybe they're factoring in the height of the handle... hmm+ dimensions are compliant with international carry-on dimensions. Key here is the 9" depth. Some airlines are very strict indeed about that, and it's common for even international carry-on sizes to be 9.5" depth, which would be an issue with those rigid bag checker boxes+ the polycarbonate shell looks stylish indeed+ integrated combination lock is maybe redundant since you won't typically be checking this bag, but it's pretty cool nonetheless+ the four double-roller wheels are free swiveling for a very smooth experience rolling this bag. It's also very stable+ compression straps are handy for keeping your clothes from shifting (on that one side of the bag, at least)Now, some negatives...- the polycarbonate finish, while slick looking, easily shows fingerprints and smudges. Over time the glossy finish will show scratches and scuffs as well. I'm a little confused as to why they went with glossy finishes rather than the brushed finish on other polycarbonate luggage, designed to conceal scuffs and scratches- there are no carry handles on the side or bottom of this bag. You can only lift it from the top. Because of the way the bag is made, the non-handle half isn't supported by anything other than the zipper, which I suspect could be an issue over time as the zipper wears with use AND with repeatedly bearing the load of the contents inside- the wheels, while smooth, protrude and are more prominent than my Samsonite bag. Since volume is such a key issue with a bag that fits within the strictest international carry-on limits, I'm surprised they didn't have the wheels a little closer to the bag body. I'd say there is a solid half-inch of extra height they could have squeezed in there -- and this does matter!- the 'compression strap' side is the only one with open storage -- that is, storage you can access without having to unzip something. My Samsonite has a mesh storage pocket in the opening hatch portion which is handy for books, toiletries, etc. With the Tumi, any small, loose stuff has to be stashed in an opaque zippered compartment- the label is bolted to the luggage. I guess that makes it solid, but it also means the backside of four bolts protrude from the inside wall. They stuck a piece of foam tape over them, but it still just seems a little weird. Why not rivet it so it's more flush to the bag? Again, this is something that eats a tiny bit of volume. It's slight, but it counts. And it'll also be an eventual source of wear for the liner material.- this might be the biggest con -- for all the touted strength / lightness of the polycarbonate material, this luggage is not noticeably lighter than my Samsonite luggage! The Samsonite is slightly wider and taller, plus it can be expanded, AND it has rigid sides (the only non-rigid part is the lid)... but it's no heavier than the Tumi, which is entirely flexible. I understand the polycarbonate is designed to flex, but I'm surprised at just how flexible it is, especially with the fact that the zipper actually has to support the two halves of the luggage wobbling around- the liner is attached with velcro to the polycarbonate. You can unzip that final layer of liner to stash stuff, but the zippers on BOTH sides were missing the pull tabs. Seriously... why have a zipper without a pull tab? It's just inconvenient to deal with.BOTTOM LINE: this is a stylish bag, that's for sure. However, there are a number of small design 'quirks' that don't make a lot of sense to me. No side handles? A shiny finish that shows scuffs and fingerprints? Wheels that protrude a good half-inch more than they have to? No easily accessed / viewed mesh storage pocket for small items? No expansion? Stuff like this makes me question the Tumi brand -- you're paying for the NAME (baggage handlers target Tumi bags for rough handling, supposedly), and you're paying dearly. For eighty bucks I'd be more forgiving... but this bag retails for nearly FIVE HUNDRED. Five hundred! That's practically a surfboard, or a road bike. If I'm dropping that much on a bag I expect a little more efficiency and a little more practicality with the design. Two stars is a really harsh rating but I honestly can't knock the earlier reviewer who gave it that. I'm saying 3 stars because I'm a little more forgiving, but would give 2.5 if I could.

I have two roommates, and we're all engineers -- there can never be too many surge protectors / power strips in my house.This surge protector is very nice for its price point. The dark gray metal is sleek looking but also unobtrusive, and won't stick out like the white plastic ones do. The outlets are oriented so that large plugs will hang off the side, instead of blocking the neighboring outlets -- it's key for when you have a bunch of bulky adapter bricks plugged into the same strip. The last two outlets are actually spaced out further apart, specifically to make room for those adapter bricks.Each outlet has a sliding safety to block off the ports when it's not being used.Mounting brackets in the back are standard and will work with any flat-head screws -- I'm not mounting mine though as it's just sitting on the ground behind my desk.The 3' cord is pretty standard, nothing to write home about, but is ample for my needs. The power switch (and a red LED above it) light up to let you know when the strip is 'ON'.All in all, this is a very nice power strip. Looks good, durably constructed, some nice little features that I wouldn't expect at this price point. 5 stars.

I was disappointed in this book. The characters were good, but it was just too predictable. Minor spoiler: the storm at the end kind of did it for me. Although the storm wasn't much of a plot point as I expected it to be, it just seemed stupid. I have liked other books in this series but was not impressed with this one.

My dog, a 6 month old Newfoundland, is really enjoying this toy. I have numerous treat dispensers and give him about 1/3 of his food in them every day. This was much more work to fill than most (it involved unscrewing the base and a cap) and it doesn't hold very much, but he likes that he can pick it up and carry it around. I expect it to get broken as he drops it on the tile floor, but in the mean time it is a big hit. The holes are very small and can't be adjusted. For example Core dog food, which looks to me like normal-sized kibble, is too big and won't come out.It is recommended for dogs over 3 months. It is heavy, so toy breeds might have trouble with it. Mine is pushing 90 pounds and has no trouble carrying it ;-).

These are a good treat without a lot of added stuff that I don't want to feed my puppy. There aren't a lot of preservatives, but they came with a shelf life over a year from receipt. I don't think they would last that long opened. My dog likes them and I am using them as a training treat. They are too big to give a lot of, but an occasional one mixed in with kibble makes him that much more attentive.

This is a nice dryer for home use, or for travel if you have lots of space. I use Babylisspro TT Tourmaline Titanium Travel Dryer, Red for travel. That is incredibly weak but tiny.  This is about 3/4 of the size of a normal dryer, which is not enough of a difference for my suitcase, but is great for a crowed bathroom cabinet or a drawer. It does an excellent job drying.

These are decent baking cups suitable for what used to be normal-sized muffins and cupcakes. It seems like the giant ones are more common now. These are quite a bit smaller, so check your pan size before using them. Most recipes make 12 normal cupcakes/muffins or 6 giant. If your pan is normal sized but your recipe makes the larger size, you can use these and cook for less time.  I find that spraying all liners, including these, with a non-stick spray (like Pam) really helps prevent the paper sticking to the food. It also helps to spray your pan to keep overflow (which you will probably get with these smaller and shorter  liners) from being a problem.They are a nice looking and good quality cup. I won't hesitate to buy more.

I bought this in Paris for a lot of money. I was disappointed to see that it is just a cheap folding umbrella with a cool color changing feature. It is small and looks like one good wind would destroy it. My puppy got it before the weather. Because of its poor quality I won't be buying another. I am looking for one with the same feature but better made.

This is a great, seemingly well-made toy, but it is big and heavy, so it is not appropriate for toy breeds unless they like to drag around stuff that is bigger than they are. I have a Newfoundland puppy and he likes it. He doesn't seem to grab the area with the squeaker very much, but likes carrying it around. It seems like one of the toys made for chewers, which he is not, so I expect it will last a long time

I like is line of product bit works well without irritating my sensitive skin. The wipes work pretty good at getting off my makeup. Like all wipes I often need a couple of passes, but then all is gone. I will buy more.

I have three different Ahava foot creams. This, of course, the one with tea tree oil, and the mineral foot cream in their water line.They all feel a little different going on, but I don't see any real difference the next day - the tea tree one might be very slightly better but not significantly. I like all three and when I am out will buy the one that is cheapest.
Nice quality oil and seriously packaged, so there was no risk of breakage. I received this for review purposes but would not hesitate to buy it again.

I did a fair amount of research on flea and tick control for my dog. What I learned is that the normal stuff, like the regular Pet Armor or Frontgard kill ticks and also fleas that bite the dog. The "plus" also kill flea eggs. In areas where fleas aren't an issue, the regular is fine, but if you live in a flea area, the "plus" is the way to go. This is exactly the dosage and content of Frontgard Plus, but at a much better price. It is kind of like buying generic or store-brand ibruprofen instead of Advil. The cheaper stuff does the same thing.

I have invested quite a lot in Sonos. I have 5 speakers (2 - 3's and 3 - 5's) plus the boost and connect. I love the way they can be connected or separate, but have never been that happy with the sound. I am a huge Bose fan and was thrilled to see they came out with something that competes with Sonos.My first impressions:It is slightly smaller than the Sonos Play 5. About 1" narrower and shorter.The power cord is pretty short - about 5'. This is similar to Sonos'.  Prepare to use a extension cord (or power strip w/ surge protector).Set up was very easy. Well, it would have been easier if I had remembered my Pandora password, but it still only took a few minutes.The sound is much better than Sonos.It allows for 6 memories to be set. So, I can hit a button on the SoundTouch or my app and have it go right to a certain Pandora station (I just have to remember which station it is). The display on the app tells me what the presets are and the unit itself has a display showing the current song. Sonos has no display.It comes with a remote, which Sonos doesn't. The app also works as a remote, but this is great for guests who want to listen to music without having the app loaded or dealing with set-up.I had no trouble loading the app on my ipad mini, iphone 6, or MacBook. I have not tried it with android or Windows. Bose says: "The app is compatible with Windows XP, 7, 8; 64-bit Macs running OSX 10.6.8 and later; any iPhone, iPad or iPod touch running iOS5 and later; Android devices running Android 3.0 and later."This allows bluetooth streaming. Cool.According to the Bose site: "You can stream music from an iPhone®, iPad® or iPod touch® to SoundTouch™ Wi-Fi music systems via AirPlay®. You cannot stream music stored on an Android™ phone or from apps on an Android phone."There are some complaints on Bose's web site about trouble using it with AirPlay. From my Sonos use I expect to mainly us it with Pandora, but I tried connecting it with AirPlay.  I couldn't even find AirPlay on my iPhone 6, so I just used Bluetooth. I had no problem listening to anything (music and podcasts) using Bluetooth.You can only have one music library linked.I tried linking my computer's iTunes library after it was already linked to a NAS drive. It didn't work. Again, I found Bluetooth the easiest way to go.All in all I like this a lot better than Sonos. The big decider for me is that the sound is just a lot better. Bose quality. I will buy more.

This is the best toilet paper around. I accidentally bought a package of the Charmin ultra soft and returned it when I realized my mistake. This is a great combination of being soft but not falling apart.

First of all, I have exclusively used Bounty for many years. These are not nearly as strong as Bounty. However, they are not nearly as expensive, either. I love this small size for covering bowls on the microwave. They are perfect for that. One sheet won't dry my hands, but they are great for the right application and to have in the car. The shorter size doesn't fit very well on my paper towel holder, but is good in one I bought on an overseas trip. I learned the hard way that US paper towels are one more thing that we size bigger than much of the world. I think I will try using a paint roller for a holder in the garage.

I have a 5 month old Newfoundland puppy, so I jumped at the chance when offered a package to try and review. They are much stronger than I expected and the large size made one wipe go a long way when cleaning what I thought was a fairly clean dog. I can see now why my carpet os so dirty - he was carrying a lot of dirt on his paws and belly. The wipes did not leave a yucky or stick mess on his fur as feared. I will continue to use these even when he has not gotten into something bad. A few seconds wiping off his underside will go a long way in keeping my house clean (or clean-ish. It doesn't help with the toothpaste in the bathroom sink).

These feel like good quality. The earbuds are comfortable and the size was easy to change (I have had trouble with some brands), The sound quality is good and the pause button was easy to use. I like having it on the cord instead of the earpiece as it is easier for me to find. I received these to review but would not hesitate to buy another set.

I have been giving my Newfoundlands fish oil for decades. Some dogs have been fine with human-grade pills, but my puppy takes them out and tries to eat them on the carpet. This liquid is much easier for both of us. He likes the taste and I like knowing the oil is getting in his stomach and not my carpet. I was given a bottle of this to review but would not hesitate to buy more.

I have a large breed puppy and my vet recommends that I feed him glucosamine for his entire life. I had been using Myristin, which comes in really big tablets. My breeder recommended it and said it was better than human pills as dog's digestive system is different than ours  - things go through very fast. Although my pup has been eating the Myristin fine for his entire life (OK, he is only 5 months, so it hasn't been that long), he decided last week  that he no longer was willing to do so, even when they were broken and mixed in with his food. When I was offered a bottle of this to review I jumped at the chance.This is easy to use and can't be eaten around like the pills. It is expensive, but one bottle should last a long time. At the highest dosage, for dogs over 100 pounds, the recommended dose is 1 ounce per day, so this will last over a month. My pup is OK with the taste. I expect to buy more of this.

My first impression of these were that they are very light. You barely feel them. Changing the earbud size was a snap (that hasn't been the case with some other brands). They paired easily with my phone and the sound quality is very good. I am not using them for running, but they stay in well for other physical activities. The only problem I have with them and similar styles is that they get hidden behind my hair and people don't know I have them in. This can be good, but has been a bit embarrassing when someone was talking to me and I didn't hear them.I was given these to review but wouldn't hesitate to buy another pair.

This was a good book that kept my interest right from the start. The plot is a bit predictable but still was quite enjoyable. It dealt with autism and dysfunctional families in a good way. I will recommend this to several friends and will be reading the author's new book.

I have been using Silpats and Exopats for decades. This feels exactly like them. The weight is the same and it feels identical. Eventually they all decline, so I will be using this to replace a Silpat that has cuts. If it doesn't hold up as well I will change my review, but right now I would buy whichever is cheaper, which will almost certainly be this one.I was given one of these for review purposes, but would not hesitate to buy more.

I bought these and paper ones (Luna Bazaar Premium Paper Hand Fans (9-Inch, Perfect White, Set of 20) for a wedding). Neither were exactly what you call great quality, but the paper pushed a lot more air than these. The paper ones did not close easily, but several of these were broken (the holding pin was broken). Because of the need for as much air as possible and the fact that I would have had to fix several of these, we chose to use the paper fans instead of these and I returned them. They looked good, but just didn't work all that great.

I bought these and wooden onesLeegoal Chinese Fans Chinese Sandalwood Scented Wooden Openwork Folding Fan (Set of 12) for a wedding). Neither were exactly what you call great quality, but these pushed a lot more air than the wooden ones. They open easily, but when you try to close them the paper does not go right back together. You have to manually push the folds where you want them. We have had other paper fans that worked and the wooden ones closed perfectly. Because of the need for as much air as possible, we chose to use these and not the wooden ones.

What can I say. This is just my favorite movie ever. From the wonderful description of people by what they like and hate, to the quirky Amelie who turns to water when she loses her chance to talk to her crush, it is just magical.

My doctor, who doesn't push medicines or supplements, recommended I take lysine. A study (U of Maryland) shows that it helps with my osteoporosis. I was happy to receive a gift of this to review. The price is good. the other brand I used recommended one pill with once a day with a meal. This one recommends one pill three times a day between meals. Looking on-line, it appears this is used as a cold sore treatment.
