Dosage, according to the U of Maryland, is 1000mg (2 pills) if you get cold sores and want to reduce the chance of a flare up, and more (3000-6000mg) if you have a flare up. No dosage was given for my use, but I will stick with 1 or 2 pills a day. Like anything, too much of this can cause problems.

This replaced a beautiful carafe of the same color as a dish soap dispenser. Unfortunately I broke the first and it is no longer available. This is nice, but quite a bit smaller than I would have liked. Still, the wide base keeps it stable and perhaps I won't knock this one over.

My dog may not care about what is and isn't in these, but I do and have no objection to any of them. They do recommend you use them up within 3 weeks of opening (my dog approves of that, too). I am not sure if it is because they dry out or of they will spoil. It shouldn't be an issue for us, even though I feed a dozen different treats. I just have to pay attention to these and make sure they get in the rotation a bit more than others.

This is a good, basic soap. I find it strange that soap is now marketed to men or women, but the scent of this is appropriate for a man. i guess most don't want florals. That doesn't mean I haven't grabbed it in the shower without any later embarrassment.

This is a nice set. I actually am not using it for bath toys, but instead for drying small stuff. I am using the suction hooks in the shower to hold scrubbies. The bag is basically a laundry bag without a zipper. The suction cups are decent quality. I received this set for review, but wouldn't hesitate to buy another.

This works well to keep my puppy busy. I put part of his kibble in it. It is loud but I still like it. Anything is better than him biting my hand.I am downgrading from 5 to 3 stars because it broke quickly. It now comes apart in both screwed together areas with just a moderate tap. Too bad. Other similar toys have made it through several dogs. The round blue one is the biggest hit OurPets Smarter Toys Interactive IQ Treat Ball Dog Toy, 5 Inches (Colors may vary) I have pretty much every treat dispenser and that is the best one I have found.

These are a good deal for the money. The sound quality is good, pairing was easy, and they stay in my ears even when active. I appreciate the sliding piece on the cord so I don't have too much extra cord. That has been a problem with other headsets as the cord kept getting caught ion stuff. The control is easy to use, it is very similar to the Apple one. I received a review set of these, but would not hesitate to buy another set.

I see why this is marketed for men. It is large and anyone, like me, with a small hand will have trouble using it. My husband says it is just OK and not to buy another. The poof side is no better than a $1 poof, actually a little less useful as it can't go as many places, like between toes and fingers and the scrubby side is not nearly as good as a BufPuf.

This opened a bit slow for me, but after a while it caught and kept my interest. I think the issue was timing. I had just finished an excellent book that also dealt with a psychopath (Every 15 Minutes by Scottoline) and in comparison this just wasn't as compelling of a read. I am not sure if the book got better or I just needed to be a few days out from Scottoline's book.We know Dominick is a bad guy. We just don't know how bad or the depths he has and will go until the end. The plot was very good and well planned. I will recommend this to several friends.

I am surprised at so many negative reviews as I thought this was fabulous. It was a quick read that I didn't want to put down. You know there is a psychopath, but you don't know who it is. The presumption is that it is 17 year old Max, who starts the book fearful of the upcoming loss of his beloved grandmother, but any reader if the genre will quickly guess that this is too easy. Or is it?Excellent book, recommended to me and that I will recommend to several friends.

This has some things I really like and some I don't.  First, the small size makes it easy to grab and use for taking notes at meetings. It has a fabric cover over the metal spiral, so I don't have to worry about it getting snagged on anything and a pen loop so I can grab it all on my way out the door and not have to dig for a pen later.The downsides: The expandable pocket really isn't very expandable.  It can hold about 1/4" of stuff. The movable pocket divider has tabs that I don't think will make it past a couple of moves. I think I will cut them off. The biggest downside for me is that, because of the fabric spiral cover, it doesn't lie flat. When you open it and try fold the front cover to the back the fabric gets in the way. Even laying it flat, there is still a bump from the cover. This makes it hard to use.  That is unfortunate as it looks good and is a nice notebook.

This is a thicker, heavier rubber than I expected.  It does squish fairly easily and looks like it will hold up well. It has a more robust squeak than most of our balls. Because of its size and weight it is best for a larger dog. Right now my pup is only 55 pounds. He has no problem picking up and playing with it. I am sure as he ages (he just turned 4 months) he will be more interested in it.

These are very nice glasses, but heavy and big. I have trouble holding them, but my husband thinks they are great. They look nice - I certainly would not be embarrassed giving them to company or as a gift.I ws given a set for review purposes but would not hesitate to buy another set.

This is a nice set and would be a great gift for anyone who likes to cook roasts. The claws are wonderful for picking up anything from a roast to Thanksgiving turkey. The injector is much more substantial than my old one. The gloves are lighter than the commercial grade ones I normally use. They are like silicone potholders. My other ones are insulated, but they also cost more than this whole set.I was given this set for review purposes, but would not hesitate to buy another. It is a great deal.

Of course I tried using this without reading the instructions. Once I did I liked it much better. The instructions say to twist the top to remove it. i couldn't go that, but was able to open it easily by sticking my fingernail in the middle. I then put water and a fragrance in it, but didn't put the top on. Water spilled everywhere and I though it was junk. Lo an behold, once I put it back together the leaking stopped. I liked, but would have preferred to not have the colors. Read the directions and found the color could be changed or stopped.I had this in my bathroom and visitors loved it so much that I actually gave it to one of them. I received this for review purposes, but will be buying another.  Maybe more.

These really are great. The size is perfect for my husband, who likes to stand at the counter and eat cereal out of mugs.  The handle has a bigger opening than our old ones, which is appreciated. Glad I bought them

Sarah Manning and her clone-sisters find themselves caught in the crossfire between their very uneasy allies, the Dyad Institute, and a clandestine military experiment involving a batch of male clones. At the same time, Sarah is closing in on finding the origin of the cloning experiments, a mission that will take her far from home, to London and the deserts of Mexico.The third season of Orphan Black opens and expands the world revealed in the opening two seasons, a world where secret experiments in the 1980s have resulted in the creation of two batches of clones. Now adults, the clones are finding one another and trying to discover the reasons for their existence, and those answers are not happy ones.The first season of Orphan Black was unmitigated brilliance, a tour-de-force of acting ability as Tatiana Maslanay moved between playing multiple but very different characters with convincing ease. The second season stumbled a little by introducing too many new players, new characters and new factions. Sorting out the Proletheans from Dyad from mercenaries from military groups from Topside could be a little confusing at times.The third season opens with these elements very much still in play, now expanded with the introduction of a group of new clones played by Ari Millen. What feels like it could become a confusing morass is abruptly reversed by some very, very smart writing decisions. The number of factions and storylines is abruptly slimmed down, some relatively convincing retcons are used to keep the same characters in play without having to bring in too many new faces and, whenever things could get too out of control, the show reels the story back in and refocuses on the core triumvirate of Sarah, Cosima and Alison. Indeed, the show knocks it out of the park with an episode that focuses on Alison's attempts to get elected as school trustee and mixes up the clones pretending to be one another, old-school style. It's extremely unusual to see a series self-aware enough to realise it's running into a problem, and then decisively fix it with both verve and intelligence.There are a small number of new characters, most notably Ferdinand, an eccentric (but lethal) enforcer for topside played with relish by the always-brilliant James Frain, whilst British acting legend Alison Steadman joins the cast in the last couple of episodes in a pivotal role. Otherwise the focus remains on Tatiana Maslany's typically compelling multiple performances. This time around Ari Millen also has to play multiple characters and does a good job at it, even if the show backpedals a little from giving them the same time and variations that the female clones have.By the end of the third season, the show has done away with a number of long-running storylines and potential long-term threats, although the finale does open things up by hinting at new dangers. With two seasons remaining in the showrunners' plan, it will be interesting to see where the story goes from here.The third season of Orphan Black (*****) restores the show to the heights reached in the first season and is compelling viewing, not to mention being genuinely impressive in how it handles a few structural and writing issues that other shows would have simply let fester.

For centuries the nations of Nasheen and Chenja have fought a gruelling, deadlocked war. Millions on both sides have been killed by airbursts, poison gas and hostile swarms of insects. Now peace has come. Hundreds of thousands of young men and boys have returned home to the cities of Nasheen to find that their female rulers don't know what to do with them, but still expect them to obey. A movement for equality and representation is building, spearheaded by a mysterious figure. Retired bel dame Nyx is "persuaded" out of retirement to deal with the problem. Her mission will involve crossing a vast desert to unknown lands, a chance meeting with old friends and the final hope that she might find some peace at last.The Bel Dame Apocrypha series has done increasingly interesting and original things with each volume. Overall, the series is a curious mix of fantasy and science fiction, set so far in the future that technology and magic have become indistinguishable and a "fallen" race of humans, divided internally by religion and ideology, must make use of them to survive on a hostile, only partially-terraformed planet. The SF elements work because they are subtle and kept in the background, and overall the "bugpunk" theme is sold because the author commits to it, making her weird concepts convincing due to how the characters treat them as ordinary.God's War was an accomplished debut, benefiting from a razor-sharp sense of story but being a bit rough around the edges. Infidel was superior, a brutal (even traumatising) novel that was incredibly powerful but made you wonder if the author should be hauled before an international tribunal for the mistreatment of fictional characters. Rapture retreats a little from being that hardcore - although it's certainly not a happy novel - and instead shifts to being a more detailed and in-depth exploration of the world and history of Umayma and how it will develop going forwards.It's a remarkable book, driven by anger and fury and burning intelligence. A lengthy crossing of a hostile desert made me draw comparisons with Mad Max: Fury Road (although Rapture predates that film by three years), not for the plot but for its sense of purpose. We learn more about the world and what's going on in remote areas, but the book remains focused on the characters and how they relate to one another. The final collapse of relationships long tottering on the edge is sad, but also inevitable and then horribly liberating, in a way that's true to life.The book is mainly concerned with its own storyline, but finds time to wrap up long-standing plot threads from earlier volumes. Indeed, characters and arcs established in earlier volumes which felt a little disconnected from Nyx and her team are here tied into the main storyline with great skill. It's not a neat ending to the series - and there is at least one large dangling plot thread that potential sequels could pick up on - but it does bring about enough satisfying resolution to work if there is never another Bel Dame novel.If the novel does have some weaknesses it might be that some of the desert sequences in the middle do drag on a long time when the book's finale (which involves crossing the entire continent) is squeezed into a few too few pages, feeling rushed to the edges of incoherence. But the author just about manages to carry it off, producing an ending that's epic, spectacular and wonderfully messy.Rapture (****) is a readable, finely-characterised and highly imaginative novel, brimming with wit and attitude. It is available now in the UK and USA.

Elias rules as the High King of Osten Ard, but his policies have triggered war between the provinces and civil war within some of them. The continent is slipping into chaos and the only hope may be the mad king's younger brother, Josua Lackhand. Escaping a devastating siege, Josua travels eastwards to find a new stronghold, gathering allies as he goes. Meanwhile, it is said that only three great swords of legend can defeat the machinations of Elias's puppet-master, Ineluki the Storm King. Simon Snowlock has recovered Thorn from a remote mountain, but two of his friends have been sentenced to death by the Qanuc, his own erstwhile allies.Stone of Farewell continues the story begun in The Dragonbone Chair, and is less the sequel than the simple continuation of that story. Memory, Sorrow and Thorn is really one titanic, 1.2 million-word novel split into three (or four, depending on edition) for ease of publication.Williams expands and deepens the story in this book, with a more thorough exploration of the various cultures of Osten Ard. In particular, the Qanuc, Sithi and Norns all get more screentime and we learn more about the meadow-people of the Thrithings, the political and religious intrigue in Nabban and how the Hernystiri are surviving in exile.These elements are fascinating, but also come at the expense of critical plot development and incident. The Dragonbone Chair was itself a relaxed novel, but Stone of Farewell is even more chilled out. Simon spends a long time kicking back amongst first the Qanuc and later the Sithi, Josua's apparently desperate flight to safety has more of the feel of a holiday outing and Miriamele spends altogether too much time hanging out on a boat. It's more the stories inbetween that resonate, with Isgrimnur's increasingly fed-up journey into the south being enjoyable for its brevity and our glimpses into life in the Hayholt (effectively under occupation by Elias's troops) via characters like Rachel and the redoubtable Guthwulf.There are moments of real horror when the story kicks into a higher gear, such as Pyrates's confrontation with the Lector or the Red Hand's assault on Jao e-Tinukai'i, but these are relatively few and far between. Instead, the novel expands itself on helping the characters (particularly Simon and Miriamele) grow into more interesting people.Stone of Farewell (****) is well-written, richly characterised and features moments of real tension and horror. It arguably takes its hands off the throttle at the wrong moment, however, allowing momentum to dissipate a little rather than ramping up for the grand finale. But if you can forgive the slower pace, a fascinating, enjoyable and deeper fantasy novel than most awaits.

Prester John is the unchallenged High King of Osten Ard, the ruler of all the lands from the Nornfells to the southern deserts. He has ruled wisely and well - but not without bloodshed - for seven decades. Now his health is failing and his son Elias prepares to inherit the throne. Elias is strong and a canny general, but is also mistrusted for his close relationship with the sinister priest Pyrates. There is also a growing rift between Elias and his younger brother Josua Lackhand that threatens the peace.Simon, a simple kitchen boy in the High King's castle, the Hayholt, is drawn into events beyond his understanding. A cold winter is coming, things are stirring in the far north that have not been seen for centuries and the fate of the world will turn on three lost swords: Memory, Sorrow and Thorn.The Dragonbone Chair is the opening novel of Memory, Sorrow and Thorn, a massive trilogy written by American author Tad Williams. First published in 1988, the novel was an important milestone in the development of epic fantasy. Previous fantasy novels had been split between easy reading versions of Tolkien (Brooks, Eddings) or insanely dark reactions to it (Donaldson, Cook), but Williams's novel was arguably the first to really engage with Tolkien on the same kind of playing field. It's a huge book (over 900 pages in most paperback editions, and only the first part of the story) filled with a complex backstory, numerous ethnic cultures and different races, lots of made-up names and maps. Lots of maps. And an appendix, just to show you that this author means business.Of course, epic fantasy is a very different field in 2015 to what it was like in 1988, so does the novel hold up?The answer is a qualified yes. This is a big, epic story which Williams tells well, with some colourful prose, some solid characterisation and development and a bit more depth to the story than it just being another Tolkien clone. The (relatively few) action sequences are well-handled and there are some evocative descriptions, particularly of the vast Hayholt and its Green Angel Tower, as well as the forbidding Aldheorte forest. The characters are a fairly diverse and interesting bunch, although Simon himself, at this early stage, is a bit too much of a wet blanket with a tendency to pass out (either from injury or magically-induced visions) every time something important happens. His companions, particularly the "troll" Binabik, are altogether more compelling in this first novel.The book also constantly develops and restructures the stakes and the scope of the story as it goes on, bringing in more history, factions and people as it develops. This works in both the Tolkien-esque sense of starting small and branching out later on, and also in forcing a constant reappraisal of the world and the situation. It's telling to see how Prester John is viewed by his own people as a mostly just and benevolent ruler but people from other lands remember him as a conqueror.There are some structural issues. The book can switch POVs several times in a conversation, which is a bit bewildering for those readers used to the modern convention of staying with one POV for a whole chapter, or for POV switches to be marked by at least a paragraph break. This is also not exactly the fastest-paced novel in the world. Compared to Lord of the Rings, The Eye of the World or A Game of Thrones, The Dragonbone Chair (which is only marginally shorter than the latter two) drags its feet a little. Williams is a good enough writer to make lengthy travelogues or conversations between two minor characters hold the attention, but you do realise from time to time that not actually a lot has happened in the previous hundred pages. Finally, the POV structure can be a bit jarring: much of the first half of the book is shown from Simon's POV, but the latter half introduces a ton of other ones, including some who have an important role to play but we only get a few pages with them because so much time is being spent elsewhere.But these are both standard (for the genre) and forgivable problems, especially given that this was only the author's second novel. The Dragonbone Chair (****) may be slow to get off the mark and occasionally low-key given the scale of the events, but it's a well-written novel that is rather smarter than it first appears (this becomes more apparent in the sequels). It's well worth checking out ahead of the publication of the sequel series, The Last King of Osten Ard, due to start in 2017.

2036. Earth is under the control of the Observers, time-travelling, genetically-engineered and cybernetically-enhanced humans from a distant future in which the planet has become uninhabitable. During their previous observations of the Fringe team and their investigations, they have confirmed that it is possible to rewrite the timeline and create a new reality, so now they plan to create a new world for their benefit...but not for that of the humans who are already there.Frozen in amber for twenty-one years, the Fringe team awaken with one goal: to stop the Observers from fulfilling their mission. But with a vastly superior foe tracking them remorselessly, the team need every ally and every resource they can call upon in order to succeed.For its final season, Fringe changes things up a lot. What had once been a procedural, investigative drama about the paranormal and pseudoscience has become a full-on nightmare dystopia, throwing in some elements of post-apocalyptic drama for good measure. These thirteen episodes form a tightly serialised drama (the writers deciding the sops to the casual viewer are no longer necessary) taking in questions about what it means to be human and how far you will be prepared to go to save your existence.There are a few problems with the situation. First off, a fair bit of important stuff happens off-screen: four years pass between the end of Season 4 and the moment the Observers actually invade, including some important character development and also further developments involving William Bell. Bell's character arc simply disappears and we don't find out the fate of his character or what happened since the last time we saw him to explain his changed relationship with Walter and the rest of the team. Some hasty exposition from other characters doesn't really help. It's a problem that can be ignored for the most part, but the lack of resolution for this key character at a moment when pretty much everyone else gets wrapped up nicely feels a bit of an oversight.More of an issue is that the compressed storytelling and the near-omnipotence of the Observers results in what feels like plot holes. The ability of the Observers to foretell the future and how far they can do their teleporting trick shifts episode from episode based on the requirements of the plot. It's not quite as bad as the tricks some shows go to in order to nerf overpowered villains (the Borg, anyone?) but it again feels a little too inconsistent even given Fringe's elastic standards of plausibility.Fortunately, most of that can be ignored. The final season of Fringe is a bold, experimental one that throws out the standard format, changes dynamics all over the place and tries to be the biggest, most epic season on a reduced budget. Thanks to some excellent CGI (the paved-over Central Park is an impressive achievement), some very strong writing and some brilliant performances from the regulars and newcomers alike, the season is pretty gripping. By now it's gotten redundant to say that John Noble is fantastic in every scene he does (although a scene at the end of the first episode involving early 1980s electronica is particularly outstanding), but it's good to see Joshua Jackson stepping up to the mark. Jackson has pinballed between Plot Device and Exposition Giver for most of the previous four seasons (although always played gamely), but in Season 5 he gets a bit more material to play with and handles it well. Blair Brown also gets a terrific story arc as Nina this season, possibly by way of apology from the writers for giving her some pretty bad material in the Season 4 finale to work with. Georgina Haig also does some great work, stepping into the established cast as Henrietta.The biggest success of the season, though, is giving a definite sense of closure to the series. Coming from some of the same creators as Lost and being heavily influenced by The X-Files, the fear was that Fringe would, like those shows, have a muddled and unsatisfactory resolution to a long-running and confusing story arc. It doesn't. Instead Fringe nails the landing more than satisfactorily, giving a good sense of closure as well as explaining most (but not all) of the show's long-running mysteries.The final season of Fringe (****) concludes the series with style, giving a satisfying resolution to the show, its mysteries and, most importantly, to the characters. Fringe, tragically, is one of the more obscure SFF shows of recent years which is a shame, as it is also one of the best.

The Fringe team has saved two parallel universes from destruction but have paid a heavy price they are no longer even aware of. Peter Bishop, who as a young boy was saved from death, irrevocably altering the timeline, has been removed from existence. His Fringe team-mates have no memory of his existence and his removal has led to numerous changes, such as the continued existence of a very old enemy. But - somehow - Peter returns to find a world which he is no longer part of. Can he find a way "home"?Fringe's penultimate season starts off in a difficult place. The timeline of both universes has been reset and although things are broadly similar, a whole host of details have changed. These include Olivia and her sister being raised by Nina Sharp and Walter, never having been brought out of his shell by Peter, still being a crazy recluse. It is fascinating to map these changes, and the way the writers cleverly use them to resurrect previously-slain foes and revisit past plot points, but it does cause some problems with the viewer not being sure how much to invest in this new universe. Is Fringe going to hit the reset button at some point and revert things back to the way they used to be?If you can get over that issue, there is much to enjoy with this season. The notion that parallel universes can exist but time can also be rewritten within those universes is one that hard SF has played around with a few times, but this is the first time that an SF TV series has treated the concept with some seriousness and not gotten bogged down in technobabble. The timeline reset also allows the writers to drop a few storylines they developed earlier on which clearly they didn't know how to follow up on (particularly Fauxlivia's pregnancy). However, a late-season development allows them to revisit some of these plot threads and give them a more elegant form of closure.Once the season sorts itself out, there is much fun to be had from having our characters (in both universes) pitted against a returning old enemy (who later turns out to be a front for another returning antagonist) who is a step ahead of them at every turn. The season does a good job of balancing out its share of characters, with Peter dominating mid-season but Seth Gabel's Lincoln Lee rising to the fore later on. Lincoln has always been an interesting character, but his early placement this season as Peter's effective replacement feels a little off. That said, the writers use the oddness of his position to inform the storyline and eventually his character achieves a destiny that is fitting.A key subplot through the season revolves around the ongoing mystery of the Observers. Some fans thought we wouldn't get much, or any, explanation for these mysterious beings and their objectives, so it's a huge shock when we do get a detailed explanation for their origins and their ultimate goals. These ramp up in the nineteenth episode, Letters of Transit, which fast-forwards to the year 2036 and a nightmarish, dystopian possible future that awaits our heroes. Given that Fringe was going to be cancelled after the fourth season (the ratings were utterly diabolical) and was saved almost solely by the goodwill of fans at the network, this was an incredibly bold decision that could have left the series on a massive downer. As it stands, Fringe was reprieved at the last minute and given a final season to wrap up its storylines.Unfortunately, Season 4 does run out of steam a little before its end. There's some wheel-spinning episodes and even Fringe's generously elastic notions of plausibility take a serious beating with some plot developments. The actual season finale is also extremely weak, with some bitty plotting and Blair Brown being given some hideous exposition to relate to the other characters (the writers seemingly later apologised by giving her an incredibly poignant and well-played storyline in the final season).The fourth season of Fringe (****) is probably the show's weakest, although it's still eminently watchable, highly entertaining and, as usual, excellently played by a tight, capable cast.

Two years have passed since the ferocious battle for Hinzerhaus Fortress on Jago. The Tanith First and Only won a famous victory, but only at a horrendous cost in lives. Battered and bleeding, the Tanith First finally won a respite, being rotated back to sector HQ on Balhaut for a well-earned rest after ten years on the front lines.However, two years of inaction has led to problems with discipline, training and morale. In the midst of these problems, Colonel-Commissar Ibram Gaunt is summoned to a clandestine meeting. An agent of the archenemy has been taken prisoner and wants to give up valuable intelligence...but the Blood Pact have been sent to silence him by any means necessary.Blood Pact is the twelfth novel in the Gaunt's Ghosts series and marks the beginning of the fourth distinct story arc in the series, "The Victory". The opening of the book feels like Dan Abnett is taking a deep breath after the mayhem of the previous novels, which featured some of the bloodiest and most frenzied battles in the series to date, but it's not too long before the action kicks in again. Blood Pact is a short novel taking place over one single night and morning of carnage as the Blood Pact - the Ghosts' sworn rivals - arrive to carry out a suicide assassination task, succeed in splitting up the Ghosts and also take advantage of internal divisions as the Ghosts find themselves still under suspicion from the Inquisition about their mission to the Chaos-tainted world of Gereon years earlier.As usual with a Gaunt's Ghosts novel, the pace is blistering, the action is superbly-handled and the characterisation shines. Gaunt's return to the world where he lost his former command but gained a new one adds new shades to his character. Background Ghosts nicely come to the fore, such as Maggs, whilst we touch base with a few key Ghosts who've been lower in profile in the preceding books. However, Blood Pact does feel like a lesser entry in the series. Perhaps it's due to the increasing frequency between novels (Blood Pact was released in 2009 and one more book, Salvation's Reach, in 2011 with nothing since), but Blood Pact feels a little like too much set-up at a moment in the series when it feels like it should be perhaps more decisively moving towards a conclusion. This can be seen in the fact that while a few key characters get a lot of time in the sun, numerous other Ghosts (including many who played key roles in the preceding few books) suddenly drop into the background. If Gaunt's Ghosts was a TV series (and we can but hope), this is the relatively low-key opening to a new season which is reacquainting you with all the characters before the big storylines kick in.On that basis, Blood Pact (***½) does a good job of setting up its immediate sequel, Salvation Reach, and tells a rollicking good action story. Not one of the best books in the series, but still an effortlessly enjoyable slice of military SF from the best author in the subgenre. If you want to read the book, Blood Pact is currently only available as an ebook from the Black Library direct. However, the entire series is being rolled out in new editions, so it should be back in paperback in a few months.

Gregor Vorbarra, Emperor of Barrayar, is due to wed Laisa, an heiress from the (reluctant) Imperial client-world of Komarr. For the Emperor's diminutive cousin Miles Vorkosigan, the great social event provides the perfect cover for his courtship of the Lady Ekaterin Vorsoisson. Unfortunately, events are complicated by the complicated love life of Miles's clone-brother Mark, two landmark legal disputes in the Barrayaran Court...and a whole ton of butter-producing bugs.A Civil Campaign (subtitled A Comedy of Biology and Manners) was originally conceived by Lois McMaster Bujold as the second half of Komarr. However, she separated the two books out for reasons of length (A Civil Campaign is the longest novel in the series by itself) and also for tone. Komarr is a serious book but A Civil Campaign is a romantic comedy that at times descends into flat-out farce.It's hard enough to carry off romance or comedy or science fiction by themselves, so for Bujold to tackle all three genres in the same novel suggests either cast-iron confidence or outright insanity. After completing the book, the key to its success seems to be a bit of both. A Civil Campaign is flat-out crazy, a dramatic change in tone from the rest of the series to date. For starters, the novel has five POV characters, which is unusual given that most books in the series have just one, Miles himself. This novel adds Mark, Ivan, Kareen Koudelka (Mark's own romantic interest) and Ekaterin to the mix. This makes for a busier and more tonally varied novel than any of the preceding ones. Even more interesting is how Bujold mixes up the POV storylines: the normally frivolous Ivan gets the serious, political stuff to deal with whilst the emotionally-scarred, PTSD-suffering Mark gets the farcical butter-bug storyline to handle. Expectations are subverted throughout with great skill.Most intriguingly, this is a novel about adults, relationships and how damaged people can help (or hurt, if they are not careful) one another or choose their own paths through life. Through comedy, tragedy, horror and humour, Bujold builds up each of her POV characters (and numerous supporting ones) and deconstructs them in a manner that is impressive and enjoyable to read.That said, a key subplot revolves around a disputed succession between a dead lord's daughter and nephew, with Barrayar's laws of male inheritance favouring his nephew...until his daughter gets a sex-change. The resulting legal maelstrom is the result of a collision between fantasy cliche and common sense (and Barrayar has always felt it had more in common with Westeros than an SF setting) and signals an impending transformation in the planet's social order. It's also - arguably - the novel's sole misstep, with Bujold uncharacteristically more interested in the legal and political ramifications rather than the character-based ones. That isn't to say that Donna/Dono isn't a fascinating character, but it feels like Bujold did not engage with the issues raised by the gender reassignment with as much as depth as she might have done.There is some action in the book (a single shoot-out, which feels a bit incongruous given the tone of the novel, and a more farcical, Bugsy Malone-esque battle sequence involving tubs of bug-butter) but primarily A Civil Campaign (****½) is a comedy of manners, a grown-up romance and a great big coming-together of almost every major subplot and character in The Vorkosigan Saga to date. It's a terrific read and is available now as part of the Miles in Love omnibus (UK, USA).

Father Yarvi has brokered an unlikely peace between the formerly warring kingdoms of Gettland and Vansterland, bringing them together to stand against the forces of the High King. Still tremendously outnumbered, Yarvi is forced to rely on an untested young queen to help lead the way to victory and a last stand at the fortress of Bail's Point.Half a War concludes the Shattered Sea trilogy by Joe Abercrombie, an experiment by the British author to write shorter novels aimed at a more general audience. How successful that experiment has been is quite debatable - the tone and feeling of the trilogy is really not far removed from his First Law universe novels - but it's certainly resulted in the impressive delivering of three very decent novels in less than eighteen months.As with the previous book, Half a War revolves around three main POV characters: Skara, the young and untested queen of Throvenland; Raith, the bloodthirsty Vansterland warrior made into Skara's reluctant bodyguard; and Koll, the woodcarver turned minister-in-training who finds himself increasingly serving as Yarvi's conscience as Yarvi is forced into more and more desperate acts to try to save his people. Previous POV characters become secondary characters in this novel, which is both clever (showing how others see them) and frustrating, particularly when they don't all survive.This is a war story, with the great fortress of Bail's Point changing hands as the fortunes of the conflict ebb and flow. Abercrombie has done big war stories and battle narratives before and does a good job of depicting the conflict here, helped by a map of Bail's Point. However, the limited POV structure means that a great deal of the details of the conflict are missing. This is effective in giving us a feel of the fog of war, with confusion and misinformation lurking everywhere, but it does occasionally make the conflict feel murkier than it should.Abercrombie's razor-sharp characterisation is on top form here, with Skara developing believably into a ruler from humble beginnings and secondary characters like Blue Jenner and King Uthil getting outstanding and memorable moments. However, it's Father Yarvi who develops most fascinatingly in this novel. Yarvi's ruthlessness was on display in the second book, but in this one it pushes him into more and more dangerous decisions that even shock his allies. The development of Koll as his moral weathervane is nicely done; without Koll, it may be that Yarvi would have become another version of Bayaz from the First Law books (i.e. Unrepentant Amoral Bastard Gandalf). As it stands he comes pretty damn close, and it's likely any future Shattered Sea books will have to deal with the fallout from his actions.Half a War (****) closes the Shattered Sea trilogy in style, with a war story that prioritises the characters over the action and ends well by not pulling a single punch.

Laia is a Scholar, a member of the underclass subjugated by the Martial Empire in the city of Sarra. When her brother is abducted by the Martials and her grandparents murdered, Laia is reluctantly forced to ally herself with the Resistance. In return for their help in finding and rescuing her brother, Laia has to infiltrate Blackcliff Academy, where the Empire's most elite soldiers are trained.At the same time, Elias is a Mask-in-training at Blackcliff. Sickened by the Empire's callousness, he contemplates running away but is instead compelled to remain when he is prophesied to become the next Emperor and could lead the Empire into a new golden age. However, first he must pass the Trials and win the crown for himself...and must defeat his best friend in the process.An Ember in the Ashes made a bit of a stir when it was acquired by Penguin last year, winning a large advance and resulting in the film rights being sold for seven figures before it even hit the shelves. The novel also piqued my interest because it was apparently a stand-alone, with more books in the same world possible but apparently not necessary.Well, that, it turns out, was not true. An Ember in the Ashes is the first volume of a multi-part story and ends on a series of cliffhangers, so those looking for a stand-alone book are directed elsewhere. The book also feels a bit overly familiar at times: the Trials that define Elias's storyline are more than a little reminiscent of The Hunger Games while the brutal regime brought down through a reluctant female double agent reminded me more than a bit of the Mistborn trilogy. Tahir mixes up the standard tropes enough that the book never feels like a rip-off, most notably by taking the standard YA central romance and turning it into more of a tragic story of betrayal and the promise of later all-out vengeance, which is at least something a bit different.Elsewhere the book attempts a few interesting things: the novel is written in the present tense, which normally would have me hurling it out the window. However, Tahir's prose is good enough to overcome this stylistic quirk (one which a lot of readers don't have). The prose is readable but occasionally feels a bit more flavoured and distinct than the norm before settling back into something more generic. If Tahir could hold the quality of the prose at her best for longer, the sequels could be a lot better. The setting, which is more inspired by Rome than most medieval fantasy settings, also holds some promise.The most disappointing thing about An Ember in the Ashes is how standard it is. It's reasonably well-written, the setting is interesting and the characters enjoyable enough to hold the reader's attention, but the book doesn't really bring anything new to the table. It's a solid story told in a solid way which is good but not outstanding. The story and setting are a little more brutal than is normal in a YA novel, including the frown-inducing appearance of almost-rape for no apparent reason, but it's not exactly going all A Song of Ice and Fire. Some of the ideas are also rather implausible: the training for the Masks is so insanely brutal that it's likely that the Masks simply wouldn't exist due to the rate of attrition among applicants.That said, An Ember in the Ashes (***½) does hold enough promise to warrant a second look when the sequel appears.

Right after this drill got fully charged (16 hour is requested) four book cases arrived to be put together.  With the multiple drill bits included this product went without a hitch for 6 straight hours.  I did not stop to recharge until completed and the estimate for staying full charged is 10 -16 hours with a recommendation of not letting it go completely drained.The drill worked perfect as the fit in my hand was amazing and the ability to have it at an angle allowed me to get to the tight sections of shelving that needed to be put together.Very happy with the size, speed, power, and function.

Mike Reardon has been in too many tough spots to ever fear the unknown.  But being asked to go into the bowels of Mother Russia and retrieve the kidnapped daughter of a high ranking military official even gives him hesitation.  Well a little hesitation until they give him the number monetary dollars he will be paid to do this job, any delays are gone.With his team of experts in place Mike moves from one piece of the recovery to the next with the mindset that everything was going too well, something bad is going to happen.  When you expect trouble it tends to show up and when it did everything start exploding, literally all around them.  The rescue had a huge glitch with the kidnappers turning out to be much worse than described and the main target having escaped but not falling into the right hands, again.Mike never walks away from a job or a good steak and in this latest Repair Man book the action never stops and the writing is as always amazing.

I had an expectation for size, speed, cartridge capability, and all the bells and whistles that I wanted for a multi function printer.  This one hit every one of them and I am really happy with the printer from every function it offers.It does not hold an entire ream of paper but that is well documented so I mention it for someone with a lot to print at one time.

These are exactly as described in color, texture, and size.  They do need to be washed more than once to soften them up but the fit is good, matches my comforter perfectly, and seems to have helped with my allergies which was not mentioned
Exact size match to what was described, quick wash/dry and hang up no ironing as promised, and great color match for my room.

This game has always been a great time when I was a kid through now with my grandchildren.  We love to sit down and experience all the fun of family time with the extended group and show a new generation how a simple game can bring such joy.The put together is non existent and the fun is over the top

I knew what I wanted to happen and that was make my Keds white again and I had heard this product could make that happen.  Well it certainly did with simple instructions and easy to use brush to place even strokes on the shoes.There is no smell or long term drying just a short period and they are ready to wear

I love the Maggie the Laundry Hag because she is such a hot mess with every normal problem a wife and mother can have.  You add Maggie to the drama in Florida that Jackie is having with too many men in love with her and this is a mix for fun and disaster.  Maggie may be pregnant but that is not going to slow her down from getting involved with the mischief Jackie has stirring in her pot of life and between them they will figure out how to solve a mystery, get through the drama once again, and try to celebrate a holiday without setting anyone on fire.Jennifer L. Hart always brings her "A" game to a story and this one is again a winner

Great fit, feel, and flexibility with the fingers which is critical in being able to hold and manipulate the bat.  They are easy to care for and provide comfort without your hands sweating or cramping.

Great product that has a wonderful glow that will work through multiple uses.  The accessories are a nice touch for a special occasion and the seller was great at answering questions and keeping in touch.The lights were the perfect accent I was searching for

Evelyn Marrington had the life she lived with her loud and over the top family who wanted nothing more than to see her married and settled in a husband’s home.  But the existence Evie wanted was independence to be a writer of adventure novels that spoke of places she had not seen and experiences she prayed she could have.  So when her cousin brought Bennett Haile, the Earl of Somersby a member of England’s elite security agency to Evie’s home to offer up a mission she saw a way out and gave no thought to the danger she could be walking in to both physically or emotionally with Bennett.In her heart Evie knows that temporarily standing in for the Queen is a tad mis-guided as she may look like her majesty but act is another part indeed she does not possess.  Bennett believes Evie capable and will train her but the distraction of having her beauty so close and her fiery temperament stir him up is becoming an issue every moment they are together.  Always thinking he would never love again after his disastrous break up, especially to a woman with such a pushy demeanor surprises Bennett in every positive way.  But should he act on these feelings or push them aside as he is wont to do.When the adventurous mission turns dangerous Evie steps up to the challenge and will not allow anyone, especially Bennett to take her home and continue in a sheltered life.  Evie continues to amaze everyone with her ability to pick herself up and move on to the next part of this assignment all the while trying to control the burning desire that she feels for Bennett.  She knows the time with him is more dangerous than any assassin but whatever stolen moments she can have wrapped in his arms, lips locked in a loving kiss, and bodies entangled in unreserved love is worth the hurt that will come in the near future.Every book Robyn DeHart writes is an experience readers delight in from page one and UNDERCOVER WITH THE EARL is another such success.  Ms. DeHart weaves a story so amazing that you feel yourself standing in the room experiencing the adventure, watching love blossom, and ready to join whatever chaos ensues.  Thank you is never enough of a phrase to say to Robyn for writing such great works of art.My favorite line….[she] could close her eyes and imagine the sound of the paper turning, the bold print of the words beckoning her into their adventure.

This toy is out of the box entertaining for any child that can sit up and want to play.  there are small parts that I took away for use later but the sounds, songs, and lots of moving action was great joy to three ages of children who had fun for hours

Cissie Rogers never had any ill intent toward the mayor of Kettle Knob Boone Braddock, until he wanted to move her historical library to a strip mall, then all bets were off.While Cissie may harbor a very under control crush for the most handsome man ever born in Boone she will not let him take the importance out of the location of the library and ruin all her good deeds.  Yes she is very happy with her life, and yes she likes the steady flow of things, plus living with her amazing Nana keeps life busy but consistent.  Is the fear Cissie has of change or Boone in general?When her house is damaged and not only does she have to work with Boone but now she is living with him at his house the sparks not only fly they create an inferno of passion two people not prepared to keep under control.  Then Cissie decides to blind side Boone and run against him in the upcoming mayoral election and all bets are off on which side of the bed you are sleeping on.But the contest for who will be the next mayor is the least of their problems as the media finds a story in what is going on in this sleepy little town and how they can create a story where there isn’t one, or is there one and no one sees it but Cissie and Boone.  Yet the problem between them is not running against each other, or living under the same room without getting naked, it is the secret Boone has been holding on to since he was a child and feels will ruin him as a man and the mayor.

Sara Medina knew every aspect of the art world that she has become an integral part of as well as she is aware of the life on a ranch.  Sara could not leave the ranch life fast enough and now she finds herself drawn back into the day to day running all over paintings owned by a man too sexy for his own good, Jay Vermilion.  Jay came back home after his tour of duty in the Army, to fix the problems his late father created.  This included a greedy ex-wife and half-brother that want it all and to heck with what happens to the ranch.What should have been a leisure search at the paintings spread around the property Sara finds herself in a gun battles, dead bodies, and too many drama filled encounters for her liking.  She is so drawn to Jay that she would not desert him with or without the commission on the paintings and when the guns for hire take aim at her she knows she is now a part of the past that will not be put to rest quietly.Jay will not let anything happen to the gift of Sara he has been rewarded with and using every skill he learned in the Army has him not only on high alert but also with a perfect aim ready to shoot down trouble.  His estranged family may be the culprit, but would even they resort to murder over a painting?  Every moment with Sara continues to entrance Jay to the point of wondering how will he be able to let her go when her time here is over.

Lorie Kauffmann felt she lost everything when her father died and was shocked to find her strict Amish father died in a car accident when the Amish did not own cars.  This turn of events rocked everything she believed in and made her want to know who her father really was and where he came from.  Lorie had a good life with her step mother and blended family but something was not right about the past her father kept hidden and the present life he led in secret that violated so many of their religious beliefs.As Lorie started her deep dive into the father she thought she knew it brought up a life prior to his becoming Amish in an English world with relatives and discoveries she could never have imagined.  While her father’s family was interesting the discovery of a grandmother was mind boggling and something in Lorie made he keep pushing past the point where she knew she should stop.The wonder of everything in the English world is mesmerizing to her including Zach Calhoun the man who is introducing her to all the life she could never have touched without pushing outside of her Amish life.  The other magic that was created with all the stress of her discoveries was the wonderful art work Lorie created from her deepest internal passions.  Lorie felt trapped in her Amish world and drawn to the English one where she could have Zach and the ability to create works of art.  What would she do with all this intense push and pull because Lorie knows she cannot be in both worlds and choosing one over the other seems an impossibility.

Hot shot bomb defused Evie Jimenez has made few mistakes in her life, but when she does they cost people their lives which is not acceptable.  When she is called in to investigate the Angel Bomber Evie has a gut feeling that something is beyond the overall appearance of what is going on exists.  She is the best at what she does but this time there is a distraction in the form of Jack Elliott who is too rich and powerful for his own good.  Evie knows something has him shaken to the core about these bombings and Evie is going to figure it all out and catch the killer before she is done.Jack is everything that Evie finds frustrating in a man so why is she so attracted to him and his over bearing ways?  He follows her every step, questions her decisions, and is proving to be excessively helpful in getting answers which is a complete irritation on every level.  Can Evie think clearly when he stands so close to her, heck no but she is a trained bomb defuser so it will happen and right now, maybe.As the pieces start to fit together and the profile leads back to a past Jack had put aside many years ago Evie peels away one layer of the psychopath’s plan at a time.  She is meticulous about her research and the details on how to find the bomber knowing one bad move could literally blow everything up in her face.  The clock is ticking with the latest victim chosen and a plan put in place that risks everything including Evie if it does not work.

Every piece of bedding is a mandatory one for a crib or play are set up.  The waterproof padding and mattress pad are perfect fits and adding the sheet and blankets for comfort and warmth are amazing to fulfill the set up.They wash and dry with quick order and the stains came right out even using the mildest detergent.Enjoy

This toy is interactive, engaging and the remote control creates additional fun with the toy.  Thomas the Train is a hit with every age of a child through the learning phases so having their own train speak to them and then turn about here and there is great fun.

I am a repeat of the Remington product owners so I anticipated this would work as expected and it did.  The color is great, the accessories perfect, the heat setting work on all hair types and the fan speed selections accommodate whatever level of drying you look to accomplish.The latest update is a texture that keeps the hair dryer from falling off the shelf or dresser you lay it on.  Which is a huge help when you trip over the cord.

Amazing!Out of the box and ready to be played with for a fun Star Wars time.  The little pieces are a danger to the smaller kids but the bigger child will enjoy the entire product.Well constructed for abuse and everything fits right back inside the ship which makes for easier storage.

First off, I must say that I'm very impressed by how the contents of this book were presented to us readers. It is well and carefully written.The content itself was exactly what it was told to be - a dictionary that gives quality ideas of what your dreams could mean from A to Z. The author doesn't go to illogical heights about the dreams, but rather gives realistic explanations. Even the text outside the dream keywords and their possible meanings is very nicely put to paper.Thank you for writing this book, Dhara. I will recommend it to my friends and hope to see more books by you.

I love to cook with a crock pot and I am always looking for new recipe ideas. I never thought of using my crockpot for a Christmas dinner. I was cutious to see the recipes in this new book by Bree Griffin. I am glad I did because I pick up several delicious recipes that I will be making over the holidays. There are plenty of recipes to chose from including warm drinks, appetizers and sides,  main dishes, and holiday treats.I made the Chocolate Peanuts the drops and the kids loved them, best of all, they were so easy to do. I can't wait to try the fruity Roast Pork, the Cheesy Chicken Meal, the Vegetarian Pot Pie, Mint Potatoes, and the Caramel Apples.Overall, the cookbook is well written and presented. Each recipe comes with concise instructions to prepare your recipe. I like that the author has nutritional information per serving for each recipe. This book is a great acquisition to my growing collection and will be my goto book for slow cooking this holiday season.

I love to entertain during the holiday season and always do the same couple of recipes. But this year I am planing to get out of my comfort zone and try new recipes. I am glad I found Holiday Parties Made Easy from Bree Griffin. There are lots of recipe to chose from and it has given me many new ideas. The recipes look delicious and easy enouht to prepare. There are recipes for appetizers, salads, main dishes, desserts, and even drinks.I have already chosen the menu for my dinner party with to start off the Cheesy Bake and the Stuffed mushrooms, for the salad I would like to make the Hot Apple Salad, and for the main, it's a toss between the Glazed Salmon and the Turkey Stroganoff. For dessert it's always hard to choose, I hesitate between the chocolate Éclairs and the Pecan Tart...maybe I'll do both ahead of time. And a holiday celebration always call for holiday cheers with an Egg Nog or some Mulled Cider.Overall, the cookbook is well written and the recipes are easy to make thanks to clear and concise instructions. There is also nutritional information for each recipe. Highly recommend for anyone wanting to get some easy to make recipes for the holidays and any time of the year.

Wicca Essential Practitionar Guide to Wicca for Beginers, Wiccan Spells and Witchcraft is an interesting book to start your study of Wicca. The author starts by explaining what Wicca is and is not, what are the various Wiccan traditions, describe in detail what the concept of deity is and how to become a witch or wiccan. And then, what I like best are the spells that you can learn to cast. There are banishing spells, protections spells, clensing spells, and more. I found the book very interesting especially the part on the different type of Wicca, because it shows the history and the different traditions that have been descending from a long time ago. The book is easy to read and well presented. Well worth reading if you are interested in the subject.

My son's been wanting to learn to play chess and honestly I would know where to begin to show him how as I am not a player myself. I am glad I found this book because it's a great beginner's guide to chess. The author explains all we need to know to become a good chess player. This includes the basics of chess, understanding the rules, the openings, the strategy, tactics and playing the endgame. Overall, the book is well presented and easy to understand. I feel I can now teach my son to play and play with him. Well worth reading for anyone interested in learning to play chess.

I am planning a family trip to Cuba shortly and was looking for a guide to give me more insight into the country. I am glad I found Diego Silvano's book. It's a great starting point to discover this warm and friendly country. The book has general facts about Cuba, traveller'advices, place to see, things to do and more. I especially like the chapter on practical things to know when travelling to Cuba. Well worth reading.

This book amply describes the way of the DASH(Dietary Approach to Stop Hypertension) diet. From explaining why certain things are to be had in what numbers and why they are good or bad, to making a profound plan for implementing the routine. Furthermore, it contains well-written recipes that are to go with all this so you don't have to search for them elsewhere. I've tried many of them and they turned out to be great, in addition to obviously being the right recipes for lowering my blood pressure and weight. I especially found the combination of Cabbage Flat Breads and the Beet Root Curry(with Coconut) impressive.I warmly recommend this Nick Bell's book to everyone who has a need for a healthier diet and is fighting against hypertension.

We rarely paid any attention to our emotional health in ourselves and others but nowadays it's easier than ever to start discovering and, if needed, healing our emotional health. This book was interesting and a good starting point to realize the importance of emotional health. The author makes it simple to understand and has a list of signs good emotional health. I like the way the author approach each topic with a step-by-step approach. In particular the 6 steps to learn to deal with feeling of emptiness was useful and a good takeaway for some of my relatives who has shown signs of loneliness. The subject of letting go of anger and negative emotions is well discussed as well as a 5 step approach to learn how to monitor your emotional health. I thought the chapter on developing the habits of happier people was very interesting and had not thought of this before. Overall, the book is short and easy to read with a straight to the point style. Well worth reading on a subject often neglected.

I enjoyed reading this book on how to develop your psychic abilities. I like the approch of the author that suggest to develop your abilities slowly and keeping your mind calm. The subjects of developping meditative abilities, being able of empaty, trusting your instincts, listening to your quiet voice, getting strong mentaly are all discussed to help you achieve your potential toward mediumship. I got a lot of tips and advice from this book to develop the basic tools needed to contact spirits and develop your full potential as a medium. Best advices from the book is keep practicing, developping and stay pure in intent if you want to achieve your goals of communicating with spirits. This book is a good starting point for anyone interested in the subject.

I was delighted when I saw that Mike Riley had published a new book. and I am happy to say that this is another Mike Riley's book that I enjoyed reading. This one goes beyond the typical serial killers and presents 5 cases of couples/partners in crime committing terrible crimes. Each case is well detailed and we get the whole picture including the timeline of the murders and crimes committed, the backstory, the detailed accounts of the crimes, the investigation, the trial and the current status. I like the way Riley presents each case, it makes it clear to imagine exactly what happened and how these horrific events took place. The best is that these 5 cases are very different from one another, making it seems like you are reading 5 different books at the same time. The Bonnie and Clyde story gave a reality check to the "romantic" vision I had of those two partners in crime. The other 4 cases, I had not heard about and was fascinated by the spy story of the Rosenberg and the unthinkable actions of Fred and Rose West. How could they have gotten away with decades of crimes and murders without being uncovered is beyond belief. The viscious nature of the human being is revealed in the case of Baguss and Lahane, how can someone be so hateful and enjoy torturing another human being is beyond words. Great choices of cases to read.If you like true crime and enjoy reading about extreme cases, you will enjoy this new book from Mike Riley. The book is wel written and researched.  Highly recommended. I look forward reading more books from this author.

I really enjoyed reading Fading Light - Post-Apocalyptic Fantasy Fiction . If you like apocalypse scenario, this is a book for you. It has all sort of twist and turns. The caracters are well develop and interesting. You wonder what is real and what is not. I can't wait to read the follow-up book to know what happened. I also like the author's style, fast past and lots of action going on at the same time. Great reading.

If you like short sexy romance, you'll enjoy reading An Unplanned Romance. The characters of Angela and Ethan are interesting and well developped by the author. The story has nice twists to it and sexy romance descriptions. Fun reading, can't wait to read the next book and see what happens.

I got this book for my niece who wants to start a family. After reading it first, I thought the book was well organized with advices before conception, to conceive and also using natural herbs as fertility boosters. Well worth reading for any woman wanting to start a family.

I had no idea how to grow weed in your own garden or home. The author share 2 method of growing marijuana. The first one involves growing from seeeds or from clones. He then covers in detail each method from the soil preparation to the harvesting and in the case of cloning how to prepare the clone. I really like that there is a section on the most common mistake to avoid so you can create a good harvest that you can enjoy. I had no idea it could be that easy to grow weed.I especially like thre tips the authors shares for growing weed like being aware of special requirement your strain may need, lighting, soil preferences, fertilizer, harvest, watering, etc.There is an interesting chapter on tips for harvesting and curing your marijuana including the 2 levels for curing the fried buds and how to store you weed. There is also advices on controlling the aroma of marijuana which can be useful like indoor or carbon filters.If you want to grow weed then this book is a good starting point for beginners

I enjoyed reading this book on willpower. I know it's one of the thing I have to work on to get more discipline and go to the gym on a regular basis. The author start by explaining what is willpower and uncovering the psychological aspects of it. He talks about drive, determination, self-control as well as giving warning of Will power exhaustion when you use it too much. I especially liked the chapter on how to develop will power and discipline. I realized that I need to find a more convincing focus if I want to improve my discipline and many more tips and strategies to improve your will power.I really like the strategy of starting with small tasks and decisions. There is also an interesting chapter on how to overcome hurdles and decision fatigue which I think play a big role on how much will power one person can have. I learned some new stategies to use to improve my discipline and resisting to temptations. Overall, the book is well written and easy to follow. Well worth reading.

This book about positive attitude is just that how to live our live with a positive attitude. To illustrate the concept of having a positive the author start by taking 3 people with each different circumstances and it's interesting as you can relates to these characters. There is a list of benefits to a positive attitude. Then you have the techniques of used to be more positive including meditation, cultivate an attitude of gratitude, making a good deed every day, enjoy moving and being active, adopting healthy behaviors, following your passions and dreams, surrounding yourself with happiness, mastering the art of gratitude. These are all part of a positive attitude and there are some great tips in the book to expand our positive attitude. A lot of what the author explains make sense. The book is well written and straight to the point. Key take away, positive attitude does make a difference in your life if you want to be happy.

This book was an interesting reading about developping your psychic abilities. I have had many déjà vu experience and never thought much about it beside having the weird feeling about it when it happens never knowing this was an opening to my psychic abilities. This book has a list of identifying elements of psychic abilities. Then the author presents an interesting chapter about the key to intuition. But my favorite part of the was the chapters on tips to develop my psychic ability and read other people mind. I like the author's approach of having good intentions when developping your psychic abilities. Finally, there is also a crash course on chakras and how to open your crown chakra to increase your psychic powers. Overall, the book is well worth reading for anyone interested in psychic abilities without going into black magick or withchcraft.

This is an interesting book to read if you are planning getting financing for your new business plan. Knowing how to organize your business plan is what this book is all about with step by step method to writte your plan. It will make you aware of evry aspect of your business including the analysis of your strenghts and weaknesses as well as opportunities and threats in your market. I like the fact that the author suggest having an exist plan. Overall, the book is well written and straight to the point. Well worth reading.

This is an interesting reading. I knew nothing about self-myofascial release techniques to manage muscular pain. The author does a good job describing what the technique is. You have it for shoulder pain, hip pain, buttock pain, and general massage. There is also a section about other variation of myofascial release and for other muscle groups. There is also a list of pros and cons of self-healing myofascial release as well as tips. If you have pain, this an interesting reading. It’s short and to the point. The description are well written and instructionsfor the technique easy to follow.

HTML has always been a scary thing for me. I am happy to say that with this book it's much easier than it sounds. I learned the HTMl terminology, how to understand the elements and tags, how attributes work and much more. I especially like that the author tells you what mistake to avoid and has a step by step approch on what to do with the basic page structure. I was able to follow on my computer at the same time I was reading the book which made it more visual. The book has all the basic fundamentals you need to learn to code in HTML and it is clearly describe and easy to follow. Great for any beginner like myself.

As a huge fan of the Blue Plague series I was certainly looking forward to the next book in that series.  Instead, I see Mr. Watson has decided to once again expand into a new genre and try his hand at fantasy.  Well, he definitely scored on this one.The story started off a little slow as the author set up the cast of characters and I was pleasantly pleased with Mr. Watson's world building efforts.  Though we see a world with some resemblance to the Tolkien stories, this is way different and is not by any stretch a "Lord of the Rings" tale here.  These characters are written as living, dynamic personalities, with their own strengths and weaknesses.  The good guys are heroic but also capable of being casual, funny, petty and spiteful, just like real people.  Mr. Watson is also a past master at creating believable supporting characters and his work in this book is no exception.  More Michi!  Just saying.The fight scenes are fast paced and filled with crazy action as weapons of both steel and magic get equal use here.  This is a book where you get to the end and realize, oh no, now I've got to wait months for the next installment!  If you enjoy Mr. Watson's quirky sense of humor and like hard edged, well written action with a heart, then this one is will hit the spot.  Bravo!William Allen

I love Mr. Reeder's take on zombies.  Much more laid back than most, and the really bad guys are the ones still breathing.  This little story is like a mission statement for more books hopefully to come.  Plus, I gotta give a loud hoot of enjoyment for the "Smith scene" at the beginning of the story.  I could actually see folks jaded by the conflict, even good people, doing just that with a dumba$$ that won't listen.  Fans of the first book and the continuing series will enjoy.  Well, except complain that it is too short, but then we want all our favorite authors to write 400+ pages of fun.  At 99 cents, this is a steal and a nice way to spend a little time while waiting for John & Co.'s next adventure.  More please.

Start to finish, probably one of the greatest and most exciting novels of this genre.  This is a companion piece though not exactly a sequel to "Hard Roads" and they can be read separately,  This is an apocalyptic adventure, but is much more as well.  Parts read like a western and other parts are science fiction, but everything works together to make for one heck of a read.  I am hungry for more Annie and hope Mr. McDonald gets back to get story soon.Also, don't miss the "Hard Roads" prequel, "The Machine".  I am not much for prequels but this one is worth the time and money.

This is an exciting, well written story authored by someone who knows what he is talking about.  That is, whether through experience of research, the story resonates with authenticity as the events unfold.  I am on pins and needles waiting for the second book to arrive, and I hope the author is able to keep the tension level at the same fever pitch.  We done, Mr. McAliley.

This is a fast paced and very fulfilling story that leaves the door open for the next installment.  Needs an editor, but the technical stuff looks good and the author has a good sense of pacing.  I'm waiting for Book Two.

Anyone familiar with this author's work knows he can write a short, blockbuster story that gets to the point and delivers a serious kick to the head.  HIs latest story here takes that talent to the next level.  Told through the eyes of the title character, I wasn't sure I even liked her until about halfway through the story, but I could not put down my Kindle.  The story is riveting and has so many twists and turns I found myself having to go back and reread a sentence to make sure I got everything.  This story will make you laugh, cry, and want to hide behind the couch.  I can't wait for the next installment from Mr. McDonald.  Check it out.
Zoe is a sweet 17 year old girl who makes an even sweeter zombie in this well written and entertaining sequel.  Left me hungry for more.

This has to rank as one the bests novels written by this author.  Gritty, painful at times and bristling with creative wit, this book addresses some key issues dating back to the first book in the series.  This one has it all, including an ending so touching, and so gripping, that I held my breath for several pages.  Read it.

This edition combines two of author Terry McDonald's best stories in one convenient package.  This is a good value as you get Hard Roads and Annie Higgins together.  If you like believable sci-fi and hard edged action, give this combo a try.

This latest entry in the Zombie Crusade series left me feeling worn out by the non-stop action and heart wrenching tale.  This carefully crafted story checked all the boxes for me and now I cannot wait for the next installment.  Bravo Mr. Vohs.

This photo printer is for people who are serious about printing photos. If you just want to print out some snapshots instead of going to the store, this printer may not be for you. However, if you want high quality photos with great detail (assuming it was great when taken) printed on high quality paper with high quality ink, this printer will impress you. The printer is small and easy to take with you. You will spend more money printing with this printer than other cheaper "photo" printers. However, this is a case where you get what you pay for.

This is the best polarizer I have ever used...hands down. If you are looking for a high quality polarizer, I would highly suggest getting this one which has the Nano coating. The Nano coating is worth the price difference. The difference between this polarizer and other cheaper ones I have used is day and night...literally. If you have never used a polarizer, you will be blown away by the new shots you will be able to get using it. Seriously, it's worth the money.

I was wanting a non-privacy screen protector for my phone, and was able to get this Otterbox to review. The first thing I noticed was the quality of the screen protector, it's not some flimsy paper thick plastic like some of the cheaper ones available. Installation was easy and quick. The screen protector has not adversely affected my usage, so I am happy.

If you are looking for privacy, this is a fantastic screen protector. I wasn't sure if I believed the marketing or not, but sure enough you can't see the phone screen from the side. It is easy to install and easy to remove, which I was worried about. The only downside is that you will need to increase the brightness on your phone, but if you are needing this for privacy, I doubt you will mind. Excellent product.

These are good latex free gloves that have been durable enough for me for multiple uses. I am personally not allergic to latex, but I know many that are, so for any projects I like to have some latex free available. Good quality gloves at a good price. No complaints here.

This is the newest version of Office, and does not require annual renewal like Office 365. It does limit you to 1 computer usage, but I think for the price it's not a bad deal. I removed an older Office version (2013) and installed this version. Installation was easy on my Windows 10 laptop. You do need to download the installer from the Microsoft website. This card basically contains the license you use on the website. Overall it's not much of a learning curve from Office 2013 in my opinion.

I am usually pretty hard on paint sprayers as far as review purposes go, but I was impressed with this PaintWiz First, they don't try to mislead you with the product description. This paint sprayer is meant for thin materials, and they say that in the description. I have seen other brands mislead customers on this kind of thing. This sprayer performed quite well spraying both stain and lacquer. Cleanup was easy as well. I do wish they would make the cords longer on these units, but it is about average or better than other products so I can't deduct for that. Overall, a great handheld sprayer for jobs that it was sold to perform.

This case not only looks great,but it feels great too. I am using an S-view cover on my Note 5 at the moment, but wanted to try out a wallet case.
