If you're the type who doesn't need a Xanax after your dead husband comes home (well... sort of your dead husband, but not really), then this flick is tailored for you.✘ Bait and switch: I signed up for sci-fi and got "Rambo's Need For Speed" instead.✘ If you are experiencing unpredictable, debilitating side effects from your brain transplant (I'm sure it's not as bad as it sounds), you should probably let your wife do the driving (Is she really his wife though? I mean, it's just his body. Do you marry someone's body, or their brain? I suspect most people marry for the body).✘ "After teaching you how to swim, pumpkin, Daddy's going to teach you how to scorch down a grownup with a flamethrower and execute people with headshots."✘ Is anyone else tired of movies that wrap up all the loose ends so neatly that you have to wonder if anything was amiss to begin with? I wouldn't be surprised if Self/less is a sad instance of the screenwriter who wrote something of substance that was subsequently butchered by the studio. Execs, in case you didn't get the memo: Riding off into the sunset is a 20th century gimmick.2.5 stars at best; Ryan Reynolds does well with what he was given, but science fictions fans will be disappointed (I can't speak for action flick enthusiasts).

These remind me of the yellow-tinted glasses I used as a bicycle messenger, which clarified my vision on grey days and when working into the night. These Marrywindix glasses also have a tint to them, which is either a Pro or a Con (depends on if you like to go thru life with tinted glasses).PROs✔ Eye health being threatened by blue light from computer screens is a real thing, if you don't believe me then read about it in the Harvard Health Letter: www.health.harvard.edu/staying-healthy/blue-light-has-a-dark-side✔ These Marrywindix glasses are comfortable. I have a relatively big head (literally and figuratively), and they still fit. If you have a *really* big head, then caveat emptor: these are rigid and won't flex to fit you.✔ I've limited credentials as a fashionista, but for what it's worth: these are stylish.✔ Comes in a handy storage/travel case.CONs✘ I won't be using these for gaming. The rims and tint prevent total immersion in games.👓 I wear these while on the web or using software on my PCs, and they seem to make a difference. I received them from the friendly people at Marrywindix in exchange for my honest opinion. 👓

On par with Bron/Broen (The Bridge), here's a similarly top notch production released on the Nordic Noir label. In contrast to The Bridge, The Killing excels at casting doubt on nearly every character introduced, to the point where the only person you are sure didn't commit the murder is Sarah Lund, the central protagonist.Bemusement reigns over not only the murder, but also other plotlines like the source of leaks in a political party (season 1). Starring Sofie Grbøl, the acting is to be commended for nearly everyone involved. The cinematography is absolutely fantastic; less gritty than Bron/Broen, but capturing more color, vitality, and emotion. I urge you to consider the Blu-ray (if you have a player that can handle region B/2) release for this reason.I had no idea there was an American remake of this series until just now when I read another review posted here. I can't imagine it being better than the original, but since "for some reason [Americans] cannot read subtitles, or they don't want to" (not my words, but Sofie Gråbøl's), it exists if you really can't abide subtitles.My only complaint about Forbrydelsen, and it is extremely minor: episodes begin with a recap lasting ~2.5 minutes. Do Danes have poor memories?As for price, it's easy to complain about it based on Amazon's US site. However, you can get this compilation of all 3 seasons for much cheaper (DVD or Blu-ray) if you go to Amazon's UK site (I'm assuming you already have a player that can handle foreign regions if you are considering this listing).Final thoughts: A set of prototypical Danish programming that's as good a place to start as any if you are new to Nordic Noir serials, and reasonably priced if you buy from overseas.

↷ spoiler-free comments ↶If you aren't suffering from post-apocalyptic scenario burnout syndrome, then this *might* be worth your time. It's basically science fiction of the "last man on Earth" (no, not the comedy) variety. Air manages to run the gamut of man vs. man, man vs. himself, and man vs. nature, but mostly on a superficial level (i.e., philosophy you might expect from this type of sci-fi is conspicuously absent). While the skeleton is set up to make us expect big things, there just isn't much meat on the bones. If Air were a meal, you'd likely still be hungry after watching it.You get the impression that Reedus was doing Air between scenes for The Walking Dead (TWD), because it's almost as if he walked off the TWD set and onto the Air set not wanting to depart too far out of Daryl Dixon mode (even his hair remains the same). Rather than a strikingly different character from the one we all know on TWD, we just get a Daryl who thinks less and talks more. Djimon Hounsou did a fine job as the counterpoint character. The soundtrack is decent, ranging from almost retro (reminiscent of Tangerine Dream) to more traditional and contemporary sci-fi incidental noise.Final thoughts: Sadly, Air doesn't break new ground. It may be worth seeing if [1] you are head over heels for Reedus, or/and [2] you're a diehard sci-fi fan, and/or [3] you have a post-apocalyptic fetish.

Sometimes I miss the LES, so I'm always up for watching films purportedly shot there, and I also favor movies in the vein [excuse the pun] of Drugstore Cowboy, so was hoping Straight Outta Tompkins (SOT) would fit the bill in that respect too. After watching it on DVD, I'm still on the fence as to whether it was a waste of time.A guy named Zephyr Benson was the screenwriter, director, producer, and [you guessed it] the lead role. Ambitious is certainly a word that applies here, yet I can't help but wonder if narcissistic is another. Control freak, maybe? With a reported $160k budget, he probably didn't have much choice in how many hats he needed to wear for getting SOT done.Whatever the case, I've seen this done before, as with Noel Clarke's Adulthood (Noel was writer, director, and lead). Whereas Adulthood is a winner, the intent of SOT will be lost on many. Dark comedy? Just Say No To Drugs? One can't take it too seriously since the drug use in SOT is so over the top. Some provocative social commentary in the first 5 minutes is followed by some edgy Half Bakedesque material, which leads to a heavy-handed downward spiral into white powders and violence for the final hour.The cinematography (by Brandon Roots) is unmistakably killer, and the video quality (for a DVD) is excellent.The acting is very hit or miss; one bright spot is newcomer Jon McCormick as Sam (newcomer to film, it looks like he's done stage acting). Whoopi Goldberg makes a cameo for a couple minutes, but other than that you won't recognize faces.Rating SOT at 3 stars may be charitable, but given that it was done on a shoestring budget in a very expensive city, Zephyr deserves some slack.Final Verdict: Not bad as a dark comedy, but I suspect it was intended as a drama.

Another top notch production from the Nordic Noir label, on par with Bron/Broen (The Bridge). In contrast to The Bridge, The Killing excels at casting doubt on nearly every character introduced, to the point where the only person you are sure didn't commit the murder is Sarah Lund, the protagonist.Bemusement reigns over not only the murder, but also other plotlines like the source of leaks in a political party (season 1). Starring Sofie Gråbøl, the acting is to be commended for nearly everyone involved. The cinematography is absolutely fantastic; less gritty than Bron/Broen, but capturing more color, vitality, and emotion.I had no idea there was an American remake of this series until just now when I read another review posted here. I can't imagine it being better than the original, but since "for some reason [Americans] cannot read subtitles, or they don't want to" (not my words, but Sofie Gråbøl's), it exists if you really can't abide subtitles.My only complaint about Forbrydelsen, and it is extremely minor: episodes begin with a recap lasting ~2.5 minutes. Do Danes have poor memories?This box set of prototypical Danish programming is highly recommended, and it's as good a place to start as any if you are new to Nordic Noir serials.

Bright and colorful, yet compact.In the past I tried to induce a pleasant purple aura into my living space by installing Computer Case Cooling Fans into one of my PCs, but while they looked okay, they were noisy.With these light-emitting diodes from Niutop, I now have an ethereal purple emanating from 180 tiny points of light.I was surprised when these arrived, because after opening the package I found that the coiled string of LEDs fit into the palm of my hand. Don't let size fool you though: these are potent and brilliant, casting a beautiful purple haze onto the wall (not overpowering, but brighter than the pictures here lead you to believe).The winding silver wire that links the LEDs ranges from nearly invisible to pleasantly illuminated, depending on how you use the string (you should experiment a little to find the right configuration for your needs).A nice feature is the detachable power supply unit (you may not consider it a benefit until you find out that it is).Every night is a party at my house thanks to these LEDs.

This is the English-subtitled version of Real Humans, the show that started it all and has been sold to numerous countries for remakes (such as Channel 4/AMC's Humans). A reminder that this set was pressed in Region 4 format, so plan accordingly.Here's a quick comparison of Real Humans versus Humans. In Real Humans:🎭 The androids and known as Hubots rather than Synths.🎭 More information is revealed to the audience up front; for example, the exact nature of the relationship between "Anita" and Leo remains undefined for most of the season in Humans. If you like mystery, watch Humans prior to watching Real Humans.🎭 The tone is both darker and (paradoxically) more humorous. Not only a bloody season premier, but a greater sense of urgency and an "us against them" mentality. An example of the humor is when David Eischer's android children walk into an abandoned church for refuge and one of them, aghast upon seeing Jesus on the crucifix (for the first time), exclaims "Disgusting!"🎭 Niska is the undisputed leader of free androids (when Leo isn't around). While Niska in Humans has a fierce streak that we occasionally see, Niska in Real Humans is a robot you do not want to mess with.🎭 The philosophical points are more readily expressed, such as Inger (Laura in Humans) expressing herself to and about Anita; additionally, Hubots replacing humans (in companionship, in the workforce) is more front and center.So which is better, Real Humans or Humans? That is almost impossible to answer, because depending on which one you watch first, the other will probably seem flawed (The same dilemma as happened with Being Human and Being Human). The British production is a bit more polished than the Swedish one, yet each has details lacking in the other (i.e., watch both!)

🏰 2 things before getting down to business:1. For the love of whatever deity or demigod you align yourself with, don't rate a movie at 1 star because you failed to read the item description. When you purchase imported movies like this one, make sure beforehand that your equipment will play discs with the region code noted in the description... it's not rocket science.2. Disclaimer: I haven't played D&D since the 1980s (yeah, I am old... although I prefer the term OG), so can't vouch for the movie's authenticity in conforming to current D&D rules and pantheon. A bag of holding is used by the hero; while other references to the game were mostly lost on me, there apparently are plenty of nods to the true campaigner.🏰 Now, the Pros and Cons if you are considering this purchase:Lawful Good (PROs)✔ Although not issued on Blu-ray, this is no reason to despair: The transfer to DVD is excellent.✔ While at times the movie feels homemade, the actors are at least actual actors... far from Game of Thrones quality, but acceptable.✔ Characters: all but one of the characters in the adventuring party are evil, which distinguishes this movie from Dungeons and Dragons 2: Wrath Of The Dragon God. The Vermin Lord is particularly well done, yet each in the party has personality, so to speak.✔ Plenty of eye candy, whatever your tastes: a chiseled, devastatingly handsome Paladin (Grayson) who likes to take off his shirt, and the obligatory ravishing female protagonist (a Shadar-Kai witch named Akordia), who in this case is leading the party (due to her badassness).Lawful Evil (CONs)✘ The plot was nothing mind-bending; at least we get a sexual tension dynamic between Grayson and Akordia (good boy meets bad girl), which keeps D&D3 from simply repeating the plot of D&D2 (but which makes it more like West Side Story).✘ Maybe I expect too much, but the ending was anticlimactic... nor did it set the stage for a sequel, which I surely would watch if Eleanor Gecks were to reprise her role as Akordia.✘ When you watch Game of Thrones, you don't find yourself seeing objects as props, or places as sets. The same can't always be said here. Not surprising since HBO throws $6M (average) at *each* episode of GoT and focuses on producing exquisite sets for the show. You really notice the difference when you see productions which aren't as well-funded and don't procure the talent.🏰 This movie can be watched on YouTube if you don't mind lousy picture quality (and probably commercials).Final thoughts: Is it unusual for a Lawful Good character band up with a party of Chaotic and Lawful Evil adventurers as a means to an end? I'll let someone who knows the rules answer since I haven't played the game for three decades.

News Flash: any food or drink can be toxic... it depends on how much you consume. Case in point: Water, overconsumption of which can kill you via electrolyte disruption. As another reviewer already pointed out, "can" is the operative word in this book. You "can" be killed by lightning when you leave the house during an electrical storm. That is good to know, but it is more useful to know your chances of being killed by lightning. Substances you choose to put into your body "can" do all kinds of things. Will they? That's what Marina Kushner fails to adequately address. She does explain the how, what, and why, but there are way too many leaps in logic and theoretical scenarios (I say this as a scientist).I consume 2 shots of espresso daily; my dose of caffeine is static. The problem with any potentially addictive substance is the temptation to increase dosage to compensate for tolerance (this is obviously a trap to avoid).There are maybe 2 reasons to buy this book:1. If you are incapable of drinking in moderation, this might be useful to "scare yourself straight."2. If you are oblivious as to what foods and drugs may contain caffeine, and what "moderation" means (and you don't know how to do an internet search).☕

PROs✔ A tale steeped in inter and intrapersonal conflicts (often borne out of political ones), with a twisty plot tying characters together usually on more than one level. This is a narrative of divided loyalties, which leads to some tricky relationships.✔ Indian Summers does pretty well in transporting you back in time, which is naturally of paramount importance for historical FICTION.✔ The writers don't pull their punches; the disparaging attitude of the Brits towards the Indians is captured unflinchingly.✔ Indian Summers was renewed for a second season, so feel free to get attached to the characters.✔ The actors! The primary reason I bought this as soon as it became available on DVD in the UK is because Jemima West is my favorite actress, and lucky us: she is Alice, sister to the central British character, Ralph (Henry Lloyd-Hughes). I was pleased to meet Amber Rose Revah as Leena Prasad, who is easily more telegenic than 90% of Hollywood's actresses. Plus some handsome fellas, if that's your thing. In contrast to her placement on the cover art, the role of Julie Walters is not front and center, although her character is quite the socialite.✔ Indian Summers is likelier to make you want to crack open a history book to learn more than is Downton Abbey.CONs✘ It was shot in Malaysia, not India. While I didn't mind this commonplace inconsistency (if I had a buck for every production filmed in a location different from the one it portrayed, I'd be able to retire), this choice apparently has garnered wrath in some quarters.📀 I purchased this season on Amazon's UK site, regrettably before I became aware of the Blu-ray release. The picture quality of the UK-released [Region 2] DVD set is disappointing. The US [Region 1] DVD release, which has the PBS ribbon across the top of the cover, is encoded differently than the UK release (it's on 4 discs rather than 3) so *may* have a superior picture. I will probably buy the Blu-ray for a second viewing of the season.📀 From the back cover of the DVD:"The year is 1932, the place is India, and the people are romanticized, politicized, and radicalized. They are drawn together and driven apart by class, race, love and theft, and the world around them is changing. In the small British colony of Simla, placed at the foothills of the Himalayas, the beliefs of the British Empire still remain but the young are hungry for freedom.Indian Summers tells a sweeping saga; stories of love, secrets, promises made and broken, and tensions that simmer in the hot, feverish days and nights of India -- an India populated by freedom fighters, star-crossed lovers, political spies, artists, orphans, expats, the rich and the poor."

While the pace of Red Knot is fairly glacial [excuse the pun], this intentional cadence was set to match life on the ship and its surroundings. The trailer (as one of the extras on the DVD) suggests that the love triangle is the plot; instead, the captain (Billy Campbell) is more of an incidental rather than a pivotal character. Billy Campbell is one of those actors with a face you'll recognized despite not knowing where you saw it... for me it was The 4400 (as Jordan Collier).As for the other actors, this is a chance for you to see what Vincent Kartheiser is like outside of Mad Men, and Red Knot is as good an introduction to Olivia Thirlby (What Goes Up) as any of the numerous other indie films she's had an important role in.Real-life husband & wife Roger Payne and Lisa Harrow round out the cast. Roger Payne (not an actor, he's instead been in several documentaries) is a famous whale biologist, and snipets of dialogue between him and Vincent Kartheiser are artfully interwoven into the story, giving Red Knot just the slightest residue of a PBS science/ ecology show.The scenes were skillfully edited, strung together creatively but logically. Accorded with a fitting economy of dialogue, words were not said when words were not needed. The composer for the soundtrack hit all the right notes and captured the Antarctic about as well as can be anticipated.PG-13? Not even: the newlywed sex scene is so tame that Red Knot might earn a PG rating from the MPAA (if it were to be rated). That said, the movie isn't for kids (it would bore them).Before ordering I was unhappy that Red Knot isn't offered on Blu-ray, but as it turns out, the transfer to DVD is flawless. As decent as it was, I now feel the need to travel and experience Antarctica firsthand.Extras:Too often, DVD extras are relegated to just the dang movie trailer. Not so here. There are 2 interviews with Scott Cohen (screenwriter/ director/ producer for Red Knot), one with Vincent Kartheiser, and one with composer Garth Stevenson. Although brief, these bonus features are revealing for audiences and filmmakers alike.🚢 Final verdict: this was a successful experiment of putting a small cast and film crew together on a ship at the edge of the world for 23 days and having something come out of it that can be enjoyed by more than just those who participated in the adventure.

This is a useful tool, most particularly because it's a multi-tasker. Comfortable to hold, rechargeable, multiple interchangeable heads for different needs, including one for exfoliating your feet (which does a very good job, by the way). I'm less enthusiastic about the shavers. There is some pinching. I didn't find it as miserable as some reviewers, but there were some "ow" moments. And the build quality is not bad, but it doesn't seem like it should be priced at $80.It's okay.

Simple form and function, yes.Quality we expect from Bose, yes.The great sound we expect from Bose, yes.Turn it on by tapping the button-free top of the radio as you walk by or by using a small remote control, yes.Bluetooth? It is optional and a separate purchase, so out of the box, no. Use a 3.5mm cord (not included) to connect from your device's headphone jack into the radio's auxiliary jack, yes.Two separate alarms with the option to make an irritating noise or automatically turn on the radio for wake-up, yes.Reset time, stations and alarms if the power goes out, no. Because there is an internal battery that will store the information for up to 48 hours.AM/FM radio with six presets for you to choose and scanning, yes.But this is the appreciation worth noting about the AM/FM radio feature: we're using the Bose Wave in a neighborhood location that doesn't get TV signals, even with a big outdoor antenna. We're too far from the transmission towers, with water a few blocks over "there" and a mountain range a few miles over "there" and "there." So no live TV. Based on that and the fact that we barely get radio signals in the car until we're a bit away from the house, I didn't hold out any hope for receiving radio signals IN the house, and just planned to use it as an alarm, of course, but also as speakers for a portable music device (Zune, I'm the one and it still works great).I almost didn't even try to set up the radio, but then thought Review! Must Try For The Review! And I'll be darned. The built-in radio antenna is built right into the power cord. Very tidy in appearance without the extraneous. However there IS a port on the back in case you need to add an external antenna for more radio signal reach.But in our little hole in the woods, surprisingly unnecessary. We get five stations (good stations, too!) and each one is crystal clear. Amazing.Really a fine piece and a big recommend if you're in the market. Enjoy!

I bought a pair of these shoes while on vacation and liked them enough that I ordered another pair in a different color. I don't know why, but I've always preferred leather sneakers. These are a classic sneaker design, but in lush Italian leather, which gets softer as they're worn -- not the shoe becoming loose or not fitting anymore, just soft and lovely.Here's the one thing, though: the shoes come with leather laces which have no give to them at all. It was hard to pull them loose to get the shoes on and hard to pull them tight before tying. I just got rid of the leather laces altogether, replacing with ordinary shoelaces. Made all the difference and I recommend any buyer do that.Quality construction, comfortable to wear. Love them.

Does a great job. Zero problems in setting it up, finding the WiFi, updating the firmware. It makes crisp, clear photo prints (I use Epson photo papers) with realistic colors. Impressive, actually. It can also print directly onto DVDs and CDs, which, even though we rarely use them anymore, it is something that comes up on occasion, so that's a convenience we appreciate. Scanner also delivers crisp images. Works with Epson Connect for remote printing, which is a convenience, too. It has a small footprint compared to most of the Epson's we've had.No FAX capability (really? In these modern times? Who needs it?), and it is not one of the new Eco-Print models where you refill the ink for much less money. Small paper capacity at 100 sheets, but it can print two-sided, if that's something important to you. And one star off because this really gets on my nerves -- the ink cartridges have a cap to seal them instead of a small strip of tape. It's very easy to get ink on yourself when changing out the cartridges. I'm sure there's a very important reason to use a chunk of plastic instead of a tiny bit of cello, but I'm annoyed by it.That aside, it's a very simple, excellent printer. Enjoy!

First thing, I hope you'll have a better sense of it by the photo I attached than from Amazon's product image, but the handle on this knife isn't just gray, it really has a lovely, swirling mother of pearl effect. Really beautiful. I also included a photo which shows the tang carrying through the handle, which is not visible in the product image as of this writing. So, proper quality construction.Also, we have four chef's knives in the kitchen. I did this very unscientific test with each one: I balanced each knife on my index finger between the bolster and the handle. The only one to rest comfortably was this Sabatier. A really comfortable weight, perfectly balanced.Sharp? Why indeed it is. Cut through everything for last night's dinner prep like it was all butter -- potatoes, tomatoes, chicken -- all like butter. I will report back if the blade pits or does something it shouldn't. For now, it's a love.As noted in the description, no dishwasher. Not if you want it to last. Enjoy!

I had one of those flat porcelain graters that you set into a bowl to catch the ginger or that you used to grate directly into the bowl. It was fine, but there were always more gratings in the (tines?) than ever landed into the bowl. Eventually the piece broke. I didn't miss it because I didn't use ginger all that often.These days we use ginger all the time and in lots of recipes, so this sparked my interest. The (tines?) seem larger than what I remember on the flat grater. I don't know if that matters, but it does an excellent job of grating lots of ginger quickly and keeps it all nicely contained instead of splashed all over the counter.I love that it's elegantly and simply styled, but best of all is that I can, for the majority of our recipes, measure the liquids right into the grater, which is about the size of a butter dish, which then lifts the ginger bits up and off the (tines?) for pouring into the recipe.Seems a silly thing, but it works really well. And it isn't just for ginger. Garlic can be grated, too. Enjoy!

I want to love it, but it won't set up. I have a new Android device, all up to date and everything. I downloaded the app from Google Play. And I've gone over the instructions, paired, set, reset, uninstalled, re-installed, fussed and for the life of me, it won't set up. Which is too bad because it has excellent build quality and we were quite enthusiastic. If only we could set it up. (Full disclosure, I'm pretty techno, so that isn't the problem.)Extra points off because it has screwed up the connection between my Android device and the modem. Not the modem and the rest of my devices, just the Android that coincidentally had the Hubble app downloaded. May have nothing to do with anything, but that is quite a coincidence. So didn't just waste time trying to set up the device, but now I have to spend who knows how long getting my Android device back into Wireless World.I hate it.

For some reason, the picture makes this humidifier seem small. It isn't. Pay attention to the dimensions. That aside, we're using it in an un-air-conditioned summer house to keep cool on hot days. The fan by itself and without water or mist doesn't cool a whole room, but does offer relief in the general area where you might be sitting. Using the fan and mist together provides clean, cooling relief. We only have limited number of days to make a review, but I see no reason why this wouldn't make a most excellent humidifier in dry climates.The faster the fan, the louder it gets, but by "loud" I mean, it hums. It isn't loud at all. It's Dyson quality. An elegantly trim design. And it works.

As I began getting into the story, I was certain that I knew exactly where it was going. "Been there, done that." Ah, no. The story has excellent pacing, a great voice, and the writer really created a suspenseful piece. Loved it. A big recommend to anyone who loves a thriller.

Good coverage, lightweight twill, the color held up in the wash (dark wash, cold water), it's adjustable without hardware, it has a useful pocket and a useful loop on the backside for hanging. This is an excellent apron. If you're a splasher in the kitchen, be warned, a good splash will seep through the material. It isn't thick. But it is well made (in India) with solid stitching and should last a long time.

Two stars means "I don't like it." I DID like it so I'm not going one-star with a "hate", but the other day when I looked down to see why my toes were cold, I realized that the fabric had broken away from the sole. I bought them in February 2015 and in April 2015 I had to throw them away. Bummer. They WERE comfortable for a couple of shining moments.

I have a brick of a surge protector on the dresser next to the bed that I use as a charging station, and it's hidden behind some framed photos, and I hate it. This is a lovely replacement!Excellent build quality (I expected flimsy plastic, and am happily surprised that the Mediabridge is not that); sleek, modern, unobtrusive design*; the ability to connect USB cables frontwards or backwards (that is such a design plus!); overload protection whether from heat or surge; adjusts to the needs of your connected device; and by my reckoning, the tablet I charge daily from virtually zero power is back to work about a third faster than usual.I do love this charger, full five stars, although when I wake up at night to the array of blue lights* (which, to be fair, are handy if you're trying to plug something in during the dark hours), I feel it is more intrusive than I'd like and maybe don't love it quite as much.This item was given to me for review and I am grateful for the opportunity.

Like others have pointed out, I don't need a bulky case that holds the device and chargers and extras. I put the charging cables in a small, single-purpose bag when I travel. I just wanted a beautiful, simple, uncluttered design to protect the computer while it's in my backpack. This is a score. The reality is just as elegant in appearance as the photo suggests. And it fits my device snuggly, perfectly. Score!UPDATE November 2015: Traveling by plane earlier this year and was sent into the Extra Inspection line by the TSA. All friendly, small airport, TSA agent just doing his job, security guard nearby.Him: "You are in this line because you forgot to remove the computer from your backpack."Me: "Ach! I haven't flown in awhile, forgot about that."Him: "No problem." (Pulling things out of my backpack, including the laptop.)Also Him: "Is this a laptop case?"Me: "Well, yes." (Laptop in the case, so, yea-uh.)Him: "That. Is. Beautiful! That is the nicest case I've ever seen, and I have to say, I've seen a lot of them."Me: "It is nice. And under $20, so not expensive, either."Security guard looks over and chimes in: "That's a laptop case? It really is a beauty."They continued to delight over the case for several more minutes. Again, they have seen them all. They agreed, this was the nicest case ever. They aren't wrong.

We aren't actually alarm clock people because {shudder} what a horrible way to wake up! But for reasons, I lately find that I must be up by a certain time and instead of panicking that I'll oversleep -- because I could -- I thought I'd try this. Light as an alarm. Brilliant!The design of the piece is quite beautiful. The light quality is beautiful (and adjustable if you don't want to awaken with too much light). The instructions are clear for setting it up and setting the sound portion of the alarm (we have the radio set to our local classical station, fairly quiet). There are some built-in sounds, too -- birds chirping and the like -- if you'd rather. The sound portion, like the light, come up slowly instead of shocking one awake.To note, while the design is beautiful, this is a very lightweight piece, very plastic. (I'm not a fan of flimsy.) But if you travel and want to bring it along, it won't add weight to your luggage. I guess that's a positive. And maybe I'm doing something incorrectly, but you're supposed to just tap the top to put the sound into "snooze" mode. That doesn't work on mine. I have to just turn the alarm off, which is just as well because no good can come of a snooze.So while the light and alarm work well and it is beautiful (and by the way, the radio's sound quality is quite good), it's a three star for the build quality and inoperable snooze.

Rearranged a few things in the house, and suddenly found myself in need of a vanity mirror. I was a bit nervous about this because it isn't entirely inexpensive as vanity mirrors go, but it might be cheap.It isn't. Excellent build quality and heft. Clear reflection in the three sizes of mirror surface (just learning that I need to do a much better job on the eyebrows -- yikes! -- and I didn't see that spot on my cheek before...huh) and three levels of light, which at any level is not glaring or uncomfortable to use. Really good quality. Score.

The good and the bad: These headphones are lightweight, very comfortable (on my head, my ears) and offer really good sound quality. The pads rest on your ears rather than enveloping your ears. And they aren't noise cancelling. But for the price, that's okay. That isn't always needed.The controls are very easy to operate, large  and obvious. Connected to your phone (mine is a Windows-based phone), you can take calls that come in. Handy. Although I'd rather not have "The Beatles" interrupted by a phone call, but there it is anyway. The Bluetooth paired quickly with two different devices and operating systems without a problem.I did have a problem when using an older Android phone as a music player. The Bluetooth connection was excellent, steady, but I couldn't lower the volume from the headphones as I could with my newer Windows-based phone, and using the volume control from the Android-based phone itself would only lower so far. Deep in the quiet of the night, the headphone volume was too loud. Something just wasn't communicating correctly between the headphones and the old-model Android (which does have the latest software updates).Also, -- not a deal breaker, but to note -- this is Bluetooth only. You can't physically connect a device to the headphones. Although we are all tired of wires all over the place, some devices that are otherwise perfectly usable don't have Bluetooth. I'd love to use this headset with my early model non-Bluetooth Zune, but no can do.I like the sound quality a lot, though.No "verified purchase" as the Aduro SB10 was submitted to me for review.

To note: I hate anything to do with "floor care". One day floors will simply take care of themselves and for my part, that day can't come soon enough. Until then, I hunt for the perfect tools to help with "floor care". I like this tool. Here's why:It's lightweight, but solidly made.It's cordless (yes, please!) and the battery has it's own compact charger so the Hoover Air doesn't need to be stowed next to an outlet (in our next remodel or move we'll have a utility closet with an outlet, but in the meantime, we don't).It does an excellent job of picking up the dog's hair from the tile and wood floors (which accumulates at an astounding rate; read, I hate anything to do with "floor care", why do I even have a dog?*). It does a passable job of picking up said-same dog's hair from the low-pile carpet. No deep cleaning happening.The beater bars (on the full and hand held portions) are removable for easy cleaning. Thank you!Did you catch that? The hand-held portion has its own beater bar accessory. I love that.It swerves and curves about the room easily and comfortably. Finally you can dance with your vacuum cleaner! (You know you want to.)It's bagless because we're well into the new millennium. The collected gunk (dog hair dog hair dog hair) drops into the trash can without having to reach into the container to pull it out. I've had to do that with other bagless vacuum cleaners. I HATE it when that happens.The battery charge lasts long enough. I'm not spending the day vacuuming. I don't need the battery to last all day. The claim is 15 minutes and I vacuumed for 15 minutes, with obvious charge leftover. That's the longest amount of time I'm ever going to spend on vacuuming so that's good enough for me.*Because we love her, that's why.UPDATE: I didn't even notice then when I was using it during the day, but this vacuum cleaner is lighted, which was very handy the night a glass went crashing to the tile floor and spread teeny shards from one end of the room to the other. They shone beautifully, and I believe we snagged every one!

I love these candles! They aren't cheap, but they are quality and worth the money. We've bought (and re-bought) both these votive candles and tapers. They make the room smell delicious when they burn, and in our experience the burn lasts for hours. Feels like any day is a holiday with these glowing around the room.

Not an audiophile, me. But to my ear this is a wonderful little speaker with clear sound quality. The Bluetooth connected quickly, easily to my Windows Lumia phone. It also has a 3.5mm audio cable (included) for connecting to a non-Bluetooth device (in my case, a Zune ... yes, I'm the one). Under the smooth top there are the usual lighted icons for controlling your music device -- forward, pause, etc. The device charges by connecting the device to either a computer or a USB wall charger with the included cable.A minor complaint that might just be in my device but not complaint enough to strike a star regards the charging light. It's supposed to be red while charging, blue when finished, so say the instructions. On my Ripple Wireless, red and blue lights flash together and when the speaker is done charging, it just stops blinking, but remains red with a sort of blue halo background. You know, oh well.The device charges in a couple of hours. What surprised me about the Ripple is, not only does it have terrific sound for such a small device, but it just keeps playing and playing and playing. I expected a few hours of play before it ran out of steam. I turned it on at 8a and turned it off at 6.30p because it was time to turn on the news. I'll report back if the energy begins to dwindle down the line, as occasionally happens with rechargeable devices.Poolside, during a lovely bath, or to use on long distance trips since the radios in our cars are really old and not digital-connect friendly, this will be a very useful and compact tool for our musical enjoyment.

My husband is a carpenter and a measuring tape is probably his most useful tool and since he took it immediately upon receipt, my review is based on his comments.Two things on this tape measure make it a potential stand-out: first, the accurate view where you can clearly see clearly what the measurement is and second is the graphite feature to automatically mark the spot.He finds the accurate view to be helpful and useful. The graphite marking feature doesn't work, at least not on the one we received.Without that feature, it's just a measuring tape. But it's a very good measuring tape. The tape recoils back into place with a good snap. The numbers are easy to read for someone with aging eyes. It's a good measuring tape. If the graphite feature worked, my husband said he would love it. As is, three stars means "It's okay." And it is.

I wanted a stovetop kettle that befit our newly built kitchen and this one is perfect. But looks aren't everything. The cork handle is comfortable to hold when the kettle is steaming. It boils up plenty of water for a big pot of morning tea. It has excellent balance. It doesn't sputter and splatter. It brings a modern design with classic sensibilities to the room. I just love it.

If you don't have a sanitizing feature on your full-size machine, this might be worth considering.First, message to Samsung: Marketing this as a Baby Care Washer is fairly narrow thinking. Once the baby is grown, this will continue to be a useful appliance for households where adult incontinence might be a problem or for people who sweat a LOT from working out or just plain working, and who are tired of their otherwise good clothes emanating that funk that develops four minutes after the articles come out of the dryer. It's also an excellent appliance for people who don't want to mix their small loads of bright, nice items with the larger loads of yard-dirty clothes. Stank sneakers, smaller or lightweight dog bedding ... there are many reasons that a smaller, quality, sanitizing appliance is useful.We have a perfectly good washer/dryer that is older and lacks a sanitizing feature. The hot water cycle on our full-size machine only gets as hot as the hot water heater setting (like, about 128-degrees). With some bleach, clothes get clean, but not really, wonderfully clean.We installed the  Samsung Baby Care Washer in the laundry area to share the inflow and outflow with our regular machines. Samsung thoughtfully included everything you'd need to install this alongside your current machines, or to install as a portable appliance in another area of the house. My husband's observation (he, who does this sort of thing) commented that the variety of installation parts were all high-quality. It was connected and ready within about ten minutes after unpacking.For the first load we threw in all the nasty working man socks, several tee shirts, under things (no more than 3.5 lbs) and let it rip on Super Sanitize WITHOUT bleach, of course. The machine makes a peculiar guh-lunking sound as it operates. Not wildly loud, but weird. The Super Sanitize cycle takes (I think I saw this correctly and I've only done one Super Sanitizing load so far) 3 hours. Based on how the outflow drain tube felt, the water was REALLY hot when the machine drained. The clothes came out clean, well rinsed and the spin cycle really wrung them quite dry. It couldn't clean months of dinginess from the clothing, but I noticed that the whites really were whiter (WITHOUT bleach). If you start your run of new working/workout clothes with this machine, I am positive they'll stay newer looking, brighter, way longer.A design flaw? The machine is very well crafted, but the top lid is a lint-attractor, which is bizarre since it goes into a room where lint shows up.We've done several loads (again, just the one Super Sanitize, although all loads resulted in really nice, fresh, clean clothes), and are really liking this machine. Will report back if anything goes horribly wrong, but it's a go.And of the blessings that come from being in the Vine program, this product was a real score and I'm grateful for the opportunity to review this appliance. -- Thank you!UPDATE: Nothing has gone horribly wrong at all. Love this appliance. Just wanted to point out in case you wondered, you might be able to run the Samsung Baby Care washer and your original washer at the same time. I can't promise that will work in your set-up, but it works in ours.

We have a large yard, a garden, and grandchildren, nieces and nephews who visit, so naturally, we've always kept a Radio Flyer around (the old-fashioned, REAL Radio Flyer -- red and metal). Kept outside, but tipped when not in use so it won't hold water, they have each lasted about ten years of fairly rough use.This wagon, however, we can well imagine will be around for longer than that, easily. Quality construction and materials, a very durable paint job to resist rust, steel wheels ... as we put it together my husband couldn't get over it. "Look at this ..." "Look at that ..." "I love the steering mechanism, so simple!"Then we put it outside next to our beloved Radio Flyer and could really see the difference. And when you roll them around the yard, you can even hear and feel the difference in quality.We love our Radio Flyer, but we really love this wagon.What don't we love? Well, the instructions weren't "Greek" to us, but it was mildly confusing in a couple of spots where I put something together and then had to take it apart again. Not a big deal, but some people might become frustrated. If you're scent-sensitive, maybe open the box outside and let it air out before diving in because WOW, that was some kind of chemical stink emanating off the tires. It dissipates, but it is thoroughly unpleasant before it does. What won't last? The wood sides. They're like balsa wood. But the way we use the wagon, we don't care. And finally, while I put it together, my husband (strong man) needed to tighten everything down.Let me note, one reviewer (maybe more, I only saw one) commented that the plastic hand grip felt cheap compared to the rest of the wagon. Plastic is cheap, of course, but when truly carting stuff around the yard or when the kids pile in and pull the full wagon hither and yon, the metal handle on the Radio Flyer can dig into one's palms. The plastic grip is a thoughtful detail, and except for the plastic wheel caps and a ball in the steering mechanism, I believe it's the only other plastic on the wagon.At the time of this writing, the wagon isn't even available at Amazon, so I don't know what this costs. I couldn't even find it in the Ertl John Deere catalogue. But if you ever come across it, this wagon is a big recommend.

I'm a real fan of apocalyptic novels and have to say, this is one of the most satisfying that I've enjoyed in a long time and certainly one of the best of the genre. The writing was honest, clear-spoken, realistic and expertly crafted to bring you into the moment. It's cliché to say, "I couldn't put it down," but I really couldn't. Well done, Mr Walker. Thanks! (This review doesn't show "Verified Purchase" because I selected it from the Amazon Unlimited collection.)

Tasty, fun and simple, taking the "blah blah blah" out of recipes and bringing them to life. Mandy Rivers put her "South Your Mouth" blog to paper and it's a treat! Classic Southern recipes from her mama and recipes she developed herself, there is plenty of good ol' home cookin' going on.Shrimp & Grits (yes, please), Sweet Chili Glazed Smoked Pork Chops (omg), Southern-Style Collard Greens (okay, collards and I don't get along, but my grandmother would have no arguments with Mandy's presentation). Not to mention real Southern Green Beans, Charleston Crab Cakes, Daddy's Fish Nuggets, Skillet Cornbread ... all the classics and then some. If you're shopping for something fun and inspiring, enjoy!

Excellent sound and I tested these headphones against classical and rock music, and videos that were all talk or talk with music in the background. The quality is well-balanced and clear, and made for very comfortable listening.The design is certainly different. The flat wires are a little more bulky than we're probably accustomed to seeing. They're wide like a full sized rubber band. This does keep the wires from tangling up as ordinary wired headphones are prone to doing. Once in place (over the back of your ears and then insert), they stay in place, is my experience, although also in my experience, it takes a moment to get the wires in the right place to stay over and behind my ears. (Maybe my ears are too small...?)I like the wide choice of buds included in the package. Not only different sizes, but different styles so you will find whatever suits you best. And I like the storage case, also included, to keep everything tidy and together, which I appreciate when traveling.The Brainwavz S1 was presented for review, but at this price point, for quality, comfort and customization, I think it's a go.

This product was in "pre-order" mode at Amazon for too long, so I ended up getting it directly from Microsoft. This isn't a verified purchase.I wanted a media device to replace my (well loved, much used) Kindle 8.9 HD, but with a modern Windows environment that would synch to my laptop and cell phone.Kindles are excellent, but limited. With the ThinkPad 8 Touchscreen, I have all the web surfing and media consumption capabilities we expect of a laptop (including the Kindle app for books), but that's comfortable to hold in one hand (while lounging on the couch!).If there isn't an app for it, I can pin my favorite websites to the tile screen, making the device customizable in a way that Kindle could never be.Any business I might do would be through a word processor and Kindle was really lame at that. I can easily use MS Word 365 on this tablet and print and whatever else, but that's what my laptop is for and so I don't. But I could, is important to note.I cuddle up with the ThinkPad and scour the latest from News Bento, watch YouTube videos, catch up on FB, see the family pics on Instagram, browse Pinterest, check trivia on IMDB and watch Netflix or HuluPlus (or Amazon videos -- pin to start!), add to the grocery list in OneNote, which will appear as if by magic (!) on the phone when I hit the store, read my favorite magazines thanks to Next Issue, fuss with my collection of phone photos that are handily saved in the cloud, and that includes editing with Adobe Photoshop Express, and comfortably Skype with friends and family, far and wide. And more! But I don't have all day.It costs less than the comparable 64gb latest generation Kindle 8.9 HDX ($440 at the time of this writing) and the iPad Mini ($600, and I'm sure retina display is swell, but it's not THAT much better). That's a win. A complaint? I wish it had an ordinary charging connection instead of something proprietary. It just makes for one more thing when traveling.That aside and to wrap up, the ThinkPad 8 has terrific resolution, is really fast, reliable, light, the right size and just exactly what I wanted when I replaced my last generation Kindle. I love it.UPDATE February 2015: Thanks to a sharp-eyed consumer who called me out on an error, I need to adjust this review regarding the "proprietary" charging cord and port that I mentioned in my original comments. With a closer look, the cord and the charging port on the device are both the current and older mini USB connections side-by-side. That's the cord and charging port, both. But you can stick a newer mini-USB version cord (like what comes with most smartphones, etc) just into that side of the port and it also charges. Or an older mini-USB version cord into the other slot. I never realized that and will adjust my review accordingly.UPDATE March 2015: I have now charged the Lenovo tablet a couple of times with the standard micro-USB connection instead of the proprietary connection that comes with the device and it is slow-slow. Slow. Really slow. If you're playing along, I recommend you use the proprietary adapter.FYI, still love this tablet.

I like this printer as I've liked all Epson printers. I have always found them very easy to set up with my PC and (now) devices (hold that thought). They always make quality prints. The cost of operation is manageable.This is a very large machine as compared to others. I'm a bit of a weakling, true, so I needed help putting the printer into position. I was able to easily set up the wireless connection. I can't speak to the FAX abilities since that feature isn't connected at this time, but the dialogue box on the printer's panel is straight forward and intuitive.Here's the holdup: I am now 65% into a driver download from Epson that still has half an hour to go over a high speed internet connection onto a zippy PC, so that I can have the proper dialogue box appear when I go to print. Without that driver, the dialogue is very basic: letter size paper, plain or glossy; 4x6 plain or glossy. That's pretty much it. All of my other Epsons featured the option of choosing plain paper in a variety of sizes up to choosing art quality photo paper in a variety of sizes and to print draft up through best, with several quality steps in between, no matter if I was using word processing or graphics design software.If I was on a slower speed internet connection, this would be intolerable. I don't understand that part. I'm sure it will all shake out in the end. I'll report back one way or another.Also worth noting, I've come to expect Epson printers to include a CD-DVD printing capability. This machine, for all its heft, bells and whistles, does not include that feature. They don't claim to, either, but some people might "assume", so I thought it worth mentioning.The color 4x6 prints I made were striking. The color output on plain paper has been perfect. The machine prints quickly and quietly. And I am delighted to now have the ability to make 13x19 prints! It's a go.UPDATE: Well this is unfortunate. I was able (in two tries) to get the drivers and firmware updated, so I now have a good-and-proper dialogue box in all of the programs that I use for printing (I have Windows 8.1, also up to date, by the way). Perfect. Except.Although I was able to print before the updates from any program, Adobe Photoshop (latest version) now crashes whenever I select print. It worked before the updates, now it doesn't. I'm sure this will shake out soon, or maybe I'll have to spend hours screwing around with it and everything will eventually work out. But in the meantime, Photoshop isn't exactly an obscure program and this shouldn't be a problem. But it is. (sigh) The good news is, files print beautifully from Adobe Lightroom, so there's that, then.ANOTHER UPDATE (FINAL, June 30th): ...and so to correct this problem, I simply uninstalled the WF-7610 from my computer and then reinstalled it. Why it didn't work out of the box, I don't know, but it works now in all of my software with the proper options and dialogue box. All that aside, it does make beautiful prints.

I like cream shampoos. They harken back, which is sometimes nice, but also a container of cream shampoo tends to go further than a container of liquid shampoo. I landed on this and decided to try it.What I wasn't expecting was that my hair would feel so wonderfully soft and full after the first wash! It lathered beautifully with just a dab of shampoo, rinsed easily and without being fly-away or unmanageable at all, my hair is really so soft. I'm kinda stunned. (As I always do, I rubbed actual coconut oil on my hands and then ran my hands through my hair before blow-drying. But I've always done that. My hair has never felt this good so it isn't because of the light coconut oil finish.)This cream doesn't really smell anything like coconut oil, but more like a clean baby -- I don't know why.To note -- at the time I ordered this I didn't realize it was coming from a company in the UK, where I'm not. They delivered in a timely manner, given that the package was sailing across a very large pond, but I'll look for this product from a US distributor the next time I order.Although. It's worth every penny, so wherever I can get it ...

We have a Wii console in a far corner of the house that couldn't play stream video from the internet because between the TV cabinet and the two concrete walls, the signal just didn't reach. Too bad for the kids.This actually was fairly easy to set up. I physically connected the main household computer to the Trek with an Ethernet cord, plugged the Trek into the wall and powered it to "wireless." After a moment a website appeared. I entered the information about the household router, applied the information, entered the required sign-in and it was done. I unplugged the Ethernet from the laptop and Trek. I went into the Wii menu and added the new wireless connection and now, lucky kids, they can stream movies from the Wii console.Easy. Done.

If you want to protect your phone against drops, bumps, dings, and scratches, and you don't mind the added bulk and lack of "sexiness" then this case is for you.  I like that it comes with a belt holster; the case snaps into the belt holster, and the holder can rotate to horizontal or vertical position.This case is good for:-protection against bumps, scrapes, and small drops (ie. from pocket or table top)-screen protection (built-in to case)-minor moisture exposureThis case is not good for:-style points; this case is build for function (protection) rather than looks (it looks rugged)-keeping a slender profile; this case bulks up your phone about 3x in thickness-charging stands; I have the Belkin MIXIT Charge and Sync Dock and this case prevents the iPhone 6+ from connecting to the lightning connector.-use with an armband carrier like the Tune Belt Armband for iPhone 6 Plus; it is a really tight fit, but it requires some effort, and the double screen protector (one for the case, one for the armband) reduces screen sensitivity to touchIf you are more into the sleek and slender look that matches your iPhone 6+ and don't care much about protection functionality, then skip this case.  I like the Tech21 cases sold in the Apple Stores (I haven't tried the Tech21 cases sold on Amazon).Solid 4-star rating.  Highly recommended.

I like everything about this planner.I like the smaller size.  At 5.38 in. x 8.5 in. page size this is a nice size to keep on my desk, or if necessary to carry around.  It takes up less desktop real estate.  I like the textured pewter colored casebound cover.  I like the 13-month date range (Jan '16-Jan '17) so I have a month overlap.  I carry this in my every day messenger bag to get a feel of it; it fits easily and is easy to remove from and replace in the bag.  I can't wait to start using it this January.The Weekly Planning layout gives a week's view per two page spread, and features a column-style layout.  There is one vertical column for each day, and includes ruled lines to jot down meetings and to-do's.  There is also a quad ruled, graphed section that runs across the bottom of the two page spread for additional notes and reminders.With the Monthly Planning, you can keep track of upcoming events and deadlines. It covers 13 months from January 2016 - January 2017 and is tabbed for easy navigation. One month per two page spread features open, unruled daily blocks so you can clearly mark key dates. A quad ruled graphed column also runs along the right side of each month for additional notes.The only flaw I see is the relatively "weak" cover.  It is essentially a textured cardboard that may be tested by constant and/or consistent store-and-carry in a bag.  I would probably replace this with a more durable plasticky cover, but not necessary.RecommendedRecommended.

I've owned this Victorinox Jetsetter tool for a few years (a gift for my birthday).  I like having a small multi-tool at all times.  I use the scissors to cut paper, tags, plastic wraps, etc.  It has some useful tools:  a magnetic phillips screwdriver tip, cap lifter/bottle opener and wire stipper.It also has a small scissors, key ring, tweezers and toothpick.  I've used all the accessories at one time or another.  And it is small enough that it barely adds weight to my keys.  I highly recommend this blade-less multi-tool.When I fly, I usually keep this in my carry-on and I have had no issues flying over the past few years.  Many TSA agents were surprised by a multi-tool not having a blade.  I've flown through SFO, OAK, EWR, DCA, ORD, LAX, SEA and many other airports without any problems.  Until recently.This was confiscated by TSA from my carry-on bag on a recent flight out of Phoenix Sky Harbor.  I was told that TSA no longer allows Swiss Army knives past screening since 2013.  I knew that, and that is why I fly with this Jetsetter (which has no blade).  The three TSA agents I was dealing with at Phoenix Sky Harbor airport somehow could not grock the idea of a swiss army knife with no knife.  I explained that it does not have a blade, but they did not believe me (or did not care to).  I asked them to open the accessories, but they would not.  I asked for the supervisor, who came by but pretty much sided with his agents.  They explained that scissors are not allowed, but I know that scissors less than 4 inches from the fulcrum are allowed, as per TSA website.  This whole time, I was jovial and friendly with the agents, and not once did I raise my voice or seem frustrated.Finally I asked them if I can show them, and they reacted as if I was a threat.  They said I had to either voluntarily surrender this utility tool, or I can go back to the check-in desk and check in this knife in a bag (and pay a checked bag fee of $35).  So I told the guy to keep it as an early Christmas present from me, but they did not appreciate the comment.  Their response was that these are discarded or thrown away, and not kept for possession or auction (b.s.).As a multi-tool, I like the minimal blade-less set for travelling.  I usually cycle among my blade collection for EDC, which include a Benchmade Mini-Griptillian, a SOG Mini Vulcan, and a Kershaw Blur S30V and I keep these in my check-in bag when I fly.  Thankfully I have another Jetsetter so I am complete again.  To save from future headache, I will not carry this on my carry-on and just check it in.  I still don't get it, but I suppose it all depends on the airport and TSA agents.  Hopefully it is merely a one-time thing.Recommended.

I received the Large (16 oz) gloves in Red and Black.  First impression was how snug the fit is (without wraps) so I was worried at first.  I have been using these almost daily on a Ringside 100 lb heavy bag, and although it got a little roomier it is still a snug fit.  This is good for me, because I don't like my hand sliding around inside gloves when I work on the heavy bag.  Once broken in (after a month) these are now my favorite bag gloves (edging out my Title bag gloves I've used the past 2+ years).I fit the Large (I have 9.25" hands below the knuckles), but these initially did not fit my wrapped hand, especially the Ringside Gel Shock handwraps and most of my 120" wraps.  These gloves initially did not fit I use the Hayabusa wraps or the Title Boxing Fist Guards but I can use the thinner gauze wraps.  Over time, the inside opened up and I am now able to use the 120" wraps.  I still can't use the fist guards, or any gel guards with the full wraps.  For now, I just tap up my hand before I wrap, and these gloves are a perfect fit.Pros:-The "D-ring" in the hook & loop wrist closure makes it easier to self-secure the wrist tightly-Soft leather cover-Thumb attachement-Fits my hand comfortably (when unwrapped)-Palm ventilation is decent, though not the best-IMF foam technology makes for a snug fitCons:-Lining is not as comfortable/soft as my other gloves-Tight fit.Very nice bag glove with wrist and fist support.

Decent buds. The sound is not the greatest, but good enough.  I've tried to break these in for a week, but the sound did not improve.  Noise isolation is good enough for me.  Not the best, but good enough.  For budget inner ear buds, the Ultimate Ears 200 works better in noise isolation and sound.  If you don't mind spending more, the Klipsch Image X10i or Shure SE535-V are significantly better.  There are three sets of earpads (S/M/L) included for a more custom, comfortable fit.The mic is good enough for voice calls.As significant downside is the severe "microphonics."  Which means that when I move and the cord rubs against my shirt/jacket/anything the sound (cord noise) transfers to the earbuds.Overall, these are decent earbuds if you can grab them for less than ten dollars.  I would not consider these if priced above 15 dollars, since there are so many other decent IEBs for less than ten bucks.

I've used this for various iPads and an iPhone 6 Plus.  It works to charge the devices, and it works to transfer data.  This is an Apple authorized accessory, and it has worked thus far.  It is a bit shorter than the Belkin 6 inch ChargeSync Cable but works just as well.  I use this cable with a Duracell Powermat GoPower Battery Charger and the cable length is just right, no more extra dangling cable.  This also works well with my MacBook Pro, with the iPhone charging next to my laptop.Pros:-It works to charge, and to transfer data.Cons:-Was shorter than expected.  If two inches longer, it would be ideal.Recommended.

This Remington PF7200 electric shaver is decent.  It shaves close, is comfortable to use, easy to clean, relatively easy to charge, and portable.  It has a 30 min charge time, 30 min run time from a single charge, two flexible foils with stainless steel blades for a close and comfortable shave, and pop-up trimmer.  However, it is not as good as my Remington F7800  which has a charging base station, digital battery life indicator, washable head, and 5-minutes quick charge, or even the or even the Remington F7400 which has a pivot-and-flex head.  Like the F7400, what I do not like is that I don't know how much charge is left in the battery.  It just starts flashing when it needs to be charged, which I suppose is good enough, but there are electric shavers that display approximately how much power is left.  Unlike the PF7400, this shaver does not shave as close as I would like.  This electric shaver is decent enough, but it does not shave close enough and often I have to shave the same area twice as much to get a decent shave with this one.  The trimmer is a nice feature, which I use to shape my sideburns.If all I had was this Remington PF7200, I would be quite happy with its performance and give it 5-stars.  Having used other (and better) shavers, I cannot give this shaver 5 stars.Product Info:Flex Foil Technology - Foils are spaced apart so that the first foil trims hair closely, then gently stretches the skin so that the second foil can get even closer.Surgical Stainless Steel Blades - Shave quickly and cleanly with the sharp, long-lasting blades housed beneath two durable foils.Pop-Up Detail Trimmer - Trim your beard and side burns for a clean-cut look.Other shortcomings:Not as quiet as the PF7400Not Washable (like the PF7400)Not as close a shave as the PF7400

It works well to style short hair.  I would not use this with longer hair.  It makes the hair look greasy and artificial.  I usually just use hair conditioner as a leave in styling product.  This styling paste is a bit too thick and stiff.  The Suave styling paste seems like the same product, and is about half the cost of this Dove product.

This electric shaver is decent.  It shaves close, is comfortable to use, easy to clean, relatively easy to charge, and portable.  Bottom line is that it works.  However, it is not as good as my Remington F7800 which has a charging base station, digital battery life indicator, washable head, and 5-minutes quick charge.  It also gives me a closer shave.  What I do not like is that I don't know how much charge is left in the battery.  It just starts flashing when it needs to be charged, which I suppose is good enough, but there are electric shavers that display approximately how much power is left.If all I had was this Remington PF7400, I would be quite happy with its performance and give it 5-stars.  Having used other (and better) shavers, I cannot give this shaver 5 stars.Product Info:Intercept Shaving Technology - This advanced feature sits between the foils to pre-trim longer hairs for a closer shave.Pivot & Flex - Allows the shaver head to adjust and maintain close contact around the chin, jawline, and neck.ConstantContour - Helps foils flex to quickly respond to facial contours.Pop-Up Detail Trimmer - Trim your beard and side burns for the perfect look.Washable - The shaver easily washes clean under the faucet.QuietDrive Advanced Motor - Engineered to vibrate less and be 20% quieter than a previous Remington model.

This charging dock for the Apple Watch is sleek, modern, and functional.  Easy to use, no issues.  While the watch is charging, the face is viewable and therefore works well on a nightstand.  No need to pick up watch to check the time, the face is angled so that you can see it.  This stand is heavy enough not to be easily knocked over, and with the non-slip padding on the bottom it will stay in place.  I brought this to an Apple store, and it fits all of the Apple Watches on display (both 38mm and 42mm).  I am considering getting another one to keep on my workstation.I received this watch stand within a few days after ordering.  It came with sufficient (and not excessive) padding to protect the product from accidental bumps during shipping.Highly recommended!!!

This review is for the Belkin Certified 4-Foot 90 Degree Lightning to USB Charge Sync Cable (Red) and it seems to be the legitimate deal.  It does not look or feel fake, and charges my iPads and iPhone 6 Plus fine.  I've used this for various iPads and iPhone 5S, 6, and 6 Plus.  It works to charge the devices, and it works to transfer data.  This is an Apple authorized accessory, and it has worked thus far.This is a foot longer than the standard Apple charging cable, which makes a big deal in the car, at work, and at home.  The extra foot gives me just enough length to put the phone on my desk at home and at work (my computers are on wheeled PC racks on the floor), which I couldn't do that with the standard 3-foot Apple cable.  In the car, it allows me to charge my phone while mounted on the left side of the steering wheel (again, couldn't do that with the Apple cable).The 90-degree bend does not affect charging my iPhone 6+ when in its Belkin Classic Case / Folio or Lifeproof case.I have not had any problems with tangled cables, so I do not know if this is better than the Flat version which is supposed to help with preventing tangles.  My experience with various "flat and tangle-free" cables has been mixed; some seemed to tangle less, and some still tangled.  My personal preference is the round cables because it doesn't feel as bulky when I fold up the cable in a rush.Pros:-It works. Period.-4 foot cable; an extra foot longer than my other cables-Muted Red (not too bright) which I like betterCons:-None that I've encountered.Highly Recommended.

Fast microSD card.  No issues when using GoPro 3 Black at medium settings.  Only encountered issues once (out of 6 tries, recording stopped ~20 minutes into shooting) when using highest setting (recording at ~45 mbps).  My SanDisk Extreme Pro microSD card has never caused me any problems in over a year's worth of recording at this setting.  Also works with no issues playing 1080p HD movies on android tablet (as expected).If you care about the benchmark results (which are not realistic), they are as follows: (performed on 2014 MacBook Pro Retina)Read - 88 MB/sWrite - 49 MB/sI will continue to test this card.  Stay tuned.  So far, happy with this microSD card.

I've paired this keyboard with various iOS (iPhone 4S, iPhone 6+, iPad 2, iPad 4, iPad Air) and android phones.  This is more of a portable keyboard with a stand, than a tablet case with built-in keyboard.  This keyboard+stand accommodates any tablet.  I took a picture of my iPhone 6+ and an iPad 4 (two of my larger devices) and although this stand can hold both up, it is very unstable and the devices go over the sides a bit.  The keys are a bit cramped, but manageable.I charged this the first day I got it.  I have been using it everyday for about 8 hours a day, and after almost a week it still has battery power.  Not bad.  I will update this section in 6 months.Pros:-Nice and clean look.-Kickstand doubles as keyboard cover.-Keyboard is easy to charge, pair, and use-Long-lasting battery life.Cons:-Not truly a tablet case with a keyboard.  It is more a portable bluetooth keyboard with a cover.  But, if you know this from the get-go, then this is not much of a con.-Not quite stable when used on lap or uneven surface.  I've tried and failed to use this on my lap while typing my email using an iPad.-Stand that holds phone/tablet is not as strong as I expected or hoped.Overall, a very good portable keyboard.  Even though I rate this 4-stars, this is the keyboard I carry everyday because I typically use my iPhone 6+ for work and play, and I carry an android phone (for work), I can use this keyboard with both devices.

This is an excellent rice cooker... and more.  We tried a few of the recipes from the included cookbook.  My favorite thus far were the Simmered Meatballs and Chinese Vermicelli and the Jambalaya.  These were made with the Tacook feature.Pros:-Makes great steamed white or brown rice-Tacook feature - Cooking plate included.  Synchronized cooking function where users can prepare two dishes simultaneously with Synchro-Cooking function and the power of Induction Heating-Timer-Easy to clean.  Unlike previous rice cookers which had minimal removable parts, this one is much easier to clean.Cons:-None thus far.

I've used this on an iPad 2, iPad 4, iPad Air.  This case accomodates these full size iPads.  My iPad mini does not fit the case (as expected) since its size is too small for the holders.  I've had many Belkin cases and have been happy with most of them, and this one does not disappoint.What I am impressed with the most is the battery life.  I charged this the first day I got it, and have been using it for almost a month now without needing a recharge.  I don't think this will last 6 months of continuous use.  The description says the battery will stay charged for over 6 months, but I think they are talking about how long the battery can keep its charge without use.  I will update this section in 6 months.Pros:-Nice and clean look-Fits all full size iPads-Keyboard is easy to charge, pair, and use-Flap in the back folds down for camera use, and accomodates iPad and Samsung camera locations without removing case-Long-lasting battery life.Cons:-Vertical viewing (tablet mode) is not easily accomodated by case/keyboard.  The keyboard is exposed in the back if the tablet is not taken off.  Otherwise, it will have to be taken off.Overall, a clean and functional keyboard case.  Highly recommended.

This works great in deep clear waters.  It is rated to 150m dive depth.  I was pleasantly surprised with this flashlight's brightness.  When you pick it up, you can feel how beefy it is.Pros:-This is bright!!!  It's nice to have three ON settings (Full, 2/3 power, 1/3 power)-Solid build.  It's hefty, and you know it's there-Comes with solid carry case-Button to cycle to ON (Hi/Med/Low) and OFF; I like this better than rotary on/off switch-Constant brightness.  However, this may be a good or bad thing.Cons:-Problems with O-ring not properly seating between body and head/light portion; that seals the battery in the compartment-Single o-ring; my LX20 has a double o-ring seal-High cost, but cheaper than my go-to dive torch LX20There is a smaller and cheaper 700 Lumen LED version from Phantom Aquatics.What comes in the box:-plastic carry case that holds everything-flashlight-sealed batteries-charger and power cable-loop strap to tether onto wrist-hand strap for hands-free use (therefore frees up hand)I have yet to use up the battery, so I will update with this info at a later time.Recommended.

Installation was straight-forward.  I wired it for separate switches to control the light and fan.  I may change out the lights with LED ones in the future, but for now I am using incandescent light bulbs.Pros:-The reversible switch for the fan.  In warm weather, run the fan counterclockwise to stay cooler. In the winter, run it clockwise to recirculate warm air from the ceiling, eliminating cold spots and drafts.Cons:-No remote.  Have to operate from the light switch or the fan itself.-Dim lighting.  This is fine in our bedroom or living room where we were able to use other lights (desk or floor lamps).  It did not work for our dining room or family room where we had no other light source.Product description:-52-inch reversible five-blade indoor ceiling fan; ideal for rooms up to 360 square feet (18 feet by 20 feet)-153-by-17-millimeter cold-rolled steel motor with three speeds (high/medium/low); reversible switch (clockwise, counterclockwise) for air up or air down-Airflow: 4,837 cfm; Energy Usage: 62 watts without lights; Airflow Efficiency: 78 cfm per watt-Includes two-light fixture, 54-inch lead wire, 3/4-inch by 4-inch down rod, pull chains and two medium-base 13-watt CFL light bulbsWhat's in the Box - Includes two-light fixture, 54-inch lead wire, 3/4-inch by 4-inch down rod, pull chains and two medium-base 13-watt CFL light bulbs

This backpack is larger than what I usually use.  I used it for my recent weekend trip to Los Angeles.  Size fits the approximate carry-on size for Virgin America (24x16x9).  Other airlines are smaller (22x14x9) but if you don't overpack this bag can easily compresses to fit.Now, I use it as a gym bag to carry my sparring gear (16oz gloves, 8oz grappling gloves, headgear, groin gear).  The shin guards don't fit completely (Top King) and can fit with part sticking out, or I have it strapped on the sides.  Water bottle pockets on the side.Pros:-Detachable Day Pack in front-Hidden pocket-Padded laptop sleeve-Large main compartment-Comfortable straps for carryingCons:-Heavier than I expected, but not as heavy as other travel packs-Zipper to main compartment catches on loose stitching/material; had to cut away a piece of the inner material-Top handle seems flimsy, and can get uncomfortable to use when carrying a full pack for a long time.Features:-Size: 23 In. X 12 In. X 13 In. Size: 23 In. X 12 In. X 9 In.-Capacity: 3600 Cu. In. (3000 Cu. In. Main Compartment + 600 Cu.In. Convertible Daypack)-Weight: 3 Lb. 13 Oz.-Body Fabric: PolyesterAdditional Features:2 Mesh Water Bottle Pockets,Side Compression Straps,Side Overflow Pockets With Zip Closures,Hidden Pocket Behind Convertible Daypack For Extra Valuables,Ergonomic Carry HandleProduct Description from Amazon:-Padded laptop sleeve with organization pockets and key fob-Adjustable webbing and Air-mesh on should straps, lumbar pad, and waist belt for a customized fit-Waist belt tucks behind lumbar pad for added lumbar pad comfortHighly recommended.

This SDXC card works well, and is an upgraded version of the PNY Elite Performance 64GB SDXC Class 10 U1 which maxes out at 90MB/s (on paper).  This U-3 card provides transfer speeds up to 95MB/s.  In either benchmark tests or practical applications, I did not see any performance difference between this U3 card -vs- the previous U1 version.  I did not encounter any issues with this card in any DSLR, point-and-shoot, or digital camcorders.Compared to the SanDisk Extreme PRO 64GB U3 this PNY 64GB U3 is slower on benchmark tests and in practical use on a DSLR (using a Nikon D7000 and D5100).
