Right out of the box it feels nice and soft, and was even more luxurious after going through a laundry cycle. As for the absorbency, it knocked it out of the park - it handled a huge load of large pots and pans, knifes (you know, the stuff that can't or won't fit into the dishwasher) without feeling like it was saturated after drying a few items. You won't have to reach for another towel or two and then you're left with the kitchen looking like the clothesline feel down with towels strewn about everywhere drying!As for the color, the blue is a really beautiful vintage-looking indigo blue, and a nice surprise is the design on the towel is asymmetrical. It looks more interesting hanging over the dishwasher handle than your average towel.

This Epson printer is a bit like the little brother in this line of new printers from Epson. Epson has long been known for their color quality printing, and this printer meets that expectation. Of course the real benefit is the refillable ink tanks that hold a lot of ink, meaning no more cartridges and plenty of ink for big projects.It is worth noting that printer is really worth the price if you do a lot of color printing (if you do a lot of black and white printing, a small laser printer is more economical). Depending on how fast you blow through color ink cartridges, this printer may or may not make sense given the price tag. Now, here's the low-down:Set-up & InstallSuper easy right out of the box. Filing the ink tanks was a snap and the placement of the tanks ensures the filling process is easy and no mess. Once that's done and the initial ink charging process complete (this step takes about 20 minutes) you can connect to your Wi-Fi network, which takes all of about 20 seconds - as long as you know your password ;-).PrintingAgain, it's that high quality Epson color printing technology that has always made Epson stand out from the crowd. I printed several photos and other color docs and all were clear, crisp and the color spot on as compared to the original. I printed on both matte and glossy photo paper with excellent results. The plain paper photos were okay, but that's a limitation of the paper, not the printer. The color docs I printed were a report with plenty of charts and graphs and that printed beautifully and looked like it professionally done as opposed to being done at the same time as I was making dinner.I also fed card stock, including a piece of heavy weight scrapbook paper and various sizes of paper through this printer and it handled everything just fine. There isn't a rear feed slot so I didn't attempt fabric, vellum or anything tricky. I do wish Epson and other printer manufacturers would add a rear feed tray, some of don't live solely in a plain paper world.Another great feature is the ability print directly form other devices. If you are Mac user, you can also use AirPrint. Epson has a basic, handy app that you can use to print photos directly to the printer. Again, it's basic but it you do any editing of the photo with any of the multitude of apps out there you can get what you want without having to do the upload/download thing to your desktop PC.Copy & ScanThis little printer does a fine job with both copying and scanning. It doesn't do two sided printing (although you can flip the paper and accomplish this manually), nor does it handle two sided scanning. With the copy function, you can really see how fantastic he Epson color technology is; color copies are virtually identical to the original.Again, a great little workhorse if you have considerable color printing/copying needs. At least you'll be able to get through a big project without running out of ink before the job is done. And you can get the job done well!

Rachael Ray has been a long time advocate for animals, particularly abandoned and mistreated pets through her Rachael's Rescue foundation. So one would expect her organization would put out a dog food product that is of the highest quality and yes, this is. Since she donates all of her personal profits to her foundation, your purchase helps pets needing a lot of love.Even though our yellow lab will eat nearly everything, except lettuce, she went nuts when I opened the bag, and I haven't seen that in awhile. We feed her excellent quality dog food, but this must have had the equivalent of of dog food umami in it as she woofed it down like she was a perpetually hungry puppy.There aren't any grains in it as advertised, and the first ingredient is salmon, and salmon meal is the second. The protein content is good, guaranteed to be a minimum of 26%. It does contain beet pulp (a ways down on the list), some consider this to be more of a filler, others claim it has properties beneficial to the dog's intestinal health. And it's all made in the US, not China so there is some comfort that your dog isn't consuming some weird cocktail of plastic bits and who knows what else. As an aside, Rachael Ray's dog food is made by Ainsworth Pet Nutrition, who consistently receives high ratings for its product quality and cleanliness and safety of production.I'm definitely sold on Rachael Ray's dog food, and the hound is happy too!

I owned an Epson many years ago and since then have had the opportunity to print to many different Epson models. The two things that always stand out for me are the quality of the color prints and the fast usage of expensive ink. I ultimately gave up my Epson for a Canon Pixma but now my trusty Canon is no match for this Epson printer - especially since Epson solved the "drinking ink" problem so elegantly. So the Canon has been happily being donated and the premium desk space awarded to this new, fabulous Epson printer. Oh yeah, and all of the cartridge inconvenience as well.A key consideration in the purchase of this printer is the economics. It's not an inexpensive printer, and the trade-off is you don't have to buy a slew of ink cartridges. It's really designed for a small office/home office and If you do a lot of printing and currently rifling through several sets of ink cartridges in a one-to-two year period, then this printer is a blessing and a bargain. If you are a home user or your color printing needs are minimal, then this printer might be overkill for your needs. As in all things, know what you need and from there you can make in an informed buying decision. Now here's the low-down:Set-up & InstallOut of the box, this was a snap to get up and running. Everything you need is in the box. After taking all the tape and packing bits off and out, you fill the cartridges. Here is the real beauty of this printer - you fill each of the 4 tanks with ink yourself, the tanks are voluminous and hold way more than the traditional cartridges. Say goodbye to the recycling, refilling or new cartridges mess and hello to a LOT of ink that should last a long, long time. After the ink has charged (the initial process takes about 20 minutes) you go through the set-up which takes about 20 seconds, as long as you know your Wi-Fi network password.Print QualityExceptional. Epson has always done a superior job with color printing, and this printer is no exception. I printed photos on matte, glossy and plain paper all with gorgeous results. The paper tray can be modified to hold various different sizes, up to A4 and as small as 3.5 x 5". Also, the print speed is incredible. The first set of photos I printed I was cursing under my breath that I must have selected a fast, draft-style print quality because the paper was shooting out so fast, but not so. And no buckling or waviness to the paper in those areas where the color is highly saturated - the  paper was perfectly flat.Copy & ScanThe copier quality was also just as excellent and you can really see the beautiful color print technology as color copies are 99% as good as the original. The same is true of the scanning technology, the scan capture is true to the original, so now you can scan those keepsakes and print them into high quality paper to share or use in a project. Both the scanning and copy functions always print super fast and another bonus is the scanning function will work over the Wi-Fi network. You also have the option to scan to your desktop or to the cloud (iCloud and Google Cloud). You can also save in a variety of file formats. Oh yeah, the copy (and print) functions can do 2-sided printing.FaxAgain, awesome quality in terms of send, receive and the print quality. I had someone fax over a document with color images and the print quality was the same high quality as any other color output this printer produces. It holds up a total of 60 contacts and contacts can be grouped (a group counts as one contact). There is a nifty little utility for both Windows and Mac OS that lets you set-up speed dial and group dial. And you can fax a doc directly from your PC with this utility.Another great feature of this printer is the app for your iOS and Android devices (iPhone, iPad, Android OS devices etc.) that enables you to print directly the the printer. I love that this eliminates the messy step of downloading images, especially since Apple really made new iPhoto app less better. However the iOS/Android app is simple and limited in scope of functionality so if you need to do any real editing, you'll still have to get the image onto your computer and do your magic from there. But given the quality of the camera in most newer cell phones and some of the editing apps available, you can still do your thing and print right to the printer - and so can your family and friends.The one thing I wish this printer had was rear tray which is so helpful when working with fabric or heavier paper or card stock. I did test this printer with card stock, and it handled printing several pages in one job like a champ, and I hope that would be true for a tray full of card stock, but I haven't had the need for this just yet.Overall, I'm thrilled about the marriage of Epson color quality and the all-you-can-drink refillable tanks! And Epson was kind enough to include in the box a set of ink to get started and a set of ink for refilling, you probably won't need ink for awhile...a long, long while!

Obviously the size of these paper towels are the big bonus. We took a roll with us for a weekend camping trip and they served us well, but the size was clearly the only bonus over taking a normal sized roll of paper towels. I could easily see if you have a small house, RV or other tight living condition, you might find these somewhat more advantageous. Regardless, this size advantage is not nearly compelling enough that I'd buy these towels.On the downside, these towels are thin and not terribly absorbent. If you need to mop up a big, wet mess, then you'll blow through a wad pretty fast (and now you'll need two rolls, so why not just have one large roll). If you are prone to big messes, then it's definitely more economical to stick to the normal size towels.

I would have never believed it if someone had told me back in the 70's that I would eventually own a set of Al Stewart's tunes. Never being a big fan of Al Stewart, and I would turn the station whenever his pop song, Year of the Cat, came on the radio.  But after hearing a track from this CD I had to hear more. This all acoustic guitar CD really showcases Mr. Stewart's serious talent as both a songwriter and guitar player. Peter White is the perfect complement too. The jazzy, upbeat tempo is sprinkled with a bit of latin and celtic riffs and it is so much more interesting to listen to - I really hope he produces more work in this genre.

My husband, who has a very light beard (not a very hairy guy) found the shaver to be comparable to his other electric razor. He noted it was a smooth, close shave but again, he can go a a few days without shaving and only then does it look likes he has a 5 o'clock shadow. He suspects this razor would not be nearly as effective for someone with heavy growth.It gets the 1-star rating as the big "bonus" of this unit is the Smart Clean which seems to work intermittently. The hubby tinkered with for several days and couldn't get to operate consistently. Again, he had to wait to get the thing full of enough hair to make it work, so maybe his light facial growth is core to the issue. Regardless, he simply resorted to cleaning the unit the same way he cleaned his old razor with just as good results. He also gives a big thumbs down to the perfumed cleaning solution, he said it reminds him of deodorant.As the other half who shares the bathroom, I'm giving it 1-star based on hideous design of the cleaning unit - it looks like a toilet brush holder sitting on the counter top. I'm secretly glad the cleaning unit was such a fail, it made it easier to get rid of it.

We've always said we're not really into karaoke, but dang, the Home Singing Machine and a group of people will change that pretty fast! This thing is an absolute blast! You don't have to be a singer to get into the act!First - of the box this unit sets up and installs quickly and painlessly. If you can pair bluetooth, you can set this unit up. A major benefit is when the unit is not being used for karaoke, you can use it as a bluetooth speaker.Quality - awesome!!! The sound quality is excellent, for both the karaoke and as a plain ol' speaker. We used this both inside and outside with equally excellent results! Also, big kudos for putting some effort into the aesthetics, this is a beautifully designed unit and you won't mind having it sit on a shelf or counter since it doesn't look like another blocky stereo component.Music Selection - again, thumbs up to a huge library of music from all genres. You can even create a playlist and download the tunes which helps keep the party moving. Scrolling through a massive laundry list of music will kill the buzz pretty quickly. We had a '70's theme party (yep, plenty of disco, polyester and bad hairdos) and put together a playlist in advance. Everyone had a blast reminiscing the music of that era, and it really made the evening! The Singing Machine company has a website where you can scroll though the music in their library by name, artist, genre, even era (this make finding the 70's stuff pretty easy). You can download audio tunes (note: the audio tunes do NOT have lyrics) or video (audio file with scrolling lyrics). Some tunes are available in both formats, some only in one. When the machine is not being used for karaoke, you can just play the music for nice background atmosphere. From our experience, it really helps to have the video, most people can't remember the lyrics, especially with the old tunes, and we ended up playing less of the audio only files for karaoke. I really appreciated that you can play a sample of the song before committing. Also, the arrangements were exceptionally well done, and sounded like the real track, sans the artist singing.Subscription - at least the folks at Singing Machine considered the use of their device, and they offer a number of really affordable options to get the most out of the machine. You can purchase a monthly pass for $15 or a yearly pass for $75 and for the infrequent user, a Party Pass good for 48 hours for $5. We used the Party Pass to compile the playlist for the 70's party. You can also go their website and purchase individual tunes ($.99 for audio and $1.49 for video).A couple of other notes:- the Mic-Remote was handy, but a little bulky and awkward as a microphone (it certainly didn't stop anyone from showcasing their talent, or lack thereof).- works with your TV, computer and mobile device. For the party, we put a large computer monitor out, plugged the machine in and large groups (who certainly fancied themselves as some sort of ensemble) were able to see the easily see lyrics. We did have some difficulty getting it to pair with an iPhone, but after some technical jiggering, we managed to get one working.While it's not an inexpensive device, it is a lot of fun and at least can live on as a nice speaker when not being used for karaoke.

First off, a point of clarification about what you get - these are not the big 8.5 x 11" sheets you feed through a printer, these labels come on a sheet about 4 x 6" with 6 per label. You can feed them through a printer if yours will handle a 4 x 6" sheet (more below).I found these labels to be much easier to work with than the large 8.5 x 11" sheets for a number of reasons, but the biggest was the accuracy of feeding through the printer. So often with the large sheets, if the sheet is not fed through exactly, the slightest slant will be exaggerated with the labels on the bottom half of the sheet. And if the image and text was set to be centered, those labels at the end of the sheet will be useless. That is not the case with these smaller sheets, a slight angle will not be noticed. Yes, you have to feed more sheets, but you lose no labels in the process.If you are stamping writing or doing any other handmade embellishments, it's easier to work with 6 labels at a time than 24. You won't get smudges and other gunk on the labels at the bottom of the page while you are working at the top of the page.The stickiness of the labels are awesome and if you stick it onto glass, they will wash off nicely with a little soaking in water - not like those nasty labels that require lighter fluid to remove the residue.Last, the kraft color is the perfect balance of rustic and brown. Not too dark and not too light.Nice job Avery!

As a rehabilitated Keurig drinker, I have one of the small Chemed drip carafes, and when the box of filters that came with the unit ran out, I thought I just use the traditional cone filters. After all the whole origami folding project first thing in the morning can be a little challenging if you have not had a cup of wake-up juice. I never realized how much difference a filter could make.In my first few attempts with the traditional cone filter, the filter would collapse and a downpour of grounds when into the coffee. Of course, then I had to pour the coffee through another filter to keep the grounds out of the cup. Not to mention I probably spilled half of the coffee all over the place (cleaning up a mess is worse that trying to fold the filter when you are still half asleep!). I tried two filters but that slowed the process to a snail's pace resulting in cooler water going into the carafe (lukewarm coffee is just the worst). After about of week, I realized I had spent more time trying to shove the proverbial round peg into the square hole and bought a box of the filters.So, my hat's off to the Chemex folks, they managed to engineer a filter that is the perfect thickness that balances the right brew of coffee such that the water stays hot and the flavor comes through and no mess.

Excellent book for new and seasoned school board trustees. I'm sure 99.99% of all school board members initially got involved out of their passion to improve the education experience for the students in their school district. And I'm sure most new school board members, and many seasoned trustees are overwhelmed with the process, legal issues, procedural issues, and can find their passion sapped by the machinations of the various entities they serve in their district. This book is an excellent primer for new members and reminder for seasoned trustees of the work of the school board and most importantly how to set policy to promote the best educational experience for the students being served. And just as important, how to get out of the way of those who are entrusted to make it happen.The concept of a school board is one of the last truly local examples of pure democracy at work, and as such those who serve are generally lay people who have never had any schooling, training or induction into the inner workings of the school board (or any governmental unit). Layered with the Brown Act, state educational code, and union contracts, there is a monumental amount of learning which can easily overwhelm anyone causing them to lose that passion. Certainly in larger districts where one may be elected on a promise to do one thing or another, this book reminds the reader that no single trustee acts alone - once elected, the ideas that they become a member of a single body and should act as a single entity can also be a bit disappointing. Don't despair, Mr. Eadie does a wonderful job of explaining why this is important and how it works to strengthen the board and the trust between the board, the staff, parents, community members and other for whom they serve.So, how can a school board member be effective? Mr. Eadie lays it out thoroughly in an easy to understand manner. He provides the guidelines and activities for how a school board can operate as a single body with impact, integrity and success. Whether you are sitting at the table during the school board meeting or talking with a neighbor, Mr. Eadie gives plenty of sound advice on how to conduct yourself so your school board maintains a strong unified front. Which is not to say that trustees cannot have their own opinion, clearly they can and certainly can vote accordingly, but once the vote is done, all trustees should act as a unified unit (you don't have to agree, but you do have to respect...maybe Congress needs a book like this too!). Mr. Eadie walks the reader through how they can do their part to ensure the school board is most effective at their number one job:  setting policy for the school district they are entrusted to lead, and just as important, how to get of the way of those who are entrusted to make it happen.Finally, this is an excellent book for stakeholders who may not understand the role of the school board (don't be disappointed if your school board trustee cannot fire a teacher or get Johnny transferred from one classroom to another - that's not their job). And if you want to make sure your school board is functioning effectively, you'll learn how to you can push for and support that effort.

While these shipping tags were traditionally used for industrial purposes, they have taken on a new life in the crafting arena. Clearly the tag and the wire are most likely strong enough for freight shipping, I immediately went to work on mine with ink, paint, stamps, punches and all sorts of ephemera along with other bits and bobs. I subjected these tags to plenty of water, glue, heat, and more, and they took the beating and I was rewarded with some awesome looking works of arts! I used some of them for some gifts and all of the recipients commented more about the tag than the gift. I also used a bunch to create a mini-photo album for a friend.Whether your purpose is for shipping or crafting or even somewhere in between, these are super sturdy tags. They come pre-wired, but I dispatched the wire for colorful twine instead. They are a perfect size and the thickness - not too thick and definitely not too flimsy.

The major benefit of these headphones is the bluetooth capability. The sound quality is OK, and of course they are super easy to "install" and get up and running. They are not the best headphones and I found I could not wear my reading glasses as the the headpiece is really hard and rigidto fit comfortably over them. All-in-all, they are a decent value for the price.Here's some more specifics:- Pairs with your computer or other electronic device super easily. I paired these headphones with computers running Windows 8, Mac OS, and other devices such as an iPhone, iPad, and a Samsung phone and Samsung tablet all without issue.- Sound Quality - quite decent for the size and technology. You can actually roam about 30 ft away from the device before you start to lose sound. Of course this is where these headphones really shine; you can easily move around your workspace without having to deal with an annoying tether!- Nice life on one battery charge. I got just a little over 40 hours of time before I needed to pop in the cable to recharge. I forgot to pay attention while the unit was recharging so I can't comment on how long it took to recharge. Another great thing about these headphones is that the battery is built into the earpiece so you only need a cable and a device that can supply power making these awesome for travel and portability.- Reasonably comfortable - the padded earphone not helps block outside sound, but also provides a nice level of comfort. I did find they felt a little tight on my head right out of the box and I wasn't able to wear them for an extended period of time. It looks like Panasonic is going for that Beats headphone look, but they might consider rethinking the hard plastic material and design of the headband, it's not that comfortable for extended wear.I let my teenaged son have a go with these headphones, they seem to be better suited for him. He really appreciated the bluetooth capability. Of course without these headphones being attached to something, I'm wondering how long before he leaves them somewhere he doesn't remember!

A very good treat for your dog, it's not made from grains and other fillers but with protein sources that are much better for dogs. I really love the little size, perfect for reinforcing training and they easily break in half. Of course our yellow lab loves them - she's highly motivated by food and this little size helps satisfy her need for a treat without over doing it.

The Maxic Compass Emergency Jump Starter is a must for anyone who lives with flaky electrical service and/or spends time outside away from any sort of running electrical current. It's super compact, sleek looking (super thumbs-up for design asthetics) and can charge up quite a few small electrical devices before completely draining the battery. We were able to test with a neighbor's car and it worked like a charm, unfortunately it was all the battery could handle, but in an emergency, you'd be glad to have it!The battery itself charges up pretty fast, but doesn't have the bandwidth to handle a lot - as the name says, it an emergency device, not a primary source of power. Although no instructions or other information come with the unit, the usage is pretty straightforward.The major downside, hence the 4 stars, is this device is NOT UL tested and rated, implying a potential quality control issue. Ours worked just fine for charging cell phones, a laptop, jumpstarting a dead car, a camping lantern with a rechargeable battery and a Nintendo device - not all at once nor on one charge, but with relative speed and ease. This is is definitely a good thing to have join case of an emergency.

Let's be clear, this isn't a "health" bar or necessarily a better choice than most other similar granola bars. A third of the calories are from fat, it's loaded with carbs (obviously, the main ingredients are grains) and has a smidgen of protein. But at 150 calories and a manageable amount of sugar at 7g, it is convenient and better than a candy bar. Also, all of the ingredients are real things, not chemical composition with the added benefit of actual whole grains. KIND made this tasty bar into a nice balance of crunch and sweetness, which is just enough to take the edge off the afternoon snack cravings without blowing the whole day on something you'll regret 15 minutes later. If you are familiar with the other, traditional KIND bars, I found this bar more preferable; it's not as sweet, and not nearly as hard to bite and chew.Everyone in our house really like this KIND bar, so I bought a couple boxes since I find the teenagers in my house are less likely to buy a candy bar on their way home from school if they have one of these in their backpack (it helps they are just enough of misers with their allowance too!). I keep one in my handbag for the same reason. With the bit of chocolate in it, it's just enough to satisfy the sweet tooth without going overboard into the sugar high/low you get with a candy bar, and definitely not enough to spoil dinner.

I was totally prepared for this to be some sort of franken-food and honestly had to get a bit of courage up to try it, but my curiosity quickly overrode any hesitation and I made breakfast burritos - sans the rolled tortilla - for family and guests. Everyone went gaga over the tortilla shape, and surprisingly, they tasted just like a soft flour tortilla should. The kids were especially enamored with the idea of a tortilla "boat" and actually ate all of their breakfast. As a plus, the trough held up really well, even with the liquid from the salsa sinking to the bottom.I have to tip my hat the folks at Old El Paso for their research and effort in making a soft tortilla hold such a shape without a ton of unpronounceable ingredients (there are a handful of these multi-syllable chemically-based ingredients to be sure). While this isn't going to replace the homemade tortilla, it would be something I'd purchase for a party or other fun event!

I LOVE everything about this little drive! Moore's Law is truly evidenced with this slim drive; I have a larger, clunky "portable" drive I use for back-ups, but this little drive runs circles around it.First, it set itself up in less than 30 seconds. Simply plug it into the USB port and go. Next, I transferred a bunch of media to it, which went just as quickly as moving the files to a new folder. Finally, opening these files right from the drive was also lickity-split fast. I had no problems plugging this drive in and using it with my client's PCs, both Windows and Mac alike.I also really love the design, clearly Samsung thought about the design - a lot. It has a very Apple-esque feel to the packaging and product. The slim, lightweight design makes it even more suited for toting around than any other portable drive I have. Often I have been up the proverbial creek due to lack of Internet access and I don't like to tote my large laptop if I can avoid it, so having this little drive has made a huge difference in enabling me to keep client files with me and up-to-date regardless of where I am or what kind of access I have. And it fits quite nicely right in my hand bag.One thing to keep in mind is if you will be going through airport security, make sure you have a device that will allow TSA to see it's not some sort of illegal thing. I almost had to give mine up, but thanks to a fellow travel warrior lending his tablet, I was saved.

My son loves these types of pencils, but so often they cannot withstand the force and trauma of a 13-year old boy's clumsy and uncontrolled strength. The Zebra pencil so far has managed to last longer than a semester, so it's by far and away the most durable. He also noted the lead doesn't break nearly as easily or often as other similar mechanical pencils.The lead is easy to replace/refill, and the weight of the pencil is more substantial than most of this type of design. A finely engineered product from the folks in Japan who really know who to make well designed and atheistically pleasing products.

We're weaning ourselves off the Keurig mainly due to the limited choices of environmentally friendly packaging, but also because you simply get better tasting coffee outside of the Keurig realm After some research, we landed on the Chemex - and LOVE it!!!It's definitely a bit more of an investment of time and labor than simply popping a Keurig plastic cup into a brewer, and on the those mornings when you need it east and fast, the Chemex solution might feel like a Herculean effort, but if you are willing to preserve, you will be rewarded with some superior coffee. It really helps if you have an electric kettle to get the water super hot and while it's boiling you can get the filter ready. Also, if you go this route, invest in a good burr coffee grinder. Amazon has a great selection of both appliances. I was totally skeptical that a grinder could really make a difference, but since we happened to have both the fancy Krups burr grinder and a cheap Krups grinder I put them both to the test, and was quite surprised to find it does make a difference. Having lost the bet with my better half over this issue, I now have to make the coffee in the morning for the next month.You do need a filter for the carafe, and Chemex of course has their version. I have to wonder about the folks at Chemex, they really made the filter thing a bit of an origami project and when you are half asleep trying to pull off a focused project, you might be tempted to throw a cup under the Keurig and be done. But if you can manage enough brain cells to get the filter folded (and the trick is make sure the little half circle thing is opened properly inside - again, a bit of feat when your eyes are barely open - otherwise coffee grounds will go right through). Chemex does sell pre-folded filters for the morning mentally challenged. So you may ask, why not just use the plain cone filters. Well, they don't fit properly and the mess you will have on your hands will leave you even more cranky than you were (yep, tried this and it was NOT a short-cut).Once the water is ready, you pour over it the grounds, wait a minute or two and repeat until the carafe is mostly full (great opportunity to get that dishwasher emptied while you are making the coffee). Remove the filter which is compostable or recyclable in the green waste can, so you can do your part for the environment, and pour your beautiful cup of joe. Obviously the major benefit of making coffee this way is you can buy really, really good beans.The carafe cleans up well and the coffee is downright awesome. If you have visited any of the more trendy coffee houses and noticed many are doing this pour-over type of coffee, and if you are patient, you will be rewarded with a truly fine cup of coffee.

Our yellow Lab who eats pretty much anything was a little lukewarm on this flavor of dog food. She's chowed through many other flavors so fast, I'm pretty sure she had no idea what the flavor was, but this one didn't get her to the food bowl with any sort of speed. Kudos however to the Nutro Company for a relatively good product. For dogs, the more protein, and protein from animal sources and not plants, is better. They don't need grain, including barley which is in this one, but on the whole this is better than average than most dry dog food.

If you don't have an empty slot in your Mac or PC, make one!!! This wireless adapter ROCKS!!!! It was a cinch to install, literally within minutes it was up and running - it took more time to get the case off and back on than it did to install and get through the set-up. This adapter is totally idiot-proof!I installed in a 2009 MacPro and it automatically instantly configured the device. It really exceeded my expectations with respect to the speed; it really screams lightening fast and the difference is definitely noticeable. With video download and playback, and online gaming, you really experience the beauty of this device. I also tried it out on a newer Windows PC and once again the speed was exceptional especially with graphics intensive apps.There isn't much else that's needed to know, the quality construction and killer speed make this wireless adapter totally worth the $$!!

Best.Headphones.Ever.Gotta love how the Japanese treat everything they do with such honor and respect. From the moment you remove the sleeve covering the box, you know you are in for something special. The packaging is so beautifully done, you'd be tempted to think you got the wrong item.The headphones are delightfully small and you may think the sound quality would be lacking, but it is absolutely not. Having just purchased a pair of Sennheiser headphones, these are so much better in every way imaginable. Here's my list of pros and cons:Super, Super Comfortable - the small size and lightweight make these incredibly comfortable for lengthy wearing. The ear piece is plenty big to cover the ear without feeling like you have Princess Leia-sized things on your head.Awesome Sound - I listened to jazz, classical, rock, opera, bluegrass and more and I really found myself so much more engaged with the music than with other headphones or going through the stereo in the house. The sound was rich and full, even with the softest of moments. And on the way more boring side, these are coming in really handy as I'm studying for the CPA exam and need to focus and block out the distractions (this is why I purchased the Sennheiser headphones). I even found the quality to be just that much better and am actually able to stay focused for a bit longer.Lightweight  & Portable - I love that these headphones are so light which makes them much easier to tote around. And this might be sort of silly, but I really like the silky feel of the cord.Volume Control on the Cord - super handy, and kudos to the nice design aesthetics.ConsThe only real con might be the price, but I think these are so awesome, I gladly paid for a pair to give to my hubby for an anniversary present (really to keep him from borrowing mine!).Denon has always been synonymous with quality and these headphones live up the that expectation. They even firmly affixed the cord to the one earpiece so there is little danger of it wearing out to the point of disconnecting any of the tiny wires inside (really, love this!!!) but it doesn't prevent the headphones from being flexible.

It's really hard to believe Jimmy Rosenberg was merely sixteen when this CD was produced, he plays as if he's had a lifetime of music at his fingertips. What's even more amazing is that apparently this young man had no formal training or instruction. It's such an immense pleasure to find and celebrate such incredible talent. If you're into music in the Django Reinhart genre, you will absolutely love this CD and if you're not, no matter, you will quickly find yourself tapping along and enjoying the upbeat tempo and in pretty amazed what a couple of young guys on guitar can produce.

In this age, where the lack of civility and disrespect have somehow become the behavior we reward, David Brooks' The Road to Character not only reminds of what the world looked like before the self-centered, screaming talking heads took over, but how much more fulfilling life can be. Best of all, he lays out the road for one to follow in the last chapter. From the first few pages, I was captivated (Mr. Brooks is an excellent story teller) and by the end, came away with a much needed renewed faith in what I can do personally as well as for mankind.Having been a fan of Mr. Brooks writing for some time, I had very high expectations of his book and while it met and in some parts of the book exceeded those expectations, there also a few lulls. Some of the vignettes fell a little flat and didn't drive the point home as well as others. However I'm sure each individual showcased in the book was carefully researched and detailed to emphatically drive the point home, so I will reread these chapters.A very obvious theme exemplified through the book and with each chapter is that becoming a person of character takes time. As with most things, it takes focus, thoughtfulness and opportunity to practice, which of course means these values will become part of one's being over time, not over night. This isn't a book about religion, although it quite spiritual, in fact if most religious leaders and their followers were to actually put into practice Mr. Brooks' Humility Code, we would find ourselves in a much more truly compassionate and collaborative world. This is one of those books that should be required reading for everyone.

We've had a lot of fun with this telescoping stick. Hands down the best part is the remote control. Having just got an iPhone 6, which takes amazing photos, now I can set up shots beyond just an arm's length. We did some fun stop animation films with toys, the dog (very uncooperative actor) and even a short film of dinner by using the stick to hold the camera steady and the remote to take the pictures. I can see this will be a must on a trip, since you can use it very much like a tripod (obviously not quite the same).Very much like a tripod, the head swivels so you can position the camera or phone into nearly any position. Also since the telescope collapses down you can use this to mount or steady the camera using a wall, car, or whatever solid structure is at hand for way more interesting shots beyond the overdone selfie. Of course the remote really gives you some great freedom. So get creative!!! There are way more interesting pictures to be taken than just ones of yourself!!

If you've got a reverse osmosis system hooked up to the kitchen sink in your house, you have this water. If you don't, at more than $3.00 per bottle, you'd pay for a reverse osmosis system in nothing flat. Even a Brita filter system would yield the same results at a fraction of the cost. We have a reverse osmosis system and the water from that tap tastes just the same and has the same qualities as this water, and it costs about 3,000% less.This is a product all about hype and little about substance, very much like cosmetics with all the cost in the packaging and very little in the product itself. Clearly this is a product designed to appeal to a certain type of buyer (not me for sure). Very nice that the packaging is recyclable and that it's made in California, but let's be honest, this is just filtered water from a top going into these bottles, not some fancy pristine spring water from some remote place.If you're a big water drinker, get into the habit of using a refillable water bottle and tote your own around. It won't take long before it just becomes second nature to fill 'er up before you leave the house and you'll be doing a lot of good for the environment. And if you must buy pre-packaged water, there are plenty of other good choices such as Smart Water or Real Water or even sparkling water.

Our dog didn't have terrible tartar build-up, she's usually chewing on a bone or other toy. The vet was recommending a cleaning, but at $350, I wanted to try something more reasonable first. Chomping on Greenies, my dog definitely reduced the tartar on her teeth. The fresh breath was a nice touch too! Of course my champion chewer (yellow Lab) got through one of these in about 30 seconds. I'll go for the bigger bag next time!

The Mavericks are back! So excited to have another solid Mavericks CD in my collection! Their CD, In Time, is one of my top twenty CDs that I listen to all the time. This is very much in that spirit, but with reflects a maturity that only a musician gains from time. The music is a mix of latin and rock that is pure Mavericks's signature style.Thanks Raul and gang for getting back together!

LOVE this product!!! I typically use a gentle exfoliation products 2 to 3 times a week, but after using this product only, twice a week for 2-1/2 weeks, I can see much bigger improvement in the quality of my skin. MY skin is much softer and this product definitely took down some of fine lines and reduced some of the bigger ones, especially on my forehead. I don't spend a lot of money or time with fancy products or treatments (heck, my whole make-up routine is mascara) mostly because I don't have the patience to wait fifteen minutes or more for some gloppy stuff to sit on my face and apply several products afterward, so this was a big game changer for me.This product is super easy to use and you really only need a very small amount to produce results. It's a two step process, first apply a thin layer onto clean skin with goo in Step 1 and wait and minute (you'll feel a slight warm/burning sensation). Next you apply a thin layer of the goo from the tube labled Step 2 and wait about 3-5 minutes (I'm not that patient, so I only went for 3 minutes). The directions say to wipe clean with a soft towel, but I rinsed my face with warm water.  And wow!!! It's like new skin! And best of all, it lasted!My skin looked brighter and clearer and felt super smooth (but not weird and shiny) to the touch. My skin is definitely fair, a bit on the dry side and I'm in my 50's. I don't have a lot of sun damage (I religiously wear sunscreen) and did not experience any irritation whatsoever. Your results may vary of course. By the way, StriVectin makes a killer moisturizer, StriVectin Extreme Creme if your current moisturizer isn't cutting it anymore.

Whoa....I'm actually in awe.I thought my Fellowes 79Ci shredder was killer, then this arrived on my doorstep. What makes this shredder worth the price is the speed, volume and noise level.1.  It's Fast...really fast. I shredded nearly 200 pages in about a handful of minutes.1.  Volume...it holds a LOT. Unlike other shredders where you have to stand hunched feeding a half-dozen pages at a time, with the AutoMax, you open the top, lay the pages down (as if you were filling the paper cartridge of a printer, but it's even easier), close the top lid and press the arrow button and away it goes.3.  Noise Level...amazingly quiet for the size of the motor. I really expected this to sound like a jet taxing down a runway, but instead found it to be almost a little white noise/Zen-like as it was shredding the giant pile of papers.A few other pluses:- It's on Wheels! you can move it out of the way when not in use, love this!!- Giant Bin! And a good thing since you can shred a monster load of paper- Shreds with the excellent micro cross-cut for super high level security- Nice, clean design, super easy to use.- Decent Safety. You can't open the top lid while it's in use.- Shreds everything, staples, credit cards, paper clips, CDs. The instructions do note it won't shred binder clips though :-)- The bin easily slides out and due the design, it has enough depth enabling you to get all the clumps hanging from the teeth into the bag instead of all over the floor (just turn it off first for safety's sake).One side note, I'd buy the Fellowes bags for this shredder, I found them much easier to use since the bin opening is larger than the standard kitchen trash bag.It is bigger than the typical size shredder, but if you have need for a higher capacity shredder, can't stand the noise of shredding machines, or loathe standing hunched over your shredder, this baby is absolutely for you!

Normally I wouldn't go for a kids' vitamin, but I have a picky eater who convulses over anything green so I'm forever looking for ways to sneak high density nutrition into his limited diet. I really love that this product doesn't contain sugar, and has a healthy dose of fiber and Omega 3. It has all the other good stuff; Vitamin D, B and the other essentials. Another plus: it's made in California so there is at least a modicum of regulatory oversight about what goes into the product.This is one of the few supplements that really goes out the way to help the consumer understand exactly what is in the consumable. Each vitamin listed also notes the source. For example, the Omega 3 source is anchovy and sardine, and no, it doesn't taste fishy (although my son said it didn't taste great, but he doesn't approach tasting new things with a sense of adventure).It is a little pricey, but if the package is true to the product, this is a pretty high quality vitamin.

I bought this with a bit of hesitation as a Christmas present for the hubby, who is pretty picky about his grill toys and loves to cook. Not only was this a huge hit, but he bought second one to replace the gargantuan outdoor grill. Here's what rocks according to the man who likes to cook with fire:- good temperature control, and excellent high heat- cleans easily (turn it on to let the gunk burn off, just like a normal grill)- size is great for our family, the second one is the spare that we use when entertaining or grilling a load of stuff- love the portability, it replaced the old camp stove and now we can grill instead being limited to only that which can be cooked in a pot or pan (get the adapter so you can hook up a small propane bottle instead of lugging the giant tank).- more efficient than the big grill which you have to heat up the whole grill for just a couple of burgers.The biggest plus - it stands up just fine to the big boys in terms of grilling quality.We built a counter outside where the two grills sit side-by-side. And since they are portable, we can move them to wherever they are needed. We even toted them to the grandparents to help with the grilling at a family event (and everyone wanted to know about the Cuisinart Grill!). I don't think we'll every own a big grill again, this does it all and it does it well!

I have a real love-hate relationship with white-out and other correction products. I need them in my line of work, and sometimes I'll redo a whole page just to avoid the clumpy mess of white-out fluid or the raised-tape-look of other correction tape products. I love Tombow's colored pencils (if you are into colored pencils, you gotta check these out, they are amazing!) and markers, and was glad I took a chance on their correction tape. It blends nicely with the paper, ink doesn't bleed through (even fountain pen ink) and as soon as you apply it, you can write over it. The rolling applicator is super easy to use, including the positioning of the correction tape - nothing worse than getting correction stuff on the good parts of the doc as you are trying to hit the errors.

In searching for a laptop stand, I didn't want something that looked like a card board box, or some strange tinker toy project. I wanted something that was functional but looked some thought was put into the design. Oh yeah, I didn't want to spend a fortune either. The mStand was a little more bucks than others, but I was willing to splurge since it looked good - and it wasn't black. The folks at mStand seemed to have gotten right. Despite not being adjustable, it works perfectly whether sitting or standing. No more hunching or a pile of books. I love the open space underneath - you can hide note pads, wires or other unsightly clutter that seems to accumulate mercilessly on the desk. It's not portable, but I only work long hours at this desk and it's much more comfortable to do so now than ever before.

Love the solid weight and feel of these cups and saucers! It's really hard to find a simple, clean design coffee cup that holds more than 12 ounces that doesn't have some snarky wording and graphics, but here is is! They stack nicely in the cupboard, work just as easily on a casual table or a more formal setting. We've also used them for serving soup and dessert - the wide opening makes for a great canvas to work with. So beautiful, substantial and durable!

I use these for both my business and fun. Business, yes, they work perfectly as a hanging file folder should; they are sturdy, hang properly and can manage with a fair amount of overstuffing. I really love the neutral color. They also lend themselves to some great crafting opportunities. I stamped all over a whole box load for a client, and they were so thrilled to have something interesting in their drawers (office drawers that is!) for a change.  I would however recommend the Pendaflex hanging file folders it you need something really durable - they are thicker and better reinforced on the bottom. For the majority of office use, the Smead folders are just fine.

I recently discovered Jambu shoes and really love how comfortable they are! I'm always looking for a shoe that can walk a few miles each day over a lot of varied terrain, get dirty but easily clean to look like new, be comfortable and stylish. A tall order for something that is really a work boot (sans the stylish requirement). The Bali Mule does all of this and more. These shoes worked fantastically with black tights and a dress and jeans, and breezed through the day and my feet were still feeling good! They weren't so good looking with dress pants, but I don't wear these as often as dresses, skirts and jeans.

Gorgeous, beautiful quality washy tape. The black is nicely saturated and the graphics are excellent. I really love the effect you can create with the black backgrounds, give everything a really different look-and-feel. As with all of My Mind's Eye products, the quality is top shelf. Check out their coordinating paper, it's just as fantastic!

I know the whole chalkboard thing is somewhat passé, but this paper works for so much more. The effect of the the black with embossed stamping, gel pens and other effects really adds a lot of depth without looking morose and dark. My Mind's Eye always produces high quality products, and these papers are no exception, the quality of the print and the paper stock are excellent. They also make some coordinating washy tape which is also stellar.

After a couple of cheap shredders, I'm sorry I didn't invest in this sooner. It will chew up just about everything you give it - paper, credit cards, card stock, there is even a slot for shredding CDs. Here's the run-down based on my usage:Pros- No Jams - really doesn't jam, I even stuffed half of an unused check book into it trying to get it to jam and while it ground up the paper more slowly, it choked it down without jamming. There is a handy reverse direction if you do encounter a jam, but haven't had to use it for that purpose.- Micro Cut Shred - much safer than simple shredding- Easy Bin Emptying - a big pet peeve is how much of the shredded bits go everywhere when you empty the bin, the Fellowes shredder is by far the easiest to empty with minimal shredded bits going everywhere. Fellows makes bags for the shredder, but I have had fine success with thin, clear plastic tall kitchen bags- Wheels!! Move it out of the way to clean or when not in use (as some reviewers noted, it is a little challenging to get the wheels installed, but boy is it worth it!)- Noise level definitely tolerable - I found the cheap shredders to be noisy in a more grating kind of way. This shredder has a pretty big motor (you will know this when you first remove it from the box) and I found the noise level to be quite reasonable.- Maintenance - couldn't be easier, when you empty the bin, run a little oil across the opening and run the shredder forward and backwards for about 30 seconds each.Con- Maybe the price? If you are super price sensitive, then go for something less, but as someone who goes through shredders like a teenage boy and sneakers, I'm am so happy at how well this shredder performs! In the short time I've had this, I've easily shredded 30 bags worth of stuff and it's just as strong and solid as the day I got it!

Woo-Hoo!!! No more multiple chargers when traveling!And no more of this scenario:  fighting over the one or two sockets in the hotel room, or worse, waiting for that device that beat you to the socket to finish charging only to forget to plug your device in, going to bed and ending up with a dead device (or one with just enough power to miss that important call or email) because now you have to check out and you purposefully didn't bring a car charger because you always leave in the rental car and are tired of buying a new one every time you travel. Yeah, been there, lived that...too many times.Get the tablets, phones, blue-tooth speaker, etc. all charged up at once and fast. If you have a lot of devices or travel as techie family, you definitely need one of these!!! I was also surprised at the speed at which everything charged up, even when we had it loaded with devices.

Kanye should have remained in his seat.One listen-through of this album and there is question Beck deserved the Grammy for Album of the Year. The intricate composition, the style, and the amazing display of talent. Listening to this at work makes the stress level drop to nearly nothing. We recently had this going in the background with friends over for dinner and it cast this pleasant atmosphere over the whole evening. A high highlight and a significant milestone in this man's career.
Terrific CD! Love the creativity of these guys and they keep getting better and better with age. Catchy tunes and great car riding music.

Gorgeous color and it lasts pretty much most of the day, and for sure longer than lipstick. This is an awesome lip stain product! I'm fair skinned, light hair and I love how this lip stain gives my lips a nice, natural color - it doesn't look at all like I'm wearing lipstick. The application is easy and it blends right in with your natural lip line. Sometimes I dress it up a little with some lip gloss which gives my lips that airbrushed look. The color isn't super heavy, although I suppose you could paint on a few layers if you wanted a darker look. Another major pro - it doesn't dry your lips out like some other lip stain products. Definitely part of the morning routine!

Upon receiving this, my kids (10 year old son & 6 year old daughter) were very excited and set up the track right away.  None of us, however, were prepared for just how fun this innovative and incredibly effective racing system would be.  They played it for hours breaking only for dinner because mom & dad made them.  They have continued to play with it frequently, a sure test of how fun a toy really is.The track is very easy to configure, assemble, and disassemble - simple enough that a child can do it.  The controller is very effective, featuring a 2 way trigger for forward and reverse and a wheel for steering.  I much prefer this over the dual joystick system employed by many RC vehicles, partly because an actual steering wheel just makes sense for steering and partly because it's easier to grasp for younger kids.  The cars handle great and respond in a very nuanced way to the controller - a gentle push or pull of the trigger will produce a slow acceleration which allows for easy turning.  Nudging the trigger a little further increases the speed incrementally up to full on pedal to the medal when the trigger if fully pressed.  The controls are just great.The technology by which the cars recognize and stay on the track pieces makes racing super fun.  You most definitely can and will veer off of the tracks if you just floor it, but that's part of the fun.  You have to use enough control to keep the car from flying off the tracks while also enjoying the assistance of the sensors that reliably keep the car on track at slower speeds.  When you do lose control and leave the course, you simply drive your car back to the track and resume racing.  In one respect this system resembles the old slot car racing sets that also required some nuanced speed control, but without the need to physically replace the cars on the track when they leave it.  Another great feature is that the cars are perfectly proportioned and designed for the track - in other words, their turning radius matches the track perfectly.  Time your turn just right and your car will remain in exactly the right spot on the track.  One of many small things that makes this great.Everything just works, too.  The sensors are reliable and always keep the car on course as long as you don't take corners too fast.  The cars handle well, recover easily when they leave the track, and physically take a licking and keep on ticking.  The kids frequently crash them into each other and into furniture, the cat, the wall, etc and they never skip a beat.  The different racing modes provide variety and flexibility.  The cars are quite fun simply as RC cars even when not racing.  And by the way, battery life is great.  These things will go for hours and hours on a set of batteries.The only complaint that I could possibly find is that the cars sometimes seem to have a mind of their own when you veer off the track and steer back toward it.  It's like the car wants to go one way to get back on the track even if you try steering it another way.  This is probably due to the way it reads the sensors on the track, but regardless it is absolutely not enough of an issue to care about.Once in awhile you find a toy that is so well done it stands head and shoulders above the rest.  This is one of those toys.  It's far more fun than other traditional RC vehicles.  It's far more fun that traditional slot car type sets.  It uses technology in a way that enhances the experience without overtaking it.  It's well made, well thought-out, and creates a fantastic experience.  My daughter said, "Dad, when you review this on Amazon you need to give it an awesome 5 star awesome rating!"  I agree.

7:25 Mins Having owned some of Alps Mountaineering's products in the past and having been very impressed, I was excited to get to try out this pack from their Alps OutdoorZ line.  The pack is incredibly comfortable, built like a tank, and has a bunch of great features.  In the video I try to cover the features of this excellent pack and offer my two cents.  Feel free to post any questions & I'll do my best to respond.

Ok there's no fire involved here, but these really are great trash bags.  They are durable, though not as malleable as some of the "flex" varieties of trash bag.  I find, however, that for our general kitchen trash purposes the more expensive flex bags are overkill and these are plenty strong.  Love having the cinch drawstring handles.  The fragrance feature is really nice - very pleasant apple aroma that isn't overbearing but provides a hint of scent (hey I'm a poet and didn't know it!) to offset potential garbage odors.  I for one was grateful that the aroma wasn't overpowering or sickeningly strong.  Thumbs up on these trash bags that cover the important bases - strong, easy to secure closure, and a very nice scent.  Would definitely get these again.

I have a 10 year old son and we've gone through quite a few R/C toys.  This one definitely ranks among the better of those we've tried.  What I like best about this is the control.  It's simpler than the ones with dual toggle sticks and more natural to control.  It has a trigger that can be squeezed to move the car forward or pushed away in the opposite direction to move the car in reverse.  Steering is handled with a small wheel.  It's a simple but effective design that even my 6 year old daughter was able to operate right away.The car operates on a small rechargeable battery pack, which is another plus.  One of the reasons some of our past R/C toys didn't get more use was that they often took 4, 6, or even 8 batteries and burned through them super-fast.  I much prefer this route, which while requiring time off to charge the battery saves a significant expense.  The car goes plenty long on one charge too.The big oversized wheels work great, and my kids loved setting up obstacle courses with other toys and objects to drive the truck over.  It worked fine around the yard too.All in all we really enjoyed this car.  I have a little concern about durability since it has an all-plastic construction, but otherwise it's a lot of fun.  Simple but effective control scheme, cost efficient rechargeable battery pack, and big monster wheels = thumbs up.

I was fortunate to receive this laptop for review purposes and decided to test it against my work-provided laptop.  For those interested in specs, this Toshiba features a 5th generation Intel core i7 processor (5500u 2.4ghz version), 12gb of ram, and Windows 10 64bit.  My work laptop is a fairly high-end Dell computer that is less than a year old (and cost close to $1500 when purchased 10 months ago) and has a 4th generation Intel core i7 processor (4510u 2.0ghz version), 8gb of ram, and Windows 8 64bit.  For fun, I also included in the test my wife's slightly older HP laptop with an 3rd generation Intel core i3 processor (3130 2.6ghz version), 4gb of ram, and Windows 8 64bit.First, I tested the startup time.  The Toshiba was consistently fast, averaging about 13 seconds from power on to the sign-in screen and about 12 seconds from sign-in to the home screen appeared.  The Dell was close behind, taking a few seconds longer to bring up the sign in screen and being about the same speed from sign-in til the homescreen.  The HP was a good bit slower, taking 35 seconds to get to the sign-in screen and another 15 to the homescreen.  In any case, the Toshiba gets up and running really fast, a testament to both the processor speed and the efficiency of Windows 10.Next, I tested the speed of each laptop performing a fairly demanding computing task.  I don't do gaming, but I do use my laptop to do audio and video editing.  I installed the newest version of a video editing program on each computer and had them edit and render (produce a finished video) the same project.  The Toshiba won the race, finishing the project in 7 minutes 19 seconds.  The Dell was fairly close, finishing in 7 minutes 59 seconds.  The HP lagged in at 9 minutes 12 seconds.  Again, the Toshiba clocked in tops.I did a battery test by streaming video with the screen set to maximum brightness.  The Toshiba won with 3 hours 21 minutes of life, the Dell was a close second with 3 hours 9 minutes, and the HP straggled behind with 1 hour 50 minutes.  Again the Toshiba came out ahead, an even more impressive feat considering that it's screen is by far superior to the others (more on this in a moment).The speaker test was one where the Toshiba was not a clear winner.  It sounds great but the max volume was a good bit lower than the Dell, which sounds just about as good but pumps out more sound.  The Toshiba speakers are clear and have good separation between the crisp highs and mid range sounds.  The HP sounded muffled and canned, but the Toshiba was rich and full - but not particularly loud even at max volume.Aesthetically, the Toshiba looks great.  The brushed metal cover with black accent trim is very sharp, and the screen is really thin, giving the laptop and nice slim profile.  The screen on this laptop is INCREDIBLE by the way, the best I've seen.  The colors are rich and natural, the blacks are deep, and its very bright without being harsh.  Comparing it side-by-side to my more-expensive Dell revealed a significant gap in screen quality that surprised me.  It is absolutely gorgeous, head and shoulders above the competition, and is almost reason enough to buy this laptop.  Seriously.  The keyboard is great too, with pleasingly tactile response, quiet action, and back-lighting for easy use in dark conditions.  I love having the numeric keypad too, a plus for those of us that have to do some number crunching from time to time.  I am not a huge fan of the current trend of clickable touchpads without dedicated right and left buttons.  As a right handed user, I find that I tend to try the left click a little too close to the center, which results in occasional right clicks or non-response.  This isn't unique to the Toshiba (the Dell I've been using for a almost a year is the same) and it's not a huge deal - and I'm sure many people prefer it - but I miss the dedicated right and left buttons.Using the computer day in and day out for awhile revealed it to be very fast.  It starts up fast, zips through opening and closing programs, loads web pages quickly, etc.  I don't know how much credit goes to Windows 10 or to the computing power under the hood, but this machine moves.The only issue I've got with the Toshiba, and the reason I'm not going for an all-out five star rating, is the build quality.  I haven't had a single problem with it, but it's light and just feels a little delicate.  Obviously light is good, and I'm sure Toshiba intentionally kept the weight at a minimum, but I'd gladly trade a few ounces of weight here for there and deal with a little more heft for something that just feels more sturdy and engenders a bit more confidence.  Again, haven't had a problem and might never have a problem, but it just feels delicate.All in all, this is a really nice computer.  Gorgeous screen, fast processor, newest and nimble OS, sleek and lightweight design, great keyboard, rich (but not especially loud) speakers...there is much to like here.  I'd think twice if you're hard on your hardware because of the lightweight build, but otherwise this is a really solid piece of gear that excels in a lot of areas, and many of them where it really counts.

***This review is for the Philips AJT4400B/37 Bluetooth Clock Radio.  Please note that there are several different clock models listed together on this one product page, so I just want to be clear which one I've reviewing (and I've included a photo with this review to help identify this model).***I am really happy with this clock radio.  First, the positives of which there are many..  This clock looks really nice.  It has a compact design with smooth lines and a classy black minimalist look.  I dig the amber colored display, which has 3 brightness settings and is easily visible without creating a harsh glow in dark conditions.  The unit includes a dedicated wire antenna and picks up a lot of stations and locks in on them well with its digital tuner.  You can preset 20 stations, either programming them manually or letting the clock automatically scan and program the 20 stations.  The dual alarms can be set to repeat every day, and the alarm sound (using the beeping buzzer sound or a radio station) starts quietly and very gradually increases in volume - a great feature if you share a bed or room and don't want to wake the other person.  The included usb port located on the rear of the clock is super convenient for bedside phone or tablet charging.  The bluetooth connectivity works great, and streaming music is easy, as is taking an incoming call using the clock's built in mic.  I had no problem hearing callers nor did they have any trouble hearing me when using the clock for calls.As for negatives, there are a few.  Perhaps the biggest is that the speaker volume isn't all that loud.  Think of it as a clock radio with bluetooth as a bonus, as the sound is perfectly acceptable for a clock radio but won't compete with dedicated bluetooth music speakers.  Another minor niggle is that the snooze button is preset to 9 minutes and can't be changed.  It's certainly not a big deal, but programmable snooze times can be nice for those who like to hit the snooze button.Overall this is a really nice feature-rich clock radio at a good price.  Dual alarms, nice styling, usb charging port, surprisingly good radio reception, and bluetooth connectivity add up to a pretty capable little clock radio.  But keep in mind, it is first and foremost a compact clock radio and the sound quality and volume reflect that identity.  If you keep your expectations reasonable for sound quality, there is a whole lot to like here.

4:53 Mins The Kenwood Persona electric variable temperature kettle is beautiful.  The brushed silver finish looks fantastic and will add a touch of sophistication to any kitchen.  Operation of the variable temperature heating functions is super simple.  This piece is designed for two kinds of people - those who are serious about their tea and appreciate the preset temperature levels appropriate for different kinds of tea, or those who simply want a beautiful kettle that works well and looks great.  If you fall into either category or both, you'll love this kettle.  Watch the video for a closer look.  Thanks!

Just got this grill cover and I am impressed.  It is very attractive, with a rich cream color on the main part of the cover and a darker brown band around the bottom.  It looks really good in person.  The construction is durable and heavy duty, and the material is definitely water resistant.  There are vents to allow airflow & prevent mildewing, which is a nice touch.  All in all this covers all of my bases for a grill cover - keeps it protected from the elements, looks great, and is built to last (with a 3 year warranty to boot).  Thumbs up!
